summary: The hoard comprised a cooking pot containing 15 Tyrian Shekels dated between 38-10 BC.
E. Morin discovered 4 aurei in the dairy foundations. No more details.

The hoard comprised an 'earthenware vase containing 47 silver Baiocasses staters.' 37 coins were donated to the Musée de Rouen (Inventory III, 2, p. 157, Inv. 2638). A further 10 were deposited in 1939 with the Musée Biochet de Caudebec-en-Caux. These were destroyed during the 2nd World War.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen, France (37 coins) (Inventory III, 2, p. 157, Inv. 2638). Musée Biochet de Caudebec-en-Caux, France (10 cois; lost during WWII)

summary: 27 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

A hoard of 155 bronze coins (2 hellenistic coins, 34 Roman imperial coins including 2 denarii, 12 provincial coins, 107 provincial coins from Gerasa), found within a linen purse close to the podium of the temple of Zeus, in a layer of reused material dated from the early 3rd c. AD.

A hoard of 432 Roman silver coins (denarii and some antoniniani), ranging from Commodus to Trajan Decius, found in the summer of 1895 during draining works at Brickendonbury, south of Hertford. The coins lay partly in a small recess cut in the virgin clay, and partly in the soil above.
The hoard comprised 53 copper-alloy coins from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Unknown number of Roman denarii, only 3 coins are known: Trajan 2, Hadrian.
disposition: Collection of Antonín Hofmeister (an archivist, 1945), Josefov, now missing.

summary: 125 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Tetricus I (AD 271-274). The hoard was found by Y. Loukianoff during an excavation. The hoard is the property of the town of Rezé and is preserved by the Direction des Antiquités Historiques
Originally, 201 silver coins. 190 silver coins are documented: Hadrian - Carus (AD 282-285). The half follis of Justin I/Justinian I is, most likely, an intruder.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Targovishte, Bulgaria; inv.no. 165 (190 coins)

summary: A pile of coins was found wrapped in a wide weave cloth bag in the vicinity of the skeleton. 409 coins: 2 aurei, 189 denarii, 59 sestertii, 39 dupondii, 118 asses, 2 Greek coins.
+8 kg, c. 2000 (515) antoniniani (radiates): Valerian - Claudius II (AD 268-270); silver w8: c. 541.0-2499.0g (after Hobbs).
10 solidi found in a domestic building: Constantius II - Honorius (AD 402-406).

14 aureii (13 mounted): Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 204); gold w8 110 g. Found with a bronze pitcher. The con10t: 2 crosses; 3 chains; a brooch; 6ty-8 pendants and 6ty-4 grains of necklace; 4teen coins of Roman emperors of the second-third century, the Anto9s mainly, and 2 bracteates.

The hoard comprised 13 denarii from Mark Antony to Septimius Severus. They were found concealed in the belt of male burial interpreted as being that of a Roman soldier. The burial was found in the courtyard of a building situated at No. 12 rue des Fantasques
206 nummi: Constantine I - Constantius II (AD 355-361).

A hoard found in 1979 to the north west of Bath and thought to be complete except for 6 coins. Very little is known about the discovery of the hoard, except that it was associated with a few fragments of lead which may be derived from a container. 1'807 of the coins were cleaned and catalogued prior to the resale and dispersal of the hoard; 1805 antoniniani, 1 denarius and 1 quinarius, ranging from Gallienus to Allectus.
The hoard comprised 30 coins of Mattathias Antigonus (40-37 BC) and 1 unstruck flan.
8 Iron Age staters, found in a field near Ryarsh, Kent.
The hoard comprises 102 antoniniani (radiates).
disposition: Museu de la Porciúncula, Palma, Spain

summary: Accidentally discovered by schoolboy Leonid Ryshchuk in 1974. The hoard was found on the territory of the Lyshchitsy peat enterprise, on the northern edge of the peat bog, near the bridge across the ditch, 250 m south of the field, south of the cemetery of the village of Ogorodniki. According to the discoverer, the total number of coins ranged from 350 to 500 pieces. Most of the coins were taken by local residents and collectors, only 48 denarii have survived from this find (transferred to the Brest Regional Local History Museum). In 1974, at the hoard find spot, L. Pobol carried out excavations, another 63 coins were discovered (transferred to the Museum of ancient Belarusian Culture of the National Academy of Sciences of Belarus). 5 coins from the hoard are in the private collection of V. Pinchuk in Minsk. A total of 116 coins are known: 115 denarii (Nero-Marcus Aurelius) and 1 imitation of denarius.
disposition: Brest Regional Local History Museum (48 coins); Museum of ancient Belarusian Culture of the National Academy of Sciences of Belarus (63 coins); private collection of V. Pinchuk in Minsk (5 coins)

summary: The 9 coins (5 denarii, 3 bronzes and 1 antoninianus, to Severus Alexander) was found in 1780 with other relics, in a meadow near Marbach, at the confluence of Neckar and Murr. It is labelled as 'Kollektivfund' in FMRD, not as hoard.
52 nummi: Constans - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
Hoard of 15 imperial denarii found with a jug in an inhumation grave: Nero - Hadrian (AD 134-138).

Between 25000-30000 coins found in 2 bronze vessels: 8 or 10 aurei from Hadrian to Severus Alexander; 5 bronze coins (Septimius Severus, Severus Alexander, Philip II, Postumus); 1 bronze medallion of Severus Alexander (with Julia Mamaea); 25000-30000 silver and billon coins from Claudius (I/II?) to Postumus; gold w8: c. 64.8 g; Silver: c.25-30000 coins; Silver w8: c.7427.6-71498.9. Together were found jewelry: 30 gold and silver rings; 2 or 3 pairs of gold earrings; a pair of bracelets, 2 styla, 30 silver spoons; a gold necklace (?).

find_spot_name: POMPEII VI, 7 - VIA DI MERCURIO, ALL'ALTEZZA DELLA CASA DEI DIOSCURI B
summary: 2 uncertain silver coins, 4 uncertain bronze coins and an uncertain group of bronze coins fused together found with a skeleton and gold jewelry in regio VI, insula 7, on the via di Mercurio near Casa dei Dioscuri.
55 silver coins, ranging from Antoninus Pius to Gordian III, found during construction work.
A widely scattered hoard of 82 Iron Age gold coins found over a period of more than a decade.
311 denarii: Republic – Trajan (AD 99).
The hoard was found in "Perron" locality, in a vase. It comprised 1200 coins from Elagabalus to Postumus (AD 260-269).
Originally, 87 silver coins. 66 pieces were recovered: 18 antoniniani (radiates), 48 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-247).
disposition: Collection Nussbaum, Timișoara, Romania; otherwise, dispersed

summary: 1 antoninianus (Claudius II) and 2 nummi (Gratian; Gratian or Valentinian II), found in an Early medieval burial (Alemannic).
3 coins found on surface 1 next to the other (AD 260-274).
The hoard was found in an earthen pot in the forest. It comprised 33 denarii from Marcus Aurelius to Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-236). Only 29 are now recorded.
About 800 denarii and antoniniani of the 1st-3rd centuries AD.
The hoard comprised 292 denarii from Domitian to Maximinus (AD 238).

The hoard comprised a copper-alloy vessel with leather bags originally containing more than 2650 Roman gold coins. Of these, 2518 have been recorded. The hoard was discovered during excavation work for a car park in the western quarter of ancient Trier. Coins range from Nero to Septimius Severus. Several coins, especially of Nero and Titus, display punch marks or graffiti. 84 coins are new types not documented before.

A hoard of 291 Roman imperial denarii: Hadrian – Commodus (AD 180-192) and their imitations was found by 2 treasure hunters in early June 2016 in the Kyiv region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published by 1 of the finders on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity on June 21, 2016. The finder reported that the coins were collected from an area of 3 square meters. The first coins were found at a depth of 10-20 cm, although the pit for their search was dug about 1 m deep. Some coins have traces of bronze oxides. In general, the preservation of coins is good (weak wear). In August 2016, the entire hoard was sold at a Violity auction. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
19 coins: 17 antoniniani (radiates), 2 nummi: Gallienus - Constantine I (AD 306-337).
30 gold coins and jewelry. Among issuers was recognized 1 of the Valentiniani, most likely, Valentinian III.

The finder of the first coin, a stater of Cunobelin stated that the first coin had been found barely beneath the surface, in early 1971. On 27 January 1973 he and his detecting partner searched the same spot again, and found the 11 additional coins - another 7 staters of Cunobelin and 4 of Tasciovanos - up to 30 m apart and from just below the surface to about 25 cm deep. The site was said to have been disturbed by roadworks and/or the planting of a hedge, which may well have scattered the hoard.
155 bronze coins, official and provincial issues of Viminacium and Provincia Dacia: Antoninus Pius - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).

Found during construction work, supervised by archaeologists. Among other coins ca. 30 poorly preserved radiates, probably a purse (?), mainly imitations of the Gallic Empire (Tetricus I), plus 1 Divo Claudio II (altar, cf. RIC V.1, p. 233, no 261 (bust K).
At least 16 coins, recorded over a period of several years, which might conceivably have originated in a hoard. No further information available
Unknown circumstances of finding. 4 solidi: Honorius 1, Theodosius II 3 (AD 441-450); gold w8: 17.8g.
disposition: Musée National du Bardo, Tunis, Tunisia

summary: The hoard comprised 160(?) silver shekels, 89 of which were published. These coins date between 258 BC and AD 68/69.

De Jersey (2015) gives a full account of this discovery and its implications. This was probably the largest Iron Age coin hoard found in Britain, but it was illegally detected and then dispersed, before a complete record could be made. The hoard appears to have been contained in a metal bowl and was associated with further gold coins, ingots and torc fragments buried above and below it. Estimates range from between 6000 and 8000 silver coins.

A hoard of 20 denarii (Antoninus Pius - Commodus, but no details known for 12 coins) was found between 1880 and 1890 in a glass bowl, between the city and the railroad, directly southeast of the confluence of the Horst- and To10graben.
(5-6 kg) 2000 coins. Identified 341 silver coins: 1 denarius, 340 antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - Valerian I (AD 259); silver w8: 2500.2 - 4759.1 g+.
disposition: Archeological Museum Zagreb (?980 coins); P. Broz collection Zagreb (83 coins), Croatia; dispersed - 1981

summary: The hoard includes 6 denari and 8 antoniniani (radiates) from Trajan to Philip I (AD 103-247) kept in a private collection.
A possible hoard (or part of a hoard) of 40 sestertii from Trajan to Valerian I (AD 253-254)?
Originally, 1500 denarii and a drachm found with a clay vessel. 1391 coins preserved: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver w8: 3924.6 g. (1.391 coins).
45 silver coins: Republic - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
The hoard comprised 1002 denarii and 2 drachms from Nero to Gordian I. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of between 1467.5g and 3140.8g.
Around 2500 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel. 1800 coins were recovered: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver w8: 859.1-1804.1g.
A small barbarous radiate hoard in the British Museum with the provenance "Beccles, Lowestoft, 1872". No further information.
Since 2001 a number of die-linked Cheriton staters have appeared in the trade, reportedly from a hoard found near Wickham, north of Portsmouth. The total of coins in the find is unknown.
The hoard comprised 33 4th century nummi of the House of Constantine.

The hoard comprised a terracotta vessel filled with gold coins. Bourignon remarked that the earliest he saw were of Augustus and the latest of Domitian, although he was assured that there were also coins of Julius Caesar.
75 siliquae and 10 nummi to AD 402.
2 silver coins: Titus for Divus Vespasianus, Hadrian.
20 Alexandrian bronzes found in ceramic vessel in the courtyard just in front of a door during excavations of a house. Ranking: Cleopatra VII - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).

A cultic area with 2 temples was excavated southwest of the intersection of Groß-Umstädter straße/Aschaffenburger straße. 1 of the 2 temples had a quadratic cella, corresponding to the Gallo-Roman type. A small hoard of 5 bronze coins (Trajan to Antoninus Pius) and a complete set of cultic vessels was found in its immediate vicinity.
43 north-eastern silver Iron Age coins found in 1997, although it is unclear if more went unrecorded.

The hoard was found in a ceramic urn which had been placed in a rectangular cavity under a large flat st1. Within the urn, were 100 small gold Roman coins and 200 in silver and bronze, as well as some b1s. The hoard was found by a farmer when he lifted a large flat st1 in a field which was bothering him. The farmer sold the coins to a collector with the exception of 1 coin each in gold, silver and bronze.
6 antoniniani (radiates) found in a small ceramic vessel: Gallienus (sole) 2, Claudius II 2 Probus 2.
The hoard comprised 12 nummi dated between AD 341-346 and AD 383-395.
The hoard comprised 8 antoniniani (radiates) of Quietus (AD 260-261).
3071 bronze coins: Hellenistic - Valentinian III (AD 455).

The hoard comprised 2 vessels containing 3080 coins. Cousin mentions 3074 coins, but the list of reverses that he gives has a total of 3071 and the total by emperor is 3084. He also described reverse types but does not match them with their obverses. The last coins are 115 SAECVLI FELICITAS issues of Postumus (Elmer 593). It was found within 7 or 8 metres of Hoard ÉTAPLES 1840 1 during archaeological excavations directed by L. Cousin.
6 silver coins found close to each other: 1 denarius, 1 antoninianus (radiate), 4 siliquae: Commodus (1), Gordian III (1), Constantius II (4).

Lafaurie dates the deposition of this hoard to the beginning of the fifth century, before the menace of the Vandals (letter of 28.06.1962). Circa 200 siliquae; Silver w8: c. 254.7-339.6 g. According to Kent: 'perhaps 'Vandal', probably Visigothic GLORIA'.
5 staters of Dubnovellaunos found in a radius of c.75 m on land near Maldon.
50 kilos (circa 165000 coins) of nummi from Valentinian I/II to Honorius. Still unpublished.
6 (or possibly more) Iron Age gold coins, found on the southern outskirts of Grimsby.
Few coins found with a ceramic vessel. Unreliable information on the circumstances of discovery. The nummus of Licinius I was found later, in 1966.

There are 21 nummi of the House of Constantine in the British Museum with the provenance Westergate, Chichester (BM 18530706). Possibly related to the grave find from Westergate donated in 1853 (Pastscape 249071) but there is nothing in the acquisition information to connect the 2 finds.
52 denarii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
Around 40 antoniniani (radiates) of Aurelianus and Severina (AD 273-275); mint of Siscia. Unpublished.

The con10t of the hoard is only briefly menti1d: 31 gold denominations dating to the reign of Honorius and Valentinian III, including coins of Galla Placidia and Licinia Eudoxia, now dispersed. The total gold w8 is unknown.

Around 500 radiates (Valerian I to Diocletian) found by a workman in a rock crevice inside a coal mine near Aberkenfig. The coins were apparently lying on a fragment of decayed cloth, suggesting a container. 3 different lists of this hoard exist, totalling c. 530, 500 and 492 coins. The list here follows the 1 given by Robertson, based on the 492 coins deposited at the National Museum Cardiff.
Historic record of 2 gold Iron Age coins found at Woodeaton in 1676.

find_spot_name: BRACARA AUGUSTA - SEMINÁRIO CONCILIAR DE S. PEDRO E S. PAULO
summary: 481 coins found together under a tile: Diocletian - Valentinian III (AD 440-455).
Hoard of 314 large Roman imperial bronze coins: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).
42 provincial bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel. 12 have been examined: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 244-249).

The hoard comprised 2 denarii (Trajan, Hadrian) and 25 aes coins ranging from Domitian Caesar to Faustina II. They were recovered during the excavation of a inhumation burial (tomb 2/1965) in the necropolis and were interpreted as the con10ts of a purse. 20 coins are preserved today, and reliable descriptions of the other 1s exist.
disposition: Ufficio dei beni culturali, Bellinzona (20 coins); lost (7 coins)

summary: The hoard 'comprised 80 gold coins dating to the 4th or fifth centuries AD. A later find in 1861, apparently in the same spot, located another 18 solidi, mixed with Medieval florins' The coins were discovered on 2 occasions. In 1844 (or 1846) 80 gold coins were discovered after a landslide near the Customs post. In 1861, a further 18 solidi were found, apparently at the same spot. Gold w8: c.404.95g
disposition: Musée de Dieppe, France (three coins, stolenin 1904)

summary: A small hoard of 4 gold coins of Arcadius and Honorius found with a gold ring outside the east wall of the temple, during the excavation of the Romano-Celtic Temple inside the Iron Age hill fort of Maiden Castle.
Urn containing 1500 Roman coins, found by a man ditching in a field. Undated.
A small hoard found early in 2004, with 2 Gallo-Belgic E staters and 4 British QB staters. 5 staters found in 2013-2014 are thought to be part of this hoard as well.

The hoard comprised a black coarseware vessel containing several 100 electrum staters. A mention of a second discovery of 20 staters at the same site is probably an error. The hoard was found by a worker in a vineyard at the bottom of the garden of the ancient Commandery of Saint-Thomas.

28 bronze coins found near a skeleton: 27 provincial coins minted on Cyprus (uncertain mint under Augustus and Tiberius; Koinon of Cyprus for Claudius, Vespasian, and Trajan) and 1 sestertius of Trajan (AD 114-117).
The hoard comprised 9 aurei from Antoninus Pius to Marcus Aurelius.
377 nummi: Tetrarchy (AD 284-310).
The hoard comprised 12 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III, Philip I, Trebonianus Gallus, Volusian, Salonina, Saloninus and Postumus.
1 uncertain Imperial denarius and 1 uncertain denarius found with skeletons and a gold necklace on the via di Mercurio.
200 bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel. 1 nummus wasd seen in 1933 by Dr. F. Hantmann.

A hoard (or part of a hoard?) of 37 4th century nummi, known through a lot of 29 nummi of the first Tetrarchy (art market, Athens) and 8 further nummi presenting the same patina, confiscated from a dealer in Delphi in 1962. Mints represented are mainly the 1s from Italy, which is curious for Greece and might be explained by the fact that this hoard could be a purse loss of an Italian visiting Greece.
2 denarii found in mound: Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius/Faustina II (Diva).

A Late Roman hoard of 475 coins, found during the excavations of the inner wall of the acropolis. It comprised 1 Hellenistic coin (Phalasarna), 1 antoninianus of Aurelian, a Gallic Empire imitation and 472 nummi (up to Theodosius II).
1606 silver coins: 604 denarii, 1002 antoniniani of the 1st-3rd centuries AD.

Around a skeleton, orientated eastwards, 'a large number' of Roman coins - estimated to 50 pieces: Jovian - Valentinian III (AD 426-430). The majority belonged to Valentinian I, Valens and Gratian. Most of the coins were sold in Vrsac (Serbia) and Timisoara (Romania). 23 coins entered the Ormos Zsigmond collection, which was later transferred to the National Museum of Banat. 2 solidi of Valentinian I minted in Treveri are still kept in the collection of the museum.
disposition: Muzeul Național al Banatului, Timișoara, Romania (inv.no. 59-60)

summary: The hoard comprised 'middle bronzes' (nummi or folles) dating from Diocletian to Constantine I. The number of coins in the hoard has been estimated at between 150 (Chapuis) and 350 (Riboud). The majority were acquired by Chapuis.
7 silver coins: 6 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate): Republic - Valerianus/Gallienus (Salonina) (AD 253-268); silver w8: 11.8-22.8 g.
disposition: Musée Archéologique de Namur, Belgium (7 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 25 coins (23 sestertii, 1 dupondius and 1 Provincial bronze of Trajan of the Koinon of Cyprus), ranging from Titus to Antoninus Pius.
5, or possibly up to 8 aurei, from Nero to Diva Faustina I (AD 161). 5 aurei are listed here, and the other 3 1s (Bland/Loriot 343-5) are listed separately as single gold finds.
disposition: Harris Museum, Preston (part); Blackburn museum (2 coins)

summary: Around 1860 a forest warden delivered, among other coins, 6 denarii that lay in rolls, stuck together in a bundle. 7 denarii, ranging from Septimius Severus to Caracalla, were listed among the single finds made in Dambach in 1901 and could be identical with the find made ca. 1860.
Hoard of 11 sestertii found adjacent to the large Cadeby hoard.
5 antoniniani of Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2475

summary: A small hoard of 12 Roman Imperial denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192) was discovered by a treasure hunter in early summer 2020. According to the finder the coins were found in a “small area” and represent “the con10ts of a purse”. The further fate of the coins is unknown: Trajan (1), Antoninus Pius (4), Marcus Aurelius (4), Commodus (1), unknown (2).
During the digging of a ditch 3 asses were found placed in a small amphora which was placed in a bigger 1: Sextus Pompeius as, Augustus as, Philip I as,
In 1959, D. Kienast may have investigated the listed series of coins in art-dealing, which reportedly were picked up as a hoard find in the city area.
40 silver coins: Nerva - Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
12 antoniniani (radiates) found close to each other: Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).

Treasure with jewelry. 29 coins: 2 aurei, 27 denarii: Republic - Domitian (AD 92). Found together with an embossed gold foil diadem, 2 partiti1d earrings, 2 earrings with insectiform or endomorphic decoration, 2 rings with semi-precious st1s.
83 nummi: Constantius II - Leo I (AD 457-474).
Hoard of 86 coins: 82 republican and imperial denarii, 3 drachms of Dyrrhachium, 1 unidentified bronze coins: Republic - Augustus (29-27 BC).
A hoard of 8 bronze coins from the Severan time (after AD 192), found in grave 27A in the western cemetery of Pella.

In Room 15, part of 'Central Group' of villa rooms, there was a small, very shallow subcircular grave 0.43m long and 0.38m wide, cut into earlier concrete floor. This contained skeleton of a neonate, disturbed & mostly removed at later date, accompanied by 4 minims, 2 minimi, a bronze vessel frag., a pot sherd & a small amount of carbonised wheat grains. In same room there was also a small hoard of ingots (composition 60% copper and 40% lead) and a casting, placed in a small pit together with a pottery vessel.
The hoard comprised over 1000 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel. 640 coins have been seen: Titus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 130 silver coins are known: 1 antoninianus (radiate), 129 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
5 denarii from Vespasian (Domitian) to Antoninus Pius (M. Aurelius). Part of a larger hoard, details unknown.
44 silver coins: 2 argentei, 42 siliquae: Jovian - Valens (AD 364-367); silver w8: 88 g
Hoard of 800 coins, divided by 3 lots. Only 77 were studied: Philip I - Gallienus (AD 253-268).
disposition: Museum of History and Archaeology, Constanța (circa 100 coins); Coin Room Romanian Academy, Bucharest (77 coins); Institute of Archaeology, Bucharest (10 coins)

summary: It comprised c. 100 bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel: Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249). Only 30 are now recorded: 29 sestertii, 1 as.
356 coins found southward of mausoleum B: 352 imitations of antoniniani (radiates), 4 nummi of Constantine I/his sons as Caesars (AD 310-337).
50 silver coins, 10 seen: Caracalla - Trajan Decius (AD 250-251).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.no. CLXIV in 1957

summary: 10 coins stuck together were found on the area of the legionary fort. Together were found a silver phalera and a silver handle from a cup. Coins ranging: Celtic 1, Republic 1, Augustus Colonia Nemausus 8.
The hoard comprised 21 denarii from Vitellius to Septimius Severus with a tpq of AD 201 to 206. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of 39.6-60.8 g.
(1122) 1040 silver and bronze coins: 5 antoniniani (radiates), 869 nummi, 177 imitations: Trajan - Magnus Maximus (AD 385-386).
An amphora with 2 antoniniani and 7 nummi ranging from Tacitus to the first Tetrarchy found on the seabed.
A scattered hoard of 11 coins found by detectorists in a field north of the oppidum at Wheathampstead. Given the wide range of dates, the coins may come from more than 1 deposit.
32 Roman imperial bronze coins found with an amphora: 11 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 20 asses: Augustus - Claudius I (AD 41-50).
Unknown initial number of silver coins. 35 coins entered the museum collection in Varna: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 244-249); Silver w8: 45.1-89.6 g.
The hoard comprised a large number of sestertii of the Early Empire including 2 sestertii of Nerva.

During the excavation of Roman fort at Reculver, a rectangular sunken room, poss. the strong room of the principia & sacellum, was excav., 23 ft 10 in. long & 20 ft wide. It had a thin skin floor of white mortar, covered in a deposit 6-12 in. deep of loam, mortar, painted wall plaster & domestic refuse, incl. pottery. It also produced frags. of 2 st1 inscriptions from commemorative tablets, 6 iron arrowheads, & 21 coins of Antoninus Pius to Constantine II, with 14 from period AD 260-293. The rubble layer above contained mortaria, roof tile & box tile frags, & may represent collapsed roof, & this layer produced another 4 coins of Postumus of AD 268.Philp, B. 2005. The Excavation of the Roman Fort at Reculver, Kent. Kent Monographs 10. Kent Archaeol. Rescue Unit, pp. 44-45
54 coins: 6 antoniniani (radiates) (4 copies), 2 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 6 asses, 39 nummi: Domitian - Constantine I (AD 335-337).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Namur, Belgium (53 or 34 coins)

summary: 2567 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Gallienus (Sole) - Probus (AD 276-282).
disposition: Gradki muzej Varaždin (2567 coins); finder (19 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised at least 82 coins with a tpq of AD 434 to 435. No further information was given about the composition of the hoard.

Hoard found in a cooking pot (not preserved) during construction work for the Nordostbahn railway track. It comprised an unknown number of antoniniani, of which 204 (possibly the greater part) are preserved in public collection, ranging from Trebonianus Gallus to Claudius II. - After the publication in 1992, at least another 6 coins from this hoard were recorded, in a private collection in Diessenhofen. The sherds of the pot are described in the 1893 publication. 4 Gallienus coins were also subjected to chemical analysis at the same time, pp. 11-12: "Derselbe hat drei Stücke auf ihre Zusammensetzung quantitativ und qualitativ, das vierte nur qualitativ untersucht und folgendes gefunden: I. 6 Theile Zinn, 94 Theile Kupfer; II. 30 Th. Silber, 03 Th. Gold, 697 Th. Kupfer; III. 18 Th. Antimon, 82 Th. Kupfer; IV. Kupfer, Antimon und wenig Bismuth."
disposition: Thurgauisches Historisches Museum, Frauenfeld (158 coins); Museum Allerheiligen, Schaffhausen (40 coins); Schweizerisches Landesmuseum Zürich (6 coins); private (6 coins)

summary: Hoard of antoniniani (radiates). Only 30 coins were seen: Gallienus (sole) - Maximian I (AD 284-293)
(54) 21 coins mixture of silver and bronze denominations: Caracalla - Constantine I (AD 324-326).
The hoard comprised 57 nummi dated between AD 337-341 and AD 474-491, and 1 Nabataean coin.
160 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
disposition: AM Zagreb (41); ZM Sarajevo (114); Fojnica monastery; dispersed

summary: A depot of 8 antoniniani and 1 denarius (Septimius Severus - Claudius II) found in a pit on 1 of the rooms of the villa rustica at Oensingen
The hoard comprised 84 tetradrachms dated between AD 211-217/8.
300 Republican denarii. All of them with the helmeted head of Rome on the obverse. Only 2 could be studied.
2 denarii: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161). Found while ploughing.
A small group of "irregular Dobunnic" or East Wiltshire silver units, found within an area of approximately 20 m2.
48 bronze coins ranking from Nerva to Licinius I. Hoard? No further details
9 sestertii: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 181).
800 nummi found with a ceramic vessel near the hillfort wall. 555 coins are hosted in the Museu Arqueológico da Citânia de Sanfins: Claudius II - Arcadius and Honorius (AD 402). Work in progress.
disposition: Museu Arqueológico da Citânia de Sanfins, Portugal

summary: 33 denarii found in a pit under a slab in a Roman house: Augustus - Tiberius (AD 14-15).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico de Santa Tecla, Pontevedra, Spain

summary: Hallaton: 14 hoards were located in and around the entrance way. Hoard 14 comprises 107 silver Iron Age coins.
The hoard comprised a ceramic pot containing approximately '400 middle and small bronzes dating to the third century AD': Valerian I - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
Found during excavations. Assemblage of 10 aes coins, Domitian to Commodus, in a roadside ditch, spread out over ca. 5x1 metres. The hoard comprised 3 dupondii and 7 asses.

Undeclared hoard of Iron Age and Roman Republican silver. Findspot disputed. Chadburn (2006, hoard 8) records a large hoard supposedly of East Anglian and Republican silver, said to have been found somewhere in the Huntingdon area in the early 1990s, supplying 4 possible findspots. Given the date of the alleged discovery it is possible that this record represents a garbled account of part of the Bowl Hoard, but Chadburn suggests that it was a genuine, separate find.
The hoard comprised 371 denarii from the Republic to Domitian dating to AD 80-81. The Republican denarii are identified to 57 'families' but cannot be given RRC equivalents.
Over 9 nummi found in a garden. Among them 1 coin of Constantius II and 1 of the House of Theodosius I (AD 379-423).
disposition: National museum, Prague, Czech Republic (inv.no. H5-H5-255.040-255.648)

summary: The coins were found in a block, stuck together with corrosion products and comprised 151 sestertii, dupondii and asses from Trajan to Commodus. The coins were found during gravel extraction in the river and may represent a hoard washed out from a riverbank or a votive deposit.

The Lengerich II find is the second of a set of 3 finds, made underneath 3 large st1s during the construction of the road Freren - Lengerich. It consisted of gold jewellery, a 10 solidi (time of Constantine I). The coins had been placed underneath a number of smaller st1s, artificially piled together.

A hoard of at least 375 coins - Tetradrachms, drachms, cistophori, denarii: Macedonian, Seleucian, Phenician, Parthian, Armenian, Pontic, Cappadocian, from Pergamon, Ephesus and Roman), ranging from 220-163 to 36-34 BC. 195 coins were well documented.
The hoard comprised around 500 tetradrachms and at least 2000 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).

The hoard comprised 10.6kg of coins. Mints represented are Rome (3195); Milan (135); Viminiacium (1); Siscia (151), Sirmium (2), Antioch (1); Cyzicus (10); Cologne (13); Trier (11); uncertain (53) Found during the construction of a vault. Silver: 28, 3590, 47 coins; Silver w8: 1008.5-4527.4
Hoard of 68 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 47 pieces were recorded: Republic - Augustus (2 BC - AD 4).

HER record of a scattered 4th century hoard from 1 corner of a field, recorded at Gloucester City Museum in 1997. Mixed group of 42 objects including 6 Roman brooches or brooch fragments and a part of a Roman copper alloy spoon. 15 of the coins date from the period AD 320-340.
57 antoniniani: Elagabalus - Valerian I (AD 253-254).
disposition: Magyar Nemzeti Múzeum, Budapest; Museum Dunaújváros, Hungary

summary: A hoard of ca. 2400 silver coins, most of them ranging from Septimius Severus to Gallienus, was unearthed in house no. 45 in 1902. 700 specimens arrived in the Kemp10 Heimatmuseum, several others in private ownership. The provenance of the coins in the Kemp10 museum can't be ascertained any more, but FMRD publishes a list of 21 coins with RIC references, and a summary list of 363 coins that probably came from this hoard.
HER record of a small hoard of 33 nummi ending with Gratian, found by the side of the road in Hambledon before 1942. Probably Valentinianic?
The hoard(?) comprised 696 bronze coins of Alexander Jannaeus (103-76 BC), which may have been derived from smaller hoards.
6 coins: 5 denarii, 1 unknown denomination: Domitian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).Uncertain whether the cooins belong to a hoard or are single finds.
The hoard comprised 8 bronze coins of the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136) found with traces of a leather bag.
4 antoniniani: 3 Gallienus (sole), 1 Claudius II (AD 268-270).
500 coins of which only 16 were seen have been found on the canabae area: Tiberius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
Hoard of at least 62 denarii. Only 13 are known: 8 republican among which Julius Caesar 1, Augustus 3, Hadrian 2.

At least 42 solidi (Valentinian II - Valentinian III, AD 439-455) found over a period of more than a century at the same spot. The first coin was found in 1842, during agricultural work. More followed in 1846, and 1906. In the 2010s, further coins (31) were discovered using a metal detector, documented on PAN. Archaeological field research was also carried out in 2016.

Excavation of a small area within the hillfort revealed a pit with a fill of 3 layers. On the surface of the lowest layer were "2, possibly 3, potin coins in an advanced state of corrosion. Nevertheless they could be identified as of Class I". There were a few sherds of pottery on the surface of the same layer, of late Iron Age date.
Hoard of 198 coins of the Bosporan kings, Rhescuporis V, Pharsanzes, Sauromates IV, Teiranes (AD 266-278).

The hoard comprised '100s of bronze coins (150 coins according to Angot). The majority were of Trajan, Hadrian and of Antoninus Pius. In the 1860s, the vicar of Fougerolles, Charles Pointeau, examined 72 coins and Chevallier acquired 'a good number, all large bronzes of Trajan to Commodus'. It has therefore been assumed that this hoard was made up of sestertii.
103 nummi found in a fire layer from a domestic building: Claudius II (Divus) - Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
disposition: Museu Convento dos Lóios, Santa Maria da Feira, Portugal

summary: The hoard comprised '1000s of Roman coins dating to the period AD 290 to 310 from the mints of London, Lyon, Trier, Rome and Carthage.' The plow originally brought 250 coins to the surface and subsequent archaeological investigation discovered 3 amphorae containing the coins.

(c. 5000) gold coins from Aurelian to Heraclius Constantius (AD 610-641). 7 solidi are preserved in the collection of the National History Museum of Transylvania Cluj-Napoca, Romania: Theodosius II, Valentinian III, Marcian, Leo I (4).
disposition: National History Museum of Transylvania Cluj-Napoca, Romania; inv.no. N 13851, 13919, 13923, 13925, 13926, 14194, 14221

summary: The hoard comprised 160 Roman bronze and billon coins from Severus Alexander to Aurelian (AD 270-275).
5 nummi: Arcadius 1, Honorius 2 and 2 uncertain (AD 393-423).
43 nummi found in the heating system of room F of the pratorium: House of Constantine I - Magnus Maximus (AD 383-388).
disposition: Museum Lauriacum - Museum der Stadt Enns, Austria

summary: 992 coins: 14 denarii, 900 antoniniani, 1 sestertius: Septimius Severus - Valerianus I (AD 259); and jewelry of precious metal
Hoard of 31 denarii. Only 1 denarius of Antoninus Pius is known.

This hoard was found in 3 ceramic pots and contained more than 4000 silver coins from which H. Ceka has published a total of about 3900 Roman Imperial coins in 1958. According to the publication of the hoard, which refers to the inquiry held by the Albanian Institutions at the time of the discovery, the hoard was constituted by silver coins and gold jewelry (rings, necklaces) but the latter was dispersed immediately after the discovery. Also, more than 100 coins were dispersed after the discovery. The coins are mostly Denarius dating from Nero to Marcus Aurelius (54-175 AD). Based on the numismatic data (there is no archaeological excavation that can help at the precision of the hoard's burying date), it should have been buried around or short after 170 AD.
disposition: The hoard is actually part of the collection of the Coin Cabinet, Institute of Archaeology, Albania

summary: 252 silver coins with now description, 4 gold coins: Maximian I aureus, Severus II aureus, Valentinian I solidus pendant (AD 367-375). An aureus of Nero as a pendant. Together with the coins were also found 2 gold coins (1 lunula).
The hoard comprised a wine amphora containing 953 coins, including 937 sestertii, 6 dupondii and 10 asses from Vespasian to Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
38 bronze coins found in a small sewer found as 1 block: Vespasian - Commodus (AD

6 denarii and 1 AE coin, ranging from Domitian to Commodus, found in cellar 207 between 1897 and 1908. These 7 coins of this find were not identified according to inventory number or type and could thus not be separated out from the list of single finds.

The hoard was found during the excavation of a fanum(?) and comprised more than 500 silver and bronze Iron Age and Roman coins. Some were completely corroded; others had been melted by an in10se heat; but a large number were well preserved. 13 coins were found inside a complete ceramic vessel (complete but broken) mixed with ash and carbonised wood. They included 6 Republican denarii and 7 bronzes of Augustus, Nero and Titus. The coins are interpreted by TAF as either a funerary deposit or successive offerings at a native sanctuary. The bronze of CABALLOS was given to the Musée Saint-Jean d'Angers on the 17.08.1897 (Reg. V, p. 88, no. 434)
1013 silver cois: 1004 denarii, 9 antoniniani: Galba - Gordianus III (AD 239); silver w8: 1417.0-3160.9 g

The hoard (a purse) comprised 7 coins including 3 denarii, 1 quinarius, 1 dupondius and 2 asses, with a tpq of AD 41/42, found within a 2nd or 3rd century layer. The coins were corroded together in a single lump suggesting that they had originally been placed in a leather or textile purse or bag.
49 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211). Found together with a gold pendant.
73 nummi found in the "House of the 2 hoards": Constantine I (Constantine II Caesar) - Theodosius I (Arcadius) (AD 388-395).
201 solidi: Valentinian II - Valentinian III (AD 425-455). Together was found a fragment from a golden bracelet.
disposition: Hermitage, St. Petersburg, Russia (53 coins); collection I.I. Tolstoi (12 coins); University of Kharkov, Ukraine (34 coins); State Historical Museum, Moscow, Russia (102 solidi)

summary: 41 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).

The hoard comprised 885 coins, including 576 antoniniani (radiates) and 309 nummi. Not all coins were catalogued. The hoard was offered for sale on the Antiquities Market and is thought to have come from the Ankara area.

A report on a hoard of Roman denarii (Vespasian - Septimius Severus), found in the forest of Cowie, 3 miles north of St1haven, about 1 ½ miles from the Roman camp of Raedykes, in 1843. 9 of these denarii were apparently presented to the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland (3, with names of emperors), the British Museum (3 with names of emperors), and the Society of Antiquaries of Newcastle (3, but without names of emperors), but could not be located. The coins presented to the BM, and to the Society of Antiquaries of Newcastle, were described as having been "found at Blackburn of Muchalls in the County of Kincardine, in 1843".
12 nummi: House of Constantine (Helena) - Valens (AD 364-375).
22468 nummi, 1 denarius, 2 solidi found with a ceramic vessel. Among the menti1d issuers: Constantine I - Valentinian III (AD 425-455).
disposition: Museu Regional de Arqueologia D. Diogo de Sousa, Braga; Museu da Sociedade Martins Sarmento, Portugal

summary: The hoard was discovered in 1859 on the 'Schänzle' in Waldkirch. It comprised 18 denarii, ranging from Vespasian to Septimius Severus.
90 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 blank flan: Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

The hoard was found in the foundations of a 15th century house and comprised a small deposit of 3rd century coins. J. Chappée told Blanchet there were 10 coins: Victorinus 2, Tetricus I 3, Tetricus II 5.
(50) 25 denarii: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161). Found together with a silver bracelet.
(169) 137 coins: 5 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate), 1 as: Domitian - Gordian III (AD 241-243); silver w8: 10.0-16.2 g
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Namur, Belgium (137, maybe 169 coins)

summary: The context of the treasure burying, although partly known, remains problematic : in fact, there are 2 deposits of precious objects, very close to each other but quite distinct, inside caches which were laid under the ground. Should they be attributed to the occupants of the houses from the second half of the 3rd century AD, or to the occupants of the potter's workshop following in the beginning of the 4th century AD? The first deposit gathers together 2 silver bracelets and a group of statuettes in the same metal, more or less fragmentary. 3 of them are fully preserved : 1 Helios dedicated to an emperor's numen, 1 Fortuna with a double horn of plenty and 1 goddess, more enigmatic, carrying a dish with 2 birds inside. The head of a Jupiter and of an amazing personage with 2 outgrowths as an ornament in the hair add to the whole which is completed by a bust-portrait, probably representing an emperor (Gallienus?). The second deposit, locked inside a wooden box, consists of crookery, jewels and coins. The silverware is made up of 1 dish decorated with a Mercure, 2 small trays ornated with reliefs (1 of them just in bronze and silver plated), 4teen spoons and 2 fragmentary cutleries. All these objects belong to well known series in Gaul : their shapes and decoration show that they were made in the 3rd century AD. The set of jewels includes 2 golden bracelets, 2 pairs of golden, emerald, pearl and mol10 glass pendant earrings, 2 bezel rings (1 of them with a nicolo), and 1 coin medallion (Gordian III aureus, AD 238-244). At the bottom of the box, there was a purse with 81 well preserved silver coins - 29 denarii and 52 antoniniani (radiates) - with a chronological curve stretching from Vitellius (AD 69) to the joint reign of Valerian and Gallian (AD 253-260). In fact, there are 2 different sets : 1 with 62 coins, that is to say 19 "old" denarii from Vitellius to Commodus, 8 more recent all dated AD 201, 33 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 denarius struck between AD 215 and AD 217 for Caracalla, as well as, 1 denarius of Diadumenian in AD 218; the second set comprises 19 antoniniani (radiates) coins issued between AD 241 and AD 258. 1 can wonder about the precise nature of these deposits. The sculptures found there do not have quite a homogeneous construction ; maybe a kind of Lares altar or objects belonging to a sanctuary, as most of them represent divinities, and 1 at least, the birds’ goddess, seems to have a strong local connotation. The silverware hardly represents more than 2 pounds of metal ; it is therefore difficult to speak of a "table set" all the less as the spoons are rather incomplete. The set of jewels, which is more coherent and of good quality but with no exceptional piece, illustrates well the favourite jewels in the well-off classes of Gaul around the middle of the 3rd century AD. Regarding the coins, there are several arguments speaking for a saving, rather than for a reserve currency, which was formerly made (maybe following 2 main payments (donativa) in AD 202 and AD 217/218, and poorly completed by a contribution in antoniniani (radiates) around AD 258-260), a small family inheritance safeguarded for sentimental reasons, maybe 1 generation away. (Aubin, G. et al. 1999)
38 denarii: Republic - Augustus ( 15-13 BC).
The hoard consisted of 2 lots of 215 and 301 antoniniani (radiates): Balbinus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260). Only 299 coins were studied.
disposition: Civiche Raccolte Numismatiche del Comune di Milano; Gabinetto Numismatico dei Civici Musei di Pavia, Italy; private collection

summary: 158 coins: 7 denarii, 151 provincial bronzes: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Archaeology Museum, Varna, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 21275-21281 (7 denarii); inv.nos. 5224-5376 (151 coins)

summary: Around 20 provincial bronze coins are known. 7 pieces were documented: Septimius Severus - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).

A hoard of more than 100 solidi, apparently, all of Honorius was found during the construction of the Bank of Algeria building in Cherchell. Although the hoard was immediately dispersed. 23 solidi were seen and described by P. Salama
disposition: Musée d'Alger (16 coins); in Cherchell Collection Louis (6 coins); Collection Albitre (1 coin).

summary: A hoard of 30 denarii and 1 as (Republic - Trajan) found by the west wall of a plaster layer during an excavation on Reismühler Straße.
Over 100 silver and bronze coins. 80 pieces were recovered: 1 denarius, 67 sestertii, 12 dupondii, 1 As: Vespasianus - Hadrian (AD 134-138).
Described as a third century hoard, including a number of aurei, 'including issues of Faustina I/II (as Diva) and Julia Maesa'.

The hoard was found in a coarseware vessel covered with a tile. It comprised 12 very worn 'large bronzes' of the High Empire (Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Severus Alexander etc) and approximately 400 denarii and radiates including issues of Severus Alexander (1 or 2), Maximinus, Gordian III (numerous), Philip, Trajan Decius, Herennia Etruscilla, Volusian, Valerian II and Salonina. The majority of the coins were very corroded. The coins were accompanied by 7 gold intaglio finger rings and 2 gold necklaces, 1 set with emeralds and the other lozengiform blue st1s.
129 aurei: Vespasian to Septimius Severus (AD 193-205); gold w8: 859.2-871.1g.

Britannia 17 (1986), 420 records another Hurstbourne Tarrant hoard from the same finder, consisting of 4 silver units of Epaticcus found "within a yard of 1 another" in Blagdon Copse, in 1985 (also listed by Haselgrove 1989, 47). These are 4 very fine examples of the ABC 1349 type. This might be a genuine find, but the coincidence of its discovery with the appearance of dozens of equally fine examples of the same type from the ransacked Wanborough temple gives some grounds for concern.
7 bronze coins finds found in excavations: Nero - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Kyustendil, Bulgaria; inv. no. 59/1-5

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 264 Roman provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 9811-10060

summary: 7 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: History Museum, Yambol, Bulgaria; inv. no. ІІ-2129

summary: Purse(?) of 4 sestertii: Trajan 2, Hadrian I 2 (AD 121-122) found near a wall in the area of the civil town.

Hoard of 397 coins of Bosporan kings: Sauromates IV, Teiranes, Theothorses, Rhadamsada and Rhescuporis VI, dated between AD 275 and AD 326 was found with a ceramic jug during the excavations of a domestic building.
7 coins: 6 solidi, 1 denarius: Antoninus Pius - Anastasius (AD 491-518); gold w8: 26.7 g.; silver w8: c. 2.75 g. Also with gold spiral ring and a faïence bead.
Hoard of 3000 nummi, fresh minted, found with an amphora: Tetrarchy - Constantine I (AD 306-337).

The hoard comprised a copper-alloy vessel filled with 15 Roman silver coins and 600 small bronzes of the same module (radiates). The reverse of 1 coin is given as MARTI PACIFERO, A/-. It appears to be an issue of Gallienus (RIC V/1 236?)
3510 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 denarius: Philip I - Aurelianus (AD 270-275)
17 coins: 1 denarius, 16 provincial bronzes: Commodus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2491

summary: The hoard(?) comprised a concentration of 15 nummi, dated between AD 316 and 329.
136 silver coins: 74 denarii, 62 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Gallienus (AD 259-268); silver w8: 38.3-350.5 g.
disposition: Collection E. De Breyen (67 coins), in 1881; Town museum, Ieper, Belgium (vanished in 1914)

summary: The hoard was concealed under a tile and comprised 10 silver or billon coins dating to the late third or early 4th century AD. It is not clear whether the Tetrarchic issues are radiates or nummi. Silver w8: 4.3-11.9 g.
33 tedrachams from Philip I (Otacilia Severa) - Diocletian. Before the m1tary reform of AD 297. Only 16 pieces could be identified.
Unknown initial number of silver coins. 300 coins have been examined by Dr. Haralanov: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
The hoard comprised 1548 antoniniani (radiates) and 2 denarii, from Caracalla to Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 259-260). Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of between 1938.2 g. and 4027.1 g.

A hoard of 745 coins of Bosporan kings, Teiranes, Theothorses, Rhadamasades and Rhescuporis VI (AD 276-323) was found within a courtyard of a domestic building. The coins were grouped in rolls, each of them was separately wrapped. Some of the coins present 'tamga' symbols.

The hoard was found in a redware ceramic vessel and comprised 300 middle bronzes (3000 according to Grille). The list of reverse types compiled by Godard-Faultrier (with the most recent coin being a SOLI INVICTO COMITI) and the absence of pieces of Licinius suggests a closing date of AD 308/309.
disposition: Musée d'Angers (Reg. I, p. 20, no. 95, 27.10.1842) - fragments of the vase and 300 coins

summary: The hoard was found in 1947 in an earthen vase. It comprised many coins. Only 10 antoniniani were recorded, from Gallienus to Diocletian.
Unknown number of coins found in a ceramic vessel. Among them those of Tetricus I, Constantine I, Constantine II, Constantius II for Constantius III Gallus (AD 352-354).
The hoard was found during the 1988 excavation in the southern part of the Roman vicus. The coins (26 denarii, ranging from Nero to Antoninus Pius) were corroded together in a clump.
The hoard comprised approximately 1200 nummi of Maximian I and Constantius I Chlorus. The hoard was found in a fissure in the rock in a quarry when a worker broke off a block of st1.

Hoard consisting of 14 gold coins, a gold mouth piece of a sword scabbard, a couple of gold spiral rings, a whole and a fragment of a gold bar found 1839. The hoards ends with coins of Zeno (AD 476-491), but as it contains imitation solidi, its tpq is set to AD 500.
29 aurei including coins of Trajan, Hadrian, Sabina, Antoninus Pius, Lucius Verus. Together were found 2 gold fingerings.

The hoard comprised 2 ceramic urns that contained more than 100kg of Roman coins (according to Payan-Dumoulin) or 40kg (according to Vallentin) equating to approximately 12000 coins. Only 4685 coins, all radiates, were catalogued: Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver w8: 3241.0-14999.1 g.

The hoard comprised a bronze vessel containing 821 antoniniani (radiates). The catalogue made by Blanchet is not accurate. Aubin published a lot of 21 radiates in 1981 which probably came from the hoard. However, it is not clear whether these are additions or whether they were included in the original numbers. The hoard was found by a farmer. Silver: 821 coins; Silver w8: 222.6-1025.3 g.
disposition: Musée d'Archéologie Nationale, Saint-Germain-en-Laye, France (copper-alloy vessel, inv.no. 50253)

summary: 8 coins of Tetricus I, including some imitations, located in the museum of Bad Dürkheim and allegedly found 1854 in an urn. This could be a hoard, or part of 1, or a grave find.
1000 denarii found in a ceramic vessel - metal detecting - in an ancient building. The latest coins belong to Antoninus Pius.
13 coins: 2 antoniniani (radiates), 11 nummi: Gallienus (sole) - Theodosius I (393-395). Found on the decumanus. Uncertain whether they were found together. (Chico provides a list of 12 only).
disposition: Museo Monográfico de Itálica, Santiponce, Spain

summary: The hoard consists of a series of finds of Durotrigan coinage from a field south-east of Maiden Castle, recovered over the course of 12 years or more. The nominal total of coins is 113. The actual number of coins in the original deposit may have been significantly higher.
62 coins found when the water level went extremely low at the present dam: Claudius II (Divus) - Julian II (AD 361-363).
Hoard of over 100 denarii: Republic - Tiberius (AD 15-16).
20 antoniniani found in a small ceramic vessel. Some of the coins belong to Philip I.
Unknown initial number of coins. 86 silver coins seen: 58 denarii, 28 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver w8: 117.6-231 g.

During various excavations at the Neolithic site (from 1842 to 1969) 25 Roman coins - ranging from Domitian to Arcadius - were found together with other artefacts (rings, brooches). Among coins were, 8 gold pieces presented here: Tetrarchy - Theodosius I. Also 3 uniface gold medallions of the House of Constantine were found (see Objects). All the coins and artefacts are considered to be votive offerings (Bland/Loriot 2010, 99).
Around 600 denarii; Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: In 1906, there were 355 coins in the Coin Room of the Royal Academy in Königsberg, 16 copies in the Museum of Prussia, Königsberg. The fate of the rest is unknown. Approximately 250 denars were melted down. Lost

summary: The hoard was found in a copper-alloy bucket or situla and comprised 76 sestertii, 4 dupondii or asses and 1 radiate from the Flavian period to Gordian III and 65 bronzes of Postumus. These included 7 doubles sestertii from the mint of Cologne, 17 'large bronzes' from an uncertain mint, 23 'middle bronzes' of which many were cast and 18 bronzes of a size and w8 which would suggest that they were imitations.
Unknown number of initial coins. 20 pieces - unknown metal - are kept in the Coin Room of the Institute of Archaeology in Bucharest: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (Ad 138-161).
disposition: Coin Room of the Institute of Archaeology, Bucharest, Romania

summary: A hoard of 420 denarii, ranging from Mark Antony to Antoninus Pius, found near Alma Wood, Londonthorpe, together with fragments of the base of a small grey flagon which judging from its size and the marks of corrosion on the inside had originally contained the whole hoard. –A.J. White, in Lincs. Hist. and Arch., 12 (1977), 81; 13 (1978), 85
disposition: British Museum (part); Lincoln City and County Museum (part); Belton Trust (part); rest returned to finder

summary: 4 coins found on a terra sigillata dish as grave-goods with an inhumation on the Inner Relief Road site B, Colchester (St Johns Abbey). Found with a greyware jar.Further details of the grave in Crummy et al. 1993, 205ff record that this was a child's grave and also contained the cranium of a dog. The coins were in a leather pouch or purse and found stacked.
7 coins found by pupils and brought to their teacher: Alexandria provincial coins: 2, Alexandria nummi: 3. Uncertain mint 2.
16 siliquae of Constantius II (AD 351-355) found numerous silver jewelry; silver w8: 33.2-50.0 g.
7 denarii undescribed (Vespasian - Severus Alexander) found in fortifications.
A lager hoard. 210 denarii entered the museum collection in Sofia. No further information.
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria (210 coins)

summary: (25) 15 denarii: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. no. 426

summary: 1087 coins: 1 argenteus, 1086 nummi of the Tetrarchy (AD 311-312).

in 1895 Roman vestiges became visible in Lechniederung. Also a find of a sliver and 34 bronze coins, a bronze key, an angular-shaped appur10ance, and a round trinket of bronze were found during repairs of Lech-bridge in Lechhausen on a Bavarian bank.
41 silver hoards: 2 denarii, 39 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus (Julia Maesa) - Gallienus (Salonina) (AD 260-268). The coins were found together in a small pit.
4 gold coins (Antoninus Pius to Caracalla), found by a farmer from the village of Umm Qeis (anc. Gadara), and seen by the archaeologist Paul Ilton.

A hoard of provincial coins (Samos, Pergamum, Smyrna, Clazomenae, Metropolis and Nysa; Gordian III - Gallienus), seen in commerce in Athens, coming from Samos. 16 coins are listed, but 21+ are menti1d in the heading.

2154 silver coins: 45 denarii, 2109 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260); + 6669 provincial bronzes: 3600 Callatis, 3000 Tomis, 6 Histria, 5 Odessos, 21 Marcianopolis, 13 Nicopolis, 8 Hdrianopolis, 6 Anchialos, 3 Dionysopolis, 3 Mesembria, 1 Pautalia, 1 Bizantion, 1 Augusta Traiana, 1 Nicaea.
It comprised 93 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 88 are now recorded: Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249).

4th century. 8 coins of AD 310-317, an unusual group Reece considers to be a small hoard, &/or from a purse. The Snow's Farm/HAD III shrine complex was an octagonal shrine within a sub-square enclosure, built on top of a BA round barrow. Investigated by Bromwich in 1950s, then fully excav. in 1983. Evans and Hodder2006, pp. 352-363. Coin report by Reece.

A scattered hoard of Durotrigan coinage, mostly rather poorly recorded, recovered over several years. The alloy of some of the Durotrigan material is uncertain and thus the division into silver and bronze staters should be treated with some caution.
Uknown number of coins. Coins documented: Gallienus 1, 7 nummi: Gratian, Valentinian II, Magnus Maximus, Theodosius, Arcadius, Honorius.

32 coins were found in the Eastern buildings of the Temple at Pagan's Hill, most of which were found in robbers' spoil or under the rubble spread to the East. This includes 13 coins (2 radiates and 11 4th c. small bronzes) from a scattered hoard found under the rubble outside the outer wall.
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 8 denarii were documented

A hoard of 3 solidi (Honorius), 33 miliarenses, 1166 siliquae and 1 nummus, found close to the Roman villa of Stanchester. A denarius of Hadrian (0.99g fragment) was found at the same time but it is uncertain whether it is part of the hoard.
The hoard comprised a small casket or box containing silver and copper-alloy coins from Vespasian, Antoninus Pius and Trebonianus Gallus.

At the end of 1852, the Musée d'Angers acquired 12 coins found in the environs of Combrée. A letter between Godard-Faultrier and A. de Barthélémy attributed the coins to the Namnètes. Musée Saint-Jean d'Angers, 1st Register of entrys, p. 97, no. 362
Grave find of 4 coins: 1 denarius, 1 sestertius, 1 dupondius, 1 as Trajan to Antoninus Pius (AD 141-161).
53 bronze nummi to AD 317, no further information on this find.
68 coins: 7 aurei, 14 republican denarii, 2 republican asses, 11 imperial asses, 33 bronzes of Paestum: Republic - Vespasian (AD 69-79). Found together with gems and other artefacts.
A hoard of 304 silver coins (303 denarii and 1 drachm), ranging from Nero to Commodus, found in summer 2019 (with 6 additional coins found in 2020) on the Adlerberg, near Pratteln.
Few hundreds silver coins. 467 silver coins were reovered: Nero – Elagabalus (AD 218-222). No further details.
disposition: Bruckenthal Museum, Sibiu (420 coins); National History Museum, Bucharest (47 coins)

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 69 bronze coins: Augustus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
9 coins of unknown denomination: Tiberius - Caracalla (AD 211-217).
25 Roman coins of the "Anto9s". Considered as possible funerary offering. No further details.

The Lengerich III find is the third of a set of 3 finds, made underneath 3 large st1s during the construction of the road Freren - Lengerich. It consisted of late Roman silver coins of the ursuper Magnentius (of which 1 is preserved), a medallion of Constantius and possibly siliquae of Constantine I. The coins had been covered by a fragmented flat silver plate.
The third Chute hoard was found in 1994, in the same field as the 2 previous finds (1927 and 1986). 96 British B staters were found, together with half of a flint nodule.
The hoard comprised an amphora containing 5200 Roman bronze coins including issues of the House of Constantine.

ca. 1496 silver coins found in a metal vessel, S.W. of the village of East Harptree, together with some cast silver ingots and a silver ring set with an intaglio. 15 miliarensis and 1481 siliqua, ranging from Constantine I to Gratian.
31 bronze coins: 1 as, 1 sestertius, denarius, 2 antoniniani, 20 nummi, 7 provincials (Vespasian-Theodosius I) (AD 383-388).
disposition: Museum of History and Archaeology Constanța, Romania (1971)

summary: The hoard comprised a vessel containing approximately 900 Roman coins, of which only 20 were identified. They are antoniniani (radiates) or nummi. The imperial portrait indicates Carus to Constantius I Chlorus.

In 1996 the Manor House Museum, Bury St Edmunds, purchased 6 staters, a quarter stater and a broken silver unit which had been found by Mr R. Nobbs on a site at Little Saxham, between January 1990 and May 1995. An additional stater from the same site, found in 1996, was acquired in November 1997. The 7 staters are likely to have originated in a single deposit, while the silver unit (ANTED(I), 0.47 g) and the quarter stater (Irstead type, ABC 1480, 1.01 g) were some distance away and thus perhaps not associated with the hoard (Talbot and Leins 2010, 12). (de Jersey).
disposition: Manor House Museum, Bury St Edmunds

summary: A hoard of 5 denarii (Vitellius - Lucilla), found while digging peat not far from Nauen. A connection with the hoard of BUCHOW-KARPZOW (ID 17335) has been postulated.
Found during excavations, to the north-east of the antique setttlement; in tomb 1, a cremation burial; 3 coins, Tiberius to Gaius, 3 different types of Divo Augusto; 1 coin burnt
disposition: Service des bâtiments, monuments et archéologie, Martigny/Sion

summary: 4 nummi of the later Tetrarchy and House of Constantine (c. AD 305-37) found at a property on Castle Bailey Street in 1871. No further information is available.

63 silver and gold coins discovered in a burial consisting in 5 imitations of Alexander III, of Alexander staters, 51 Parthian drachms: Artabanus I or II? 2, Sinatruces 1, Phraates III 1; Mithridates III 3; Orodes II 43, Phraates IV 1; 2 drachms of Polemon I of Pontus; a denarius of Augustus; 4 aurei: aureus of Tiberius, aureus of Nero, aureus of Vitellius, and aureus of Vespasian.
The hoard comprised 72 bronze coins dated between 37-4 BC and AD 330-335.
14 Roman bronze coins and 1 autonomous Histrian coin found in a small ceramic vessel: Hellenistic - Hadrian (AD 117-138)
disposition: Coin Room, Institute of Archaeology, Bucharest, Romania

summary: In 1931, 14 bronze coins (Domitian to Antoninus Pius) were found on the surface in front of the southern gate of the Roman fort, which were oxidised together in a clump. Some specimens show exposure to fire.
800 nummi found with a ceramic vessel. Among issuers: Valentinian I, Gratian, Theodosius I and Honorius.
A hoard of 7 gold Iron Age and 28 silver Roman coins found during a metal detecting rally in 2014. The latest Iron Age coins date to c. AD 20-50 and the latest Roman coins are of Tiberius.
From 465 only 60 denari are known: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138). Found in a ceramic vessel.
It comprised 258 antoniniani (radiates) from Elagabalus to Aurelian (AD 270-275).
Among the ruins of an ancient building were discovered 80 coins: 1 antoninianus (radiate), 9 double sestertii, 70 sestertii: Flavians - Victorinus (AD 269-271).
16 Iron Age potin coins, found in the woods at Castle Hill Ruffs, New Addington in 1978 and 1979.
14 silver and bronze coins of unknown denominations: Republic - Antoninus Pius/Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) (AD 145-176).
In the vicus was found a hoard of 161 sestertii: Vespasian - Postumus (AD 267).

96 coins: 10 silver denarii, 1 quinarius, the other 85 coins are copper asses, dupondii and sestertii, and 1 unknown copper denomination. Other finds include 18 wire fibulae, a fragment of a bracelet and 1 unidentified artefact. Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 138-180).
(ca. 600) 569 denarii: Mark Antony - Commodus (AD 180-192)
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. ХХХІІІ - 398 coins

summary: The hoard comprised 64 'bronze' coins from Caracalla to Gallienus. The denominational composition of the hoard is not given. It was found in the South Stoa. In front of shop XX was a strosis covered with a thick layer of burned debris. In this charred stratum, within the storeroom, were found the iron fittings of a m1y box containing the hoard.

In 1844, numerous skeletons were found, buried 1 on top of the other. 1 wearing an iron mail shirt, also possessed 'un coeur en bronze doré', 17 denarii and 4 bronze coins. Like TAF V. 33, the assemblage has been interpreted as representing the savings of a soldier killed in the battle between Septimius Severus and Clodius Albinus in AD 197.
15 aurei and 470 denarii, ranging from the Republican period to Marcus Aurelius, found by a labourer at work in Rudchester grounds, while digging up the foundation of an old fence in 1766.
64 bronze coins, (residual): Siculo-Punic - Valentinian III? (AD 425-455).
370 coins: 12 denarii, 358 provincial bronzes: Marcus Aurelius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
24 silver coins: 3 denarii, 21 antoniniani: Caracalla - Aemilian (AD 253).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2372

summary: The hoard comprised between 1121 and 1123 bronze coins dating to the 4th century AD.
disposition: Kadman Numismatic Pavilion at Muza Eretz Israel Museum Tel Aviv

summary: 19 denarii found by metal detecting: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 241-243).

A hoard of at least 98 antoniniani (the publication is not numbered, but states that the hoard is preserved in its entirety), found by a farmer on the site of ancient Aspledon, on the northern bank of the Copaïs Lake. Acquired by the art historian E. Basserman-Jordan (Munich).
64 solidi: Arcadius - Leo I (AD 457-474). From the text in the Revue Numismatiques there is no information that this hoard was found at Sousse. (Hadrumetum). L. Focher believes it is Sousse.
1456 nummi up to AD 355 and pottery.
Around 1000 gold coins found with crater: 1 solidus of Theodosius I and 2 gold pieces of Honorius and Arcadius are known; gold w8: c. 4450g.
At least 1772 antoniniani (radiates) found with a copper alloy jug: Claudius II - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 287-288).
200 nummi (module AE2) with a horizont of AD 393-395 found in the close vicinity of the villa. Unpublished.
175 denarii: Republic – Hadrian (AD 134-138).
1032 nummi of Constantius II, Gratianus, Valentinianus II, Theodosius I, Magnus Maximus, Arcadius, Honorius were found near the porta principalis dextra of the fort (AD c. 400).
disposition: Museum Lauriacum - Museum der Stadt Enns, Austria

summary: Unknown original number of coins. 15 pieces are known: 14 denarii, 1 dupondius: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Museum of Moravia, Brno, Czech Republic (7 coins); Collection Červinkova (8 coins)

summary: 3 denarii found during excavations in a field near an archaeological site, prior to the construction of a water treatment plant.
9 coins found near a broken m1y-box: 5 antoniniani, 2 denarii, 1 sestertius, 1 unidentified denomination: Septimius Severus/Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
5 burned nummi of the 4th century, 1 issue by Gratian (Siscia, AD 367-375).
disposition: Narodni muzej, Numizmatični cabinet, Ljubljana, Slovenia

summary: 36 sestertii, but only 16 are identified: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-183).
Hoard of 44 coins: Republican denarii 42, Vespasian 1 denarius, Macedonia Prima tetradrachm 1.
disposition: National History Museum of Transylvania, Cluj-Napoca, Romania

summary: 27 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I of which 23 imitations
6 coins of Alexandria: Nero 1, Vespasian 2, Hadrian 2, Lucius Verus 1. No information about site or circumstances.

Metal detector find of a large hoard of Icenian silver coins, along with ceramic sherds and fragments of textile. Subsequently excavated by the Norfolk Archaeological Unit. Further batches were found after this date.
53 denarii found with ceramic vessel: Hadrian - Severus Alexander (AD 223).
A small hoard of 8 (?) gold British Iron Age coins found at Yarmouth, in the Isle of Wight in 1867.
30 aurei and several hundred denarii and antoniniani up to mid-3rd century. The coins were found together with 4 golden rings with gems and a gold ingot.

1 of the largest hoards of Iron Age coins found in Britain. Some 50 coins were recorded by the British Museum, but a much larger part of ca. 5300 coins is thought to have come from the same location. Both parts consisted mostly of Durotrigan base silver coins.
15 nummi: House of Constantine I - House of Theodosius I (AD 388-402). In a glass jar from a destruction layer of a Roman house.
Several hundred Roman coins. "Except for 9 pieces that went to the museum in Sigiriya, the whereabouts of the rest of the hoard are unknown."
Around 1857 a developer found a roll with 80 identical coins (all with she-wolf suckling twins) on Bolongarostraße. Coins were individually sold and can't be traced any more.

Unknown originally number of coins found with a linen or leather bag placed in a bronze vessel. Only 12 antoniniani (radiates) are known: Aurelian - Carus/Carinus (AD 283-285). Probably, part of the hoard VALHASCOS 1880-1890.
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueologia, Lisboa, Portugal

summary: 2211 silver coins: 10 denarii, 2201 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius (Diva FaustinaI) - Valerian I (AD 259); silver w8: 2765.1-5725.2g

1 denarius (Severus Alexander), 2 gold coins (Libius Severus, pseudo-imperial solidus; Julius Nepos, pseudo-imperial tremissis) found at Oxborough, where an Anglo-Saxon cemetery is known. The Libius Severus coin is set in a pendant.
A clipped solidus of Anastasius (AD 491-518) and a solidus of Justinian I (AD 527-538) found in the tomb of rouran princess buried in AD 550.
The hoard comprised a cut half-as of Trajan and 800 antoniniani (radiates), which were mostly imitations from Gallienus to Probus.
Unknown number of aurei and denarii: Gaius - Antoninus Pius (Faustina II) (AD 145-161).

The find comprised 80 bronze coins from Augustus to Constantine I, placed on a copper-alloy dish, along with a variety of vessels and objects interpreted as a carpenter's toolkit. Both coins and objects were placed in a box.

All of the coins are of types produced in the Hampshire-Dorset-Wiltshire area in the late Iron Age. 5 (2012 T82b-f) are uninscribed gold staters of the so-called "Chute/Cheriton Transition" type (ABC 752). These coins date to about 80-60 BC. The 6th coin is an uninscribed silver stater of the "Cranborne Chase" type (ABC 2157); struck a little after the gold coins, in about 60-20 BC. 3 more coins found in 2015 and 2016 (PAS).

A small hoard of 13 Roman imperial denarii: Trajan - Maximin I Thrax (AD 235-238) was discovered in October 2018 in Crimea, probably in its eastern part. Information about the find and a general photo of the coins were published on 21 October 2018 on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity. The finder himself identified the coins as “purse of denarii”. The coins have a very good preservation. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
The hoard (a sanctuary box) comprised c. 38 Celtic and Roman bronze coins, from Augustus to Domitian (AD 81-96).
11 denarii piled together found in a kitchen of the hillfort: Republic - Augustus (15-13 BC).
166 sestertii: Nerva - Postumus (AD 260-269).
A hoard of 61 Roman coins to Hadrian and 616 Iron Age bronze coins found some years ago in Southants. It was contained in an earthenware pot which was broken in the course of the discovery.
disposition: British Museum (part); Hunter Coin Cabinet, Glasgow (part); Red House Museum, Christchurch (part)

summary: Hoard discovered on the surface and during the archaeological investigations: Trajan – Septimius Severus (Clodius Albinus Caesar) (AD 193).
disposition: History Museum, Târgu Neamț (23 coins); History Museum, Piatra Neamț (7 coins); private collections (6 coins)

summary: 21 denarii: Republic - Severus Alexander (AD 233-235).
A hoard of 52 bronze antoniniani (Gallienus - Tetricus) found in the quarry of Weisenau in 1910.

About 1638, 16 (or 8?) gold coins, and ca. 800 silver coins, containing the 'whole history of the Roman Empire, from Julius Caesar till Constantine the Great', found while digging a cellar. The coins are thought to be siliqua and solidi.

Around 100 coins found on a beach. Among them: 1 denarius, 98 antoniniani (radiates), 1 radiate fraction: Severus Alexander - Maximian I (AD 297-298). There were many debates on the original findspot and the number of coins.

4 coins found on 28 August 2003, recorded by de Jersey and listed here. A fifth coin (a quarter stater of Verica, ABC 1208) was discovered about 700 m distant, but is not included here, nor is the the as of Claudius from the PAS list (stray find).

The hoard was found in a broken ceramic vessel and comprised 8 to 9 kilos of coins. Magaud catalogued 2406 coins: 1 denarius, 2405 antoniniani (radiates) and in 1910, the abbot Angot added another 43 coins which Magaud incorporated into the hoard. The hoard was found by a farm labourer in a field: Maximian I Thrax - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver w8: 651.7-5724.2g.
The surviving part of the hoard consists of 613 silver denarii ranging from 157-156 BC to the reign of Claudius (51-52 AD).
disposition: Padua, Soprintendenza per i Beni Archeologici del Veneto

summary: 11 denarii from Lucius Verus to Elagabalus/Severus Alexander (1 denarius of Julia Soaemias is a hybrid with a reverse of Severus Alexander). Found during the excavation of the cathedral apse
Unknown number of silver coins. 42 pieces entered the museum collection in Kardzhali: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Kardzhali, Bulgaria

summary: Preliminary record of a hoard currently consisting of 8 gold Chute staters and 219 silver staters, of the uninscribed south-western types traditionally attributed to the Durotriges.

The hoard comprised approximately 400 bronze coins dating from Seleucid period to the House of Theodosius (AD 379-455). Only 159 of these coins are preserved by the IAA and recorded at the level of the coin.

Coins belonging to 3 different hoards are now kept together in the museum and it is not any more possible to attribute them to the original hoards, which is why FMRD lists all coins together. This list is longer than the original number of coins and therefore also includes some other coins. Patina and conservation are however very similar, so it is likely that these coins were also found in Trier, possibly close to the hoards. The 3 hoards are: 1) Feldstraße (summer 1885). 240 small bronzes, found while installing a canalisation; 2) Pfützenstraße (mid-1886): a hoard of 513+ coins, found during foundation work. 513 were acquired by the museum, the others dispersed. 3) Trier-Euren (autumn 1859): an earthenware vessel containing 1 denarius of Geta and 114 badly preserved small bronzes, found in association with a building that had a mosaic floor. The list given here is the 1 given in FMRD.

About 13 lbs. (c. 5.8 kg) of Roman bronze coins. „Found in 1896 on the little islet of Perumamarakkaladuwa in the Madu Gaoga. Allegedly, the hoard contained gold and silver coins as well but n1 was ever seen. Based on the average w8s of the Roman coins he had examined himself, Still calculated a total of approximately 5800 coins. Bell, the then Archaeological Commissi1r, was able to secure some 250 pieces from this hoard. The list of identifiable coins is based on Still’s examination and description of these pieces.” The coin types are: House of Constantine I: gloria exercitus (1 standard); Constantine I (Divus) (quadriga); vot xx mult xxx; fel temp reparation (falling horseman). House of Theodosius: vot x mult xx; vot x mult xx; vot v; salus reipublicae (victory/captive); virtus exerciti (emperor/victory); concordia augg; urbs roma felix; gloria romanorum (3 emperors).
31 denarii found in a ceramic vessel inside a mound: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

A multilayered Roman st1 wall was unearthed during excavation work for the construction of a public utility on Weberbach Strasse. Shards and 79 bronze coins from the 4th century AD to Theodosius stemmed from the last Roman burnt layer.

The hoard was found in a cave and comprised 60 Roman coin copies as well as numerous fragments of copper-alloy bar with Roman coin flans stamped on them. The hoard was interpreted as belonging to a forger.
Over 600 denarii found while digging up a grave. Only 6 pieces provide information on the issuers: Trajan - Commodus (AD 179-180).
132 nummi: Magnentius - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-395).

Within circular pit 1.22m diameter & 0.68m deep, in corner of Room 11 in 'Northern Group' of villa rooms, there were 3 small, coarse handmade cooking vessels, animal b1s & portions of skulls, with cut marks, iron knives, & 13 coins from Constantine II to Fel. Temp. Rep., with 1 of Tetricus II. Suggest pit filled in after AD 345-361. Pit occupied NW corner of back corridor before gravel floor of vestibule laid over it, in the 'Northern Group' of villa rooms.

The hoard comprised 1094 antoniniani (radiates) including issues of Valerian I, Gallienus, Postumus, Marius, Victorinus, Claudius II, Divus Claudius II, Quintillus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II and Aurelian. Silver w8: 208.4-798.1 g.

The hoard was found in a copper-alloy vessel sealed by a further copper-alloy vessel. It comprised 48 kilos of coins which were sold for 40 francs to an antiquarian. The coins were dispersed without being studied. The earliest report by Augé de Lassus notes coins of silver billon or of bronze (radiates and aureliani) with portraits of Trajan (Divi series?), Valerian, Gallienus, Postumus, Claudius II, Tetricus, Aurelian, Tacitus, Probus, Carus and Carinus. Dubiez notes 'large bronzes' (Folles) of Diocletian, Maximian Herculeus and Galerius?, Constantius Chlorus, Constantine II and Maxentius. The hoard was found by M. Révillon while working in a vineyard.
726 denarii: Nero - Commodus (AD 187-192).
1500-1700 nummi probably held in a textile container as some fibers survived. 612 coins have been studied so far: Gallienus - Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
disposition: Museu Municipal Abade Pedrosa, Santo Tirso, Portugal

summary: Found in the garden of 1 of the villagers. Consisted of denarii (quantity unknown), which were in a pot. The coins were taken by villagers. V. Lyaskoronsky in 1926 saw only 2 denarii from this hoard (Antoninus Pius and Marcus Aurelius). In 1964, L. Pobal examined the probable place of the find, but did not find additional information about the hoard.
5 denarii, with no certainty whether they were found together.
