2 solidi: Theodosius II, Zeno (AD 476-491). With a frame of twisted gold- thread in a loop, ornamented by filigree-work.
116 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251). The issues are from the mints from Moesia and Thracia, mainly Marcianopolis, Nicopolis ad Istrum and Viminacium

The hoard comprised 9 gold coins: 1 multiple of 6 1/2 aurei, 8 aurei: Trajan (Plotina) - Florian (AD 276). Together were found jewelry: small gold male bust, 3 old bracelets, 3 gold armillae, rolled gold band, jet (or black glass paste) bracelet, black material bracelet, 6 small jet (or black glass paste) pieces, bronze pin.
15 sestertii: Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
The hoard was found 50 metres from a Gallo-Roman villa during excavation and comprised 40 coins including sestertii, denarii and radiates from Hadrian to Philip I.
36 denarii found in the military amphitheater: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166).
disposition: Museum Carnuntinum, Bad-Deutsch Altenburg, Austria (29 coins); 7 coins lost

summary: 2329 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 289-290) found in a jar, buried beneath the doorway between a room and the courtyard, during excavations of a house.
The hoard comprised 86 denarii from Mark Antony to Antoninus Pius (AD 143).
2 silver units found "on top of each other" at a depth of 15 - 20 cm.
39 bronze coins of Alexandria: Ptolemy I - Augustus (13 BC). Found during excavations in the sand near the Nile.
19 nummi found in a storage room in east of the Neon Library: House of Valentinian - House of Theodosius I (AD 388-402).
13 antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus and Claudius II part of a larger hoard?
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueologia, Lisboa, Portugal

summary: 487 silver coins: 227 denarii, 260 antoniniani (radiates): Balbinus - Philip I (AD 244-249). No further details.
Hoard of 279 silver coins from the Republic to Domitian, was found together with silver objects by a local man on his field.
disposition: National Museum in Belgrade [76 coins]; National Museum in Požarevac [203 coins - since stolen]

summary: The hoard comprised 4 tetradrachms, at least 20 denarii, and "a large number of bronze" coins of the Bar Kokhba Revolt (AD 132-135/136).

A hoard of Iron Age coins and 2 as of Claudius I, found while digging gravel. Evans lists 107 silver units of the Iceni, consisting of 29 uninscribed and 78 inscribed, plus 2 asses (originally classified as dupondii) of Claudius (AD 41-4). 53 Icenian coins from the hoard can still be identified today.

25 coins of AD 260-290 from Poverest Road West site, thought by R. Reece to be a scattered hoard. Majority (21) found scattered on surface of an upper metalling deposit (Feature 8), other 4 were from deposits above metalling & may have been derived from it. Some tile frags. among st1s of metalled surface, & RB pottery, a bronze stud, iron nails & 2 glass beads.Philp, B. and Keller, P. 1995. The Roman Site at Fordcroft, Orpington. West Wickham: Kent Archaeological Rescue Unit, pp. 15, 28-29.
160-180 denarii found in a ceramic vessel - metal detecting - within an ancient settlement. The coins are dated to the 1st-2nd centuries AD.
4000-4500 antoniniani found in a cooking pot. 1501 pieces are presented here combining the evidences of Brunšmid from the year 1880 and the FMRSl I: Gallienus - Carinus (AD 283-284)
disposition: Narodni muzej Ljubljana, Slovenia (few coins); Kunsthistorischen Museums, Wien, Austria (coins of Claudius II); Collection Markl (coins of Tacitus); Collection Kolb. (coins of Florian); Archaeological Museum, Zagreb, Croatia; dispersed

summary: Approximately 800 antoniniani (radiates) were recovered of which 750 were recorded: Valerian I and Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
disposition: Museu de Arqueologia e Numismática de Vila Real, Portugal

summary: IARCH record for 5 silver Iron Age units found during the course of archaeological excavation by Suffolk County Council in 2010.

In 1960, a farmer found 36 Republican denarii while working in a field. In 1962, his plough hit and broke an already damaged ceramic vessel containing 424 denarii which were studied by Giard. A later article by Gambier gave details of a further 12 denarii (8 of which were not seen by Giard and 4 which were found later). A farmer, F. Joyeux found 36 Republican denarii in a field, close to the hamlet of Grande Bernegoue, approximately 80 metres from the marshland. 2 years later, his ploughshare broke an already damaged pottery vessel from which the coins came. The hoard was acquired by the Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliothéque Nationale (Inventory no. 1981-347 = 453 coins of which 424 were studied by Giard with an extra 29 examples).
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliothéque Nationale, Paris, France

summary: The original find comprised 5578 coins, of which only 2330, including 7 ancient forgeries, were recovered by the authorities. These can divided into 2 lots; first, 1067 denarii from Vespasian to Macrinus/Elagabalus (217/22), second, 1263 antoniniani from Severus Alexander to Gallienus (260/8).
1175 billon tetradrachms: Claudius I - Vespasian (AD 69-79). From excavations by the Egypt Exploration Society.
(300) 194 Ant: Gordian III - Valerianus I or Gallienus (sole reign ?) Gordian III 52
Over 20 denarii. No further information.
About 200 silver and bronze coins.
4 nummi of Constans. No further information.
(2000) 27 nummi: Constantius II, Constans, Vetranio (AD 350).
disposition: Magyar Nemzeti Múzeum, Budapest (28 coins), in 1904

summary: The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing approximately 400 Roman sestertii from Nerva or Trajan to Postumus. 77 coins were examined.

Circa 450 bronze coins were found under an old tree. The majority of coins belonging to the emperors of the latest quarter of the 4th century AD and are AE2 denominations. 5 earlier and late Chers1sus issues, 5 provincial coins and 1 nummus of Galerius were also among the coins.
38 nummi found burned and solded. 3 nummi seem to belong to Constantine I, 1 of them possible of Constantine II (Caesar).

4th century. Coins 80, 83 & 84 - 3 coins found in small pit/posthole [148] outside doorway of House 1. No other finds from feature, & coins may have been deposited after removal of a post (pp. 360). These coins were approx. 20 years later in date than those used in house infill.
22 asses: Augustus - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161) .
15 Republican denarii found in regio VI, insula 11, under the floor of the living room of building 18 (house)
The hoard comprised a few tetradrachms and approximately 50 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).

The hoard comprised 2 Samian ware vessels containing 3 aurei and 250 denarii and quinarii from Nero to Septimius Severus for Geta. The coins were collected together and sold by the Arras antiquarian Algave.
16 denarii: Republic - Augustus (2 BC - AD 4). Part of the hoard ONNA 1884 (CHRE 9983)?
5 aurei (Nero - Domitian) found during the excavation of the legionary fortress in Caerleon. The aureus of Titus has M engraved on obv.
The hoard comprised 5 drachms of Trajan minted in Bostra (AD 113).

475 silver coins: 1 Celtic drahm, 1 provincial drachm, 3 republican denarii, 470 imperial, found in the river near the former Postumius Bridge pillar. It was presumed that the coins may have been kept in a chest/box: Celtic - Gordian III (AD 240).
disposition: Musei Civici di Castelvecchio di Verona, Italy

summary: Over 200 silver coins from Vespasian to Hadrian (Ad 117-138). No detailed information.

A small group of coins found over a period of years, reportedly in the same field. A stater of Tincomarus was found at Faringdon in September 1874 and it is not impossible that it came from the same location.
Hoard of circa 350 coins. 285 were seen: 284 antoniniani (radiates), 1 aureus: Claudius II - Diocletian (AD 284-294); gold w8: 5.34g; Silver: 284 coins; silver w8: 51.2-90.8 g.
444 silver coins found with a bronze vessel: Domitian - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253). Together were found 2 silver spoons
1545 coins: 1 denarius, 1544 antoniniani (radiates): Trajan - Tetricus I (AD 271-273).
45 nummi: Diocletian - Theodosius II (AD 408-423).

142 coins were recovered from an area of approximately 2 square metres during a metal detecting rally in early September 2004. 2 other coins were found "a few yards" away (TAR 2004, 169 no. 418). The 144 coins declared included 2 Roman bronzes of the third century AD which were regarded as unassociated with the hoard. In addition to the coins, 2 copper alloy fragments, an iron object, 3 flints and 23 pottery sherds were reported. The pottery included 3 handmade Iron Age sherds, black burnished ware and the base of a Roman colour coat vessel; n1 of these sherds had any signs of contact with coinage, and n1 of them joined, suggesting that n1 of them had formed the hoard container.
The hoard comprised 438 (or only 380) sestertii found in a black coarse ceramic vessel: Augustus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).

The hoard was found in a vessel in a villa (?). The vessel contained about 200 nummi from Constantine II to Valens, as well as 2 radiates of Trajan Decius and Gallienus and a larger bronze of Constantine I.
33 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus to Aurelianus (AD 270-275).
disposition: Museo Arch. Reg. "P. Orsi", Siracusa, Italy

summary: About 70 provincial bronze coins minted in Marcianopolis, Nicopolis ad Istrum and Philippopolis. No further information.
The hoard comprised an unknown number of coins of which 24 denarii, including 11 Republican issues and 13 imperial issues from Vitellius to Antoninus Pius were recorded.

The hoard comprised 1953 bronze coins in a broken cooking pot was unearthed adjacent to the northwestern entrance of the synagogue, in the western corridor (Bijovsky 1998, 77). The very poor state of conservation has allowed only 380 coins to be documented. The range: 103-76 BC to AD
The hoard comprised several hundred coins (mostly Constantinian nummi) of which only 6 were recorded in any detail. It was found in rubble associated with a large and rich Gallo-Roman villa.
A case of folded copper sheets was unearthed at a rustic villa while building barracks in 1937. It contained 12 coins (Crispina - Magnus Maximus).

The hoard was 1 of 2 Iron Age hoards found in La Châtaigneraie around 1901. It is difficult to establish which coins belonged to which find. M. Roy of La Rochelle acquired nearly all the coins of 1 hoard, amounting to 43 coins. Only 1 was gold. Vallette notes a find of 30 Iron Age electrum coins found in the 'ancient rocks of Moulins.' Does this statement related to the first or second find? The hoard was found during quarrying.
5 aurei found in grave no. 6: Nero, Galba, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Commodus (AD 180-192). Together were found 11 drachms of Gotarze and 3 denarii of Augustus.
The hoard comprised 100 Continental Iron Age silver coins.
370 Roman provincial bronze coins of the 3rd century AD. No further infiormation.
276 denarii including 1 imitation: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
3 denarii: C. Cornelius Blasio, Gargonius/Ogulnius/Vergilius and Vespasian, found near the protestant cemetery. Uncertain whether the coins were found together.
disposition: National History Museum of Transylvania, Cluj-Napoca (inv. nos. 63–1906)

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 40 tetradrachms and 150 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
250 coins: 2 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate), 247 sestertii: Vespasian - Caracalla (AD 213-217); silver w8: 7.4-8.5 g.
Iron Age coin hoard consisting of 2 gold staters. Both are Norfolk wolf staters, so-called JB types with a left facing wolf.
119 nummi of the Tetrarchy (AD 307). Part of the Seltz hoard.
76 denarii: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 134-138).
disposition: Collection Baron of Senzeilles (76 coins), in 1890

summary: The hoard comprised a vessel containing 94 bronze coins, of which 82 were examined. They included 2 sestertii and 80 double sestertii of Postumus, mostly LAETITIA AVG, VICTORIA AVG and FIDES MILITVM reverse types. Tpq AD 266-267
Bizeul described 5 antoniniani (radiates) found in Quénet which may be part of a larger hoard or perhaps the con10ts of a purse.
172 nummi (Tetrarchy to Licinius I, AD 316/7) found in a bronze vessel in the courtyard just in front of a door during excavations of a house.
(200+) 103 silver coins: 78 denarii, 25 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 246)
21 antoniniani: Valerian I - Gallienus (AD 2659-268). Found in a ceramic jug with 1 handle.
disposition: National Bank of Romania, Numismatic Collection, Bucharest

summary: 6 coins found grouped on the chest area of an inhumation in the Butt Road Roman cemetery in Colchester (Grave 431, C1653). The coins are 3 Fel Temp FH copies and 3 Magnentian copies. Thought not to have been in a container due to pattern of scatter.
64 denarii from Vespasian to Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

The hoard was found in a Gallo-Roman cemetery scattered over an area of some metres and comprised an unknown number of coins. 43 were recovered by private individuals and recorded by FMRL: Valetian I and Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).
9 kg of silver and billon coins of the 3rd century AD. 2504 coins have been noticed: Caracalla - Postumus (AD 268).
(200) 17 sestertii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 11-180).
Unknown quantity of bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel. Dr. Harlanov saw 1 sestertius of Antoninus Pius and a provincial bronze coin of Caracalla minted in Marcianopolis.
42 denarii: Otho – Septimius Severus/Caracalla (AD 193-217).
disposition: Coin Room, Library of the Romanian Academy, Bucharest, Romania (inv.no. 1198)

summary: The hoard probably comprised more than 889 late Roman bronze coins: Probus - Honorius (276-395 AD).
disposition: Sala Consiliare di Brendola; Soprintendenza Archeologica del Veneto, Padova; Museo Civico G.Zannato, Montecchio Maggiore; private collection

summary: Grave 1012 contained an adult female skeleton, buried with 2 bracelets and 10 mid-4th-century coins dated between A.D. 337 and 364, possibly a purse group.

The total number of coins originally found is unknown. There are 2 catalogues which slightly vary in the numbers of coins present. The 1 in May 1968 is entered here: Claudius II (Divus) - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
It is alleged that more than 3 kg of coins were found. 34 denarii: Galba - Elagabalus (AD 218-222); silver w8: 67.2-111.4 g.

In 1958 a man discovered a Roman well during the construction of a telecommunications office between Cäcilienstraße and Sternengasse. The well was filled with building and fire debris; therein lay 22 coins.
A hoard of solidi menti1d in a private letter by Mr. Thurston: Theodosius II - Justin I.
The hoard comprised a terracotta vessel (broken before discovery) containing between 1600 and 1700 poorly preserved bronze coins of Probus, Maximian I and Constantine I.
610 nummi considered as 'residual coins': Claudius I - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
136 denarii: 100 republican, 36 imperial: Republic - Trajan (AD 98). Hoard under study.
The hoard comprised more than 60 late Roman bronze coins: Constantine I - Constantius II (AD 352-354). Only 8 coins are recorded.
c. 1200 silver coins: 1 denarius and antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - Postumus (AD 260-269).
32 Roman imperial coins: at least 1 antoninianus (radiate): Augustus - Maximian I (AD 286-310). Some doubts have been expressed about this discovery!

In 1979 Philip Kinns saw in the Herakleion Museum a coin from the ΜΥΩΝΙΔΗΣ+tripod issue of Rhodes (43/42 BC until some time during the reign of Augustus) which had apparently been found at Axos with a coin of Augustus or Caligula.

A hoard of 87 coins of the mid-4th century was found near West Wycombe. The pieces were scattered in a field, but they almost certainly belong to a single find. Most of the pieces were in very poor condition with the result that although the reverse types could be identified in most instance, some of the obverses and many of the mint marks were either illegible or only partly legible. All of the coins except 1 (an imitation of a VICTORIAE DD AVGGQ NN type of AD 347-8) either were minted after the reform in 348 and before 353 or copied official types of these years.

HER: Cemetery, in a cottage garden about 120 yds north of the line of the north wall (of Wroxeter). In 1862 a single interment was found here, with traces of others. It consisted of a pit 6 feet square & 3 ft deep, lined with clay 12ins to 16ins thick, baked or fired hard. Contained a large ceramic urn full of b1s, on 2 flat tiles cemented together with 2 AE of Trajan in mortar. A coin of Hadrian was also found.
The hoard comprised a coarseware vessel filled with 250 (or 1250) large Roman bronzes. It is likely that these coins were sestertii, or possibly nummi (folles).
18 nummi of Valentinian I and 2 crossbow bronze brooches were found together in a courtyard (AD 364-375).
(102) 101 silver coins: 24 denarii, 65 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius (Faustina I) - Valerian I (AD 253-259); silver w8: 131.2-264.8 g.
8 Roman coins found in a wooden square well: 5 sestertii, 3 dupondii from: Trajan, Hadrian, Aelius Caesar, Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius, Septimius Severus.
1 dupondius and 6 asses (Vespasian to Trajan) discovered beneath the concrete bedding for the flagst1s at the south-eastern end of the basilica.
700 antoniniani (radiates) of Claudius II, Aurelian, Severina, Tacitus, Probus, Carus, Numerian, Nigrinianus (AD 283-285).

The hoard comprised 'quite a considerable number of gold coins' of which only 2 were seen and identified. The hoard was found by a farmer. Only 3 aurei: 1 Augustus, 2 Tiberius have been seen and described.

A hoard of 11 coins (denarii and bronze coins ranging from Hadrian to Alexander Severus) was found in 1965 in a walled Roman st1 cellar, west of the Jewish cemetery. It lay concealed without a container under the threshold to the cellar.
(150) 102 bronze coins: 1 imperial, 149 provincial coins: Commodus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.no. 866 (102 coins)

summary: 22 nummi with a tpq post AD 375.

HER report of a hoard found in 1976 and sold in trade, reported by a dealer in 2002. "The hoard was examined by Malcolm Lyne who produced a report. 48 dupondii and sestertii were identified. They had been found in a truncated Rowlands Castle grey ware jar dating from the third century. [The dealer] believed that the sestertii and dupondii had been accompanied by an uncertain number of antonianii of Galienus, Victorinus, Claudius II, Tetricus I and II and Quintillus. These had been retained by the landowner".
The hoard comprised a copper-alloy vessel containing approximately 1440 denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Of this total, 1424 were catalogued by Chanel. Silver: 1358 coins; Silver w8: 246.9-3528.5g
91 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 18

summary: "About 100 tetradrachms and denarii together with a few dozen Roman coins (the latest being a fresh Hadrianic denarius...)" (Mildenberg 1984, 55).
Hoard of unknown original number of coins found with a ceramic jug. 96 denarii: Trajan - Clodius Albinus (AD 193).
disposition: Museum of History, Kyiv, Russia (50 coins; inv.nos. AR/9256-9304); Local History Museum, Chernovitsy, Ukraine (46 coins)

summary: The assemblage comprised 20 'small bronzes' (Tacitus and Probus) assumed to be antoniniani (radiates) dating to the end of the third century AD. Blanchet considered the find to be a small hoard. TAF suggests it might be a purse hoard. The hoard was found during demolition of an old building.
872 antoniniani: Elagabalus - Valerian I (AD 253-259); silver w8: 632.6-2244.5g
248 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani: Vespasian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 14

summary: 2596 denarii (among: 1 plated, 47 'barbarous'): Republic - Caracalla (AD 214).
An uncertain number of coins. Only 2 denarii of Caracalla were identified.
The circumstances of discovery are unknown, but may partially or totally be the result of excavation.
disposition: Musée Saint-Jean d'Angers, 5th Register of entries, p. 188, no. 1088 (=12535)

summary: 651 denarii and antoniniani, ranging from M. Antony to Philip I, found in a Roman cellar south-west of the Roman fort.
212 coins were preserved. They comprise radiates, Reform radiates of Aurelian and 3 denarii of Severina
disposition: Museu da Região Flaviense, Chaves, Portugal

summary: 30 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani. 12 pieces were recovered: 5 antoniniani, 7 denarii: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver w8: 39.0-70.0 g.
2 aurei Vespasian and Titus (AD 79-81) together with gold jewelry: 2 necklaces, 1 pair of earrings and a "Mercury".
disposition: Museum of Vienne, France, since 1946 (only jewelry)

summary: 6.7 kg of antoniniani, of which 2125 pieces entered the museums in Sofia and Vidin: Gallienus - Diocletian (AD 284-293).
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. no. 1079 (1990 coins); National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 8130-8264; 8679-8696 (153 coins)

summary: 282 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 222 coins were recovered: Vitellius – Septimius Severus (AD 195).
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest (182 coins); Institute of Archaeology ”Vasile Pârvan”, Bucharest (40 coins)

summary: 45 nummi (AD 320-33) found on Twyn Bwmbegan in 1997.
The hoard comprised approximately 300 radiates of which 64 survive.
130 nummi found with the remains of a leather bag. 74 coins are kept in the Vorarlberg Museum in Bregenz: Constans - Constantius II (AD 352-354).
The hoard comprised 32 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I and Gallienus to Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
(700) 170 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani: Trajan - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-268).
21 nummi minted in Thessalonica in AD 319 except for 1 brockage specimen, possibly struck in Ticinum/Aquileia in the early 20s of the 4th century.
8 denarii found on a field: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 161-180).

The coins were found in 1938/39 during excavation works on the west wall in the region of Geilenkirchen-Linnich (Kreis Jülich). 14 of the coins were lost. The remaining 21 1s are sestertii, ranging from Trajan to Commodus. All are very worn.
Over 2891 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Claudius II - Diocletian-Maximian (AD 287-288) found in an amphora beneath the floor, during excavations of a house.

A hoard of 103 Roman imperial denarii: Otho – Caracalla (AD 211-217) was discovered by 2 treasure hunters in the mid-October 2009 in the Kyiv region. The first report about the hoard was published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity on October 26, 2009, and on October 29, November 2 and 23 photos of the coins were published. According to 1 of the finders, initially, not far from the unexcavated earlier pits from other treasure hunters, 71 coins were found on an area of 5x5 meters with a depth of 15-20 cm. At a later time, on the findspot was made sondage and the next 19 coins were found, and later – a further 13. The coins were cleaned by finders. The preservation of the coins is mostly good to very good. The further fate of the coins is unknown.

The hoard comprised 65 sestertii from Domitian to Commodus (AD 180-192). All the coins were very worn. Fragments of a ceramic vessel were found in association with the coins suggesting it was originally placed inside a pot.
5 denarii, from the reigns of Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, and Commodus, discovered in a garden in Berlin-Lichterfelde in 1919.
A hoard of 11 solidi (Constantius II to Arcadius) found in North Saqqarah, in a cache under a wall of 1 of the Christian houses north of the sanctuary.
562 coins, mostly denarii, 1 aureus (Galba) and some antoninianii, ranging from the late Republic to Severus Alexander, found in Baden-Baden, auf dem Quettich. No further informations given in FMRD.
A hoard of 34 solidi (AD 364-403), found by a farmer in the foundation of his house during demolition work. These foundations were not Roman, which means that the hoard was found twice.

2 staters found about 60 m apart, at a depth of c.8 cm, in March 2000. Approximately 30 late Roman bronzes, and first or second century AD brooches, were also reported from the site. Not certainly a hoard.
At least 13 denarii found on a field: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 196-211).
disposition: Museum of Cultural History Stralsund, Germany (5 coins); Münzkabinett Berlin, Germany (2 coins); Museum Szczecin, Poland (until 1944)

summary: 2 denarii of Hadrian (AD 134-138).
7 coins: 1 denarius, 6 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Quintillus (AD 270). The denarius is unidentified.
The hoard comprised an 'unknown number of sestertii and 12 silver coins of Gordian III': Nerva - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
Originally 3 denarii (Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, imitation) found within an Iron Age settlement together iron, earthenware, b1 artefacts.

Roll of 12 silver coins, dating to the Roman Republic and Augustus, found during excavations. Roman Republic: 1 half victoriatus, 6 denarii and 2 quinarii; Augustus: 2 denarii and 1 quinarius. The total sum equals 150 asses.
5 nummi found while digging in the ground: Constantine I 4, Constantine II (Caesar) 1 (AD 306-337).
328 nummi of the House of Constantine I (mid. 4th century AD).
Circa 585 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III to Postumus (AD 260-269); silver w8: 176.4-730.3g.
Unknown number of silver coins. 42 pieces are kept in the Regional History Museum in Ruse: Caracalla - Gordian III (AD 243-244).
disposition: Ruse Regional Museum of History, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1600 1-43

summary: A hoard of 29 silver coins, found fused together during the excavations of Dura Europos, in the street west of the 'Cistern House,' against the wall of the house at the floor level of the big room to the south of the central court of that house. It consisted 4 distinct groups of coins: 15 posthumous Philip Philadelphus tetradrachms (45 – 20 BC), 7 tetradrachms of Antioch (5 Nero, 1 Galba and 1 Titus), 6 imperial denarii (Trajan - Commodus), and 1 radiate (Valerian). The radiate of Valerian might be a posterior addition to the other coins.
6 denarii: Caesar - Domitianus (AD 81).
The hoard comprised between 400 and 500 sestertii from Trajan to Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238). 92 were acquired by the City Museum of Nevers.
A group of 19 siliquae coming from a private collection, possible found in Trier: Constantine III - Iovinus (AD 411-413).
The hoard comprised 391 bronze coins from Hadrian to Trajan Decius. The denominational composition of the hoard was not further described.
22 antoniniani were discovered during archaeological excavations in 1 room: Trajan Decius - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
Around 400 denarii of the 1st-2nd centuries AD. 153 provided information on the issuers: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Tsarist Archaeological Comission, St. Petersburg, Russia (153 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised an unknow number of aurei, at least 12(?), from Vespasian to Hadrian (AD 136).
The hoard comprised 19 antoniniani (radiates) dated between AD 255-257 and AD 271-272.
40 sestertii discovered at 1.40 m depth. Among them 2 of Commodus and 7 or 8 of Postumus (AD 260-268?). No further information.
46 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169).
The hoard comprised 2 aurei, more than 400 denarii and some bronze coins and was found in association with a grave: Vespasian Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
200 nummi of Constantine's I family. Only 17 pieces are known (AD 354-358).
1 Iron Age gold stater and 37 denarii to 47. The gold stater was found about 7.5m from the main scatter of coins but in the same field
Originally, around 50 denarii. Only 10 are recorded: Republic - Tiberius (AD 14-37).
200 antoniniani and nummi. Only 3 coins of Valerian I for Gallienus, Licinius I and Valentinian II were noticed.

The excavation of the well was concluded in 1966. It was 99ft deep and its diameter below the weathering c1 average 9ft to within 6ft of the bottom. 2 radiate coins of late 3rd C. and iron fittings of several buckets found within bottom 6 ft thick silts, along with large group of late 3rd and early 4th C. ceramics, at approx. 95 ft depth. In layer between 81ft and 85ft were masses of broken Huntcliff vessels & 3 Valentinianic coins - matching sherds of pot throughout this dump imply it was a single event.The coins, by P. Curnow in I.M. Stead ed. 1980 p.128.
67 antoniniani (radiates): 57 Gallienus (sole), 10 Salonina (AD 260-268).
disposition: Civiche Raccolte Numismatiche di Milano, Italy (inv.nos. M 999.08.1-M 999.08.67)

summary: 2 coins: 1 bronze Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II/ Diva Faustina II), 1 antoninianus (radiate) Claudius II (AD 268-270)
Hallaton: 14 hoards were located in and around the entrance way. Hoard 03 comprises 141 coins: Iron Age, Roman Republican and Roman Imperial.
Aurei found in a Germanic princess grave. 3 of the coins, pierced, where part of a necklace: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius(2). 1 in the mouth: Gallienus. Rich funerary inventory.
disposition: Museum für Ur- und Frühgeschichte Thüringens, Weimar, Germany (inv. nos. 16-19)

summary: 100 provincial bronze coins entered the museum collection in Shumen: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 13604/1-100 (100 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised a whiteware vessel containing approximately 2000 'small bronzes.' These are considered to have been antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Postumus). The latest coins (E332334 and 336) were struck in Cologne in AD 263. Archives of Musée des Antiquités de Rouen: Inventory III, p. 78, no. 2316 (12.06.1912)
About 5000 denarii: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

1091 coins placed in a cloth and a ceramic vessel: aureus, denarii, antoniniani (radiates), imitations: Septimius Severus to Diocletian/Maximian I (tpq. AD 297); silver w8: 204.0-2827.6 g. Together were found 3 silver rings.
The hoard comprised a small iron safe containing 2 aureii and a variety of jewellery.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen, France

summary: 10 coins found in the bottom of a bowl in locus 29.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing several thousand (more than 4000?) coins from Septimius Severus to Postumus 'all in silver, with varying titles'. A list of numbers of types (rather than numbers of coins) exists. The coins were discovered 'by chance' in ancient ruins at the site. Silver: 4000+ (480) coins; Silver w8: 921.7-10397.2+
disposition: Musée d'Orbigny (20 coins), France; Musée de Guéret, France

summary: 3 solidi (Gratian, Theodosius I and Valentinian II), found in July 2005.
(Unknown initial number of coins, 5.76 kg): 367 denarii: Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192).
21 coins discovered within the ruins of a Roman settlement. 11 pieces in the museum of Targovishte: Gordian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
16 bronze coins found in a destruction layer scattered on a very small area: Claudius I - Gordian III (AD 241-244).

12 coins, presented to Gunnersbury Museum by a Major Salter, were said to have been found "wrapped in sacking" in Gunnersbury Lane. The sacking was not preserved and the coins were subsequently stolen.
2 solidi: Leo I, Zeno (AD 462-466); gold w8: 8.81 g.
It comprised 210 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel, notably from Hadrian, Antoninus Pius and 1 of the Faustinas.

Before 1889, 2 aurei of Tiberius and 1 of Claudius were found. It is not clear whether they were found together. The coins were acquired by the Musée Saint-Jean, Angers (Reg. IV, p. 144, nos. 565-566, 5.02.1889)

In 2010 archaeological excavation of the northern part of Tyritake city-site (site XXVIII) a boxlike altar made of limest1 tiles was found in Room I. Altar clearing uncovered 2 golden staters of Bosporus kings Eupator and Sauromates II, which are most likely to have been offerings to Dionysus. Sauromates II’s stater suggests dating offerings to Dionysus to AD 179 or a little later.
96 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269).

The hoard comprised a grey ware vessel containing 9065 small bronzes, weighing 25kg. The coins included issues of Gallienus, Salonina, Claudius II, Quintillus, Aurelian, Postumus, Victorinus, Tetricus I. Several months later, the same finder discovered a second vessel filled with approximately 4000 coins. According to Etoc-Demazy, 4/5ths of the first hoard was acquired by the Musée du Mans. In 1981, a lot of 181 coins was sold at the Hotel Drouot which may have been part of the second hoard.
Only 303 antoniniani (radiates) are identified. The exact findspot is not known, but it is possible that it comes from Oudenburg, Gistel or Torhout: Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269).
Unknown originally number of denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 63 coins were recovered, 62 denarii, 1 drachm: Vitellius – Marcus Aurelius (AD 162-163).
Unknown originally number of coins. 20 denarii are kept in the Town museum of Târgoviște: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 148-149).

In approximately 1834, Benjamin Bréchard de Fon10ay acquired 100 radiate copies of Tetricus I in mint condition along with some pieces of Constantine I and Constans, found in Château-d'Olonne. Are the coins of Constantine I and Costans part of the same hoard?

Hoard recovered during archaeological excavations at the site of Catcote undertaken by Tees Archaeology. Originally, 18 coins were reported from the hoard, but post-excavation review of the document uncovered 3 additional coins from the same context. 21 nummi to AD 348.
The hoard was found in the aqueduct supplying Lugdunum. 252 coins: 1 republican denarius, 251 nummi: Republic, House of Constantine I - House of Valentinian I (AD 364-375).

The hoard was found during the excavation of the fill of a Roman well in a previously unknown area of the vicus and comprised 54 radiates from Gallienus (sole reign) to Tetricus II with a tpq of AD 274. The coins were interpreted as the con10ts of a purse.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée National d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg, Luxembourg; inv.no. 1990ss-100/10

summary: 1 solidus of Valentinian I, found in 1838, certainly associated with 4 nordic bracteates (6th c.), found in 1858. All were found close to Landegge, on the edge of the sand dune 10ge in the moor.
Hoard of 134-200 denarii: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211). No further details.

The hoard comprise a pot of at least 2721 coins, found while unrooting a tree. The hoard contained also a silver ring with a engraved gem setting. Coins range from Gordian III to Carinus. Of the 2555 coins known to Vischer, 5 (Gordian III, Gallienus (2), Severina, Aurelian) are denarii, the others are radiates.
disposition: Archäologie Baselland; Historisches Museum Basel; Solothurn

summary: In 1981, 245 coins spread over an area of about 60 yards by 30 yards were discovered. The hoard consisted of siliquae which were almost entirely clipped, and as such can be dated to about 410. There is considerable evidence of Roman activity on the Downs but no habitation sites have been positively identified in the vicinity of the hoard. A further 36 siliquae have been found in addition to the original 245. The new coins cover the same span, and are as heavily clipped.
19 gold medallions, a gold chain with 52 pendant amulets, 24 gold foil rings, a disk-shaped pendant, a ring, the fragment of a bracelet, and a pendant in the shape of a human figure.
disposition: Kunsthistorisches Museum, Vienna, Austria; Hungarian National Museum, Budapest

summary: 250 denarii (3 imitations) found with a ceramic vessel. 215 coins were studied: Republic – Augustus (19 BC).
disposition: Coin Room, Library of the Romanian Academy, Bucharest, Romania (photos)

summary: Few hundreds coins found with a large ceramic vessel and wonderful jewelry. 53 coins were studied: Trajan - Gordian III (AD 239-241); silver w8: 75.8-153.3 g.
disposition: Museum of Oltenia, Craiova, Romania (53 coins).

summary: 645 Alexandrian tetradrachms: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166-167) purchased by Currelly and Frost from "native diggers".

The hoard comprised a metal vessel containing 43 Roman coins, including 4 bronzes and 39 denarii and radiates from Trajan to Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole)(Gallienus) (AD 253-268). The hoard, missing 10 coins, is in the collections of the Musée de Rouen. The silver mirror and vessel are lost. In the Hoard file in the Archives of the Musée des Antiquités is a handwrit10 note without a date (April 1912) listing 38 coins.

The hoard and its context are discussed in detail by Edwards and Dennis; a summary of the find is in TAR 1997-98. Most of the hoard was recovered in August 1998, with the exception of 1 stater of Cunobelin found during a subsequent archaeological excavation (December 1998). (PAS).

Approximately 10000 coins. Information on only 925 pieces, billon Alexandrian. Portion of a hoard in the possession of Louis T. Dilauro, June, 1979. Some 400 additional pieces were said to have been culled at random, and the original size of the whole is said to have been in the range of 10000 pieces.
disposition: Louis T. Dilauro (June, 1979, part of the hoard); 3 in New York, the rest in trade. Detailed list in New York (William E. Metcalf).

summary: 12 denarii: Marcus Aurelius - Septimius Severus (AD 201).
14 Iron Age silver coins found over a period of several years
The hoard comprised approximately 200 'small Roman bronzes' of the Anto9 period, most of which were well preserved. Unfortunately, an acid bath rendered them indecipherable.
21 silver coins: 9 denarii, 12 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus (Geta Caesar) - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: County Museum of History and Art, Zalău, Romania (inv.no. CC 256/00)

summary: The hoard was found in a coarseware vessel and comprised 114 antoniniani (radiates). TAF comments that the presence of the coin of Magnia Urbica is very unusual. It questions whether this coin was added to the hoard after its discovery or whether the hoard was only part of a larger assemblage. The hoard was found in a hole surround by a large amount of masonry (possibly ancient) during the demolition of a 15th century building: . Silver: 113 coins; Silver w8: 31.5-140.3g.
See hoard IARCH-4FC580 for details of the find. This record has been created for the coins from pot 2.

Unnown number of Roman coins found duing the construction clay station. Among them: Antoninus Pius/Marcus Aurelius dupondius, Marcus Aurelius sestertius, Gordian III dupondius, Philip I (Otacilia Severa) sestertius, Gallienus (Salonina) antoninianus (radiate).

Found in the necropolis of Hawara during the excavations of W.M. Flinders Petrie in 1888 and first published in 1938. 1120 late Roman coins, 4 casts imitations and 2 lead disks. All except 2 coins, were halved or even quartered. The 2 coins that were not halved are: an imitation of type Copy G and a barbarous SALVS.
6 tetradrachms of Alexandria found in a grave ranging from Probus to Constantine I.
25 denarii, ranging from Vespasian to Septimius Severus, found together in a lump, on the site of the vicus of the Roman fort Dambach.
About 2000 antoniniani and 4 aurei up to AD 270.
4teen staters and 2 silver units.

12 coins found together in a pit that served as a cellar to an agricultural building. Probably were kept in a leather or fabric purse: 1 bronze medallion, 7 sestertii, 4 dupondii: Trajan - Gordian III (AD 240).
Hoard of 130 silver coins: Alexander III, Lysimachus and 128 denarii. Found with a ceramic vessel.
23 denarii: Republic (L. Thorius Balbus) - Hadrian (AD 117-138).

find_spot_name: POMPEI I, IX, 1 - CASA DI CERERE
summary: 301 coins found in the House of Ceres: 3 aurei, 298 denarii: Republic - Vespasian (AD 74-79).
This hoard it formed by provincial betican coinage (Urso, Gades, Obulco, Castulo, Acinipo, Laelia,Onuba) and an aes-as of Augustus, minted in Emerita Augusta.
399 silver coins: 245 republican, 22 serrati, 4 republican quinarii, 128 imperial denarii: Republic - Gaius (AD 37-38).
disposition: The casts of these coins are in the Musée d'Archéologie de Lons-le-Saunier, France. Since December 7, 1960, 240 coins are kept in the same museum.

summary: Mr. I.L. Faingold may have inherited a hoard of 100 denarii from his father. 44 coins were documented: Galba - Commodus (AD 190).
disposition: University Museum, Kyiv, Ukraine (44 coins until 1917)

summary: "Hoard of 22 "small bronze Roman coins", some, 11 mm in diameter, only 1 was identifiable: Theodosius II(?), AE IV, 408/450".
disposition: Museum of Litoměřice, Czech Republic (possible inv.no. 172)

summary: 1 republican Denarius, 4 imperial Sestertii (Nero, Galba and Vespasian), 4 uncertain imperial AE and 1 uncertain AR found in regio IX, insula 11, fallen from a rack on top of amphorae leaning against wall E of building 2 (thermopolium).
The coins (44 denarii, Vespasian - Severus Alexander) were discovered during excavation in room D of building I of a mansio close to Sigmaringen.
5 coins found in room 3 of the House of 4 Season: Commodus 1 denarius, Septimius Severus 1 denarius, Caracalla 1 denarius, Julia Mamaea 1 sestertius, Maximinus I Trax 1 sestertius.
35 gold coins: 31 Aksumite, 4 Solidi: Constantius II - Kaleb (AD 5600-520).
disposition: Kunsthistorisches Museum, Wien, Austria (inv.nos. GR 31252-31282; RÖ 35945-35948)

summary: 7 denarii found under a pile of Roman bricks: Trajan – Septimius Severus (AD 197).
211 silver coins: 106 denarii, 105 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 242-243).
disposition: Private collection Dr. Coriolan Bucur, Bucharest, Romania

summary: The hoard was found with a metal detector in 1983 'along the Sarum Road'. The 52 coins were all minted between 330 and 348.
196 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Valentinian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (Salonina) (AD 253-268); silver w8: 245.0g.
57 billon: Hadrian - Gallienus (Salonina) (AD 264-265) found as an unprotected heap on the floor of an underground room during excavations of a house. Range: Hadrian - Gallienus (AD 260-268).
disposition: 37 in Ann Arbor, the rest in various Egyptian museums

summary: The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel and comprised 722 'bronzes'. It has been suggested that they were sestertii dating from the reign of Hadrian to Commodus. Found close to the brickworks.
527 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms: Tiberius - Galba (AD 68-69). 'Presented to the Antiquities Service by Daira Sanieh.'
disposition: 'Formed the beginning of the numismatic collection in the Giza Museum. This collection was transferred 1896 to Alexandria'

summary: The hoard was found in a funerary casket with an ornate lid decorated with a red marble plaque. The casket contained cremated b1, 2 small amphorae, a glass vessel, a copper-alloy spatula and 7 dupondii and asses from Tiberius to Severus Alexander.
25 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus - Maximianus I (AD 285-286); silver w8: 4.6-6.8g.
Around 25 kg = 7656 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
15 nummi Tetrarchy (AD 294-305).
8077 antoniniani (radiates) found with a cooking pot: Philip I to Aurelian/Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver w8: 1532.5-14662.1g.

43 coins (1 Iron Age silver unit, 42 denarii and antoniniani ranging up to Gordian III) discovered in 1922 in a cave in the cliff above the East Wood, Ashover. A silver ring was found at the same place, in a niche between 2 large st1s.
56 nummi: Constantine I - Gratian (AD 378-383).
disposition: Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya, Barcelona, Spain

summary: 272 nummi of Constantine I (AD 316-317).
Hoard originally with 50 coins from the reign of Claudius I. Only 4 coins were studied.

45 billon provincial coins of Alexandria: Claudius I - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161). Examined and photographed December 1962 in Athens by Hackens at a dealer of antiquities, who reported the hoard to have been found near Aswan.'
Around 200 denarii. 7 denarii from Antoninus Pius to Severus Alexander (Julia Mamaea) (AD 222-235) are known..
103 coins, range: Valerian I and Gallienus to Probus. No further details.
20 provincial bronze coins minted in Pautalia. No further information.
20 nummi found near the hillfort of A Peneda: Claudius II - Valentinian II (AD 383-392).
200 poorly preserved Roman copper coins and 2 well-kept 1s were found in the surrounding sand; 1 was of silver. Near an inscribed relief dedicated to Jupiter.

14 bronze coins, ranging from Caracalla to Philip, found in a clay vessel in the destruction layer of a building in the north section of the Agora. More than 100 bronze (provincial, judging from those ill. in fig. 4 in AEMTh 18, 2004, p. 382) coins were also found in the same layer.
14 nummi: Valens - Magnus Maximus/Flavius Victor (AD 3787-388). In a destruction layer of a Roman house.
1522 nummi found with a bucket: Constantine I - Constantius II (AD 355-361).
disposition: Museo Nacional de Arqueologia, Lisboa, Portugal

summary: 322 denarii are issued from Nero to Septimius Severus (AD 193-195).
22 denarii, part of a hoard: Vespasian - Clodius Albinus (AD 193-197).
646 denarii layed in the ground: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195). 152 coins of this find disappeared between 1907 and 1975.

1022 denarii: Republic – Commodus (AD 180-192). The first lot of coins was found in 1943, the second 1 it was pre10ded to have been discovered in 1970 at the same place and by the same person. In fact there was just 1 hoard.
disposition: History Museum, Piatra Neamț, Romania (537 coins)

summary: 2 nummi were discovered during garden landscaping. It is possible that they form part of a small hoard. Diocletian and Galerius (Caesar), both coins minted in Treveri.
The hoard comprised 831 bronze coins from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
16 denarii (Galba - Hadrian) coins were found, covered with a terra sigillata plate, on Tiefenthaler Str.
24 nummi considered by some authors as a possible hoard/deposit (AD 358 - 395).
32 silver coins discovered in a small ceramic vessel: 7 antoniniani, 25 denarii: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2574

summary: 379 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Nero - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 295-296) found in a small amphora at floor level in an underground room during excavations of a house.
disposition: 329 coins in Ann Arbor, the rest in various Egyptian museums

summary: 62 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 253).

In 1840, Hucher bought a block of 12 (although he sometimes states there were between 15 and 20 coins) silver coins, found in the canton of Montfort-le-Rotrou and perhaps at Chapelle-Saint-Rémy. The coins were of K type (Type BN 5967-5981) attributed to Aulerci Cenomani or of the Carnutes.

4 bronze coins (Trajan - Marcus Aurelius), found on the Dowe-See estate on the Bullenteich in Braunschweig, next to other small Roman objects (bronze fibula, bronze ring, glass pearls, spindle whorl, etc.).
10 denarii and 1 sestertius: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver w8: 15.6-28g.
A hoard of 5 early 4th century nummi, found in a grave in the east cemetery of Thessaloniki (Agios Dimitriou street).
The hoard comprised 5 sestertii with a TPQ of AD 97.
Preliminary record of a hoard of 27 Durotrigan staters found in June/July 2010. The coins were scattered over an area of some 10 square metres.
1 denarius, 33 antoniniani (radiates), 16 sesterti, 16 antoniniani (radiates) fragments, 4 nummi: Hadrian - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
277 nummi: Constantine I (Constantine II Caesar) - Valentinian III/Vandals (AD 425-435). Found together with a small copper alloy sheet of cladding. Total w8: 145 g.
disposition: Soprintendenza per i Beni Archeologici di Ostia - Lidia Paroli

summary: 6 coins: 4 AE and 2 AR; Trajan-Elagabalus, with no further details currently available.
64 bronze coins: sestertii, dupondii and asses: Augustus - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-178).

In Room 14, part of 'Northern Group' of villa rooms, there were 2 shallow, circular pits 0.55m in diameter & c. 0.20m deep, along W wall. [S pit contained 18 coins from Crispus (AD 320-324) to Constantinopolis (AD 330-337), with 1 coin of Urbs Romana (AD 330-337) 0.15m E of pit & poss. from it. Coins fresh & in uniform condition]. The N pit contained 4 coins from Constantine I (AD 320-324) to Constantine II (AD 320-324). Each group of coins concentrated within its pit, & may have been within cloth bags. Meates suggests that these hoards were buried underneath beds of servants.
Unknown initial number of coins. 29 provincial bronze coins are known: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).

A hoard of 116 coins found over a period of several years in a field, including 3 Iron Age coins, 87 Republican denarii and 26 Imperial denarii up to Claudius I. Other finds were restricted to post-medieval metalwork, prehistoric flints and a single Romano-British brooch, a Colchester derivative of rear-hook type belonging to the mid first century AD.
Around 350 denarii found in Duurzerdiep near Balloo. Only 85 denarii are known: Nero - Commodus (AD 180).
disposition: Drents Museum, Assen (84 coins), RMO, Leiden (4 coins), KPK, Leiden (1 coin); most disappeared PMD 84 coins; RMO 1 coin; [KPK 4 coins]; PMD: 80 coins: 58 in collection van der Feltz, 3 bought in 1871, 4 bought in 1873, 3 bought in 1881, 12 in the Frisian

summary: 20 denarii of similar types with the coins in the hoard POMPEI I, IX, 1 - Casa di Cerere. No further details. Ending with coins of Vespasian ?
15 bronze coins: 8 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 6 asses: Gaius (Agrippa) – Severus Alexander (AD 228).
disposition: Regional Museum, Hradec Králové, Czech Republic (inv.nos. N 2963-2977)

summary: 'Found without container spread on few square meters: 66 Celtic coins, 1 183 Roman coins. The Roman coins: 234 silver coins, 949 bronze coins. The bronze coins: 6 Republican, 100 coins type Nemausus I - 41 halved, 197 coins type Nemausus II - 28 halved, 553 first altar series from Lyon and 5 fractions. The coins of Nemausus are countermarked. Dated to AD 7 - 10.
60 solidi in a lead vessel: Marcian - Zeno (c. AD 490); gold w8: 267g.
134 silver coins: 6 denarii, 128 antoniniani: Hadrian - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 259-260); silver w8: 166.1-340.8 g.
The hoard comprised 9 silver coins of the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
The total number of coins is apparently 1067 denarii: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 152-153).
691 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 284-293). No further details.
6 bronze coins: 1 sestertius, 5 provincial: Hadrian - Septimius Severus/Caracalla (AD 209-212 Found on a shipwreck

1000 solidi of the 5th century AD were found in a ceramic vessel with lid. Based on some photos and press release information pieces of Honorius, Valentinian III, Libius Severus, Anthemius and Leo I are among the coins (AD 472-474). Together were found jewelry and fragments of gold artefacts, probably to be reused.
116 coins: 1 antoninianus, 115 nummi found in a ditch under a st1, 200 m from the auxiliary fort: Gallienus (sole) - House of Constantine I (AD 337-340).

find_spot_name: CASTELNUOVO VAL DI CECINA - SAN BERNARDINO
summary: 102 coins found with the remains of a textile bag: 94 sestertii, 7 dupondii, 1 as: Galba - Trajan (AD 112-114).

The hoard comprises 32 antoniniani (radiates) from Aurelian to Numerian). The first publication by Taracena notes 1 coin of Aurelian and 2 of Numerian. However, Gurt notes 2 examples of Aurelian and 1 of Numerian.

36 gold and silver Iron Age coins had been handed in to the Russell-Cotes Museum, Bournemouth, in October 1980, and said to have been found at a depth of c.75 cm "buried beneath a flat st1". There are persis10t suggestions in the published and unpublished reports of the find that a) it was much larger than the declared portion, and b) it was found somewhere other than the given location. A large quantity of Roman bronze - up to 200 coins, mostly of the second to 4th centuries AD, of which "over 100" were donated to Dorset County Museum - was reported to have come from the same location; there were also 2 Durotrigan bronze staters from the site, but apparently not associated with the hoard.
Found during excavations, at the border of the road south of Insula 18. 10 asses, of which 5 were halved.
39 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms: Claudius I - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 255-256). Purchased by Currelly and Frost from "native diggers".
disposition: 'Selection in Oxford, where there is also a handwritten list (Milne); some of the rest are probably in Toronto'

summary: Outside of Room 7 in House XI, to the east a hoard of some 250 minimi was found. The present hoard may perhaps be dated with some certainty to the period AD 370-450.
Unknown number of antoniniani. 27 coins entered museum collection in Haskovo: Gordian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: History Museum, Haskovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. N 656, N 1039

summary: 29 imperial denarii (Augustus to Vespasian), 30 uncertain denarii and 163 uncertain bronze coins found with silver tableware in regio VI, insula 7, cubiculum south of Tuscan atrium of building 20 (house).
IARCH record for a small hoard of 10 radiates. Possibly associated with the Chalgrove II hoard (IARCH-CB9058) but recorded separately due to uncertainty over this association.
2 solidi of Constantius II and Constantius III Gallus (Caesar) and a gold foils with a stamp from a solidus of Valentinian II were found in a vault.
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia (inv.no. 1820/8350837)

summary: With 294 denarii republicans and 9 imperial of Augustus. Also 1 quinarius republican and 2 quinarios of Augustus (25-23 BC).
disposition: Museu Arqueológico de Citânia de Sanfins, Portugal

summary: More than 200 Roman silver and bronze coins were found in 1880, in the barn of the house no. 20 in Ronsberg. 61 were identified in the Munich state coin collection and 6 are listed in FMRD; the imperial series ended with Severus Alexander.

These coins are referred to as a hoard because of their uniform composition and patination. Details on locality and circumstances are not known. Originally, there were 106 coins, but 81 nummi were studied, all issues of Constantine I (AD 313-318).
Coins were found by 2 detectorists between 6 May and 16 July 1979, apparently scattered across a wide area (up to 900 m2) within an earthwork.

18 Cappadocian silver coins (didrachms, drachms and hemidrachms), sold to the museum of Zugdid by a farmer in the 1930s. The coins range from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161), with 10 specimens being illegible. The coins were examined by Zograf in 1937.
Unknown number of coins. 4 coins in the museum of Lovech: Septimius Severus, Julia Domna, Severus Alexander, Philip II.
(c. 250) 45 denarii: Republic - Tiberius (AD 14-37).
(30 kg) 10700 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani: Caracalla - Probus (AD 276-282); silver w8: 1919.3-27660.6g
disposition: Académie florimontane, Annecy, France; Musée d'Annecy, inv.no. 3058; Schwizerisches Landesmuseum, Zürich, Switzerland (187 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 7 antoniniani (radiates) of Postumus (AD 260-269).

25 antoniniani (hoard or purse) bought in 1938 from a drunken labouring man who claimed to have found them in the Dünnern river bed. Coins range from Aurelian to Carinus: 15 Aurelian, 9 Probus, 1 Carinus. 22 coins out of the 25 are clearly identified/preserved today (15 Aurelian and 7 Probus).

26 coins which were found in a sandhole at Cholmondeston, not far from the Watfield Pavement. Most of them were judged to be coins of Constans, having the legend FEL TEMP REPARATIO, and on the obverse of some D N CONSTANTIVS P F AVG.
99 nummi recovered from the sea: tpq AD 313.
3 denarii found at the bottom of a cooking pot. Probably, a foundation offering: 1 Republic, 2 Augustus (15-13 BC).

Preliminary record for c. 22900 radiates and nummi (22523 coins catalogued; total does not include 1 fused block estimated by w8 of c. 365 coins). See PAS-D7EA4C for further details. Note the presence of a possible organic container(s) and 3 iron ingots.
26 coins found together at the archaeological site: 1 antoninianus (radiate), 25 nummi: Divus Claudius II - Constantius II (AD 355-361).

36 billon provincial coins of Alexandria: Balbinus and Pupienus (Gordian III Caesar) - Claudius II (AD 270-271) found in a jar, placed upright with its top just beneath floor level in a corner, during excavations of a house.
disposition: 32 in Ann Arbor, the rest in Cairo

summary: 6 British coins, 1 in gold and 5 in silver, discovered in various localities in Dorsetshire and Wiltshire. The silver coins were found chiefly at Langton, near Blandford, with several others, in a field between Shapwick and Badbury Rings, with 2 in copper of the same type; and at Tollard Royal, Wilts, with about 20 more of the same type". The report is difficult to interpret because Langton is not "between Shapwick and Badbury Rings", but about 6 kilometres to the north-west. The mention of the field between Shapwick and the hillfort clearly raises the possibility that these coins were a precursor to the massive hoard found here in the 1980s. 2 of Durden's coins from "Langton" can be fairly securely identified in the Salisbury Museum collection (SCBI 24, nos 903 and 916); they are also illustrated by Roach Smith (1848, pl. LVI, 10, 12), with a third which is harder to match to modern records. The "2 in copper" (also recorded by Evans 1864, 117) cannot now be identified."
11 burned antoniniani: Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 270-275). 2 lots of 8 (24.09g) and 3 (8.83g) coins.
5 clipped and 4 pierced solidi (more than 3 holes) found in a grave dated in AD 575: Leo I, Justin I, Justin I and Justinian I (2), Justinian I.
399 coins found near the legionary fortress: Gallienus - Valentinianus I (AD 375-383). 2 lead seals were found with the coins
250 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel. 10 coins have been seen by T. Gerasimov: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
Hoard of 17 denarii (Mark Antony - Augustus) and 29 sestertii (Nerva - Hadrian) (AD 117-138).
37 antoniniani and nummi found under an oak tree. Among the coins were noticed issues of Gallienus, Valentinian I and Valens (AD 364-378).
disposition: Private collection of the mayor Artmayr in Gallspach, Austria (in 1903); today, lost

summary: The coins were found in the burnt layer of a destroyed heater of a Roman house. The coins were found in the fire layer of the destroyed heating system of the Roman house. According to the composition, it could be a scattered hoard.
375 Roman provincial bronze coins of the 3rd century AD. No further infiormation.
2250 denarii: Galba – Commodus (AD 180-192). No further details.
9 bronze coins, date, grave: Gaius - Quintillus (AD 270).
16 coins: 1 as, 15 nummi found with a pitcher: Antoninus Pius - Constantine I (AD 324-325). Hypothetically, it can belong to a funerary context.
disposition: Museu D. Diogo de Sousa, Braga, Portugal

summary: About 1200 coins were turned up by the ploughshare in the year 1791 in an arable field known by the name of Walls. They had been deposited in an earthen vessel. Undated.

Votive deposit comprising 3 Iron Age coins. It was characterised as being 1 of 16 individual votive deposits found at the site of an important Gallo-Roman sanctuary during excavations. Inventory No: 76.317 a to c

The hoard comprised 'several hundred small bronze coins'. Canel distinguishes this hoard from those found in Préaux (TAF IV. 57). The hoard was near the top of the hill, close to the plough, approximately 1km from the ancient abbey of Saint-Léger.
30 siliquae: Constantius II - Valens (AD 2364-367); silver w8: 59.2-91.6 g.
disposition: National History Museum of Romania, Bucharest (30 coins) 1974

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 21 bronze coins are known: Antoninus Pius – Theodosius (AD 388-393).
disposition: Museum of Česká Lípa, Czech Republic (inv.nos. A 20.167-20.187)

summary: 163 antoniniani (radiates) found with a storage jar: Valerian I and Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
Hoard of 608 denarii: 1 republican, 607 imperials: Republic - Trajan (AD 98-117). Only 173 coins were studied.
The hoard comprised '57 Roman coins including 1 of Antonina (sic), 1 of Antoninus Pius or Commodus and 1 of Maximinus.'

The hoard comprised some Constantinian nummi (approximately 40 according to Fillon). Most of the coins had very small flans and were either VRBS ROMA or CONSTANTINOPOLIS types. They appeared to be copies.
15 probably antoniniani (radiates). According to NUMIS they are dated around AD 270. No further information.
The hoard comprised Roman gold and silver coins: Galba - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
2 staters of VEP CORF which were reportedly found together, c.1984, were sold some 2 decades later.

The hoard comprised a funerary urn containing the remains of Sextus Polleius Solemnis, an oculist's toolkit and 16 coins from Trajan to Valerian and Gallienus. The latest coin was a radiate of Valerian, from the mint of Cologne dating to AD 259 to 260.
38 aurei: Tiberius - Nero (AD 62-63).
718 coins: 2 denarii, 2 quinarii, 667 antoniniani (radiates), 3 sestertii/double sestertii: Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 262-265); silver w8: 203.3-1735.5g.
The hoard comprised 13 silver shekel and half-shekel coins from the first 4 years of the First Jewish Revolt (AD 66-70).
40 bronze coins, only 18 were identified: 1 sestertius, 14 nummi.

The hoard comprised 15 coins including 1 2nd c. sestertius, 1 denarius, 11 radiates and 2 Provincial coin from Athens from Period VI (AD 264-267), found under burnt debris on the floor of a room of a large Roman house on the lower slope of the Hill of the Nymphs.
The hoard was found in an iron box deposited under a mosaic depicting Bacchic themes and contained 40 coins of Gordian III to Postumus. The denominations of the coins were not specified.

Hoard from the Roman villa at Chesters.What is menti1d in Garrett & Harris 1938 and shown on a plan (p. 97, fig. 1) is a small group of coins associated with a 'hole in upper flagged floor' in Room I. This hole was 'filled with various debris, amongst which coarse pottery, pseudo-samian ware, late coins (Decentius, Constantius II, barbarous, & minimi), twisted copper bracelet wire etc'. Also 2 glass beads.
Hoard of 105 coins of the Bosporan kings: Rhescuporis II, Sauromates I, Cotys II, Rhoemetalces, Sauromates II, Rhescuporis III, Cotys III, Sauromates III, Rhescuporis IV, Ininthimeus.
90 silver coins: 36 denarii, 54 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius - Valerian I (AD 257); silver w8: 114.7-196.4 g.
Unknown originally number of denarii. 27 coins are known at the moment: Republic - M. Aurelius (AD 161-175).
A hoard of 54 bronze coins (Tiberius - Diva Faustina II) found during excavations in the Roman vicus; it was unearthed in stages, in 1983 and then 1986.

A hoard of 86 Roman imperial denarii (from Vespasian to Commodus) was discovered by a treasure hunter in 2015 or 2016. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on 10 February 2016 on the treasure hunter forum Violity, but without specifying the exact location of the find. However, on May 25, 2017 on the YouTube channel “Poisk klada Alexander & Co” there was information about the location of the find, as well as photos of the coins previously published on Violity. There is no information about the conditions of the hoard discovery. The coins are of average preservation. In February 2016, the hoard was sold in 1 lot at Violity auction, the further fate of the coins is unknown.
4 coins of Gordian III: 2 antoniniani (radiates), 2 sestertii P M S COL VIM (AD 238-244).
70 denarii: 69 Rome issues, 1 imitation: Trajan - Commodus (AD 187-188). Together, it was found a ring made of a silver-coloured metal.
698 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
9 coins of the Bosporans kings: Eupator, Sauromates II.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 4000 plated coins. The hoard was found by workmen digging ditches on the ancient route from Mans to Paris.

The hoard was found in a ceramic 'piggybank' and comprised 3 cistophorii from the mint of Asia and 402 denarii (including 1 ancient copy). Following x-ray and the use of endoscopy, the coins were removed through the slot in the m1ybox by a conservator at Side Archaeology Museum, S. Okumuş Tek and technician Z. Avcu. The hoard was found in a deep trench in the north eastern carpark during the excavation of the Late Antique Baths

It is not certain whether there were 1 or 2 hoards. The hoard(s) seems to have comprised between 100000 and 380000 coins: Mark Antony - Maximinus I Thrax. 2 hoards were found in a short period of time, 40 m from 1 another in January 1936 in March 1936.
disposition: National Museum, Niš (3,941); National Museum, Belgrade, Serbia (3,123); Archaeological Museum, Zagreb, Croatia (4,096); National Museum, Ljubljana, Slovenia (c. 830); National Museum, Prague, Czechia (15,000); Šipuš collection (64 coins);

summary: 63 denarii found by metal detecting: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195).
disposition: Sold; Local museum Olevsk, Ukraine (3 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 10 bronze coins dated between the reigns of Nero (AD 54-68) and Nerva (AD 96-98).

Unknown initial number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 4 coins provided some data: 2 denarii, 2 antoniniani (radiates): Marcus Aurelius, Elagabalus, Maximinus I Thrax, Gallienus (sole reign).
7 antoniniani (radiates), 4 sestertii and 5 dupondii: Nerva - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
A hoard of circa 169 provincial coins of Tarsus found on the site of the ancient city ranging in date from Septimius Severus to Trebonianus Gallus.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel 64 sestertii and 77 denarii or antoniniani (radiates) from Vespasian to Valerian I and Gallienus. There was also 1 gold finger ring and 1 silver finger ring. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 between 22.3g and 197.1g
Originally, circa 600 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 115 were available for study: Augustus - Tiberius (AD 14-37).
5 2nd century AD bronze coins, found in the area of the town hall.
10 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Claudius II (AD 268-270); silver w8: 3.7-11.5g.
A hoard of 296 denarii (Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius), found by a grave-digger in Allerton Bywater churchyard.
300 silver and billon coins: 1 Augustus, 1 Vespasian, ending with Valerian I (AD 253-260).
62 provincial bronze coins, issues of the mints from Nicopolis ad Istrum and Marcianopolis.
The hoard comprised 'approximately 120 Roman bronzes, principally sestertii, of which many were very crudely manufactured 'trés frustes'.
41 coins: 1 antoninianus (radiate) and 41 imitations in an alloy of copper and lead: 1 Valerian I, 40 Gallienus (AD 257-258).
A widely-scattered hoard of 37 staters of Addedomaros, discovered by 8 or more detectorists in repeated visits to the site.
245 coins found in a fire layer from a domestic building: Diocletian - Theodosius and his sons (AD 392-395).
disposition: Museo Municipal de Ronda - Palacio de Mondragón, Spain

summary: 'Some kilos' of coins were found of which J.Gricourt saw 1 group of 19 coins, which were all of the House of Constantine.

6 denarii "fairly close together, possibly a small purse hoard. Not possible to obtain details of 2 of these, but the remaining 4 consists of: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius for Faustina II, Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
133 sestertii studied from a total of 300 found: Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 2543-259).
A concealed hoard of 22 aurei of 'Nero, Hadrian and the Anto9s' found c. 1888. It is believed that the hoard was from Wanborough / Durocornovium, but this is not certain.
The hoard comprised 35 gold coins dated between the reigns of Valentinian I (AD 364-375) and Anastasius I (AD 491-518).
809 silver coins: 91 denarii, 718 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius (Faustina II) - Valerian I (AD 258). Found with 2 ceramic vessels.
The hoard comprised 2 aurei from Antoninus and Faustina II and 5 denarii from Trajan, Antoninus, Faustina I, Faustina II and Lucilla. It's probably a part of hoard.
It comprised c. 800 sestertii found with a red ceramic vessel. Only 299 are now recorded: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
10 nummi of Constantine I and his family found in a pond of Roman villa.
78 silver coins: 65 denarii, 13 quinarii: Republic - Augustus (29-26 BC).
disposition: Museum Milano, Italy (collection Brera, inv.nos. M.992.18.1-M.992.18.78)

summary: 4 bronze coins, 3 sestertii and 1 as, were found together in a wall: Domitian, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161)
A pot hoard deposited c. 215 of 105+ bronze coins of Hypaepa dating from Commodus to Septimius Severus / Caracalla. Almost all the coins were countermarked with a figure of Artemis (GIC 233).
28 denarii found during archaeological excavations together with jewelry: Republic – Domitian (AD 81).
The hoard comprised 192 coins of the first century AD, the majority of which date to the First Jewish Revolt.

In 1999, the numismatics department of the Pushkin State Museum of Fine Arts acquired 197 nummi, which were part of the hoard discovered near the village Molochne of the Saki region of the Republic of Crimea, probably in 1989-1990. Unfortunately, the circumstances of the discovery are still unclear. Constantine I - Constans and Constantius II (AD 347-348).
disposition: The Pushkin State Museum of Fine Arts, Moscow, Russia (197 coins)

summary: 58 tetradrachms of Alexandria, 1 bronze coin: Vespasian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 294-295). Found in a heap beneath the floor of a passageway during excavations of a house.
disposition: 57 in Ann Arbor, the rest in Cairo

summary: 7 bronze coins: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (AD 152-153) found secreted in a wall of a vaulted storage room during excavation of a granary.
Unknown number of coins. 4 coins entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: 1 denarius Maximinus I Thrax, 3 antoniniani : 1 Caracalla, 2 Gordian III.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2591

summary: At least 2 British O quarter staters, found about 3 metres apart. A stater, described as bearing a "disjointed horse", was found about 400 m distant in 1996, but is unlikely to have been associated with the quarters .

The hoard was found during the excavation of a Roman villa and comprised 3 separate deposits of coins from Gallienus to Probus. The first deposit comprised 29 coins of Postumus. The second deposit comprised 19 radiates from Gallienus to Probus and the third, 5 radiates from Gallienus to Victorinus.

Hoard from the initial phase of excavations at Bat10 Hanger Roman villa, directed by J. Magilton. Currently in preparation for publication. Details from M. Lyne (pers. comm.). The site consists of a Roman villa and aisled building, with occupation into the fifth century.
22 silver coins found in an ash layer at a Roman sacrificial place.

7 coins discovered outside Vaenor in 1945, 4 of which were either lost or too worn to permit identification. The 3 surviving coins are all nummi of Maximinus II Daia (A.D. 305-313), Maxentius (306-312), and Constantine I (307-337).
48 coins: 13 antoniniani (radiates), 16 denarii, 17 sestertii, 2 asses: Nerva - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
50 denarii found in the debris from a house foundation: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169).
disposition: Kärntner Landsmannschaft, Klagenfurt, Austria (46 coins); private collection (2 coins), lost (unknown number)

summary: A hoard of 255 silver siliquae was found in 1983 in a hedgerow in Newton Mills Park, between Newton St Loe and Saltford, near Bath. Coins range from Constant to Magnus Maximus.
114 provincial bronze coins: Antoninus I (Faustina I) - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Burgas, Bulgaria; inv.no. inv.no.741-758, 760-766,768-770,772-780, 782-842, 845-855, 982

summary: Uncertain findingspot, presumably from the Shumen's area, as it was part of the Dr. Vasssil Haralanov collection: Republic - Augustus (19-18 BC)
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Shumen,Bulgaria (former Dr. Vasssil Haralanov collection; inv.nos. 203- 284)

summary: 16 silver coins: 4 denarii, 12 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Postumus (AD 260-269).
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 2600 antoniniani (radiates) from Caracalla to Postumus with a tpq of AD 263.
4 Iron Age silver units. Addenda of 3 units 2012.
A small hoard of 6 south-western (Durotrigan) staters, discovered in September 2008.
42 denarii found by metal detecting near the Dacian citadel: Republic - Tiberius (AD 14-37).
disposition: Muzeul Judeţean de Istorie şi Artă Zalău, Romania

summary: IARCH record for a fused lump of denarii, of which 3 could be identified as issues of Severus Alexander, The others (3 and a fragment) could not be identified due to the condition of the coins. Possibly burnt as they are deformed into a fused mass (total wt. = 14.01g).For further details and images see YORYM-6C737B

The hoard was found hidden in the hollow base of a statue and comprised coins of Postumus, Victorinus, Tetricus, Claudius II, Probus and Tacitus. The nummus of Constantine I/Gratian, probably, a intruder.
The hoard comprised 16 radiates from Aurelian to Probus, found on the Agora in Athens beneath the post-Herulian wall, lost during the construction of that wall.

Several thousand Roman coins reported to have been found in 1852. 32 coins, findspot menti1d "Malvaglia" and "Val di Blenio", entered the collection of the Antiquarische Gesellschaft Zürich (AGZ) and have now integrated the collections of the Schweizerisches Nationalmuseum, Zürich. They are probably part of this hoard (32 antoniniani, Aurelian to Diocletian).
disposition: Schweizerisches Landesmuseum Zürich (32 coins); the other ones are lost.

summary: A little more than 20 coins were found (only 11 known and recorded). The coins were found while leveling 2 tumuli revealing some 'depots' of denarii Trajan - Commodus (AD 181-182).
34 British coins declared Treasure in 1983 with group I.
(c. 300) 22 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 261); silver w8: c. 82.0-374.0 g.
disposition: Musée Curtius, Liège, Belgium (7 coins); collection L. Renard-Grenson, Liège, Belgium (13 coins)

summary: During the excavation of a rural Roman bath-house, 10 coins were discovered in the ashes of the praefurnium. The b1s of a 12 year old child were found in the same place. TAF suggests that the coins were a purse loss or a funerary deposit.

Iron Age British silver and copper-alloy coins, Roman Republican silver denarii, Roman imperial denarii, Roman copper-alloy coins, totalling 465 specimens. The assemblage seems to constitute continuous votive deposition rather than a hoard.
Circa 80 silver coins. Only 2 of Caracalla, 3 of Gordian III, 1 of Philip I are known.
5 late Roman coins (time of Constantine I), found in a light-brown container, approximatively towards the end of the 19th c.

A hoard of Roman coins, contained in an earthenware vessel, was discovered about 1902 while digging for gravel (shale) for the parapets of local roads on the rock. 6 of the coins were of Constantine the Great (310-15 A.D.)
The hoard comprised approximately 20 bronze coins from the second and third centuries AD.
31 silver coins: 8 small silver Celtic (1 Karlstein type; 7 Magdalensberg/Gurina type), Republic: 16 denarii, 2 denarii serati, 2 quinarii; 3 imperial denarii: Celtic - Augustus (AD 2-14).
575 denarii: Nero – Gordian III (AD 238-244).

A hoard of about 280 Roman imperial denarii was discovered by a treasure hunter on the south-western outskirts of Vinnitsa, near the district “Polyana”. The hoard was found in the forest, and the coins were ploughed during the planting of this forest. In addition to the coins, a fragment of a golden rod ("golden wire") and the remains of a pot were found.
20 coins: 6 republican denarii, 14 imperial coins: 1 dupondius, 13 asses: Republic - Claudius I (AD 50-54).
The hoard comprised 1 aureus, 30 Republican denarii and 35 denarii from Augustus to Nero. It was found within a dwelling.
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Orense, Spain

summary: 1499 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 295-296) in an amphora beneath the floor during excavations of a house.

A hoard of 6 siliquae (Valentinian III), partly clipped, which were found in 1980 by a private person in diggings or a building material in the area of the curia von der Leyen of the cathedral of Trier. The coins were photographed in the Rheinisches Museum (no w8s taken) but remain in private ownership.
38 nummi ending with a coin of Honorius (AD 393-402).
disposition: Museo Arqueolóxico do Castro de Viladonga, Spain
