summary: 152 nummi: Constantius II, Constantius II Gallus (Caesar), Julian II (Caesar). Together were found 2 bronze rings.
disposition: Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Adria, Italy

summary: A hoard of 46 mostly bronze coins (26 provincial and 20 imperial), ranging from Domitian to Trajan Decius, found scattered on the floor of Villa A, in a destruction layer associated with the Sassanid invasion.
A hoard of around 1200 imperial denarii was found while metal detecting. The coins were placed in 3 pitchers.
Around 3000 antoniniani (radiates) found with a bronze vessel. 2813 coins were studies: Valerian I and Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver w8: 760.5-3515.3 g.

3 denarii of Hadrian, found around 1896 on the Debra, a plateau approx. 1.5 km northeast of Rudolstadt, near Debrahof, on Rudolstadt-Teichweiden road; the coins could form part of a larger hoard of denarii.

Initially 805 antoniniani (radiates). 786 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 268). It included issues from the mint of Siscia, but the number is not given. Data for other mints was not recorded.
142 coins found with pot. 132 were studied: Republic – Honorius (AD 395-401).
106 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Carinus (AD 283-284).
disposition: Narodni muzej, Numizmatični cabinet, Ljubljana, Slovenia

summary: 698 silver coins: 1 denarius, 697 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 268); silver w8: 190.0-1811.7 g.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (10 coins of Postumus); collection De Bove (34 coins), in 1882

summary: 118 nummi (folles) of the Tetrarchy found with a ceramic vessel.
Unknown number of solidi. 3 solidi of Valentinian I, Valens, Arcadius, tpq c. 400; gold w8: 13.35g
The listed coins lay together under the label "railway 1914 N 46" in a box. All are deeply sintered.
39 nummi, probably, part of a larger hoard, found by metal detecting: 3rd century - Constantius II (AD 355-361).
Around 200 denarii. Only 60 coins provide information on issuers: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
Hoard of 867 nummi of the House of Constantine I of which 864 are imitations of various mints issues (AD 347-348).
140 republican and imperial denarii ending with Domitian's issues (Caesar or Augustus?). Found with a ceramic vessel.
Unknown quantity of silver and bronze coins found in a copper vessel. 11 coins in the History Museum in Lom: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
The hoard was found in a wall. It comprised c. 400 bronze coins from Nero to Gordian III (AD 238-244). This hoard was divided in 2 lots.
disposition: H. Ponroy Collection; Berry Museum, St. Moritz, Switzerland

summary: of 4033 pieces, 3296 were recorded at the British Museum: 592 denarii, Domitian-Gordian III; 2704 antoniniani, Caracalla-Trajan Decius, including 2 “Divi”. The other were all antoniniani of Gordian III, Philip I, Philip II and Trajan Decius.
121 denarii: Republic - Tiberius (AD 14-37). Found in a ceramic vessel.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1502

summary: Hoard of 7 medallions and silver brooches of the 4th. c. AD. 4 medallions w8 70 gr each, 2 medallions of circa 28 gr each and a small gold coin with a suspension loop of circa 14 gr. V. A. Shugayevski considers the heaviest medallions as multiple of 6 and and 10 solidi.
4000 coins found in a ceramic vessel: antoniniani (radiates), double sestertii, sestertii from Postumus, Aurelian, Tacitus and Probus (AD 276-282).

Circa 30 denarii: Republic - Septimius Severus (AD 194-197). Near the denarii, a silver "pendant" was found, a piece of a brown object of unspecified utility, coins from the 15th to the 20th century and sherds of pottery (probably modern). The coins from the hoard were identified based on poor or very poor quality photos.
7 aurei found in grave no. 7: Nero 2, Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius 2, Faustina II (AD 161-180).
Coins from Trajan to Septimius Severus found with a ceramic vessel.
Around 300 nummi were found with a ceramic vessel. Only 5 coins were recovered, all from the time of Constantine I.
600 silver coins. N. Moushmov have seen 387 coins: Republic - Nerva (AD 96-98).
3 drachms of the Parthian king Gotarzes II (AD 40-51) and 16 denarii of Augustus (2 BC - AD 4) were found during excavations.
The hoard comprised 22 denarii overstruck by the Bar Kokhba administration (AD 132-136).
157 denarii were found but details were only provided for 37 coins: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 117-138)
disposition: Archaeological Museum in Zagreb (37 coins); dispersed

summary: A grave found in the peribolos of the west cemetery of ancient Rhodes (reused in late Roman times) contained a hoard comprising 4 Roman bronze coins: 1 of Aemilianus (in the mouth of the deceased), 1 of the first to second century AD, 1 of Caracalla and 1 of Alexander Severus (beside the head).

In 1978, Mr. Charles Pire, a coin dealer from Brussels, bought about 500 pieces from a lot of 972 coins found in the region of Amiens. It consisted generally of about 15 antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus and Salonina, a dozen of Postumus, a hundred of Victorinus, around 20 of Claudius II, about 300 of Tetricus I and II from the mints of Trier and Cologne. Other 30 pieces consisted of imitations of Tetricus I, large module. 235 coins are presented in detail: Trebonianus Gallus - Tetricus I (AD 271-273); silver w8: 185.7-1213.9 g.
disposition: Private collections: Ms. A. Wattecamps; Mr. S. Genvier; Mr. J.-M. Doyen; Mr. Pire

summary: Hoard of more than 200 denarii. Only 10 were documented: Hadrian (Aelius Caesar) - Pertinax (AD 193).
(c. 60) 27 denarii: Republic - Vespasian (AD 71).
disposition: Muzeul Olteniei, Craiova (21 coins); Institute of Archaeology, Bucharest, Romania (6 coins, inv.no. 742/1945)

summary: The coins came into view in section A-B in a 30cm deep destroyed layer of the used stratum of the residential house, north of the Mithraeum. Not only the find circumstances, but also the collocation suggests a small hoard find.
disposition: Rheinisches Landesmuseum, Bonn, Germany (inv. no. F 8125a)

summary: A hoard of 68 denarii and antoniniani, ranging from Titus to Trajan Decius. The exact provenance is unclear, but coins were found in Ladenburg. Only 2 thirds of the coins could be traced in the collections of the Baden-Baden museum.

In Room 14, part of 'Northern Group' of villa rooms, there were 2 shallow, circular pits 0.55m in diameter & c. 0.20m deep, along W wall. S pit contained 18 coins from Crispus (AD 320-324) to Constantinopolis (AD 330-337), with 1 coin of Urbs Romana (AD 330-337) 0.15m E of pit & poss. from it. Coins fresh & in uniform condition. [The N pit contained 4 coins from Constantine I (AD 320-324) to Constantine II (AD 320-324)]. Each group of coins concentrated within its pit, & may have been within cloth bags. Meates suggests that these hoards were buried underneath beds of servants.
Hoard of 190 denarii found with ceramic vessel: Republic (?) - Hadrian.

A hoard of 8 Roman provincial coins (Thessalonica, Pella, Edessa; Caracalla to Philip), found at the sanctuary of Zeus Ammon in Kallithea. This sanctuary was located on the territory of the Roman colony of Cassandrea.
244 silver coins: 117 denarii, 127 antoniniani: Nero - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253). Found in a bronze vessel.

12 coins listed as 'loosely associated with the hoard' from Cadeby in CHRB (no. 2519) and said to have been found 60-80 yards away. These were treated as a separate Treasure Trove case so an additional entry has been created here. They may have been part of another scattered hoard.
6 denarii found together on a floor of a Roman edifice from the Dacian kingdom capital of Sarmizegetusa Regia Republic - Trajan (AD 101-102).
disposition: Muzeul Civilizației Dacice și Romane, Deva, Romania

summary: A hoard of 6 provincial coins of Philippi, found in grave T23 in the eastern cemetery of Philippi.
1745 coins: 1742 antoniniani (radiates), 3 denarii: Gallienus - Diocletian (AD 285); silver w8: 318.0-439.9 g.
The hoard comprised 493 denarii and radiates from Commodus to Valerian and Gallienus.
The hoard comprised 1000 antoniniani (radiates) dating to the reigns of Victorinus and the Tetrici. Only 3 coins were described.
Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 63 antoniniani (radiates ) are known: Gordian III - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
15 sestertii of which Antoninus Pius 1, Faustina II 1, Commodus 1 were found by fishermen in a dune.
Unknown originally number of coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Among the coins were recognized those of Vespasian, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II).

The assemblage comprised 2 discrete hoards (SOUTH WEST NORFOLK I - II). The second included only silver coins. It included uninscribed and inscribed coins and was probably deposited at the time of, or soon after, the Roman invasion of southern Britain in AD 43. (PAS).

In 1906, a find of 107 small bronzes (radiates) was reported in Treffieux. These are very likely to be part of the same find as those reported by Fabre as being found in a garden in the early 20th century AD. This hoard comprised 2 lots of 909 and 44 radiates respectively which were studied in 1953 and 1958. Silver: 908, 1 coins; Silver w8: 246.1-1134.0g.
122 Republican and Imperial AV, AR, and AE found in regio VI, insula 17, building 42 (house), ground floor room, possibly a bedroom.
Group of 3 denarii: Nerva, Trajan, Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

The original hoard comprised of approx. 24000 "medium and small bronze" coins (folles for the most part, some fractions, serveral argentei and billon as well as some radiates). Only circa 14000 have a basic description of the reverse type and emperor (not included here). Others are recorded to greater detail. The hoard was split and a significant part was sold by De la Fontaine (governor) to Brussels, but there is no catalog. There may be some at Cologne (1324) but the largest portion went to Rollin et Feuardent (paris) in 1874. The hoard comprises 34 nummi from Diocletian to Galerius with a tpq of AD 302 to 303. No further details are given about the discovery or context of the hoard.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg (inv.nos. 162-194); Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Münzkabinett, Germany (34 coins)

summary: Unknown originally number of denarii. 8 coins are known:Vespasian – Septimius Severus-Caracalla (AD 193-217).
disposition: Museum of Moravia, Brno, Czech Republic

summary: A hoard of 1545 coins (270 tetradrachms, 1 bronze, 1274 antoniniani down to Claudius II, AD 270), found during the excavations at Capharnaeum.
Found close to the Brotonne forest on the property of Thouzé, which was once part of the park of the Château de la Mailleraye, demolished in 1857. The hoard was found under a tree.

find_spot_name: JERUSALEM - WESTERN AND SOUTHERN WALLS 1975 A
summary: The hoard comprised 34 bronze coins deposited during the First Jewish Revolt (AD 66-72).
The hoard comprised 41 denarii from Vespasian to Septimius Severus.

Uncovered by workmen levelling a stretch of Offa's Dyke. At least 32 coins of the 1st-4th centuries along with an assemblage of small finds, a votive altar, and several probable cinerary urns. No further contextual information is available. Owing to their wide range, it is highly unlikely that the coins ever constituted a single hoard. 2 small hoards of the 1st-2nd and 3rd-4th centuries are possible, as is Guest and Wells' suggestion that the entire assemblage might represent a votive deposit that was built up over time.

Unknown number of nummi of the first and second Tetrarchy. 10 pieces are known from public auctions: Diocletian - Constantine I (AD 307 and post). Mints: Treveri 4, Lugdunum 3, Ticinum 1, Serdica 1, Cyzicus 1
The hoard, found before 1964, comprised 281 sestertii: Trajan Septimius Severus (AD 197-211).
Unknown originally number of coins. 60 pieces were recorded: Republic - Claudius I (AD 41-45).
disposition: Câmara Municipal de Felgueiras, Portugal (25 coins); private collections (35 coins)

summary: 196 nummi of Constantine I and its family (AD 335-337). Found within the temple of Hadrian.
Unknown initial number of coins. 6 pieces entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: Vespasian 1, Nerva 1, Hadrian 1, Antoninus Pius 1, Faustina I 1, Marcus Aurelius 1.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2429

summary: A hoard of 14 Republican denarii and 1 quinarius (Augustus) found in Stühlingen, were Roman buildings were found.
A pot containing a 'large quantity' of Roman gold and silver coins from which 1 Tiberius and 1 Septimius Severus are menti1d.
Over 1000 denarii: Nero - Commodus (AD 186-191).
Over 191 antoniniani (radiates) found in a ceramic vessel: 1 Aurelian, 190 Probus (AD 276-282).
(110) 15 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - ValerianI-Gallienus (AD 253-268); silver w8: 137.5-160.6 g.

summary: 48 antoniani found as a roll in a destruction layer at the eastern gate of the Roman fort: Claudius II - Carinus (AD 283-284).
Several hundred denarii found with an iron jar. Only 6 provided data on the issuers: Hadrian - Commodus.
The hoard comprised 17 gold coins dated between the reigns of Valens and Anastasius.
112 (102 AR, 8 AE, 2 Uncertain) coins from the Republic to Augustus.
During the excavations of 1890, a hoard of 170 bronze coins were discovered: 169 sestertii and 1 provincial bronze: Augustus - Postumus (AD 260-268).
The 4 coins appeared together in the west corner, belonging to a room structure erected with walls of opus vittatum.
An unsatisfactory record of what seems to have been a substantial find of North Thames gold and silver" found by illicit detecting in 1993-4.
Hoard of 17 aurei. Only 2 are known: Pertinax, Septimius Severus.
45 nummi found together in a layer of ashes from a domestic building: Constans - Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
disposition: Museu Convento dos Lóios, Santa Maria da Feira, Portugal

summary: 55 antoniniani (radiates): Pupienus - Valerian I (AD 253-260); silver w8: 69.9-128.8 g.
Initially, there were 1500 aurei. 144 aurei studied: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-162). Together were found 1 gold and 2 silver ingots.

337 silver coins: 272 denarii, 65 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius - Valerian I (AD 255). The hoard found in an urn contains also jewelry. It was found in an area where other archaeological evidence suggests Roman occupation.
The hoard comprised 40 coins of Tetricus I and II and were found alongside a toilet set, a glass vessel and a necklace in a female tomb dating to the first quarter of the 4th century AD.

A hoard of 35 denarii, found under the floor of the North Stoa of the Palace of Galerius in Thessalonica. This and other finds highlight the importance of the Roman phase which preceded the Palace and was burnt down in the middle of the 3rd century AD. The hoard is described as ranging from Vespasian to Commodus OR Caligula to Gordian III.

find_spot_name: OPLONTIS - VILLA B, SKELETON 27, THE DRAWER
summary: 192 coins found with a drawer near a skeleton: 15 aurei, 177 denarii: Republic - Vespasian (AD 77-78).
The hoard (8 denarii and antoniniani, Elagabalus - Philip I) was found at the bottom of a container during construction work at Heilbronn street.
24 provincial bronze coins entered the museum collection in Shumen: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 1676-1699 (24 coins)

summary: 437 antoniniani (radiates) in a ceramic vessel: Valerian I - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
disposition: Musées royauc d'Art et d'Histoire - Koninklijk Musea voor Kunst en Geschiedenis (Brussels)

summary: 339 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274). Silver: 254, 85 coins; silver w8: 69.6-316.5g.
288 denarii found in a ceramic vessel within the Carpic settlement: Nero – Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
The hoard comprised 18 denarii, sestertii, dupondii and asses dating to the second century AD. TAF interprets the hoard as the con10ts of a purse lost when the building was demolished.
15 denarii: Galba - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
60 sestertii of Trajan (AD 98-117).
200 bronze coins: Domitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
Earthen jar containing 1600 pieces of the small brass of the Roman empire, found in Guilthwaite Common. Undated. Probably 3rd or 4th century AD
24 denarii found ina lump of earth: Domitian – Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Found on 3 separate occasions in 1970, 1971 and 1978 in the embankments of the motorway A1 E. Probably a dispersed hoard. Gold: 3 coins; Gold w8: 13.35g;

Found during construction work. The subsequent excavations provided no information on any archaeological context. The findspot is situated in the slope above the vicus of Muralto. Hoard/deposition of 4869 aes coins: 1 as, 1 dupondius and 4867 sestertii, in an amphora, Claudius I to Gallienus (253/254).

The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel and comprised 368 coins including denarii and sestertii from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius and Provincial bronzes of the Koinon of Thessaly from Marcus Aurelius to Maximinus I. It was accompanied by some pieces of gold jewellery.
disposition: Éphorie des antiquités préhistoriques et classiques de Larissa

summary: Hallaton: 14 hoards were located in and around the entrance way. Hoard 15 comprises 59 silver Iron Age coins and 2 Roman Republican denarii.
45 bronze coins - antoniniani (radiates) and nummi - presumably found together south of the Ritona temple.

Around 1910 a hoard with 423 Antoniniani was salvaged during excavation of a building pit. The find spot ('auf den Kästrich') could not be further circumscribed, so that it is uncertain whether the deposit was found inside or outside of the legionary camp. The find is said to have been found with leather remnants in an earthenware container.
The 1849 Whaddon Chase hoard comprised between 450 and 2000 British Iron Age gold staters. In 2006, a further 73 gold staters were found, followed by 2 more in 2008.
disposition: Buckinghamshire County Museum (part); Dispersed through trade (part)

summary: IARCH record for a hoard of 206 Constantinian nummi. For full details and images see DENO-6F8801.Found whilst metal detecting on ploughed land up to 8 inches down. Coins were found scattered over 30-40 metres with most within a 15 metres area. The coins were possibly contained in a pot as suggested by just 1 undiagnostic rim sherd from the same findspot, though this was uncertain.Unpublished catalogue by V. Drost.
Circa 80 Celtic coins found in a ceramic vessel by a farmer.

The hoard was found at a very shallow depth placed under or on a flat, square st1. It comprised a vessel containing 3369 coins. J. Chappée bought the hoard and compiled a catalogue of 3075 antoniniani (radiates) and imitations. M. Amandry undertook a new study of the hoard in 1983 and compiled a catalogue of 3052 coins. It is this catalogue which is recorded in our database. Silver w8: 784.8-3627.8g.
8 solidi, among: 1 Constantine III, 1 Joannes, 3 Valentinian III (AD 425-455); gold w8: 22.25 g.
The hoard comprised an unknown number of Roman coins of which 13 were kept and including issues of Trajan to Postumus.

A hoard of more than 212 coins (Valerian I - Postumus) came into view in 1969 on Saarstrasse 135 during building work; it was dispersed. The RLMT bought 91 coins, 121 further coins were seen in private collections.
2 solidi (Magnus Maximus and Honorius). The discovery of 2 solidi, struck within 20 years of each other, in the same field suggests strongly that this is likely to be a small hoard.

The hoard reportedly con­sisted of 1200 gold coins of Theodosius I (AD 379-395) and 2 gold ingots bearing an imperial stamp. 1 coin from this hoard was recovered by the Hatay Museum, Antakya. The remainder disappeared through illegal channels. The solidi were said to weigh a total of 5.3 kg. Gold: c. 1200 coins; Gold w8: c. 5340g;
disposition: 1 coin in Hatay Archaeological Museum; the rest dispersed on the market

summary: 2 denarii found together: Hadrian, Marcus Aurelius.
11 coins: 1 Celtic bronze coin, 1 republican dupondius, 9 asses: Celtic - Augustus (10 BC - AD 14).
A group of 13 coins, thought to have possibly been contained in a bag or pouch. Found in Colchester Lion Walk site R (between insulae 29 and 37/388a) in a post-Roman pit.

Several finds have been made 1932 in the course of digging flints for road making on the Downs between Eastbourne and East Dean. Not far from Birling Manor 5 small contemporary forgeries of Ancient British gold coins occurred. They are copper, thinly plated with gold, and they represent uninscribed coins and 1 of Dubnovellaunus
46 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 imitation: Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269-271).
A hoard of 20 denarii (Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius), found in a Roman house, in a room next to the furnace of the hypocaust.
349 denarii: Vitellius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-228)
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 9

summary: The hoard was found during the excavation of a human skeleton and horse skeleton and comprised 8 nummi of the House of Constantine I.

Unknown number of argentei of the Tetrarchy found somewhere around Milano. 200 coins were offered for sale in Milano. The coins were minted during the Tetrarchy I: Diocletian, Maximian I, Galerius, Constantius I.
Hoard of 2093 coins of the Bosporan kings, Ininthimeus and Rhescuporis V (AD 242-276).

The hoard was characterised as a 'cachette'. It comprised approximately 350 antoniniani (radiates) of Gordian III, Philip I, Aurelian and other emperors of the period. The coins were generally well-preserved.
179 antoniniani (radiates) and 2 forgeries (antoniniani): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269).
The hoard comprised 21 sestertii and 2 dupondii or asses from Trajan to Severus Alexander. It was found on an ancient floor surface in the corner of a room during archaeological excavations.
44 silver coins: 16 denarii, 28 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 243-244); Silver w8: 57.8-100.7g
The hoard comprised between 200 and 300 coins either in or close to a grave: Pupienus - Postumus (AD 260-269).
A group of at least 4 Constantinian nummi melted and fused together, recorded by C. Barclay at the Yorkshire Museum in 1998 (details from A. Woods, hard copy of report in Yorkshire Museum). 8.62g
4 asses found during the excavations. To be checked whether were found together.
21 bronze coins (Vespasian-Hadrian) published in am auction catalogue without details on the circumstances of discovery.
320 denarii and antoniniani found in a building from the ancient settlement. 22 coins were reviewed: Gordian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).

10 Iron Age silver units and 4 denarii to Tiberius, found by 5 metal detectorists at a rally held between 24 and 26 August 1996; another detectorist found the second batch, of c. 369 coins (sources don't agree on exact figure), on 26 July 1997, at a depth of c. 30 cm. 7teen body sherds of a wheelmade vessel in a sandy, micaceous fabric were found nearby, possibly from a globular beaker and perhaps the container for the hoard (Chadburn 2006, hoard 54).
24 antoniniani (radiates) and 42 imitations found in the basement of a Roman villa: Gallienus - Maximian I (AD 285-291).
The hoard was found by a farmer.
158 nummi: Constantine I - Theodosius I/Honorius (AD 388-402).
disposition: Museo Arqueolóxico do Castro de Viladonga, Spain

summary: 1124 denarii: Nero - Macrinus (AD 217-218).
2 aurei of the Antoninian dynasty. No further information
The hoard comprised 28 4th century nummi from a variety of mints, found in a vase.
The hoard contains in total 18 coins. 1 antoninianus, 17 denarii. Coins of Septimius Severus, Julia Mamea, Severus Alexander, Maximinus I Thrax, Philip I (AD 244-246).

The hoard comprised 2 Iron Age coins and a Republican denarius. It was characterised as being 1 of 16 individual votive deposits found at the site of an important Gallo-Roman sanctuary during excavations.
Originally 30 denari, 29 preserved: Nerva - Commodus (AD 179-191); silver w8: 78.54 g.

Around 1600 of which 1168 identified: 1 Republican denarius of Mark Antony from 32–31 BC from the legionary series; 1259 imperial denarii, 1 drachm, 5 imitations of imperial denarii: Nero - Macrinus (AD 217-218). Together with the coins was found a gold pendant.
Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 156 silver coins: 147 denarii, 9 antoniniani (radiates): Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 247); silver w8: 198.8-366.5 g.
435 coins: 1 antoninianus (radiate), 434 nummi: Victorinus - Constantius II (AD 355-361). Found in a pit/trench while excavating an archaeological site dated from Neolithic to Middle Age.
23 solidi, 3 milarenses and 23 siliquae, ranging from Constantius II to Libius Severus, with 1 Republican denarius, found in a field, south-west of the village of Patching, West Sussex.
775 denarii: Nero – Severus Alexander (AD 228).

9 coins, all contemporary types dating to AD 330s with no copies, frags. of poss. 2 more coins present. Found within small irregular pit 1029, prob. placed in a wooden bucket, as there were also 2 iron hoops. Coins within arc of the 2 hoops, which were both at same h8, plus a conc. some frags. of copper alloy sheet & iron, poss. from a stud.
In 1886 the coins were found in a small dark varnished container in Cologne. Particular circumstances of the find are unknown.
44 coins found in a grave in Lefkohori, Langada in 1970. The coins included 1 denarius (Marcus Aurelius) and 43 provincial coins (Thessalonica, Edessa, Dium, Pella, Stobi, koinon of Macedonia).

The hoard comprised an urn containing 218 (or 318) Roman silver coins, both denarii and antoniniani (radiates). A silver statue depicting a 'wise old man' was also discovered at the same findspot a little later. The hoard was found by a farmer called Filliol while working in his field; silver w8: c.60.4-563.7g.
5 antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268), most likely, part of other hoards found here (e.g. Dalheim II). Was found in a jug that was destroyed by a plow.
Grup of 3 denarii: Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius. Found in a plundered grave dated in the second half of the 6th century AD.

A set of 206 coins (Claudius II - Gallic Empire), dug out during dredging work in the Mosel river, ca.100m below the Kaiser Wilhelm bridge on the western edge of the narrow island. The coins were soldered together in a clump. The 8 coins listed under ID 16853 (FMRD 30113) belong probably to the sam find.
Hoard of 56 coins: 1 antoninianus (radiate), 55 nummi: Claudius II - Constans (AD 346-350) found at the site was a Gallo-Roman villa.

12 denarii, of which 10 plated, were found with a ceramic vessel in a garbage pit: Trajan 3, Antoninus Pius 2, Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) 3, Antoninus Pius (Faustina II) 2, Marcus Aurelius 1, Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) 1 (post AD 173-174).
Unknown number of silver and provincial bronze coins. 100 silver coins were seen: Pertinax - Philip I (AD 244-249).

find_spot_name: CANTERBURY, MARLOWE CAR PARK AREA MT
summary: Marlowe Car Park Area MT, scattered hoard of 87 Theodosian coins, & 1 of Honorius from disturbed layers used to backfill medieval pit 21. Deposition date of AD 402 or later (though single Honorius could be intrusive).

HER record of a hoard of 32 Roman copper coins, "chiefly of the Middle Empire" found in 1772 at North End in Turville. 8 of the coins were said in 1797 to be in the possession of Col Innes of Ibst1 House, of which there were 2 of Antoninus Pius, 2 "Faustinas", 2 "Vespasians", 1 Trajan and 1 "Aurelius". Source: Thomas Langley 1797 "History and Antiquities of the Hundred of Desborough" p.383.

The hoard comprised a total of 259 coins from Augustus to Probus including mostly sestertii, a few asses and 1 radiate. Most of the coins are from the 3rd c. AD and well preserved. The hoard was found between Agia Galini and Kokkinos Pyrgos, in the sea on the site of a shipwreck.
A hoard of 3 large gold medallions, 23 aurei, 4 gold bars, 2 gold tintinnabula and several amulets of gold and lapis lazuli, probably deposited in the reign of Gordian III or Philip the Arab.
disposition: BNF, Paris (Alexander Medaillions); G. de Demetrio (Gold Objects)

find_spot_name: KÖLN - ST. MARIA IM KAPITOL XII
summary: Around 600 coins from the Maria im Kapitol hoard were acquired in 1902 by K. Hallama.

32 gold IA British Q staters. Other coins reported at the same time included a plated silver unit of Eppillus (CCI 07.0882), an early uninscribed southern silver unit (precise type uncertain), and 2 denarii (1 plated) of Tiberius. De Jersey has not included them in the hoard, but they are listed here.
disposition: Ashmolean Museum (part); River and Rowing Museum, Henley (part)

summary: The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 2000 coins from Probus to Gratian. Unfortunately, the exact composition of the hoard is not known.
9 coins of Gallienus found in a field, without any further indication on denomination or types. N1 of these coins has been preserved.

In 1867 a hoard of denarii was discovered in a sand hill on the left bank of the Oste river 2 miles from the estuary. The 6 preserved coins run from Vespasian to Commodus. It is to be assumed that the hoard was composed of more specimens.
54 coins found spread close to each other in a layer of ashes: Domitian - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
14 sestertii found in a house: Nerva - Philip I (AD 244-249).

A gold solidus of Valentinian I and 2 of Valens found 2½ miles S.E. of Melton-Mowbray, by a labouring man employed in working the st1 of the country, together with 2 small brass coins, 1 of which is indecipherable, and the other is of the Emperor Allectus.

According to Carlier, the hoard filled a hat(!) and is likely to have originally comprised at least 600 pieces.Although originally comprising more than 600 coins, the hoard was quickly dispersed. The forest administration confiscated 98 coins, Carlier bought approximately 300, the brothers Gérin took 40, while Demonteville, the librarian of Douai, took 100 sestertii, 5 or 6 'middle bronze' and 12 silver coins: Tiberius (Divus Augustus) - Commodus) (AD 181-190).
28 sestertii in a ceramic vessel: Domitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
(circa 80) 26 silver coins: 3 denarii, 23 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie a Județului Vâlcea, Râmnicu Vâlcea, Romania;

summary: 18 antoniniani (radiates) found stuck together on the elbow of a skeleton in a grave: Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
22 silver coins: 10 small silver Celtic (1 Karlstein type; 7 Magdalensberg/Gurina type; 3 Eis type), Republic: 10 denarii, 1 quinarius; 1 imperial denarii: Celtic - Tiberius (AD 14-37).
4 coins: 1 denarius, 3 sestertii: Vespasian, Hadrian Marcus Aurelius (2)
38 coins: 9 antoniniani and 29 provincial bronzes found within the ruins of an ancient building: Macrinus - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
disposition: Regional History museum, Dobrich, Bulgaria; inv.no. I 2761

summary: A small bronze cauldron containing a linen bag with the coins. The m1y consists of 889 antoniniani (radiates) from Elagabalus to Valerian I and Gallienus. 2 pieces of silver-plated crockery, a plate and a platter, were found next to the cauldron.
500 antoniniani found in a ceramic vessel. 243 were published: Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
Possible part of a larger hoard. Only 4 antoniniani (radiates) are known; silver w8: 5.0g.
The hoard comprised 38 antoniniani, ranging from Gordian III to Gallienus (sole reign).

The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 600 sestertii from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius. A further sestertius of Marcus Aurelius was overstruck with a double sestertius of Postumus. The coins were arranged in textile bags. Fragments of the bags survived where coins touched the walls of the vessel.
87 bronze coins: 2 imperial, 85 provincial: Trajan - Gordian III (AD 238-244)
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv. no. 3635 (87 coins)

summary: 40 denarii: Republic – Vespasian (AD 69-79).
Around 30 coins found with ceramic vessel. 16 were recovered: Vespasian (Domitian Caesar)/Domitian - Severus Alexander (AD 231-235).
disposition: Civiche Raccolte Numismatiche di Milano, Italy

summary: 61 coins: 1 gold, 48 bronze, 12 nummi: Magnentius (AD 351-353)
disposition: Musée Curtius, Liège, Belgium (12 coins); Cabinet des Medailles, Bruxelles, Belgium

summary: 14 coins ranging from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius (1 denarius of Trajan; 11 provincial coins: Dium, Koinon of Macedonia, Stobi; 2 uncertain), found in grave 5 in Sevasti.

A hoard of 381 silver coins (denarii and antoniniani ranging from Geta to Postumus) and 1 provincial coin, found in a vessel surrounded by fire rubble in a building located in front of the SE corner of the Roman fort. The coins had been contained in a bag made of hemp. A large number of ornaments had been placed on top to the vessel.
A suspicious hoard as there is no evidence for the conditions of discovery, except 1 note in a local newspaper: Vitellius - Septimius Severus (Plautilla (AD 202-205).
Unknown originally number of coins. 18 coins are kept in the Hungarian National Museum in Budapest: Augustus – Gordian III (AD 243-244)
7 aurei: Vespasian - Hadrian. No further information.
Unknown number of coins, including 3 solidi: Theodosius II 2, Majorian (AD 457); gold w8: 13.35 g.
disposition: Museum of Moravia, Brno, Czech Republic

summary: 6 aurei of Gallienus (sole) coins found during the development works of the harbor. Very doubtful.
28 coins found in the Dionysos House: 1 sestertius, 22 provincial coins, 5 undocumented coins: Septimius Severus/Caracalla (Julia Domna) - Philip I (AD 244-249).
160 nummi of the 4th century AD. Possible, part of the hoard SIRACUSA 1896 A. Work in progress.
disposition: Museo Arch. Reg. "P. Orsi", Siracusa, Italy (inv.no.: 16535)

summary: 136 large imperial bronzes (sestertii?), well-preserved: Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).

The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 9 aurei, some gold jewellery and a jet amulet. Gold: 9 coins; Gold w8: 45.4-46.0g. The entire hoard was acquired by Dr. E. Poncet for his private collection.
A hoard of 376 denarii (Mark Antony to Severus Alexander), found in an earthenware pot while digging a trench on the O'Sullivan Building Estate, in Forest Way, Orpington in July 1934.
65 republican coins: 1 aureus and 64 denarii found in a flint m1y-box (families: Aemilia, Cassia, Iulia, Marcia, Pompeia).
2 aurei of Nero (AD 54-68).
23 Iron Age gold coins found over a period of several years.
30 coins of Constans (FEL TEMP REPARATIO) were found rolled together on a surface strewn with brick.
3 bronze coins in a small vessel: 1 sestertius Trajan, 1 AE Hadrian, 1 AE L. Aelius (AD 137-138).
The hoard comprised a large ceramic vessel containing 62 sestertii of the first to third century AD.
Hoard of 227 coins of the Bosporan kings dated (AD 276-341). No further information.

The hoard comprised a large greyware 'olla' filled with small bronze coins, totalling approximately 2000. These were partially dispersed although 500 coins were studied by Janicaud and 137 examples donated to the Musée de Guéret. No coins of the Gallic Empire were found in this hoard. The hoard was found when a farmer's plough struck a vessel.

In 1946 during peat digging the find was discovered in a marsh, between St. Annen and Lunden. The find consisted of a wooden box (not preserved) containing a small silver vessel (destroyed) with 9 pearls, 1 sestertius of Antoninus Pius, rolls of 23 denarii (Antoninus Pius - Caracalla), and 2 small bronze rings.
The hoard comprised 12 Roman coins, of which 8 were identified by H. Desaye: Gordian III - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver w8: 7.5 g.
A hoard of 543 Roman coins from the time of Constantine I, found in 2 small vessels hidden in a house with a mosaic floor.
Unknown originally number of coins fund with a ceramic vessel. 23 antoniniani (radiates) were studied: Trebonianus Gallus - Quintillus for Claudius II (Divus).
The hoard comprised 8 Iron Age coins. It This is 1 of 16 individual votive deposits found at the site of an important Gallo-Roman sanctuary during excavations. Inv. 1969.13.216/a to h
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 38 sestertii were recovered: Domitian - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
Hoard of 80 coins of Bosporan kings (AD 232-254). 1 denarius of Severus Alexander among the coins.

Approximately 500 sestertii from Flavian issues to Valerian I found during the construction and landscaping of the military stadium in Cherchell. The hoard was dispersed immediately after discovery, with many being sold to Italian collectors, but some of the coins were acquired by the Collection Bouchereau in Algiers.
Unknown initial number of coins. 3 denarii: Vespasian - Titus (AD 79).
disposition: Narodni muzej Ljubljana, Slovenia; 1 coin; dispersed

summary: It is unclear whether this is a complete hoard or belongs to other coin finds (not recorded).
Unknown originally number of coins. 160 pieces are hosted in the Casa-Museo Posada del Moro in Torrecampo, Spain: Gallienus - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
disposition: Casa-Museo Posada del Moro, Torrecampo, Spain

summary: Due to the common find spot, 30-50 cm under the lower edge of the walled threshold, the supposition is that the coins represent a small deliberately concealed stock of cash.
3750 coins, mostly Syrian tetradrachms ranging from Caracalla to Volusian, some antoniniani and a few denarii, found in a destruction layer in the 'Poseidon villa' in Zeugma.
Circa of 1000 republican and Augustean denarii. 126 coins were recorded.
The hoard comprised a tinned copper-alloy vessel containing several hundred antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

The hoard comprised a ceramic lamp containing 3 coins including a quinarius of Faustina II and 2 4th century nummi. TAF interprets this assemblage as being funerary in nature as it was found during the excavation of a tumulus.
The sculptor Zanda of Desulo discovered a deposit of Roman bronze coins, near the church of San Pietro. 1 of them belongs to Faustina I and 1 to Lucilla.

These coins were found during the excavation of an imperial building. They appear to represent the remains of 2 separate hoards. The first (A) may have been deposited in the middle of the third century AD (AD 249). The second (B) composed of radiates dates to AD 270 to 275.

The hoard comprised 116 silver coins: 111 denarii, 1 denarius serratus, 2 quinarii, 2 drachms: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 157-158). Found in a ceramic vessel with a terra sigillata bowl serving as a lid.
Around 700 denarii. 110 coins provided information on the issuers: Vitellius - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
13 Roman bronze coins of the 1st century AD, including a sestertius of Vespasian, found in a garden in Hillingdon, Pinner Road.

A find of 43 Roman bronze coins, ranging from Agrippa to Domitian, associated with 18 Ancient British coins of the 'Hod Hill' type (Durotrigan, uninscribed) in an earthenware vessel found is Timsbury, in 1907. The find included several Claudian copies (3 of which are now in the BM). The coins were 1 "first brass", 42 "middle brass", and 18 Ancient British AE: AE Ancient British 18 Agrippa 3 Claudius 24 Nero 9 Vespasian 4 Domitian 3 61 (Sir) John Evans, in NC, 1908, 80 NC, 1908, Proc., 11, stated that "the imperial bronze coins ex10ded from Agrippa to Domitian, the latest being struck circa AD 90 [sic]." F.A. Walters, in NC, 1907, 360, said the hoard contained "several of these rather barbarously executed coins of Claudius." Cp. D. Allen, Problems of the Iron Age in Southern Britain (1961), 244

c. 1300 billon provincial coins of Alexandria: Vespasian - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-261). 'Common terracotta vase buried in a fairly deep hole, dug out in the sandst1. Found during excavations for a monumental tomb in the Armenian cemetery.'
65 AR (Cistophori) found during excavations dating to between 190-53 BCE.
The coins were found in a glass urn along with a human cremation. Among issuers Hadrian and Antoninus Pius.
39 coins: 1 antoninianus (radiate), 38 nummi found on the Roman street near the nort-east side of the market: 2nd half of the 3rd century AD - Theodosius I (AD 379-395).
86 of various denominations - sestertii, asses, antoniniani (radiates): Marcus Aurelius - Quintillus (AD 270).
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 3 solidi of Honorius are known; gold w8: 13.35g.
10 denarii found within an bog: Titus - Septimius Severus/Caracalla (AD 196-217).

"The 10ant of 1 of the gardens dug up, within the last few years, at least 5 hundred Roman coins. They are a "denarius of Valentinian, and small brass of Tetricus, Carausius (?), Magnentius, and Constantine". The large number of coins found suggest that they did come from a scattered hoard. The coins of Tetricus must have been antoniniani, those of Carausius? probably so.

A letter in the British Museum from M. Foreman of Kingston-Upon-Hull Museum in 2000 reads "We have 9 other 4th to 5th century coins listed as an 'Ulrome Hoard. These are not the same as the 9 coins from a cliff-fall" (ie hoard 2426). In fact, from the details given there would appear to be 26 coins (under 9 headings) ie those menti1d as being found before 1961 in correspondence in the file.
IARCH record for 2 silver Iron Age coins found together.
180 coins ending with issues of Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Trajan was the other issuer recognized among the coins of this hoard.
A hoard of 24 denarii, found on the Dwoberg in 1795. Of these, 22 (Hadrian - Commodus) were found to be in the Oldenburg state museum.
50 coins of Valentianian III and Galla Placidia (AD 425-455).
Unknown originally number of coins. 68 denarii are kept in the collection of the Library of the Romanian Academy: Republic – Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Coin Room, Library of the Romanian Academy, Bucharest, Romania (inv.nos. 29069-29136)

summary: 18 aurei: Nero - Domitian? (AD 81-96).
176 Roman coins wer found with a terra sigillata. Some authors have expressed their doubts whether the find is really a hoard.

A hoard of 387 silver coins, including a large quantity of posthumous Philip Philadelphus (121, year 19 to 32, i.e. 31-18 BC), Roman denarii (141, up to AD 207), Syrian tetradrachms (29), Arabian didrachms (Trajan, 3 coins), as well as Parthian drachms (92 up to Artabanus IV, 213-227). The later coins of Severus and the members of his family are in mint state. Found in the 9veh excavations in the 1929-30 season.
disposition: British Museum (154 coins); the Birmingham City Art Gallery (17 coins); Sir Charles Hyde (25 coins); Bagdad museum (196)

summary: 1 solidus and 49+ siliquae, found during building work in Whiltey (Reading). 50 coins are in Reading museum and some doubt has been cast on the number (47, 70?) said to be in other hands, or whether theses coins actually came from this hoard at all. The list given here lists only the coins in the Reading museum.
At least 250 siliquae but only 20 siliquae entered museum collection: Constantius II (AD 355-361).
disposition: National Museum of Ethnography and Natural History, Chișinău, Moldova; inv.nos. 13.415/AR 6.902-6.921

summary: Few hundreds, 150 were documented: Republic - Commodus (AD 186-187).
132 denarii: Republican through to Augustus C CAES AVG F. Notable for absence of legionary denarii
disposition: Museum of Municipium Bucharest, Romania (122 coins); Bruckenthal Museum, Sibiu, Romania (10 coins)

summary: 46 imitations of antoniniani (radiates) of the Tetricus I and II (AD 271-274)and unidentified onject (button?).

1300 antoniniani (radiates). "Due to the poor state of preservation of the radiates hidden in Varzi, which were completely covered by corrosive elements… The first group of 95 radiates were restored between 2020 and 2021 […] The issuing authorities are Gallienus (3%), Claudius II (64%), Quintillus (8%) and Aurelianus (3%). The remaining part (22%) consists of unidentifiable specimens. Only 43 radiates can be attributed (for now) to a specific mint: the majority to the Siscia 1 (86%), followed by Rome (11%) and Mediolanum (3%)."
disposition: Soprintendenza Archeologia Belle Arti e Paesaggio, Pavia, Italy

summary: 337 antoniniani, "almost all of them bearing the portraits of Claudius II and Tetricus I" (AD 271-274).
Hoard of 21 sestertii. Among them coins of Domitian, Nerva, Hadrianus and Antoninus Pius (AD 138).
(8-10 kg) 36 antoniniani (radiates) of Claudius II, Aurelian, Tacitus, Florian, Probus, Carinus, Magna Urbica, Numerian, Diocletian, Numerian (AD 293-294)

A very large hoard of approximately 25 or 30000 coins (Severus Alexander - Gallic Empire, probably Victorinus), found in Friedrich-Wilhelm-Strasse. The coins were dispersed. 907 of them are listed in FMRD, in 6 different lists according to the place where the coins are kept today: 1) 595 coins in the RLMT Trier (FMRD 30643) 2) 54 coins in the RLMT Trier, with mention 'probably from that hoard' (FMRD 30644) 3) 41 coins bought by the RLMT Trier in 1925 from a private collector (FMRD 30645) 4) 30 coins in the RGM Köln (FMRD 30646) 5) 1 coin in private coll. (FMRD 30647) 6) 186 coins bought by the archaeological Museum in Zagreb in 1906/7 (FMRD 30648)
disposition: RLMT Trier; RGM Köln; private collection Lückger, Germany; Archaeological Museum, Zagreb, Croatia

summary: In 1925 a hoard comprising 1081 bronze coins, originally included in a pottery vessel, was found after agricoltural works. Coins inlcuded in this hoard returned to the finders and went missing, except for 1 sestertius of Didia Clara now kept in the Museum Bottacin in Padua. Only a brief report on the coins included in the hoard is now available.

Listed on the website of the Penrith and Eden Museum (accessed 10.10.2014): "Roman and Romano-Alexandrian coins found in the vicinity of Low Borrow Bridge Roman Fort near Tebay, Cumbria.The coins were recently donated to Penrith Museum by the great granddaughter of James Day, who was a Railway Engineer on the stretch of the Lancaster to Carlisle Railway, which runs through the upper Lune Gorge and over Shap Fell.They were found by workmen operating in the area adjacent to the Roman Fort at Low Borrow Bridge.The coins consist of 4teen Constantinian issues of the AD 330s, which, because of the homogeneity of the wear and general condition almost certainly constitute the whole or part of a savings-hoard; the remainder are all aes-issues from the mint at Rome or the city-mint at Alexandria. Some of these may safely be regarded as casual losses of the Roman period."
450 denarii: Republic - Augustus (27 BC -AD 14.
disposition: Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Cividale, Italy

summary: 6 or possibly 7 aurei ranging from Nero (either 3 or 4 aurei) to Domitian, found on the farm at Brooholm.
189 antoniniani (radiates) found together in the theater of Caesaraugusta: Valerian I - Tetricus I (AD 271-274). Work in progress.
112 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel with 1 handle: 34 antoniniani, 78 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2745

summary: 77 coins: 11 denarii, 39 antoniniani (radiates), 12 AR, 10 sestertii 5 AE: Tiberius - Postumus (AD 266-267); silver w8: 31.3-136.1 g.
36 solidi: Honorius - Basiliscus (AD 475-476); gold w8: 160.2 g.

The hoard comprised 26 coins, mostly large bronzes. 13 coins were broken. The others bear the portraits of Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Lucilla. The 4 bronze coins of Postumus are cast and middle size (AD 264-265?).
disposition: Musée Saint-Jean, Angers, France (Reg. II, p. 184, no. 453 bis.)

summary: 126 denarii: Galba – Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
disposition: Coin Room, Library of the Romanian Academy, Bucharest, Romania (inv.no. 1524)

summary: The hoard comprised 120-500 silver coins of the First and Second Jewish Revolts.
19 nummi foud spread an area of 20 sqcm on pavement in the vill urbana: Constantius II - Theodius I (AD 393-395).
74 nummi of the House of Theodosius I found in a layer of ashes in a Roman villa.

A hoard of 298 aurei dating from Nero to Lucius Verus was discovered in Vienna in 1799 during the construction of the Wiener Neustadt Canal. Of the 298 aurei, 24 were stolen and 274 initially were recovered. There is information for 279 coins: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). The average w8 of the coins was 6.3g.
disposition: Münzkabinett, Kunsthistorischen Museum, Vienna, Austria (191 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 70 nummi, of which 18 were cleaned, dated between AD 330-335 and AD 351-361.
2 nummi of Magnentius/Decentius (AD 350-353).
61 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).

1 of 3 coin hoards found in a villa on 8een Acre Field, all buried just before the end of the 3rd c. AD. 114 coins lying in a kind of trench, below the bottom of the opening near the stoves, ranging from Gallienus to Carausius.
23 coins (2 denarii; 21 provincial coins: Dium, Thessalonica, Koinon of Macedonia) found in grave 12 in Sevasti.
230 provincial coins of Alexandria: Nero - Galba (AD 68-69). Found in a jar during excavations of a house.
Iron Age gold, silver and copper alloy units, as well as a Republican denarius and 1 Roman as of Augustus, found from 2008 to 2010 by several people.
The hoard comprised 'a vessel containing 100 sestertii': Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

A group of 6 coins (Marcus Aurelius - Valens, including a provincial issue of Tium), found in an iron box, discovered during excavation work on the premisses of a house on the main street of Niebüll, in the soil approx. 1 1/2 meters deep. It is possible that some coins were dispersed and not recovered.
49 coins were discovered near an ancient settlement during archaeological excavations: 31 antoniniani, 17 denarii, 1 provincial bronze: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
7 imperial AE found with 7 skeletons in regio IX, insula 14, vestibulum of building C (house).
54 silver coins: 26 antoniniani, 28 denarii: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver w8: 72.6-130.1 g.
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. CCXX

summary: 200 denarii, 36 recovered: Titus – Septimius Severus.
6 bronze coins: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
A hoard of 402 silver coins: 31 tetradrachms (Marcus Aurelius - Macrinus), 370 denarii (Nero - Caracalla) and 1 tridrachm (Trajan) found in 2 jars at Dura Europos.
386 denarii: Mark Antony - Severus Alexander (AD 231).
186 coins: 185 antoniniani (radiates), 1 billon Alexandrian drachm: Gallienus - Maximian I. Circumstances of find not known.

HER record of a hoard of 190 coins found with a ceramic pot base in High Wycombe under the roots of a tree. Described variously as having a date range AD 240-400 and "of approximately early 4th century date". Dr. Cathy King studied the hoard at the Ashmolean and concluded that it was "problematic" because "some of the mid 4th century coins present never turn up in British hoards" and it had similarities with material more common in early fifth century Egypt. The finder had some archaeological experience and was not using a metal detector.
A hoard found in a field south of Castlethorpe, comprising 20 denarii and 35 bronze coins, up to Lucius Verus.
The hoard was found in a void within a Roman wall and comprised 5 sestertii: 1 Hadrian, 1 Antoninus Pius, 2 Marcus Aurelius, 1 Faustina II (AD 147-176).
47 denarii. Only 5 coins are kept in the Museum of Assen: Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 176)
73 nummi of the House of Constantine. No further details.
8 provincial bronze coins issued under Gordian III by Edessa (6 coins) and either Edessa or Carrhae (2 coins).
4 coins on PAS database centered to village - possibly a hoard or addenda to 1 of the previous hoards?Other PAS records associated with this hoard: CAM-531F17

Mint totals are given but not linked with coins. This indicates that a full listing of coins must exist. The hoard was found not far from a Roman villa, next to the ancient road (cf. Gallia 20 (1962) p. 429) The hoard was deposited in the Cabinet des Médailles de la BN. Silver: 1098, 3602 coins; Silver w8: 2577.8-6108.2
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliotheque Nationale de France

summary: 18 provincial bronze coins found in a small ceramic vessel. 16 coins entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) - Caracalla (AD 211-217).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2677, 16 coins

summary: The hoard was found in a small wooden box and comprised between 5 and 600 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).

A hoard of 310 Roman imperial denarii (from Trajan to Commodus) and their barbarian imitations was discovered by treasure hunters in November 2017 in the Kyiv region. Information about the find and the first 104 coins were published on November 29, 2017, on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity, followed by the next 117 coins on December 6, 2017. The hoard was discovered by 4 treasure hunters in a ploughed field and appears to have been partially ploughed (the coins were collected from a relatively large area). A total of 310 coins were found, which were divided among the finders (2 of the treasure hunters did not publish photos of their coins). The coins were in a hand-made vessel, a significant part of which has been preserved. A silver buckle, a bronze brooch, an iron knife with a b1 handle and a “spinning wheel-like thing” (probably a knife tip?) were also found with the coins (all artefacts are specific for the Chernyakhiv culture). The coins are very poorly preserved (heavily worn). 1 of the coins was pierced, another had a plugged hole. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
The hoard comprised 2394 bronze coins: sestertii, dupondii and asses Galba to Gordian III (AD 238-239).
Unknown initial number of coins. 55 silver coins: 10 denarii, 45 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius; silver w8: 15.3-26.2 g.
disposition: Regional History Museum of Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv. nos. M V 8541-8596

summary: The hoard comprised 700 Roman Republican denarii.
There is debate over the number of coins found. Jennepin states the total as being 100; Bernier 300: Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver w8: c.41.5-186.5g.
125 coins: 4 antoniniani (radiates), 121 nummi: Gallienus/Claudius II - Valens (AD 364-367) or Valentinian II/Arcadius (AD 383-408) (Pinto 2007, p. 156).

Several hundreds coins (principally of Nerva, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, and Faustina), found in 1842, while removing some sods from the surface of a piece of moss land. 3 publications (see under references) list groups of coins belonging to this hoard. Some coins had marks indicating that the hoard had been buried in a bag of coarse cloth. 1 further denarius of Trajan in HCC, p. 34, no. 207, Glasgow.
A hoard of 138 denarii (Galba - Hadrian), found at Sleddle Mouth, Mallerstang Edge, concealed in a hole in the ground and covered by a flat st1.
disposition: Carlisle Museum and Art Gallery (part); British Museum (part)

summary: 4 denarii, unknown whether they were found together or were part of a larger hoard: Titus, Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Faustina II, Crispina. Most likely

150 bronze coins of the Lower Empire (for the most part illegible, the faces and figures sufficiently plain), found in 1815, during the demolition of a tumulus. A farmer in the neighbourhood had 2 or 3 of gold, though the Crispus coin (CRISPVS NOB CAES/VOT XX 2 Victories) is actually an AE issue.

A hoard of 39 antoniniani (Gordian III and Philip I) was discovered by a treasure hunter in the middle of November 2017 in Khmelnytskyi region. Information about the hoard and photos of the coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity on November 14, 2017. There is no additional information about the conditions of hoard find. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
218 nummi: Constantine I - Constantius II (AD 341-346).
2239 coins: 4 antoniniani (radiates), 2181 sestertii, 6 dupondii, 1 as, 47 cast sestertii: Republic - Valerian and Gallienus (AD 254-256); circa 50 kilos.
disposition: Gabinetto Numismatico di Milano, Italy (inv.nos. M.0.9.22769-M.0.9.25007)

summary: In 1968 a person came upon a hexagonal water tank with a circuit and a cellar on the east side of Neumarkt during the construction of a railway entry. 34 coins lay in the infilling of a pit under the cellar between porphyry and marble remnants. The pot/jar found probably served as a m1y bank.
Unknown initial number of coins. 6 coins in the museum of Lovech. No further information.
Hoard of 41 silver coins: 15 denarii, with 2 didrachms, 23 drachms, and 1 hemidrachm minted in Caesarea in Cappadocia: Tiberius – Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).

4 gold coins apparently found at a 2001 metal detecting rally at Climping. Another 3 were recorded by a private collector. As this rally took place on different fields to those searched in 2000 and 2002, the coins were presumably not associated with the original Climping hoard.
7 coins found in a m1y-box: 1 denarius, 1 plated denarius, 3 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 1 as: Nerva - Philip I (Marcia Otacilia Severa) (AD 246-247).
disposition: County Museum of History and Art, Zalău, Romania (inv.nos. M 29)

summary: 11 Celtic staters. The hoard was found when an old tree was uprooted.
Hoard of 1000 nummi (AE4). No further information.
50 denarii found with a Dacian ceramic vessel: Republic – Augustus (14-2 BC).
disposition: National Museum of Union, Alba Iulia, Romania

summary: The hoard comprised a vessel containing 3000 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I described as being small in size and therefore likely to be barbarous.
Around 500 denarii. Only 3 are known from Domitian and Trajan.
disposition: Muzeum Archeologiczne i Etnograficzne w Łodzi, Poland (3 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 60 silver coins, almost all of Gallienus (AD 253-268).
Hoard of 36 coins of the Bosporan kings, of Theothorses, Rhadamsades, Rhescuporis VI (AD 295-327).
5 denarii (Vespasian - Hadrian) found together in Rottweil, in the south of the Roman city (Parzelle 969/3, Firma Mahle).

in 1852 on a hoard was dug out on a hill in a peat deposit of the Landstuhl municipality, on the island called Krimm. 11 silver coins (denarii and antoniniani, Geta - Philip) were published, but it remains unclear if this is the entire find or not.
76 gold coins found in the 9ties: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD

A set of 7 gold pendants made of solidi from the Constantinian period was found by a treasure hunter near Bronnaja Hara village in the spring of 2018. The 6 coins available for study were struck between the years 335 and 347. All of them had fluted suspension loops attached, uniform in type, and pointing to the integral rather than combined nature of the set. The coin-pendants could either be a hoard or a part of a funeral assemblage.
122 Iron Age coins, found in a field. No precise information on their context in known.
The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel hidden under a st1 and comprised 3 coins including a sestertius of Nerva, a denarius of Trajan and an as of Hadrian.
(c. 300) 143 described denarii: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211); silver w8: c. 550.3-937.7 g
disposition: Musée des Beaux-Arts de Chambéry , France (12 coins); the rest entered various private collections: Serand, Gaillard, Périssou etc.)

summary: The hoard was found by a worker preparing the ground in a vineyard. Silver: 1328 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-260); silver w8: 360.9-3450.5 g.
In a bronze bucket 951 bronze coins: Augustus - Postumus (AD 260-261).
61 coins found during fieldwalking and research at the place: 59 antoniniani, 2 denarii: Elagabalus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 255-257).
8 sestertii of Tiberius found in a ceramic vessel. All of the same type RIC 48 (Rome, AD 22-23).
810 silver coins: Trajan - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver w8: 1014.2-2363.7 g.
4418 tetradrachms of Alexandria and 3 bronze coin: Claudius I - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus). 3 large amphorae, filled with coins, dug out of the cellar of a house.
disposition: Type set of 519 coins in Oxford. 114 in London. 80 billon coins, presented to Glasgow in 1902 by the Egypt Exploration Fund and now among the duplicates, probably belong to this hoard. The rest dispersed. Detailed list in Oxford

summary: 2 coins: solidus of Anastasius (AD 491-518), denarius of Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161) found on a site of an old dwelling.
It is not clear whether this hoard forms part of the hoard found within the well in 1869 (See 5528). The vessel contained between 141 and 144 bronze coins from Augustus to Postumus.
3 solidi of Magnus Maximus (AD 383-388).
Originally 16 denarii, 15 preserved: Domitian - Septimius Severus(AD 193-211); silver w8: 42.63 g. (15 coins).

A group of 13 antoniniani (Gallienus - Tetricus), found in Wehde, which is the location of a Saxon urn burial ground (2nd - 5th c. AD). It is uncertain whether the coins lay together in an urn or whether they were spread out in different urns. In 1886 the coins were purchased by LM Han. from a private owner. Addressed as Hoard?/Gave find? in FMRD.
174 provincial bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel. Mints of Lower Moesia and Thrace. No further information on the issuers.
12 nummi found with an amphora in a Roman complex: Constantine I - Arcadius (AD 383-408).
A hoard of 120+ Syrian tetradrachms dating from Caracalla to Trebonianus Gallus.
ca. 1500 to 2000 coins, but only 528 are identified: Valerian I - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
The hoard, discovered during excavations with MAGNY-COURS 2009, comprised 497 coins: 1 antoninianus (radiate) and 496 nummii of the first Tetrarchy (tpq AD 303).
33 coins - 5 antoniniani (radiates), 28 nummi - found together leaning against the wall: Gallienus (sole) - Magnus Maximus (AD 383-388).
disposition: Museo Monográfico de Itálica, Santiponce, Spain

summary: A hoard of 965 bronze coins, ranging from the 2nd c. BC to AD 365, when it was lost during an earthquake. The coins were brought to the museum in Heraklion, with the indication they came from Knossos.

The hoard comprised 1 vessel containing a harness fitting and 800 copper-alloy and silver coins of Commodus, Pertinax, Septimius Severus, Albinus, Julia Domna, Caracalla, Plautilla, Geta, Macrinus, Elagabalus, Julia Paula, Julia Maesa, Julia Soaemias, Severus Alexander, Julia Mamaea, Orbiana, Gordian I, Pulpienus, Balbinus, Gordianus III, Philip I, Philip II, Otacilia Severa and Herennius Etruscus.
The hoard comprised 73 denarii from Septimius Severus to Maximinus and 215 radiates from Pupienus to Valerian (AD 253-260). Hobbs estimated a silver w8 of between 372.6-693.8g.
12 asses of Claudius I found together on the area of the Visigothic necropolis.

The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing approximately 900 coins of which 200 were dispersed. They included issues of Trajan, Plotina, Hadrian, Sabina, Antoninus Pius, Faustina I and II, Marcus Aurelius, Lucius Verus, Lucilla, Commodus, Crispina, Clodius Albinus and Julia Domna. The cataloguer menti1d these coins in particular: 1 of Diva Faustina, 2 coins of Divus Antoninus Pius (RIC 1262/1265 and 1274) and 1 of Commodus with a quadriga on the reverse.

Found in the necropolis of Hawara during the excavations of W.M. Flinders Petrie in 1888, in a jar and interpreted as a funeral offering by Flinders Petrie. The hoard comprised 1 small provincial bronze coin of Trajan (18 mm), 2629 late Roman coins and 369 cast imitations.
35 antoniniani (radiates), 28 seen: Marius - Tetricus (AD 271-274); silver w8: c.10.5 g.

Hoard of 460 coins: 446 antoniniani (radiates) from Elagabalus to Gallienus, 11 denarii from Caracalla to Gordian III and 3 Provincial bronzes (Septimius Severus of Hadrianoi and Gordian III of Metropolis).
disposition: National Museum, Athens, Greece (124 coins and the list of the entire hoard)

summary: A hoard of circa 4000 nummi from the time of Constantine I. Lost.
1152 specimens - late antique bronze coins and remains of a container were found.
76 coins: 48 antoniniani (radiates), 28 provincial bronzes: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of History, Stara Zagora, Bulgaria; inv. no. 1938. Stolen

summary: 5 nummi of the first Tetrarchy (tpq AD 302-303) discovered in a grave from a necropolis.

The hoard comprised a red ceramic vessel containing between 1000 and 1200 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 denarius. Pilloy saw approximately 300 of these coins and commented that 5/6ths were of Gallienus (particularly his zoo issue) and of Claudius II or Divus Claudius II. The remainder were of Salonina, Quintillus, Victorinus, Aurelian, Severina and Numerian, with the last 3 authorities represented by 1 coin each.

The hoard comprised 35 Iron Age coins and 1 obol from Massalia. It was characterised as being 1 of 16 individual votive deposits found at the site of an important Gallo-Roman sanctuary during excavations. Inventory No: 76.062
5864 coins found in 2 vessels: 5283 antoniniani (radiates), 10 denarii and 571 nummi: Severus Alexander - Tetrarchy (AD 302-303).
The hoard comprises 17 asses from Vespasian to Hadrian (AD 117-138).
1 solidus of Leo I and 15 denarii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 457-474); gold w8: 4.26 g.; silver w8: 38.50 g.
16 aurei: Vespasian - Trajan (AD 107-110).
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 300 Roman coins including denarii, dupondii, asses and radiates terminating in a single issue of Postumus.
Unknown originally number of coins. The hoard comprised 28 sestertii from Gordian III to Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).

The hoard comprised a coarseware vessel containing silver and billon coins (denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Although the hoard was immediately dispersed, 183 coins were examined by M. Le Pesant: Antoninus Pius - Postumus (AD 260-269)
The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing 30 bronze coins of Antoninus Pius. A bronze bell was found at the same findspot.
185 coins: 4 antoniniani (radiates), 1 solidus, 180 nummi: Gallienus (sole) - Honorius (AD 408-423). Together was found a scale w8.

The hoard comprised approximately 1200 antoniniani (radiates). The following emperors were represented: Valerian, Mariniana, Gallienus, Salonina, Saloninus and Claudius II. It also included a radiate of Macrianus (SOLI INVICTO) and 3 of Postumus (CONCORD EQVIT; MONETA AVG; and P M TR P COS II P P). The last coin is a DIVO CLAVDIO radiate with eagle reverse.
The hoard comprised a vessel containing 150 nummi, mostly from the mint of Trier dating to the period AD 323/4 and AD 347/348.
The hoard comprised 30 Republican and Imperial denarii of which only 5 were identified.
307 denarii: Republic – Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Muzeul Județean de Istorie și Arheologie Maramureș, Baia Mare, Romania

summary: 9 solidi: Honorius - Leo I (AD 457-474); Gold w8: 40.05 g.
2 solidi (Eugenius and Arcadius) and 7 siliquae (all of AD 394-402). All the coins were found together within an area defined by using a radius of 14 metres.

A number of late Roman coins, found by railroad workers in the vicinity of Bischleben during gravel quarrying. In doing so most of the coins were scattered and lost, and only the listed 6 specimens were salvaged.
The hoard comprised 54 antoniniani (radiates) of Postumus with a FELICITAS AVGVSTI reverse type. The hoard was found 20 meters from the deposit found in 1865 at Fontaine Saint-Aubin.
The coins (9 sestertii, Marcus Aurelius to Gordian III) were found during building work on the premises of Neckarhalde.
450 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic urn: Philip I - Valerian I and Galienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).
The hoard comprised 66 bronze coins, dated between AD 341-346 and AD 476-491.

A summary of the coins in this hoard exists, but gives family names rather than identifications for Republican denarii. The hoard was discovered in a crevice in the rocks amongst a mass of carbonised material.
(128) 126 siliquae: Constantius II (AD 355-361).
disposition: National Museum of Ethnography and Natural History, Chișinău, Moldova; inv.nos. 2.545/AR 950-1.075 (coins), 2.545/A 35/1 (vessel)

summary: Over 200 solidi found with a small red ceramic vessel. Only 13 coins were recovered: Gratian - Honorius (AD 393-395)
disposition: The National History Museum of Moldova, Kishinev (13 coins) - 1952

summary: 67 nummi found scattered on very small area of a preafurnium: House of Constantine - House of Valentinian (AD 364-375)
The hoard comprised 72 Provincial bronzes, 70 of Gallienus from Lacedaemon, 1 of Septimius Severus from Gytheion and 1 of Caracalla from Mantineia.
145 denarii: Republic – Augustus (27 BC – AD 14). Today, lost.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 40 'middle bronzes' of the 4th and fifth centuries AD.
23 antoniniani (radiates): Claudius II - Tetricus I (AD 271-274; silver w8: 0.4-0.6g.
In 1908, 6 denarii (Domitian to Antoninus Pius) were found lying together at the entrance of cellar 208 (in the vicus surrounding the Roman fort).

A hoard of 543 tetradrachms (Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus), antoniniani (Gordian III - Gallienus) and 1 bronze coin (Gordian III) found at Dura Europos, in a house near the city wall which had been buried in the great embankment with which the walls themselves were reinforced.

A small hoard in a clay vessel was found. It was apparently of the same type as TAF I. 4 from Bourg-d'Hem (4 radiates ending in Gallienus/Postumus). The hoard was dispersed before it could be studied although 1 coin of Postumus was acquired by the Musée de Guéret.
The hoard comprised 15 bronze coins found under the doorway of the great room at the west end of the façade" (Kelso 1950, 20).
51H includes the coins which were found in front of the temple, in the court by an urn.
A find of 45 Roman denarii (Otho - Antoninus Pius) was made in a garden in Vicht. The coins were found in charcoal residues.
7 antoniniani (radiates) of Postumus (AD 260-269).
2 Gallo-Belgic C staters recorded in trade, possibly a small hoard.
The hoard comprised 50 aurei dating to the reign of Nero and Vespasian. Only 2 coins are known are the moment.

Unknown originally number of gold coins. Only 7 pieces are known: 5 aurei, 2 solidi: Severus Alexander (2), Trajan Decius, Valerian I and Gallienus for Gallienus, Constantine I, Arcadius, Theodosius II; gold w8: 34.87-38.95 g.

126 nummi: Constantine I - Theodosius I (Aelia Flacilla) (AD 379-386) Mints: Londinium 1, Treveri 39, Lugdunum 13, Arelate 7, Aquileia 1, Roma 6, Heraclea 2, Constantinopolis 3, Alexandria 2, unidentified 28.
disposition: Musées royaux des Beaux-Arts de Belgique (126 coins)

summary: Coins, jewelry, lamps and pot. 1 solidus Vetranio; 3 nummi: Divus Maximianus, Constantius II. Clay pot, 3 lamps, 1 cameo hanging on a gold chain, 3 bracelets, 2 earrings, 1 ring, 1 gold necklace, 1 silver belt buckle
8 bronze coins. According to Boersma 1967, no. 164, they are dated around 16 BC - AD 14. No further information.
A hoard of 7 provincial coins (Thessalonica, Nero) found in a grave in the region of Serres, placed in a vase.
666 coins: 665 denarii, 1 drachm: Nero – Antoninus Pius (AD 140).

The hoard was found in a well under the Roman ramparts and comprised 18 denarii from Septimius Severus to Severus Alexander and 8 antoniniani (radiates) from Philip I to Trebonianus Gallus. All the coins were from the mint of Rome, with the exception of a denarius of Severus Alexander from Antioch and 2 denarius copies of Caracalla and Severus Alexander.
100-200 silver coins. Only 4 coins are known: 1 denarius, 3 antoniniani: Septimius Severus (Caracalla) - Gordian III (AD 241-243).

The hoard comprised a vessel containing a copper-alloy finger ring, 2 gold finger rings, 1 with an engraved intaglio setting and 2334 denarii and radiates from Antoninus Pius to Postumus. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of 702.5g to 6042.8g.

Portions of this hoard were acquired by the ANS in 1911 and 1912, totaling 783 coins. 451 of these could be identified in the museum's collection, including 448 denarii, Vespasian to Commodus (AD 183-184) and 3 Cypriote didrachms of Vespasian. This hoard is said to have been discovered in Larnaka, though no details are available.
Around 800 denarii of wchich 189 provided information on the issuers: Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192).
601 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel: Septimius Severus - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
201 sestertii from Domitian to Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 254-255).
9 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195).
Unknown originally number of denarii. 10 coins were seen: Vespasian 2, Trajan 4, Antoninus Pius 1, Marcus Aurelius 3. Possible, part of the same hoard with Strunga II and III.
2 denarii: Trajan, Marcus Aurelius.
5 gold coins (Nero and Titus) closely packed together in the clay floor of an early structure, at Vagniacae (Springhead).

4 copper alloy coins (1 provincial coin from Antioch and 3 local SC imitations produced in Hatra), acquired from locals at Hatra, during the Assur excavations by the Deutsche Orient-Gesellschaft, 1903–1913. These coins could be a hoard or single finds.
2 nummi found in an early medieval burial (Alemannic).
Unknown initial number of coins. G. Dembski expresses his doubts about the cois issued before the reform of AD 348 being part of the hoard: Antoninus Pius - Gratian (AD 367-383).
27 denarii: Republic - Nerva (AD 97).
Unknown number of silver coins found on a field where a grave was found: 1 denarius Augustus, 1 antoninanus (radiate) Gordian III. A brooch was found withe coins. No further Details on it.
4 Alexandria tetradrachm: Claudius II- Tacitus (AD 275-276).
disposition: Museo Arch. Reg. "P. Orsi", Siracusa, Italy (inv.nos: 49600-49603)

summary: 2042 Roman bronze coins. Confirmation required. No further information.
The hoard comprised 377 antoniniani (radiates) of which only 198 were studied by Debray: Gordian III - Tetricus I (AD 271-274). Hobbs estimated a silver w8 of between 102.8-470.3g.
(c.700) 601 bronze coins: 598 sestertii (+ imitations), 2 dupondii, 1 as: Vespasian - Postumus (AD 262).
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (37 coins); in 1959, 13 private collectors: 564 coins

summary: 16 copper alloy coins from a pit on the same site as the Snodland hoard, found during archaeological excavation. All 16 coins were nummi, mostly of the House of Constantine dated to AD 330-335 but the latest coin identified was a slightly worn coin of Magnentius, AD 350-353.
c. 300 sestertii from Hadrian to Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). No further information about composition of hoard.
disposition: Archaeological Museum Zagreb, Croatia; dispersed; Ervin Meixner coll.

summary: 9 nummi found in a sandpit: Constantine I - Theodosius I (AD 388-393).
60 denarii (Nero to Domitian), but only 1 is known and recorded.
Uknown number of denarii and antoniniani found in a ceramic vessel. 9 denarii are kept in the museum collection in Popovo: Marcus Aurelius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
2 clipped solidi of Anastasius (AD 491-518) found in a grave dated in the period of the Tang dynasty.
(4-5 kg) 280 silver coins: 75 denarii, 205 antoniniani: Vespasian - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-260); silver w8: 367.8-888.5 g.
(c. 300000) silver coins: 1 denarius, 4463 antoniniani/radiates: Marcus Aurelius - Tacitus (AD 275-276).
Unknown originally number of coins. The hoard initially contained gold and silver coins. 95 denarii were documented: Republic - Vespasian (AD 74-75).
disposition: Local history museum, Simferopol, (31 coins); Local Museum, Evpatoria (26 coins), Crimea; The gold coins were sold to a private collector

summary: The hoard comprises 51 antoniniani (radiates) from Gallienus to Tetricus I with a tpq of AD 274.
25 provincial bronze coins: Caracalla - Gordian III (AD 238-244). Mints: Nicopolis ad Istrum, Marcianopolis, Hadrianopolis
disposition: Regional History Museum, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1780 1-25

summary: 10 silver coins: 9 denarii, 1 antoniniani(radiate) (AD 251-253).
The hoard comprised 311 nummi dated between the reigns of Constantius II and Honorius/Arcadius.
Hoard found with pot: 19 denarii, 8 antoniniani (radiates), 4 sestertii: Marcus Aurelius - Gallienus (sole) (AD 267-268).

A hoard of 47 late Roman coins, found on the area of a former Roman villa rustica, in front of a glas furnace (Context 1482). These archaeological remains prove that this area was still in use in the 4th / 5th century AD. The coins were found compacted close together which might indicate that they were packed together in a bag which is lost.
56 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Probus (AD 276-282).

A hoard of 1290 nummi (aes 3), from the reign of Constantine I (AD 306-337) with the latest coins dating from AD 332-335, found near Bubendorf, in the forest in the vicinity of Castle Wildenstein. The coins were found in a pot and a piece of leather divided the coins into 2 parts.
Hoard of 9 aurei found in a ceramic vessel: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius 3, Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) 1, Marcus Aurelius 4 (AD 177-178).

296 AE radiates to AD 286. The coins were 1.5ft below the plough soil with no visible signs of a container. A circular, corroded stud with a narrow band and possible inscription was also discovered with the hoard. This is believed to be Medieval or post-Medieval and, as such, is not considered part of the hoard. A farthing (Seaby, 3992) was also found with the coins during conservation.Addenda of 618 coins found in 2104 added here.
25 nummi found in the prafurnium channel: Constantine - Constans/Constantius II (AD 348-350).
2 solidi, Honorius and Theodosius II, found during some demolition works. Uncertain whether they were found together.
The hoard(?) comprised a "cluster" of 13 silver and bronze coins deposited during the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
The hoard comprised 73 aurei from Augustus to Domitian found with an earthenware.
A hoard of 206 Iron Age staters found close to where a second, smaller hoard of 50 staters was found.
Around 60 coins, 41 pieces are known: Vespasian – Theodosius II (AD 408-450).
disposition: Museum of Moravia, Brno, Czech Republic; Collection Červinkova

summary: The hoard comprised 93 silver coins dated between AD 211-218.
17 coins: imitation antoniniani (radiates), nummi: Tetricus I - House of Theodosius I (AD 388-402).

The hoard comprised approximately 600 silver coins (denarii and radiates). The antoniniani (radiates) were described as being of 'large and medium module' according to Bocquillet. There were 38 different types from Commodus to Postumus Found during embankment works for the Château-l'Abbaye road.

Hoard of 36 coins (31 bronze and 6 silver) "from 76 BC to AD 180 or 270" found during Pitt Rivers' excavations at the settlement site of Woodcutts, 6penny Handley. Said to have been found with the remains of a bronze-mounted casket near a hearth, possibly within a house."... the discovery here, within an oblong area of ' depression ' and near a hearth, of the remains of a bronze-mounted ornamental casket, with glass, a silver spoon, a penannular brooch, etc., and 31 bronze and 6 silver coins, from Claudius I to Claudius II (268-70)". (Hawkes, C.F.C. 1947, 'Britons, Romans, and Saxons Round Salisbury and in Cranborne Chase: reviewing the excavations of General Pitt-Rivers, 1881-1898' Archaeological Journal 104, p.46).
89 coins found spread close to each other in a domestic building: Celtoiberic - Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
