A hoard of 30 or 40 coins, packed in clay in the form of rouleau. 8 of them were of Trajan. The others are of Trajan, Tiberius.
The hoard comprised 53 antoniniani (radiates) (AD 270-275, Aurelian).

11 antoniniani (radiates) found with a small ceramic vessel in a well: Gordian III - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253). The hoard was found together with a brooch and/or a Gold ring (according to Dembski).
2 solidi, 1 of Theodosius II minted in Rome (AD 430-440).
c. 400 nummi, 172 saved for the museum in Zagreb (1883): Constantius I, Constantius III Gallus, Julian (AD 355-363).

Hoard found over a period of period of several months, with a first coin found in 2007 already. In 2009, the con10t was listed (treasure case 2009 T465) as 5 solidi (all Honorius), 12 siliquae (Julian to Honorius), 1 nummus (Constantine II Caesar) and 1 gold finger ring. A further 1 denarius, 2 solidi, and 19 siliquae were found in 2010 (2010 T670).
The hoard(?) comprised 7-9 coins that were scattered on a living surface, deposited around AD 317.

Late 3rd - early 4th century. 7 coins of Gallienus, Claudius II, Constantine I & 2 radiates, found together in short c. 4m) excav. section of shrine enclosure ditch near entrance, with a glass bead & a cu alloy knife handle. Poss. another small hoard. The Snow's Farm/HAD III shrine complex was an octagonal shrine within a sub-square enclosure, built on top of a BA round barrow. Investigated by Bromwich in 1950s, then fully excav. in 1983. Evansand Hodder 2006 pp. 352-363. Coin report by Reece.

1 drachm of Caesarea in Cappadocia (Julia Domna) and 78 antoniniani (radiates) (Julia Maesa to Gallienus), found in the northwest-west suburb of Kerch. 71 of these were published by N. Kunina in 1962. To these, Golenko adds a further 8 antoniniani.

The hoard comprised approximately 60 Republican denarii The coins were stolen and presumably melted down soon after their discovery according to Madame Malva Vincent, Director of Excavations at Portus Magnus.
74 silver coins. No further information
7 solidi: Valentinian III, Majorian, Leo I, Anastasius 3, 1 uncertain imitation. 9 denarii: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 186-187). On the same field was found 1 gold spiral.
The hoard comprised approx. 2500 sestertii, ranging from the 1st to the 3rd century AD, finishing under Gallienus, and found in a burial in Akriai, near Gytheion.

The hoard was found at the summit of Puy-de-Dôme amongst sherds of 1 or more ceramic vessels. It comprised approximately 800 bronze coins dating to the first century AD. Giard studied 212 coins, which equated to approximately 1 quarter of the hoard. These coins ranged in date from Augustus to Titus. The earliest coins was an as of Augustus (C. Asinius Gallus) struck in 14 BC. Numerous coins were counter-marked. TAF suggests that these were offerings (stips) to a mountain deity, which were later gathered together in a vessel.

572 silver coins: 22 denarii, 550 antoniniani (radiates): M. Aurelius (Lucilla) - Postumus (AD 268); silver w8: 180.5-1484.6 g. Found together with Gold jewelry: 1 necklace, 2 rings, 2 sets of earrings
37 sestertii: Hadrian - Elagabalus (AD 221-222).

The coins were found in a purse close to the head in Burial 160 and comprised 26 coins from Claudius II to Julian II (Caesar) along with 22 bronze and lead alloy rings. A nummus of Magnentius was found in the left hand of the burial and 2 coins of Magnentius were placed in the eye sockets of the skeleton.

Found by labourers while ploughing a field near Ibikon. The hoard consisted of 10 silver coins and 169 aes coins, in a pot. The writ10 sources name Maximinus Thrax as latest reign represented. Today only 44 aes coins are preserved: 33 coins in the Museum für Urgeschichte(n), Zug, and 11 coins in the Schweizerisches Landesmuseum, Zürich. The latest coin preserved dates from Commodus (SFI 1707-5.1) Another 12 coins, now in the Museum für Urgeschichte(n), Zug, might be part of the same hoard (SFI 1707-5.2). The latest coin of this lot dates from Gordian III.
disposition: Museum für Urgeschichte(n), Zug; Schweizerisches Landesmuseum, Zürich

summary: 344 denarii found with ceramic vessel: Nero-Septimius Severus (AD 202); silver w8: 629.0-1075.4g
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing between 2000 and 3000 coins. The hoard was immediately dispersed but contained at least 20 radiates of Gallienus and Postumus.
1486 tetradrahms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian (AD 295-296) in a disintegrated cloth bag on the floor of underground room J during excavations of a house.
A hoard of 200 coins, 'mostly silver, 10 of gold, but only a brass of Domitian', found at Crown Inn, Trafford Street, in 1840.
'Some years before 1882, on a Gallo-Roman site, a ceramic vessel containing 30 gold coins mixed with copper obols' was found.
1156 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) together with 136 bronze coins found in 2 ceramic vessels ranging from Trajan to Gallienus.
241 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver w8: 67.4-624.3 g.
512 provincial bronze coins were found in a ceramic vessel. 480 coins are kept in the museum of Sevlievo: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244)
disposition: History Museum, Sevlievo, Bulgaria; inv. no. 263

summary: 15 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
64 nummi found with a ceramic vessel within a Paleo-Christian basilica: Constantine I - Valentinian I and Valens (AD 364-375).
HER record of "7 worn minims, presumably a hoard" found by a metal detectorist in Aston Clinton in 1993.
782 nummi of the Tetrarchy (AD 294-306).

In 1981 a hoard of 159 Antoniniani of the last third of the third century (Gallienus - Diocletian, and Gallic Empire) was unearthed during excavations of the Institute for Pre- and Early history of the University of Johannes Gu10berg at Mainz. The hoard was found in a cellar.
449 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).
A hoard of ca. 300 denarii, found in 1842, during peat digging, close to the so-called 'Römerbrücke' in the Bourtanger Moor. The coins are now lost, except for 2.
Hoard of 400 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Trajan to Septimius Severus (AD 193-211). W8: 117.34g Found in woods buried under a tree.
7 coins found stuck together: 4 denarii, 1 plated denarius, 1 sestertius, 1 as: Mark Antony - Hadrian (AD 121-122).
disposition: County Museum of History and Art, Zalău, Romania (inv.no. CC 315/90)

summary: 42 coins found in a 2 sqm area on a floor from the gate tower no. 1:
30 nummi found scattered in room 65 from a Roman building: Constans - Theodosius I (AD 379-395).
Hoard of few kilos of denarii. Only 6 coins are known: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius 4, Lucilla.

The hoard comprised 11 sestertii from Domitian to Balbinus. The coins in the hoard were stacked on top of each other and corroded together, forming a cylindrical shape. It appears they were originally in a small bag or pouch which has not been preserved.
The known part of the hoard comprised 15 silver coins from the first century AD, ending with coins of the First Jewish Revolt (AD 66-73).
disposition: The Reuben and Edith Hecht Museum

summary: Hoard 141 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Elagabalus (AD 218-222). W8: 484.16g.

Udmarken on Bornholm has yielded 3 hoards with a total of 217 denarii. All 3, A, B, C, have been interpreted as being of either the same hoard or of chronologically identical hoards. A and B were found a week apart in 1853 and C was found in 1857. Udmarken B contains 53 of the 217 denarii.
1680 silver coins: 1085 denarii, 595 antoniniani: Commodus - Valerian I (Gallienus (AD 254); silver w8: 2151.6-3837.1 g.

2208 nummi of the Tetrarchy before and after the reduction of Maxentius divided by mints. Before the reduction (36 coins): Gaul 1, Rome 6, Carthage 17, Ticinum/Aquileia 12; after reduction (2172 coins): Rome 1196, Ostia 879; Carthage 29, Ticinum/Aquileia 68.

The hoard comprised 39 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Valerian I and Gallienus. They were found under a layer of burnt material and many of the coins were blackened, melted or twisted. 34 coins were minted in Rome, 3 in Viminacium and 1 in Cologne with the latest coin being a Cologne issue from AD 256 to 258. Although TAF notes the mint distribution, they are not assigned to coins of particular emperors.

Reference to this hoard on a ticket ticket with 1 of the ANTED staters in the Evans collection. 4 coins illustrated in BNJ 1 (1904), 357, nos 14-17, then in the collection of P.W.P. Carlyon-Britton, ‘may well be from this hoard’ as well. Exact ex10t of hoard uncertain.
32 coins found near altars in front of the Nemeseum: 29 antoniniani, 3 nummi: Valerian I and Gallienus - Constantine I (AD 315-316).

The first 3 coins were recovered on 24 August 1997, and the remainder of the initial 38 - consisting of 15 British Lb (ABC 2442) staters and 23 British Qb (ABC 488) staters - discovered in the first week of September. In August and October 1999 2 further staters were found at the same location, 1 each of British Lb and Qb. Another Lb type was found on 5 May 2001.
(951) 14 unknown denomination: Maximinus II Daia - Valens (AD 364-378).
3000 bronze Alexandrian coins, 'mostly drachms', 1st century and early 2nd century. Intact hoard belonging to "qualche officina m1taria".
The hoard comprised 3850 Tyrian tetradrachms, 110 drachms, and 275 Roman denarii.
disposition: Israel Antiquities Authority (737 coins: IAA 5876-5881; 8782-9512); Kadman Numismatic Pavilion at Muza Eretz Israel Museum Tel Aviv (304 coins); Kibbutz Hanita Museum (64 coins); the Rueben and Edith Hecht Museum (81 coins)

summary: Roman settlement at Rowler Manor Estate first recorded in 1991 during archaeological watching brief, when Roman pottery & 2 coin hoards were recovered. Later investigation revealed st1 building remains & 4th C. mosaic floor. APs suggest this just 1 of many buildings in much larger complex over 5ha in ex10t.During excav. in 2002, demolition layers removed from Room C, & comprised silty sand, mortar, limest1 frags., st1 & ceramic tile frags. & charcoal. Within context 12 were 14 coins of Constantinopolis to Constantius II & House of Constantine.Guest, P. 2008. The Roman coins. In M. Dawson Excavation of the Roman villa and mosaic at Rowler Manor, Croughton, Northamptonshire. Northamptonshire Archaeol. 35: 45-93.
40 denarii: Titus - Pertinax (AD 193).
32 bronze coins found glued to each other: Domitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

The hoard comprised 'numerous Roman coins, which the finder distributed amongst his friends.' The finder's daughter possessed 24 which included coins of Valerian I, Victorinus, and Tetricus I. The hoard was found during ground levelling works
115 nummi of Constantine I found with a ceramic vessel.
150 nummi of GENIO POPVLI ROMANI type of 3 different module sizes.
3 aurei: Trajan, Septimius Severus, Caracalla (AD 213).
(c. 1000) 995 silver coins: 203 denarii, 792 antoniniani: Vespasian - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-268); silver w8: 1277.0-2659.3 g.
2 denarii (Hadrian and Commodus for Crispina) and 25 solidi: Honorius - Justinian I (AD 527-565). Found together with several gold fragments and 1 piece of bronze.
disposition: Swedish History Museum, Stockholm (inv.no. 19800b ß denarii; 19130, 19310, 19536, 19800, 20214)

summary: Unknown number of silver coins. 29 coins entered the museum collection in Targovishte: Vespasian - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
Group of 4 coins: Republican (2), Augustus, Tiberius (AD 27-28) Coh. 244
disposition: Collection of J. Thomayer (1926), Hradiste, now missing

summary: 1548 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 204); silver w8: 2788.4-4765.7 g.

A large hoard of c. 22500 gold and silver coins, ranging from Claudius to Maximinus I, found in 1909 during excavation works for the construction of a house on Gertrudenstraße, approx. midway between Wolfstraße and Neumarkt. Of the c. 22500 coins found, 4513 are identifiable to RIC number. Only part of these coins are preserved today.

Unknown originally number of coins. 88 pieces were available for study: Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282). I. Pereira Rodriguez suggests that this hoard is 1 and the same with a poorly recorded hoard known only as coming from 'Serra, Portugal'.
disposition: Museu Municipal de Santiago do Cacém (Sintra), Portugal

summary: At least 38 Icenian silver units.

Hoard of around 4000 coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 166 pieces were studied: Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetrarchy (AD 292-293). Not clear whether the coins of the Tetrarchs include also nummi or only antoniniani (radiates).
11 denarii: Republic - Trajan (AD 105).
35 nummi of the Tetrarchy.

140 coins: 1 antoninianus, 139 nummi of the House of Constantine and House of Valentinian (AD 364-378). It was found in the Principia building of the fort. No further information about the context was given.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 'several hundred', '75kg' or 'approximately 3000 sestertii from Domitian to Maximinus I Thrax. The entire hoard was quickly dispersed.
(55) 17 silver coins: 9 denarii, 8 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver w8: 21.6-34.1 g.
500-600 nummi of the tetrarchs (AD 294-305).
Originally, there were 37 denarii. The hoard is incomplete, but the documented coins were 7 republican and imperial denarii. Hoard dated in 2 BC-4 AD.
A hoard of 10 coins (Republic - Claudius I), found in Moers-Arsberg, Römerstraße. All coins have banker's marks.
Preliminary record of 7teen gold staters and 9 silver units of Cunobelin, found to the south of Winslow in September 2008.
(ca.30) 12 sestertii and dupondii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Pleven, Bulgaria; auxiliary fund, inv.no. 693

summary: 10 denarii (Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius) found corroded together with a bronze fibula and a clasp. They might have been contained in a purse.
The hoard comprised 96 bronze coins from the Bar Kokhba Revolt (AD 132-135/6).
Group of 38 bronze coins: 28 sestertii, 3 dupondii, 7 asses: Nero - Postumus (AD 260-268).
2 denarii and 436 radiates (Septimius Severus to the Tetrici), 2 silver finger rings, and 1 small silver ingot found beneath a st1 by workers widening a road between Amlwch and Bull Bay.
Unknown number of coins. Gallic staters (unepigraphic and VIROS inscription), 4 republican denarii, imperial denarii ending with 1 denarius of Tiberius (AD 14-37).
300 aurei: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

Around 300 coins of various periods and denominations: Carthaginian 2 ; republican and early empire 51; late empire 120; uncertain (imperial) 50; asses 23; fragmentary 55. Issuers: Augustus, Claudius I, Nero, Galba, Vitellius, Domitian, Antoninus Pius.
52 coins: 1 denarius, 31 antoniniani (radiates), 5 antoniniani (radiates) imitations, 12 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 2 unknown denomination: Vespasian - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 5 denarii are known: Tiberius - Antoninus Pius (Marcus Aurelius Caesar) (AD 145-160).
50 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
Found during excavations, early medieval cemetery. Tomb 476: inhumation, female; among grave goods 4 Aes coins, part of the "Gehänge"
9 coins: 2 republican denarii 4 sestertii, 2 asses, 1 bronze coin. Among them issues Claudius I and Vespasian.

The hoard was found during excavations directed by the Direction des Antiquités Historiques de Poitou-Charentes on the site of the Trésorerie Générale: Claudius II (Divus) - House of Constantine I (AD 347-348).
The hoard comprised 497 coins, including 2 denarii and 495 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 257-260).
The hoard comprised '20 coins of which the most recent was an issue of Marcus Aurelius' The hoard was discovered by peat cutters.

HER record of a hoard of 120 4th century nummi, "bronze coins of Constantine I, and Helena". The source is given as Devizes Museum daybook, 1903. This hoard does not appear to be recorded elsewhere, although it could possibly be related to the pot from the same parish in Devizes Museum.
61 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel: Hadrian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251). Found together with a bronze brooch.
disposition: Regional History Museum Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. M IV 8346-8406

summary: 600+ late Roman gold coins, found by labourers in a Sand-Pit at Eye in 1781. It included coins of Valentinian, Gratian, Valentinian II, Theodosius I, Arcadius, Honorius and Constantine III.

The hoard comprised an unknown number of Roman coins, which was divided in 2 by the finder. 1 part was melted down and used to make buttons, chains and a watch. The other part included 3 sestertii and 5 radiates from Trajan to Trajan Decius. It is possible that this hoard is part of 1 known as Lusigny A.
2 solidi - Valentinian I, Theodosius I - found at the same spot, different years.
Le Musée de la Société des Antiquaires de l'Ouest acquired 4 staters and 1 drachm from this hoard. 70 to 75 of the staters were dispersed among numerous collectors or melted down.
2 boar/horse B silver units stuck together.

During the excavation of the signal station at Carr Naze, Filey, 2 hoards of small brass coins were found, 1 of 110 coins, the other of 22 coins, ranging from Carausius to Arcadius and Honorius. This is hoard A, comprising 110 nummi up to AD 402. Robertson lists 110 coins but as few reverse types are given, Craster's list has been used here.
3 coins of Postumus were found in the basement area of the hypocaust heating room inside the main building of a villa rustica located north-east of Niederzier, in the 'München Busch' wooded area.
The hoard comprised approximately 400 silver coins of Augustus, all in mint condition.

In 1961 a Roman layer was uncovered during earth movement for the north-south shaft north of Cäcilienstraße. 1 found a destruction layer with burnt silt, plaster, roofing tile, charcoal, iron nails, and 209 coins. It is certain that here a house was destroyed by fire, and at it the coins must have existed together in a container.
Group of 5 coins: Tiberius (Divus Augustus) as, Claudius I as, Nero 1 denarius, 1 sestertius, Hadrian sestertius (AD 117-138).
Hoard of circa 100 coins. Only 2 pieces are known: Claudius I sestertius, Caracalla provincial bronze minted in Serdica.

The find comprised 65 coins of Hadrian and Antoninus Pius, 7 copper-alloy figurines, a st1 figurine of Sucellus, some copper-alloy and glass plates, a scythe, some knives, an amphora, moulded glazed cups, bells, an incense burner, a triangular st1 pediment and some carbonised cereals.
40 aurei found in a ceramic atramentarium (inkpot): Augustus - Claudius I (AD 41-42).
2 Ingoldisthorpe staters (a new type at the time of discovery) found in 1988.

A pit dug through remains of building 2/3 at Alchester Road, contained small hoard of 3 coins of Claudius Gothicus (268-70) found "cemented together in a stack". The pit fill was black, very ashy with burnt & smithing material mixed with unburnt st1. This demonstrates with other examples in area pattern of coin discard comparable to smaller urban foci elsewhere, though there are interesting anomalies within the Towcester group that would reward further study.Brown, A.E. & Woodfield, C. 1983. Excavations at Towcester, Northamptonshire: the Alchester Road Suburb. Northamptonshire Archaeology 18, 43-140
Hoard of circa 100 antoniniani (radiates), only 7 were recovered, period of AD 260-275; silver w8: c. 28.0-124.0 g.
180 bronze coins: Trajan - Caracalla (AD 211-217).
Hoard of more than 4000 coins found with a ceramic vessel: Severus Alexander (Julia Mamaea) sestertius - Honorius.

A hoard found in Barton Wood, consisting of nearly a gallon measure of Roman brass coins. The coins, from being originally deposited in a box, had become so corroded, that they were unable easily to be separated, and in the attempt to effect this separation by a strong liquid the coins were rendered nearly illegible. Some were, however, rescued for the Newport Museum, and include an Augustus, a Trajan, 2 of Antoninus Pius, 2 of Lucius Verus, and 2 of Faustina, wife of Marcus Aurelius.

At least 3000 denarii were found in ceramic vessel (2 of silver and 1 of bronze, at least). A gold medallion of Jovian. Together were found silver plates. It is not clear whether there were 1 or 2 hoards discovered. The denarii run from Vespasian to Septimius Severus.
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Warsaw (Byzantine vessels, Med); Shevchenko Museum, Lvov (362 den.); Ukrainian National Museum, Lvov (61)

summary: The hoard comprised an earthenware vessel containing between 600 and 700 radiates of Gordian III to Postumus. The hoard was immediately dispersed, although subsequently 2 lots of coins were recovered for study.
A hoard of silver and bronze (perhaps also gold) coins. There is only data for 2 coins of Antoninius Pius.

Hoard of 170 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel: Thassian tetradrachm, Thassian tetradrachm imitations 39, republican denarii 124, 2 denarius imitations, and imperial denarii 4: C. Renius - Augustus (29-27 BC).
Roll of 5 nummi found on a field near the Roman villa: Constantine I 5, Licinius I 2 (AD 316-317).
67 of the coins are uninscribed Iron Age gold coins of a type known as "South Ferriby" staters. 1 is a gold quarter stater of Cunobelin.
70 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
272 antoniniani (radiates) ranging from Caracalla to Trajan Decius (AD 249-251). 6 coins have been lost.
188 bronze coins fund in a ceramic vessel: 151 sestertii, 16 dupondii, 4 dupondii/asses, 17 asses: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177).
2000 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Augustus - Severus alexander (AD 222-235).
disposition: Dispersend among locals, and buyers from Novara and Torino.

summary: A Roman arm purse was found on a field, southwest of Hahn (today in the district of Pfungstadt), in the vicinity of the Hofgut Grabenbruch. The purse contained 8 Roman denarii, ranging from Galba to Trajan.
22 bronze coins found together: Obol, prutahs, local, provincial issues: Ptolemy VIII Physcon - Antoninus Pius (AD 158-159).
3 iron Age silver units, that have no connection with either the Urchfont II hoard or the group found in the neighbouring parish of Chirton.

In 1919, during the excavation of the Iron Age hill fort on Traprain Law, a pit was found in the latest floor. That pit was so close to the surface that the deposit obviously belonged to a later date. The hoard contained 160+ pieces of silver hack, much folded and crushed, as well as 4 siliquae. 2 of them were clipped, the other 2 are too badly corroded to be sure.
disposition: National Museums of Scotland (silver vessels, coins)

summary: 25 republican silver coins: 1 quadrigatus (225-31 BC).

The earliest source to mention the circumstances of the find appears to be the Carlyon-Britton sale catalogue (Sotheby, 17 November 1913), at lots 24, 37 and 49, all of which are described as "Found in a tumulus at Cackham Farm, West Wittering, about 1840". Haselgrove (1984, 297) has suggested that the tumulus "was probably a sand dune or clearance", and he includes the Cackham Farm finds among the larger assemblage from Selsey (267). While it is possible that Carlyon-Britton had some particular knowledge of the circumstances of discovery, the record is too vague to be of much value now (de Jersey).
14 sestertii: Antoninus Pius (Faustina I) - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
Hoard of circa 40 solidi only 2 are known today: Honorius and Valentinian III (AD 425-455).
disposition: Münzkabinett Berlin Germany; Museum of Szczecin, Poland (until 1944)

summary: 131 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms: Nero - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-259). Purchased by Currelly and Frost from "native diggers".
disposition: 'Selection in Oxford, where there is also a handwritten list (Milne); some of the rest are probably in Toronto.'

summary: The hoard comprised 207 Greek and Roman coins.
Unknown originally number coins found with a ceramic vessel. 25 coins are preserved in the National History Museum in Bucharest. No details on the composition.
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (file 1906, p. 68)

summary: Unpublished hoard of 14 bronze coins of Augustus.
disposition: Formerly Archaeological Museum, Zadar, Croatia (11 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised some broken vessels containing approximately 4000 bronze coins which were thought to have mostly been sestertii.
c. 60 republican denarii. 20 pieces were recovered: 19 denarii, 1 quinarius (32-31 BC).
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie Națională și Arheologie, Constanța, Romania (20 coins); inv.nos. 76552-76567

summary: The hoard comprised 7 bronzes coins from the reign of Nero, dated between AD 67-68, which may have belonged to a Roman soldier during the First Jewish War.
On 4th April, 1950, between 346 and 369 coins and pieces of pottery were dug up by workmen at Acacia Avenue, Laleham Road, Sunbury.

4 gold coins found in a st1 sarcophagus during excavations: Vespasian, Titus, Hadrian 2. Together were found 4 denarii: Augustus, Trajan, Hadrian, Faustina I. Together were found gold and silver jewellery, vessels, glass objects.
A hoard of gold and copper coins found in a vessel. Only 10 solidi are known: Honorius - Theodosius II (AD 424-425).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Sofia, Bulgaria; 10 solidi; inv.no. 865-874

find_spot_name: OPLONTIS - VILLA B, SKELETON 27, ON THE CHEST
summary: 123 coins found on the chest of the skeleton no. 27: 89 aurei, 34 denarii: Republic - Vespasian (AD 78-79).
The hoard comprised 135 sestertii from Vespasian to Postumus with a tpq of AD 260.
The hoard comprised 120 4th century nummi from a variety of mints, found inside a st1 cavity in a Roman house.
26 antoniniani (radiates) found with traces of textile recipient: Aurelian - Carinus (AD 283-285).
disposition: Laboratory of Restoration of Soprintendenza Speciale per i Beni Archeologici di Roma (inv. nos. 508899-508924)

summary: The hoard comprised 5 gold coins of Anastasius dated between AD 498 and 518.

The hoard comprised 'a ceramic vessel containing more than 300 middle bronzes. They were of Marcia Severa, the young Gordian, Gordian II. They were all different, but all base silver.' It is clear that the coins were radiates, although it is possible that there may have also been some denarii if the identification of coins of Gordian II is correct. The hoard was found by a labourer.

18 silver coins: 4 denarii, 14 antoniniani (radiates) found with ceramic vessel: Trajan - Claudius II (AD 268-270). Together were found jewelry: 2 silver bracelets, 1 gold pendant, 3 gold rings, 1 gold earring and fragments of silver earrings.
disposition: Museo di Antichità di Torino, Italy

summary: 416 billon tetradrachms of Alexandria: Gordian III - Carus (AD 282-283) found in the courtyard, having been stored in an amphora and placed in a bin, during excavations of a house.
4128 coins found in 2 vessels: 3 denarii, 4125 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 252).
28 bronze Roman imperial coins: 2 sestertii, 26 nummi: Antoninus Pius, Faustina II (Diva), Constantius II - Magnentius (Decentius) (AD 351-353).
The hoard comprised 235 nummi of the House of Constantine. The circumstances of its discovery and details of its findspot are unknown.
The hoard comprised 1147 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Gallienus (AD 260-268).
15 aurei were found during diggings at Vinukonda, in the old fort.
194 Roman provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Valerian and Gallienus/Gallienus (AD 253-268).
disposition: Museum of anamur, Turkey (coins); Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliothèque Nationale de France, Paris, France (moulds)

summary: Unknown number of antoniniani, among, those of Aurelian and Severina.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. M III 6197-6234 (38 coins)

summary: A small hoard of possibly 800 coins was unearthed in a bronze jar close to the railway bridge on the right bank of the Iller. Coins were mixed up with a similar hoard from Öschlesee. Coins were 'silvered bronzes' and reportedly 6 aurei. FMRD gives a summary list of 33 coins.

Between December 1988 and January 1989 a third deposit (Hoard III) was located about 500 m to the south-west. This deposit consisted of 7 Iron Age staters (2 Gallo-Belgic E and 5 Chute). –– Probably part of the same deposit as hoards I and II.
96 silver coins: 33 denarii, 63 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 253); silver w8: 128.2-226.5 g.
disposition: National History Museum of Romania, Bucharest, 96 coins

summary: Unknown number of Roman bronze coins, only 3 pieces are known: Augustus, Nero, Hadrian
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 2 silver intaglio finger rings and at least 23 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
2 solidi of Honorius (AD 393-423); gold w8: 8.9g.
11 denarii: 5 republican, 6 imperial: Republic - Domitian (AD 81-96).
A hoard (or 2 hoards?) of ca. 25000 coins dating mostly from the period AD 313-317, found in 2 earthenware vessels in the vicinity of the burgus (fort) of Mittelstrimmig.
1745 small flan bronze coins: Hellenistic (Lipara) - Leo I (AD 457-474).
60 denarii found, probably, with a ceramic vessel: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).

The hoard comprised between 450 and 500 coins of which only 46 were identified. The coins come from the mints of Rome and Cologne. Found during building work during the German occupation of 1914-1917. The hoard was found a couple of 100 meters from the hoard at Noyelles-Godault (TAF II.57) Silver: 450-500 (45, 1) coins; Silver w8: 129.2-592.8 g.
108 bronze coins of Postumus: double sestertii, sestertii, imitations (AD 267-269).
Unknown originally number of coins. 27 were recovered for the museum in Cluj: Vespasian – Elagabalus.
disposition: National History Museum of Transylvania, Cluj-Napoca, Romania

summary: 25 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) till AD 255-256.
Hoard of 15 coins - no information on the denomination. Among issuers Vespasian and Trajan.

The hoard comprised 69 Iron Age Continental bronzes and Roman coins. The Iron Age coins were Ambiens bronzes of Scheers types 59, 80, 96, 104, 105, 143, 163 and 217, a bronze of Scheers type 170 attributed to Viromanduens, another with the legend VANDIILOS attributed to Bituriges, 1 with the legend SEGISV (BN 4628) and 16 with the legend GERMANVS INDVTILLI L. The Roman coins included plated Republican denarius, a cut dupondius from Nemausus, 3 worn cut asses, 4 asses of Augustus, 1 quadrans and 1 as of a type depicting the altar of Lyon of either Augustus or Tiberius, 2 quadrantes of Tiberius and 2 of Claudius.
Around 142 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Friends of Science Society, Poznań, Poland (143 coins)

summary: `Roman gold coins' found in an allotment.
The hoard comprised a copper-alloy vessel containing approximately 400 large and small bronze coins nearly all of the Late Empire.
More than 1000 silver coins (Trajan - Postumus), found while establishing a water ditch on a field. The composition of the hoard is difficult to reconstruct, see FMRD for details.
17 silver coins: 1 Celtic, 12 republican denarii, 4 imperial denarii: Republic - Tiberius (AD 14-37)

273 mostly Late Roman Coins ranging from Celtic (30-5 BC) to Honorius (393-423). A nucleus of Late Roman nummi can be easily distinguished, probably consisting of several hoards, all determined as far as possible.

At least 18 radiates (Gallienus to Tetricus I) found in the area of Tintern some time around 1872. It is uncertain that these represent the entirety of what might have been a hoard. No further information is available.

IARCH record for a scattered hoard of 6 denarii. Other coins have been recorded from the immediate area but they were not considered to be part of this hoard. For full details and images see SOM-D0A907.
14 denarii: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (Commodus Augustus) (AD 177); silver w8: 38.41 g.
The hoard comprised between 1400 and 1500 'copper' coins from Nero to Antoninus Pius.
Found in a ceramic vessel, 120 coins: 66 denarii, 54 antoniniani: Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver w8: 147.7-320.3 g.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2442, 120 coins

summary: Unknown number of denarii were found in unknown circumstances. 18 pieces are kept in the museum collection in Ruse: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).

The hoard comprised a black pot containing between 500 and 600 Iron Age coins and approximately 120 Republican coins. The most frequent legends on the Iron Age coins were ABVDOS, ANDECOMBO, ANORBO/DVBNO, ATISIOS, ARIVOS/SANTONOS, AVLIRCO, ATEVLA/VLATOS, Q.DOCI SAMF, DVBNOCOV/DVBNOREX, DURAT/IVLIOS, DVRNACVS (?), EPAD, LITA, MEDIOMA, NINNO, COIOS/ORCETIRIX, POTTINA, SOLIMA, TOGI/TOCIR, TVRONOS, VIIPOTAL The hoard was found in a field east of the village of La Jante.
33 republican and imperial denarii: Republic - Tiberius (AD14-37). Possible part of PALERMO? 1893-a
disposition: Museo Nazionale di Palermo, Italy; inv. no. 1721 (in 1893)

summary: 257 Iron Age coins were discovered throughmetal detectingand excavation at Essendon between 1992 and 1994. The assemblage can be divided into several distinct hoards but is treated as 1 due to lack of available contextual information. The excavations remain unpublished but the archaeology suggests a sequence of deposits within an enclosure in a similar manner to Hallaton and Snettisham.
1489 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 295-296) found in a heap on the floor of the underground room N during excavations of a house.
174 bronze coins: Tetricus I (Tetricus II Caesar) - Valentinian III (AD 425-435).

c. 1400 coins, mostly aurei, of which only 45 specimens were recorded, ranging from Nero to Antoninus Pius (43 aurei, 1 denarius of Nero and 1 of Galba), found during illegal excavations in Kuşakkaya.
disposition: Adıyaman museum; Kahramanmaraş museum; private collection in Ankara

summary: Preliminary record for the material derived from recent Treasure cases from 2003 to 2007. This includes a mixture of Iron Age and Roman coins and artefacts and presumably includes several hoards within the group. de Jersey gives the following account: ‘at least 2 distinct, scattered coin hoards’ were found by a metal detectorist in May/June 2003. These were said to consist of 1) ‘a group of 12 cast ‘Thurrock type’ coins’, and 2) ‘a group of 25 struck silver coins of types traditionally attributed to the Iceni’
Hoard of 13 silver coins found by chance: 12 didrachms Hadrian, 1 drachm Septimius Severus, all minted in Caesarea Cappadociae.
33 coins: 1 denarius, 32 antoniniani (radiate) found in the house known as the 'House of Domitian's Diploma': Severus Alexander - Quintillus (Divus Claudius II) (AD 270).
21 denarii: Galba - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-196).
disposition: Coin Room, Library of the Romanian Academy, Bucharest, Romania (inv.nos. 14845-14865 - in 1944)

summary: The hoard comprised a matt white ceramic vessel containing 205 sestertii from Vespasian to Septimius Severus. The hoard was placed under some tiles.
6 sestertii were found at a gravel pit close to Eisenfeld.
The hoard comprised 1200 aurei from Hadrian to Elagabalus together with 16 artefacts of silverware. 2 amphorae found close to the surrounding north enclosure of the Precinct of Amun-Ra in Karnak.
18 silver coins found in a small ceramic beaker: 5 republican denarii, 2 imperial denarii, 6 republican quinarii, 5 imperial quinarii (1 plated): Republic - Augustus (2 BC - AD 12).

A hoard of 220 Roman Imperial denarii: Domitian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211) was discovered by a treasure hunter in late 2019. The hoard was found in the woods, the first coin was found on the surface in a mole hole, 15 meters from the main cluster. The pot containing the hoard was broken. The bulk of the coins were close to the modern surface in a 3x3 meter area. On 28 December 2019, photos of the coins were published by the finder on the treasure hunting forum Violity. On 5 January 2020 the treasure was sold at the Viloity auction for 33050 UAH (1203 euros as of 05.01.2020).

ca. 40-50 solidi (40 of which listed by emperor), silver coins (the coins were badly preserved, and some might have been bronze coins), 2 gold rings' gold bracelet and a silver ingot (?) found in 1781 while cleaning a ditch.
14 provincial bronze coins: Marcus Aurelius - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 19

summary: Circa 10 - 11000 coins (c. 61kg), from Valerian II to Constantius II. Together were found 3 silverware.

The hoard comprised a vessel containing approximately 2000 small bronze coins of the Late Empire, including issues of Galerien [sic for Valerian], Gallienus, Claudius II and a considerable quantity of Tetricus I. A large number of coins were illegible. Blanchet mistakenly doubled the total of the coins in the hoard and placed it in the parish of Aubigné-Racan.
2 aurei of Nero (AD 66-67).
disposition: Muzeul Național al Unirii, Alba Iulia, Romania; inv.nos. 6975-6976

summary: In 1888 while digging in the garden of the Sandmeier farm in the parish Alswede, 180 denarii were found caked together. Later in 1891, a further 40 were found at the same place. 160 of these 220 denarii (ranging from Vespasian to Septimius Severus) were published in 1889-1891. The remaining portion of the hoard appear to have come into the possession of the Osnabrück museum. Compared with other hoards from Westphalia, LASHORST I has a higher percentage of barbarous imitations. - see the LATZEN hoard as well, showing that 2nd c. denarii circulated until the middle of the 4th c. AD.

A small hoard of 4 Roman imperial denarii: Marcus Aurelius - Didius Julianus (AD 193) was discovered by a treasure hunter in early July 2023 somewhere in Cherkasy region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity July 3, 2023. The finder reported that the coins were discovered “in 1 small pit”. The further fate of the hoard is unknown.
48 denarii: Republic - Tiberius (AD 26-37).
In 1857/8 at least 11 denarii ranging from Vespasian to Hadrian were found during building work in the basement of a house.
The hoard originally comprised 21 bronze coins found with an amphora: Vespasian-Antoninus Pius (73-145 AD). Only 18 coins are still available.
disposition: Soprintendenza per i Beni Archeologici del Veneto, Padova, Iatly

summary: 3000 coins: Septimius Severus – Philip I (AD 244-249). No further details.
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (unknown number of coins)

summary: 3000 to 5000 silver coins, ranging from Augustus to Severus Alexander, found while digging gravel close to the Jever castle, on the city moat. 2200 coins were melted down, the rest dispersed. Zedelius published 564 coins attributed to the hoard.
disposition: Oldenburgisches Landesmuseum (part); Schloßmuseum Jever (part); Ostfriesisches Landesmuseum, Emden (part); Münster museum (part)

summary: A hoard of 28 antoniniani, ranging from Gordian III to Valerian I, discovered in an earthenware container at a field in Met10bach.
70 coins: 35 sestertii, 27 dupondii, 8 asses hidden in the wall of a Roman building: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 168).

Large numbers of moulds for casting spurious coins, principally antoniniani of the period AD 260-74, have been found at Lyons Court Farm, Whitchurch, near Bristol, in 1891, 1897 and 1960. Coins were found as well, clearly part of a hoard accidentally incorporated into the levelling-material. In 1891, 16 Roman bronze coins were found while cleaning a ditch: Faustina 2, Lucilla 2, Commodus 10, Crispina 1, Postumus 1, associated with large st1s, animal b1s, and sherds of Samian, Upchurch and rougher pottery. Followed the discovery of a bronze of Commodus, and 1 of Maximinus. In 1897, additional clay moulds were found and 2 bronze coins oxidised together (Commodus, Septimius Severus). The 1960 finds include a sestertius of Marcus Aurelius and 4 antoniniani (3 Tetricus II and 1 Aurelian).
174 coins: 32 antoniniani (radiates), 142 nummi: Gallienus - Theodosius I (Honorius) (AD 393-395).
disposition: Casa-Museo Posada del Moro, Torrecampo, Spain

summary: A hoard of late Roman bronze coins from the time of Constantine I, of which only 7 specimens were acquired by the Altertumsmuseum. The coins are now lost.
Group of 5 coins discovered in an ancient cellar: 4 double sestertii of Postumus, 1 imitation of antoninianus (radiate) of Victorinus (AD 269-271).
3762 coins found with an amphora: Gallienus - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
19 aurei: Tiberius - Claudius I (AD 50-51).
In 1931 the discovery of 14 late Roman coins (Tetrarchy - Gratian) is reported during building work.
The first (Δα) of 2 hoards found in a grave in the east cemetery of Thessaloniki (Agios Dimitriou street). It contained 6 nummi from the time of Constantine I.
A hoard of 260 provincial bronze coins (Domitian - Gallus, including 1 from the First Jewish Revolt), found at Dura Europos, in L8 W102, the street along the wall near the main Gate.
Hoard of initial of just over 100 aurei, 91 recovered (650 g = 2 Roman pounds): Nero - Severus Alexander (AD 231).
disposition: National Archaeological Museum, Madrid (at the moment); Provincial Archaeological Museum of Cáceres, Spain (final destination)

summary: 54 coins: 5 aurei, 45 denarii, 3 quinarii, 1 drachm of Apollonia: Republic - Tiberius (AD 14-37).

4 imperial As, 3 imperial Dupondii, 1 imperial AE (Augustus to Vespasian) and 1 uncertain imperial As, 29 uncertain imperial AE found with a female skeleton with golden jewelry in regio IX, insula 8, inner corridor to cubiculum with erotic scenes of building 3 (house).
23 nummi found in a pit under the floor of a domestic building, range: Constans - Theodosius II (AD 408-450). Possible, part of the hoard Termini Imerse 1984 B.
disposition: Museo Civico "B. Romano" Comune di Termini Imerese

summary: 26 solidi and 3 siliquae, ranging from Julian II to Valentinian II, found near to the Horkstow Villa. N1 of the siliquae was clipped.

find_spot_name: CANTERBURY ROSE LANE SITE E XXI, D (12) HOARD 6
summary: Rose Lane Site E XXI, D (12) Hoard 6. 16 coins from Tetricus I to House of Constantine, incl. 3 corroded & illegible & 2 4th C. copies.
18 denarii found together during the archaeological excavations at the Dacian fortress: Republic – Augustus (16 BC).
The hoard comprised at least 250 nummi from the reign of Constantius II (AD 337-361).
The hoard comprised 150 antoniniani (radiates), of which 129 survive from Philip I to Claudius II/Victorinus. This is 1 of 4 hoards from the site. Silver w8: 31.3-233.2g.
Unknown initial number of coins. 40 denarii entered Museum Collection in Opole in 1973:
disposition: Municipal Museum Opole, Poland (40 coins in 1973)

summary: The hoard comprised a lead container containing more than 500 silver and bronze coins of the Roman Republic, Augustus, Claudius I and Nero.
6 coins, possible kept in a purse, found in a building with unknown use: 5 republican denarii, 1 aureus of Augustus (BC 9).
4 coins, probably part of a larger find: Probus antoninianus (radiate), Constantine I nummus, Valentinian I nummus, uncertain bronze (AD 364-367).
disposition: National museum, Prague, Czech Republic and collection E. Štorcha.

summary: 88 nummi: Constantine I - Theodosius I (AD 379-383). Mints after AD 364: Treveri 1, Lugdunum 17, Arelate 25, Aquileia 9, Roma 4, Siscia 7, unidentified: 11
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (88 coins).

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 133 pieces were documented: Constantine I - Theodosius I/Arcadius/Honorius (AD 393-395).
(316) 214 silver coins: 23 denarii, 191 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 261); silver w8: 112.2-779.3 g.
In 1889 a large hoard was unearthed on Stephanstraße in front of the corner house on Hohe street.
42 bronze coins: Antoninus Pius - Caracalla (AD 215).
disposition: Collection J. De Bast (42 coins), in 1808

summary: The hoard comprised 41 bronze coins dated between 37-4 BC and 4 BC-AD 6.
Rally find. Found under a st1.
14528 nummi deposited in a cooking pot: 321-324 - 337-341. Work in progress
Found during years 1864, 1876, 1893, 1940, 25 solidi: Honorius - Anastasius (AD 491-518).
disposition: National Museum Szczecin, Poland; Museum of Cultural History Straslund, Germany; Pistorius collection; private colletions

summary: In early June 1958, 368 coins (4 aurei and 363 denarii, 1 Lycian drachm and 1 as) were found near Barway, Soham in Cambridgeshire. Further finds made in 1977, 1989, 1990 and 1991 bring the total to 471 coins, ranging up to Commodus.
disposition: Ashmolean Museum (part); Fitzwilliam Musem (part); British Museum (part); returned to finder (part)

summary: Unknown number of originally number of coins found. 19 pieces provide detailed information: 9 solidi (6), 7 solidi (1), 3 solidi (1), 1 1/2 solidus (3), solidi (7): Constantine I - Constantius II (AD 342-350). See note in RIC VII concerning incorrect pairings of casts. Here, the coins are entered at the coin data level after correcting the pairing of casts! Gold w8: 249.2 g (according to Hobbs).
disposition: Cabinet de médailles (inv.no. F. 2366; robbed in 1831), Paris, La Haye, France; Royal Cabinet, Hague, Denmark; private collection

summary: 17533 antoniniani (59 kg) found in a bronze vessel: Vespasian - Trajan Decius (Herennius Etruscus) (AD 249-251)
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. no. 932

summary: 2 solidi: Valentinian I (AD 364-367), Valentinian III (AD 425-455).

A hoard of 7 as from a grave. Cemetery, mainly inhumations, from Late Iron Age (from LT C) to Roman times. Tomb 422: 7 coins, Augustus, all minted in Rome. - Tomb described as "Ensemble problématique du point de vue de la documentation".
A hoard of ca. 100 silver Iron Age coins found near Portsmouth. The records about the hoard are quite confused. 9 coins in the British Museum are ticketed as "found at Portsmouth in 1830".
13 coins (10 provincial coins of Philippi, 2 denarii of Trajan and 1 imperial bronze of Domitian) found in grave T45 in the eastern cemetery of Philippi.
The hoard was found during the excavation of a taberna in the forum and comprised 20 aurei from Nero to Nerva.
This hoard comprised 4000 coins from Gallienus to Probus (with many imitations). It was found at the Hameau des Boulins. 3219 coins are now at the Museum of Clamecy.
A small hoard of quarter staters of Sills's Insular Cf2 type, recorded by a private collector in May 2005.
105 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Targovishte, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 31173-31277

summary: The hoard comprised 4 denarii from Antoninus Pius to Severus Alexander with a tpq of AD 228 to 234.

73 coins (44 denarii, 3 aurei and 23 bronze coins), ranging from Mark Antony to Severus Alexander, found together over time within the foundation walls of a Roman building located in the vicus surrounding the Roman fort of Eining. The earlier finds had been dispersed, but most of them could be traced in FMRD.
2 solidi of Theodosius I for Arcadius minted in Constantinople (AD 394-395).
disposition: Museo Arqueolóxico do Castro de Viladonga

summary: A hoard of 2500 bronze coins, of which only 16 were identified. They included a radiate of Gallienus and 4th century nummi. There was 1 Punic bronze coin (bust left; resting horse) amongst the assemblage.

The hoard comprised 'a large quantity of 3rd century coins, of which 39 were given by M. Richard to the Musée de Laval (Mayenne): Severus Alexander - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver w8: 12.5-46.8g. 3 coins, Severus Alexander, Maximinus I Thrax and Saloninus are lost.

The hoard was found as the result of deep-ploughing which brought 126 small Roman bronzes to the surface which were collected by farmers. An archaeological excavation then revealed a greyware vessel filled with more radiates and a further pink ceramic vessel containing 1276 coins. 2 containers, 1 with 988 antoniniani (radiates) from Julia Domna to Postumus, the other 1437 from Valerian to Tetricus II Silver: 2425 coins; silver w8: 730.8-3581.8g.
The hoard comprised a radiate of Divus Claudius II and 14 nummi of the House of Constantine with a tpq of AD 347 to 348. It was found during the excavation of Insula 20 at Colonia Ulpia Traiana.
(c.100) 34 coins: 27 antoniniani (radiates), 7 nummi: Gallienus - Valens (AD 364-378).
The hoard comprised 32 coins, including 2 denarii and 30 antoniniani (radiates) from Julia Maesa to Postumus. It is suggested that they were originally stored in a box.
Hoard of 700 silver coins. 578 pieces were recovered: 577 denarii, 1 drachm: Nero - Commodus (AD 185).
disposition: Pokrajinski muzej, Celje, Slovenia (578 coins); dispersed

summary: 2 medallions (Hadrian, Commodus) were found with a vessel. Together were 7 bronze tintinnabula, 1 patera, and 2 iron objects.
86 silver coins: denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver w8: 108.1-222.5 g.
6 denarii (Domitian - Hadrian), found in the estuary of the River Weser in 1842.
Hoard of an unknown number of denarii. Only 4 coins were documented: Trajan, Marcus Aurelius, Lucius Verus, Commodus.

The hoard comprised 16 coins from Tiberius to Claudius II and were found along with the remains of a coarseware pottery urn. TAF interprets the assemblage as being successive votive offerings rather than a hoard. The coins were found at the entrance to a cave.
Originally, 31 denarii, only 18 recorded: Republic - Augustus (2 BC - AD 4).
Around 20 coins, 10 are known: Claudius II – Valens (AD 364-378).
A hoard of 8 Roman Provincial coins from the mints of Thessalonica, Edessa, Pella and the Macedonian Koinon from the period AD 222-235, found in grave 52 in the western cemetery of Pella.
(30) 7 silver and bronze coins: 2 denarii, 1 antoniniani; 1 provincial bronze; 3 bronze unid. denom: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Private collection Andrei Pănoiu - architect, Bucharest, Romania

summary: 12 silver and bronze coins found on a small area: Republic - Augustus (2 BC - AD 4).
The original number of coins in the hoard was not ascertained and only the 2 Lycian drachmas were acquired.

6263 denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Rome (4921); Viminiacum (4); Milan (340), Ticinum (6); Cologne (44); Trier (38); Lyon (2); Siscia (216); Sirmium (2); Antioch (2); Cyzicus (12); uncertain (4); imitations (1068): Gordian III - Diocletian (AD 287-289). Found during the laying of electrical cables.

A clump of at least 14 denarii mol10 together. The only reasonably identifiable coin is 1 of Antoninus Pius for Diva Faustina I, minted between 141 and 161 AD. Another denarius was likely issued under the authority of Marcus Aurelius.
Circa 2000 antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
85 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel within a burial ground of the Wielbark Culture: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 184).
25 bronze coins of which are know Augustus 1, Hadrian 1, and 1 of the 2 Faustinae (AD 138-180).

A ceramic vessel with 1032 Roman provincial bronze coins minted in Marcianopolis, Nicopolis ad Istrum, Callatis, Odessus, Anchialus, Augusta Traiana, Hadrianopolis, Philippopolis and Creteia-Flaviopolis: Marcus Aurelius - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: History Museum, Targovishte, Bulgaria; inv.no. 201 (894 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 2 coarseware ceramic vessels containing approximately 5000 radiates from Gallienus, Claudius II and Aurelian, as well as issues of the Gallic Empire. 16 coins from the hoard recently reappeared and comprised issues of Gallienus, Claudius II, Quintillus, Postumus and Victorinus.

Originally this hoard consisted of approx. 10000 mostly bronze (some exceptions) coins but only a fraction have been recorded. The Cabinet of Medailles due Musee d'Histoire et d'Art has the following coins listed here. Others are in Trier, although it no longer is possible to determine which 1s these are. 4 arg., 74 nummi copies, 2439 nummi Silver: 2, 4 coins; Silver w8: c.13.4g

During agricultural works, followed by archaeological investigations 2 gold coins were found in a grave: solidus of Constantine I minted in Nicomedia (AD 324-325), and an imitation aureus of Numerian.

462 coins, mostly provincial issues of Caesarea in Cappadocia (150 coins) and imperial bronzes (130 coins), other bronze provincial issues and some imperial silver, closing with Gordian III, found in a deposit associated with the mid-third-century destruction of Zeugma.
Hallaton: 14 hoards were located in and around the entrance way. Hoard 69 comprises 12 Iron Age coins.
54 antoniniani (radiates) found near a wall of a building (Principia?) from the legionary fortress: Gordian III - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-259).
IARCH record for a hoard of 4 denarii 2014 T669. For full details and images see BH-A74A1A.
The hoard comprised 1 denarius of Severus Alexander and 277 radiates from Gordian III to Gallienus' joint reign with a tpq of 258 to 259.

A group of coins 124 coins and 3 fragments (Constantine I - Constans – FMRD gives a list of 125 coins), recorded during archaeological investigations in the southern half of the east crypt of the cathedral in Trier; in addition, a small cube, a token, a bronze ring, and other small pieces were found. These coins were found in a layer of 'black soil' and might have fallen through gaps in a wooden floor.
The hoard, discovered 1 year after MAGNY-COURS 2008, comprised 466 antoniniani (radiates) and 366 heavy nummii.
820 coins of which 818 are preserved, all imitation of antoniniani (radiates) of Claudius II, Claudius II (Divus), Tetricus II.
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Badajoz, Spain

summary: A hoard found in the vicinity of Suez in 1930, seen by an informant of K. Regling. It comprises 38 aurei of Septimius Severus and his family, including 1 of Caracalla with Plautilla.
Hoard of 35 Roman imperial bronzes: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: M.K. Ciurlionis National Museum of Art, Kaunas, Lithuania

summary: 13 nummi of Constantine I and his family (AD 328-329).
680 nummi found with ceramic vessel: Claudius II - Theodosius II/Valentinian III (AD 425-450). There were other circa 1000 small bronze disks (blanks?) with irregular edges.
disposition: Soprintendenza Archeologica di Roma, Gabinetto Numismatico del Museo Nazionale Romano, Italy (inv. nos. 123711-123771)

summary: 4 solidi: Theodosius II - Glycerius (AD 473-474); gold w8: 17.8 g. Found at different times but in same field
66 denarii: Vespasian - Severus Alexander (AD 228-231); silver w8: 94.0-193.2 g.
32 coins: 1 republican denarius, 31 bronze coins: Augustus - Septimius Severus (AD 197-198).

This hoard was probably discovered off the coasts of Sicily in the late 1950s. It comprised at least 174 coins, including 35 gold multiples and 139 aurei, spanning the period from AD 276/277 to 308. The con10t shows that the treasure was amassed through regular withdrawal of currency in circulation but also, more importantly, through successive donativa.
disposition: Cabinet des médailles de la Bibliothèque Nationale de France (aureus Probus); collection Biaggi (8 aurei); collections in Boston, Bruxelles, London, Paris; parts dispersed in on auctions.

summary: 800 denarii. 274 pieces were studied by V. Haralanov: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
The hoard comprised 17 bronze coins dated between AD 317-320 and AD 351-361.
A hoard of 7 nummi (AD 311-318) found in a grave in the east cemetery of Thessaloniki (Agios Dimitriou street).
IARCH record for a small hoard of 3 denarii found in 2014. For further details and images see WMID-AABF6.
C. Hipolito stated that the hoard contained 100 bronzes. The 5 asses of Claudius I and the dupondius of Claudius I for Antonia are the only 1 recorded.

Bean (2000, 279 no. 33) provides the only published account of this undeclared find, made in the autumn of 1991 and initially said to have come from Hatfield in Hertfordshire, but subsequently relocated to "near Reading". He suggests that it contained c.90 coins, almost all of Verica.
(200) 41 sestertii: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180)
disposition: Musées royaux des Beaux-Arts de Belgique (41 coins)

summary: 141 Iron Age gold coins found over a period of several years.
20 nummi were found in 1901 during excavation works on Fleischstrasse.
5 radiates "of Tetricus" found near the surface by a digger driver during gravel extraction at the site of the now destroyed supposed Iron Age hillfort known as "The Walls" in Nursling.
The hoard was found on the left Mosel bank between a school and a barracks, also between Hohenstein-and Markus street.
The hoard comprised a vessel containing several hundred bronze coins from Trajan to Antoninus Pius.

1 as, 25 radiates, and 30 nummi (Gordian III to the House of Valentinian). O'Neill (1933-35) noted that the collection "has always been supposed to be from Abergele", although the date and precise location of their discovery is unknown.
This appears to be part of a larger hoard and should not be confused with other hoards from Bavay which were composed of bronze issues. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of 10.5-82.7g.

Hoard of 14 kilos of antoniniani (radiates) found during the construction of the overpass on the Corso Ivrea. 601 coins were transferred from the Regional Museum of Torino to the Soprin10denza della Valle d'Aosta: Trebonianus Gallus - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (AD 253-268).

2 denarii found during construction of a local railroad in 1880. 4 gold objects (2 bars, 1 ring and 1 bracelet), were reportedly found with the denarii. A st1 with a portrait was also said to be found with the menti1d items but is an obvious modern fake of unknown origin.
10 denarii found within a cemetery together with other objects. The antoninianus (radiate) of Aurelian may be an intruder.
disposition: Initially in the collection of Councilor Scotti, later in the Museum of Wroclaw, Poland; today, lost.

summary: The 32 coins were reportedly found together decades ago in the Nennslingen part of the Weissenburg Forest. A more precise find location cannot be determined, though it must be within the limes border. Coins range from Augustus to Theodosius I. It is uncertain whether this is a hoard.
The hoard was comprised a black pot containing 356 denarii and antoniniani (radiates)
Over 600 sestertii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
300 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Trajan - Didius Julianus (Manlia Scantilla) (AD 193).
Around 200 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Trajan - Didius Julianus (AD 193).
disposition: Münzkabinett, Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Germany (2 coins)

summary: 8 solidi: Valentinian II 2, Theodosius 4, Arcadius 1, Honorius 1 (AD pre-395). Estimated gold w8: 35.6g.
865 coins: 29 aurei, 833 denarii: Republic - Hadrian (AD 137-138)
12 antoniniani, ranging from Gordian III to Valerian I and ending ca. AD 255, found on the Zugerberg.
disposition: Amt für Denkmalpflege und Archäologie, Zug

summary: 19 coins: 18 nummi: Constantine I - Arcadius for Theodosius II (AD 401-403). Among these coins 1 imitation of a Kussano-Sasanian coin.
disposition: State Museum-Reserve Kulikovo Field, Tula, Russia

summary: The hoard comprised 216 coins (without doubt mostly denarii and antoniniani (radiates) and a range of silver vessels, gold and silver jewellery and a copper-alloy figurine. The earliest coin was an aureus of Galba and the latest were issues of Gallienus. The hoard was found close to a mill at a depth of 15 inches. Most of the hoard was acquired by the Musée de Genève. The aureus of Galba was stolen before 1903.

Found during construction work, partially supervised by an archaeologist, in the ruins of a Roman rural building; 15 sestertii, Antoninus Pius to Philipp I, found together with shards possibly of a container. The hoard has been interpreted as a 'Bauopfer' or foundation deposit.

The hoard comprised a copper-alloy jug containing more than 1800 coins, mostly of Diocletian and Maximian. According to Derriaz, there were a few issues from the mint of Rome, with the remainder being mint of Lyon issues. The jug was acquired by the Musée de la Civilisation gallo-romaine, Lyon (Inv. Br. 208)
114 coins of the First Jewish Revolt up to the 4th year (AD 69/70) were found in a m1y-box.
7 denarii: Trajan 1, Marcus Aurelius 1, Severus Alexander 1, uncertain 4.

A number of coin finds were made during controlled archaeological excavation by Wessex Archaeology at the RLE sites Springhead Roman Town (RLE Event Code ARC SPH00) and Springhead Nursery (ARC SHN02) as part of the programme of archaeological works undertaken in advance of the construction of the Channel Tunnel Rail Link (now known as HS1), between 2000 and 2003.
Large number of Roman denarii. Only 11 denarii documented ranging from the Republic to Augustus.
The hoard was found in a funerary urn and apparently comprised 50 'small bronzes' or radiates of Gallienus.

The assemblage comprised a) a copper-alloy box containing 2 aurei, items of jewellery and a fragment of silk; b) a further earthenware vessel containing a large quantity (10 kilos in total) of small module coins (radiates). 250 of these coins were examined by F. Rever, with the most recent being an issue of Quietus; c) 50 'large bronze' coins were scattered on the surface; d) some iron tools including pruning equipment. It is not clear whether all the constituent parts of the find should be considered to represent a single hoard deposit or at least 2 separate hoards. Found in a field belonging to M. Denesle (or Denêle) in the course of digging.
A hoard of 4 aurei: Nero, Trajan 2, Antoninus Pius for Faustina I (Diva).
disposition: Madras Museum, Chennai except for Trajan coins

summary: 3 solidi (Honorius and Arcadius) and 1 silver ingot, found while digging the foundations for a new office in the Tower of London, in 1777.
50 denarii ranging from the 2nd century BC Republic coins to Trajan, and including 1 plated specimen, found in a wooden building from the late 2nd century AD.
The hoard comprised an urn containing approximately 700 base-silver coins, which were not described in any detail. TAF suggests that this was a hoard of antoniniani (radiates).
Hoard 345 coins found on a wall from the Roman vicus: Tiberius - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
The hoard comprised 1 tetradrachm of Philip Philadelphus and 21 posthumous tetradrachms of Philip Philadelphus, found in the environs of Aleppo.
A hoard of 8 late Roman gold solidi was found 1990 by a man using a metal detector at Butterfield Down.

The hoard was found in a small square cairn created with Roman tiles stuck together with red Roman cement and was surrounded by numerous st1 sarcophagi. It comprised 87 sestertii from Vespasian to Gordian III and an oculist's stamp inscribed with the name C. TITTIVS BALBINVS.
14 silver coins: 13 denarii, 1 antoninianus: Antoninus Pius - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver w8: 20.8-37 g.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2247

summary: 5 aurei: Augustus 1 Tiberius 1, Claudius I 3 (AD 46-47).

A hoard of 18 Late Roman coins (AD 378-383), found near the NW corner of city wall. 3 further coins were found close to this group, and may or may not belong to it (1 of them has an earlier date: Constantius II, AD 347-348).
8 coins found inside a sarcophagus: Augustus - Postumus (AD 260-269).
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing between 900 and 1200 gold Continental Iron Age staters. 3 examples from this hoard can be found in the Museé de Rouen (Inv. 382/2, 382/3 and 409/2).
The hoard comprised 31 sestertii from Vespasian to Commodus, 1 dupondius of Caracalla and 281 denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of 351.8g to 729.5g
5 solidi found in a lead box in a burial: Leo I 1, Zeno 3, Anastasius 1.
The hoard comprised 8 nummi from the 4th century AD.
The hoard comprised 7 denarii from the Republic to Domitian.
Between 80 and 100 solidi: Theodosius II - Justin I (AD 518-522).
70 coins found with a leather bag: 22 denarii, 47 antoniniani, 1 provincial bronze: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Radnevo, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 28-97

summary: The hoard is thought to have comprised at least 600 coins but only 229 were recovered from the finders. The coins are described as being 'di grande modulo' and this has been interpreted as sestertii: Vespasian/Domitian - Philip I (AD 244-249). Found during the construction of a house for Corrado Tedeschi di Modica.
disposition: Museo Arch. Reg. "P. Orsi", Siracusa, Italy (31 coins)

summary: 35 denarii: Nero - Severus Alexander (AD 228-231). There is no certainty that this was the total number of the m1tary group. The owner could have retrieved part of the coins, as well as the following agricultural works, probably, led to the finding of other pieces.
disposition: County Museum of History and Art, Zalău, Romania

summary: Antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 300 coins, of which 196 were identified by A. Fillioux. The rest of the coins were small bronzes (radiates) of Gallienus, Salonina, Valerian-Saloninus and of Postumus, for the most part worn or copies. The latest coin of Postumus (E. 593) dating to AD 269. Silver: 1, 193+ coins; Silver w8: 54.9-502.2+
Unknown originally number of coins. 173 silver coins were recovered: 172 denarii, 1 drachm of Apollonia. 1 imperial denarius is attributed to either Vespasian or Domitian.
disposition: Kunsthistorische Museum, Vienna, Austria (82 denarii, 1 drachm)

summary: Hoard of 32 coins found with ceramic vessel: 21 denarii, 11 sestertii: Trajan - Severus alexander (AD 222-235).

465 AE radiates to AD 289. This debased radiate hoard was clearly quite scattered as it was found with late Roman bronzes of other periods. The material from Valerian to the Tetrici seems to form a discrete group, with the coins of Carausius also regarded as part of this hoard.

530 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269). Mints: until AD 253 Rome (except for 1 Volusian from Antioch); after 253: 72 Rome, 40 Cologne, 1 Milan, 2 Viminacium, 45 unidentified and for Postumus, 334 Cologne and 7 imitations. Silver: 580 coins; Silver w8: 145.0-295.5 g.

A Roman arm purse purse with at least 2 Roman coins (2 denarii, Republic - Vespasian) as con10t was dug out in 1957 during excavation work of the Altrhein. The find arrived inside the Heimatmuseum of Erfelden.

find_spot_name: KÖLN - ST. MARIA IM KAPITOL X
summary: This set is said to represent the remainder of the scattered find, which was acquired in 1922 by the coin shop Riechmann & Co. in Halle.
During the construction of a spinning factory in 1852 a hoard consisting of gold and silver coins, ranging from Nero to Severus Alexander, was unearthed. Only 27 specimens were documented.

In 1838, dredging works along a length of river measuring approxiamtely 100 metres, brought to light numerous Roman coins in mint condition (between 15000 and 20000 approximately). They ended with issues of Tiberius. The assemblage was found during dredging works of a stretch of river measuring approximately 100 metres in length, at the confluence of the River Achenau and 10u.
A hoard of 6 provincial coins minted in Alexandria (Claudius II - Aurelian), found in or near Ipswich in 1922.
60 large bronze coins (i.e. sestertii) were found in a bowl in Trier, in the suburb St. Barbara inside Roman st1work.
38 silver coins ranking from Trajan to Valentinian (AD 364-375); silver w8: 61.5-118.2g.
366 coins: 6 denarii, 235 antoniniani, 123 nummi, 2 provincial bronze coins found in the Principia: Nero - Constantine I (AD 313-317); silver w8: 44-310.1 g.
29 denarii: Otho - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
disposition: Museum of Cultural History Stralsund, Germany (26 coins); Museum Szeczin, Poland (3 coins)

summary: The coins were lifted en masse and when treated in the conservation lab at the BM some were found to be fused together in rolls with remains of cloth and string preserved in the corrosion products; good physical evidence that they were buried together in antiquity.

Hoard of 225 coins: 1 imperial denarius, 8 gold stateri, 216 bronze staters of Bosporan kings: Rhescuporis III, Cotys III, Sauromates III, Rhescuporis IV, Ininthimeus Rhescuporis V, dated between AD 80 and AD 251.
Hoard of initially 90 silver coins. 41 were recovered (denarii, antoniniani (radiates): Hadrian - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
The hoard was found in Burial 21 of a Roman cemetery and comprised a purse containing 32 coins of Magnentius, Valentinian, Valens and Gratian.

In 1962 an excavator found a jar with 7 aurei, 1346 denarii (Nero - Marcus Aurelius), and 4 Lycian drachms (Domitian - Trajan), while building the foundations of the new building for the paper mill factory at Stockstadt.
disposition: The majority of the find was sent to Aschaffenburg Municipal Museum

summary: 26 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Philip I - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver w8: 8.0-31.5g.
disposition: Prof. J. Coupry, Faculté des Lettres de Bordeaux, Director of Bordeaux Department for Antiquities

summary: Few hundreds denarii. 14 pieces entered the museum collection in Stara Zagora: Faustina II 1, Septimius Severus 5, Julia Domna 2, Geta 2, Caracalla 3, Maximinus I Thrax 1.
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Stara Zagora, Bulgaria; inv.no. 3520-3525

summary: Hoard of 2826 bronze coins: Augustus/Galba - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
disposition: Munzkabinett, Kunsthistorisches Museum, Wien; private collection Innsbruck, Austria; private collectio, Merano, Italy

summary: Found by a fisherman amongst rocks off the coast of Ambleteuse. Silver: ? (137) coins; Silver w8: ? (24.8-43.8g)
disposition: Boulogne (statue, cup, spoons); The British Museum (ewer)

summary: The hoard comprised 7 Celtic Iron Age coins. No further information was given regarding the composition of the hoard.
About 2000 antoniniani were discovered in unknown circumstances. No further Information.
56 antoniniani (radiates) found on the western wing of the cryptopórtico of the forum of Conimbriga: Gallienus (sole) - Victorinus (AD 269-271).

A large vessel of 4th century coins recorded in Pastscape. 133 coins of the younger Constantinus, Constans and Magnentius. British Museum Add MSS 53717 ff.310-2 sketches etc. (Rev. John Skinner, 7.5.1830).

2 gold solidi were found during construction work in October 1979 in a bank of soil protecting a new housing estate at Haydon Hill, Aylesbury. They were found about 1 metre down in soil which could have come from almost anywhere on the housing estate.
disposition: British Museum (Theodosius coin); the other coin sold by Sotheby’s (15 July 1980, lot 196A)

summary: 5 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 imitation.
The hoard comprised a ceramic container, the characteristics of which are unknown which contained 667 sestertii, 1 dupondius from Vespasian to Gordian III and 1 Provincial bronze of Hadrian.
disposition: Museo Arqueologico Provincial de Alicante, Spain

summary: 4 Iron Age coins acquired by the British Museum, said to have been found at Hurstbourne Tarrant, with possibly some additional coins.
Around 8000 nummi." This ‘hoard’ is only menti1d once by Bopearachchi and then never again; neither by him nor by any other author." No further information.

A possible small hoard of 30 coins given to Alton Museum in 1953. An accompanying label stated that they were dug up "more than a century ago" at Hartley Mauditt. HER record states that they "include 9 of Claudius II, 20 of Gallienus and 1 of Valerian".
A hoard of 62 denarii (Republic - Augustus), found in 1882 during drainage work in a moor in Niederlangen.
A hoard of aurei. Only 2 aurei of Domitian (Caesar) have been seen.

Hoard of circa 6000 siliquae (11.5 kilos). 3 lots from this hoard are known, comprising 536 coins: Constantius II (98); Julian (24); Jovian (20); Procopius (9); Valentinian I (128); Valens (157); Gratian (17); uncertain (92).
32 Roman gold coins of Augustus, Nero, Gaba, Vespasian and Domtitian, found at Callingwood, on the side of Needwood Forest in 1793 (or possibly 1788).
(130) 79 coins: 3 denarii, 4 antoniniani, 71 provincial bronze coins: Elagabalus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
Ritual deposit. Found during a metal detectorists' illegal survey. 3 siliquae, Valentinian I and Valens
18 denarii found on a field: Otho - Hadrian (AD 128-136).
The hoard comprised 12 solidi of Honorius, only 1 of which was described in any detail. Gold w8: 53.4g.
2 Corieltavian staters found about 6 or 7 metres apart in September 1999.
Hoard of 100 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Unknown initial number of coins: 28 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166); silver w8: 54.2-84.4g.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.no. M I 233-250

summary: The hoard comprised 4 sestertii ranging from Trajan to Faustina II. They were recovered during the excavation of a inhumation burial (tomb 2/1957) in the necropolis and were interpreted as the con10ts of a purse. Only 2 coins preserved, but descriptions of all of them exist.
disposition: Ufficio dei beni culturali, Bellinzona (2 coins); lost (2 coins)

summary: A hoard of 9 Alexandrian tetradrachms (Nero - Hadrian), found in house E.
IARCH record for a hoard of 33 copper alloy nummi of the House of Constantine. For full details and images see WMID-778A93.
(118) 114 aurei: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 196-211).
disposition: National History Museum Budapest, Hungary (114 coins)

summary: 435 nummi found in the area of room 116 of the bath complex: Constantine I - Theodosius II/Valentianian III (AD 402-455).

The hoard comprised more than 100 Provincial bronze coins of Ninica-Claudiopolis (1) and Tarsus (100+, with 115 listed by emperor) with issues ranging in date from Caracalla to Gallienus. Coin Hoards II, 153 gives the end date as AD 260.

3997 bronze coins recovered from a shipwreck on the bottom of the Garonne river. The coins were recovered in 2 stages: 939 in 1965, 3058 in 1970. In total: 3663 sestertii, 270 dupondii, 33 asses, 31 dupondii/asses: Claudius I - Antoninus Pius (159-161).
The hoard comprised 13 provincial tetradrachms dated between AD 60-61 and AD 107-110.

216 coins: 1 aureus, circa 200 silver and 13 bronze pieces: Galba to Valerian I (AD 253-260) found with a copper vessel, and inside was an envelope made up of 2 silver foils joined by very numerous and very small silver studs. Together were were found jewelry and tableware. Aurei including 1 of Galba. AR coins run from Vespasian to Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-260).
disposition: Musée d’Art et d’Histoire (MAH) de Genève, Switzerland

summary: 391 silver coins: 287 denarii from Vespasian to Gordian III; 101 antoniniani from Gordian III to Philip I; 3 bronze coins: 1 sestertius, 1 provincial, 1 unidentified (AD 244-249); silver w8: 437.2-913.2 g.
219 nummi: Constantius II - Arcadius (AD 402-408). Although are menti1d 228 nummi, only 219 are catalogued.
disposition: Soprintendenza Archeologica di Roma, Gabinetto Numismatico del Museo Nazionale Romano, Italy (inv. nos. 123676-123710)

summary: Fused lump of 10+ base metal coins. The hoard is a fused in a lump which has been squashed as if extruded through a narrow gap. Perhaps the result of concealment in a building which has subsequently burnt down. N1 of the uncertain number of coins can be identified but they are of the size of debased radiates or Constantinian nummi. W8 = 80.05g and max length = 75mm.
The hoard comprised 294 denarii from Republican issues through to Vespasian (AD 69-79).

About 800 denarii (Mark Antony to Caracalla) and fragments of a possible ceramic container found by workmen digging a ditch near Bron-y-Berllan farm. The original size of the find is uncertain; Davies (1929) records that the workmen who made the find pocketed an unknown number of coins, and that the remainder of the hoard was split between the British Museum (18 coins) and the Verney family of Bodelwyddan Castle, Anglesey. The size and condition of the hoard cannot be accounted for until 1918, when only 333 coins were transferred from Bodelwyddan to the Bangor museum. Robertson's examinations of the hoard in 1937 and 1948 identified 350 coins split between Bangor and the British Museum; the whereabouts of the remainder are unknown.
disposition: Storiel Museum, Bangor (c. 300 coins); British Museum (18 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised somewhere between 10000 and 32000 pieces, with an approximation of 15000 being the most likely. 4473 of the coins were recorded. 4471 of these belong to the Tetrarchy, 1 is dated AD 314/315. The hoard also contained a provincial coin issued in Nysa (Lydia) for Valerian.
The hoard comprised 30 electrum staters.
12 aurei: Galba - Aurelian (AD 270-275); gold w8: 73.8-98.7+g.
1 solidus and 8 siliquae, ranging from Julian to Gratian, found in September 2002, scattered over an area of some 30 yards square, during a metal detecting rally.
2000 silver coins found during road repairing works: Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249).
200 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel. 100 pieces were recovered: 92 denarii, 8 antoniniani (radiates): Vespasian – Philip I (AD 244-247).
disposition: History Museum, Caracal (17 coins); Museum of Oltenia, Craiova (83 coins), Romania

summary: The hoard comprised 42 bronze coins from Nero to Gallienus including imperial bronzes (sestertii) and Provincial bronzes from Knossos, Kydonia, Koinon of Crete and Alexandreia Troas.
47 coins - 1 antoninianus (radiate), 45 sestertii, 1 as - found with a ceramic vessel in a Roman villa: Antoninus Pius - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-259).

It comprised 500 Roman silver and billon coins, of which only 104 were identified dating from the reign of Antoninus Pius or Marcus Aurelius through to Carinus. It is possible that the radiate of Magnia Urbica is an intruder. Besançon mentions a coin of Maximinus Daia, but is an error resulting from confusion with Maximinus of Thrace. The hoard was found few meters from the hoard SAINT-GEORGES-DE-RENEINS 1880.
(50) 48 nummi House of Constantine I (AD 334-335)
disposition: Narodni muzej, Numizmatični cabinet, Ljubljana, Slovenia (48 coins)

summary: 441 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).

The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing several 100 bronze Iron Age coins. Chauvet catalogued 377. Although the tpq was originally fixed at 12-10 BC, the presence of a semis from Lyon may suggest a date between AD 10 and 14. The hoard was found by a farmer cutting hay.
disposition: Sold to B. Ledain, Daerocq and Rollin et Feuardent, the big coin dealers i Paris; the Lot Ledain in the municipal library in Poitiers (Roman coins); Musee Grandes Ecoles, Poitiers, France

summary: The hoard comprised 341 bronze coins dating to the 4th century AD.
The coins were found during the excavation of an underpass across form a T-junction of Hohenzollernstrass at Leoplatz.

'The hoard comprised an earthenware vessel filled with approximately 40 gold, silver and bronze coins with portraits of Trajan, Claudius II and Probus. The composition of this hoard is thought to be suspect.' The hoard was found in a small valley on the Guillet property.
The hoard comprised 15 sestertii of Faustina I to Valerian I.
