Hoard of 82 Republican and imperial denarii (including 16 of Augustus) found within the Dacian citadel during archaeological excavations: Republic – Augustus? (27 BC-AD 14). Found together with jewellery.
45 denari: Nerva - Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
783 denarii Republic to Domitian (AD 95-96) and 1 of Marcus Aurelius as intruder
disposition: National History Museum, Budapest, Hungary (1879, no 161/1-146).

summary: A possibly large number (1700?) of Roman coins were found at Cadnam, in the Forest, contained in a thumb pot. This included coins of Tetricus (I or II?).

Roman coin hoard: 9 3rd-4th century coins fused together. The coins have been burnt, with some charcoal adhering to the corrosion products. The coins are visible in 2 stacks, 1 of the stacks has considerably more damage due to burning. 4 coins are clearly visible in 1 stack, with 1 face exposed. No detail is visible on the exposed coin face - there is possibly a radiate crown, however this is uncertain due to the level of corrosion. The exposed coin has a diameter of 13.24mm. The amount of coins on the second stack is more difficult to assertain due to the fused and melted condition. This area appears to have 4 coins stacked on top of each other with corrosion products inbetween, a further coin joins the 2 stacks together. The remaining area of corrosion contains fragments of coins, however due to the burnt condition it is unclear whether these are part of the coins listed above, or are additional coins. It weighs 12.74 grams.
Originally, it consisted of more than 5 kg of silver. Iberian and Roman denarii, today lost. Only 20 denarii studied.
disposition: Museo Provincial de Zamora, Spain (jewelry only)

summary: A hoard of an unknown number of denarii. Only 15 coins were documented: Hadrian (Aelius Caesar) - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-178). Kropotkin suspected that it may be the same hoard as Sosnitsa.
disposition: University Museum, Kyiv, Ukraine (15 coins until 1917)

summary: Hoard of 158 coins found with a ceramic vessel: 7 imitations of Thasian tetradrachms, 138 republican denarii, 13 imperial denarii: Republic - Augustus (19-4 BC).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Stara Zagora, Bulgaria (inv.no. 2865)

summary: 10 bronze coins minted in Deultum: Severus Alexander, Julia Mamaea, Gordian III, Otacilia Severa.
3942 nummi (3.40 kilos): pre-Constantine I - Valentinian III (AD 425-455).
The hoard comprised 24 antoniniani: Gallienus (sole)-Claudius II (Divus) (AD 270 AD).
disposition: Museo Civico Bottacin di Padova, Italy (inv.nos. 24174-24196)

summary: A hoard of 15 clipped siliquae from the Artillery Folley area of Colchester (an area used as a cemetery in the Roman perid). Crummy (1987, 71) states that the latest issues are of Arcadius and Honorius. However, Radford and Gascoyne (2013) describe this as 15 siliquae of Constantine III (apparently a mis-reading of Crummy 1987's comments).
Circa 300 denarii and 6 aurei were discovered on the Anselmi proprty. Today, are known only 20 denarii and 2 aurei: Republic - Augustus (29-27 BC).
Hoard of 23 nummi - possible, House of Constantine I - found in the area G at the site La Alcudia. Some scholars considered it as single finds.
Unknown number of antoniniani. Dr. Harlanov examined 15 pieces: Caracalla 1, Gordian III 13, Philip I 1; silver w8: 20.1-37.6 g.

The hoard comprises 182 antoniniani (radiates). The 182 pieces were found stacked on 3 rows: in the first 2 there were series of 13 to 15 coins forming tubes on the edges above the lowest series. At the lower level they appeared more arbitrarily placed in a larger radius. 3 tegulae formed a vault over the whole.
2 Gallo-Belgic Ca staters thought to be from the same deposit.
2 solidi of Valentinian II.

All of the coins are Iron Age coins, specifically of the 'North Eastern' regional series that is of10 ascribed to the Corieltavi tribe. The coins comprise 3 basic types; the so-called "South Ferriby", "Domino" and "Kite" type staters.

c.50 loose coins and concreted mass weighing 1.8kg· The hoard probably consists of c. 400 ish coins which have corroded into a single concreted mass - the single block weighs approximately 2 kilos and there are another c. 50 loose coins.An organic container was thought likely - traces of leather were found.
12 denarii (Trajan - Caracalla) were registered at the Landesmuseum Hannover in 1916, as having been found together at Klein-Hesebeck. The coins are now lost.
2 Republican denarii, 1 denarius of Augustus, and 2 gold quarter staters of Cunobelin.

6 coins were found together with the artefacts of this hoard: Domitian bronze coin, Trajan (1 sestertius, 1 dupondius), Hadrian 1 sestertius, Antoninus Pius 1 dupondius, Postumus 1 antoninianus (radiate). The Chaourse Treasure is made up of 39 objects in total, all of which are silver apart from 5 small vessels and a silvered bronze mirror. There are 4 large serving platters; 1 of which has the swastika in its central medallion, another has a gilded figure of the Roman god Mercury holding his caduceus flanked by a ram and a cockerel. In addition, there are plain silver drinking cups, various jugs, 2 large situlas 1 of which has an acanthus-scroll frieze, shallow plates, hemispherical bowls (1 of which was used for washing hands), flanged and fluted bowls (some with engraved decoration of animals amid floral patterns), some mirrors, an ornate strainer with floral and geometric designs, a statuette of the deity Fortuna and a pepper-pot in the shape of an African slave-boy. (Wikipedia)
277 antoniniani (radiates) and 29 imitations (28 radiates and 1 denarius): Severus Alexander - Victorinus (AD 269-271).
Hoard of circa 200 coins. Only 17 antoniniani (radiates) were recovered: Trajan Decius - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 259).
1576 coins found in 2 ceramic vessels: 1 denarius, 1575 antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander (Julia Mammaea), Trebonianus Gallus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver w8: c. 300.6-2110.7 g.
8 solidi: Valentinian I - Honorius (AD 402-408) and 2 gold rings; gold w8: 35.6 g.
Unknown initial number of denarii. 40 coins entered the museum collection in Sofia: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.no. X

summary: Over 4500 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Claudius II - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 293 -294) found in a room (same rooms as KOM AUSHIM A51, A100, A115, A118, A119), stored on the floor, during excavations of a house.

The hoard comprised a bronze vessel containing approximately 6000 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) (2500 coins according to Guilmeth). 19 examples were acquired by the Musée de Rouen (Inv. I, no. 411) Found by a peasant called Renard; silver w8: c. 1621.0-7499.1g.
Circa 2000 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani from Vespasian to Trajan Decius. Mostly, Gordian III and Philip I. Found in a ceramic vessel.
7 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 imitation: Claudius II - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
7 antoniniani: Tacitus - Carinus (AD 283-284)
Circa 150 nummi found with a ceramic vessel. Only 75 pieces were documented: Gratian - Theodosius I and his sons (AD 393-395).
disposition: Casa-Museo Posada del Moro, Torrecampo, Spain

summary: The hoard comprised 104 small bronzes [antoniniani (radiates)]of Tetricus I. Of 97 examined by Bizeul, 76 were illegible and 27 difficult to recognise because their legends were incomplete, their reverses were barbarous or their flans were too small to strike. It is clear these coins were all barbarous radiates.
100 solidi of Honorius type RIC 35c Mediolanum; gold w8: c.445.0g.
Over 100 aurei. 94 aurei documented: Tiberius - Domitian (AD 88-94).
A farmer in 1864 found over 60 specimens of Roman silver coins during plowing on a small hill in the vicinity of Erfurt. 29 coins were described (Trajan - Marcus Aurelius).
Hoard of 109 gold stateri of Sauromates II found during the excavations (AD 205-206)
133 denarii found, most likely, with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211). Skok mentions also coins of Severus Alexander, probably mistaken for Septimius Severus.
872 Iron Age silver units in a pot.
49 nummi: Constantius II - Arcadius (AD 383-388)
Hoard found during ploughing, 200 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
2000 bronze coins, probably, kept in a wooden box: Hadrian - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
The coins were 'found in a lead cremation urn containing human b1s and comprised 40 copper coins of Tiberius and 3 silver pieces.'
1103 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Gallienus (sole) - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 296) found in a disintegrated cloth bag in an underground room during excavations of a house.
Hoard of 106 denarii found while metal detecting and during the archaeological investigations that followed: 77 republican, 22 imperials, 7 imitations. Tpq. 11-10 BC.
The hoard comprised at least 39 electrum staters and 175 electrum quarter staters attributed to the Iron Age Amorican tribe Osismii.
18 (?) silver coins, found 1925 on the street 'Am Römerwall'. 21 coins are menti1d in the inventory of the Altermusmuseum, but the coins are now lost.

In 1978 a small hoard of 13 Roman silver coins (11 miliarenses and 2 siliquae) of the late 4th century was found at the edge of a road leading to Kempston Church. Most finds of late Roman silver consist primarily of siliquae with the addition of a small number of miliarenses, but the present find of 11 miliarenses and only 2 siliquae is unusual.
The hoard comprised 73 bronze coins dated between the first and second century AD and AD 393-423.
The hoard comprised a terracotta vessel containing approximately 50 sestertii of Trajan, Hadrian and Antoninus Pius. The hoard was found on the Mortrais farm.

At least 33 denarii (Vespasian to Marcus Aurelius) found in 1940 by gardeners engaged in converting a 10nis court into a vegetable patch. Pye reports that the hoard was contained in a pot with a tile lid, since lost, and that 1 of the finders removed at least 27 of the coins, n1 of which were recovered. 4 further reports of coins from Corton House appear in the Transactions of the Radnorshire Society over succeeding years; whether these were new discoveries at/near the same site or part of the original find is unclear. The original size of the hoard is, therefore, uncertain, and is likely to have been larger than the 33 denarii detailed here.
44 denarii: Trajan - Didius Julianus (AD 193). Found together with a silver brooch dated between the end of the 4th century beginning of the 5th century AD.

Remains of a wealthy residential development was unearthed during excavation for the new synagogue. In the process 11 Roman bronze coins were found (2 großerz of Antoninus Pius, 2 mittelerz of Commodus, and klenerz from the father Tetricus).
7 antoniniani (4 copies) Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Namur, Belgium (11 coins); collection Vandermaelen (2 coins and the shards from vessel), in 1851

summary: The hoard comprised 'a large number of coins of various rulers'. It is likely to be the same hoard as 1 found 'close to Saint Pol' comprising 200 coins menti1d in a letter from the antiquarian Beaucousin to Mionnet
2 denarii of Hadrian

33 Alexandrian tetradrachms and a fragment of a bronze-ring. Found in a wooden jar in the courtyard just in front of a door during excavations of a house. Ranking: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 292-293).

2 wooden caskets (wooden has vanished) comprising coins and jewelry were found at 50 cm 1 from the other in a pithos pit in the citadel of Artezia. The first casket contains 146 coins: 145 bronze staters: autonomous issues and Bosporan kings and 1 denarius of Tiberius. Together, there had been a variety of items of jewelry: 1 thin annular bracelet made of twisted silver, 3 large penannular bronze bracelets – some twisted and some smooth (silver hairpins fused with 1 of them), a string of hollow bronze beads cylindrical in shape, a necklace of very large paste and glass eye-beads, a thin and flat bronze mirror round in shape, a large bronze ring which had lost its oval inlay; a small silver earring; a fragment of an iron ring (?) and part of a badly corroded thin-walled bronze item (clasp?).
A hoard of 6000+ AE of Apamea (56.5 kg) found in a pithos dating to the mid first century BCE.
54 coins: 53 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 nummus found with a ceramic vessel: Gallienus - Constantine I (AD 316-317).
2 denarii: Antoninus Pius, Commodus (AD 183).

17 denarii of a hoard found in 1690, allegedly in the collection of the 'Königlich-Sächsisches Münzkabinett', though the inventory books of the museum do not contain any mention of a find made in Querfurt. Coins ranged from Vespasian to Trajan.
A hoard of 19 denarii and 31 antoniniani (radiates), ranging from Galba to Trajan Decius (AD 249-251), found during excavations in Bavay.

find_spot_name: KÖLN - ST. MARIA IM KAPITOL I
summary: A person found a large hoard in 1895 during excavation works for a new parish office on the north side of Marienplatz, next to a dismantled corner house, on a bricked road at the parish house of St. Maria im Kapitol. The coins were situated partly in several amphorae, part in a wooden cask from molded wood remains, and there were also rings. The coins were oxidized together in a large clump. Immediately after the discovery of the hoard the coins were acquired by a museum. The record identifies 600 Roman specimens from St. Maria im Kapitol purchased in 1895 by S. Job. The museum must have acquired altogether approx. 628 specimens.
7 gold coins: 4 solidi, 3 tremisses, all of Zeno (AD 474-491);gold w8: 22.3g. Found with jewelry in a grave.

Hoard of 1 silver coin and 21 Aes coins: 1 denarius (Domitian), 13 Asses (1 Lugdunum I, 1 Divus Augustus PROVIDENT, 6 Flavian, 4 Nerva, 1 Trajan); 6 dupondii (3 Flavian, 1 Nerva, 2 Trajan); 2 sestertii (Titus and Trajan).
1300 republican and imperial denarii, ending with issues of Augustus and Tiberius (AD 14-37).
A scattered hoard of Gallo-Belgic uniface staters, found in several episodes of detecting from 1999 to 2014.
30 sestertii found stuck together in a Roman edifice: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD162-163).
disposition: Museo de Arqueología de Álava, Spain

summary: A hoard of 10 aurei and 120+ denarii, found in 1878 near the Roman fort. The closure date of this hoard is AD 192. However the penultimate coin is an issue of 185 and a 7 year gap between the terminal issues is unusual. In the event the hoard is listed as closing with RIC 241, with the caveat that the last coin may be a site find rather than a hoard item (P.J. Casey).
(c. 1000) 88 silver coins (denarii and antoniniani): Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver w8: 1251.6-2848.4 g
21 provincial asses of Tiberius: 20 Segobriga, 1 Turiaso.
17 sestertii and middle bronzes from Augustus to Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
The hoard comprised 39 radiates of Gallienus and Salonina, found in the Euripides / Peristeria cave, on the south of the island of Salamis.
The hoard comprised 119 gold coins, consisting of 102 aurei and 17 multiples, dating between the reigns of Probus and Constantine.
The hoard comprised 44 coins dated between the 4th-3rd century BCE and the reign of Hadrian (AD 117-138).
7 nummi displayed as funerary offering near the skeleton: House of Constantine I t- House of Valentinian I (AD 367-375).
20 copper Roman coins from a salt spring: Nero - Philip I (AD 244-249).

Hoard of circa 1200 'large bronzes' found with a large ceramic vessel: Trajan - Aemilian (AD 253). The largest number of coins belonged to Severus Alexander, Gordian III, Philip I and Philip II. Rare issues of the emperors Pertinax, Clodius Albinus, Gordian I and II,
Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 52 denarii were recovered: Republic – Augustus (19 BC).
disposition: Museum of Oltenia, Craiova, (50 coins); private collection in Craiova (2 coins), Romania

summary: 1 as, 1 sestertius, 1 denarius and 7555 radiates and a bronze ring to AD 274.
65 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 257); silver w8: 82.6-167.6 g.

35 mostly Constantinian nummi (c. AD 310-35) found during excavation of the fort's eastern rampart. It is likely that the hoard was contained in 3 ceramic jars, bases of which were found in fragmentary condition along with the coins. Boon (1982) suggests that the bodies of these containers, along with many more coins, were lost to plough action long ago.

In 1806, on the south-west side of Trinity Court, near the Turnpike Road, a hoard of nearly 1 hundred Roman coins was found. 79 of them were listed, ranging from the Republican period to Trajan. A few days after, a medal of Nero, and 1 of Antoninus Pius were found on the same spot. The Republican coins were certainly silver, but the metal of the others is uncertain.
6 nummi: Licinius I - Constantine I.

The hoard comprised a ceramic jar containing 37 bronze and silver coins dated between 146-139 BC and AD 193-211. The hoard was found in association with the remains of an ancient building, but this was destroyed during construction work.
Unknown original number of denarii. 20 coins are known: 5 antoniniani (radiates), 15 nummi: Gallienus (sole) – Valens (AD 64-378).
disposition: Museum of Moravia, Brno, Czech Republic; Collection Červinkova

summary: 12 denarii entered the collection of the Pedagogic High-School in Iași: Vitellius – Hadrian (AD 125-128). Part of the hoards Strunga I and II.
(100) 32 coins, 1 aureus, denarii and antoniniani: Vespasian - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; 29 coins; inv.no. LVII; History Museum, Lovech; 2 coins; inv.no. 1784 1-2

summary: At least 50 denarii and antoniniani (radiates), but only 5 are identified: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
167 coins of the 3rd-4th centuries AD well preserved. No further information.
The hoard comprised 525 nummi from the House of Constantine.
(c. 4.300-4500) 4148 denarii: Vitellius - Gordian III (AD 240); silver w8: 5625.4-11847.6 g
disposition: Museum of Pitești, Romania, 4,126 coins; private collction Ioan Ciucă, Sâmburești, 16 coins; private collection Traian Cantemir, Bacău, 6 coins

summary: The hoard comprised a vessel containing 6 gold coins and 29 silver coins of the Roman emperors. No further information.

The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing approximately 1100 antoniani (radiates) from Valerian to Diocletian and Maximian I. Those of Saloninus, Salonina, Tacitus, Numerian, Carinus and Constantius I were quite numerous; those of Postumus, Victorinus, Tetricus I. Aurelian, Probus, Maximian I and Diocletian were quite abundant; those of Gallienus and Claudius II were the most numerous. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of between 131.1g and 1248.9g.
651 silver coins: 435 denarii, 216 cistophori found with a jug: Republic - Augustus (2 BC - AD 4).
4 aurei: Vespasian, Antoninus for Faustina I/Diva Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius, Septimius Severus. No detailed information.
Hoard of around 2000 denarii. 90 denarii entered the University Museum in Kyiv: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

The hoard comprised about 50 kg antoniniani (radiates) of Valerian I, Gallienus, Salonina, Postumus, Laelian, Marius, Victorinus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II, Claudius II, Divo Claudio, Quintillus, Aurelian and Tacitus. 2226 coins and 1 blank have been studied.

This hoard of 64 denarii and antoniniani (Antoninus Pius - Trajan Decius) was found in 1846 «Im Lustgar10». The entire hoard arrived in the private collection of Großherzog Leopold, but could not be traced after that.

214 coins were discovered during the emergency excavations. Around 60-70 nummi were found with sherds of late terra sigillata and considered as a possible hoard: Constantine I - Magnus Maximus (AD 383-387).
The hoard comprised an earthenware vessel containing 700 silver and billon coins (denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - MArius (AD 269).
hoard of around 100 coins, mostly nummi of the 4th century AD: Gallienus - Constantius II (AD 355-361). 1 barbarous plated imitations of a denarius.

A hoard of 1925 denarii (Republic - Severus Alexander), found during levelling operations in the area of Bell's Meadow, in Falkirk, ca. 400 m NW of the Anto9 Wall, in a vessel of red earthenware. A piece of cloth had been used to protect the mouth of the vessel. A few coins were lost, but all others passed into the hands of the Crown Authorities as treasure-trove. In all, 1925 coins, comprising 1923 denarii, 1 drachm of Lycia, and 1 bronze core of a plated denarius, were examined and published in 1934 by G. MacDonald. A new list, based on visual examination of the preserved coins, is given by Robertson, Studia Paulo Naster Oblata (1982). The latter recorded only 1917 coins. The missing coins were 2 denarii of Vespasian, 1 of Domitian, 2 of Trajan, 1 of Antoninus Pius, 1 of Diva Faustina I, and 1 of Septimius Severus. Recent studies have shown that 3 of the denarii attributed by Sir George Macdonald to Caracalla should be assigned to Elagabalus.
disposition: NMAS, Edinburgh (pot, cloth frag. and most of the 1925 coins)

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. Circa 200 sestertii were seen From Flavians to Septimius Severus (AD 197). Only 29 were available for study.
10590 nummi: Constantine I/Licinius I (AD 324)
357 antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Claudius II (AD 268-270); silver w8: 97.4-445.3 g.
disposition: Collezioni Governative del Medagliere Milanese, Italy (in 1923).

summary: 6 Iron Age silver units, found between 1999 and 2002.
The hoard comprised 47 shekels of the First Jewish Revolt (AD 66-72).

The hoard comprised an amphora containing more than 33 kilos of coins, estimated as representing more than 8000 examples. Vallier examined 'a suitcase full' of coins which included issues of Gallienus, Claudius II (rare), Aurelian, Severina, Tacitus, Florian, Probus and Numerian. It appears that there were also some earlier coins dating to the first or second centuries AD but the information is vague.
146 coins: 1 denarius, 91 antoniniani (radiates), 49 antoniniani (radiates) imitations, 3 sestertii, 2 dupondii/asses: Marcus Aurelius - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
1300 coins found with a ceramic vessel: Claudius II - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
Hoard of 300 republican denarii. Partially recovered. Latest issue: 43-42 BC.

A hoard of 97 tetradrachms (Nero–Severus Alexander), 25 denarii, and 1 antoninianus, found in a trench excavation at Gindaros. As no further excavations were d1 araound that trench, the archaeological context remains so far uncertain.

Over 300 denarii, only 8 coins were seen: Antoninus Pius 1, Antoninus Pius (Faustina I/Diva Faustina I) Marcus Aurelius 2, Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II/Diva Faustina II), Marcus Aurelius (Commodus Caesar), Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla).
Scarce Information on a hoard, in which circa 20 antoniniani depict portarits of 7 emeperors between AD 238-268 from Gordian III to Claudius II (AD 268-270).
disposition: Museum of Sain-Sulpice, France, but no records of them in the registers.

summary: Around 160 denarii of which 148 preserved, found with a ceramic vessel: Republic - augustus (-2 BC - AD 14).
disposition: National Museum in Kielce, Poland, inv. No. MNKi/A/2353/1-147; Regional Museum in Sandomierz (Muzeum Okręgowe w Sandomierzu), inv. No. MS-585/h

summary: The hoard was found in Burial 12, in the late Roman cemetery of Abbeville. It comprised a purse filled with 12 late Roman nummi. There was also a siliqua of Valens placed inside the mouth of the deceased.
210 denarii of Augustus (issue AVGVSTVS DIVI F / IMP X), all RIC 167a.

77 bronze coins: 1 sestertius, 76 nummi, 2nd century AD, House of Constantine I, House of Valentinianus I (AD 367-375). The hoard was found in a leather purse together with 3 bronze rings. The purse was discovered between the legs of a Skeleton in a grave beside a knife. 7 more coins were found in the same grave displaey near the left leg (see VRON 1).
Find of 4 aurei.
Unknown number of silver coins found in a ceramic vessel. 50 coins were seen: Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
1424 nummi found with a ceramic vessel: Constantine I/Licinius I - Gratian (AD 375-383).
(488) 168 silver coins: Commodus - Quintillius (AD 270)
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. LXVII (75 coins)

summary: 84 nummi found spread on the pavement of a room: Constantius II -Avitus (AD 455-456).
A large number of denarii. 78 denarii are kept in the Regional History Museum, Vratsa: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. M II 4191-4268

summary: Part of a larger hoard. 50 silver coins: 13 denarii, 37 antoniniani: Domitian - Philip I (AD 247-249); silver w8: 64.6-130.2 g.
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Stara Zagora, Bulgaria; inv.no. 3173-3186

summary: 2 solidi - Valens, Honorius - found at the same findspot in different years.
163 nummi: House of Constantine I (AD 346-350)
270 coins found in a ceramic vessel: 70 antoniniani (radiates), 200 sestertii. 107 coins were examined: 16 antoniniani (radiates), 91 sestertii: Trajan - Marius (AD 269).
5 denarii found together: Augustus - Elagabalus (AD 218-222).

At least 4 Irstead quarter staters formerly owned by Henry Mossop were said to have been found at Cherry Hinton, 3 of which (nos 1, 3 and 4 below; Haselgrove 1989, 24) came from the same source. No further information is available on the circumstances of their discovery.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 1109 coins. They include 1108 radiates from Valerian to Tetricus and 1 denarius copy of Elagabalus.
IARCH record for a hoard of 17 silver siliquae (including fragments) and 4 copper alloy nummi. For further details and images see NMS-38CFB0.
12 Roman copper coins, found in Marsh Lane, Nantwich. No further information.

The hoard comprised a terracotta vessel containing carbonised wood, a gold finger ring with a st1 setting, a gold earring, a copper-alloy earring, a copper-alloy bell, a pewter spoon and 12 coins of the Late Empire.
"Urn filled up with coins of the ancient emperors of Rome".
The hoard comprised approximately 1200 radiates of 'the epoque of Postumus and some contemporary official and ursurper emperors.'
87 silver coins found in the "Ancient theater": Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
IARCH record for hoard of 2 Iron Age gold coins.
5 bronze coins found in room 42 of the 'Gordian's Palace': Antoninus Pius 1 sestertius, Faustina II 1 sestertius, 1 as/dupondius, Gordian III 2 sestertii.
A small hoard recorded only by Chadburn (2006, Appendix H, hoard 4), combining normal face/horse units with 1 ANTED unit. No further details of the discovery are known.

The hoard comprised 773 aurei - 18 coins were already missing in 1874 - from Claudius I to Septimius Severus (Geta Caesar) with a tpq of AD 205-207 and was found in association with a staircase, presumably part of a Roman building or cellar. There are at least 3 different catalogues giving different totals of coins and it is likely that on discovery several coins were retained by the workmen who discovered the find. The Cabinet des Médailles acquired 15 coins from the hoard, for which RIC level data is available. Hobbs estimates a gold w8 of approximately 8520.6 to 9239.4g.
3 Gallo-Belgic C staters believed to have been found together.

83 bronze coins and (silver coins?) found in a marble rock. There is some information on 28 coins: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). The 3 denarii may not belong to this hoard (Dembski 1977).
disposition: Museum Carolino Augusteum, Salzburg, Austria (26 coins); Prähistorischen Staatssammlung, München, Germany (3 coins?)

summary: Found during excavations (Fouille C [b/6], layer II), around st1s that probably were part of a dirt floor.

22 East Anglian silver units and a Republican denarius were found in a field at North Creake in 1990. In May 1995 2 detectorists found another 16 silver Icenian units and 1 Republican denarius (103 BC). It seems likely that all of the coins may have come from a single scattered hoard.
735 denarii found with ceramic vessel and a textile bag: Nero – Septimius Severus (AD 195). Found together with a silver T-brooch within a Sarmatian settlement.
disposition: Numismatic Collection of the Institute of Archeology, Iași, inv. no. 323370 (the brooch)

summary: A hoard of Roman aurei and denarii as well as punch-marked coins. This is the only hoard from India which definitely contained coins of 2 metals. Some of denari are broken.
7 antoniniani (radiates) found in House 1: Gallienus 6, Salonina 1. The coins were stacked to each other.
Unknown number of denarii hoard. 4 coins entered museum collection in Yambol: Vespasian 2, Nerva 1, Trajan 1.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Yambol, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2924-2929

summary: The hoard comprised a large number of denarii and radiates, although only 160 were recorded and were issues from Septimius Severus to Postumus. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of 50.3g to 413.7g.
A hoard of 1 Aureus of Nero, Rome, AD 65-66, 4 denarii (Republic and Vespasian) and 5 bronze rings, found Canisius College terrain in Nijmegen.
disposition: Museum Het Valkhof (see links under individual objects and coins)

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 840 well-preserved sestertii, of which 808 were identified by Auvray. The composition of this hoard varies slightly in lists compiled by Ledru and Cauvin. L'annuaire l'An VIII mentions coins of Septimius Severus and of Caracalla from the same parish. It is possible that these were also a part of the hoard, although they have not been added to the database record.
13 nummi: Constantine I – Constantius II (AD 337-361).
disposition: Collection František Brož, Prague, missing today.

summary: 3 uniface Atrebatic staters, all from the same reverse die and reportedly found together.
A rather confused record of a series of finds, totalling 62 Iron Age staters found in a field. 4 Roman silver coins also menti1d as stray finds in 1996
The hoard comprised somewhere between 2000 and 2500 coins, of which a large proportion were taken by the finders. Only 308 coins were catalogued.
36 aurei: Vespasian - Trajan (AD 103-111) found hidden in the wall of a Roman house.
The hoard comprised approximately 600 coins from Gallienus to Postumus. Found during flint extraction.
400 imperial denarii and 1 aureus of Domitian. No further information.

On the 30.5.1862, approximately 4000 billon coins and small radiates dating to the third century AD were found during marshland reclamation work. On 21.07.1862, an excavation of the site, recovered a further 3000 coins of the same date. The coins were deposited in 2 piles 1.5m from each other at a depth of 0.95m. They were found in a layer of aquatic plant debris. Fillon lists the emperors represented as Volusian, Valerian, Gallienus, Salonina, Saloninus, Claudius II, Quintillus, Aurelian, Postumus, Laelian, Marius, Victorinus, Tetricus I and Tetricus II. There were no more than 100 coins dating to before the death of Postumus. According to Fillon, the radiates of Postumus without exception dated to the Ivth and Vth consulates. The coins of Tetricus made up 9/10ths of the hoard. There were about 10 coins of Aurelian (pre-reform) and for the most part were found in the second pile. Fillon's engravings indicate that there were also barbarous copies of coins of Divus Claudius, Victorinus and Tetricus. The hoard was found during drainage of marshland on the land of Mme de Craon-Beauveau.
50 Roman imperial coins, only 10 are known: Augustus - Constantius II (AD 337-361).
disposition: Coin Room, National History Museum of Latvia, Riga (inv.nos. LNVM NUM - CVVM 120189: 1-17

summary: The hoard was found within the cella of a Gallo-Roman 'fanum' or shrine. It comprised a black ceramic vessel containing 49 nummi of Constantine I, Crispus, Constantine II, House of Constantine Constantinoplis and Roma issues, Constans, Constantius II and Magnentius.
5989 Roman denarii (Augustus - Septimius Severus, AD 209) and 1 drachm of Caesarea in Cappadocia (Antoninus Pius) were uncovered, hidden under the floor of a house.
The workers discovered a metallic vase with 20 kg of coins (maybe antoniniani). Only 214 are now recorded, from Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (Gallienus) - Diocletian (AD 284-293).
disposition: Berry Museum, St. Moritz, Switzerland (part of the hoard)

summary: (c. 1400) 1352 antoniani (radiates): Caracalla - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-268); silver w8: c.1751.4-3638.7 g.
disposition: Museum Dauphinoise, Grenoble, France; part of the coins and the container.

summary: The hoard comprised about 600 bronzes of Postumus.

A hoard of 48 solidi, ranging from Valentinian to Magnus Maximus, found in or near a small furnace in site 12 in Corbridge. The coins showed no signs of having been subjected to heat, and the furnace must have been aband1d before the date of its deposit.
130 silver coins: 109 denarii, 21 antoniniani: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-246); silver w8: 187.6-294.9 g
The assemblage comprised 73 Roman coins. They may represent a hoard.
The hoard comprised 461 bronze coins, including 4 dupondii and asses and 457 sestertii of Galba to Marcus Aurelius, with a tpq of AD 172 to 173.
(32) 2 denarii: Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180)
The hoard comprised 2 silver drachms of the Koinon of Crete (Caligula, given to Gortyn? in RPC I), found in Grave 12 of the Roman cemetery of Agios Nikolaos.

The hoard comprised a vessel (or vessels) containing 7kg of coins, equating to approximately 2500 silver Republican coins and base-gold and silver Iron Age coins. In 1876, an excavation of the findspot revealed a further 60 coins which are likely to be part of the same assemblage. The number of Republican coins known from the site total 1298 plus a further 30 found in 1876. The Iron Age coins known from the site total approximately 1160 plus a further 30 in 1876.
A hoard of 1153 denarii (Republic to Nero, AD 64), found in a field in 2008 (1121 specimens), with 5 additional coins found in 2012, and 2 more in 2013.
The hoard comprised 13 bronze coins, dated between AD 244-253.
12000 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) - 33 Kilos - found with ceramic vessel: Antoninus Pius - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).

Forger's hoard of 121 coinsand blanks (only 2 coins). The finder also found a fragment of copper alloy rod, a sherd of courseware pottery and a brooch. It is possible, but by no means certain that the hoard was secreted in a pot, but the surviving rim comes from a vessel much larger than was needed to contain the coins and other objects.

The hoard derives from the collection of the musician Simon Antoni, which was acquired by the Kreuznach museum in 1888, with an inventory of 1488 Roman coins. Of these, some coins were found 'am Lemberg', probably between 1830 and 1860. FMRD lists 102 antoniniani, ranging from Valerian (for Saloninus) to Tetricus.
3 aurei found at the bottom of "an old wall": Faustina I, Faustina II under Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Caesar). The hoard was found by a farmer.
75 silver republican coins: 59 denarii, 16 quinarii. The latest issue, 48 BC.
13 nummi: Tetrarchy - Constantius II (AD 337-361).
disposition: Coin Room, National History Museum of Latvia, Riga (inv.nos. LNVM NUM - CVVM 12675: 1-13

summary: Originally, were 250 coins found with a ceramic vessel. The hoard comprised sestertii and dupondii dating to the reign of Claudius I. The coins are all die-linked.
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Nacional de Tarragona, Spain

summary: The hoard comprised 79 denarii including issues of Domitian.
8 denarii up to AD 37 and 6 bronze coins to Nero. The Iron Age unit was not considered to be part of the hoard when reported.
The hoard comprised 23 bronze coins of Alexander Jannaeus (103-76 BC).

The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel covered with a copper-alloy plate and comprised approximately 10000 radiates of Tetricus I, Victorinus, Gallienus, Claudius II, Aurelian, Tacitus and Probus. Only 18 coins were preserved.
2 solidi of Leo I (AD 462-466). Probably, a much larger hoard as there was some information on more solidi found by locals at the same site in the previous years.
255 denarii found and sent to the Ministry of Finance. The coins were found with pieces of an urn during the removal of st1s from a field.
An iron box containing between 200 and 300 setstertii issued in the 2nd century AD.
The hoard was found during the excavation of a villa and comprised 105 nummi dating to the 4th and fifth centuries AD.
A group of coins and artefacts reported to the HER that was subsequently identified as a possible scattered hoard.
The hoard comprised 90 bronze coins, 85 of which were identified, dated between AD 351-354 and AD 365-378.
126 sestertii: Domitian - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
19 silver coins: 18 denarii, 1 quinarius: Republic - Augustus (2 BC - AD 14).
95 denarii: Republic – Vespasian (AD 69-79).
31 denarii found in a silo at the site of the Cherniakyv Culture: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192). Together were found 2 silver loops.
disposition: Institute of Archaeology of the Academy of Sciences, Kyiv, Ukraine (11 coins, 1 loop); School museum, Davydovka, Ukraine

summary: Unknown number of coins found in a ceramic vessel while ploughing. 32 pieces (denarii, antoniniani, provincial bronzes) entered the museum collection in Shumen: Marcus Aurelius - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 1507-1537, 1546

summary: 23 nummi of Constantine I Family and Licinius I (AD 306-337).
30 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180), latest coin, AD 156-157.
disposition: Rijksmuseum van Oudheden Leiden, Netherlands; inv.no. 17379

summary: 8 antoniniani ranging from Philip I to Victorinus 8, possibly part of a hoard found in 1935. The coins were found in northern area of Edlington Wood, below Crags.
5 gold coins: 1 multiple 1 1/2 aureus, 4 aurei: Maximinus II Daia - Constantine I (AD 317); gold w8: 27.8g;
disposition: National History Museum, Coin Room, Belgrade, Serbia (1981)

summary: 67 coins found in the ruins of an ancient building, on "Trajan's road": 66 silver, 1 bronze of Philip II of Macedon: Philip II of Macedon - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
Approximatively 200 denarii (or only 141?), ranging from Galba to Septimius Severus, found on the Hill of Megray, north of St1haven, of which only 20 were preserved and described.
disposition: National Museums & Galleries of Scotland, Edinburgh (part)

summary: Circa 100 coins. 12 silver coins: 4 denarii, 8 antoniniani are kept in the local museum of Sevlievo: Elagabalus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
Unknown number of silver coins found in a ceramic vessel. 138 were examined and 18 entered the museum collection in Dalgopol: Titus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: History Museum, Dalgopol, Bulgaria; inv.no. N. 0026/1-18 (18 coins)

summary: 800 coins of unknown denomination and issuers: "many Roman medallions (Schaugeld) and mounted coins (Gneden-Pfennig)".
3 coins which were described as "virtual surface finds" in a ploughed field, within 35 feet (11 m) of 1 another.

In the summer of 1959, during excavations on a pre-Roman and Romano-British site on the east bank of the Avon at Armsley in the parish of Godshill, Hants, a small hoard of 4 Durotrigic coins was discovered together with a bronze fibula of La Tène III type. No further details of the context of the "hoard", or its precise association with the fibula are given. The 3 staters are described (Shortt 1960, 1) as "showing evident signs of silver plating.
The hoard comprised 25 bronze coins dated to the reign of Alexander Jannaeus (104-76 BC).
(180) 141 silver coins: 140 denarii, 1 Lycian drachm dating from the Republic to Trajan.
disposition: Union Museum Alba Iulia, Romania (141 coins)

summary: 4 staters and a gold droplet found near Saxilby in October 2007.
4 denarii: Trajan, Hadrian, Marcus Aurelius, Commodus (Crispina) (AD 178-188); silver w8: 10.25 g.
13 bronze coins: 4 sestertii, 2 dupondii, 7 asses: Claudius I - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-175).
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie Națională și Arheologie, Constanța, Romania; inv.nos. 64682-64694

summary: Suspicious hoard as the coins were found in successive years: Republic - Claudius I (AD 50-54).
Originally, over 100 denarii, only 34 were studied: Augustus - Tiberius (AD 14-37).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Oviedo, Spain

summary: 3200 silver coins found with bronze cauldron: 3197 denarii, 3 drachmas Lycia: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 158-161) . 10.8 kg
disposition: Museum ”Dr. Molnár István”, Cristuru Secuiesc, Romania (1965)

summary: A purse hoard recorded by Penhallurick as being found during Radford's excavations in 1955 of the Great Ditch below the Lower Ward's outer bank on the mainland part of the Castle. The purse was not recognised as such until later on and is thought to have been a leather draw string purse which contained 10 coins.
360 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Augustus - Septimius Severus (AD 200-201).
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 2400 denarii with the latest coin being of Severus Alexander (or according to Blanchet, Gordian III).
Hoard of around 1600 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 573 coins were documented: Titus - Septimius Severus Severus (AD 193-211).
26 denarii of Augustus, all of RIC type 264 (29-27 BC).
78 denarii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).

10 Roman imperial denarii were found in the vicinity of ancient Olbia, to the west of Adzhigolskaya Balka, near the villages of Dmitrivka and Ivanivka (the exact location is not known). The coins have been identified by V. Stolba and U. Peter from photographs. The cirent location of the hoard is unknown.

A mixed hoard of Syrian tetradrachms, Cypriote tetradrachms / didrachms, and denarii, ranging in date from Nero to Hadrian. 1 coin of Vespasian is countermarked by Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-180), which is why the closing reign is given here as Marcus Aurelius.
In 1873, Alph. Frappier gavie to the Société de statistique des Deux-Sèvres, 37 silver Roman coins which were said to come from a hoard found in the region.
48 coins: 1 aureus, 31 denarii, 16 sestertii: 116 BC - Nero (AD 56)
290 antoniniani: Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.no. CXLV

summary: Hoard bought by E.T. Newell in Cairo in Dec. 1923, found near Sakha. It comprised 299 coins: 33 Greek silver coins from the 2nd and 1st c. BC, 261 denarii (Nero to Trajan) and 5 provincial silver issues of Trajan (1 Arabian drachm; 3 drachms of Cyrenaica and 1 hemidrachm of Cyrenaica).
1 antoninianus (radiate) of Maximian I and 4 nummi of the Tetrarchy found n the rear facade of the so-called Major Baths of the monumental complex of Partida de Mura in the Roman city of Edeta
The hoard was found in a burial in a Roman inhumation cemetery and comprised 10 nummi of Gratian to Theodosius I.

3 early British uninscribed staters struck from the same pair of dies have been recorded from a site "2 miles south of Winchester", probably in the vicinity of Twyford. No further information is available.
The hoard comprised 15 sestertii from Titus to Julia Domna, found in Gonousa, close to Sicyon.
Unknown initial number of denarii found in a ceramic vessel. Gerasimov have seen 3 pieces: Galba, Vespasian, Nerva

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 1968 denarii and antoniniani (radiates). 1862 of these coins were identifiable (219 denarii and 1643 antoniniani (radiates) and form the basis of a catalogue by Le Gentilhomme (1946). The current hoard catalogue outlined here needs checking against this original publication.
The hoard comprised 1 denarius and 72 antoniniani (radiates) ending with coins of Aurelian (AD 270-275) found with a bronze vessel.
10000 nummi. According to Walburg: "extremely doubtful". "No details are reported, and indeed no further mention has ever been made of this hoard since Bopearachchi’s short notice quoted above.
5 denarii found together following metal detecting: Hadrian (Sabina) - Commodus (AD 190).
2 aurei of Trajan (AD 98-117). No further details.
Unknown initial number of coins. 100 denarii: Nero - Elagabalus (AD 218-222). Found in a ceramic vessel.
disposition: Institutul de Cercetări Eco-Muzeale, Tulcea, Romania; inv. nos. 49.717-49.816

summary: The hoard comprised between 500 and 800 silver coins (Celtic and Roman denarii).
84 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel; Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166); w8: 281 g.
disposition: Muzeului de Istorie și Arheologie, Piatra-Neamț, Romania

summary: The hoard comprised a coarseware vessel containing more than 600 denarii from Augustus to Elagabalus (AD 218-222).

108 kg found in a large ceramic jar and, probably, a box or, rather, of a canvas bag or leather, according to the rectangular shape of the second heap of coins: 41200 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 denarius. Among issuers Valerian I, Gallienus, Quintillus, Aurelian, Claudius II, Postumus, Laelianus, Marius, Victorinus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II. Notably Gallienus and Claudius II (27%), the Gallo-Roman emperors Victorinus, Tetricus I and Tetricus II in particular (56%), and local imitations. A rare denarius of Tetricus I.
“300” coins of unknown type (Roman?). No details were reported.
50 denarii found in a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
The hoard comprised several thousand coins, mostly of Postumus. It is possibly a hoard described as being found in a copper-alloy basin.
30 imperial bronze coins: Augustus, Agrippa, Vespasian, Domitian (AD 81-96).
732 nummi: Constans - Constantius II (AD 352-354).
3 staters of Armorican type found on the same beach over a period of time.

A group of 9 copper alloy Flavian coins found together during the excavation by Surrey Archaeological Society of a new circular temple a short distance from square temple complex robbed for several years by metal detectorists. The group was found "just within the wall line of the Phase 4 temple and within" it (context 48) (Williams 2007, 171). The temple was fully excavated. In his report on the Roman coins, Abdy (ibid. p.228) notes that "the 2 Domitianic asses are of the AD 86-7 shipment" and the hoard is therefore likely to be later than this.Other coins from the excavation are likely to be part of the same dispersed depositional activity on the site covered by record IARCH-ABD376Interim note: Howe, T., Jackson, G., Mal1y, C. & Saich, D. 2000. Archaeology in Surrey 1998-9. Surrey Arch. Coll. 87: 185.
7 denarii found within the Dacian citadel during archaeological excavations: Republic – Vespasian (AD 75).
Hoard of 600 coins of Sauromates I, Cotys II, Eupator, Sauromates II, Rhescuporis III, Cotys III.
10 nummi found near a "crumbling piece of fabric": Constantius II 5, Julian II (Caesar) 3, Valentinian I 1, Valens I (AD 367-375).

The hoard was recovered from the site of a Gallo-Roman vicus during illegal excavations and comprised a denarius of Septimius Severus and 561 sestertii from Vespasian to Septimius Severus (ad 193-211).
The hoard comprised a greyware vessel filled with between 60 and 80 Roman bronze coins of unknown date. The hoard was found at the top of a ditch on at a tree nursery.
The hoard comprised c. 3/4000 antoniniani (radiates) ending with coins of Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

The hoard comprised 2 separate deposits. The first contained 28 sestertii, dupondii and asses from Trajan to Postumus. The second contained 622 radiates from Philip I to Victorinus with a tpq of AD 270. The circumstances of discovery means that a clear relationship between the 2 hoards cannot be established with any certainty.
Unknown originally number of coins. 156 pieces are known of which 39 antoniniani (radiates) of Gordian III, Philip I, Trajan Decius.

HER record of a hoard of 548 coins excavated in 1991 in a badger sett by the Dean Archaeologial Group. 521 coins were dated AD 348-64. The badgers had burrowed under a wall thought to be of Roman date.
40 silver coins: 5 denarii, 35 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Valerian I (AD 258-259).
(2000) 167 silver coins: Trajan - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver w8: 39.3-79.5 g.
The hoard comprised approximately 1600 aureii, from Julius Caesar to Commodus. Most of the hoard was immediately dispersed and sold.
2 solidi of Constantine I and Constantine I (Constantius II Caesar)/Constantius II (AD 337-361).
disposition: Collection of Mr. Lorenc (displaced from Czechoslovakia after 1945), missing today.

summary: 6.6 kg of coins, 2110 or 2400? antoniniani (radiates): Trebonianus Gallus - Claudius II/Postumus (AD 268-270) silver w8: 570.7-2636.5 g.
The hoard was found with several fragments of a red-orange ceramic vessel which presumably was its original container.
Hoard of circa 300 denarii found in a 'sack': Trajan - Septimius Severus.
disposition: History Museum, Kursk (7 coins); private collection in Korocha (8 coins), Russia; History Museum, Kyiv (15 coins), Ukraine

summary: A small hoard seen by a private collector, which was said to have contained 3 Durotrigan staters and between 5 and 7 Gallo-Belgic E staters. The only coin of which an image is available is described as gold, and is evidently very early in the Durotrigan series. — The coin in question is described as base gold but probably higher in silver?

The remnants of a large residential premises might have been surveyed in 1901 during excavation of an ice cellar in Haus Martinerfeld for the branch store of Bitburger Simon brewery. The coins were found in the building rubble.
102 bronze coins found with an amphora and dispersed in the coin trade: Tiberius - Marcus aurelius (AD 161-180).
276 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Marcus Aurelius - Gordian III (AD 241-243); silver w8: 387.6-713.7 g.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (3 coins); May 1967, 273 coins and the vessel

summary: Rescue excavation undertaken by the archaeological service. 20 antoniniani and 3 denarii, ranging from Caracalla to Gallienus (sole reign) were found.

A hoard of 19 Iron Age gold coins reportedly found on the site of a housing development in July/August 1995. The hoard was not declared and some of the information provided might not be entirely reliable.
13 nummi (AD 352-354): Constantius II 12, Constantius Gallus 1, found in a grave.
237 coins: 11 denarii, 226 bronzes (most of them sestertii): Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
The hoard comprised 79 sestertii from Vespasian to Treboninanus Gallus (AD 251-253).

A hoard of at least 121 denarii and antoniniani (Septimius Severus - Valerian I), found by 2 metal detectors in 2006. Some coins were preserved in fragmentary form and these fragments could account for another 1-3 specimens.
The hoard comprised 4 radiates of Aurelian. It is suggested that the coins were the con10ts of a purse or part of a larger, scattered hoard.
116 silver coins: 4 denarii, 112 antoniniani: Caracalla-Diocletian (AD 292).
47 denarii: Vespasian - Didius Julianus (AD 193); silver w8: 87.1-137.5 g
The hoard comprised 13 Theodosian nummi with a tpq of AD 395 to 402.
1 kilo of antoniniani (radiates). Among the coins, 20 were issues of Claudius II (AD 268-270).
95 nummi found with a ceramic vessel: Constantine I - Constantius II (AD 347-348).
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueologia, Lisboa, Portugal

summary: (8) 5 sestertii: Domitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 150-151)
140 silver coins: 26 denarii, 114 antoniniani: Septimius Severus to Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver w8: 175.6-362.9 g.

Hoard of 126 Roman imperial denarii was discovered by a treasure hunter on the outskirts of Uman in mid-November 2014. Information about the discovery of the treasure and a photo of 53 coins were published on November 16, 2014, on the Ukrainian treasure-hunting forum Violity. The finder reported that the treasure was found on November 13, 2014, in the forest on the outskirts of Uman. The coins were dispersed over a small area, and on the first day of the search, 4 treasure hunters managed to find 62 coins. On the second day, the search was continued by 3 treasure hunters, they found an additional 32 coins. On November 18, 2015, the same informant reported that a total of 126 coins had been discovered. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
The coins were found on the st1 floor of a heating system in a trench dug at Förster/Karthause. The specimens lay in the doorway to the hypocaust heating room at the lower floor.
15 nummi found on the floor in an ancient building set on fire: Constantius II - Gratian (AD 378-383)
A hoard of 29 nummi (Gratian - Arcadius for the coins that could be identified, with also a 5th century monogram type), discovered in sector D (inv. 79D/18) of Tell Atrib.

A hoard of 208 gold coins (mostly solidi), found on the Menzeler Heide in an earthenware vessel. The coins were dispersed, but a list of them was made. Coins range from the late Republic to the early 5th c., with the majority belonging to the 4th c.

The hoard was found in a bathhouse and comprised at least 25 gold coins which were immediately sold after their discovery. Not long after the original discovery, some metres from their findspot, an aureus of Trajan was discovered. It is likely to be part of the original hoard.

Hoard of 34 bronze sstaters of an autonomous (Agrippia) city and Bosporan kings: Aspurgus, Gepaepyris, Rhescuporis II, Sauromates I, Cotys II, Sauromates II and 1 issue of the mint of Agrippia Caesarea (Phanagoria).
disposition: Museum of Anapa, Russia (labelled as the "Gunyaevsky Hoard"; inv.nos. AM 10750/1-34)

summary: A hoard of 21 badly corroded provincial bronze coins, dating from Septimius Severus to Gordian III, found in Dura Europos.

The 15 (lost) coins, "mostly poorly preserved middle bronzes from Augustus to Trebonianus Gallus", were found in 1913/14 during earthworks on the edge of a ravine near the Bühren estate. "The coins were scattered over 100 m, 1 m deep."

The hoard, handed to the Serres archaeological service by a local resident, comprised 15 Roman Provincial coins (14 Koinon of Macedonia and 1 Thessalonica). It has been suggested that it is part of the Evelpidis hoard.

The coin hoard was discovered during the third season of excavations, where archaeologists unearthed an amphora containing 80 copper staters, whilst researching evidence of a destruction layer caused by fire from the 6th century AD. A closer inspection of the coins reveals that they are mainly copper staters of the Bosporan kings of the late 3rd – early 4th century AD.
Hoard of 99 electrum and silver stateri of the Bosporan Kings, Cotys III and Sauromates III (AD 232-233).

In 1927 about 360 denarii and antoniniani (Caracalla - Postumus) were unearthed. The coins were strewn on the ground, on a place located on the floodplain of the river Rhine. There was also half of a longsword, remnants of scissors, 4 bronze rings and 50 tokens of glass and glass base.
35 nummi found together in a domus: Constantine I - Theodosius I (AD 393-395).

A hollow b1, probably of an ox (about 6 in. long), a small bronze seal-box, a bronze bow fibula, 2 small bronze rings, 5 Ancient British silver coins (recently been attributed to the Coritani (or Corieltauvi?), 13 denarii, and 5 bronze coins, found in a cavity behind a piece of rock, at Honley, near Huddersfield. At least some of the coins (if not all) were contained in the hollow b1.
disposition: British Museum (part); Tolson Memorial Museum, Huddersfield (part)

summary: A very large find of Roman denarii, made in 1858 in the vicinity of Filsum. Around 1960, 3 further denarii (Domitian Caesar, Commodus) were found on a field, and can probably be connected with the same find.
A hoard of 33 late Roman nummi (AD 317-328), found in an ancient rubbish heap during the papyri excavations of J. Johnson at Antinoe in 1913/1914.

In 1919 a farmer found more than 1000 Roman small bronze coins, ranging from Claudius II to Constantine I, in an amalgamated compact mass. Only a cursory description of the coins exist, and they are now lost.
2 solidi of Jovian and Theodosius I (AD 388-392) minted in Constantinople and Treveri.
disposition: Frisian Museum, Lcenturyarden (collection Quaestius nos. FML 359, 360)

summary: Group of 5 coins: Caius (Agrippa) 1 as, Nero 1 dupondius, Galba 1 as, Vespasian 2 as (AD 69-79).
Hoard of 216 antoniniani (radiates): Aurelian - Probus (AD 276-282).
397 solidi: Constantius II - Anthemius (AD 467-472); gold w8: 1766.65g.
8 antoniniani (Gordian III - Philip) contained in a small metal box in Berbericherstraße between 1918 and 1920.

The hoard comprised 76 tetradrachms: 26 of Philip Philadelphus, 6 of Cleopatra and Antony, 35 of Posthumous Philips (Caesarean years 26 – 31, i.e. 24/23 – 19/18 BC), 8 of Augustus from Antioch and 1 of Augustus from Seleucia), deposited around AD 12.
16 denarii and 4 radiates, ranging from Diva Faustina to Philip I
The hoard comprised an amphora containing between 6000 and 7000 antoniniani (radiates), mostly of Claudius II, Victorinus, Tetricus I and II. Only 5 coins were identified more closely.

A hoard of originally more than 200 antoniniani of which 147 were split up between different museums and a private owner. 116 of these were published in detail by Laser in 1972 (114 of these could be documented de visu by M. Schlapke in 2015) and FMRD gives a full list of all 147 coins. Unfortunately, the FMRD list is faulty. The mistakes are difficult to correct, as the coins are not all accessible any more today. As a result, all coins ever documented have been listed here, with 3 FMRD entries having their quantity set to 'zero' (0), as no matching coin exists among the 1s seen by M. Schlapke. Surviving coins range from Valerian to Postumus. No trace of a container could be seen.
disposition: Weimar, Museum für Ur- und Frühgeschichte Thüringens (96 coins); Sondershausen, Schlossmuseum (8 coins); Gotha, Stiftung Schloss Friedenstein, Münzkabinett (31 coins, which cannot be identified any more within the collection) and 12 coins in private hands

summary: Several Freckenham staters were recorded in the trade with this provenance and seem likely to have originated in a hoard. No further details are available.

10 radiates (Gallienus to Carausius) found along with fragments of a possible bronze container by a farm worker ploughing a field near Plas Nanteos. The coins entered the collection of a local antiquarian and were sold upon his death. No further information is available.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing at least 11 coins (10 sestertii and 1 dupondius) found during construction work. The pot and 11 coins were given to the Museum Laufen, where, ca. 2014, only these 11 coins could be identified: Domitian (1 coin), Trajan (1 coin), Hadrian (5 coins), Antoninus Pius (1 dupondius), M. Aurelius/L. Verus (1 coins), Commodus (1 coin), Crispina (1 coin).
More than 500 nummi found in a Roman building. Only 179 were recovered: Costantius II - Gratianus (AD 375-383).
disposition: Historische Museum der Stadt Wien, Austria

summary: 700 radiates The hoard was bought by H. Rigaux, but doesn't appear to have g1 to Lille Museum with the rest of his collection.
These 22 bronze coins, ranging from Augustus to Gratian, were reportedly discovered as a hoard in 1834 near Pödeldorf, yet the find arguably in no case involves a hoard.
Unknown initial number of coins. 18 antoniniani (radiates) are kept in a private collection: Gallienus - Quintillus (AD 270).
4 silver denarii: Hadrian (Sabina), Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2562

summary: 381 coins: 1 antoninianus, 380 nummi: Probus - Gratian (AD 367-375)

A hoard of 358 tetradrachms (Septimius Severus - Philip II), denarii (Crispina - Gordian III) and antoniniani (Julia Donna - Trebonianus Gallus) from Dura Europos, found in a common-ware jar near the citadel.

A Roman coin hoard consisting of 106 denarii (Republic - Commodus) was discovered in 1908 during the renovation of a grinding mill, 2 km south-west of Unterammergau. The hoard was in earthenware jar, that had apparently been placed between rocks. The coins are now lost.
8 Iron Age silver units and 1 denarius of Augustus. Declared Treasure in 1982 with St1a Grange I group II but considered a separate hoard. Part of group detected from site prior to excavation.
The hoard comprised 60 Osismii billon staters found with a ceramic vessel (60-20 BC).
3 denarii (Antoninus Pius, 2 Marcus Aurelius Caesar) (AD 145-160).
Unknown originally number of coins. 104 Iberian bronzes and provincial coinage of Hispania have been documented.
With 4 denarii republicans and 280 imperial of Augustus.
A small hoard of 38 copper alloy coins dating to the 370s AD, was recovered from a pit beside a pond near the Wootton Fields Roman villa (Chapman and Thorne 2004).
In total 12 denarii: Mark Antony - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211)

The hoard comprised at least 227 silver coins: 119 Nabatean denarii, 14 provincial tetradrachms of Antioch, 5 didrachms reattributed to Antioch (Trajan), 5 tridrachms and 33 drachms of Trjan reattributed to an Arabian mint, and 51 imperial denarii, down to AD 122.
disposition: Israel Antiquities Authority (108), Ecole Biblique, Amman Museum

summary: The hoard comprised 119 coins: 1 sestertius and 118 nummi from Antoninius Pius (Diva Faustina I) to Constantine I (AD 317-318). The coins appear to have been stacked and stored in some sort of roll.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités (Musée Stéphane Gsell) d'Alger

summary: 394 bronze coins of unknown denomination. Among them were identified coins of Sabina, 1 of the 2 Faustinae and of Postumus (AD 260-268). No further information.
797 silver coins: 641 denarii, 156 antoniniani (radiates): Vitellius - Philip I (AD 244-245).
197 Late Roman coins from the period AD 330 to 348, with 1 earlier coin (AD 307-8), found next to the furnace of a Roman building.

An entry in the diary of Sir Simonds D'Ewes, for 12 November 1646 reads: 12 Nov Postquam pranseram lustravi octo Numismata aurea, et ultra 500 argentea Romana nuper in agro Varnice'si Neronis, Vitellij, Vespasiani Traiani (BL Harleian MS 484, f. 130v). After I had dined I looked at 8 Roman gold coins and a further 500 silver recently found in a field near Warwick, of Nero, Vitellius, Vespasian, Trajan.

A hoard of about 500 Roman imperial denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180) was discovered by a treasure hunter somewhere near the Dniester, on the borderland of the Ternopil and Ivano-Frankivsk region. The hoard was found in a pot (a few fragments are preserved). Several coins were glued to the fragments of the vessel. The coins are quite well preserved (minimal wear). Deposit was not published on Violity, and was immediately sold to 1 of the collectors. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
28 denarii found in the wall of the ”Domus of denarii”: Mark Antony - Tiberius (AD 14-37).
65 billon Alexandrian tetradrahms: Nero - Diocletian/Maximian (AD 292-293). 'Presented to the owner by Felix Cary in Marseilles and reported to have been found in Upper Egypt in 1760.'
disposition: 'Probably now in Gotha as the rest of Schachmann's collection'

summary: Unknown number of initial coins. 8 denarii donated to the museum in Tulcea: Nero - Domitian (AD 88/89).
disposition: Danube Delta Museum, Tulcea, Romania; (8 coins)

summary: 31 silver Celtic coins of the Aduatuci.
39 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel: 31 denarii, 8 antoniniani (radiates): Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249). Found together with a brooch and a silver ring.
(500) 48 denarii: Republic - Augustus (AD 2-11)
disposition: Hungarian National Museum, Budapest, Hungary; Inv. no. 12 A- 13 A. 1898 (25 coins)

summary: A hoard of 49 denarii (Mark Antony - Commodus, including a Lycian drachm of Trajan), found while digging for peat in the vicinity of Dellstedt (Nordermoor). The coins were found in a cavity, reflecting the size of the original container (leather bag or wooden box). 8 coins have been lost.
1126 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms, 2 Ptolemaic bronze coins: Ptolemaic dynasty - Aurelian (AD 270-275). 'Acquired in Egypt by Dattari, who sold it to Milne and Currelly'.
disposition: Partly in Oxford, partly in Toronto. Detailed list in Oxford

summary: 2 denarii: Antoninus Pius, Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Regional museum, Chrudim, Czech Republic (now, missing)

summary: 22 denarii of Augustus found in 1 layer during archaeological excavations at the site of Bagineti.
The hoard comprised 93 antoniniani (radiates) ending with coins of Probus (AD 276-282).

1 Iron age silver stater, 2 miliarenses, 82 siliquae and 1 unidentified bronze coin to AD 402 together with pot fragments and 3 sheets of rolled lead. The Iron Age silver stater (uninscribed South-Western Durotriges) and the bronze coin are probably a stray finds.
Denarius hoard consisting of 17 denarii. Vespasian to Commodus.

Found in the necropolis of Hawara during the excavations of W.M. Flinders Petrie in 1888, in a jar and interpreted as a funeral offering by Flinders Petrie. First published in 1938. The hoard contained 5 genuine coins (AD 383-404) and 122 coin shaped metal discs, that might have been local imitations, though n1 is recognisable.
The hoard comprised 180 tetradrachms (Nero-Macrinus), 22 denarii (Septimius Severus-Geta), and 35 bronze coins (Alexander Severus-Philip I). Details for 145 of the coins have been published.

During a violent storm in 1991, coins and many other artefacts dating from the Roman Empire, such as pottery vessels and bronze w8s, were washed up from the seabed a short distance from the ancient city of Camarina on the most south-easterly point of Sicily. Among issuers: Gallienus, Claudius II, Quintillus, Victorinus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II.
disposition: Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Camarina, Italy

summary: The hoard comprised 8 coins: 1 denarius and 7 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Maximian I (AD 293) and gold jewelry.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités (Musée Stéphane Gsell) d'Alger; inv.no. 1098/1910

summary: 2 solidi, found in Dully Wood in 1897 and 1899. These 2 solidi must have come from a scattered hoard.
Around 200 denarii of which only 8 have provided information on the issuers: Vespasian 1, Trajan 3, Hadrian 2, Antoninus Pius 2.
13 antoniniani: Gallienus - Tacitus (AD 276).

The hoard comprised an amphora containing 1400 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Victorinus (AD 269-271). A catalogue exists for 1335 antoniniani (radiates). Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of between 421g and 1749g.

The hoard comprised 200 bronzes of CONTOVTOS, 3 or 4 of 'poitevin primitif' type, a good number of silver potins depicting a winged horseman and some bronzes with the legends ANNICCOIOS, ATECTORI, CONTOVTOS and Luccio. A mutilated coin die was found in association with the coins.
170 Roman imperial large bronze coins: Hadrian - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268). Possible part of the same hoard as Capoterra 1928b.
131 coins, 125 menti1d in the catalogue: 7 antoniniani (radiates), 2 denarii, 2 asses, 115 nummi: Claudius I – Thedosius I (AD 379-395).
c. 120-150 aurei: Julius Caesar - Domitian (AD 81-96).

883 coins (Constantine I - Zeno, including 459 cast imitations) and 9 lead disks (8-11 mm), found in the necropolis of Hawara during the excavations of W.M. Flinders Petrie in 1888, in a jar and interpreted as a funeral offering by Flinders Petrie. First published in 1938.
Hoard of 96 gold staters of the Bosporan kings: Cotys II, Rhoemetalkes, Eupator, Sauromates II, Rhescuporis III, Cotys III.
150 denarii, 139 studied, found with a ceramic vessel: Republic - Tiberius (AD 14-37).

306 coins: 255 antoniniani (radiates), 50 denarii, 1 sestertius: Antoninus Pius - Gallienus (AD 253-268). Together, were found jewelry: 2 silver rings, 1 pair of gold earrings and 1 gold children’s earring.
6 Republican denarii, 1 quinarius of Augustus, and 1 denarius of Vespasian found in a piece of canvas in regio VI, insula 15, building 20 (house)
83 denarii: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
(3-4000) 2276 nummi of the Tetrarchy: Diocletian - Constantinus I/Maxentius (Caesar) (AD 309-310).
disposition: Narodni muzej, Numizmatični cabinet, Ljubljana, Slovenia; 2,275 coins

summary: 33 gold coins: 6 solidi multiples and 27 solidi, 1 gold earring: Constantine I with sons. 160.53 g.

A container with possibly 3000 antoniniani (Valerian - Quintillus) found in the Schwarzbruch forest close to Orscholz. The coins were dispersed, but 2842 were described. 619 were given to the Rheinisches Landesmuseum in Trier where 227 coins could still be traced.
Unknown quantity of coins found in a ceramic vessel. 6 pieces entered the museum collection in Pazardzik: Julia Paula, Gordian III, Otacilia severa; silver w8: 8.1-13.5 g.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Pazardzik, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 441-445

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 313 silver coins went to the Museum of History in Silistra, Bulgaria: Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
disposition: Museum of History, Silistra, Bulgaria (313 coins); inv.nos. 5584-5896

summary: A small hoard probably of 4 or 5 Atrebatic (British Qc) quarter staters, recorded at the British Museum.
Around 800 denarii and amber pieces found with a ceramic vessel.
disposition: Three private collections; Museum of Prehistory, Poznan.

summary: The hoard originally comprised an undetermined amount of denarii. Only 12 coins are known: Trajan-Marcus Aurelius (114-175 AD).
50 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). No information about circumstances.
Around 1460 denarii - a number established based on an average w8 of 3 g/coin (4.510 g)- comprising Republican issues to Commodus (AD 1180-192). 19 coins entered the collection of the Ermitage.
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia (19 coins)

summary: 145 Roman nummi: Constantius II - House of Marcian (AD 450-457). Supposedly given to the Colombo Museum in 1935.

Originally the hoard had 150 silver coins and possibly 2 bronze. A full list was published in 1850 but the museum was only able to identify 50 silver coins (radiates and denarii). Silver: 15, 35 coins; Silver w8: 65.2-117.1g
3 (possibly 4) solidi and 11 siliquae, ranging from Julian II to Honorius, AD 402, found in a small vase at Carlton in 1807.
disposition: Norwich Castle Museum (on loan: 3 solidi and 11 siliquae)

summary: Originally 164 coins, only 45 were identified: Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetrarchy (AD 299).

Approx. 80 small bronze coins, of which 13 are imitations of Tetricus I, found on a brickyard located between the Lehmstrasse and Am Schlütershof. Apparently, they were contained in a small metal box.
Over 345 billon coins deposited circa 311 AD.
The hoard comprised 20 large bronze coins of Mattathias Antigonus (TJC 36c).
Unknown initial number of silver coins. 21 were kept in the museum of Elbing: 7 antoniniani (radiates), 14 denarii: Mark Antony - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology and History in Elblag (former Town Museum Elbing) in 1903.

summary: 102 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian and Diocletian (AD 286-287) found in a pile at floor level (along the wall of a room) during excavations of a house.

A hoard of 3119 mostly late Roman coins, found in the necropolis of Hawara during the excavations of W.M. Flinders Petrie in 1888 and interpreted as a funeral offering by Flinders Petrie. First published in 1920. The hoard comprised 2 Greek coins, 2 Roman provincial coins, 2245 late Roman imperial coins, 3 small lead disks, and 870 cast imitations.
Unknown number of nummi found in a container close to the shore in front of the city of Chioggia.
Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 20 pieces entered the museum collection in Shumen: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 825-844 (20 coins)

summary: 115 denarii: Vespasian - Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
Unknown number of silver coins found in a ceramic vessel. 117 entered the museum collection in Sliven: 84 antoniniani, 33 denarii: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver w8: 157.2-281.4 g.
The hoard comprised 4 copper-alloy statues and 2 copper-alloy vessels. 1 of the copper-alloy vessels contained 6 bronze coins of Marcus Aurelius and Divus Lucius Verus. 1 coin was lost.
The hoard comprised a small copper-alloy vessel containing 7 antoniniani (radiates) or imitations of Tetricus I. It was found hidden under a large st1 slab.
During a rescue excavation, 13 coins were found close to each other or even glued: Celtoiberic - Valens (AD 364-375).
The hoard comprised 16 sestertii: Hadrian - Gordian III (AD 240) minted in Rome and a further 1 from the mint in Viminacium (Trajan Decius, AD 251).
(200) 162 silver coins: denarii, antoniniani: Antoninus Pius - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver w8: c.251.5-548.5 g. Found together with 2 bronze bracelets.
The hoard was found under a large st1 and comprised 'a certain number of bronze coins' dating to the late third and 4th century AD.

Hoard was found at a brickworks called Les Caves du Roi, between the road from Paris to Calais and Estrées and on the route of the trainline towards Berck. 3 sestertii were overstruck upon pieces of Antoninus Pius (1) and Marcus Aurelius (2). Together wuth These coins were found: a coin-die (!); a pickaxe (dolabra); a spearhead.
17 bronze coins (Constantine I - sons of Constantine) found in Hauen, on the Pilsum-Greetsiel road, during gardening works in a flower bed. The coins were strewn on a surface of 3 x 5m in 2 places.

21 Roman bronze coins (as) were found within a ceramic container, each placed on an oil lamp. Burnt animal b1s (thigh of sheep or goats) were scattered among the lamps. 1 of the Nero coins was countermarked SPQR.

38 bronze coins "in northwest by the heating system bordering the narrow room in the incendiary and debris layer above the st1 floor. They possibly form a small hoard; the composition also speaks for it."

A hoard of 11 provincial coins (Thessalonica, Pella, Dium, the koinon of Macedonia) ranging from Marcus Aurelius to Gordian III, found in a grave, part of a vast necropolis in the eastern part of Veroia.
The hoard comprised 200 Roman coins, of which 62 were acquired by the Musée de Beauvais including antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Victorinus.

Found during construction work, no container reported. Located probably in the area of a Roman villa rustica. Hoard of 2377 radiates: Gallienus (4), Claudius II (2), Divus Claudius (1), Aurelian and Severina (1115), Tacitus (730), Florian (4), Probus (519), Tacitus or Probus (1).
535 nummi of which 58 were cleaned: House of Constantine I - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-423).
The hoard was found in a cremation burial dated to the beginning of the 1st century AD by its grave goods.
2 antoniniani (radiates) of unknown issuer. According to the NUMIS the tpq is around AD 256.
The hoard comprised 11 bronze coins, dating between AD 79/80 and AD 119/120.
203 silver coins, 5 denarii, 198 antoniniani (radiates), found in earthenware with 2 golden jewels: Republic - Postumus (AD 260-269).
The hoard was found in a layer of carbonised material and ash. It comprised a group of 60 Roman coins stuck together with corrosion products.
81 bronze coins: 80 sestertii, 1 as: Hadrian - Aemilianus (AD 253).

The hoard comprised 2 separate parcels of coins concealed within a cist constructed with 5 bricks and covered with a silver embossed leaf. The first parcel comprised nearly 700 sestertii dating from Galba to Severus Alexander. The second parcel, wrapped in fragments of linen, comprised denarii and radiates from Trajan to Volusian.
(?) 39 antoniniani: Claudius II -Diocletian (AD 293-294); silver w8: 7.1-12.5 g.
27 coins: 1 antoninianus (radiate), 1 siliqua, 25 nummi found with a bronze saucepan; Valerian I (VDivus Valerian II) - Constantine I. Suspicious case.
disposition: Museo Arqueológico e Histórico de A Coruña, Spain

summary: 19 antoniniani (radiates) of the period Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-259); silver w8: 5.6-13.4 g.

The hoard was found in a niche in a wall structure and comprised an 'important assemblage of gold and silver Roman coins which were dispersed amongst the workmen. It appears that there were more than 2000 coins, mostly silver issues dating up to the reign of Septimius Severus. There were 2 aurei of Commodus mounted in jewellery. Comarmond notes 2 aurei of Nero and a gold quinarius of Commodus. Issues of Septimius Severus and Julia Domna were numerous and well-preserved, but there were no coins of Caracalla or Geta. There were also numerous items of gold jewellery, weighing a total of 741g, which the brother supervising the works managed to collect together. The jewellery was the subject of a detailed publication by Comarmond. The hoard was found by workmen digging foundation trenches for a new boarding school run by the Christian Brothers.
3 denarii were found in a ceramic vessel: Julia Domna 1, Severus Alexander 1, Julia Mamaea 1 (AD 222-235).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2724

summary: 69 aurei and 121? uncertain denarii found on the Via dei Sepolcri near the Porta Ercolano

'A Find of 265 Early British Coins, with a very crude design of a head on 1 side and a horse on the other; found at Brentford about 1860, many varieties' –– Sotheby 8 December 1915, lot 280. This was sold to Baldwin’s, who seem to have made quite leisurely progress in selling on the coins, and indeed almost 6ty years later they provided the CCI with photographs of 71 still in their possession.
The hoard comprised 12 bronze coins, 5 of which have been identified.

The hoard comprised 259 nummi of the House of Constantine and Valentininian I (AD 364-375. The coins kept in the Shahat Archaeological Museum related to this find are 271, as proved by a recent survey which also made possible to identify more coins listed as illegible in the Goodchild's report. Terminal year remains unchanged. Many of the coins are clipped.
5 Roman imperial denarii. No information whether they were found together.
460 nummi of the Tetrarchy placed directly on the ground: Diocletian - Licinius I (AD 311-312).
The hoard was found in burial 403 in a Roman cemetery and comprised 'a purse containing 5 sestertii, as well as 70 coins of Tetricus, Licinius, etc.'
The hoard comprised 70 antoniniani (radiates) imitations of Tetricus I and II.

The hoard was found in the foundation trench of a Gallo-Roman wall. It comprised 43 denarii from Vitellius to Marcus Aurelius as Caesar (AD 148/149). It may originally have been placed in a small box, as fragments of copper-alloy scrap were found in association with the coins.
The hoard comprises 232 cast denarii: a rejected series of coins depicting emperors from Vespasian to Elagabalus with a tpq of AD 218-222 or soon after.
disposition: National Union Musem, Alba Iulia, Romania (Inv.no. 7438-7673)

summary: 2 Roman gold coins. 1 of Valens and 1 of Valentinianus.
A hoard of Norfolk Wolf and Snettisham type staters.
500 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166). TR POT XX IMP IIII COS III
disposition: Okrazen Istoriceski Muzej, Pleven, Bulgaria; circa 250 coins, inv.no. 853 1-128

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 19 pieces are known - 7 denarii, 12 antoniniani (radiates): Commodus - Filip I (AD 244-247).
Hoard of 115 coins of the Bosporan kings (AD 288-341).
2043 AR: Galba/Hadrian - Valerian I (AD 253-259); silver w8: 2555.4-6392.7 g
