6 Roman imperial bronze coins. The latest 1 is a sestertius of Antoninus Pius: Gaius - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
(c. 200 silver, 2 gold coins) 31 gold and silver coins: 1 aureus, 18 denarii and 19 antoniniani/radiates: Vespasian - Valerian and Gallienus I (AD 258); silver w8: 40.6-67g
disposition: the Prince of Schaumburg-Lippe collection; Town Museum Virovitica, Croatia (173 coins); dispersed; Archaeological Museum Zagreb, Croatia (archives)

summary: Over 1000 coins, believed to be of the House of Theodosius (AD 388-423).
The hoard comprised 94 provincial bronze coins dated between AD 49/50 and 252/3.
It comprised 23 coins found in "un grand mortier de pierre" (mortarium). Only 3 were identified: Augustus, Marcus Aurelius, Aurelian.
The hoard was found in a hollow st1 and comprised 300 denarii: Vespasian - Caracalla (AD 211-217).
31 denarii: Republic - Augustus (2 BC - AD 4).

The hoard comprised 'an earthenware vessel filled with 652 silver and billon coins (denarii and radiates) and 100 bronzes (sestertii and dupondii or asses). The silver and billon coins weighed 3.7kg. A further 186 coins were offered for sale in Rouen in 1971 and appear to be from the same hoard.' The coins were deposited at the Bibliothèque municipale de Rouen, where 168 examples were actually conserved and catalogued by Mme J. Delaporte. Archives Inventory No. 2-653.
disposition: Bibliothèque municipale de Rouen (Archives Inventory No. 2-653)

summary: Hoard of 280 denarii found with Dacian ceramic vessel. 271 coins were recovered: Republic – Tiberius (AD 14-37).
disposition: National Museum of Szekely Land, Sfântu Gheorghe, Romania (inv.nos. 14633-14904)

summary: Unknown originally number of denaarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 10 coins were recovered. Among issuers: Augustus, Tiberius, Nero, Antoninus Pius, Commodus and other emeperors.
Unknown number of coins found during construction work. Only 5 denarii are known: Republic, Vitellius, Antoninus Pius (2), Lucius Verus.
disposition: Before World War II some of the coins from the hoard were kept in the collections of the St. Elisabeth Gymnasium in Wrocław (Sankt Elisabet- Gymnasium in Breslau). Lost

summary: The hoard comprised 22 silver coins from the reign of Macrinus (AD 217-218).
Probably a funerary find, containing circa 20 nummi of Constantine I and Constantius II (AD 337-361?).

The hoard containing over 193 specimens dated from Tiberius to Caracalla was found in 1992. It included slashed coins, coins transformed into ornaments, and an unknown number of imitations. Unfortunately, the find was never published.
147 denarii found with a ceramic vessel of Dacian manufacture: Republic – Augustus (12 BC).
20 coins: 2 antoniniani (radiates), 18 sestertii: Trajan - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).

The Snettisham hoard F consisted principally of 9.2 kg of broken metalwork contained within a bronze vessel (Stead 1991, 447): fragments from at least 50 torques, at least 70 ingot rings/bracelets and 3 straight ingots, as well as 9 coins. 5 of the coins were contained within a piece of tubular torc. 7 more coins have been associated with this hoard, as they may be scatters from hoard F. The British Museum excavation conducted after the initial discovery revealed a further 27 Iron Age coins and further metal detecting revealed 11 more coins.
The hoard comprised 7 bronze coins of the 5th century AD and a lump of unidentified coins from a shipwreck.
90 silver coins: 23 denarii, 67 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver w8: 125.5-252.4 g.
68 nummi: Constantine I - Arcadius (AD 395-402).

The hoard comprised an unknown number of 4th-century nummi which was immediately dispersed on discovery. Bertrand catalogued 292 coins which were being sold by a dealer in Vichy and other collectors. They date from the Tetrarchy to Constantine I with a tpq of AD 309. The latest coins are issue from Lyon mint (RIC 287/289 and 295).
The hoard comprised 'more than 8100 antoniniani (radiates), weighing approximately 30 kilos: Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 270-271).
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen (172 coins; Inv. II nos. 606 and 680), France

summary: 81 imitations of solidi: Zeno - Justin I (AD 518-527); gold w8: 360.45g.
Circa 900 billon provincial coins of Alexandria. Probably, issued in the 1st c. A.D. Found in a ceramic vessel.
2 solidi: Marcian, Zeno, (AD 474-491).
(300) 57 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus, Postumus, Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

A doubtful hoard due to its composition and being found using metal detectors on a very large area. 34 coins: 2 sestertii, 10 antoniniani (radiates), 22 nummi: Severuss Alexander - Theodosius I (Arcadius ) (AD 388-392).
192 denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Republic 1, Vespasian – Philip I (AD 244-249).

29 Roman silver coins found at Chew Stoke, ranging from Republican denarii to the 3rd century AD. This may be the hoard menti1d by Rahtz (1957, 114) as having been found on Pagan's Hill by its then owner Mr Gray in 1870, though 40-50 silver coins were found. Very wide date spread, which may indicate a shrine or temple in use for a long time rather than a specific hoard (EG).
The hoard comprised 14 radiates from AD 253 to AD 259.
The hoard comprised 18 antoniniani (radiates) from trebonianus Gallus for Volusian to Postumus with the most recent issue a SAECVLI FELICITAS reverse type (Elmer 593).

A hoard of 331+ coins (324 post-Diocletianic reform nummi, 1 Aurelian radiate, 6 Roman provincial coins) found in Verroia. These 331 coins are only a minor part of the total hoard, estimated between 1/3 to 1/5. The hoard was split for sale by antiquities dealers.
8 Roman bronze coins to Antoninus Pius plus 8 Durotrigan cast bronze coins
The hoard comprised a vessel containing 198 (or 186) sestertii dating from Nerva to Septimius Severus, along with a statue.
310 antoniniani (radiates) found wrapped in a piece of cloth and placed in 2 ceramic vessels: Trebonianus Gallus - Tetricus I (Ad 271-274). The Tetricus I coins are imitations.
Before 1856, 5 nummi of Maximian Herculeus were found in Nantes and acquired by the Musée départemental d'archéologie. This assemblage was interpreted as possibly a hoard or a purse loss.
15 solidi: Marcian - Justinian I (AD 527-538).
A hoard of approx. 5500 denarii (Nero to Septimius Severus), 15 kilos, found in Oberhausen, Augsburg.

A hoard from the Southern building adjacent to the Brean Down temple. Numerous coins from the site (possibly including other hoards) but the other concentrations of coins seen as not in situ - interpreted as dispersed in destruction.
The hoard comprised a vessel containing 550 3rd century ADcoins including issues of Gordian III and Philip I.
36 coins: 34 denarii, 2 asses: Republic - Tiberius (AD 14-37).
The hoard comprised a vessel containing more than 1500 antoniniani (radiates), including issues of Postumus.
14 silver coins: Trajan – Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268). At the same place as ČESKA SKALICE 1884
disposition: Museum of Náchod, Czech Republic (inv.nos. N 1605-1618)

summary: 1 aureus of Tacitus, 1 gold barbarous imitation of an aureus, 4 drachms Hadrian, 1 denarius Septimius Severus were found in a grave together with jewelry.
25 coins found in small ceramic pitcher: 2 denarii, 18 antoniniani, 4 provincial bronze medallions, 1 provincial bronze coin: Severus Alexander - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
23 denarii found with a m1y-box: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 175-176)
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie a Județului Vâlcea, Râmnicu Vâlcea, Romania

summary: Hallaton: 14 hoards were located in and around the entrance way. Hoard 18 comprises 180 silver Iron Age coins and 3 Roman denarii.
c. 100 antoniniani: Gordian - Philip I (AD 244-249). No further information.

The hoard was found in a heap of st1s without any obvious container and comprised 'some Roman gold coins. There is some debate over the number of coins found. According to Chassant, there were 5, but Leclerc de Pulligny suggests there was 'a multitude'. Pulligny also mentions a coin of Lucius Verus, but this is not recorded amongst the coins examined by Chassant. Found in a pile of st1s with no obvious container.
A couple of hundred denarii of Trajan found on a pasture and sold to the silversmiths to be melted down. (AD 98-117).

The hoard comprised 1016 coins (1015 antoniniani-radiates and 1 denarius). The hoard was discovered by 2 workmen on a building site, less than 50 metres from the Gallo-Roman baths, in an earthenware pot that got broken. The Hôtel de Ville d'Allonnes has preserved 386 coins from the hoard.
(750) 639 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver w8: 937.5 g.
disposition: Museum of History, Silistra, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 468-1108 (641 coins)

summary: 80 nummi of the first Tetrarchy (AD 293-305).
(+1000) 92 antoniniani: Gordian - Valerian I (AD 253-259
disposition: Archaeological Museum Zagreb, Croatia (63 coins); dispersed -1981

summary: 700 aurei and denarii found with a pot, probably ending with coins of Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
19 asses found within 1 square meters: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 177).
Hoard of around 200 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
disposition: Institute of Archaeology of the Academy of Sciences, Kyiv, Ukraine (22 coins); National History Museum, Moskow, Russia (inv.no. 92088; 105 coins); private collection (1 coin)

summary: The hoard comprised 100 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates) of Caracalla, Elagabalus, Severus Alexander, Maximinus I, Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).

The hoard comprised 152 coins of which 128 were studied by Dancoisne. There were 12 sestertii and 116 denarii and antoniniani (radiates), although Dancoisne does not specify which coins are which! The hoard was found by workmen by the side of the river: -116 coins; silver w8: 34.0-336.1g.
A hoard of 13+ drachms of reduced w8, struck by Rhodes in the late 1st c. BC. The find spot is given as Rhodes (?) in CH II, but Marmaris in CH VII.
At least 6 Gallo-Belgic E staters discovered over a period of a year or more by a single detectorist and described as having been found "a few hundred yards apart".
6teen Iron Age coins found on 10 August 1995, within a small area of 1 field.
disposition: Museum of the Iron Age, Andover

summary: 126 nummi of the period of AD 378-423 found in a sewer of a Roman house part of the later Euphrasian Basilica.

A small hoard of 25 Roman aurei and their imitations. This hoard was never published, however, according to Berghaus it contained 2 genuine issues and 23 cast imitations of Roman aurei, which prototypes can be dated from Lucius Verus to Septimius Severus. More than a half of them show evidence that they were made of the same moulds.
6 nummi recovered after a flood: Constantine I 2, Constantine II/Constantius II 1, Cionstantius III Gallus 1, Valentinian I 1 (AD 364-375).
Hoard of 238 denarii found in a ceramic vessel: Republic - Trajan (AD 98-117).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.no. CLXX (237 coins in november 1957)

summary: This hoard comprised originally at least 51 coins. Today only 33 of them can be identified. They are bronze coins (As, dupondii) from the time of Augustus.
(+200) 126 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-268); silver w8: 38.8-156.5 g.
758 imperial and provincial bronze coins entered the museum collection in Sofia: Titus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 42288-46046

summary: 17 antoniniani (radiates) found in the wall plaster of a domestic building: Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver w8: 5.6-20.3g.

A hunter stooping to pick up a hare, noticed 30 Roman coins scattered on the ground surface. Further investigation led to the discovery of another 50 coins, presumably a hoard dispersed by ploughing: Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269).
294 found with a black coarse ceramic vessel: Republic – Gaius (AD 37).
Hoard of an unknown originally number of nummi found with a ceramic vessel. Only 3 coins are presented: Magnus Maximus 2, Theodosius I.
The hoard comprised 10 (or 12) denarii concealed in a hollowed out flint. The hoard was found while breaking st1s from Etrimont.
1209 coins found with a ceramic vessel: 1 antoninianus (radiate), 1208 nummi: Claudius II (Divus) - House of Valentinian (AD 378-383)

A small hoard of 31 Roman Imperial denarii: Trajan – Commodus (AD 193-211) was found by treasure hunter in January 2022, possibly in Kharkiv region. Information about the hoard and photos of the coins were published in 1 of the groups on Facebook, dedicated to treasure hunting, by user Vasiliy Kopat'ko (Василий Копатько). The conditions of hoard finding are unknown, but judging by the photos from the post on Facebook, it was found in the forest. Since the hoard was discovered in winter under snow cover, it is possible that not all coins were found.
800 silver coins: 503 denarii, 297 antoniniani (radiates): Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-247). Near the hoard was discovered a votive inscription.
disposition: Muzeul Olteniei, Craiova, Romania; inv. no. I 3555

summary: Unknown number of denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 2 of them were known: 1 Trajan, 1 Faustina II.
21 kilos (c. 70000 coins): Aurelian - House of Theodosius I (AD 388-423).
4 nummi of the House of Constantine found during archaeological excavations at the Katsuren castle — a UNESCO world heritage site — which stood from the 12th to the 15th century AD.
6 gold Roman coins found in a burial: Vespasian 1, Trajan 1, Hadrian 4.
4 antoniniani (radiates), that may have belonged to a hoard: Gordian III, Philip I, Trajan Decius for Hostilian (Caesar/Augustus), Gallienus (AD 253-259).

The hoard was found in a ' copper alloy m1ybox in an inhumation grave and contained coins of Claudius II, Tetricus etc.' Taking into account the size of the m1ybox, the hoard cannot have comprised more than 20 or 30 coins

The hoard was found in a black ceramic vessel which was broken. It comprised 546 bronze and 'billon' Roman coins from the 2nd and 3rd centuries AD. It was a mixed hoard of Anto9 bronzes and later radiates. M. Lepel-Cointet of Jumièges owns the remains of the vessel and some coins.

1 sestertius (Lucilla) and 29 denarii, ranging from Septimius Severus to Julia Mamaea. The sestertius was not menti1d in FMRD. No trace of container was found, although it could have been made of organic material.
disposition: Weimar, Museum für Ur- und Frühgeschichte Thüringens

summary: 191 coins: antoniniani (radiates), nummi and imitations: Gallienus (sole) - Theodosius I (Arcadius, Honorius) (AD 388-402).
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg

summary: 30 provincial bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel. Only 3 pieces are known: Septimius Severus (Pautalia), Caracalla (Hadrianopolis, Philippopolis).
72 bronze coins of Alexandria purchased from an itinerant dealer and said to have come from this site: Cleopatra VII - Augustus (27 BC - AD 14).

Found during excavations in a Gallo-Roman "Vierecktempel" on a hilltop, above a cliff. Among many single finds a depot of 66 antoniniani (latest coin Diocletian, AD 293), found in the cella of the temple.
350 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only coin of Julia Maesa is known.
6 denarii to AD 161 - "hoard 2" Davies 2000. From an occupation layer in range 3 of structure 1, Pickfords Garage site. Scattered in a small area with no evidence of a container.

The hoard comprised a vessel containing approximately 900 silver coins (denarii). The older coins show wear patterns consis10t with long circulation, while the more recent issues were in mint condition: Hadrian (Sabina Augusta) - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
The hoard comprised 25 sestertii from Hadrian to Valerian I (AD 253-260).
Around 3000 nummi of Constantine I and his family (AD 324-337).

A hoard of 21 nummi found during excavations, in the Mithraeum, niveau de fréquentation. Ritual deposit, 21 aes coins in the lower part of a broken pot, placed next to the north-eastern basis of the arc above the cult relief.
disposition: Service des bâtiments, monuments et archéologie, Martigny/Sion

summary: The hoard comprised 1000 aurei ending in issues of Claudius I found with a ceramic vessel. 2 thirds belong to Tiberius the type of seating Livia. The rest of coins were issued for: Augustus, Nero Drusus, Germanicus, Gaius, Claudius I, Antonia and Agrippina I.
12 bronze coins of Viminacium probably issued under Gordian III and Philip I (AD 246-247)
disposition: Museum of Sofia; inv. nos. CIII and CLXVII (1936 and 1953)

summary: Unknown original number of coins. 184 denarii of which 2 imitations: Vespasian - Didius Julian (AD 193). Found together with a "belt set of 1 massive silver buckle for a sword belt and 2 buckles for a girdle. The find also contains 8y-4 silver belt plaits. This belt set, dating to the latter half of the 5th century AD (phase D2 of the Great Migration Period), is a girdle for bladed weaponry."
disposition: The State Museum of Military History and Natural Preserve “The Kulikovo Polye”, Tula, Russia (inv.no. BX 1823/1-184)

summary: Around 100 denarii, among them, 1 of Antoninus Pius for Faustina II. No further details.
More than 1500 coins were discovered in a bowl. However, only 77 pieces are known in any detail, 5% of the original hoard: Caracalla - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-259).
12 late Roman coins found during archaeological excavations: Constantius II - Theodosius I (AD 335-388).
Over 100 silver and bronze coins. 19 pieces have been noticed: Rhometalces I 4, Rhometalces II and Tiberius 14,
disposition: Once in a private collection, Plovdiv, lost?

summary: Circa 5.8 kilos of silver coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 160 were recovered: Republic - Augustus (4 BC).

The hoard was discovered during antiquarian exploration of a Gallo-Roman site. It appeared to have been originally stored in a cabinet measuring 6 feet square and comprised more than 300 base-silver coins. According to the finder, villagers who knew the findspot continued to find coins in abundance there. 300 silver coins: Severus Alexander - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268); silver w8: 76.1-710.8+g.
Hoard of 50 denarii: Republic - Tiberius. Only 3 denarii were available for study, based on a photo

The hoard comprised 4 Iron Age coins. It was characterised as being 1 of 16 individual votive deposits found at the site of an important Gallo-Roman sanctuary during excavations. Inventory 76.617 to 620

find_spot_name: SIRACUSA, EX VIGNA CASSIA, PRIMA TOMBA (GRUZZOLO A)
summary: Hoard in grave, 114 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).

The hoard comprised more than 500 Roman coins, which were immediately dispersed. P. Tes10oire-Lafayette identified 50 coins dating to the 4th century, which had been kept by the finder. It is thought that these coins are likely to be representative of the composition of the hoard as a whole.

27 silver denarii, from Vespasian to Severus Alexander (75-235 AD), have been found scattered over a cultivated field by volunteer archaeologists. Coins are now kept in the Archaeological Museum of Povegliano Ver1se.
(c. 1200) 122 denarii: Nero - Maximinus I Tharax (AD 235-236); silver w8: c. 1681.7-3754.3 g.
727 denarii and antoniniani found in a ceramic vessel: Nero - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no.8442-9165

summary: A chance discovery of 4 silver coins was made in the Derbyshire Dales . An excavation around the findspot in October 2013 produced a further 22 coins (including gold, silver and base metal types) as well as a number of base metal and non-metal objects.
The hoard comprised approximately 200 antoniniani (radiates) found in a ceramic vessel. Preliminary study suggests that 10% are of Gallienus, 60% Postumus and some coins of Tetricus I and II.
The hoard comprised 2 lumps of coins struck by Constantine I and Licinius I from a shipwreck assemblage.
16 coins of Hadrian (AD 117-138). No further information.
The hoard comprised 1 radiate of Claudius II and 38 Provincial coins of the early third century AD, found in a grave (Grave Θ) in Amphipolis in 1976
62 coins, mostly sestertii: Trajan - Gordian III (AD 238-244)
Unknown originally number of denarii. 8 denarii, 1 drachm of Dyrrachium and 1 denarius Antoninus Pius (Faustina I/Diva Faustina I) were recovered.

A hoard of about a 100 Roman bronze coins, found on the estate of Carstairs house (= Monteith House). Nero, Trajan, Faustina, Germanicus, M. Aurelius, M. Antoninus are menti1d. To this hoard belonged 13 coins presented to the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland in 1781 (Trajan, Hadrian, the Empress Faustina, and Germanicus, are menti1d; the coin with Germanicus probably refers to an emperor Germanicus in its titles, e.g. Nero, Domitian or Trajan). No coins from this hoard have been located in NMAS, Edinburgh, or in Hunterian Museum, Glasgow. There is, however, in the University archives a letter from Mr. W. Fullerton, Carstairs House, dated 20 Oct. 1781, to Dr. A. Stevenson stating: "I send you a small box containing a dozen or more bronze medals in10ded for the College. About a hundred or more of them were found together by some workmen in repairing a road to a miln near this place [i.e. Carstairs House]. {...} They are cheifly [sic] Trajans Hadrian Antoninus Pius 2 or 3 Faustinas and 1 Marcus Aurelius Caesar and several others which from the inscription being much worn out their age cannot be so easily ascertained tho' on comparing them with Vallaint's [Vaillant's] Numismata they seem to be of Domitian. The place where they were found is about a quarter of a mile from an old Roman encampment or station [i.e. the Roman fort at Castledykes] of which part of the vallum remains still partly intire."
"Few hundreds" Roman coins found in a field. Only 33 coins provided some information and some of them have been entered to the level of the coin. The precision is not certain.
A large hoard of at least 990 base silver staters of the Durotriges, found in and around the base and lower body of an Iron Age or Roman pot.
113 antoniniani (radiates) - 68 imitations: second half 3rd c., burial: 274 (during or after Tetrici's age)
disposition: Museo Arch. Reg. "P. Orsi", Siracusa, Italy (inv.nos: 80699, 80700, 80701-80703)

summary: 4 aurei (Nero to Antoninus Pius) recorded at 4 different points in time, between 1996 and 2002, clearly forming a hoard. Many other metal-detected finds from site, Roman-post-medieval.
271 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 268 handed to the National Museum in Bucharest: Nero - Marcus Aurelius. 1 denarius may depict Julia Domna?
disposition: National Museum of History, Bucharest, Romania; Museum of History and Archaeology, Piatra Neamț, Romania (the vessel)

summary: 3 coins, unknown denomination: Trajan, Hadrian and Marcus Aurelius (Caesar) (AD 145-161).
101 coins: 96 sestertii, 3 antoniniani (radiates), 2 bronze copies: Domitian - Postumus (AD 260); silver w8: 3.5-6.2 g.
disposition: Local museum, Petigny, Belgium (82 coins); private collection (11 coins), in 1960; Archaeological Museum, Namur, Belgium (8 coins)

summary: 3598 antoniniani (radiates) of which 3032 are imitations: Valerian I and Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).
5 denarii found together: Vespasian – Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
Hallaton: 14 hoards were located in and around the entrance way. Hoard 13 comprises 189 Iron Age coins.

“1 or 2 hoards? 72 Late Roman bronze coins, 41 Naimana imitations, and 9 unidentifiable small bronze coins. Viewed in the possession of an antique dealer in Colombo in 1978. Allegedly found as a group when digging up the soil for the foundations of a church in Moratuwa in c. 1976.”
The hoard was found in 1886, in "La Grange Rouge". It comprised 250 bronze coins of the Late Empire.
30 coins, 27 described, found inside a rich grave. Includes 1 2nd. c. denarius and 1 ‘Dortmund’ copy. tpq c.430 Silver: 1, 21 coins; Silver w8: 29.42g+
18 provincial bronze coins entered the museum collection in Shumen: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 13869/1-18 (17 coins)

summary: Group of 2 coins found with an urn: Maximinus I Thrax bronze, Gordian III antoninianus (radiate) (AD 238-244).

In 1904, Ali Farah, of the Eastern Telegraph Company, Aden, donated 3 gold coins to the British Museum: 1 Aksumite coin ofEbana, 1 imitation of a solidus of Constantius II, and a solidus of Constantius II minted in Arles.
At least 140 solidi and 1 aureus (Gordian III), found in 2 lots (1822 and 1838), but certainly belonging to the same hoard. Tpq of AD 430/445.
disposition: Münzkabinett, Staatliche Museen zu Berlin (76 coins); Archäologisches Institut der Georg-August-Universität Göttingen (3 coins)

summary: Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 7 sestertiiare known: Trajan - Commodus (AD 181).
Few hundreds imitations of antoniniani (radiates), between 500-2000 pieces of Tetricus I (AD 271-274), 400 studied.
A hoard of 30 coins, ranging from Gallienus to the time of Constantine I, found in Mainz-Bretzenheim.
4811 denarii and antoniniani, found in 1 (or 2?) urns, in the garden of the school. Coins range from Caracalla to Postumus.
Few hundreds of provincial bronze coins. 92 entered the museum collection in Sofia: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 26923-27020 (92 coins)

summary: 78 coins: Claudius II (Divus) - Constantius II (AD 355-361).
disposition: Museo Arqueolóxico do Castro de Viladonga, Spain

summary: 84 sestertii and 1 forgery: Trajan - Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
The hoard comprised 13 sestertii and dupondii from the first century AD to Gordian III, found in a large pithos. They might have been be part of a larger hoard.
43 silver coins: 42 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate): Vitellius - Gordian III (AD 241-243).
disposition: Museum of History and Archaeology, Constanța, Romania

summary: 5 denarii: Republic - Tiberius (AD 14-37). Part of the hoard ONNA 1884 (CHRE 9983)?
A doubtful hoard of 3000 antoniniani (radiates) found by amateur archaeologists. Not confirmed by the "official research".
Unknown initial number of coins. 183 denarii: Nero - Pescennius Niger (AD 193-194).
40 nummi: Constantine I (Constantius II Caesar) - Theodosius II (AD
61 bronze coins minted in Tyras found with a ceramic vessel: Septimius Severus - Severus alexander (Julia Mamaea) (AD 222-235).
The hoard comprised 4000 coins with emperors from Severus Alexander to Postumus represented. The hoard was found by a farmworker.

A coin hoard comprising 44 Iron Age staters of the 'Norfolk Wolf' Uninscribed Icenian JB type. These were found scattered in what appear to have been 2 groups over a relatively small area, the first group in November 2012 and the second around March 2013. If 2 hoards were concealed, however, these must surely be 2 part of 1 main deposit; the 2 groups of coins share die-links as well as being of the same type. (PAS).
The hoard comprised a coarseware vessel containing 196 bronze coins from Trajan to Valerian and Gallienus and a small silver bracelet.
5 gold coins: 3 aurei, 2 solidi: Tetrarchy - Constantine I/Constantine II (AD 317-340).
The hoard comprised '400 gold coins found under a st1 including issues of Diocletian, Maximian and other emperors'. Gold w8: c.1768.1-1799.2g.
53 large Roman imperial bronze coins (sestertii?): Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
500 antoniniani (radiates): Probus - Diocletian (AD 284-293).

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing '30 silver and bronze coins, including 1 of Nero. It is possible that this hoard is the same as the hoard of large and medium bronzes of Domitian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Commodus and Gordian III which were examined by Deville.
1200 imperial bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel: Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (Salonina) (AD 253-268).
Unknown initial number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 350 coins were basically examined : Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Balaton Museum Keszthely (312 coins); Magyar Nemzeti Muzeum, Budapest (38 coins), Hungary

summary: The hoard comprised 10320-10500 silver denarii and tetradrachms, ranging from Vespasian to Elagabalus, found in a bronze jar.

The hoard comprised 24 Iron Age coins and 4 Republican denarii. It was characterised as being 1 of 16 individual votive deposits found at the site of an important Gallo-Roman sanctuary during excavations. Inventory No: 76.943.1 to 28

A hoard of 24 provincial coins (ranging from Antoninus Pius to Geta) and 5 antoniniani (Gallienus) were found in a small pocket behind the stage of the theatre in Corinth, at the level of the marble pavement.

The hoard comprised a 427 coins of Constantine I and his sons. Close by, 166 coins dating to the period AD 320-335 were also found. Although originally interpreted as site finds, it is possible that they represent a further portion of this hoard. A lot of coins from this hoard is preserved in the Musée de Laval (Mayenne) with the label 'Jublains Hoard'.
17 bronze coins: 3 dupondii, 15 asses: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
Originally between 80 and 100 coins were found of which only 2 aurei and 16 denarii were retained: Trajan - Caracalla (AD 214).
disposition: Escuela de Capataces forestales (Castillo de Coca), Madrid

summary: 43 Republican denarii and an aureus of Nero found in the Villa Diomede.

The hoard comprised a vessel containing between 100 and 120 aurei (or more than 150 coins according to Godard-Faultrier). Most publications state that the latest coin is an aureus of Augustus. The aureus of Nero may be an intruder or an isolated find. The hoard was found by a miller, J. Alleaume

19 Roman gold and about 580 silver coins, prior to the reign of Trajan, but principally of Vespasian and Domitian, found while improving the road from Shap to Kendal, in 1830, under some blocks of granite.
An undeclared hoard of perhaps 25 or 30 Iron Age staters, dispersed in trade, consisting mainly in staters of Dubnovellaunos, V169/ABC 303.
18 Iron Age potin coins of Class I Flat Linear type were discovered whilst metal-detecting near Boxley.
1049 bronze coins found in 3 ceramic vessels placed 1 next to the other: 1045 sestertii, 3 dupondii, 1 as: Nero - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Cabinet des médailles de la Bibliothèque Nationale de France

summary: 300 denarii: Augustus - Commodus (AD 180-192).

1138 silver coins: 25 Greek drachmas, 1033 republican denarii, 54 imperial denarii and antoniniani (radiates), 2 provincial bronzes, 3 nummi, 21 unknown denomination: 150 BC - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-268). 3 coins of the House of Constantine I/Constans (AD 333-350) are most likely intruders; silver w8: 1552.6-3959.8 g.
A group of 27 coins, together with a further silver coin fragment. Addenda of 3.

The first 20 (?) denarii from the hoard were discovered by schoolchildren in 1968, 8 of them were transferred to the Coin Room of the Belarusian State University. V. Ryabtsevich tried to establish the place where the hoard was found, but to no avail. In the first hoard's publication the village of Žukievičy was named as its location. After that, at the hoard's place, amateurs conducted further searches for it. Separate denarii were found, 2 of which (Trajan and Antoninus Pius) were transferred by V. Kakareka to the Coin Room of the Belarusian University. The rest of the hoard was discovered by treasure hunters in 2011 near the village of Aliekšycy: 426 denarii and 18 fragments of brooches, which were donated to the Museum of the National Bank of the Republic of Belarus. Later, 10 more coins were transferred there. In total, 446 coins are known from the hoard (Vespasian-Septimius Severus).
disposition: Coin Room of the Belarusian State University (10 coins); Museum of the National Bank of the Republic of Belarus (436 coins)

summary: 4 denarii: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Septimius Severus, Caracalla.
52 gold coins found with a ceramic vessel. 41 coins were recovered and studied: Theodosius II - Marcian (AD 450-457); gold w8: 182.45g.
Over 800 republican denarii, of which 659 were recovered. Latest issue from 40 BC. Found with an earthenware jar.
In 1937 a small hoard of 9 sestertii (Trajan - Commodus) was found in the north of Faimingen in the foundation walls of a Roman building, between the Roman road and the contemporary road.
Hoard of 135 coins of the Bosporan kings dated between AD 286 and AD 328. No further information.
115 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 167).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1617-1730 (115 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 77 silver coins dated between 32/31 BC and AD 125-128.
Unknown initial number of coins. 12 silver coins: Antoninus Pius - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver w8: 5.3-26.2 g.
2 denarii: Antoninus I (Faustina I), Marcus Aurelius.
1268 coins: 7 aurei, 1261 denarii: Republic - Hadrian (AD 136-138). Total w8: 4023.93g.
disposition: Historischen Museum der Stadt Wien (Karlsplatz), Austria

summary: 3 silver coins found stuck together. There is some doubt about the reliability of the provenance.
Unknown number of silver coins were found in a ceramic vessel. N. Moushmov examined 119 pieces: Nerva - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
1267 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) ranging from Trajan to Philip I (AD 247-248) found with 2 ceramic vessels.

8 detectorists from the Stour Valley Search and Recovery Club found 9 Chute (ABC 746) staters on 22 September 200 and a further 6 on 24 November 2001. A 6teenth coin of the same type was discovered in the same area on 23 February 2002 (TAR 2001, 90 no. 176), and 2 more in April 2005 (NC 169 (2009), 331 no. 1; PATAR 2008, 186 no. 462).
16 silver coins: 2 denarii, 14 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
167 silver coins: 97 denarii, 70 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Diocletian (AD 295).
disposition: formerly Regional museum Tiel (destroyed during WWII)

summary: The hoard comprised 123 nummi, 10 of which were dated between the 4th and 6th centuries AD.
The Kirchgasse 62 find includes 100-200 coins, ranging from Gallienus to the time of Constantine I. Of these, 70 have been described.
312 denarii, range: Republican (211-210 BC) - Augustus (2 BC/AD 4). Large number countermarked.
disposition: Museo Arch. Reg. "A. Salinas", Palermo: inv. 16037-96; 16103-79; 16181-89; 16190-363

summary: 300 denarii, found with a ceramic vessel 237 coins were recovered: Otho – Septimius Severus (AD 195).
disposition: History Museum, Piatra Neamț, Romania (227 coins); National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (10 coins; inv.no. 361)

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 350 sestertii of which 250 were too worn to identify. Hahn compiled a catalogue of 107 examples which is given here. A news article mentions a sestertius of Severus Alexander which is not included in Hahn's catalogue which may or may not be part of the hoard.
Unknown originally number of aurei. 40-5 coins from Nero to Trajan were recovered. 7teen coins were studied in detail. 9 coins were acquired in 1937 by the mayor of Villeurbanne.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel 'containing 9kg coins, mostly 3rd century small bronzes of the Gallic emperors, Gallienus, Postumus etc., although according to Triger there were some earlier coins of Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Faustina, and Justine (sic). This information was repeated by numismatic reviews and by Blanchet. In 1911, Ledru wrote about the coins acquired by Julien and Louis Chappée and gave a list of emperors. A lot of 1219 coins were bought by the Musée du Mans in 1890. The hoard was found during quarrying. Silver w8: c.812.3-7797.7g.
108 solidi, includes 2 imitations: Arcadius - Valentinian III (AD c. 435); gold w8: 480.6 g. Found with a ceramic vessel.
disposition: Archaeological Institute of the Slovak Academy of Sciences in Nitra

summary: 9 denarii placed in a cavity: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 185).

The coins were found in the area of Fleischstraße 68-76 during excavation works for the construction of a store. They lay in a ceramic container (an amphora, according to some sources). Large parts of the hoard came in private possession and its full ex10t is unknown. FMRD gives 3 lists, totalling 3595 coins (all antoniniani, ranging from to ): 1) Part 1 (3351 coins; FMRD 30622) 2) Part 2 (Private coll.; 25 coins; FMRD 30623) 3) Part 3 (218 coins seen by K. Cibis, only a list of emperors is available; FMRD 30624) 4) Part 4 (Private coll., 1 coins; FMRD 30625)
21 sestertii, 1 dupondius and 1 AE (copper or brass) found in the neighborhoud of a Roman building next to some clay sources.
Unknown number of silver coins. 31 pieces were noticed: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
Around 100 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 29 coins were recovered and sherds from the vessel: Vespasian – Commodus (Divus Marcus Aurelius ) (AD 180).
Hoard of around 100 denarii from the time of the Anto9 dynasty. Only 4 coins are documented.
75 denarii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius. No further details.
disposition: Museum of Southern Podlasie, Biała Podlaska, Poland

summary: 153 silver coins found with a jug: 102 drachm, 48 didrachm, 1 Seleucid tetradrachm and 2 Seleucid didrachms.
A hoard of 62 Caesarean provincial bronze coins dating from Septimius Severus to Gordian III.

Hoard(?) of a very diverse composition: Greek coins, billon provincial coins of Alexandria, imperial denarii, nummi. Reported to have been found in a dining set during ploughing. Most likely a private collection.

The coins were dug out during excavation for the construction of St. Paulus elementary school, on Zuckerbergstrasse. A Roman street was cut into (a decumanus) as well as the remains of a residential development.
(4033) 3296 silver coins recorded: 592 denarii, 2704 antoniniani: Domitian to - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251). Found in a ceramic vessel.
disposition: The British Museum, London, United Kingdom

summary: 6 billon coins of Alexandria found in a grave: Probus - Maximian I (AD 293).
Unknown original number of sestertii: Titus - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Town museum, Kaliningrad, Russia (inv.no. КГОМ 1.18842/1-119); Archive Rudau (in 1911) (inv.no. Rudau_wNL_SH_1_3-150_2, Rudau_wNL_SH_1_3-148_1, Rudau_wNL_SH_1_3-150_1)

summary: 25 silver coins: 2 republican denarii, 21 imperial denarii, 2 antoniniani (radiates): Republic - Postumus (AD 260-269).
The coins were discovered around 1930/35. The circumstances of the find cannot be further ascertained. Nearly all of the specimens are of excellent preservation.
52 coins: 51 antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - Postumus (AD 269). 1 Denarius.
3 coins of odd combination found corroded into a single lump in June 1983, in the garden of 39 King's Lane.
A small urn found by a workman stubbing gravel. It contained 30 coins of the Lower Empire, 1 gold and 20-9 silver, in very fine preservation.
About 20 antoniniani (radiates) found during prospections. Only 10 of them were studied: Valerian I and Gallienus or Gallienus (sole reign) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).

199 denarii found at wetland deposit. Not 1 hoard, but a collection of several all deposited together. The earliest known contexts for Imperial denarii in Scandinavia are the Illerup weapon sacrifice dated by dendrochronology to c. 210 AD.

A hoard of about 20-25 Roman imperial denarii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180) was discovered by treasure hunter in the late 2010s between the villages of Pysarivka and Hrushkivtsi in the Vinnytsia region. The coins were found on an area of ca. 20x20 m and all had the same traces of bronze oxides. The finder did not provide a photo of the coins, but said that among the coins were denarii of Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina (I or II?), Marcus Aurelius (including those with the rank of Caesar). The further fate of the coins is unknown.
Unknown originally number of coins found by metal detecting. Only 41 denarii are recorded: Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II Diva) (AD 176).
The hoard was found in a cut st1 vessel and comprised more than 1800 antoniniani (radiates) of Gordian III, Gallienus and Carinus.
138 nummi found next to a wall south west of the market at street level: House of Constantine - Valens (AD 364-378).
Few hundreds denarii found in a ceramic vessel. Only 16 pieces recovered: Marcus Aurelius - Severus Alexander (AD 228-231); silver w8: 28.8-66.0 g.
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Stara Zagora, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 2146-2154

summary: 2 Cheriton staters were found by Mr Brian Radford, near Fareham, in February 2006. They were stolen from Westbury Manor Museum, Fareham, on 29 April 2010, and unfortunately no images appear to exist.
Hallaton: 14 hoards were located in and around the entrance way. Hoard 02 comprises 163 Iron Age coins.
17 antoniniani (radiates); Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269).
523 denarii belonging to a larger hoard found within the area of the hillfort. The earliest coins were issues of Octavian/Augustus (32-27 BC).
1450 coins - possibly found with a ceramic vessel: 1 bronze Iberic, 1 as, 1 solidus, 8 antoniniani (radiates), 1440 nummi: 2nd c. BC - Honorius (AD 404-408). Together was found a golden ring.
disposition: Museo Nacional de Arte Romano, Mérida, Spain

summary: The hoard comprised 372 coins that were fused together in a single lump. They comprised 1 denarius and 371 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Victorinus. The mint distribution is given in TAF (Rome: 210; Cologne: 93; Trier: 24) but not related to issues of particular emperors. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of 100g to 111.0g.
ca. 40 coins in a leather purse, but only 5 coins are identified: Septimius Severus (1), Postumus (4).
A hoard of ca. 800 silver and 20 bronze coins, found in a pot while ploughing a field (at Hermendonk?, not far from Wach10donk). The coins are not preserved, but a list of emperors exists.
4942 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero - Elagabalus (AD 222).
disposition: Brukenthal Museum, Sibiu, Romania, 3,500 coins; County Museum, Pitești, Romania, 867 coins; Museum of History, Râmnicu Vâlcea, Romania, 531 coins; Institute of Archaeology, Bucharest, Romania, 44 coins

summary: The hoard comprised 15 Continental Iron Age silver coins and between 360 and 400 obols from Marseille.
The hoard was found north of the village, in 3 ceramic vessels. It comprised c. 500 bronze coins. 180 sestertii, dupondii and asses from Vespasian to Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
The hoard comprised between 31 and 34 bronze coins primarily dating to the mid-4th century AD. It was found deposited in a pit close to a water feature (possibly a latrine) within a Roman fort.
5 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-269)
2 aurei found within the modern prison ground, all in the same year. They are presented as single finds in bibliography: Tiberius, Domitian.
HER record of 8 radiates found "below st1 bridge".
195 silver coins: 102 denarii, 93 antoniniani: Commodus - Philip (AD 246); silver w8: 232.3-420.8 g.
disposition: County Museum Gorj, Tg. Jiu, Romania; Ion Luben collection, Bucharest (3 coins)

summary: The coins are plated denarii or ancient forgery with superb style depicting the portraits of Vespasian and Nero.
247 antoniniani (radiates): Gordiasn III - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
26 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 176-177).

Hoard from the excavated Town House at Colliton Park, Dorchester (excavated 1937-8 and published in Durham and Fulford 2014, 59). 9 coins were found near the East door of room 13, building 182. However in revaluation (ibid) these were thought to be a residual scatter. In his report, Reece (same volume p.103) notes the presence of this hoard and 5 others identified by Mark Corney (2 first to third century and 3 Theodosian). However his report does not attribute these hoard coins to particular hoards and they are therefore difficult to reconstruct.The latest coin in this hoard was of Crispus AD 317-326, though the hoard coins from this hoard do not appear to be in Reece's catalogue.
The hoard comprised 6 bronze coins dated between AD 318-319 and AD 378-383.
62 coins: 1 aureus, 56 denarii and 5 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 253-256).
868 coins: 346 antoniniani (radiates), 522 nummi: Treboniaus Gallus: Volusian - Tetrarchy (AD 303)

The hoard was found in 2 boxes next to a lead coffin in a Gallo-Roman cemetery. The boxes contained masses of radiates and included amongst them, issues of Postumus and Tetricus I. Found in a sandpit.
Circa 100 silver coins of the 2nd-3rd centuries AD were found in a ceramic vessel. Scattered.
The hoard contains 21 gold solidi struck in Antioch and ranging in date from Valentinian I to Valentinian II.

find_spot_name: KÖLN - ST. MARIA IM KAPITOL XI
summary: The coins came into the possession of H.J. Lückger. Variants and features of this collection were published in 1902. Since only particular specimens were made known in the menti1d publication, it is believed that this only represents a small part. It is unknown how many coins from the hoard actually made it into the possession of Lückger.
7 Jewish coin, including 3 of the first uprising (AD 67-70).
The hoard comprised 51 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Valerian II with a tpq of AD 258. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of 65g.
8 solidi, ranging from Valentinian II to Honorius, AD 406.
128 provincial bronze coins: Antoninus Pius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1022-1141

summary: (500-600) 142 denarii: Vespasian - Balbinus (AD 238); silver w8: 771.6-1621.0 g.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (11 coin); collection L. Renard-Grenson (113 coins), Liège, Belgium; private collection (22 coins).

summary: The hoard comprised 1218 antoniniani (radiates) and nummi from Gallienus to Honorius. Mint distribution is given but not explicitly linked to individual coins. TAF states that the abundance of 'cut' coins suggests a deposition date of approximately AD 420. R. Delmaire mentions circa 1330 coins.
3 bronze coins: 1 sestertius, 2 nummi: Gordian III, Maximianus, Severus II (AD 306-307).
disposition: E. Buysse, Lauwe, Belgium (3 coins), in 1960; vicar Vercauteren, Lauwe, Belgium (3 coins), in 1960

summary: A large number of denarii and antoniniani was found in a ceramic vessel. 520 denarii are kept in the museum of Ruse: Vitellius - Gordian III (AD 242-243).
disposition: Ruse Regional Museum of History, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1705

summary: This hoard of 20 3 coins was found in 1928, and it consists mostly of cast imitations of the second-century aurei. Many of them are mould-linked.
c. 600 silver coins found with a bronze vessel (urna aerea): Gordian III, Philip I, Philip II.
204 aurei found with a ceramic vessel, 97 pieces studied: Nerva - Commodus.
The hoard was found within a wall during the excavation of a Roman villa and comprised 53 bronze coins, including 1 Iron Age issue and 52 nummi of the House of Constantine and House of Theodosius.
Unknown originally number of coins: "a large quantity of Roman coins". Only 10 nummi of the first Tetrarchy.
Hoard of 140 Naimana imitations and 1 Roman coin - nummus (AE4) (AD 380-470) was found at a Buddhist site (Gal Vihara).
1439 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Claudius II - Diocletian-Maximian (AD 295-296) found as a heap in an underground room during excavations of a house.
2 aurei of Nero, same type (AD 64-65).

According to the finders, the hoard was found with the help of a metal detector in a ploughed field between the villages of Buzhany and Rzhyshchiv. It contained 265 denarii, 2 silver fibulae, a ring-shaped silver pendant, an iron axe and several fragments of other (unidentified) objects. The main part of the hoard - coins, axe and brooch - was in the lower part of the clay pot, of which, in general, only a few fragments have survived. Other items from the treasure were spotted 3-4 meters away. They were probably contained in the upper part of the same vessel, broken by a tractor plough. That is, the pot was at a depth of only 35-40 cm and was destroyed during the cultivation of the land by the modern method of deep ploughing. Today the hoard is in a private collection.

A hoard of at least 385 Roman imperial denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180) was allegedly discovered in the late 2010s in the vicinity of Ivano-Frankivsk. The hoard contained mostly coins of "early mintages", and the latest 1s date back to the time of Antoninus Pius and Marcus Aurelius (10-15 such coins in total). No further information.
7 solidi: Valentinian I - Constantine III (AD 407-411); gold w8: 31.15 g.

A hoard of 538 bronze nummi ranging to AD 316 and discovered in a field to the north of Downside Abbey, Stratton on the Fosse. The site lies approximately 400 metres to the west of the Fosse Way in an area that has produced other Romano-British material. The list includes 4 coins "found in the close vicinity of the hoard".
(1616) 971 bronze: 2 antoniniani, 1 plated denarius, 1 as, 1 imitation, 966 nummi: Trajan - Arcadius (AD 388-393)
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie, Etnografie și Artă Plastică, Lugoj, Romania

summary: 3 aurei of Trajan found in a mound in the region of Groningen.
30 antoninianii, ranging from Gordian III to Volusian, were unearthed at the Roman fort Biriciana, on the via principalis near the porta dextra during excavations in 1892.
Unknown initial number of provincial bronze coins. 50 coins are kept in the museum collection in Sofia: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244)
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 22 092-22 141 (50 coins)

summary: A hoard of 200 silver and bronze coins was dispersed: 44 provincial coins of Antioch (Pisidia) and 13 nummi of the period of AD 306-366).
disposition: University Museum, Kyiv, Ukraine (57 coins; inv.no. 2593)

summary: The hoard comprised 11 sestertii: Hadrian-Philip I (117-246 AD).
disposition: Soprintendenza per i Beni Archeologici del Veneto, Padova, Italy

summary: 113 coins: Gallienus - Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
disposition: Museu Municipal de Etnografia e História da Póvoa de Varzim, Portugal; private collection

summary: A hoard of 50 coins found in a Roman building: 18 antoniniani (radiates), 4 denarii, 3 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 24 provincial bronzes: Antoninus Pius - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).

The hoard was found in a large iron pot and comprised approximately 29 kilos (close to 120 marcs) of Roman silver coins. The coins were denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from the reign of Septimius Severus to Gallienus and Postumus. Cochet suggested purely hypothetically that this hoard was found in Saint-André-Sur-Cailly.
Unknown original number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 13 nummi are now known: Constantine I - House of Valentinian I (AD 364-392)
disposition: Serviço de Arqueologia da Câmara Municipal de Vila do Conde, Portugal

summary: A purse containing 7 gold coins (solidi and tremissi), minted between AD 424 - 468 CE by the eastern Roman emperors in Constantinopolis, found 20 km south-west of anc. Meli10e.
Large hoard found while ploughing. Only 13 antoniniani identified: Caracalla 7, Philip I 6.
The hoard was hidden inside the camp: 25 aurei, 610 denarii, 2 asses, 1 quadrans, as well as gold and silver jewelry in a bronze cauldron: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 165-166).
disposition: Historischen Museum der Stadt Regensburg, Germany

summary: A scattered hoard of 31 staters of Cunobelin, found on 3 occasions between 7 October and 2 November 1990, including 9 linear type, 13 wild, 5 plastic and 4 classic.
The hoard comprised 20 Tyrian shekels (AD 8/9- AD 60/3) and 7 tetradrachms of Nero (AD 54-68).
Around 1000 antoniniani (radiates) found with an amphora. Among coins, issues of Gallienus, Salonina, Saloninus, Claudius II, Quintillus, Aurelian (AD 270-275).
4 Durotrigan base silver staters, which may perhaps have come from a hoard, confiscated from metal detectorists.
A hoard of 300-400 antoniniani (radiates). 336 coins were examined by Salama at the home of a dealer in Tunis on 6.5.1965: Gordian III - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).
Over 747 billon tetradrachms of Alexandria: Vespasian - Gallienus (sole) (AD 262-263) found in a pile on the floor of an underground room during excavations of a house.
disposition: 744 in Ann Arbor, the rest in various Egyptian museums

summary: 192 denarii: Nerva - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
23 siliquae found in unknown circumstances in the area of Girona: Gratian 4, Horius 4, Maximus of Barcelona 15 (AD 410-411).
Unknown quantity of bronze coins. Among them issues of Severus Alexander, Gordian III, Philip I. 11 pieces entered the museum collection in Shumen.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 3902-3912 (11 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 5 sestertii, dupondii or asses from Tiberius to Commodus and was found in association with a key handle, an incense burner, 2 statues (1 being of Mercury) and a statue base. The remains of a Roman building, the function of which was undetermined, was found close by.
38 coins: 16 denarii and 22 bronze coins found together in a tavern in the 19th century. Only 12 denarii could be re-identified:
disposition: Il Medagliere del Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Napoli, Italy

summary: The hoard comprised 19 Provincial bronzes of Severus Alexander issued in Caesarea Maritima.
The hoard comprised 86 sestertii from Vespasian to Septimius Severus, although the author proposes a deposition date in the reign of Postumus.
About 700 Roman coins were found in a ford in the river Pettarel near Carlisle in 1762. Coins seem to range from Nero to Faustina. A list of 64 of them (1 aureus, 62 denarii and 1 sestertius) exists.
Around 418 silver coins: 416 denarii, 2 drachms: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 164-180).
disposition: Muzeum, Koszalinie; Muzeum Zamojskie, Zamość; private collections, Poland

summary: In the Fanum Voltumnae with a st1 container 221 coins: 185 republican asses, 2 republican denarii, 1 republican quinarius, 18 imitations of issue "Divus Iulius" (RRC 535/1), 15 imperial asses of the IIIviri series (AD 15 BC).
A small ceramic vessel with 6 silver coins: 2 denarii, 4 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2601

summary: The hoard comprised 327 sestertii and 3 dupondii from Galba to Severus Alexander with a tpq of AD 233.
In 1831, 4 Republican denarii were found and then another in 1835. It is not clear whether they represent a hoard.
29 solidi, but only 8 were known: 7 Honorius, 1 Marcian (AD 450-457).
108 denarii and antoniniani: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 241-243).
Unknown number of bronze coins. 40 pieces entered the museum collection in Shumen. No further information.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 12347/1-40 (40 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel including Roman coins. The hoard was dispersed immediately. The hoard was found during house construction on the site of the church of the Jacobins: Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
11 antoniniani: Septimius Severus (Geta Caesar) - Philip I (AD 244-246).
4 radiates foundfused together.

A hoard of approx. 5200 coins, found in a garden close to the station of the railway Cleve - Köln. The hoard was dispersed, though a list of 1203 coins was made and 55 coins are in the museum in Trier. The FMRD list therefore encompassed 1225 entries.
35 bronze coins: medallions and coins: Nero, Vespasian, Titus, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
Ritual deposit. Found during a metal detectorists' illegal survey. 2 antoniniani, Gordian III and Philip the Arab.
Group of 6 coins: aureus of Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I), aureus of Postumus and 4 denarii of Augustus found in grave no. 8.
17 sestertii: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 186-187)
disposition: Collection L. Eloy, Namur, Belgium (14 coins), in 1966

summary: 29 nummi found with a ceramic vessel: Tetrarchy - Constantius II (AD 355-361).
disposition: Museu D. Diego de Sousa, Braga, Portugal

summary: 42 denarii, ranging from Nero to Didius Julianus. It is unsure whether 3 antoniniani (1 Gallienus, 2 Probus) and 1 denarius of Elagabalus were part of the hoard as well.
1446 denarii found during construction activity: Republic - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (AD 177-192).
disposition: Münzkabinett, Kunsthistorischen Museum, Vienna, Austria (964 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 300 coins of which 50 were Augustan asses of the altar of Lyon type.
A hoard of 3 provincial coins, found in a grave in Amphipolis.

A hoard of 12 Roman Imperial denarii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211) and a silver ingot was discovered in July 2019 in Sumy region. The finder reported that first 10 coins and a silver ingot were discovered, a few days later he discovered 2 more coins at the same location. On 20 July 2019, the finder published photos of the coins and ingot on the Ukrainian forum for treasure hunters Violity.
9 coins: 2 sestertius, 4 antoniniani (radiates), 3 nummi: Trajan - Constans (AD 347-348).
Over 1100 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 720 coins are kept in the National History Museum in Budapest, Hungary: Vitellius – Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
disposition: National History Museum, Budapest, Hungary (720 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 24 sestertii, asses and antoniniani (radiates) from Augustus to Probus and was found in the courtyard garden of a house during excavations of the Roman town of Clunia.
The hoard comprised 300 coins of Claudius II, along with finger rings and intaglios in10ded for finger rings. Found in a sewer.
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueologia, Lisboa, Portugal

summary: 1 solidus (Theodosius) and 12 siliquae to Honorius, AD 402, found in 2011 and 2017, most of them quite heavily clipped.
4 solidi of Honorius found over a period of a year.
A hoard of 94 silver coins, comprising 78 tetradrachms (dated between AD 69 and AD 219-222), 16 denarii, and 1 antoninianus (radiate).

A small hoard of 6 Roman imperial denarii: Vespasian — Hadrian (AD 117-138) was discovered by treasure hunter in 2014, possibly in Rivne region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on November 28, 2016, on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity. The finder reported that the find was discovered about 2 years ago before publication in a ploughed field. The coins were collected from a small area, but he did not probe to sondage on the place of find, assuming that he would find new finds after each ploughing. However, he has not found any new coins at the site in 2 years. All coins are equally well preserved (minimal worn) and close chronologically, which allows them to be considered as 1 deposit. In December 2016 and January 2018, the coins were sold on Violity auction. Coins: Vespasian (Titus) (1), Titus (2), Hadrian (3).
The hoard, found in a temple box, comprised 207 bronzes of the 3rd c. AD.
8 denarii found stuck together within a necropolis: Elagabalus - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
Unknown number of denarii. There is information on 4 coins: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Caesar), Faustina I/II (AD 138-180).

The hoard "consists of 109 pieces of silverware, as well as gold jewellery (necklaces, bracelets and earrings) and over 1100 gold coins. Items from the hoard vary in date from the 4th century BC to the 1st century AD. Many of the silver items from the treasure are considered masterpieces of Roman art that could only have belonged to the very elite sections of society. A few objects also seem to be family heirlooms passed down the generations. Parts of the hoard are inscribed with the name Maxima who were perhaps the original owner." Most of the coins are aurei of Nero. The database presents 117 types mainly based on Tameanko and Blanchet.
disposition: Louvre Museum, Paris, France (since 1896). Donation Edmond James de Rothschild

summary: Hoard of circa 100 antoniniani (radiates), of which only 39 pieces were seen: Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
Initially 368 denarii, nowadays, 367: Vitellius - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver w8: 1009.47 g.
disposition: The National Historical Museum, Stockholm (inv.no. 10155/1-167, 169-368); Stockholm Numismatic Institute, Stockholm (inv.no. 179)

summary: Group of 14 coins of poor state of preservation: 3 denarii, 1 sestertius, 3 asses, 7 bronze coins. Among them issues of Claudius I and Nero (AD 54-68).

A person came upon a pit during excavation works in 1966 between Marienplatz and Mühlenbach, approx. 4 m north of the Roman city wall in a depth of 4.5 m, in which 20 plated denarii lay tougher in a heap. 1 of them broke into fragments during recovery.
108 antoniniani radiates: Gallienus (sole) - Quintillus (AD 270).
disposition: Museo Archeologico del Territorio di Farini, Gropallo, Italy

summary: A hoard of at least 259 Roman imperial denarii was found by treasure hunters in 2016 in Cherkasy region. On October 4, 2016, a video of the process of sondage at the site where the hoard was found by 7 treasure hunters was published on YouTube, on the “Sokrovische nacii” (“Treasure of the Nation”) channel. A few days earlier, another group of treasure hunters found a batch of denarii - 192 specimens - on the surface (up to 15 cm deep in an area of about 10x10 m) of a ploughed field. Then, on October 4, on this place was made several sondages (approx. 2-3x1 m), in which, at a depth of 40-50 cm was found another 67 coins (each of the 7 treasure hunters took as many coins as they found). According to the assumption of 1 of the treasure hunters there may be more coins at this place. The video footage shows coins with traces of patina, among which can be distinguished denarii of Hadrian (incl. for Sabina), Antoninus Pius (incl. for Faustina I), Marcus Aurelius (incl. for Faustina II), Commodus. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
The hoard comprised 42 coins including 2 sestertii of Commodus and Balbinus and a silver coin of Attila(sic).
5 staters and 290 Iron Age silver coins
1776 denarii (5.5 kg): Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211). Most likely were kept in a wooden box, as 8 silver rivets "have been discovered at the site".
40 silver coins found in the Roman Forum. The last 1s are from Philip I (AD 244-249). No further information.

A hoard of at least 50 Roman Imperial denarii and a silver and gold buckle were discovered by a treasure hunter no later than 2021, probably in Zhytomyr region. Information about the hoard and general photo of the coins with the buckle were published in 1 of the groups on Facebook, dedicated to treasure hunting on November 1, 2021. 1 of the group members (Vasyl Ugrynchuk of Volodarsk in Zhitomyr region) reported that the hoard was discovered by his acquaintances (possibly also from Zhytomyr region). On the photo denarii of Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Commodus can be recognized. The buckle is quite massive (ca. 5-7 cm), on the clip there is a gold plate with ornamentation. The further fate of the hoard is unknown.
300 denarii and antoniniani (radiates), 130 coins were recovered: Vespasian - QuintillusI (AD 268-270).
(200) 27 silver coins: 6 denarii, 21 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-268); silver w8: 251.3-514 g.
Unknown initial number of coins. There is some information on 7 coins: 1 denarius, 6 antoniniani: Severus Alexander (Julia Mamaea) - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
Unknown originally number of coins, but for certain, a large number. Only 4 siliquae were documented.
disposition: Muzeul Național de Istorie a Moldovei, Chișinău (inv.nos. FB-13135 – FB-13138)

summary: 1943 silver coins found with a bronze vessel: 1942 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate): Antoninus Pius - MAximinus I Thrax (AD 236).
Unknown number of imperial and provincial bronze coins. 44 pieces enetered the museum collection in Popovo: Traian - Gordian III (AD 238-244).

322 denarii: Mark Antony - Commodus (AD 181-182). The hoard also includes silver and gold jewelry. Gold: 1 bracelet, 1 ring. Silver: 1 patera, 1 chain, 2 brooches, 1 necklace, 1 bracelet, 2 cups. All items were placed in a silver casket.
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 2 nummi are known: Constantine I, Constantius II (Constantius III Gallus Caesar).
(53) 50 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
263 coins found in a beaker covered by a plate: 1 denarius, 125 antoniniani (radiates), 3 double sestertii, 1 sestertius, 134 nummi: Trajan - Constantine I (AD 317).
700-750 bronze coins. 483 provide some information and 273 can be entered at the coin data level: Augustus - Postumus (AD 260-269).
Unknown originally number of coins. 50 denarii were sent to the Sankt Petersburg. Among issuers: Vespasiaen, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Commodus (AD 180-192).
84 nummi made after the late Roman m1tary reform of AD 348, ranging until 356 AD.
Around 600 republican denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Latest issue 43-42 BC.
967 coins, found in an amphora on a shipwreck: Domitian - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 256-257).

The hoard comprised a cylindrical coarseware vessel containing 2 kilos of coinage (with estimates of between 300/400 and 1000 coins). Coins of the 2 Tetrici (including 4 imitations), Constantine I, Constantine II, Constantius I, Urbs Roma, Magnentius, Valentinian, Valens, Gratian, Valentinian II, Theodosius, Magnus Maximus, Eugenius, Arcadius and Honorius (the most numerous). In addition, a bronze coin of Anastasius was also recorded, probably an intruder. The closing date is given as 393 or 395, or according to J. Lafaurie between 402 and 408).

Hoard of 39 denarii, 26 glass and amber beads, several fragmentary specimens, and fragments of metal ornaments, including 2 silver brooches: Vespasian - Commodus. "Denarii are dated to the second half of the 1st century – the end of 2nd century AD, dating of the brooches, however, indicates that the hoard was deposited in the second half of the 5th century AD."
IARCH record for a hoard of 14 clipped siliquae YORYM-F6AE88 (2014 T45). All the coins were worn and heavily clipped.
The hoard comprised either 1200 bronze and silver coins of the Tetrarchy or 1500 of the House of Constantine Gratian and Theodosius I found in a copper alloy vessel.

More than 100 bronze coins have been found. 68 were seen: Commodus - Gordian III - minted in Nicopolis ad Istrum 35, Marcianopolis 27, Hadrianopolis 3, Anchialus 2, Serdica. 19 are kept in the museum collection in Lyaskovets.
40 similar coins (1 is described: Constantine I), found together during building work 1963 and kept in private possession.
9 solidi found at the same findspot over a century: Theodosius II - Basiliscus (AD 475-476).
11 prutahs found together while demolishing a wall of a Roman domestic building: Augustus - Nero (AD 59).
242 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver w8: 67.7-626.9 g.
3 late Roman gold coins (Constantine I - Magnentius), found in relative close proximity (20 meters) at the same location from June to August 1935, along the river Niers during drainage work.
140 nummi found with a cooking pot: Gratian - Theodosius I/Arcadius/Honorius (AD 393-395).
64 denarii found in a wall of a glass workshop: Nerva - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

Although only 40 aurei are known, there is evidence that originally there were more, including aurei of the emperors Lucius Verus, Lucilla, Hadrian and Septimius Severus (Mira 1997, 121). Gold w8: 313.1-340.4g.
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueologia, Lisboa, Portugal

summary: 3501 antoniniani: Gordian III - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
50 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus - Claudius II (Divus) (AD 270).
Circa 50 denarii, kept in a belt? 49 documented: Galba – Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II/Diva Faustina II) (AD 161-180).
disposition: National Museum, Prague, (inv.nos. H5-27.066–27.073); Museum of Poděbrady (inv.nos. 15.566–15.574, 15.576–15.577, 15.579–15.591) (inv.nos. 15.575, 15.578 were stolen), Czech Republic. Some of the coins are missing today.

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 500 Roman billon coins (radiates), with the most recent being issues of Diocletian and Maximian.
363 silver coins which were first placed in a bag and then in a ceramic vessel: Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2205

summary: Originally, a hoard of 400-500 denarii, only 40 allowed for examination: Republic - Augustus (15 BC).
1325 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Philip I - Probus (AD 276-282).
Around 800 denarii found with a copper alloy vessel: Vitellius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
Unknown number of denarii found in 2 small ceramic vessels placed 100 m from each other. 38 pieces are known from 1 of the vessels: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 163-164).
disposition: Ruse Regional Museum of History, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1600 44-81

find_spot_name: VILLA DE LA FUENTE DE LAS PULGUINAS
summary: 5 bronze coins found 1 next to the other: as Republic, 3 asses Hadrian, 1 dupondius Antoninus Pius.
39 nummi: Constantine I 30, Licinius I 9 (AD 321-324).
The hoard comprised approximately 250 sestertii dating to the second century AD and weighing between 5 and 6kg.

Various parcels of coins started to appear on the market in late 1996, allegedly from Great Waltham or Great Dunmow. These included groups of worn Gallo-Belgic A staters and quarter staters, along with a significant quantity of British A staters including previously unrecorded varieties. A parcel of 10 staters (consisting of 7 ABC 2430, 2 ABC 2424 and 1 ABC 2427), said to have been found at Great Waltham in August 1998, was declared and reported in TAR 1997-98, 26 no. 110.
9 bronze coins from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius, most likely a part of a larger find.
This hoard was found in a Roman building. It consisted of 7 denarii, ranging from the late Republic to Antoninus Pius. The coins lay stratified in a roll and the find appears to be complete.
15 of the sestertii from a larger hoard were identified by S. Bottin. The hoard was originally located in Bellaing in error.

Although Farnham is neither a particularly substantial nor complex hoard, the fact that coins have been dug up on at least 5 separate occasions over some 150 years has created a rather complicated writ10 record
137 silver coins: 112 antoniniani, 25 denarii: Clodius Albinus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver w8: 176.8-335.2 g.

3 Roman hoards found in St1a. This hoard comprises 37 denarii ranging up to Gordian III and was found with Iron Age coins seen as a separate group (St1a Grange I group I). Part of the group was detected from site prior to excavation.

The hoard comprised 6010 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 as from Severus Alexander to Probus. In 1967, a further 7 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I were recovered from the same findspot and are assumed to be part of the same hoard. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of between 1084.4 or 15626.3g.
13 aurei: Elagabalus - Severus Alexander and silver coins of Gordian III (AD 238-244).

A hoard of mostly FEL TEMP REPARATIO coins of Constantius II, Constans and Gallus, also including a single specimen of Constantine I, believed to have originally contained over 2000 coins of which 606 were examined by the British Museum dating to c. 354.

The hoard comprised a small earthenware vessel containing 100 'small bronzes' (radiates) of which 86 were identified by the finder: Valerian I and Gallienus/ Gallienus (sole) for Gallienus - Tetricus I (Ad 271-274).
The hoard comprised 16 antoniniani (radiates) dated between the reigns of Caracalla and Elagabalus.
Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 44 denarii were recovered: Republic – Augustus (16 BC).
501 silver coins. 496 entered the museum collection in Pazardhzik: 78, 427: Antoninus Pius - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver w8: 644.3-1323.4 g.
disposition: Regional History, Museum, Pazardhzik, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1904-2087

summary: 142 bronze coins (sestertii, antoniniani?): Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260); silver w8: 27.9-59.7g.
43 kg = +8000 silver coins: denarii and antoniniani: Hadrian - Valerian I (AD 258)
Unknown originally number of coins. 412 pieces are documented: Claudius II (Divus) - Valentinian III (AD 430-455).
disposition: Instituto de Antropologia «Dr. Mendes Corrêa» Oporto, Portugal

summary: The hoard comprised 1 gold stater, attributed to the Osismii, and 3 petit billons amoricains.

A hoard of 402 denarii and antoniniani (Antoninus Pius - Trebonianus Gallus) was unearthed on a property in the Mangelhausen district of Wiesbach. The coins were originally contained together with a golden finger ring in an earthenware jug.
Around 100 denarii, 27 were studied: Nero – Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) (AD 161-175).
A dispersed group of barbarous radiates noted by Penhallurick. Possibly a hoard. The identifiable prototypes are of Tetricus I and II.
2 denarii issued by Marcus Aurelius (AD 166-176) were bought from the same local person.
Unnown initial number of coins. 35 silver coins: Marcus Aurelius - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver w8: 45.1-89.5 g.

find_spot_name: JERUSALEM - WESTERN AND SOUTHERN WALLS 1975 B
summary: The hoard comprised 13 bronze coins, deposited during the First Jewish Revolt.

(1982) 1981 antoniniani (radiates) and nummi: Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetrarchy (AD 300-301); silver w8: 267.6-1850.2g. Almost all of the treasure, 1982 pieces, was acquired by the Section history of the Grand-Ducal Institute. Many "duplicate" copies were used for exchange purposes, so that the State Museum's Medal Cabinet, where the Historical Section's medalist is kept, has only 1192 specimens left.
Hoard of 759 bronze coins: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192). Uncertain whether is part of MORSHANSKOYE 1838 hoard (?) or a separate 1.
The hoard comprised 39 sestertii from Vespasian to Julia Domna, 4 denarii from Septimius Severus to Severus Alexander and 7 radiates from Gordian III to Otacilia Severa with a tpq of AD 248 to 249.
12 nummi found in the Roman villa. Unknown whether they were found together: House of Constantine I (AD 341-346).
Hoard of 174 denarii. 53 coins are kept in the National Museum in Budapest, Hungary: Republic – Domitian (AD 81-96).
disposition: National Hungarian Museum, Budapest, Hungary (53 coins)

summary: 147 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269).
Large hoard. Only 25 silver coins are known: 9 denarii, 19 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Philip I (AD 247-249); silver w8: 32.6-59 g.
disposition: Museum of History, Stara Zagora, Bulgaria; inv. no. 3343

summary: 35 republican and imperial denarii: - Tiberius, found while metal detecting on the area of the Dacian citadel
(220) 175 silver coins: Antoninus Pius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235) + silver vessel; silver w8: 309.9-499.3g+
57 denarii: 47 republican, 10 imperial: Republican - Vespasian (AD 77-78).

A hoard of 47 bronzes, found in 1 of the buildings of Area 2 (on the floor of courtyard 6) during the Hatra excavations. Most of them were imitative SC coins (Hatra), with radiate head and eagle types, and some were 'senatorial dupondii' cut in half. It is unclear what is meant with 'senatorial dupondii', but these could be either provincial or imitative coinages.
Partial record of a small group of early Corieltavian staters. No further information.
The hoard comprised 12 gold coins dated between the reigns of Valentinian I (AD 364-375) and Anastasius I (AD 491-518).
5 nummi: Constantine I - Constantius II (AD 341-346). Mints: Treveri 6, Lugdunum 6, unidentified 1

Ceramic vessel containing 610 Roman provincial bronze coins: Commodus - Gordian III (AD 235-238). Minted mostly in Tomis (today, Constanța, Romania). Other mint, identified so far, Deultum; At the bottom of container, iron carpentry tools: penknife, clamping clamp, ax/chisel, wood gripper, bolt.
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie Națională și Arheologie din Constanţa

summary: The hoard comprised 381 radiates from Valerian I and Gallienus to Probus and was found under a complete Roman tile. The coins were acquired by the City Library of Bourg.
(250) 238 nummi: Tetrarchy - Constantine I (AD 312-337) Mints: Treveri 59; Lugdunum 116; Londinium 12 (1 Imitation); Roma 11; Ticinum 24; Aquileia 4; Siscia 4; Carthago 7, 1 uncertain.
disposition: Museum d'Aix-les-Bains, France (187 coins); collection Duc (40 coins); collection Lagier-Bruno (12 coins)

summary: 73 nummi of Constantine I and his sons found in the bath-house complex. A hypothetic tpq of AD 335.
A group of 8 coins (Armenian, Parthian, and Roman), ranging from 62 to 31 BC, was discovered in 1955.
4-5 antoniniani (radiates) of which only 2 coins are known: Gordian III, Trajan Decius (Herennius Etruscus Caesar).
356 silver coins: 294 denarii, 62 antoniniani: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 243-244); silver w8: 490.5-1026.8 g.
disposition: National History Museum of Romania, Bucharest, Romania (348 coins), County Museum Tg. Jiu, Romania (8 coins)

summary: Unknown initial number of denarii. 11 denarii provided information on the issuers: Trajan - Commodus (AD 183-184).
disposition: Zasadniczej Szkoły Zawodowej w Krasniku Fabrycznym, Poland (1 coin)

summary: A hoard of 41339 radiates of which an inventory of 4000 was completed by Salama on 10.3.76: Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
The hoard comprised 'some 500 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) of which only 20 were examined' Found at the ancient port in unknown circumstances.
Few hundred silver coins (?), kept in a wooden box similar to a casket, covered with amber lumps at the top (?). The hoard was probably found in a swampy meadow.
30 provincial bronze coins minted in the 3rd century AD found by metal detecting within the area of an ancient settlement.
Circa 1000 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus to Aurelian; silver w8: c. 271.0-1249.0g.

Unknown originally number of denarii. 199 denarii were examined and identified: Republic - Augustus (2 BC - AD 4). Found somewhere in the Vratsa/Montana/Pleven regions. Seized by the custom authorities at Sofia Airport in November 2000 during an illicit export attempt. Unpublished (Paunov 2021, 31-32).
IARCH record for a hoard of 4 Iron Age gold staters.

There is debate about whether 2-3000 coins were found (Lebarbier-Arnoux) or 5-6000 coins (Bottin). The librarian in Valenciennes, Hécart, saw about 500. An English officer, Drummond Hay, took a large portion of the hoard. Found with a ceramic vessel Severus Alexander - Postumus (AD 260-269).
Unknown originally number of coins. 21 denarii were recovered: 18 republic, 3 Augustus (2 BC - AD 4).
disposition: Institute of Archaeology, Iași, Romania (inv. no. 70 051)

summary: A hoard of at least 202 radiates. The latest coin in the hoard is radiate of Gallienus (sole reign) from Milan mint dating to AD 262. Mint data exists for this hoard but TAF is not specific enough to allocate mints to rulers. Museum Inventory No: 75-7. Silver: 8, 223 coins; Silver w8: 71.8-592.1

De Jersey writes:"On the index card for CCI 79.0098, Melinda Mays refers to a letter of 14 June 1913 from G.F. Hill, in the Red House Museum archives, mentioning the discovery of that coin "in a broken pot not preserved, with a Constantius and 6 SW British type".
