If the association with the Roman coin is correct then this might be better regarded as a Romano-British deposit. It is possible that 1 of the other coins was CCI 79.0225, a struck bronze stater (ABC 2175) found by Mr Pester at Pokesdown Cliffs, Southbourne, in 1912 (Haselgrove 1984, 137), but the precise location of the find is not certain; it is tempting to think that it may have been made at Hengistbury, just 2 kilometres east of Southbourne."
The hoard comprised 13 sestertii from Trajan to Severus Alexander.

The coins are said to have been found (in the 19th c.) by children on the "Hetzheide" approx. 1.5 km northwest from the site. Further particulars do not survive. Doubtful as a hoard, given the large time spam and the composition.
It comprised 3000 antoniniani from Gallienus, Claudius II, Postumus, Victorinus and Tetricus I (AD 271-274). Found with a copper vessel.
The hoard comprised 'more than 500 coins of uncertain denomination and type' but including issues from Vespasian to Commodus (AD 180-192).
Unknown originally number of coins. 40 coins were documented: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).

Preliminary record of a small hoard of Gallo-Belgic E staters found in October 2010. The classifications given on the PAS record vary slightly from the assessment by John Sills which is given in de Jersey.

Arm purse containing 63 coins (3 aurei and 60 denarii), ranging from the late Republic to Hadrian, found while quarrying st1s. Each of the gold coins was wrapped up in a separate piece of greenish leather or vellum, which was still quite tough and strong.
disposition: Clayton Memorial Museum, Chesters (purse). The coins are said to have been given to the Blackgate Museum, Newcastle, but have not been located there

summary: 32 bronze coins: Augustus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
Few hundreds, only 16 (8 imitations) antoniniani (radiates) known Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
The hoard comprised a vessel containing a gold finger ring, a silver bracelet and 28 coins from Marcus Aurelius to Valerian I.
895 denarii and antoniniani
disposition: Possible that 753 coins are in the National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.no. CXXX

summary: The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel or a small square pot and contained more than 100 gold Iron Age coins. The exact total is not known with any certainty. 111 (Godard), 120 (Parenteau), 150 (Martin). The hoard was found by the son of the landowner and a servant in a field on the land of M. Gardais. 1 coin was aquired by the Cabinet des Médailles (BN 6723). The Musée Saint-Jean, Angers acquired 2 staters which were stolen in March 1885 (Reg. II, p. 10, no. 23, December 1860). The Musée départemental d'Archéologie, Nantes acquired 1 stater
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Paris (1 coin, BN 6723); Musée Saint-Jean, Angers (2 staters, stolen in 1885); Musée Départemental d'Archéologie, Nantes (1 stater); M. Gardais

summary: 162 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms: Claudius I - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 252-253). 'Purchased by Currelly and Frost from "native diggers".'

470 coins found with a ceramic urn. 20 coins were spread among locals. The hoard consists of mostly Augustan coins, together with republican and Celtic issues. Although the coins appear in good condition almost all of them were hammered or halved, and countermarked. Found on the same allotment as Quiberon 1985. 1 hoard split into 2 vessels. 32 more coins were discovered while searching the area after the discovery of the Quiberon 1985 hoard.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles (Département des Monnaies, médailles et antiques de la Bibliothèque nationale de France), Paris, France (in 1951)

summary: Hoard of 127 denarii found during archaeological excavations: Republic – Augustus (13 BC).
The hoard comprised 1 as of Domitian and 2 dupondii of Trajan.
Around 40 Roman coins of the 3rd century AD. No further Information.
The hoard comprised an earthenware vessel containing 100 Roman coins including denarii, sestertii and dupondii, nearly all issues of Antoninus Pius, Faustina I and Faustina II.
234 nummi: Diocletian - Constantine I (AD 306-337).
A hoard of 11 solidi (Valentinian I - Constantin III) found Greebenstraße in 1955.
The hoard comprised 185 coins, deposited during the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).

763 coins found with a bronze jug. It comprises mainly nummi of Constantius II and his caesares. The earliest coin is a denarius of Antoninus Pius for Diva Faustina I. The latest coin is a nummus of Julian II (AD 361-363).
10 nummi were found grouped together in soft soil against the east wall of Room 3 in MMS-I, under a mortar floor.
400 denarii: Marcus Aurelius - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211). Dispersed.
disposition: Part of the hoard is kept in an unknown private collection; dispersed.

summary: 3 solidi of the House of Valentinian (AD 364-383).
28 nummi, presumably from the time of Constantine I (AD 306-337).
Hoard of 29 Sasanian drachms of Peroz (AD 459-484) was discovered in Bolnisi while digging the ground.
Unknown originally number of coins. 11 aurei: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 162-163).

Hilltop settlement. The hoard was found during metal detectorists' surveys next to many single finds. It comprised ca. 50-60 antoniniani (ca. Claudius II to Postumus), which were partly melted down and fused into a lump. A few types are visible: PAX AVG, MARTI PACIFER(O) and FELICITAS AVG.
15 coins: 11 antoniniani (10 copies), 4 nummi: Tetricus I - House of Valentinian I (AD 364-383).
Group of 7 coins reported in HER as a hoard, including denarii of Augustus and Tiberius. No further information. The source is given as Devizes Museum Daybook 783.
Hoard of 300 kilos, circa 180000 coins. Only 3647 coins divided into few lots are documented: 1341, 478, 63, 1760 pieces: Hieron II - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
5 silver coins of the 2nd century AD. No further details.

The hoard was found during the demolition of the praefurnium by M. Plessis. It comprised 4625 coins weighing 12kg. Hucher compiled a catalogue of 4518 coins (14 worn bronzes; 4504 radiates and imitations). Imitations account for approximately 44% of the coins in the hoard of which 2.8% were minimi. Silver w8: 1219.4-16076.0 g.
160 denarii, 80 recovered: 41 republican, 39 imperial: Republic - Trajan (AD 102-103).
disposition: National Museum of Union, Alba Iulia, Romania

summary: Aucti1d at Dorotheum in 2003, 68 nummi found near a well: Constans 55, Constantius II 13 (AD 350-351).
21 solidi: Theodosius II - Anastasius (AD 491-518); gold w8: 93.45 g. Found together with 2 gold arm bands.
disposition: National Museum, Stockholm (vanished); Lunds Universitets Historiska Museum (inv.no. 19672 f)

summary: A hoard of 2 Anto9 sestertii and several items of gold jewellery, found in grave 23 in the western cemetery of Pella.
Unknown quantity of bronze coins. 3 sestertii: Claudius I, Nero, Marcus Aurelius were offered to the Regional History Museum in Ruse.
disposition: Ruse Regional Museum of History, Bulgaria

summary: A Roman hoard was found and dispersed, in recent years in Nembro. Some bronze coins of the 3rd century were seen. It is an Antoninianus (radiate) from Salamina (sic!) and dupondii of Claudius II and Aurelian (determination of E. Arslan). Soprin10denza Archeologica della Lombardia (7 coins).
The hoard was found in an amphora and comprised 63 coins of Elagabalus to Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).

The hoard comprised approximately 1000 antoniniani (radiates) of which only 604 coins were catalogued. TAF outlines the numbers of coins by emperor and by mint but the 2 sets of figures do not tally. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of between 116.4g and 1097.6g.
9 coins of unknown denomination were found with a pitcher in a gravel pit: Constantine I - Theodosius I (AD 379-395).
disposition: Münzkabinett des Kunsthistorisches Museum, Wien, Austria (old collection)

summary: Around 1200 aurei (according to Savio/Cavagna): Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192). Reported to have contained thousands of coins. The main part had been dispersed before the rest was confiscated.
Hoard of 89 coins of the Bosporan kings: Sauromates I, Cotys II, Rhoemetalces, Eupator.
Hoard of around 200 silver coins comprising Parthian drachms of Gotarzes II, Vologases III; Roman denarii of Otho, Vespasian, Trajan, Hadrian, Sassanid drachms of Varakhran II (AD 274-291).
29 antoniniani (radiates): Aurelian - Probus (AD 276-282).
Hoard either of 98 or 40 denarii. Some of Augustus, the others of Tiberius (AD 14-37).
The hoard comprised 2118 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Aurelian with a tpq of AD 270 to 275.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg; inv.no. 1991-214/1 - jug; 2:1 - 2120

summary: The hoard comprised 15 copper-alloy coins from Hadrian to Commodus and we found next to a skeleton.
28 Late Roman coins (Constantine I - Constantius II) forming probably a small hoard.
61 denarii: Republic - Augustus (9 BC).
23 denarii, group of single finds, found within a settlement: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 183-184); silver w8: 57.89 g.
A hoard of 371 nummi found in a small jar. The coins run from Constantine I to Valentinian III. 62 of the coins were barbarous and 172 fully illegible.
The hoard comprised 8864 antoniniani (radiates) Valerian I - Carinus (tpq AD 283, Numerian). Silver w8: 1596.1-6470.3 g.
2 clipped solidi - Anastasius, Justin I, found in a grave of Princess Ruru dated in AD 550.

The hoard comprised 500-600 provincial bronze coins of Byblus, Berytus, and Sidon, found while digging for construction st1s, found in a 'cavity' (Höhlung) close to Beirut. Coins range from Macrinus to Severus Alexander, most of which minted in Berytus and Sidon.

A hoard of ca. 150 Roman bronze coins (Trajan - Septimius Severus), found in Winnefeld while planting trees. 133 coins were acquired by the museum in Hannover, 117 of which can still be traced. Several coins are badly preserved and identifications are 10tative.

"A Roman aes of Constantine 1 (AD 307-337)and a follio of Severus 2 (AD 306-7) were found in an electricity trench at the junction of Copley Road and Christchurch Road, with 6 others corroded to powder" YAJ 42 1969 252.

Landron estimated that there were 35642 coins in the hoard, whereas Blomme suggested a total of 57775. Leclercq dates the hoard to the end of the Gallic Wars. Found by 2 agricultural workers while emptying a manure pit on the farm of Mme Revel de Saint-Mart. The hoard was dispersed. The curate of Ledringhem took 200 of the coins. A. Preux of Douai took others and 150 were sold in 1853.
The hoard comprised 114 sestertii: Trajan-Gordian III (98-243 AD).
Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. Circa 200 nummi went to a private collector: Constans - Honorius (AD 395-423).

The hoard comprised 'a lot of bronze and billon coins, of which 83 coins were recovered and give by M. Timbaud to the Musée de Rouen…'it is likely to represent a hoard or a portion of a hoard'; Antoninian dynasty - ; silver w8: 17.6-151.6g.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen, France. Museum Inventory III, p. 61, no. 2157 (donated 17.5.1909)

summary: The hoard comprised a whiteware ceramic jug contained approximately 2000 coins of Postumus.
The hoard (a purse?) comprised 8 coins of Gallienus, Postumus, Victorinus and Quintillus.
1447 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) - Diocletian-Maximianus I (AD 293-294).
17 antoniniani (radiates). According to Boersma 1967, no. 175, they are dated between AD 253-268. No further information.
190 coins: 1 antoninianus (radiate), 189 nummi: Claudius II (Divus) - Theodosius I/Honorius (AD 388-402).
disposition: Museo Arqueolóxico do Castro de Viladonga, Spain

summary: 146 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver w8: 40.4-181.5g.
Hoard of 67 denarii found within the Dacian citadel during archaeological excavations: Republic – Tiberius (AD 14-37).
An unknown original number of coins. 232 antoniniani (radiates) and 56 denarii are known: Vespasian - Postumus (AD 260-269).

The hoard comprised a very large quantity of 'medals of middle bronze'. A hundred were studied in more detail with Antoninus Pius, Faustina (I or II?), Marcus Aurelius, Lucilla, Commodus and Septimius Severus represented.
2 solidi: Julius Nepos, Romulus Augustulus; gold w8: 8.84 g. Found in same field at different times.

8000 Late Bronze Roman coins, bought by the director of excavations at Aphrodisias Kenan Erim. The coins include a Rhodian piece dating to the 2nd century BC and 50 radiates, but the vast majority date to the 4th century AD. At least half of the hoard comprises SALVS REI PVBLICE issues of Valentinian II, Theodosius I and Arcadius.

A hoard of 144 coins (1 aureus, 134 denarii and 9 quinarii, Republic - Vespasian) was discovered in 1913 during excavations of the historical museum of Pfalz, in the Rheingönheim Roman fort. The denarii were found in 2 rolls, with the aureus between the rolls.

2 small parcels of coins have been found in this location near Pocklington. In September 2006, 2 staters in the ploughsoil, 1 each of the domino and kite types. In the following year (August 2007), 3 more staters - 1 South Ferriby type, 1 kite type and 1 DVMNOCOVEROS - and an AVN COST silver unit. The 2006 coins were found at the same time as a parcel of Roman coins (2006 T148), although it is not believed to be related. There may however be a link to groups of Iron Age coins found in a neighbouring field, recorded as Driffield (hoard 2955, de Jersey 293). (de Jersey).
Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 151 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver w8: 41.7-187.8 g.
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (inv.no. 327, 2 coins)

summary: 12 antoniniani: 1 Philip, 11 Claudius II (AD 268-270); silver w8: 4.2-14 g.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Pazardzik, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 969-980

summary: 1020 coins; 9 aurei Vespasian to Plautilla. Gold: 9 coins; Gold w8: 64.0-64.7g; Silver: 1011 coins; Silver w8: 1851.2-2920.7g
24 coins: 1 antoninianus (radiate), 22 sestertii and 1 dupondius. The latest coin is a sestertius of Trajan Decius for Herennia Etruscilla (Augusta) (AD 249-251).
20-1 coins were recovered, all from the topsoil, during a controlled search of an area of about half a hectare.
4 solidi: Theodosius II - Majorian (AD 457-461); gold w8: 17.8 g. Found at different times on the same field.
An Antoninianus of Gordian III, discovered along with 10 other similar coins in 1909 during the construction of the Baumgar10bridge over the Havel-Schielow lake.
907 aurei, but only 857 have been identified. They were found by accident. There were also 10 'restored' coins of Trajan. Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-207)

Originally were 500 coins found with a ceramic vessel. 120 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Clodius Albinus to Valerian I and Gallienus. Until AD 253, Mints represented: Rome, except 2 from Laodicea for Septimius Severus and Geta; 2 from Antioch for Elagabalus and Philip I; 2 from Viminiacum for Treboninanus Gallus and 2 from Milan for 'les divi'; after AD 253: 1 Rome, 9 Cologne, 1 Viminiacum, 1 Milan, 1 2nd eastern Mint and 1 uncertain. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of 698.4-1425.8g
Hallaton: 14 hoards were located in and around the entrance way. Hoard 07 comprises 137 Iron Age coins and 1 Roman denarius.
Hoard of 1000 denarii of the Anto9s and 6 aurei of Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius and Faustina II.
49 silver coins found with ceramic vessel: 36 denarii, 13 quinarii: Republic - Augustus (2 BC - AD 4).
(c. 1500) 64 antoniniani (radiates): 8 genuine, 56 copies: Valerian I (Salonina) - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver w8: c. 390.0 g.
Hoard of 1000 coins, only 20 nummi survived: Constantine I 1, Crispus 19.
297 nummi with a tpq around AD 375
The hoard comprised 60 silver Iron Age coins within a hollowed out st1. Found during road construction. The Musée de Rouen acquired 16 coins from this hoard.
Unknown originally number of nummi. 192 were documented: Constantine I - Gratian (AD 383). Found together with a bronze statuette of Victory.
disposition: Museo Arqueológico de Asturias, Oviedo, Spain

summary: A man uncovered the coins on the south side of the hospital vineyard located in front of Heidenkopf during demolition works. 12 Roman coins were found during the digging-up of the wreckage. These are labelled as 'Kollektivfund?' in FMRD.
5056 silver coins found in 1 or more ceramic vessels: 17 denarii, 5039 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus (Geta) - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver w8: 966.5g.
The hoard comprised about 4000 coins of Gallienus, Salonina, Postumus, Marius, Victorinus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II, Claudius II, Aurelian and Probus in a vessel. There may be 2 hoards.
9 solidi (Valentinian I - Valentinian II) and 1 cen10ionalis (AE 3) of Jovian, found in the garden of the school and a neighbouring property in Eidinghausen-Hahnenkamp.

In 1749 an earthenware vessel with 70 denarii (Republic to Septimius Severus) was unearthed in a garden next to the Buxheim monastery. In 1833 2 specimens from the find were donated to the hall of antiquities in Augsburg, of which 1 is now lost. A list of emperors is given in 1760.
13 denarii from a discovery in the surroundings of the city: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-178).
85 nummi dispersed by excavator: Constans - Eugenius (AD 392-394).

During the excavation of a monumental temple site, numerous votive offerings and coins were discovered. The total number of coins varies according to publication but was between 359 and 385 Iron Age coins and between 17 and 19 Roman coins. The Roman coins were not examined in any detail in the publication but appear to have been Roman Republican and Imperial denarii. The latest coin was an issue of Nerva.

Unknown initial number of silver coins. According to some information from a private collector the number of coins was between 2500 and 3000. 26 coins entered museum collection in Sofia: Otho - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. 32865

summary: Around 40 aureii. The hoard comprised 17 coins of which 11 were sold to MM. Loir et Colin. These were recorded in detail. The hoard was discovered by peat cutters.
While ploughing, a ceramic vessel with 13 antoniniani of Aurelian was found.
The hoard comprised a clay lamp with 139 bronze coins dated between AD 42 and AD 59.
A hoard of more than 2000 coins of which only 47 were seen: Vespasian - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).

On the site of the Romano-British settlement at Camerton, near Bath, a small hoard of barbarous radiates, mostly minimi, was found just outside the wall of a small Roman building. It would appear to have been deposited there after the construction of the wall, which was not earlier than mid-third century. With the exception of the piece of larger module, and some scraps of the more usual imitations, the coins of the hoard are radiate minimi of average diameter of 8 mm.
The hoard comprised 6 aurei and silver jewelry. 2 of the aurei are mounted in gold frames. The coins are: Antoninus Pius, Caracalla, Julia Domna, Macrinus and 2 of Severus Alexander (AD 234).
disposition: Musée national des Antiquités et Arts musulmans, Alger, (ex Musée Stéphane Gsell), Algeria; inv.nos. 1045 - 1053

summary: The hoard comprised 15 gold coins dated between AD 350-355 and AD 527-565.
102 coins: 5 antoniniani, 23 sestertii, 74 bronze (sestertii?): Domitian - Gallienus/Postumus (AD 260-268); silver w8: 4.0-12.1 g.
disposition: Musées royaux des Beaux-Arts de Belgique, Bruxelles, Belgium (102 coins)

summary: The hoard was found in Burial 63 and comprised 20 coins of the 4th century AD.

Around 5000 antoniniani (radiates), 13.5 kg. The majority of coins belonged to Tetricus I and Tetricus II. Other issuers: Gallienus, Salonina, Victorinus, Postumus, Marius, Cludius II, Quintillus, Quintillus (Divus Cludius II), Aurelian.
48 denarii: Republic - Vespasian (AD 74) found in the vicus near the fort of Fectio.
disposition: Rijksdienst voor het Oudheidkundig Bodemonderzoek Kerkstraat 1, 3811 CV Amersfoort, Netherlands

summary: Before 1889, 8 coins were found in a garden in Campbon. These included 1 radiate of Tacitus and 2 of Probus. They may represent a portion of a larger hoard.
The hoard comprised 1 denarii and 25 antoniniani (radiates) from Elagabalus to Victorinus. The coins were stuck together with corrosion products.
2 sestertii, 1 dupondius, and 1 as (Vespasian and Titus Caesar) found in an unstratified context during excavations at Usk East.
The hoard comprised 1 tetradrachm and 22 bronze coins of Tyre, deposited after 74 BC.
2 aurei of Constantine I minted in Treveri (AD 310-313).
A hoard of 1005 Alexandrian tetradrachms (Tiberius to Nero), found during excavations in 1967 in Karanis, though no details about the exact findspot are known.
258 nummi: Valentinian II - Zeno (AD 474-491). Found in the basilica.
A hoard of an unknown originally number of coins found by metal detecting. 44 coins were recovered: Republic - Trajan (AD 102).
disposition: National Museum of Union, Alba Iulia, Romania

summary: 1120 silver coins: 711 denarii, 409 antoniniani: Hadrian - Valerian I (AD 254-255); silver w8: 1401.3-2899.5 g.
disposition: County Museum Râmnicu Vâlcea, Romania (779 coins); County Museum Giurgiu, Romania (344 coins); Silviu Istrate Puerece Collection, Sibiu, Romania (4 coins)

summary: 9 asses of Augustus (AD 9-14).
Probably, 2 solidi of Valentinian III (AD 425-430).
About 100 antoniniani up to the 3rd century AD.
A hoard of more than 14 solidi dating from Constantius II to Theodosius I (Arcadius I) (AD 383-388).
Hoard of a dozen or more kilos of silver coins. Only 15 denarii are known: Hadrian - Septimius Severus/Caracalla (Julia Domna) (AD 193-217).
918 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel: 916 denarii, 1 drachm, 1mitation denarius: Nero – Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
50 gold coins: 1 aureus, 1 multiple 1 1/4 solidus 48 solidii: Maximian I - Constantius II (AD 337-343); gold w8: 225.62g; silver: 9 ingots; silver w8: c. 2647.24g
disposition: Schatzkammer und Zentralarchiv des Deutschen Ordens, Vienna

summary: 583 antoniniani (radiates). The precise location is unknown. Based on the high frequency of coins minted in Antioch has been considered a site near this city. Coins: Elagabalus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
The hoard of 17 aurei of Augustus was found during repairs to the paving of rue Saint-Esprit (actually rue Gondinet).
4 late antique bronze coins found in excavations of the Propsteikirche St. Mariä Himmelfahrt in Jülich. They derive from a destruction layer located beneath a furnace.
357 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 denarius, ranging from Caracalla to Aemilian (AD 253); silver w8: 448.5-804.5 g.
disposition: Archives de la Commission d'assistance publique (358 coins); private collection (3 coins); Musée communal de Bruxelles"

summary: The hoard comprised a greyware vessel sealed with a wooden plug, containing approximately 820 Roman silver and billon coins, of which 811 were identified. They range from a denarius of Antoninus Pius to a radiate of Probus. They were accompanied by 2 silver finger rings in a textile wrapping.
The coins were found as a heap on the west side of the gallery, behind the apse, just above the floor.

In the SW barrack of Chesterholm, in 1937, 6 (?) AE3 coins were found, stuck together. The top 1 being a VICTORIAEDDAVGGQNN of c. AD 340-348, the lowest an VRBS ROMA of c. 330-335, the others all of similar mid 4th century date.
The hoard comprised approximately 422 sestertii and 4 antoniniani (radiates) from Vespasian to Trebonianus Gallus with a tpq of AD 253. An anonymous catalogue gives details of 409 coins.
300 denarii. Only 32 recorded: Republican - Tiberius (AD 14-37).
disposition: Museu da Região Flaviense, Chaves, Portugal (11 coins)

summary: Depression F2409. Contained 12 re-deposited (curated?) Palaeolithic flint handaxes in gravel at bottom of feature, also 3 3rd C. coins. Then an octagonal st1 font inserted. After font fell out of use, depression filled with series of black upper fills, poss. derived from midden material, containing large quantities of animal b1, oyster shell & pottery; but also objects incl. a silver pin, a copper alloy enamelled fitting, decorative strips & frags. of finger & ear rings & bracelets (some chopped up), pins, copper beads, door fittings, and an iron latch lifter, hand saw, auger & trowel, an iron wool carding comb, a st1 cult figure, & 32 4th C. coins
The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 189 silver and copper-alloy coins - denarii and antoniniani (radiates) - from Antoninus Pius to Gallienus.
5 or 6 silver denarii. The coins were originally corroded together. 3 coins were separated, leaving a stack of either 2 or 3 denarii.
14 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: 9 republican, 5 imperial: Republic - Domitian (AD 81-96).
disposition: National Museum Bucharest, Numismatic Department (inv.no 1165); Coin Room of the Romanian Academy, Bucharest,

summary: The coins listed here are those reported and declared Treasure at various inquests in the late 1970s and early 1980s. The findspot became public and coins were being regularly found at the site. Their findspot was no longer reported accurately and so the coins should probably be considered together (with caution) as a scattered hoard. It is possible that some of these coins are addenda to hoards 496 and 2634. These 2 hoards do appear to have been spatially separate, found above and below the Crags respectively, but it has been suggested that a hoard may have been disturbed and spilled over the Crags.
Some coins, unknown denomination, of Nerva, Trajan and Marcus Aurelius
The hoard comprised 224 coins from Nerva to Aurelian. This included 28 sestertii from Nerva to Septimius Severus, 1 worn dupondius or as and 95 radiates from Gordian III to Victorinus and Aurelian.
1000 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms 'Acquired by Dattari, who sold it to Milne.'
disposition: Partly in Oxford, partly in Toronto. Detailed list in Oxford

summary: 826 coins found with a ceramic vessel. 763 denarii were: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 167). The hoard was entirely recovered but not published accurate.

A hoard containing 3 silver finger rings, 4 silver spoons, 2 solidus of Eugenius, 206 siliquae and 1 half–siliqua of emperors from Constantius II to Honorius, discovered on a ploughed field at Burgate, Suffolk, between 1991 and 2006. A least 27 of the siliquae were clipped. Since the publication in CHRB X, 18 additional siliquae have been reported from this hoard, see TAR reports. A further 20 siliquae and 1 solidus were found in 1997 and are included in the PAS dataset.
disposition: Ipswich Museum (part); Diss Museum (part); British Museum (part)

summary: 18 denarii: 5 Iberian, 9 republican, 4 of Augustus found together in a taberna: Iberian - Augustus (2 BC - AD 4).
disposition: Museu d’Arqueologia de Catalunya, Barcelona, Spain

summary: 89 denarii found with a jug: 1 Celto-Iberic, 68 republican, 20 imperial of Augustus (11-10 BC).
disposition: Museu d'Arqueologia de Catalunya, Barcelona, Spain

summary: 51 denarii: 43 republican, 8 imperial: Republic - Augustus (2 BC - AD 4). Found in a vessel.
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie Națională și Arheologie, Constanța, Romania

summary: Originally were 447 coins. Only 168 pieces survived: Valerian I - House of Constantine I for Constantine I (Divus) (AD 337-340).
2 solidi of Honorius, 1 semis of Arcadius found with other artefacts: several necklace beads; a small gold ingot; 2 notches; 4 silver spoons and other small copper objects.
disposition: Museo Arqueológico y de Historia de Elche, Alicante, Spain

summary: 272 denarii: Tiberius - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver w8: 813.04 g
disposition: Complexul Muzeal "Iulian Antonescu", Bacău, Romania; inv.nos. 7008-7236

summary: The hoard comprised 8 dupondii from Titus to Gordian III.
13 coins examined of 14 originally: Theodosius I - Honorius/Constantine III; gold w8: 51.95g. Together was found a gold ring.
disposition: Museo Arqueológico de Asturias, Oviedo; Museo Arqueológico Nacional, Madrid, Spain

summary: 92 bronze coins: 1 as, 91 nummi (6 imitations): Nero - House of Theodosius (AD 388-402).
Unknown quantity of coins. 3693 antoniniani entered the museum collection in Plovdiv. No further information.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2644; 3,693 coins

summary: 23 British Iron Age silver and debased silver coins found on farmland near Donhead St Andrew in Wiltshire in 2012. The coins were scattered over a small area within the plough-soil. During the same period, the finder uncovered a separate concentration of 3 Iron Age coins, around 65m from the first. The second group comprised 1 gold coin and 2 silver or debased silver coins. What were apparently 2 separate deposits could not be separated and have therefore been treated together by the PAS.

The hoard was discovered by workmen and comprised gold and silver coins, jewellery and silverware. Many of the coins and medallions were stolen shortly after the discovery of the hoard (Bastien and Metzger 1977, 9). The catalogue was constructed using material from private collections and archives, a catalogue created by R. Ratto in 1923, photographic plates taken by E. Bourgey, publications of A. Baldwin, numerous scholarly articles and sales catalogues. Of a total of approximately 700 specimens, 472 coins have been catalogued. The silver vase in which the coins were found is missing 'On discovery, the find was placed in a bucket and much of it was stolen by the workmen in the course of the following night. As the result of a legal action, the workmen gave back a number of coins and jewels, but retained the greater part, in particular, the gold multiples which they sold in Belgium…they spread the rumour that some gold medallions had been melted down and destroyed' (Bastien and Metzger 1977, 214)
572 silver coins: 2 denarii, 570 antoniniani: Macrinus - Valerian I (AD 253 -259); Silver w8: 1143.8-2361.7g

A hoard of 180+ AE provincial coins of Thrace (1), Macedonia (2) and Asia Minor (177, mostly Pamphylia (64), Pisidia (50) and Western Cilicia (10)), dating from the first century AD to the reign of Aurelian.
The hoard comprised 5 Roman Provincial coins: Thessalonica (1 Septimius Severus, 1 Julia Domna, 1 Elagabalus, 1 pseudo-autonomous), Edessa (1 Gordian III), found in a grave.
HER record of a first century hoard found on Sheringham Beach along with remains of a ceramic container, exposed through cliff erosion. Only 5 coins were examined but the hoard was much larger.
50 Iron Age staters, found close to where a second, larger hoard of 206 staters was found.
51 coins: 50 sestertii and 1 as with 2 fibulae found in a looted Roman building
Hoard of 37 coins: 6 republican denarii, 1 imperial denarius, 25 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 4 asses: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 157-161).
The hoard was found in April 1841, in an ceramic vessel under a st1. It comprised 140 sestertii, dupondii and 1 as, all from the anto9 dynasty.
The hoard comprised a vessel filled with 76 antoniniani (radiates) from Balbinus to Postumus (AD 260-269).
The hoard comprised 2 solidi of Constantine I and Magnentius, found at the St-Luzisteig pass, ca. 1863.

De Jersey (2015) writes: "Iron Age gold coins - principally Gallo-Belgic E staters - have been recorded from the cliff and/or beach between Weybourne and Sheringham for 1 hundred and 50 years or more, and consequently the reconstruction of exactly what has been found is complicated." He gives a detailed discussion of discoveries from 1847 onwards in the area and the difficulties in assessing whether the various finds come from 1 or more deposits. The PAS listing is taken from his summary. The finds also include a fragment of a tubular torc.
Over 2897 antoniniani (radiates): Treboninaus Gallus - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
disposition: Landesmuseum Joanneum, Graz, Austria (for restoration work - in 1977)

summary: Probably, over 1000-1500 silver coins because of the container: a bucket. Only 45 are recovered: Nero - Severus Alexander (AD 231-235). The latest coins is a plated ”barbarous” imitation of a Commodus denarius. Most of the coins were sold in batches of 100 pieces each, at the fair in the nearby commune of Puiești. According to the authors, this hoard is the very same with the 1s of Tutova, Cetățuia and Băcești. (see Munteanu, L. and Popușoi, E., The Roman coin hoard from Iezer, p. 3)
disposition: Museum “Vasile Pârvan”, Bârlad, Romania (inv. nos. VPMB B/317-368)

summary: The hoard comprised 2 black ceramic vessels containing approximately 20000 coins from Gallienus to Carinus (AD 283-285).
Unknown originally number of coins. 6 denarii of Marcus Aurelius were seen.

70 Roman coins and 3 silver Gaulish coins (possibly a separate hoard?) are said to have been found, in pits and wells, along with many artefacts, but there is no contextual information. From the lists given (see Robertson for details), it might be possible to extract the traces of a hoard of AE coins (possibly with some denarii) to Severus Alexander, partly mixed with a hoard of antoniniani to the Tetrici. There is actually no mention of a pot, so that it is not really certain that it was a hoard, according to Roberston.

The hoard comprised 6 Iron Age coins. It was characterised as being 1 of 16 individual votive deposits found at the site of an important Gallo-Roman sanctuary during excavations. Inventory 76.748 to 76.753

The hoard comprised 'a black coarseware vessel containing 32 electrum staters and some Republican and imperial coins in quite a good state of preservation.' The hoard was found by quarry workers in a quarry

A small hoard of 9 antoniniani: Gordian III to Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253) was discovered by a treasure hunter in early September 2022 possibly near the town of Bar in the Vinnitsa region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity September 16, 2022. The conditions of discovery of the hoard are unknown. At the end of September 2022, 5 of the 9 coins were sold at a Violity auction. The further fate of the other coins is unknown.
52 nummi found in a grave: Maximian I - Constantin I (AD 317).
23 coins found near a wall of domestic building: Glaudius II (Divus) - House of Theodosius I (AD 383-395).
7 nummi: 5 Constantine I, 2 Licinius I (AD 317-318).

A hoard of ca. 850 Alexandrian tetradrachms (Nero to Antoninus Pius) found at Amheida (Dakhla/Dakhleh oasis) in area 4, divided in 3 textile bags, on top of a mudbrick debris layer filling pit F90, immedialely adjacent to the temple of Thoth.

Hoard of 32 silver coins: 9 imitations of Thasian tetradrachm, 30 republican denarii, 1 imperial: L. Thorius Balbus - Augustus (AD 19-4 BC). '1 of the Thasian barbarous imitations has the head of Roma l. and letter X behind the goddess, clearly copied from an obverse of 2nd c. BC’ RRD; another bears a punch-mark –anchor, the emblem of Apollonia Pontica. Apparently, all the coins are worn, but the imitations are almost uncirculated.' (Paunov)
The hoard comprised a silver patera on which were placed 23 denarii or antoniniani (radiates)(?) of Gordian III (AD 238-244).
Con10ts of a little purse. 7 denarii: Nero - Trajan.
27 antoniniani: Elagabalus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
Group of 3 Roman coins: Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) 1 denarius, 1 sestertius, Marcus Aurelius (Diva Faustina II) dupondius (AD 161-180).

Around 400 denarii found during archaeological excavations. Only 25 denarii provide information on issuers: Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-192). Together with the coins was also a silver bar of 155g and, possible, a brooch.
disposition: Friends of Science Society, Poznań, Poland (25 coins)

summary: An urn of antoniniani (radiates) found between Sizzano and Fara. Only 2 coins are known of Philip I and Claudius II, as being donated to the museum in Fara.
disposition: Museo dal Sig. Luigi Spagnolini di Fara (on the May 10, 1886; donation record no. 723 (3)

summary: At least 9 parcels of coins have been recovered on this site, apparently originating from a single hoard. de Jersey includes coins from trade which are more or less reliably said to be from the Driffield hoard, but are not included in Treasure cases.
11 denarii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2206

summary: Few kilograms of silver coins found within the ruins of an ancient settlement. 15 silver coins were seen: Antoninus Pius - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
29 coins of unknown metal from "the 4th consulate of Vespasian to the 4th year of reign of Antoninus Pius " (AD 149.
20 coins, antoniniani (radiates) and nummi: Gallienus - Theodoius I (AD 379-383).
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 40 electrum staters. 32 staters were purchased by the Col1l Allotte de la Fuÿe, 1 by Blanchet and some by 'an amateur in Paris'!
A scattered hoard of Chute staters, found in the same field as the Chute I (1927) find.

Coin Hoards records 39 denarii, ranging from Nero to Nerva. However, Carradice 'Coinage and Finances in the reign of Domitian AD 81-96', p. 173, no. 1 adds notice of 3 more coins, without further information.
A hoard of 30 denarii (Republic - Augustus), found in 1902 during forestry work on the Sürser Berg, south of Gehrden.
5 kilos (c. 3000 coins): Constantine I - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-408).
The hoard is incomplete, but the coins documented was 3481 republican and imperial denarii. Hoard dated in 27 BC. Originally, there were 5000 denarii and 9 silver balls found with ceramic vessel.
Hoard found with an amphora: 2 aurei, 2804 denarii, 2 bronzes: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166). Together was found a ceramic lamp.
disposition: Private collections: A. Ancona,F. Gnecchi (365 coins), M. Anti (1,080 coins) (in 1887)

summary: 376 silver coins from Elagabalus to Gordian III (AD 238-244). Found in a cooking pot together with silver brooches, bracelets, fingerings, chain.
disposition: Brukenthal Museum, Sibiu, Romania; mixed with the rest of museum collection; National History Museum of Romania, Bucharest; jewelry.

summary: 3 provincial coins (Edessa, Thessalonica) found in a grave in Europos (Kilkis).
The hoard comprised 13 sestertii from Trajan to Commodus.
123 sestertii, ranging from Caracalla to Valerian I.
(c. 1550) 1512 coins: 1022 antoniniani (radiates), 490 nummi: Valerian I - Tetrarchy (AD 306).
disposition: Collection Müller, 31 coins. The rest of hoard is lost.

summary: 5 antoniniani without any certainty that they were part of a hoard: Gallienus - Quintillus (AD 270).
The hoard was found under a st1 and comprised a hundred silver Celtic coins and at least 5 Republican denarii.
39 aurei, of which 38 were documented (Augustus–Trajan), found underwater, 100 m from the shoreline.
(+hundreds) 94 denarii and antoniniani: Caracalla - Valerian I (AD 253-259); silver w8: 118.9-243.0 g
The hoard was hidden amongst a pile of Roman tiles and comprised more than 2000 sestertii. TAF suggests that the large bronze of Gallienus should in fact be identified as a medallion.
2191 silver coins found with an urn: 2147 denarii, 44 antoniniani (radiates): Mark Antony ´- Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238); silver w8: 3112.7-7821.9g.
disposition: Salzburg Museum Carolino Augusteum (41 coins); Münzkabinett, Kunsthistorisches Museum, Wien, Austria (10 coins)

summary: Hoard of denarii and antoniniani (radiates), 7206 coins: Septimius Severus - Postumus (AD 260-269). The largest number of coins belonging to Gordian III
10 bronze coins of Cunobelin found scattered at the base of rectangular pit D9, sealed below a deposit of puddled clay, in region 4 of the Sheepen site (Hawkes and Hull 1947, 101, 140).

The hoard comprised 70 gold coins: Tiberius - Claudius I (AD 50-54). Blanchet compiled a catalogue of 64 examples including 54 quinarii of Tiberius, 4 aurei of Caligula and 4 aurei of Claudius. However, in 1933, Labouret published a completely different catalogue for 70 aurei including 59 of Tiberius (Cohen 15 = RIC 3), 6 Caligula (2 RIC 10, 2 RIC 11, 1 RIC 16, 1 RIC 20), 5 Claudius (RIC 30, RIC 41, 2 RIC 80, RIC 92). It is difficult to know how to account for this discrepancy unless the hoard was larger than the original report suggested.
5 coins found in a cist?: 4 Republican denarii; 1 as Tiberius. The imitation of a Postumus' denarius is, most likely, an intruder.

Coins discovered during the excavations appeared to include 2 hoards, 1 of 7 nummi (Gatcombe I), the other of 9 nummi (Gatcombe II), found as quite distinct deposits trampled into a single occupation layer on the floor of building 3. Hoard II ends with coins of Magnentius and Decentius, rev. VICTORIAE DD NN AVG ET CAE(S).
The hoard comprised 112 sestertii: Trajan-Septimius Severus (98-196 AD).

The hoard comprised 44 nummi (378-383) of Valentinian I, Gratian and Theodosius I of the type REPARATIO REIPVB (Emperor raising kneeling turreted woman and holding victory on globe), found in Gortyn, at the Megali Porta bath complex. The mints were occidental and from the Balkans (no details given). This hoard seems to be linked to an inscription (IG IV, 285, dated AD 381) mentioning the distribution of gold and silver coins in Crete.
3 coins: Vitellius sestertius, Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) denarius, Philip I antoninianus (radiate) (AD 244-245).
78 sestertii including 2 imitations, Vespasian to Commodus with 1 Severus Alexander

Hoard found during railway construction work, in a copper-alloy vessel (not preserved). Mainly Tetricus or Tetricus imitations (N. Dürr, Beobachtungen zur römischen Münzprägung. JbHMB 1953, p. 34, mentions Bonosus - this is wrong!). More than 5000 coins. 5% of these were coins of Claudius II (mainly Consecration issues, mostly of barbaric fabric).
2 Iron Age coins found at Pickering, Yorkshire, in 1853. 1 of them is in the BM.
The hoard comprised 19 coins dated between AD 351-361 and AD 378-383.
4 nummi packed found on the Nadasdny meadow: 1 Valentinian I/Valens, uncertain 3.
95 sestertii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 195).
43 silver coins: Vitellius - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver w8: 61.6-125.1 g.

The hoard comprised a double deposit within a single room of a building. In 1 corner of the room, there were 4 coins, including 1 of Marcus Aurelius, 1 of Lucilla and 2 of Commodus. In the opposite corner, there was an identical deposit.

A hoard of at least 125 Roman imperial denarii: Hadrian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211) was found by 2 treasure hunters in early April 2020 in Lviv region. Information about the hoard and photos of the 105 coins were published by user Sergej Ovsijchuk (Сергій Овсійчук) in 1 of the groups on Facebook, dedicated to treasure hunting on April 3, 2020. In the comments to his post he informed that the hoard was found in a field (in a pasture), at a depth of between 30 and 70 cm in clay soil. No pottery fragments were found. Additional photos to the post show that the finders made a probing (about 2x1m) at the site, up to 1m deep. Some of the coins had bronze oxides. The photos of the coins published in the post are of rather poor quality, besides many coins had contaminations, so only a part of the deposit coins is defined. The hoard was divided into 2 parts: most of the hoard (105 coins) belonged to the author of the post, the other part (at least 20 coins) belonged to the second treasure hunter. The further fate of the hoard is unknown coins.
4 solidi: 1 Honorius under Theodoius I, 3 Theodosius II (AD 441-450); gold w8: 17.8g.

Hoard 8 was found on 18 Nov. 1932 and hoard 9 on 22 Jan. 1933. Both were under the floor of the same room, just west of the South-West Tower of the Citadel and certainly part of the same deposit. it comprised 2821 coins and 11 illegible 1s, including 1 AE of Seleucus III, 1 tetradrachm of Philip Philadelphus, 2 denarii (Severus Alexander) and 2817 provincial bronze coins from a large variety of mints (Domitian - Decius).
539 antoniniani (radiates), ranging from the sole reign of Gallienus to Aurelianus, incl. Vabalathus. Hoard hidden in the debris of an earthquake dating from AD 241, covering the stadium building.
188 silver and bronze coins: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
56 coins found in a ceramic vessel: 21 silver coins, 35 provincial bronzes: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2070

summary: The hoard comprised 46 tetradrachms dated between AD 60/1 and AD 118.
497 bronze coins: 496 sestertii, 1 provincial coin: Vespasian - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
disposition: Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Venezia (252 coins)

summary: 1551 coins, 7 antoniniani (radiates), 1544 nummi: 3rd century AD - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueologia, Lisboa, Portugal

summary: 14 nummi found together: Constans - Theodosius II (AD 402-408).
30 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. 17

summary: A an aureus of Commodus and an imitation were acquired by Nagpur Museum.
The hoard comprised about 200 silver coins from Antoninus Pius or Marcus Aurelius to Gallienus.
320 nummi found in the Baths of the Months. 283 coins issued for Maxentius (AD 312).
A hoard of more than 36 sestertii (Domitian - Julia Domna) found around 1860 on the promontory between the Krummen and Neuedorfer lake ('Scheersberg').
85 nummi closing with issues of Valentinian III (AD 425-455).
131 silver coins: 19 antoniniani, 112 denarii found with an urn: Antoninus - Gordian III (AD 242-244). Some scholars also mention gold coins.
disposition: Münzkabinett Kunsthistorisches Museum, Wien (6 coins); Landemuseum Joanneum, Graz (72 coins); Institut für Alte Geschichte, Universität Graz

summary: 6 denarii: Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina II (AD 161-180)

The coins were found in a destruction layer, scattered on the floor of a room alongside agricultural implements. It comprised 17 sestertii and 5 asses and 1 nummus, dating from Republic through to a nummus of Constantius II for Julian II (Caesar).
11 silver coins: Nerva – Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268). At the same place as ČESKA SKALICE 1884
disposition: Museum of Náchod, Czech Republic (inv.nos. N 4007/1-11)

summary: 18 nummi: Tetrarchy I (AD 304-305).
2 aurei, Domitian (Caesar), Marcus Aurelius (Caesar) found in sequential years, in the same forest. Close chronological range.
The hoard comprised 273 sestertii from Vespasian to Trebonianus Gallus.
298 provincial bronze coins found within the ruins of an ancient settlement: Commodus - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria, inv.no. 3634 (262 coins - 218 were stolen)

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 50 silver coins (almost certainly radiates) from Gordian III to Gallienus.
Unknown originally number of coins. 18 denarii are kept at the Institute of Archaeology ”A.D. Xenopol” Iași, Romania: Vespasian – Hadrian (AD 134-138).
disposition: Institute of Archaeology ”A.D. Xenopol” Iași, Romania (inv.nos. 2042-2059).

summary: 52 aurei ranging from Nero (AD 63/66) to Marcus Aurelius (AD 164), found at the Stephansgasse, in the foundations of a st1 building. This hoard could be connected with the Marcomannic wars.
62 coins found with a vessel and traces of textile material. Only 29 pieces are now recorded: Elagabalus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 260-268).

56 bronzes of Postumus. Only 26 were considered worth preserving. The coins were acquired by the musée de Douai under inventory no. 6271. The dating in AD 270-271 is based on the abbreviation PIAV (vonius), nomen of Victorinus, on 1 of the coins.

8 coins: 7 aurei: Nero - Vespasian (AD 74). Found together with a Celtic coin. No further information on this coin. The site is located near Nijmegen, on the other side of the Rhine. The coins were found at a depth of 1 and a half meters in the infill of a residual channel (stream gully) near Lent.
The hoard was found in a vessel containing coins of the Principate, including 2 coins of Antoninus Pius and Marcus Aurelius.

Found during excavations, in "Brandschicht" in a room in the western part of Insula 30. 4 coins, 2 antoniniani (Philip I and Volusian) and 2 missing, found together with fragments of a bronze vessel (lost).
17 gold coins, all of Honorius: 13 solidi, 4 tremisses (AD 422-423). Gold w8: 63.85g.
The hoard comprised 110 denarii: Vespasian-Severus Alexander (AD 222-235 AD).

In 1945 on the south side of the Drusbach, case fittings, bronze fibula, a bronze arm ring, glasses, a vine knife, cast circles, cutlet knives, a Dächsel, and 44 bronze coins (Constantine I - Magnentius) came to light. It is thought that these all belonged to a cooper and the hoard was probably buried around 353.
The hoard comprised approximately 100 aurei from Nero to Hadrian. Only 7 were examined: Nero, Vespasian, Trajan 2, Hadrian 3.
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Oviedo, Spain (7 coins)

summary: During the excavation of the signal station at Carr Naze, Filey, 2 hoards of small brass coins were found, 1 of 110 coins, the other of 22 coins, ranging from Carausius to Arcadius and Honorius. This is hoard B, comprising 22 nummi up to AD 395.
6 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III 1, Philip I 4, Valerian I 1 (AD 258-259). Found with jewelry.
disposition: Museo Nazionale Romano, Medagliere, Rome (inv.nos. 516410-516415 coins; 517911-517915)

summary: Originally 312 denarii, 299 preserved: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver w8: 758.24 g. (299 coins).

A number of coin finds were made during controlled archaeological excavation by Wessex Archaeology at the RLE sites Springhead Roman Town (RLE Event Code ARC SPH00) and Springhead Nursery (ARC SHN02) as part of the programme of archaeological works undertaken in advance of the construction of the Channel Tunnel Rail Link (now known as HS1), between 2000 and 2003.
154 denarii found with a small ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: According to W. Łonak, the coins were kept by the Provincial Heritage Department for Cultural-Historical Soil Alterations in Racibórz.

summary: 872 silver coins: 45 denarii, 10 denarii plated, 381 antoniniani, 434 antoniniani plated, 1 quinarius, 1 drachm: Commodus - Gallienus (AD 260-268)

The hoard was found in a well in a Gallo-Roman villa and comprised 2 vessels containing a little more than 900 radiates of Elagabalus, Philip, Herennia Etruscilla and Postumus. More than 600 pieces were issues of Postumus.
157 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver w8: 43.5-370.6 g.
disposition: Collection Huybrigts, Tongeren, Belgium, in 1902; destroyed by fire in 1914

summary: 7 provincial bronze coins entered the museum collection in Shumen: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 13620/1-7 (7 coins)

summary: 13 denarii found with a m1y-box: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 153-154).
3 rolls, each comprising 50 nummi, of Constantine I and Constantine II (Caesar). Reverse types Tranquilitas, Beata Tranquilitas, Fides exercitus. Mint: Arelate
181 denarii found in the foundations of a prehistoric house: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 197-198); silver w8: 491.23 g. Found together with sherds and animal b1s.
175 silver coins: 173 denarii, 1 quinarius and 1 drachm: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Stadtmuseum, Neunkirchen (165 coins), private collection? (10 coins), Austria; lost (unknown no.)

summary: A small deposit of 10 coins: 9 sestertii, 1 antoninanus (radiate): Vespasian - Carus/Carinus for Magnia Urbica (283-285). The last coin, possible, intruder.
67 nummi found during the excavations in the cetral hall of the cathedral: House of Constantine I - Theodosius I (Arcadius) (AD 382-392).
Over 2000 aurei found with a ceramic vessel: Tiberius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235); gold w8: c. 12801.4-15598.6g.
(62) 10 denarii of Tajan (AD 112-114)

A hoard of 15 aurei (Marcus Aurelius to Caracalla), to be associated with Caracalla’s campaign in Adiabene in AD 216 and found in an Arsacid period house, south of the Sin-Shamash temple (find location fC6V).

The 22 coins (sestertii, Trajan - Marcus Aurelius) are the remnants derived from a hoard of at least 5 pounds from a meadow (Eckenweiher) where Roman villas have been found. The find is labelled as 'Kollektivfund' in FMRD.
(260) 257 denarii found in a ceramic vessel: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
A large hoard of 10 kilos of coins found with a ceramic lagoena. Only 161 pieces are available for study: Constantine I - Constantius II (AD 355-361).
disposition: Instituto de Antropologia «Dr. Mendes Corrêa», Porto, Portugal

summary: The hoard comprised 33 radiates of which 25 are Divus Claudius II radiates (AD 270).
Hoard of unknown number of bronze coins. 1 coin of Antoninus Pius and 1 of Faustina I (Augusta/Diva) were seen.

1 of 3 coin hoards found in a villa on 8een Acre Field, all buried just before the end of the 3rd c. AD. 334 coins were extracted from a hole sunk in the earth below 2 large st1s, placed as it seemed, purposely above it. The coins were of Gallienus, Probus, Tacitus, and Claudius Gothicus.

A hoard of many bronze coins was found on a field between Klettham and Siglfing. The coins were dispersed. The 5 coins listed in FMRD were reportedly part of this hoard. These coins were in the Museum Erding, but have been lost.
c. 50 antoniniani (radiates): Postumus (AD 260-269).
66 coins found with a ceramic vessel: 47 antoniniani (radiates), 19 nummi: Gallienus - Magnentius (AD 350-353).
disposition: The Karl Ernst Osthaus Museum in Hagen (impossible to identify them)

summary: Hoard of 228 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic pitcher. 225 were identified: Valerian I and Gallienus - Quintillus (AD 270); silver w8: 61.5-279.0 g.
disposition: Direzione generale per le Antichità e le Belle Arti, Torino, Italy (in 1904).

summary: The find comprised 'an important hoard of coins, dishes and cult statues, 2 in silver and 6 in bronze, from a sanctuary. There were approximately 40 silver coins which were melted down immediately by a goldsmith.'

The hoard comprised 2 vessels which were found on 2 separate occasions in 1903 and 1908 within 10 metres of each other. The first contained 32 kilos of coins from Gallienus to Diocletian and the second, 28 kilos from Julia Domna to Diocletian.
A group of 11 bronze coins dated between AD 383 and 425 were discovered together, either as isolated coin finds from the building of the wall or a low-value foundation deposit.
141 silver coins: 3 denarii, 138 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-259); silver w8: 178.1-367.1 g.

The hoard comprised approximately 200 gold aurei. Some gold coins were found while the miller, Chereau was ploughing in the church's field. He then found quite a large quantity while digging in his field.
191 billon tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian (AD 274-275) found in a pile at floor level in room during excavations of a house. 1 bronze coin of the Ptolemy V may be regarded as a intruder?
6 denarii found on the construction site: Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166).
32 gold staters of the Bosporan kings: Eupator, Sauromates II, Rhescuporis III.
7 Roman imperial coins: 1 denarius, 3 antoniniani (radiates), 3 nummi: Marcus Aurelius - Valentinian I (AD 364-375).
A group of 5 coins (4 denarii and 1 antoninianus), found in the moor of Aschen, while extracting peat in ca. 1935.
Unknown originally number of denarii. 8 coins are kept in the History Museum in Iași: Domitian 1, Trajan 1, Hadrian 2, Antoninus Pius 3, Marcus Aurelius (Divus Antoninus Pius) 1.
disposition: History Museum of Moldova, Iași, Romania (inv.nos. 680, 714/9, 744, 768, 774, 779)

summary: 12093 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Aurelian/Tetricus I (AD 270-275), found during the building of the railway in an urn covered by a slate pate. W8: circa 40 kg.
disposition: Coins given to the 'Kön. Münzkabinet'; Berlin (part: 167 coins acquired in 1879, acc. no. 1879/283)

summary: A hoard of 82 Roman imperial denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211) was found by treasure hunter in the summer of 2020 by 2 treasure hunters near the village of Merva in Volyn region. On March 22, 2021, in 1 of the groups on Facebook, dedicated to treasure hunting, user Anatoly Login (Анатолий Логин) published information about the discovery of a hoard of Roman coins and its photos. According to him, the hoard was discovered by him and his wife near the village, in the pasture, on the bank of the river Styr. The hoard was ploughed up, and the coins were also found in the neighboring vegetable gardens of local residents. Fragments of a hand-made vessel were found among the coins. Coins are very worn. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
2 gold coins of which 1 of Vespasian.
81 denarii found with a ceramic vessel while building a new house: Otho - Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) (AD 161-180).
382 coins. 332 coins in the museum in Vidin: Galba - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 438-463 (today, less than 300 coins)

summary: Hoard of around 1000 silver coins. 29 coins are kept in the Joanneum, Graz. According to G. Dembski the coins may rank from Severus Alexander to Gallienus.

The hoard of 79 denarii (1 Republican denarius; imperial coins range from Nero to Antoninus Pius) and 1 Lycian drachm was found in 1882 during plowing of a court at Middels-Osterloog. The coins lay in a container.
Unknown number of aurei and silver coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 5 aurei were seen: Trajan 4, Trajan for Plotina 1.
The hoard comprised 10 bronze coins: Vespasian - Trajan (AD 103-111). W8: 68.27 g.
disposition: Soprintendenza per i Beni Archeologici del Veneto, Padova, Italy

summary: Hoard of circa 80 coins of gold, silver and bronze belonging to Vitellius, Vespasian, Titus, Nerva and Trajan. Together were found gold jewelry.
The hoard comprised 43 radiates from Gordian III to Gallienus. It was found in the same area as Oštra Luka II.
54 antoniniani (radiates) found in a wall with a ceramic vessel: Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
71 nummi found in the Necropolis Church: Valentinian II - Marcian (AD 450-457).
1764 coins, probably antoniniani (radiates), found with 2 ceramic vessels: Valerian I - Diocletian and Maximian I (AD 284-293).

Found during excavations, in the Mithraeum, sector NW, niveau de fréquentation (found in 1994, 69 coins) and above in the demolition layer (found in 1993, 4 coins). Hoard, most probably packed in a container of perishable material, no traces found; 73 aes coins, Nero (?) to Philip I, mostly sestertii with a few dupondii and asses.
disposition: Service des bâtiments, monuments et archéologie, Martigny/Sion

summary: Hoard of 5 kilos of coins (c. 16.500 coins), among 2 antoniniani (radiates): Claudius II - House of Theodosius (AD 388-423).

24 nummi of Constantine I and his family found somewhere around Beaumaris. No further information is available. 20-4 folles of Constantine I –G.C. Boon, in BBCS, XXII (1966-8), 308, no. 88. Guest and Wells date these all to AD 330-7 but no reverse types are given.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 600 coins. They are described as being base silver coins from Caracalla to Gordian III. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of between 751.3g and 1558.7g
336 denarii found in a ceramic vessel: Tiberius - Trajan (AD 98).
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Burgas, Bulgaria; inv.no. VI

summary: The hoard comprised a total of 130 coins including 6 sestertii from Hadrian to Trajan Decius and 124 Roman Provincial coins from Athens dating to Periods V and VI (Hadrian to Gallienus). This hoard is linked to the invasion of the Goths in AD 267. It was found 300 m north of the archaeological site of Eleusis.

'7 tiny coins (nummi) below the floor level were found embedded in the tamped loess at the elevation of the base of the hut’s walls; 6 were close to the entrance, below the st1 step, where it seems they were placed on purpose. They were poorly preserved and disintegrated upon removal.' (Haimann 2008).
32 coins: 23 sestertii, 7 dupondii and 2 antoniniani (radiates): Titus - Postumus (AD 260-268).
The hoard comprised 9 bronze coins dated to the reign of Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
Unknown original number of denarii, 69 preserved: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 168); silver w8: 194 g.
The hoard comprised 138 aurei from Claudius I to Domitian (AD 81-96).

483 of mostly the latest Hellenistic coinage of Athens (finishing with coins from period IVD and E, i.e. mid 20's-19BC and 15-10 BC), found in Chaidari and donated to the Athens Numismatic museum by Mrs. L. Serpieri-Averof in 1929. The Attica hoard (IGCH 343, 44 similar coins) from 1927 might well belong to the same depot.
The hoard comprised 39 bronze coins dated between the reigns of Herod Philip (4 BC - AD 34) and Gordian III (AD 238-244).
4 aurei. The latest 1 bears the portrait of Geta (AD 198-211).

7 coins: 4 antoniniani, 2 sestertii; 1 medallion of bronze and gold and silver jewelry were found within a child grave: 4 antoniniani, 2 sestertii: Septimius Severus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 257-258).
The hoard was found in 1880. It comprised 150 radiates, from Gordian III to Postumus. Only 123 are now recorded.

20 coins from Constantine I to House of Valentinian. Found at Methodist Chapel on Durngate Street near Greyhound Yard excavs - attributed to Period 16 (19th C.), so possibly redeposited/ residual in later footings?Not menti1d in main text - only in Reece's coin report (in Woodward et al. 2003 p.116), but he classes it as a hoard.Woodward et al. 1993. Excavations at Greyhound Yard, Dorchester 1981-4. DNHAS Mono. 12, 116.
The hoard comprised 60 silver coins and some bronzes, including 1 of Faustina I.
Probably a hoard of solidi, in which the coins were found at various dates. Only 4 solidi of Theodosius II minted in Constantinopolis (AD 430-440) are known.
disposition: Nyulászíj István; Báthori-István-Museum, Nyírbátor, Hungary (inv.no. 67.248.2); Déri-Museum, Debrecen, Hungary (inv.no. 1913.70)

find_spot_name: KÖLN - ST. MARIA IM KAPITOL XIV
summary: Based on the year of acquisition and types of the coins an inference is permitted that they might derive from the Maria im Kapitol hoard. The hoard involves a small set of coins in the Höchst museum, in RGZM Mainz, in the Suermondt museum of Aachen and in Oberlahnstein.
disposition: Rheinisches Landesmuseum, Mainz; Museum Höchst; Suermondt Museum, Aachen; Museum, Oberlahnstein, Germany

summary: A hoard of Roman denarii comprising at least 47 coins ranging from Nero to Septimius Severus.

The hoard was found on the site of a Roman villa and comprised 4 vessels containing 4399 coins. 156 were denarii from Antoninus Pius to Gordian III and 4245 were radiates from Gordian III to Gallienus' sole reign and Postumus. Vessel 1 contained a single denarius of Severus Alexander and 1057 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Postumus with a tpq of AD 264-265. Vessel 2 contained 986 antoniniani (radiates) from Elagabalus to Postumus with a tpq of AD 268. Vessel 3 contained 155 denarii from Antoninus Pius to Maximinus I and 575 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Postumus with a tpq of AD 268. Vessel 4 contained 1627 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Postumus.
13 coins found in a tomb: 6 Ptolemaic, 2 Alexandria provincial coins: Augustus, Tiberius. 5 tesserae.

find_spot_name: SIRACUSA, EX VIGNA CASSIA, PRIMA TOMBA (GRUZZOLO B)
summary: Hoard in grave, 13 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Quintillus/Aurelian (Divus Claudius II) (AD 270-275).
The hoard of 15 gold coins of the Late Empire was found in a hollow flint.
(c. 600) 5 denarii: Titus, Hadrian, Faustina I (Diva), Crispina, Julia Domna
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie a Județului Vâlcea, Râmnicu Vâlcea, Romania; 5 coins, inv .no. 13388-13992

summary: 2 denarii of Augustus found in a st1 burial (S-A) during the archaeological excavation of Samtavro cemetery by I. A. Dzhavakhishvili.
(c. 215) 199 bronze coins: 194 sestertii, 5 dupondii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 191).

A hoard of 551 coins, found in a drainage ditch on farmland half a mile from Llanarmon Dyffryn Geiriog, Denbighshire. Of these, 507 coins (502 denarii and 5 antoninianii, ranging from Mark Antony to Severus Alexander) are now in the British Museum. 3 further coins were reported in 1929, but the remaining 1s are lost.

2987 coins: 2982 silver, 5 bronzes found with a red coarse ceramic vessel inscribed Selvius Callistus (in Greek letters): coins of the 2nd-3rd centuries AD. The hoard is still work in progress, only few parts are documented so far: Republic - Septimius Severus (AD 202-210).
The hoard comprised more than 250 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I and II.
6000 nummi found with ceramic vessel: Diocletian and Constantius I (Caesar) (AD 295-305). 3000 coins were minted in Ticinum, 6 in Alexandria.

A photograph of a Dubnovellaunos stater was forwarded to the CCI in 1983 by John Kent, with the comment that it was "found with 2 others (1 plated) and an anonymous AV ¼ stater of Addedomaros type in the Cambridge (?) area c.1982?

The hoard comprised a large quantity of coins, although only 11 were identified. They included issues of Gordian III, Gallienus and Salonina. It seems likely that this is the same hoard as 1 menti1d by M. Faujas de Saint-Fond in 1810 which comprised 'a very large number of medium and small bronze Roman coins from Gallienus to the House of Constantine'.
Hoard of an unknown number of denarii. According to some incriptions the issuers were Antoninus Pius and Marcus Aurelius (ANTONINVS PIVS, ANTONINVS ARMENIACVS). 6 or 8 denarii were noticed.
Few dozens of denarii of the Anto9 dynasty (AD 96-192). Only 10 denarii are known: Trajan, Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius.

A hoard of ca. 3220 Roman silver coins (denarii and antoniniani), ranging from Antoninus Pius to Postumus, found in a vessel during works at the Erthalstraße in 1886. Some of the hoard was dispersed. 1872 coins are listed in FMRD.
4 provincial coins (Pella, Cassandrea) found in a grave in Potidaia in 1973.
The hoard comprised Parthian silver tetradrachms, found by treasure hunters among 'ruins' at Akura, 50km east of Byblos. 29 specimens (Artabanus II to Volagases I) were seen on the market in Beirut.
The hoard comprised 1100 nummi, dating to the first part of the 4th century AD.
disposition: The Institute of Archaeology of the Hebrew University of Jerusalem

summary: 1365 silver coins: 1361 denarii, 4 drachms of Lycia: Republic - Elagabalus (AD 219).
disposition: National History Museum of Romania Bucharest (Inv. no. MNIR 189402-190766)

summary: 4 bronze coins: Hadrian - Severus Alexander (Julia Mamaea) (AD 222-235). Found together with an iron scale, a bronze weigh and scale pan fragments. Most likely ot a set for weighing.
The hoard comprises a small greyware vessel containing 12 denarii of 1 of the Faustinas.

2901 nummi: Constantine I - Theodosius I (AD 379-395). It must be noticed the absence of the coins of the House of Valentinian I. The mints: Ambianum 1, Treveri 1, Lugdunum 3, Arelate 6, Roma 53, Aquileia 91, Siscia 509, Sirmium 715, Thessalonica 440, Heraclea 143, Constantinopolis 247, Nicomedia 86, Cyzicus 146, Antioch 29, Alexandria 3, uncertain mint 418, barbarous 10
disposition: Museum of the Highland Banat, Reșița, Romania

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 82 bronze coins were studied: 81 sestertii, 1 dupondius: Titus - Gordian III (AD 240/241).
(36) 34 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Philip (AD 244-249).
2469 denarii and provincial silver of which only 210 were recorded - Otho to Antoninus Pius (208 denarii, 2 drachms of Amisus of Hadrian and Antoninus Pius)
disposition: Museum of Anatolian Civilisations, Ankara; Balıkesir museum

summary: 60 silver and bronze coins found by workers 19 provincial bronze coins were aquired by the Varna Archaeological Society: Gordian - Philip I (AD 244-249).
The hoard comprised 3604 small module radiate copies, known as 'minimi' [antoniniani (radiates)]. The hoard was found in an amphora covered by a tile while digging foundations for a building
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliotheque Natiobnale de France (in 1937)

summary: 39 silver coins found near the castle of Millière: 35 Celtic, 4 republican denarii.
2 aurei of Vespasian.
disposition: The British Museum (?), London, United Kingdom

summary: The hoard was unearthed on a field, approx. 1 km east of Marmagen. It comprised 200-300 follis (Tetrarchy). Of these, 125 are now in the museums in Heidenheim and Schwäbisch Gmünd. These are listed in FMRD. The coin of Gordian III might not belong to the hoard.
The hoard comprised 31 tetradrachms, 17 denarii, and 7 bronze coins from the Bar Kohba Revolt (AD 132-136) and 1 denarius of Trajan.

Unknown original number of denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Among issuers: Gordian III, Philip I, Otacilia, Gallienus, Salonina. Uncertain whether this is part of the 1840 hoard also found in Echternach.
Unknown number of nummi of the House of Constantine I. Only 5 nummi have been seen in a private collection in Soest (1867>
The hoard comprised 258 nummi.
63 coins found in a grave: Claudius II - Constantius II (AD 355-361).
Silted-up stream palaeochannel contained over 30 Iron Age coins, incl. gold stater of Tasciovanus.
2 coins: 1 Alexandrian bronze of Vespasian, 1 provincial bronze of Elagabalus found together with 6 lead tokens (produced in Memphis) during excavations.
disposition: Museum of Anthropology of the University of California, Berkeley, USA (1935)

summary: 2 Iron Age gold quarter-staters, 18 denarii and 1 quinarius to Antoninus Pius and 6 copper-alloy votive objects.
237 denarii were discovered on different occasions, most of them following the excavation in 1931: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
disposition: Swedish History Museum, Stockholm (inv.nos. 19119, 19276, 19687); Collection Zonnander, Ranneslov, Sweden

summary: The hoard discovered no later than 1900; the total number of coins is unknown. A city dweller with the surname Shapiro bought 44 coins (Vespasian-Commodus; total w8 127.43 g), of which only 8 were identified in the Imperial Archaeological Commission (by E. Pridik) and then were returned to the owner.

A hoard of 124 coins, comprising tetradrachms (Philip I - Gallus), denarii (Domitian - Alexander Severus, 1 quinarius (Caracalla) and 1 provincial bronze coin (Gordian III & Abgar), found at Dura in G1, during the season 1936–7. No container was reported.
The hoard was found in the foundations of an ancient building and comprised a collection of very corroded dupondii and asses arranged in rows from Augustus to Trajan (AD 98-117).
51 bronze coins: 18 sestertii, 2 dupondii?, 31 provincial coins: Marcus Aurelius - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238). Together, were found bronze finger-rings, and fragments of bracelets.
12 provincial coins: 3 drachms, 15 bronze coins: Augustus - Trajan. 2 Claudian coins are countermarked by Trajan and Hadrian. Quake sealed context.
All are imitations: Claudius II - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver w8: 116.4-203.9g.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg

summary: 5 denarii: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 183-184); silver w8: 14.16 g.
Initial quantity of silver coins: 13 kg, Studied: 9 kg (Gerov, B.) = 1790 coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver w8: 2238.1-4652.9 g.
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 843-856 (1716 coins, stolen 1407)

summary: 80 denarii from Mark Anthony to Marcus Aurelius with a tpq of AD 165.
Hoard of a large number of nummi. Only 9 pieces were recovered, all from the time of Constantine I.
disposition: Family of Mr. Alfredo Ayres Gouvêa Allen

summary: 226 silver coins were found at a spot somewhere between school and a mound: Nero - Gordian III (AD 238-244)
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 2259-2286

summary: The only data published on this hoard indicates that it comprised 800 antoniniani (radiates) dating from the reigns of Gordian III to Gallienus (AD 260-268).

A pot containing approx. 20 or more Roman coins, found in about 1918 on the farm of Halcroft, in the vicinity of Corsock. 2 of these coins were described (Urbs Roma; Constantius II). The coin of Constantius II, Aug. had rev. FEL TEMP REPARATIO, Emperor, 2 captives, of AD 348-51 (LRBC 2010).
12 nummi of Maximinus II Daia and Constantine I and his Family found in a hypocaustum (AD 306-337).
1 barbarous imitation of a Roman gold coin found in a grave together with a denarius of Augustus coin of Caius and Lucius and a plausible drachm of Gotarzes II.
Unknown originally number of coins. 42 denarii: Otho - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver w8: 78.0-122.8 g.
(150) 109 coins: 18 denarii, 19 antoniniani, 2 sestertii, 70 provincial bronze coins: Antoninus Pius - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver w8: 42.3-83.4 g.
disposition: History Museum, Kazanlak, Bulgaria (20 coins); Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1566-1672 (106 coins)

summary: 6 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
During excavation of Roman villa at Keston, a series of IA pits pre-dating the villa complex were investigated. 4 Iron Age potin coins were found in pit 31.

The hoard comprised 159 coins: 55 Syrian tetradrachms (Caracalla to Trebonianus Gallus) and 104 antoniniani (Trebonianus Gallus to Maximian), found in a pot in an underground beneath a church in Iafa, near Nazareth.
Hoard of 281 antoniniani (radiates) found on the territory of the legionary fort: Valerian I and Gallienus - Diocletian (AD 285).
disposition: Museum Lauriacum - Museum der Stadt Enns

summary: Single finds of 21 Roman coins, Tiberius to Gallienus, found during metal detectorists' surveys on the site of a Roman villa rustica. Some of these might be part of a scattered hoard. Among coins found 1998-2011: 11 antoniniani and 10 denarii, Antoninus Pius to Gallienus (joint reign) and Postumus. 9 of these have been published with full references.

A bronze jar with many coins was found in 1832 along the road going to Burgweinting on a field. The find was divided up, a small part being bought by the Regensburg museum. The coins in the museum comprises 2 denarii and 116 antoniniani, ranging from Diva Faustina to Gallienus.
1401 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
Unknown number of coins. 5 antoniniani are in the museum collection in Székesfehérvár: Gordian III, Philip I, Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
310 nummi found during the excavations at the archaeological site. Among them issues of Constantine I, Constantine I (Fausta), Constans, Constantius II.
(c. 7 kg) 300 silver coins: Hadrian - Maximian I (A284-293); silver w8: 56.7-852.5 g.

The coins (15 denarii, ranging from Marcus Aurelius to Maximinus, with the probable addition of a further denarius of Septimius Severus) were found together at the southwest foothills of the Lehenbühl, SE of Fridingen.

Towards the end of October 1878 3 aurei were discovered in Bliesen between the Church of St. Remigius and the Rhine road. These date from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius. The coins are now in the collection of the Munzkabinett im Rheinischen Landesmuseum. A 4th aureus in the possession of this museum has been associated with the Bliesen hoard. It dates to the reign of Vespasian (72/3) and was acquired from the Bliesen area.

The hoard comprised 84 coins (probably radiates) of Gordian III, Philip I, Philip II, Otacilia Severa, Trajan Decius, Herennius Etruscus, Hostilian, Herennia Etruscilla, Trebonianus Gallus, Volusian, Valerian, Gallienus, Salonina and Valerian II.
20 coins: denarii, antoniniani (radiates), nummi: Antoninus Pius - Julian II (AD 361-363).
50 coins found between the pillars of the hypocaust in 1 of the buildings of the civilian city of Carnuntum: 3 argentei, 47 nummi of the 1st Tetrarchy (AD 305).

97 coins: 1 denarius and 96 bronzes found concentrated around an earthenware dish within a level of a building: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166-167). The coins were found together with a brooch, as well as several pieces of pottery and nails.

Unknown original number of coins. 23 gold coins were recovered: 16 solidi, 7 Aksumite gold coins: Constantius II - Kaleb (AD 510-530). No details if the hoard was found in a container, and have no information about any archaeological context.
2 Celtic quinarii, type "Büschel", deposited in a posthole of the Roman villa (Period I, Pfos10loch A032/B174).
(c. 600) 300 silver coins: 299 denarii, 1 drachm: Mark Antony - Commodus (AD 180-183).
Unknown number of denarii. 5 pieces entered the museum collection in Kazanlak: Domitian 1, Trajan 4.
disposition: Museum of History, Kazanlak, Bulgaria; inv.no. 3994-3998

summary: Around 24 aurei " 12 of Nero and just as many of Vespasian" (AD 69-79) found in a ceramic vessel. No further information.
Unknown initial coin numbers. 6 republican denarii were recovered 32-31 BC
disposition: Institutul de Cercetări Eco-Muzeale, Tulcea, Romania; inv.no. 54015-54020

summary: 107 coins. 65 coins: Victorinus - Theodosius I. No further information. 42 coins were found in 1995 at the same findspot.
523 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 292-293) found in a jar, hidden in a hole dug out beneath the floor of underground room H, during excavations of a house.
disposition: 507 coins in Ann Arbor, the rest in various Egyptian museums

summary: Discovered at a place with Roman structures. Some doubts whether it is actually a hoard. 8 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269-271).
24 silver coins: 23 denarii, 1 quinarius: Republic - Augustus
10 solidi: Valens - Theodosius I (AD 394-395).
The hoard comprised a greyware vessel covered with a tile containing 2300 nummi of the Tetrarchy.
The hoard comprised more than 230 denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus (Geta and Julia Domna) - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver w8: 288.1-596.9 g.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen (198 coins; inv.nos. III 2099-2102); Musée d'Avranches (32 coins)

summary: A hoard of ca. 460 Roman silver denarii (Nero - Marcus Aurelius for 344 of them, the others are lost), found in an earthenware container 1 1/2 feet under the soil while removing st1s ('Steineroden') in the heather, at Wassermühle on the Wingstberg.
The hoard comprised a ceramic urn containing 50 corroded, worn, illegible Roman coins, with the exception being 2 sestertii of Hadrian and Antoninus Pius.
2 denarii: Trajan, Antoninus Pius/Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II).

The hoard comprised a fine greyware vessel containing approximately 280 (large?) bronze coins, stuck together with corrosion products. Next to the ceramic vessel, there was an empty glass vessel. 210 coins were presented to the Commission des Antiquités of Seine-Inferieur by Brianchon.
disposition: Thoulmin; Musée d'Évreux (6 coins; Inventory p. 42, no. 1895; given on 24.4.1892); finders; sold to Grard, Chevallier, Lemariez and Bisson.

summary: 140 bronze coins: 130 sestertii, 10 dupondii: Vespasian - Macrinus (AD 217-218).
929 coins found in a ceramic vessel: 2 denarii, 9 argentei, 918 nummi: Hadrian - Tetrarchy (AD 300-302).
disposition: Cabinet des médailles de la Bibliothèque Nationale de France.
