summary: The hoard was found in a burial chamber and comprised 3 silver coins (tetradrachms) and 3 bronze coins dated between AD 40-70 and AD 70-106.
488 silver coins: 227 denarii, 1 plated denarius, 260 antoniniani: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-247).
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie Națională și Arheologie, Constanța, Romania

summary: 3 gold coins found together with a gold wire ring: Theodosius II solidus, Zeno solidus, solidus imitation from a coin of Anastasius I (AD post 491).
disposition: Museum Szczecin (2 coins); Museum of Cultural History Stralsund, Germany (inv.no. 1962:302)

summary: A hoard of at least 60 Roman imperial denarii: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192) was discovered by a treasure hunter in the late 2010s. The hoard was found in a forest, the coins were collected from an area of 10x10 m (slightly higher was another area of 30x40 m where several coins were also found). 60 coins were collected by treasure hunters during 6 trips. A fragment of an iron Roman sword blade was found 200 m from the hoard. The coins have a rather bad condition (heavy wear). The further fate of the coins is unknown.

The hoard (5 bronze coins ranging from Domitian to Faustina I) was found in 1964 northwest of the Jewish cemetery in house pit 27-29 of Ernst-Kahn-straße, in a depth of 30 cm. The coins lay in a varnished pot. The hoard remain in private possession.
Hoard of 60 coins of unknown denomination or metal: Antoninus Pius - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
20 denarii, 11 studied: Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) – Severus Alexander (Julia Mammaea) (AD 222-235).
disposition: Museum of Týniště nad Orlicí, inv.nos. 63–73, today missing.

summary: A hoard of 44 bronze coins mainly Valentinianic, was found in July 1984 during observation of redevelopment work on Hay's Wharf by the Museum of London's Department of Greater London Archaeology. Since the hoard came from the edge of a machine-dug trench, some coins may have been lost when the trench was dug. However, the size and shape of the depression suggests that at least half of the hoard was probably recovered. The latest coin in the hoard dated to 378-83. However, of the 36 Valentinianic coins identified, 21 (including most of the latest coins in the hoard) were in a state of wear which suggested that they had been in circulation for some period.
2 aurei (Nero and Vitellius), c. 100 Republican denarii, and 15 uncertain AE found in regio VI, insula 2, building 2 (house).
24 provincial bronze coins: Caracalla - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie Națională și Arheologie, Constanța, Romania; inv.nos. 67360-67382

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic 'olla' containing 121 Roman silver coins mixed with burnt material. It was found in an orchard behind the cemetery on the Frémont property. 14 of the coins were sold to Rouen just after the hoard was found with the rest being acquired in 1908 (Inventory III, p. 52, nos. 2091 and 2097).
Unknown originally number of coins. 8 silver coins: House of Constantine I (AD 330-347)
disposition: National Museum Prague, Czech Republic (5 coins) 1981

summary: The hoard comprised 3 asses of Tiberius. No evidence that they were part of a hoard.

At the beginning of 1884, a mass grave dating to the 1793 war was found south of the Hammermühle in Wiesbaden-Biebrich. At the same place was also found a hoard of ca. 30 Roman denarii, ranging from the Republic to Elagabalus. FMRD lists 32 coins. The composition of the hoard is highly unusual and FMRD considers the last 3 coins (Antoninus Pius and Elagabalus) as po10tial intruders. If that was the case, the hoard would end with Titus.

The hoard was found in a vessel and comprised approximately 2000 antoniniani (radiates), with the majority being Gallienus, Postumus and 'some other Gallic emperors' 'The hoard was found on the ground surface during flint extraction in the triage du Parc, around 2 km from the village in the Breteuil forest.' There appears to be an error with this findspot description as the triage du Parc is 8 km from Breteuil and is in the village of Bémécourt.
35 aurei of Augustus: 33 Lugdunum, 1 Pergamum, 1 uncertain mint (2 BC - AD 4).
disposition: Museum of Angers; Cabinet des Médailles, Bibliothèque Nationale de France, Paris (galvanic-plastic copies)

summary: The hoard comprised 4 coins including 1 earlier coin of Thasos (2nd c. BC) and 2 Roman Provincial coins: Philippoi (1 imperial period), Topeiros (1 Antoninus Pius) and a further 1 unidentified coin, found in grave T11 in Lithochori.
Unknown number of bronze coins: Augustus - Commodus/Pertinax (AD 193).
The hoard comprised c. 24 silver coins, only 8 tetradrachms recorded: 101/0 BC - 73-63 BC.
47 solidi: Valentinian III – Anastasius (AD 491-518). Found with a gold ring.

The hoard was found when a farmer noticed coins in a molehill. The villagers then excavated the area and found a st1 vault from which 2 copper-alloy vessels were recovered, along with between 25000 and 30000 silver and billon coins which had placed in a pile close by. 1 vessel contained jewellery and some gold coins. The second vessel contained approximately 620 denarii. Fillon noted that coins of Gordian III, Philip I, Trajan Decius, Trebonianus Gallus, Volusian, Valerian, Gallienus, Salonina and Postumus represented 9/10ths of the the assemblage. The latest coins of Postumus date to Elmer's 14th issue. The discovery attracted at10tion and soon other villagers discovered 2 bronze vessels and the vault in which they had been stored. The hoard was dispersed amongst numerous private collections in 1856. These included Arthur Parenteau de la Voute (250 reverse varieties), O. de Rochebrune, Hanaël Jousseaume, De La Brière, Charvet etc. 23 examples were give to the Sociétè Industrielle d'Angers, 18 to the Sociétè des Antiquaires de l'Ouest. Fragments of the 2 copper-alloy vessels were acquired by the Musée de la Roche-sur-Yon and some coins, including the sestertius of Julia Domna. The Musée archéologique de Nantes acquired 4 spoons, 18 finger rings, 2 earrings, 2 bracelets and 414 coins, of which 212 were of Postumus.

1 coin is a Western uninscribed gold quarter stater of a type produced in the Gloucestershire-Worcestershire-Oxfordshire area between about 40 and 10 BC. The other is an Eastern gold quarter stater of Cunobelin struck in about AD 10-40.
14 early Roman bronze/provincial coins found with "a small coarse ware jar...at least 1 had been minted at Alexandria during the reign of Tiberius (14-37 AD)."
Large hoard of silver coins. Only 7 denarii are kept in the museum of Pleven: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Okrazen Istoriceski Muzej, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1452 1-7

summary: 42 bronze coins: 1 sestertius, 6 dupondii, 35 asses: Augustus - Trajan (AD 98-99).
Found with a ceramic m1y-box. 1 bronze coin serve as a lid: 285 denarii, 1 as: Republic - Augustus (7 BC).
30 nummi of Constantine I (AD 306-337) found near the foundation of the Tower of Pisa.
The hoard comprised a vessel containing '60 Roman coins of the 3rd and 4th century AD'. Found together with another ceramic vessel decorated and bearing the inscription ASSVTA.
A suspicious hoard of 24 nummi found with a metal detector: Constantine I - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
7 denarii: Vespasian 3, Nerva 1, Trajan 1, Marcus aurelius 2 (AD 166-167).
The hoard comprised 5 hundred of Roman coins from Maximian, Aurelianus, Tacitus, Florian, Probus, Carus, Numerian and Diocletian.
The hoard was found in small red brick 'ampoule' in a grave next to a skeleton. It comprised 307 radiates from Valerian I to Victorinus with a tpq of AD 270.
The find of Adlerterrain in 1903 comprised 12 antoniniani and denarii ranging from Maximinus Thrax to Gallienus.

A hoard of 180 Roman imperial denarii (from Trajan to Septimius Severus) was discovered by a treasure hunter in April 2017 in Sumy region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on April 18, 2017 on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity. According to the finder, the coins were discovered on a ploughed field, near the river. On the same field in other parts of it were found single finds of denarii, many fragments of pottery, late Roman time bronze fibulae (i.e. material characteristic of the settlement of the Chernyakhiv culture – K.M.). The coins were in a hand-made pot, of which only the bottom was preserved, found at a depth of 40 cm. The finder assumed that the upper part of the pot (i.e., hoard) had been cut by a plough, as some of the coins were on fragments of this vessel or within a meter of it. Early medieval material (Kievan Rus) was also found in the same field. The further fate of the hoard coins is unknown.
The hoard was found in a Roman theatre and comprised 1065 coins. 12 imitations of antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I. 1053 blanks and 6 rejected blanks.
68 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269-271).
The hoard comprised bronze coins from the First Jewish Revolt (AD 66-70).
2 solidi found together: Honorius, Valentinian III; gold w8: 8.9 g.
6 sestertii recorded with the PAS, 3 further from excavation of the site (see Amber Valley barbarous radiate hoard). Not classed as Treasure.
Thousands of coins found in an iron vessel. No further information
The hoard comprised close to 8000 nummi of the House of Constantine, including SOLI INVICTO, PROVIDENTIAE CAESARVM NOSTRORVM, GLORIA EXERCITVS, VRBS ROMA and PIETAS PVBLICA and PAX ROMANA.
3 solidi of Leo I (AD 462-466); gold w8: 8.9-13.35 g.
7 coins: Nerva – Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
disposition: Regional museum, Kolín, Czech Republic (6 coins)

summary: 16 denarii found by metal detecting: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-163).
disposition: East Fife Museums, St. Andrews, United Kingdom (5 coins)

summary: A hoard of at least 105, possibly up to 115, denarii found at the end of December 1930, of which only 105 are still identified in the records of Rabat Museum. Chatelain, the original excavator, listed 114 coins in the find, including 2 coins of Juba II, 1 of Nero, 1 of Galba, 9teen of Vespasian, 7 of Titus, 20-3 of Domitian, 3 of Nerva, 40-8 of Trajan and 10 of Hadrian. However it is clear that Chatelain misidentified 2 of the Republican denarii as coins of Juba II. The next publication of the hoard, by Ruhlmann, came in 1933. This list largely agrees with the records kept by Rabat Museum, but includes 10 extra coins, taking the total up to 115, which must now be regarded as lost. The missing coins listed by Ruhlmann are as follows: 1 Republican denarius, 1 denarius of Vespasian, 2 denarii of Domitian, 5 denarii of Trajan and 1 Hadrianic denarius. There are no further details concerning the types of these coins, because Ruhlmann only published in detail the 9 latest specimens from the find. The whole hoard was contained in a hollow bracelet and was probably buried circa 122.
192 coins found with a ceramic vessel: 1 antoninian (radiate), 191 nummi: Victorinus - Theodosius I (Arcadius) (AD 383).
2 double-pierced gold coins, an aureus of Septimius Severus (AD 203), and its imitation were reported from a village.
9 sestertii found within the south-west district: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 247).

Unknown initial number of coins. The hoard comprised 1068 denarii and 2 asses dating from Nero to Balbinus and Pupienus with a tpq of AD 239. The hoard has a silver w8 of between 1496.9g and 3341.1 g.
disposition: Coin Room, National History Museum of Transylvania, Cluj-Napoca, Romania

summary: 58 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211); silver w8: 107.3-170.0g
14 denarii found at a distance of a few hundred meters from each other on both banks of the Sonia River, the tributary of the Sona: Titus - Commodus (AD 185).
Aureus of Carinus minted in . Solidus Valens minted in Antioch (AD 367-375). Both coins are pierced.
Approximately 130 silver coins, the majority of which were denarii, of which only a small proportion were identified.

Udmarken on Bornholm has yielded 3 hoards with a total of 217 denarii. All 3, A, B, C, have been interpreted as being of either the same hoard or of chronologically identical hoards. A and B were found a week apart in 1853 and C was found in 1857. Udmarken A contains 157 of the 217 denarii.

4 large gold pieces, and imbedded in clay 40-50 more, found in 1787-8 on land belonging to Haverhill Place. This hoard was thought by Robertson to be late empire but seems to be Iron Age according to additional information found by P de Jersey (2015).
24 nummi, part of a larger hoard, coming from a private collection: Constans - Julian II (AD 361-363).
480 denarii: Republic – Antoninus Pius (Marcus Aurelius Caesar) (AD 155-156).
25 nummi found in of the rooms of the bath complex: Valentinianus I - Honorius (AD 395-423). Dembski offers information on 24 coins.
The hoard comprised approximately 46 tetradrachms and 200-350 denarii of the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
disposition: L. Hamburger (British Museum); Montagu Collection; J. Evans; Kelsey Museum of Archaeology in Ann Arbor, Michigan; Detroit Institute of Arts

summary: 42 silver coins: 2 denarii, 40 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
5 denarii: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161) found during excavations.
disposition: Muzeul Dunării de Jos, Călărași, Romania; inv.nos. 46511-46514, 46518

summary: Over 200 silver coins. 168 are known: 166 denarii, 2 drachms of Lycia: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 167).
64 nummi found inside the cave of Abauntz, apparently with a ceramic vessel: Constantine I - Theodosius I/Arcadius (AD 388-392). Together were found a bronze ring and an iron hoe.
disposition: Museo Arqueológico de Navarra, Pamplona, Spain

summary: 3428 antoniniani (radiates) found with a copper alloy pitcher: Trebonianus Gallus - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver w8: 922.5-4265.3 g.
disposition: Museo Civico «Ala Ponzone» di Cremona, Italy

summary: The hoard comprised 75 gold coins. The best specimens were bought by Huppy and Raineville and after his death passed to de Rohant and de la Hayette. Gold: 75 coins; Gold w8: 333.75g. Part of the hoard VILLERS-L'HÔPITAL 1643?
disposition: Huppy, Raineville, de Rohant, de la Hayette

summary: In digging gravel, 1753, on Ockford hill near the road that leads to Turnworth, 70 or 80 British silver coins were found. A similar find is reported for 1788. The report mentions that they were scarce broader than a 6pence, but much thicker, flat on 1 side, and convex on the other, weighed 83 grains, and were valued at 11d. each, and resembled 1 in Dr. Borlase's History of Cornwall, p. 242, Plate xix. No. 11 (a British A (Westerham) stater, ABC 482, the prototype of the Durotrigan silver). If the w8 quoted (83 gr, or 5.38 g) is accurate, then the coins must have been from relatively early in the series, with a high silver con10t.
The hoard comprised 6 shekels and 6 half shekels from the First Jewish Revolt (AD 66-73), found in a bronze vessel.
2236 silver coins: 415 denarii, 1821 antoniniani (radiates): Commodus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
(c. 400) 3 denarii: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
disposition: Archaeological Museum Charleroi, Belgium 13 coins, only 5 retrieved)

summary: A building of the Roman period lay on the premises of a wine dealer on Nikolausstrasse 113. In the cellar of the building, a hoard of approx. 50 bronze coins from the time of the Tetrarchy was found in 1887, surrounded by ash.
431 coins: 295 denarii, 136 antoniniani: Commodus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 253); silver w8: 584.0-1024.5 g.
15 sestertii as a foundation offering: Trajan - Commodus (AD 190-191).
81 coins of different denominations (sestertius, dupondius, as, and 1 denarius): Claudius I - Gordian III (AD 241-243).

The hoard was found at a natural spring and comprised votives (including numerous wooden statuettes) as well as '149 copper coins of Roman emprors'. 79 of these coins were identified. The others were illegible.
The find consisted of 1435 copper coins. Except for 1 provincial coin (Septimius Severus?) and 1 antoninianus radiate) of Diocletian, the rest of coins - nummi - covers the period of AD 313-383.
The hoard consisted of an unknown number of Roman coins, only 10 of them had a basic description.
c. 5500-6000), there is some information on 530 coins, and only 70 can be precisely identified: Constantius II - House of Valentinian I (AD 367-375).
disposition: Library of the Romanian Academy, (31 coins); Municipal Museum, (91 coins); Institute of Archaeology, Bucharest, (400 coins mixed ); 3000 coins in a private collection in Caracal, today lost

summary: 2 solidi apparently found in the same garden: Leo I, Libius Severus. A solidus of Justinian I is not certain as is belonging to the same find as it is menti1d "Guéret surroundings".

212 aurei found with a ceramic vessel: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211); gold w8: 724.3-734.3g. The archives of the Cabinet des Médailles preserve the list of 102 aurei sent by the in10dant Lescalopier and the register 48 bis, of the same Cabinet allows identifying 22 pieces on the lot of 110 addressed by the bishop and the chapter of Troyes to Cardinal Fleury to be presented to the King. Research carried out in the Marne and Aube archives by MM. Gandilbon and Waquet, unfortunately, did not reveal the full list of the 110 pieces.

Hoard found during archaeological excavations at the Cups Hotel, Colchester. A late Roman b1 comb was found in the same context as over 100 Roman coins, thought to be a dispersed hoard. A belt mount found nearby may have come from the same context (Crummy 1981, 7).

From 57 coins found on the excavated area, according to B. Prokisch 24 coins may have been part of a hoard: Caracalla - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 257-259). A gold bracelet was found with these coins.
48 antoniniani: Gordian III - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 16

summary: The hoard comprised a jar containing more than 7000 denarii and some radiates. Some contemporary reports suggest that there were as many as 12000 coins. Hugon suggested that the gaps in types and paucity of the latest issues and the presence almost exclusively of denarii indicated that the hoard was sorted by type and denomination and that originally there may have been further jars. Indeed, in 1943, a further vessel containing 28 denarii was found at the same findspot and is considered to be part of the same hoard.
23 denarii: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 160-161).
disposition: Museum of Dacian and Roman Civilisation, Deva, Romania

summary: 160 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Diocletian (AD 284-293).
disposition: Sold to a British private collector.

summary: The hoard comprised a vessel containing approximately 40 electrum staters. The hoard was found while digging the foundations for a new church. The majority were sold to a jeweller and dispersed. The Musée de Niort acquired some examples.

320 D: Mark Antony - Commodus (AD 180): Discovered in an onion field after it had been ploughed. The finder carefully collected the coins together, but discarded fragments of the pottery container. Found whilst harvesting onions in a field in the north-western part of the village, next to the road leading to Gruia.
26 bronze coins: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 183).
disposition: Musée Château d'Annecy, France; Registre d'entrée, II, p. 230, no. 12.428

summary: 20 antoniniani of the 3rd century AD were find during metal detecting activity. No further information

In 1837, 143 denarii and antoniniani were found on a field (Mühlen) next to the lime kiln, during excavation of an old boundary st1. No trace of a container was seen. Of these 143 coins, only 32 (Tiberius - Severus Alexander) have been described.
311 denarii and 1 drachm, ranging from Nero to Commodus (AD 187-188), found in a leather purse while cutting peat.
8 solidi of Arcadius (AD 402-406).
62 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Claudius I - Hadrian (AD 127-128)
50 Roman bronze coins. No information whether were found as a hoard.
Hoard of 126 siliquae Constantius II (AD 337-361); silver w8: 397.74g.
disposition: National History Museum of Modolva, Chișinău (125 coins) - 1951; one returned to the finder; inv.nos. 2545; 950-1076

summary: 89 nummi: Constantine I (Helena) - Arcadius (AD 383-408) Mints: Treveri 1, Lugdunum 2, Arelate 8, Aquileia 1, Roma 1, unidentified 71
The Cheshire HER lists "A small hoard comprising a silver denarius of Faustina II (AD 176), 2 unidentified Roman bronze coins and a bronze dolphin-type booch datable to 1st to 2nd century AD".
The hoard comprised more than 1500 Roman coins. The Museé de Boulogne bought 100 coins ranging from Septimius Severus to Gallienus.
53 silver coins found with a purse in the fortress wall: Antoninus Pius - Gordian III (AD 243-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Haskovo, Bulgaria; inv. no. N 1229-1238

summary: The hoard comprised 23 bronze coins dated between AD 141 and AD 251-253. "The hoard contains a mixture of imperial asses and sestertii, with bronzes from regional 'provincial' mints (Gaza, Ascalon, Caesarea Maritima, Aelia Capitolina, and Nysa-Scythopolis), many of which are countermarked." (Kool, 41).
The find comprised 2 solidi of Constantius II, which were discovered several metres from each other, but are considered to represent a hoard.
The con10t of the hoard is only briefly menti1d: 3 "aurei" in the name of Aelia Verina, now dispersed. The total gold w8 is unknown.
1173 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver w8: 317.7-1465.3g.

A hoard of ca. 677 provincial coins, ranging from Commodus Caesar to the joint reign of Valerian and Gallienus (AD 253-60), found in the sanctuary of Apollo Smintheion. Coins were mainly minted in Alexandria Troas (665 coins), but also in Parium (6 coins) and Abydus (1 coin). Çizmeli connects the deposition of this hoard with the invasions of the Goths in Asia Minor.
disposition: Laboratoire du Musée des Civilisations Anatoliennes, Ankara, Turkey

summary: Only a fraction of the coins that were once found in a pot are known. The hoard was split between various owners, with only the 7 coins currently in the Musee de l'Etat recorded.
disposition: Mr. Demuth; Mr. Michel Hoss; Dr. Graf; Mr. N. Thill

summary: The hoard comprised 8 bronze prutot dating to the reign of Mattathias Antigonus (40-37 BC) and was probably concealed in a cloth bag.
Unknown number of coins found in the 1980's. 4 pieces: 2 denarii, 2 antoniniani entered the museum collection in Targovishte: Julia Domna, Philip I, Gallienus.
129 bronze coins (1 provincial) unknown denomination: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 157-158)
The hoard comprised 252 denarii and radiates from Commodus to Quietus with a tpq of AD 260. It was found in 2 ceramic vessels.
Unknown initial number of coins. 169 (but there is evidence only on 161 coins) bronze coins were studied: Vespasian - Postumus (AD 266-267).
Hoard of 500 coins of the Bosporan kings: Ininthimeus, Rhescuporis IV and V.
Hoard of circa 600-700 denarii. 433 pieces were studied: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
The hoard comprised 2109 antoniniani (radiates) and 'aureliani' dated between AD 247-293.
72 denarii: Mark Antony - Septimius Severus (Caracalla Augustus) (AD 203); silver w8: 133.5-256.7g

The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel and comprised a number of Roman coins. All coins were sold. 94 coins in 1 particular collection are thought to originate from this hoard. Most are 'frustes'. It is possible that the composition of the hoard is incorrect and some pieces sold on the Antiquities market have entered into the record. According to family tradition, the hoard was found by Auguste Audonnet while he was constructing a hut in a field to the south of the station between the N. 171 and the railway line.
Group of 125 coins recovered from feature 0902 in subsoil of inner ditch. Found in close proximity to 1 another, along with scraps of bronze and a bronze ring.

In October 1987 members of the Andover Metal Detecting Club found 142 staters in 2 distinct clusters, approximately 55 m apart, 1 containing 58 coins and the other 84 (Haselgrove 1989, 13, 14). Each hoard - and it seems almost certain to be 2 separate deposits, rather than a scattered single hoard - contained a mixture of Gallo-Belgic E and British B (Chute) staters.
Over 248 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Gordian III - Gallienus (sole)(AD 260-268).
disposition: Museum of Vojvodina, Novi Sad, Serbia (230 coins), Vl. Macković collection Novi Sad, Serbia (18 coins) - 1982

find_spot_name: CANTERBURY, MARLOWE CAR PARK AREA M II
summary: Marlowe Car Park Area M II, scattered hoard of 119 coins, found in flood silts sealing Structure R22. Contains coins of Constantine & Valentinian (intrusive), but also of Carausius, Gallienus & barbarous radiates, latter make up approx.. half of group.
19 antoniniani found during archaeological excavations: Aurelian, Tacitus, Probus
8 coins: 7 denarii, 1 sestertius found in a destruction layer caused by fire: Vitellius - Antoninus Pius (AD 159-160).
The con10t of the hoard is only briefly menti1d: 29 "aurei" (solidi) dating to the reign of Honorius and Theodosius II, now dispersed. The total gold w8 is unknown.
The hoard comprised 400 silver coins to Gordian III or Gallienus with a tpq of AD 244/268.
190 coins found with a pot: Gordian III - Carinus (AD 283-285).
A hoard of nummi from the time of Constantine I (1022 coins listed in FMRD), found on the field 'Im Hahnen' in Weckhoven, close to Neuss, between 1951 and 1953.

353 coins, among 1 aureus of Septimius Severus, found with 2 bronze vessels: Marcus Aurelius - Valerian I and Gallienus (Valerian I) (AD 253-260). Together were found 2 gold rings and a silver necklace.
171 coins: 169 denarii,1 sestertius, 1 dupondius: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 158-159).
disposition: Balaton Museum, Keszthely (91 coins); private collection (72 coins), Hungary

summary: 874 antoniniani (radiates) found in a ceramic vessel: Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
The hoard comprised 300 coins from the Roman period.
173 nummi of the Tetrarchy.
5000 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 59 coins were recorded: 46 Augustus, 13 Tiberius.
Unknown original number of coins. 36 denarii were recovered: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).

A hoard of 12 Roman coins (apparently silver), found in 1755 while building a road from Taymouth to Glenquaich, near the crest of the hill. The same find (but described as 14 denarii) is recorded as having been found while digging the foundations of a tower near Taymouth. The coins are from the Anto9 period, n1 later that Marcus Aurelius. No further details given.
Unknown initial number of coins. 17 solidi: Valentinian I (inc. ‘RESTITVTOR’ type) - Honorius (AD 404-423); gold w8: 75.65g+.
Unknown initial number of denarii. 10 known: Antoninus Pius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235); silver w8: 58.2-107.9 g.
Unknown initial number of coins. 15518 nummi of the House of Constantine I found in 4 kegs (AD 347-348).
disposition: Cabinet des médailles de la Bibliothèque nationale de France, Paris, France

summary: Circa 30 silver coins were found with a ceramic vessel. 10 antoniniani (radiates) were identified: Gordian III - Valerian I (Gallienus) (AD 254-255).
Large hoard of Roman denarii found in 2 ceramic vessels. Only 3 have provided some information on the issuers: Trajan 2, Antoninus Pius (Marcus Aurelius caesar) 1.
Unknown number of solidi. 32 solidi were known: Theodosius II - Zeno (AD 476-491).
disposition: Cabinet des médailles de la Bibliothèque Nationale de France (10 coins).

summary: The excavation of an inhumation grave uncovered a hoard of 31 very damaged/corroded imitation nummi measuring between 6 and 8mm in diameter.
6 gold coins found in a grave during archaeological excavations: 1 solidus, 1 multiple of 1 1/2 solidus, 2 plated imitations of solidi, 1 blank: Constantine I and Constantius II (AD 347-355).
Hoard of 66 bronze staters of the Bosporan king, Rhescuporis V (AD 242-267).
Unknown initial number of coins. 2788 antoniniani: Philip I - Gallienus (AD 260-268)
disposition: National Museum, Belgrade, Serbia (2,639 coins); inv.no. 233-697, 730, 731; National Museum, Niš (149 coins), inv.no. 1668-1786

summary: The hoard comprised 283 tetradrachms dated between the reigns of Septimius Severus (AD 193-211) and Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
316 coins: Philip I - Constantius II (AD 337-361). There are some doubts whether there were other coins added at the core of this hoard.
315 denarii: Vespasian - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 236).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2319/1-315

summary: A hoard of 768 nummi (first Tetrarchy, AD 295-305), originally wrapped in a linen cloth, found in the barracks of the Roman fort of Vemania. The hoard was buried in early AD 305, Garbsch / Kos, pp. 70-1. N.B. Though the number of coins catalogued is 768, the total number of coins is menti1d several times as 771 in the publication of Garbsch / Kos.
An unknown number of silver coins: 1 denarius, 16 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2631

summary: Over 56 aurei and argenterei of the Tetrarchy found in a ceramic vessel; 22 coins of Diocletian and 10 argentei of Galerius were known (AD 305).
The hoard comprised 10 bronze coins dated between 175-173/2 BC and AD 98-117.

Snettisham hoards B and C were initially discovered by a tractor driver in November 1948. When the finds were collected, the 2 hoards became mixed. The 12 coins from hoard B listed here, however, were not discovered until the excavation which was directed by Clarke in December 1948. The torcs listed here may have been associated with hoard B or C.
152 denarii: Vespasian - Caracalla (AD 211-217). Circumstances of find not known.
2 ceramic vessels containing over 8500 antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
Unknown initial number of coins. only 6 silver coins are known: Gordian III, Philip I, Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver w8: 7.5 g.

Scattered hoard, found in the Dünnern river bed during correction works of the river bed. Over 1100 coins reported, 906 of them preserved. 8 coins from the 1st/2nd c. AD, the others range from Septimius Severus to Aurelian and Postumus to Tetricus II. Mostly antoniniani, except for the 1st/2nd c. coins and a denarius of Gordian III. Large numbers of coins from Gallienus and Claudius II.
A hoard of 40 provincial coins from Athens (periods VB, VB/C, VC and VI), found among brocken crockery on the floor of the kitchen of the south house, on the northern slope of the Hill of the Nymphs.

HER record of 5 clipped siliquae "and some copper alloy coins" found at a rally in 1993 and noted as a possible hoard. This hoard does not seem to have been recorded elsewere from the limited information available.
Originally 44 coins, 41 pieces recovered: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).

1005 nummi: Constantine I - Constantius II (AD 350). "Mints: Alexandria (28); Antiochia (45); Aquileia (48); Arelate (2); Heraclea (26); Constantinopolis (55); Cyzicus (81); Lugdunum (1); Nicomedia (71); Roma (37); Siscia (142); Thessalonica (177); Treveri (4)".

HER record of a scattered hoard of 117 coins from Gallienus to Tetricus "with 1 very clipped denarius" and further finds from area. As far as it is possible to ascertain, this is not part of the other hoards recorded from the parish.
The hoard comprised 2445 silver coins (denarii and antoniniani-radiates) from Septimius Severus to Valerian I (AD 257) found in a lead container.
5 AE (2 Hadrian, 1 Antoninus Pius and 2 unidentified)

Hoard of radiates from the excavations at Angel Yard, Colchester. The exact number is uncertain - the exis10ce of a scattered hoard was assumed from the profile of coin loss at the site. The coins were distributed in an accumulation of topsoil dating from the third century to the medieval period. A group of 9 denarii to AD 222, a group of silvered radiates and a group of barbarous radiates are all thought to have come from this hoard accoding to Crummy and Crummy (1990, 4) but it is perhaps more likely that more than 1 hoard was present within this group.
10 coins (denarius, as, dupondius) from Republic to Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
A bunch of 12 antoniniani: Claudius II - Probus (AD 276-282).
526 nummi: Constantius II - Valens (AD 364-378). No further details
disposition: Accademia di Sant’Anselmo di Aosta, Italy

summary: Originally, 47 coins. 33 denarii were described: Vitellius - Trajan (AD 103-111).
Hoard of 191 coins: 190 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 Roman provincial coin (Ephesus) found as a pile on the caldarium's floor: Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 272).

140 antoniniani were found on the bottom of a ceramic vessel by the excavation team of the University of Milan. Based on preliminary information drawn from the web, coins in this hoard date to the reign of Gallienus (AD 260-268).
500 sestertii found in a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Severus alexander (AD 226).
Aureus of Trajan Decius found together with and a denarius imitation.
158 denarii: Republic - Nerva (AD 96-98). Found together with 3 silver torques.
6 gold Gallo-Belgic E staters, found in 2 groups of 3.
A small hoard of Iron Age coins from Alfriston, but it exact composition remains subject to discussions.
Child's burial, found by the local teacher; among grave goods 3 coins to the left of the body, Augustus, Tiberius and Claudius I. No details given on the metal, so probably Aes.
242 tinned bronze nummi from the time of the Tetrarchy (Diocletian - Constantine I), buried in rouleaux between the bricks of the floor of a Roman house at the back of the temple.
7 asses: Domitianus - Hadrianus (AD 121-122).
(?) 17 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) with portraits of Julia Domna, Gordian III, Valerian I, Gallienus, Claudius II (AD 268-270).
14 bronze coins: 10 dupondii, 4 asses: Tiberius - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 164-169).
8 coins: 5 double sestertii, 2 sestertii, 1 dupondius: Antoninus Pius - Postumus (AD 261-269).
3 aurei; Hadrian 2, Antoninus Pius for Faustina I.
107 denarii, ranging up to AD 227 (Severus Alexander).
disposition: Society of Antiquaries of Newcastle upon Tyne

summary: 111 denarii, 29 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 sestertius, ranging from Hadrian to Trebonianus Gallus (Hostilian). The coins that make up this hoard were found a ceramic beaker, which was found in a pit in the northwest corner of a house that contained a metal workshop for bronze. Fragments of a 1:1 bronze statue (possibly an imperial statue) were found close to where the beaker with the coins was discovered.

6 (or more?) Roman gold coins found on a field. First, 3 were found by labourers in 1845: Domitian (1 coin) and Hadrian (2 coins). Then came a report that "2 years ago" 2 aurei of Vespasian had been found in the same field, and probably more, thrown out by the labourers as brass items. In 1860 another gold coin found in the same field was reported. - The 3 aurei found in 1845 were described in detail and documented in sealing wax (lost) and later copied in drawings (preserved).

1043 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Diocletian (AD 285-286). The emperors represented include: Valerian, Gallienus, Claudius II, Quintillus, Divus Claudius II, 'Imp. Gallo', Aurelian and Probus. However, the original number of coins was ca. 3.840.
disposition: Museu de Arqueologia e Numismática de Vila Real, Spain

summary: Unknown originally number of coins 'a handful of Roman coins'. Only 2 nummi of Magnentius are known.

A hoard of 255 Icenian and 72 Roman silver coins found in early 1972 on a building site at Lord's Walk, Eriswell, Suffolk. The condition of the latest Icenian coins in the hoard is worse than that of the latest Roman, and suggest that the minting of Icenian silver ceased well before 60, perhaps even in 43.
The hoard was found in a broken ceramic vessel. It comprised approximately 150 'large bronzes' likely to be sestertii. The hoard was discovered by a farm labourer on the plain of Saint-Rémy.
Originally, 274 nummi, 119 coins available for study dated between AD 335 and AD 361.
The hoard comprised 700 Republican and imperial denarii and 12 aureii of Domitian.
Hoard of around 20 gold coins - aurei and solidi: Diocletian - Magnentius. Found together with 2 gold plated bracelets.

The hoard comprised 9000 antoniniani (radiates) (35kg) found in a terracotta vessel: Valerian I - Dioletian/Maximian I (AD 284-293). L. Dancoisne bought 1000 of the more interesting and better conserved coins, which may not be representative of the whole assemblage. Found whilst digging in garden; silver w8: 1621.1-11249.1 g+.

In 1732 a hoard was found in "Herrenwäldchen" near Schloßborn, whose con10t was soon afterwards identified as "heydnische müntz," which was at the time definitely a description for Roman coins. The coins, described as 'white', were melted down, totalling a w8 of 3044.446 g, which would correspond to 700 antoniniani or 1000 denarii.
184 nummi found with a ceramic vessel. The large number belong to thee issues of Gratian with the reverse type REPARATIO REIPVB, ending with issues of Honorius.
2 denarii found on a field: Antoninus Pius, Commodus (AD 185).

2 aurei of Vespasian (AD 69-79) and an aureus of Domitian (81-96). Uncertain whether they were found together. However, the chronological segment, the close vicinity of findspots and the absence of any other Roman artefact found in this area may suggest a hoard.
4 denarii (2 Republic, 1 Tiberius, 1 Trajan) to Trajan and 4 IA gold staters
227 denarii and antoniniani found in ceramic vessel during archaeological excavation in a villa rustica: Maximinus I Thrax - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2548/1-240

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 43 denarii are kept at the town museum in Piatra Neamț, Romania: Republic – Antoninus Pius (AD 147-148).
disposition: Town museum, Piatra Neamț, Romania (43 coins)

summary: (58) 14 coins were donated: 7 republican denarii, 6 imperial denarii, 1 provincial bronze: Republic - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver w8: 76.6-205.9 g.
41 denarii: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (Divus Antoninus Pius) (AD 161)
The hoard comprised 188 bronze coins from a variety of provincial mints in the Levant.

Urn, containing about 300 silver coins, found in 1852 while making a ditch at Weston, near Attlebridge. These were Iron Age coins, associated with 3 Republican denarii. Only 54 of the Iron Age coins can still be reliably identified today.
92 silver coins: 91 denari, 1 antoninian (radiate): Hadrian - Severus Alexander (AD 230).
disposition: Museo Archeologico Nazionale, Monetiere di Firenze, Italy (inv.no. 78377-78458)

summary: The hoard comprised around 72 tetradrachms, 'recently found near Tyre' and sold by Sotheby (26 March 1888, lot 170-190): 6 Seleucid coins, 17 from Arados, 11 from Tyre, and 38 (?) from Antioch (Augustus to Vespasian according to Noe, though the Sotheby catalogue also lists a coin of Philip, which might be an intruder, if this is really a hoard).
400 nummi, almost all of the Constantinian period were found with a ceramic vessel.
A small hoard of dupondii and asses was found during the excavation of Tomb 68 in excavations of the site: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
The hoard comprised 10 Imperial denarii. No further details were given regarding the composition of the hoard.
131 Roman nummi and 1 Naimana imitation: House of Theodosius - Theodosius II (AD 425-435). Supposedly given to the Colombo Museum in 1935.
117000 ”bronze coins of the 3rd century”, weighing about 38 kg, buried in a pit sealed by tiles. Probably, they were in10ded for re-minting.
disposition: Institut national de recherche archéologique préventive

summary: 2 silver units of EISV found in the same field in 1990 and 1998 and recorded with the CCI. E. Ghey notes: Penhallurick (2009, 104-109) lists a variety of coins metal detected from the same field and immediately surrounding area between 1990 and 1998. It is difficult to disentangle separate hoards from what we now know is settlement evidence. However these 2 Iron Age coins have been considered here separately as a hoard due to the unusual nature of this find.

A hoard of no less than 27 Roman imperial denarii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211) was discovered by a treasure hunter in the late 2010s near the village of Filiopil in the Vinnytsia region. The hoard was found at the foot of a medieval earthen defense structure. The coins were collected from an area of 30x30 m. After the first search, 37 coins were found, and it is likely that other treasure hunters have subsequently searched the site. The finder reports that the coins were well preserved, with bronze oxides. In total I have been informed of finds of denarii from the time of Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Commodus and Clodius Albinus. The photos I received from the finder show images of 10 coins (Trajan, Hadrian, Marcus Aurelius, Lucius Verus, Commodus, Clodius Albinus, Septimius Severus). The further fate of the coins is unknown to me.
20 AR denarii to AD 37.
93 nummi found while investigating within the fort. 88 coins were studied, all of the Constantine's I family (AD333-337).
200+ sestertii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
The hoard comprised approximately 150 antoniniani (radiates). Only 12 were identified, all being of Valerian I.
12 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 125-127).

The hoard comprised a copper-alloy spoon and 147 copper-alloy coins from Titus, Domitian, Nerva, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Lucilla, Commodus, Septimius Severus, Julia Domna, Caracalla, Julia Mamaea, Severus Alexander, Maximinus, Pupienus, Gordian III and Philip II.

469 (or more?) silver coins of Caesarea in Cappadocia found with a ceramic vessel. These range from Nero to Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169). The hoard also included 1 denarius of Augustus and a barbarous imitation of a stater of Lysimachus.
disposition: National Museum of Georgia; National Museum of Abkhazia (91 coins); Pushkin Museum of Fine Arts in Moscow, Russia (104 coins)

summary: At least 453 coins found by a boy in a ploughed field at Pertlow Farm, Aylesbury, ca. 1937-1939, ending before AD 375. The hoard was dispersed, but lists of 2 lots of coins exist, 1 of 36 small AE coins, from Constantius II to Valentinian II, and the other of 417 coins (1 ant. and 416 AE). It was noted that n1 of theses coins was clipped.
11 provincial bronze coins minted in Hadrianopolis found in the dirt when digging a sewer: Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Kardzhali, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 618, 624, 628, 632, 635, 639, 642, 645, 648, 654, 657, 684, 694

summary: Circa 50 denarii: Republic – Vespasian (AD 69-79).
381 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 260-269).
Coin hoard consisting of 54 Roman sestertii (Domitian - Commodus) was discovered in 1922 while excavating an old lime tree. The coins were stratified in 3 layered rolls. They have been lost.

A hoard of 8 complete and 1 halved Roman provincial copper alloy coins (Antioch, Beroea, Laodicea, uncertain) from the reigns of Trajan and Antoninus Pius, found at Assur, iC6V, West, 50 cm below the surface of the hill.
43 bronze coins: 1 antoninianus (radiate), 42 nummi: Gallienus - Honorius/Valentinian III (AD 408-435).
2 clipped solidi - Justin I, Justinian I - found in a grave dated during the Sui dynasty (AD 581-618).

A group of 14 Roman provincial bronzes of Pontic cities (Zela, Amasia, Comana, Sebastopolis), now in the Ankara museum, and judging from its composition, probably found nearby Zela. All coins were minted in the year 205/206, under Septimius Severus.
32 antoniniani (radiates) belonging to a purse: Gallienus (sole) - Quintillus (AD 270).
disposition: Museum Lauriacum - Museum der Stadt Enns, Austria

summary: In 1955 an earthenware container with 7 antoniniani and 888 nummi (Tacitus - Constantine I, AD 318) was found within remains of a Roman occupation layer, during excavation of a dung pit on the site of Winger street.

The hoard was found within the temple temenos in Insula 20 at Colonia Ulpia Traiana. It comprised 390 denarii and radiates from Marcus Aurelius to Postumus with a tpq of AD 260 to 269, as well as a gold finger ring, 2 silver finger rings, a pair of gold earrings, a silver bowl, 3 silver spoons, some silver fragments and a copper-alloy vessel. A silver denarius of Hadrian was set into 1 of the silver finger rings.

Found in1935, the 3378 nummi of the Tetrarchy and Maxentius were deposited in the Archaeological Museum in Pula, Croatia. Shortly before the end of the Second World War, the find was taken to Italy; afterwards it was brought back, but only only 2150 coins.
67 potin coins. These could be were Massiliot issues or more plausibly Kentish derivatives.
At least 100 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 92 were studied: Nero - Septimius Severus/Caracalla (AD 193-217).
Unknown original number of coins. Only 10 pieces were recovered: 8 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate), 1 plated denarius: Trajan - Gordian III (AD 241-243).

A hoard of 500 silver coins (Mark Antony - Caracalla) found in a beaker on a new housing site, to be known as Clarney Place. The find was made 400 yards from the Darfield 1947 (Darfield I) hoard, but their depositions do not seem to be related. Carson and Corder published the hoard in 1948, but the catalogue does not align exactly to the coin summary. Trajan, Hadrian, Septimius Severus and Caracalla all have 1 fewer specimens in the catalogue compared to the summary, while the reverse is true for Otho. Since it is agreed that the hoard numbered 500, the summary has been regarded as the correct description of the hoard's con10ts.
The hoard comprised 27 coins from Gallienus to Postumus and Tetricus I and 1 gold ring. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of between 8.7 and 31.5 g.
Unknown original number of denarii. 32 denarii have been studied: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193).

A hoard of 169 bronze coins (K.2387) found at Kish in Mesopotamia, east of Babylon, in the Sasanian levels. The coins were badly preserved and only ⅔ of the coins could be identified. These are 1 chalcus of Seleucus I (N.B. The opening year of the hoard does not include this coin), 98 Late Roman bronzes (House of Constantine: 2; House of Valentinian; House of Theodosius: 69; uncertain: 23), 9 Sasanian bronzes (badly struck, only 1 could be identified: Bahram V).
disposition: Ashmolean Museum, Heberden Coin room (accessioned on 20.9.1933)

summary: 67 silver coins: 63 denarii, 4 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Direction des antiquités historiques, Paris, France

summary: Hoard of 340 denarii were found with a bronze cauldron. Together was a silver ring.
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia

summary: 88 nummi found as a homogenous pile - probably leather bag - in a fire layer. The coins have been published, so far, only by chronological segments: House of Constantine I - Honorius (AD 410-423).
disposition: Sección de Investigación Arqueológica Municipal (SIAM), Valencia, Spain

summary: 3 coins: 1 antoninianus Aurelian, 3 provincial bronzes of Faustina II.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Kyustendil, Bulgaria; inv. no. 1289-1317

summary: Found in the necropolis of Hawara during the excavations of W.M. Flinders Petrie in 1888, in a jar and interpreted as a funeral offering by Flinders Petrie. First published in 1938. The hoard comprised 303 late Roman coins, 43 cast imitations and 2 Byzantine coins.
62 coins: 2 denarii, 1 dupondius, 59 asses: Augustus - Claudius I (AD 41-54).
Unknown initial number of coins. 6 antoniniani of Trebonianus Gallus are kept in the Regional History Museum Vidin (AD 251-253).
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. no. 11759-11764

summary: 19 nummi found inside the place for the handle of the mobile side of a st1 hand-mill: Constans - Valentinian II (AD 378-383).
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 200 denarii dating to the first century AD.

2 detectorists found 9teen Chute staters in an area of about 1.7 m diameter, at a depth of 5-10 cm, between 12-14 May 1987 (Cowell et al. 1987, 6-7). Examination of the site by Andover Museum located "a pit nearby with a charcoal layer at the bottom", but it is not clear if it had any definite relationship with the hoard.
261 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Valerian I and Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).
6 coins found in associated with box fittings "of a type of10 associated with casket burials" (Crummy 1987, 75) from Culver Street site J (insula 34) in Colchester.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 8000 well-preserved antoniniani (radiates) depicting 28 emperors from Gallienus to Maximian I (AD 285-293).
The hoard comprised between 30 and 40 electrum staters of Type LT XIII, 4395, weighing between 6.5g and 6.8g. There is no suggestion that a Namnète stater found in Savenay is part of this hoard.
The hoard comprised 6 gold coins from AD 337-350 to AD 527-565.
Around 1200 antoniniani (radiates) found with amphoras on a shipwreck. 229 coins were studied: Gallienus (sole) - Maximian I (AD 284-293).

The hoard comprised 23 sestertii struck for Trajan, Hadrian, and Antoninus Pius. Discovered at a depth of 4 metres when a drainage ditch was being dug during road improvement works to the south of the railway station in Kiesen.
Hoard of antoniniani (radiates) and denarii. 128 coins were kept in the museum in Modena in 1829: Maximinus I Thrax (Diva Paulina) - Claudius II (AD 268-270).

The hoard was found in association with broken vessels and a copper-alloy bracelet. It comprised a considerable number of Iron Age coins. It is not clear whether the coins were originally contained within a vessel. The total number of coins included in the hoard is not precise. According to Grille, there were 100s of PB and 1000s of quinarii. According to Bellouard, there were 2 bushels. Dr Gruet estimated that there were 6000 potins and 25000 silver coins. The hoard was found by M. Roncin while digging a pond. The hoard was found in a sump filled with dark earth. 55 examples were acquired by the Cabinet des Médailles (BN 6432-6486). 50 were acquired by the Musée d'Angers.
4 asses found on an artillery practice ground by metal detecting: Augustus, Claudius I, Titus, Nerva (AD 96-97).

20313 nummi of the Tetrarchy before and after the reduction of Maxentius divided by mints. Before the reduction (3168 coins): Gaul 132, Rome 661, Carthage 2002, Ticinum/Aquileia 373; after reduction (171455 coins): Rome 8002, Ostia 5190; Carthage 1099, Ticinum/Aquileia 825, Balkans and East 196, uncertain 1833 (AD 310-311).
25 denarii found on the east wing of the north facing gate: Galba - Caracalla (Julia Domna) (AD 214).
3 solidi minted in Treveri: Valens 2, Gratian 1 (AD 367-375); gold w8: 13.35g.

A hoard of approx. 400 Roman Imperial denarii from 1st-2nd AD and other late Roman – early Great Migration period silver, bronze and gold items were found by a treasure hunter at the end of July 2021 and then its photos were published on the Ukrainian forum for treasure hunters Violity. According to the finder, the coins and items were found together. 4 gold pelta-shaped pendants with zoomorphic ornaments, 4 gold leaf-shaped pendants (same type from Brangstrup hoard, Denmark), 24 silver temporal rings, 3 silver axe-shaped pendants with rings, silver shield-shaped pendant, 5 different types of plate pendants, plough-shaped pendant with ring, silver neck ring, silver and bronze buckle, fragments of silver brooch (?), and others.
IARCH record for a group of 99 base metal coins, primarily Magnentian with a few earlier radiates and nummi plus 1 Valentinianic nummus. The coins were in poor condition.

A hoard of 50-60 antoniniani, ranging from Gallienus to Maximian I, uncovered in 1961 at the construction of a garage. Further particulars about the find circumstances are unknown. Only 40 coins have been described.

find_spot_name: CANTERBURY ROSE LANE SITE E XXI, B (1) HOARD 3
summary: Rose Lane Site E XXI, B (1) Hoard 3. 117 coins from Claudius II to House of Theodosius, with 47 of latter; & incl. 33 illegible 4th C. coins.
The hoard comprised a coarseware urn containing 1806 radiates from Valerian I and Gallienus to Allectus.
Found during excavations, in an early medieval cemetery. Tomb 569B: inhumation, male; among grave goods 3 (?) Aes coins, part of the "Tascheninhalt".
The hoard was found in a burial of the Late Empire and comprised a purse containing 25 nummi of Licinius, Crispus, Constantius II, Valentinian I, Valens and Valentinian II.
4 Danubian tetradrachms and 4 Iron Age staters found in Portland in 1720. De Jersey considers it unlikely that the British coin was deposited with the Danubian tetradrachms.
The hoard comprised 20 nummi dating between AD 383 and AD 395.
1 kilo of silver coins found with a Dacian ceramic vessel. Only 8 denarii were recovered: Republic 7, Vespasian (Domitian Caesar) 1.
disposition: Eastern Carpathian Museum, Sfântu Gheorghe, Romania (inv.nos. 16023-16033)

summary: The hoard comprised 26 bronze coins and 3 silver coins dated between the reigns of Vespasian and Hadrian.
118 coins : 114 bronzes and 4 denarii (1 nummus of Constantin intrusive)
758 coins from Augustus to Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
disposition: Medagliere del Museo Nazionale Romano, Roma, Italy

summary: 64 denarii found with a ceramic vessel in a Roman Villa: Republic - Augustus (Lugdunum, 2 BC - 4 AD).
The hoard comprised 1 vessel containing 8760 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian, Gallienus, Claudius Gothicus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II and Aurelianus. Silver w8: 1664.9-6394.3g.
12 bronze coins: 11 sestertii, 1 dupondius/as found stuch together in a layer of fire: Nero - Hadrian (AD 129-130).
Over 50 nummi, among them 1 coin of Honorius
37 sestertii found during rescue excavations. 32 coins were found in a ceramic jug and 5 next to it: Vespasian - Commodus (Divus Marcus Aurelius) (AD 180).
The hoard comprised over 8550 nummi, 1608 of which have been identified, dated between the reigns of Constantine I (AD 307-337) and Valens (AD 364-378).
72 coins: 4 solidi, 68 siliquae: House of Valentinian (AD 364-392).
The coins were found during the rescue excavation of a villa: Trajan - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
Unknown number of denarii. Only 2 of them are known: Hadrian, Marcus Aurelius for Lucilla (AD 161-180).
30 denarii: Augustus - Antoninus Pius (AD 140-144). Found near the Roman villa.
156 coins: 2 antoniniani (radiates), 143 sestertii, 3 dupondii, 8 asses; silver w8: 6.4-8.6g.
In 1934, 40 denarii and 12 sestertii were found with an urn in a field north of Narcott Lane. The coins range from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius.

The hoard comprised 353 radiates from Caracalla to the joint reign of Valerian and Gallienus with a terminus post quem of AD 257. The alloy of the 2 latest coins (RIC 241, 377) is described by FMRD as extremely good which is taken as an indication that these coinsmust date from the beginning of the joint reign of Valerian and Gallienus (AD 253), and not AD 257 as suggested in RIC. FMRD therefore gives the terminus post quem as 253 and sees a relationship between the deposition of the hoard and the incursions of the Germans the same year.
disposition: Stadtmuseum Ludwigshafen (but some coins are lost)

summary: The hoard was found deposited in an old wall and comprised 838 antoniniani (radiates). Hucher compiled a catalogue of 810 coins: Trajan Decius - Postumus (AD 260-269). Hucher acquired 351 coins for the Musée du Mans (Manuscript of entries 1863-1909, p. 4 and 5) and the Hospice kept 487 coins.Silver w8: 227.2-1046.5 g.
88 nummi
Originally were 196 coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 88 coins were recovered: Claudius II (Divus) - House of Theodosius I (AD 388-392).
disposition: Câmara Municipal de Ribeira de Pena, Portugal

summary: 3 coins: 1 denarius Antoninus Pius, 2 aurei Probus (AD 276-282).
disposition: Collection de Pitteurs, Budingen, Belgium, in 1850

summary: The hoard comprised 5 gold coins, 15 silver coins, and 4 bronze coins dated to the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
Over 1000 denarii. Only 13 coins were described: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (Faustina I Diva) (AD post AD 141).
2 Gallo-Belgic E staters found 40 m apart, on 1 March and 23 March 1987, with no trace of a container; not certainly a hoard.

Hoard of 386 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211). Together were found jewelry: 30 silver rings with pearls, 1 silver twisted bracelet, silver large rings/bracelets, 20 amber perls, silver ring with 1 coin of Constantius II (!) mounted.

A hoard of 178 Roman denarii, ranging from Marc Antony to Hadrian, found at the bottom of an earthenware jar in 1934, in a field south of Louth, Lincolnshire. Among the coins, 1 hybrid of Domitian with a reverse of Hadrian (now in the BM).
disposition: Lincoln City and County Museum (part); British Museum (part)

summary: 14 silver coins: 3 denarii, 11 antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - Valerian I (AD 257-258); Silver w8: 17.9-30.6 g.

A small hoard consisting of 28 Roman imperial denarii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211) and a silver lunula was found by a treasure hunter in 2020 on the border of Cherkassy and Kirovohrad regions, near the village Kapitanivka, in the direction to the village Zhuravka. The hoard was found in the forest, on the slope of a ravine (20-30 m from bottom; the angle of the slope is about 15-20 degrees), at a depth of 50-60 cm. Together with the coins, several fragments of pottery were found.
2 gold coins - 1 Valentinian I, 1 unidentified - were found in the vicinity of skeleton. The coin of Valentinian was dated in AD 368 (!). No description.
Unknown originally number of denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 304 coins were recovered together with the vessel's sherds: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195).

In the vicus located at the Roman In the vicus located at the Roman crossroads near the La Mône a vessel of 40 kg (8-10000 bronze and billon coins) was found. The sestertii run from Augustus to Postumus, while the denarii and antoniniani (radiates from Antoninus Pius to Macrinus and Quietus (AD 270).
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 250 Roman coins of Gallienus, Saloninus, Postumus, Marius, Victorinus, Tetricus, Claudius II, Quintillus and Aurelian.
104 gold coins: 36 solidi, 68 tremisses “mostly barbarous”: Leo I - Justin I (c. AD 525); gold w8: 262.2g. Together were found a chalice and a golden plate.
483 antoniniani: Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282)
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria (unknown number)

summary: 21 coins found hidden behind in a wall whole in a Roman villa: 1 antoninianus (radiate), 18 sestertii, 2 asses: Domitian - Philip I (AD 244-249).
The hoard comprised 20 nummi dating to the period AD 351-354 and AD 395-408.

Hoard found during railway construction work, probably from the area of the site of a Roman villa rustica. It comprisesd at least 2114 coins, but no more than 2300. Coins run from Valerian to Aurelian, mainly Gallienus and Claudius II. Reported coins of Tacitus, Probus and Diocletianus (dated 289) seem to be intruders from the Reichenstein hoard (Schaub-Gysin 1930, p. 70).
88 antoniniani (radiates) found by metal detecting. Only 44 pieces were available for study.
2000 denarii and antoniniani. 872 coins in the Regional History Museum in Vratsa: Vespasian - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv. nos. M III 5335-6194 (860 coins); inv.nos. 8407-8418 (12 coins)

summary: 40 nummi found together during the excavations in the Roman forum: House of Constantine I and Magnentius (AD 353).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Nacional de Tarragona, Spain

summary: 84 antoniniani (radiates) from the area of Lisbon: Gallienus (sole) - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
disposition: The British Museum (?), London, United Kingdom

summary: Hoard of 171 denarii, only 139 were recorded: Nero – Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Museum Complex Iași, Romania (121 coins); National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (50 coins)

summary: During the excavation of the Roman town, 2 small hoards of both silver and bronze were found from below the front of site VI. Hoard A comprised 23 coins, ending with Hadrian.
The hoard was enclosed or set within a square-cut st1 and comprised 11 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I and Gallienus to Postumus (including E.384 and E.385).

The circumstances of discovery and the composition of the hoard were judged to be suspect. De Vesly questi1d whether this hoard might actually have been stolen and assembled as a hoard. However, there is nothing to support this hypothesis. Found by a workman in a quarry in the Duclair forest: Nero - Hadrian (AD 125-128). 2 or 4 coins are missing.
The hoard comprised 11 Tyrian tetradrachms, dated between 142-29 BC.
14 denarii found with ceramic vessel of which only 5 are known today: Trajan 2, Hadrian 1, Hadrian (Antoninus Pius Caesar) 1, Antoninus Pius 1 (AD 140-143).
Hoard given to Sfax Museum in October 1961, examined by Salama: 36 antoniniani: Valerian I and Gallienus - Gallienus (sole)? (AD 260-268).
(c. 1 kg) 90 nummi of the House of Constantine (AD 330-341).
The hoard comprised 9 nummi of the House of Constantine with a tpq of AD 309 to 315. It was found on the banks of the River Danube.
(500-600) 120 republican denarii (tpq 36 BC).
Around 560 gold coins. Only 4 or so were seen; latest coins of Valentinian III (AD c. 440?).
40-7ound with a ceramic vessel. 45 coins provide information on issuers: Vespasian - Caracalla (Julia Domna) (AD 211-217).
18 nummi of the Constantine I and his family (AD 330-335?).
The hoard was found in a human inhumation burial and comprised a pile of 27 nummi placed between the tibia b1s of the skeleton. The coins were corroded and stuck together.
A hoard of late Roman coins comprising 19 gold solidi, 114 silver siliquae and 2 copper-alloy radiates. The silver coins are all clipped.
A find, comprising 1 aureus and 7 denarii, was made at the south end of site XXVIII. The coins were found loose on the floor of a house of the Anto9 period.
The hoard comprised over 100 Tyrian Shekels, dated to year 166 (AD 40/41).
(304) 294 coins: 123 antoniniani (radiates), 1 argenteus, 170 nummi: Caracalla - Constantine I (AD 306-337). Mints: Londinium, Lugdunum, Arelate, Treveri, Roma, Carthago, Siscia.

3044 coins: 3029 antoniniani (radiates), 14 denarii, 1 provincial coin: Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 274-275). "The bulk of the hoard was formed in 273; several pieces, if not intrusions, were added in 285." (Harl, 79, n. 11).

75 coins: 73 antoniniani, 1 as, 1 as/dupondius found in a house at an altar, ranging from Domitian/Hadrian to Carinus for Numerian (Augustus) (AD 283-284). The specimens listed here follow Marion's publication, but Thouvenot's inventory differs slightly in that he records 2 specimens of RIC Gallienus 178, only single specimens of RIC 207 and 28, he omits RIC 36, 45/6 and 1 illegible specimen for Claudius Gothicus, but instead gives 2 examples of RIC 48 and another illegible type, and he also mistakes RIC 705 (Antoninus Pius) for a silver coin.
9042 silver coins: denarii, antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Valerian I (AD: 257-259); silver w8: 11297.5 g. Approx. 300 unidentified badly preserved coins.

Iron age staters from the trade which all seem to have originated from the same source, and have probably formed all or part of an undeclared hoard. It combine an unusual and poorly understood uninscribed type - the W1rsh stater (ABC 527) - with staters of Commios, and with the rarest type of Tincomarus (ABC 1052). The list of con10ts provided here should be treated with some caution given the lack of reliable information (de Jersey).
23 nummi: Constantine I - Magnus Maximus (AD 383-388).
3124 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258).
17 sestertii found with a large black urn. The earliest coin belongs to Gaius, the latest 1 to Titus (AD 80-81).
A hoard of more than 280+ late Hellenistic and Provincial large bronzes from Rhodes, dispersed in trade.
12 nummi found with a jug: House of Constantine I - Zeno (AD 474-491).
The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing between 1500 and 1800 antoniniani (radiates) and 3 sestertii of Divus Antoninus Pius, Severus Alexander and Postumus.
This hoard comprised 3727 imitations of antoniniani (radiates) of c. AD 265-275.
56 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2069

summary: Found during uprooting an old tree, in a pot. The early reports give varying dates of discovery (1809 or 1810), numbers of coins (2000 or 4000 coins) and lists of emperors represented. Probably a 3rd century hoard of debased radiates, Tetricus/Quintillus/Claudius II/Gallienus, mixed later with some other coins. Today, only 7 coins preserved: 6 antoniniani of Gallienus and 1 nummus (aes III) of Valens.
disposition: Bernisches Historisches Museum (6 ex.); Schweizerisches Landesmuseum Zürich (1 ex.); the rest lost

summary: 63 republican and imperial denarii: Republic - Augustus (2 BC - AD 4).
The con10t of the hoard is only briefly menti1d: 20 gold coins ranging from Valentinian I to Constantius III (?), most probably Constantine III, now dispersed. The total gold w8 is unknown.
The hoard comprised at least 12 Tyrian Shekels (126/125 BC- AD 69/70) and shekels of the First Jewish Revolt.
disposition: A. Reifenberg, on loan to the Israel Museum

summary: 40-8 Roman denarii were found with a ceramic vessel in the rubble of a Sarmatian house in 1995 in the area of ​​an Avar burial ground in Hetényegyháza.
Around 100 bronze coins of 'large and medium size' from Trajan to Postumus (?) (AD 260-268).

The hoard comprised 2769 coins including a plated copy of a denarius of Severus Alexander and radiates from Valerian to Probus. It was found concealed in a broken ceramic vessel covered with a schist slab in a cavity in the southern wall of Building E (V) of a Gallo-Roman villa. Elements of the hoard were found on 2 occasions. First, in August 1983 and then in 1984 when further excavation of the site took place. Severus Alexander (plated denarius); Valerian I and Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée National d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg, Luxembourg; inv.no. 1984-72

summary: (303) 292 silver coins: 240 denarii, 52 antoniniani (radiates): Vespasian - Philip I (AD 247-249); silver w8: 380.4-892.2 g.
11 provincial bronzes issued in Rhesaena by Trajan Decius and his family, found in destruction deposits of Room 9J.

A hoard of 127 bronze Bosporan coins of 1st–3rd centuries AD was accidentally found at the Mithradates Mount in Panticapaeum in 2009. It comprises Bosporan staters of the following Bosporan Kings: Sauromates I – 4; Cotys II – 3; Rhoemetalkes – 3; Rhescuporis III – 48; Cotys III – 3; Sauromates III – 8; Rhescuporis IV – 2; Ininthimeus – 31.
The hoard comprised coins from Gallienus to Probus. There are some doubts on the real number of coins from this hoard!
4 solidi of Gratian minted in Treveri (AD 375-378); Gold w8: 17.8g.
The hoard comprised 800 bronze coins of the Nabataeans.
disposition: Kadman Numismatic Pavilion at Muza Eretz Israel Museum Tel Aviv

summary: 28 antoniniani found during a fieldwalking: Elagabalus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 256).
76 imperial and provincial bronze coins were found in a ceramic vessel: 46 sestertii, 24 dupondii, 1 as, 2 nummi, 3 provincial bronzes: Domitian - Diocletian (AD 284-305).
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Burgas, Bulgaria

summary: The composition of this hoard was reconstructed by Paul Reinecke. The coins (10 denarii, ranging from Galba to Maximinus) were found in a wood belonging to the abbey at Met10, soon after 1800.
102 coins: 80 antoniniani, 22 denari: Elagabalus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 255-257).

(+250) 243 Celtic and Roman republican silver coins. 37 Celtic coins of the horseman type and inscriptions DORNACOS/AVSCROS and DVRNACVS/DONNVS. 206 Roman republican coins: 195 denarii, 11 quinarii: 211 BC - 27 BC.
disposition: Musée archéologie nationale, Saint-Germain-en-Laye, France (Inv.no. 1153-1355 - Roman coins; inv.no. 1356-1392 - Celtic coins)

summary: 11 bronze coins, dupondii and asses. 9 of Augustus (1-6 BC).
4127 antoniniani: Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver w8: c. 1261.0-5249.0 g
disposition: Musée d'Annecy, France; inv.no. 3477 (3828 coins); 400 coins dispersed

summary: In 1853 not far from the Oste river during earthworks 3 bronze coins (Marcus Aurelius) were found at a depth of 10 feet. Pit holes and other remains indicate a settlement.
A hoard of around 270 copper coinage, only 229 were recovered and identified: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 158-161).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Split, Croatia; partly dispersed

summary: 73 solidi of 1 of the Valentinians (I-III).
disposition: Private collection (Van Roije van Wichen: 2 coins, 1960)

summary: Hoard of 10 nummi found by metal detecting: Constantius II - Arcadius for Honorius (AD 406-408).
disposition: State Museum-Reserve Kulikovo Field, Tula, Russia

summary: 520 silver coins found with a lead recipient: 513 republican denarii, 2 imperial denarii, 1 republican quinarius, 4 drachms: Republic and early Imperial denarii terminating in issues of Augustus dating to 29 BC.
disposition: Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Venezia, Italy

summary: List of recorded coins in the catalog of coins under the find spot Stephanstraße. Of the 76 coins there are 6 specimens of a different provenance.

The hoard comprised a greyware cup containing between 8000 and 9000 nummi of the House of Constantine. They include GLORIA EXERCITVS nummi of Constantius II as Caesar and VRBS ROMA and CONSTANTINOPOLIS issues. The mints of Trier and Lyon are menti1d.
Hoard of around 200 denarii. Among the issuers Vespasian and Titus. The hoard was dispersed.
The hoard comprised 14 Roman provincial bronze coins (AD 100-270).
The hoard comprised a small greyware vessel containing 50 silver and billon Roman coins ending in issues of Postumus. It was found not far from TAF VIII/2.1 (Oise) (CHRE 3546).
8 denarii, ranging from Vitellius to Marcus Aurelius, found on the north bank of the Tay at Inchyra, east of Perth.

Cotton and Wood (1996, 26 nos 37-8) record 2 or possibly 3 cast bronze coins found downstream of Chiswick Eyot. 1 of them may be a Massiliot bronze prototype; the second is a class IL (ABC 171) flat linear type.
Hoard of 1312 denarii: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211). Together were found 2 impressive silver gilded brooches, a bronze ring.
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia

summary: It comprised 200 sestertii from Antoninus Pius to Commodus (AD 180-192) found with a ceramic vessel.

On the site of a Roman temple or shrine (?) in a field: 30 coins, significantly limited to the inner recessed area. The number joined by corrosion suggests the possibility of a disturbed hoard. They are mainly debased antoniniani covering the same period as the hoard found during the last century. Undated. Late 3rd century AD

find_spot_name: ROME 1911 - BETWEEN VIA G. BRANCA, B. FRANKLIN AND THE TIBER
summary: 885 silver and bronze coins: Antoninus Pius - Gallienus (AD 260-268).
A small scattered hoard of Gallo-Belgic E staters, found between October 1998 and March 2003 in several batches up to 30m apart.
Over 600 bronze coins found with ceramic vessel. Only 11 pieces are recorded: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 163-164).
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueología e Etnología, Lisboa, Portugal

summary: The hoard comprised a copper-alloy vase containing 73 antoniniani (radiates) (or 60 according to Blanchet) from Gallienus to Probus.
Few hundred coins. Only 98 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) are recovered: Elagabalus - Gallienus (sole) (AD 267-268).
86 denarii: Republic - Tiberius (AD 15-37).
The hoard comprised 8 bronze coins dated between AD 378 and AD 388.
The hoard was found in pot with 1600 low-grade silver coins of Postumus. Silver: c.1600 (500) coins; Silver w8: c.432
A hoard of 4 provincial coins of Philippi, found under the orchestra of the theatre.
Unknown orignal number of coins. 72 antoniniani (radiates) were available for study. The hoard was found in 2 large ceramic vessels.
Group record for a hoard of 6 silver coins.
2 ceramic vessels with around 500 coins: Elagabalus (Aquilia Severa) to Carinus (AD 283-285). Hobbs estimates the w8 of 63.5-843.8g.

Found during the excavation of a inhumation cemetery in a leather purse hanging by the belt (possibly Frankish?). All coins are nummi of the Constantine I and his family members. Although it is said that there 11 coins were found, only 10 are menti1d.
The hoard comprised 2755 bronze coins dated between AD 348 and AD 355.
The hoard comprised 200 sestertii with no further information about the composition given.
7 denarii discovered together in the Dacian fortress: Republic 6, Vespasian 1 (AD 70).
disposition: Eastern Carpathian Museum, Sfântu Gheorghe, Romania (inv. nos. 16036–16042)

summary: The hoard comprised 2 gold multiples and 3 silver multiples of Constantius II and Constans with a tpq of AD 340-350.
403 antoniniani (radiates) and 34 imitations: Valerian - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
10 denarii: Domitian - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-211).
26 antoniniani found in the house known as the 'House of Domitian's Diploma' with a small ceramic vessel: Severus Alexander - Quintillus (Divus Claudius II) (AD 270).
71 nummi were found in a pilgrim flask, in a pit under a tile floor in a domestic quarter dating to the fifth century AD: House of Theodosius I - Zeno (AD 474-491).
Provincial coinage of Hispania (Gades, Colonia Patricia & Italica) for Augustus (27 BC - AD 14).
(619) 607 silver coins: 1 republican denarius, 235 imperial denarii and 371 antoniniani: M. Antony to Trajan Decius (AD 249-250); silver w8: 775.8-2053.0 g.
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 13

summary: Circa 20 sestertii of Gordian III (AD 238-244) found in a layer of ashes.
18 sestertii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-183).
The hoard comprised of 27 aurei from Nero to Hadrian. 26 are identified.
232 Imperial AE found in the Villa Diomede. Among the issuers Galba and Vespasian.

3494 antoniniani (radiates) and nummi, 16835 kilos: Probus to Constantine I and Licinius I (AD 313-316). Distribution of coins by mints: 1470 Trier, 1527 London, 366 Lyon, 50 Rome, 36 Ticinum, 10 Aquileia, 8 Siscia, 4 Cyzicus, 13 Carthage, 2 Arles, 23 Ostia, 1 Heraclea.
Around 300 denarii possible found with a leather bag. 134 coins provide information on the issuers: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Krakow (132 coins); private collection, Gnojni (2 coins)

summary: A deliberate deposit from the excavations at Ashwell. E Ghey writes: Group 2002 T215 (5) consisted of items in a 'placed deposit' in context 203. This deposit consisted of 2 copper alloy units of Tasciovanus, 4 copper alloy units of Cunobelin, 1 silver Icenian unit, a pierced dupondius of Claudius, an as of Vespasian and an as of Hadrian. The non-coin objects consisted of second century AD Roman objects (a brooch, mounts, numerous fragments of iron mail armour and implements, a fragment of a pipe-clay figurine) and part of a Bronze Age spearhead, in addition to fragments of pottery, animal b1 and cremated b1. The as of Hadrian places deposit (5) in the second century AD at the earliest; a time in which the coin evidence as a whole suggests a reduction in activity at the site.
The hoard comprised 2 radiates and 17 Provincial coins (Thessalonica, Edessa and Koinon of Macedonia), found in Koufalia.
10 large Roman imperial bronze coins: Hadrian 3, Antoninus Pius 4, Faustina I 2, Lucilla 1.
A large hoard of antoniniani (radiates). Only 204 coins were noticed: Gallienus (sole) - Carinus (AD 283-284); silver w8: 36.8-65.2 g.

2 antoniniani (radiates) of the brothers Macrianus II and Quietus, placed on either side of the head of the deceased, and a coin (pierced) of Caracalla minted at Paphos, placed over the chest. Burial cave.

From information obtained by Khaled Ben Rhomdane, the hoard comprised 2000 Republican denarii, although there is some suggestion that there were also imperial denarii including issues of Antoninus Pius. The hoard was stolen.

More than 1000 pieces were found, of which nearly 700 were brought to the museum. Due to corrosion products on the coins, only about 100 of the coins were identified. There were problems of identification and classification and therefore it is not possible to date the latest coin in the hoard. However, several coins had the legend GALLIENVS AVG suggesting a date range of AD 260 to 268.

A. Pinchaud bought 8 base silver Iron Age coins from M. Deniau which were found 'in the vicinity of Nantes'. The coins depicted on the obverse a head with long hair facing right and on the reverse, a human-headed horse right, surrounded by florets. Under the horse was a boar; on some of the coins, the boar was replaced by another symbol. The coins were of varying typs but quite well-preserved, although they were poorly struck. It seems that they were billon coins of Classes III or IV attributed to the Vénètes (type LT, XXII, 6667)

Found during excavations in the Roman villa rustica of Hüttwilen-Stutheien, in the north-western corner of room VIII. A group of 5 coins, 2 sestertii (Trajan, Hadrian) and 3 antoniniani (Gordian III). Possibly a purse.
3 aurei of Hadrian. Only 1 was seen.
65 Roman silver coins found a small urn or earthern vessel, while removing the root of a tree near the house of Mr. Burke, at Beaconsfield. The coins ranged from Vespasian to Faustina.
76 bronze coins: obols, and provincial issues: Ptolemy I Soter - Claudius I (AD 41-54).

The hoard comprised 50 aurei: Augustus - Civil Wars (AD 69). It was found in the remains of a Roman camp that burnt down in the revolt of AD 69, during excavation on the Domplein square, in the centre of Utrecht.
disposition: Centraal Museum, Utrecht, Netherlands (see links under individual coins)

summary: 18 gold staters, 138 silver staters, 1 thin silver coin, 7 copper alloy coins of the Roman period, 2 silver ingots, 1 copper alloy ingot, 5 sherds of Iron Age pottery and 1 copper alloy unidentified object.
235 nummi: Constans/Constantius II - TheodosiusI/Arcadius.
disposition: Museo Arch. Reg. "P. Orsi", Siracusa: inv: 42664-42669: 5 pcs.

summary: c. 6000 nummi of the Tetrarchy. 2042 nummi are kept in the coin room of thee National Museum of Slovenia in Ljubljana. 695 coins were studied in detail.
disposition: Narodni muzej, Numizmatični cabinet, Ljubljana, Slovenia; 2,042 coins

summary: 6 denarii: Antoninus Pius 3, Marcus Aurelius, Commodus, Septimius Severus (AD 193-211)
1243 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 denarius from Caracalla to Valerian I.
25 coins? "Medium-sized hoard. Allegedly Bar Kokhba silver and bronze together with Syrian tetradrachms and Roman denarii" (Mildenberg 1984, 56).
c. 400 of antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Postumus (AD 260-269).
disposition: Town museum, Oudenaarde, Belgium (some coins and the vessel); collection C.A. Serrure, in 1861
