summary: Hoard of around 1081 bronze coins: Republic - Septimius Severus found with a ceramic vessel. The Soprain10deza has considered as a discovery of 'nessun valore' and retuned it to the finder. 1 sestertius of Didia Clara was kept in Museo Bottacin.
57 nummi of the House of Constantine I (AD 322-325) found in the floor in a Roman villa.

The hoard was found in the ruins of a small round temple and comprised a tripod cauldron containing 251 Roman sestertii from Domitian to Gordian III. Coins of Hadrian, Marcus Aurelius and Commodus were the most numerous.

Penhallurick (2009, 182) notes the find of 2 illegible "second brass" of Vespasian found at "a depth of 8 feet (grave 15 J5) together with some cow b1s, lying in an ancient trench" in Penzance cemetery. Presumably therefore found together and a small in10tional deposit.
80 bronze coins of the Late Empire, presumably nummi.
The hoard comprised a vessel containing 23 Roman Imperial coins, which were not further described along with a variety of jewellery (including 3 finger rings) and precious metal objects.

The hoard is composed of 10 poorly preserved Anto9 bronzes. It was found during 3 archaeological(?) surveys of Noires-Terres in the Bois-en-Ardres in February 1980, at the end of 1981 and in early 1982) and interpreted as the remains of a dispersed hoard, as they were all found in the same place.
Hoard of around 200 denarii found with a small ceramic vessel. Only 34 coins were documented: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Historical Museum, Moskow, Russia (inv.nos. 98100-1; 036 658-1; 036 685 - 28 coins); Historical Museum, Kyiv, Ukraine (inv.no. 12607/1-6 - 6 coins)

summary: 1602 silver coins: denarii, quinarii, antoniniani (radiates), drachm: Trajan - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
500 provincial bronze coins. N. Mouchmov saw 6 of them: Marcianopolis: Septimius Severus 2, Macrinus 1, Elagabalus 1, Severus Alexander 1; Nicopolis ad Istrum: Macrinus 1

A hoard of 200-300 mainly gold coins (Claudius - Hadrian), found while digging peat in Gustorf in 1838/1839. Several finders are reported. Some coins were bought by the Berlin Münzkabinett (16 gold, 2 silver and 3 bronze coins).
Unknwon number of solidi including 4 of Theodosius II (402-450).
4000 antoniniani (radiates). 1967 were available to identify the issuers: Valerian I and Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
2 solidi of Constantine I found near the church in the year 1829, and several copper and silver coins of that emperor and others, have been found in the parish.
A pile of antoniniani were found under a st1. 18 coins were seen: Gordian III - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
22 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic jug in a room of the Roman villa: Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
Unknown number of denarii. V. Haralanov studied 52 pieces: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

24 mostly later Roman coins were given to the state museum collection in 1966, which supposedly were found at Steinkirchen. Find-site particulars and circumstances of the find were not ascertained. This could be a hoard or single finds.
50 radiates, mainly of the Gallic Empire and terminating with Carausius, found near Conwy shortly after 1945. No more specific information on the find spot is available.
The hoard comprised 401 antoniniani (radiates) terminating in an issue of Postumus (AD 260-269).
1170 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel. 1159 coins were recovered: 1158 denarii 1 drachm: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195); silver w8: c. 2142.4-3660.8 g.
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie și Arheologie Piatra-Neamţ, Romania (inv.nos. P 706-1865 MAPN; P 105 MAPN)

summary: 200 antoniniani, most of them belonging to Gordian III, were found beneath a collapsed roof within an ancient settlement.
81 coins: 2 asses, 1 antoninian (radiate), 78 nummi; silver w8: 0.3-2.6g
Uknown originally number of coins. 854 pieces were recovered: Nero - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico de La Rioja, Spain

summary: On the eastern exterior of the late Roman NO-tower of the cathedral in Trier, a shaft for the protection of the tower foundation was laid out during main10ance work in 1980. The hoard was dug out in a depth of 5.20m. The 43 coins were soldered together in spherically formed clumps. The coins were originally preserved in a leather bag and lay on an antique st1 floor.
The Musée de Rouen has preserved 25 coins from this find, initially, it consisted of 33 antoniniani (radiates).
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen (collection Thaurin), France

summary: "A hoard of 147 copper alloy late Roman coins, deposited between AD 379-388. A large flint nodule was placed on top."
Unknown number of silver coins. 15 denarii of Vespasian are kept in the History Museum in Lovech, Bulgaria.
disposition: History Museum, Lovech, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1266-1280 (15 coins)

summary: 17 antoniniani (radiates) found while building a house: Valerian I and Gallienus (Gallienus) - Probus (AD 276-282).
5 republican denarii found by metal detector (77 BC).

The hoard comprised 20 coins, including 2 Iron Age issues and Roman issues from Augustus to Trajan. They were accompanied by some pipeclay and terracotta figurines. The findspot is presumed to be that of a Gallo-Roman sanctuary.
The hoard comprised at least 49 bronze coins from the reign of Herod (37-4 BC).
disposition: Kadman Numismatic Pavilion at Muza Eretz Israel Museum Tel Aviv

summary: Over 30000 coins - 50 kilos - found with a ceramic vessel: Claudius II - Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
The hoard comprised 118 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel: Domitian-Commodus (90-183 AD). Most of the coins are kept in a private collection (Antonio Egger).
disposition: Museo Civico di Bassano (26 coins); Museo Bottacin di Padova (6 coins); private collection Egger family (86 coins).

summary: Unknown originally number of denarii. Only 11 coins were registred in Janury 1978. According to the finder, the coins were issued between "+- 104 - 4".
Only 110 antoniniani (radiates) from a hoard of several hundred coins was preserved: Gordian III - Gallienus (AD 260-268); silver w8: 131.3g.
750 coins: 4 antoniniani (radiates), 746 nummi: Valerian I and Gallienus - Theodosius I/Arcadius/Honorius (AD 393-395).
(3043) denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180)
disposition: Regional History Museum, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 1453 1-349; 1466 1-8; 1468 1-25; 1470 1-352

summary: (884/894?) bronze coins - "mostly sestertii": 648 sestertii, 8 dupondii/asses, 1 provincial: Domitian - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
Large number of denarii and antoniniani. Only 27 pieces were identified: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
46 nummi found scattered near a tile kiln, on its eastern corner, in a debris layer Constantius II - House of Valentinian I (AD 364-383).`

The hoard comprised a vessel filled with sestertii, which were shared amongst the finders. After an investigation by the Gendarmarie, 59 were found. In 1980, illegal metal detecting on the site recovered a further 5 coins which are likely to be part of the hoard.
It comprised c. 400 silver coins. Only 149 are now recorded: 148 antoniniani (radiates), 1 denarius: Septimus Severus - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole).

A 'placed deposit' in context 201/206 which included 3 coins, a gold stater of Tasciovanus, a silver North-Eastern half-unit and a copper alloy unit of Cunobelin. The non-coin objects consisted of contained 2 iron spearheads, a sherd of Roman glass and a fragment of copper alloy sheet. This deposit is difficult to date from the artefacts but falls within the Roman period, possibly the first century AD.
9 coins: 5 denarii, 4 sestertii: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 134-138).
disposition: Narodni muzej, Numizmatični cabinet, Ljubljana, Slovenia

summary: (c. 230) 145 gold coins: 1 medallion, 144 aurei: Trajan - Galerius (AD 305-306); gold w8: c. 1625g+;
disposition: Kunsthistorisches Museum, Vienna; National Hungarian Museum Budapest; formerly Ivan Nepomuk Labaš de Blaškovec collection

summary: 2 aurei found during agricultural works: Nero, Vespasian for Domitian (Caesar). Uncertain, whether they were found together.
disposition: National Székely Museum, Sf. Gheorghe, Romania (inv. no. 11115, vanished in 1944)

summary: The hoard comprised 5 tetradrachms (Trajan-Caracalla) and 1 denarius (Faustina II).

The hoard (4 coins, Republic - Faustina I/II) was found with around 20 coins in 1772 during the digging of a draw well in front of the castle. - not sure which castle is meant, as there are 3 of them in Jagsthausen.
HER report of about 50 late 4th century coins found in a pot. 11 coins dated c. 306 to 383 survive but no denomination or metal is given.
200 nummi found with a ceramic vessel: Maximian I - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-423).
A group of 32 coins (Constantine I - Gratian) found during excavations in the choir section of the Liebfrauen church in an area between 2 building barriers.
The hoard comprised 24 nummi dating to the period AD 351 to 378. They were found in the northern part of the area sacra at building XV.
38 bronze coins: 2 sestertii, 4 dupondii, 28 asse, 4 dupondii or asses: Titus - Commodus (AD 192).
The hoard comprised between 400 and 500 radiates: Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) for Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
50-8 staters discovered between 28 August and 11 September 1998, within the grounds of the Jealotts Hill Research Station north of Bracknell.

A very large hoard of denarii of Juba II found in Banasa (and not in Ksar el-Kebir as initially thought), comprising several thousand coins (4'000 or possibly more) ending in AD 17/18 (regnal year 42). The coins are said to have been found in 3 large jars. The find was rapidly dispersed, but a number of coins were bought by international numismatic museums.
5 aurei: 2 republican, 3 imperial: Republic - Augustus (AD -11-10).
65 solidi, 11 survive: Gratian - Theodosius (AD 394-395).
Barbarous radiate hoard F734. 329 coins, all imitation ant. of AD 270s. Scattered, but form a cohesive group, & may have been deposited in an organic container. No further contextual details.
40 coins: 4 imitations of antoniniani (radiates), 36 nummi: Tetricus I - House of Theodosius (AD 388-402).
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg

summary: Metal hoard/deposition, silver, bronze, iron, carefully stored in a cavity, in a small room close to the southern porticus. Bronze vessels, iron tools, jewellery and coins stored together between 2 bronze vessels. The hoard comprised 59 (62 ?) coins including 4 sestertii, 4 dupondii, 50 asses and 1 dupondius or as terminating in issues of AD 249-51 and including many pre-103 AD coins: these were not taken from normal coin circulation in mid-3rd cent., but carefully selected.

In 1955 during ground work at a cemetery children randomly found a Roman hoard with a large quantity of coins. All coins except for the 10 described here (sestertii ranging from Vespasian to Marcus Aurelius) were dispersed. The true size of the hoard is unknown.
127 silver coins: 86 denarii, 41 antoniniani: Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver w8: 174.4-359 g.
1 denarius and 2 aes (Republic to Trajan) found in the earliest level of occupation in Room 3.
49 nummi found in a cave beside other votive offerings: Constans - Theodosius I/Arcadius/Honorius (AD 393-395).
The hoard comprised 10 sestertii from Trajan to Commodus with a tpq of AD 190. TAF interprets the hoard as being a purse drop.
The coins were discovered in an earthenware container during roadworks: Severus Alexander - Tetrarchy (AD 303).
disposition: Rheinisches Landesmuseum, Trier (inv.no. EV 69/36); private collections K. Cibis, K.H. Zimmer, Trier, Germany

summary: 1 Republican denarius, 197 Imperial AE found in regio VI, insula 17, building 25 (house)
542 coins: 1 antoninianus (radiate), 541 nummi, found with a bronze pitcher (Blechkanne), only 38 coins can be entered at the coin data level: Aurelian - Tetrarchy (AD 300-303).
disposition: Soprintendenza per i Beni Archeologici della Lombardia

summary: 98 coins: antoniniani (radiates), argentei, siliquae, nummi: Claudius II - Julian II AD 361-363); silver w8: c.197.2-312.4 g.
The hoard comprised a broken earthenware vessel containing 50 'middle bronzes' of Augustus, including 1 with a reverse type depicting the Altar of Lyon
237 silver denarii and antoniniani: Hadrian - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver w8: 297.8-690.4 g.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1881

summary: The coins were found during excavation at Thermen-it might concern Barbara-Thermen, because there the emperor Thermen for a long time administered an imperial palace. The expression "so-called Thermen" remains problematic.
The hoard is described as being 32 small bronze coins (radiates?). There are 20 coins of Gallienus and 12 of Claudius II.

An assemblage of nummi of the House of Constantine spread in the upper and lower fills of a midden with second to third century pottery. Possibly a dispersed hoard. 3 coins found stacked together suggestive of a purse hoard.
67 denarii found with ceramic vessel: Antoninus Pius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235); silver w8: 95.2-182.9 g.
13 denarii found in a room of a Germanic house: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).
Over 28 aurei, of which 8 are bearing the portrait of Claudius I. No further details.
The hoard comprised 46 coins, with the latest coin dating between AD 346-350.

In 1805 a hoard of unknown size was found next to the Lich10burg mill close to Vilsbiburg. 15 coins were menti1d in 1862 and 14 listed in 1877. The 2 lists do not quite match, which is why 17 coins are listed in FMRD. Coins range from Titus to Magnentius.
1 radiate and 19 nummi to AD 317-324.
Unknown number of gold coins and jewelry: Severus Alexander - Claudius II (AD 2680270)? Together were found silver and gold jewelry, 1 gold diadem and 2 gold ingots.
North-west of the cemetery of Palencia, a hoard of more than 400 coins of the 4th century AD was found. No further information.
Votive offering at the entrance in the cave - 15 coins. Group of single coin finds with portraits of several emperors from Augustus to Arcadius (AD 383-408).

During archaeological excavations. 8 coins were found in a layer of ashes: 2 Hellenistic (Mar1a and Enos), 1 uncertain - provincial bronzes and minted in Anchialus: Hadrian 1, Antoninus Pius 1, Lucilla 1, Commodus 1 and Geta 1.

Discovered in 2007 in a field, near a village, between the village and the Lyasnaya river; the coins were scattered over an area of 500x100 m and had 2 large concentrations (2 hoards?). Included at least 500 denarii, of which only 20 are available for study (Vespasian-Clodius Albinus). Information about the hoard in 2009 came to the archaeologist V. Belyavets, and in the spring of 2010 V. Sidarovich examined the place of the find. In the same field, other items were found: fragments of silver brooches, a gold brooch, a spearhead, a gold ring (?). Their relation with the hoard is doubtful (items from the settlement?)
163 kilos of bronze coins (7000-7400 coins) discovered at the beginning of the 19th century. Only 200 coins are known: Trajan - Postumus (AD 260-268).
Hoard of 108 Roman denarii and 2 silver pendants. Coin w8: 297.5g.
91 tetradrachms of Alexandria in a small pot found during excavations. Range: Claudius I - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).
disposition: 12 in London, 5 in Oxford. The rest dispersed. Detailed list in Oxford

summary: A hoard of 35-40 nummi found inside the Roman fort at Mainz-Kastel between 1895 and 1900. 27 coins have been preserved and they belong to the Tetrarchy (AD 293-305).

The hoard was found during the excavation of the Roman town of Baelo and comprised 13 antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus and Claudius II with a tpq of AD 269-270. The coins were stacked 1 on top of the other next to a piece of limest1.
20 Iron Age bronze coins were found on the shore of the Lac de Grand-Lieu (or according to Hucher, on a jetty in the lake).
220 denarii: Republican (163), Imperial (57); Republican - Antoninus Pius (AD post 141)
disposition: Union Museum Alba Iulia, Romania (49 coins)

summary: A small quantity of north-eastern coinage, possibly a hoard; the stater seems rather out of place.
1937 antoniniani (radiates) found in a cooking pot: Caracalla - Postumus (AD 263).
1088 denarii and antoniniani were found in a copper vessel: Septimius Severus - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 9221-10309

summary: In 1854 at Ritsch, 900 m from the Elbdeich, an old German earthenware container with 20 Roman nummi (Theodosius I - Arcadius), human remains and glass pearls was found. The find position lay in the area of a small hill. It certainly was a female burial within a migration period burial ground.
10 provincial bronze coins. 1 of Septimius Severus, 1 of Caracalla, minted in Nicopolis ad Istrum and Marcianopolis.
23 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel: 10 denarii, 11 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2678, 23 coins

summary: The hoard was found inside a textile bag placed within a ceramic vessel and comprised approximately 300 silver coins, apparently all antoniniani (radiates). The hoard has a tpq of AD 261.
41 antoniniani (radiates) ranging from Gallienus to Tetricus I (AD 271-274) found in a savings box.

A hoard of 21+ Republican and early imperial coins (mostly denarii and a few bronze coins), found in 1863 at Soltborg under a clay layer in a depth of 7 feet. These coins lay loosely separated without a container. The coins were sold in 1930/1. Soltborg is in the vicinity of the Roman camp of Bentumersiel.
Hoard consisting of 36 solidi found 1850-1851. The last coins belong to Anastasius, but 1 of them is an imitation, which explains the tpq of AD 576.

A mixed hoard of denarii, some sestertii and a few antoniniani, ranging from Hadrian to Trajan Decius. It was found in soil dug out during building work in Niederlahnstein (Weiherstraße). The hoard, which was partly dispersed, might have comprised 200 coins or more, but a description of only 142 exists.
421 denarii and 1 aureus found with 2 ceramic urns in a quarry: Republic - Domitian (AD 84).
Circa 350 republican and imperial denarii discovered. 79 denarii have been studied: Republic - Trajan (AD 103-111).
disposition: Muzeul Județean de Istorie și Arheologie Prahova, Ploiești, Romania (35 coins), inv. nos. 920730-920761; private collection (44 coins)

summary: (160) 130 silver coins: 129 denarii, 1 antoninianus: Antoninus Pius - Gordian III (AD 239); silver w8: 181.8-353.2 g.

Before 1939, an archaeologist bought a hoard comprising 2065 antoniniani (radiates) from a clerk in Évron. The hoard appears to have come from the north of the département, perhaps Aron or Évron, or, according to Cordonnier is another hoard from Jublains: Trajan Decius - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
20-2 denarii found on an agricultural land: Otho - Commodus (AD 187-188).

A hoard of Roman coins, found in Western Crete without any known find spot and handed over by Chatzigrigorakis. Reports on its con10t diverge (see bibliography): it comprised either 143 coins (Augustus - Gallienus) or 206 (Hadrian - Maximinus). Most of these were sestertii, with very few provincial coins (Syria and Koinon of Crete or Alexandria and 1 unknown mint). The report given by Vlachogianni has been followed here.
9 denarii: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 128-130).
Hoard of 52 denarii found at the site: Republic - Tiberius (AD 14-37). Among them, issues of Julius Caesar, Mark Antony, Augustus, Tiberius.
A bronze jug containing 160 aurei, found on site 29 in Corbridge. 2 bronze coins were found filling the narrow neck of the jug, where they had been placed, to act as a stopper to the narrow neck.
17 bronze coins with the latest issues of Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
A hoard of 10 aurei (Domitian - Antoninus Pius), found in the 1880s in Trier, in a small earthenware container; it was published in 1928 as part of the collection of Dr. Leopold Seligmann.
The hoard comprised more than 6000 radiates from Julia Domna to Postumus, the most numerous being of Gordian III, Philip I and Philip II. Found by a workman on the land of B. Flamand
255 solidi: Arcadius - Basiliscus (c. AD 480); gold w8: 1134.75g.
(?) 8 nummi: House of Constantine I (AD 337-341).

A person engaged in digging near the entrenchments which surround the castle at Bourn, lately discovered a small urn, containing upwards of 6ty Roman coins. 1 of them is an aureus of Nero; the others are denarii and sestertii of Constantine, Augustus and Maximilian [sic]." The account of the emperors represented in the hoard, and the denominations included are unlikely.

The hoard comprised an offering of vessels to Minerva including silver and bronze objects and numerous bronze coins dating from the reign of Tiberius all the way through to Constantine I. The hoard was found by a farmer planting a vineyard. The hoard is preserved as the Notre-Dame-d'Allençon hoard in the Musée du Louvre, Paris
disposition: Louvre Museum, Paris; Archaeological Museum of St. Jean, Angers, France

summary: 10 bronze coins minted in the time of Gaius (AD 40-41): 2 dupondii, 8 asses.
1243 silver coins: 1241 denarii, 2 drachmas: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 164)
42 nummi of Constantine I (AD 320). No further Information.

2 coins of Valens AD 364-78, found near hand of SK33 (3-5 year old child) in double grave with mature adult female (SK34). Child also had 3 cu alloy bracelets. Grave 3050.SK33 14C dated to AD 250-420.
Hoard of 500-1000 denarii: Second Triumvirate - Augustus (27 BC - AD 14).
445 silver coins probably buried directly in the soil: Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallu (AD 251-253).

A hoard of 15000 - 20000 coins, found ploughing a field at Riby Wold Farm on the east side of Lincolnshire Wolds, some 4-5 miles north-east of Caistor. The coins are all antoniniani, ranging from Gordian III to Probus, AD 281. Included were many coins of Gallienus, and of emperors from the Gallic Empire.
disposition: Lincoln City and County Museum (part: pot and 24 coins); Ashmoleum Museum (part)

summary: (70) 16 denarii: Republic - Domitian (AD 81-96).

During the excavation of the Roman villa at Andover, in the east wing of the villa, a large urn of the ordinary black ware, was found. It was buried upright in the ground, and covered with a large flanged tile, which had been crushed down into the mouth of the jar, by pressure from above, probably by the plough. 6 small bronze Roman coins were found in it. This seems to be the villa at Clanville. "Small bronze" might suggest a third to 4th century hoard
(116) 101 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 241).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. CXXIV

summary: The hoard comprised 34 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Valerian and Gallienus; Silver w8: 33.8g.
Circa 80000 republican aurei minted between 46 and 38 BC, found with a vessel. Gold w8 650 kg.
Gold and silver coins found together with tableware, 2 gold bracelets and rings in a lead chest. At least 2 aurei of Philip and Gallienus. Gold: 2+ coins; Gold w8: 10.2g+;
Around 500 antoniniani (radiates). 352 coins were recovered: Caracalla - Valerian I (AD 253-259).
A hoard of 78 Roman silver coins (Vespasian - Commodus, Constantius II, and Julian, some of which were imitations), found in a pot in a garden in Laatzen.
The hoard originally comprised 6 nummi of Maxentius discovered with a small glass vessel. Coins are now missing.
(10kg?) 18 denarii: Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-183).

10 solidi found in an area with 3 Iron Age houses. The first 7 coins, FP 5142, were found within 15x35 meters. In spite of the relatively large distance between the coins they are probably a ploughed-up hoard. No denarii have been found yet at this site.
A suspicious hoard as there is very confusing information whether there is a hoard or more hoards put together following the excavations in the area of a Romano-Visigothic necropolis:
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueologia, Lisboa, Portugal

summary: A small set of coins that were glued together to form a small cylinder were found next to a corpse.
47 nummi of the time of Constantius II, all of the Fel Temp Reparatio - falling horseman (AD 348-360).

1397 silver coins found with a bronze vessel: 4 denarii, 1393 antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver w8: 380.9-3311.7 g. Mints represented: Rome, Cologne, Trier, Milan, Siscia and Antioch.

A hoard of 203 bronze coins was found on the Thames foreshore. The coins range in date from the 280s to AD 402. The bulk of them date to AD 386-402, and in the main consist of coins of Valentinian II, Theodosius I, Arcadius and Honorius.
70 nummi: Constantine I - Constantius II (AD 351-355).
disposition: Groninger Museum (52 coins), private collection (18 ex.)

summary: The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing between 1100 and 1500 silver and bronze coins, weighing 2.5kg. Desjobert who saw a small number of the coins, detailed that the coins included issues of Caracalla, Plautilla, Severus Alexander to Claudius II. When the hoard was dispersed, Drouet bought 27 radiates for the Musée du Mans including 7 Gallienus, 4 Claudius II, 4 Postumus, 3 Victorinus The hoard was found by a worker cleaning a fountain.
A hoard containing 3000 coins from Gallienus to Constantine was found at Cervon before 1838.
277 antoniniani (radiates) + 28 imitations antoniniani (radiates) and 1 imitation denarius: Valerian I and Gallienus for Saloninus (Caesar) - Victorinus (AD 269-271).
disposition: Musées royaux d'Art et d'Histoire - Koninklijk Musea voor Kunst en Geschiedenis (Brussels)

summary: 17 coins (denarii) found by a farmer on a field, ranging from the Republic to Titus (AD 79).
Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 12 coin entered the museum collection in Svishtov: Antoninus Pius - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
1069 silver coins found with a ceramic cooking pot: Republic - Augustus (11-10 BC).
disposition: Medagliere del Museo Nazionale Romano, Rome, Italy

summary: Hoard 2 from Housesteads. Brickstock and Casey in Rushworth ed. 2009, 375 describe the hoard thus: "consists of 4 Radiate Copies found corroded together (SF No. 9396) in 1981 in H14:4:7, the chalet barrack phase of Building XIV. The identifiable prototypes of the copies are issues of Tetricus I and II (AD 270-73). Deposition may have taken place early in the period AD 273-86 (Period 19) since the copies are of large module and relatively unworn."
The hoard comprised 14 nummi dated between AD 352-354 and AD 383-395.
280 republican and imperial denarii: Republic - Tiberius (AD 14-37).
7499 bronze coins: 7486 sestertii, from Augustus to Valerian I (AD 255-256). 158 kg.

The hoard comprised 606 radiates from Balbinus to Postumus with a tpq of approximately AD 263. The hoard contains official issues up until Postumus' Issue 1c (AD 261) but there are 2 radiates which copy coins of AD 263. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of between 141.2 and 1222.6g.
51 bronze coins, probably, kept in an organic container (carbonised traces): Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249).
1900 nummi of the Tetrarchy (AD 294-306).

Unknown number of coins. 61 coins that may be kept in a private collection suggest a chronological segment from the reign of Nerva to Gratian (AD 367-383) but there are strong doubts that these coins belong to the hoard. Hoard found with a ceramic vessel.
1498 coins: 9 antoniniani (radiates), 1489 nummi found in a corner of a dwelling: Claudius II - Thedosius II (AD 423-425).

IARCH record for a fused hoard of coins and jewellery found in Colchester during excavations by Colchester Archaeological Trust. Full details are not yet available due to ongoing conservation work. The latest coins fully identified are denarii of Augustus but the hoard contains copper alloy coins thought to be Claudian in date.N. Crummy writes: "The objects consist of gold and silver bracelets, a silver chain, gold finger-rings, gold and pearl earrings, a lidded wooden box covered with thin silver sheet and set on ivory legs, a copper-alloy pendant, a glass intaglio, and about 22 silver and 3-4 copper-alloy coins (precise number still uncertain). Some of the objects had been in the box when buried, and most of the coins had been buried in a leather or cloth bag or purse. 2 iron nail fragments found with the objects may be residual or associated in some way with the scooping out of the hole." (Unpublished cor1r's report by N. Crummy 2014 T577)

The circumstances of discovery of this hoard are unknown. Some of the coins were in the Védie Collection. Évreux museum had 1 gold stater (LT 7017) with the same provenance, but it is not clear whether it was from this hoard.
Hoard of 125 denarii found with ceramic vessel: Republic - Augustus (2 BC-AD 4).
disposition: National Museum of Archaeology, Sofia, Bulgaria (inv.nos. CCXIV / 1962, 124 coins)

summary: 13 asses found as a foundation offering: Augustus - Claudius I (AD 50-54).
2 antoniniani (radiates) of Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
A hoard of 56 denarii (Republic - Augustus), of which 42 coins were found in 1895 and 14 more in 1899/1900.
161 coins: 19 denarii and antoniniani, 142 provincial bronzes: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 4428-4588

summary: Coins from the area designated as BMR 2649 (situated a bit south of the BMR 1191 area) at Bornholm Museum. 'A' is a hoard consisting of 6 solidi, 5 gold bracteates, 2 gold pendents and 8 gold beads which must be interpreted as a grandiose necklace. All items were found wrapped up into a Roman silver plate.

Hoard found in a bronze pot during the removal of a fence. It comprised more than 1100 radiates, mainly from the Gallic Empire (Postumus, at least 763 coins). Bought by J. J. Wilhelm Bachofen-Burckhardt, Basel, but some coins dispersed in trade (ca. 100 coins). In 1925, his heirs sold 472 coins to the Swiss National Museum. Then, in 1941, they sold the container and the remaining coins to the Historisches Museum Basel.
Funerary deposit near skeleton (viaticum): 40 coins: 7 antoniniani (radiates), 33 nummi: Valerian I and Gallienus - Constantine I (AD 310-313). Found together with 2 finger rings.
The hoard comprised 2 ceramic vessels containing between 6000 and 7000 copper- alloy coins from Macrinus, Severus Alexander, Maximian, Gordian III and Philip I.

The hoard was found in a sandst1 or earthenware vessel hidden in a wall and covered by a large st1. It comprised 19 kg of corroded silver, billon and bronze coins, equating to approximately 3600 coins. No certainty, that the latest coins belong to Postumus.
The hoard was found on 2 February 1985 - initially 1 coin and then another 30-2 about 15 cm deeper, with the remains of a pottery vessel.
195 Roman imperial bronze coins: 192 sestertii, 3 dupondii/asses: Trajan - Gallienus (AD 260-268).

73 denarii (Vespasian to Commodus) found beneath a millst1 by workmen removing "a quantity of loose st1s and earth" near a lime kiln in a quarry. A pair of spurs was reportedly found at the same time. RCAHMW states that the precise location of the find is unknown "but there is apparently only 1 lime kiln on the estate" in a place still known as Limekiln Covert.
disposition: In the collection of T Assheton Smith Esq. M.P. (1849)

summary: 6 solidi: Honorius - Leo I (AD 457-474); Gold w8: 26.7 g. Found on the same field under a flat st1.
disposition: Swedish History Museum, Stockholm (inv.nos. 2rn3, 2355, 2843, 2872, 4098) and one in Town museum Kalmar, Sweden

summary: 1 of 3 coin hoards found in a villa on 8een Acre Field, all buried just before the end of the 3rd c. AD (see Robertson nos. 649 and 888). 67 coins, ranging from Valerian I to Allectus, placed in a cist dug in the earth together with animal b1s, pieces of coarse pottery, and a blue bead, nearly the size of a walnut.
403 denarii: Tiberius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 167-168); bronze and gold jewelry and bronze tweezers.
642 BI radiates to AD 282. Addenda of 100 coins found in 2015.
2 solidi of Leo I found together (AD 476-491).
37 denarii most likely kept in a textile bag: Republic – Nero (AD 65-66).
Original hoard contained about 66 coins, of which 17 are extant. Found 'in a mound of broken flints'.
Unknown number of silver coins found in a ceramic vessel. 105 pieces entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: 100 denarii, 5 antoniniani: Trajan - Gordian III (AD 243-244); silver w8: 148.6-305.1 g.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2226, 105 coins

summary: 14 denarii part of a hoard found on the same field like GANDARVE 1927, 1928, 1928-1931: Vespasian (Domitian Caesar) - Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) (AD 161-175); silver w8: 22.67 g (8 coins).

The hoard comprised a plain ceramic vessel containing 628 Roman coins from Trajan Decius to Tetricus I. These included 3 denarii of Postumus and 625 silver, billon or bronze coins (denarii and radiates) of several emperors. The coins of Claudius II and the Tetrici constituted 5/6ths of the hoard.

On discovery, most of the find was melted down and therefore it is difficult to establish the exact con10t of the deposit. It is reputed to have included 30000 gold and silver coins. Buried around AD 260. Together were found 8 silver statuettes and 1 silver plate remain from the original treasure.
disposition: Department of Greek and Roman Antiquities, The British Museum, London, United Kingdom; Musée des ursulines à Mâcon (copies of the statuettes)

summary: Hoard of 600 coins. Only 61 were documented: Claudius II - House of Theodssius I (AD 395-402).

In 1852 a hoard of antoniniani from the middle of the third century was discovered in the neighbourhood of Klugham. 31 specimens from the hoard fell into the possession of the Historischer Verein von Obb. 33 coins are listed in FMRD, including 2 denarii (Caracalla - Valerian).
Circa 500 denarii, of which 264 were brought after 1873 to the National Hungarian Museum in Budapest. 168 coins were identified: Nero – Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) (AD 141-161).
1 aureus of Vespasian, 63 uncertain AR, 28 uncertain AE found in regio VI, insula 10, atrium of building 2 (house)
498 solidi found with a ceramic vessel: Honorius - Romulus Augustulus (AD 476).

A hoard of 12 provincial coins of Gordian III and Tranquillina (Thessalonica and Edessa), found during the excavations of a farmhouse in ancient Lete (preceding the construction of the Egnatia motorway) and linked to the Gothic invasions of the middle of the 3rd c. AD.
1071 silver coins: 6 denarii, 1065 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Gallienus (AD 267); silver w8: 290.7-2781.5g
disposition: Museum of History and Archaeology Tulcea, Romania (1971)

summary: A hoard of 26 solidi and ca. 304 siliquae, found with 2 gold rings in 1824 in 2 pots, 1 for the silver coins, 1 for the gold coins and the gold rings. 2 bronze coins recorded at the time may have come from a Romano-British habitation site in the neighbourhood. The list given by O'Neil in 1933 includes 26 solidi and 296 siliquae.
Around 30 antoniniani in freshly minted condition, of Gallienus, Macrianus, and other contemporaneous issuers.

232 Iron Age coins, found in a field. It is not sure that all the coins belonged to the same deposit. The site si considered as the location of a Romano-British temple with an earlier, Iron Age phase.

33 denarii (Mark Antony to Antoninus Pius) found by a party of schoolchildren among rubble in a chamber of the prehistoric and Roman mine workings beneath the hill fort at Llanymynech Ogof. The coins were fused together before being separated by a local antiquarian. A piece of black pottery picked up on another occasion close to the site of the discovery may possibly indicate that the hoard has been disturbed at some time.
disposition: National Museums Wales, Cardiff (part); Oswestry Museum (part)

summary: A hoard composed of 130 + AR Lycian hemidrachms, including 60 from Cragus and 7 from Masicytus, dating to c. 25 BCE.

The hoard comprised 14 sestertii from Antoninus Pius to Trajan Decius. The hoard was found in the north eastern corner of the Big Northern Room of a Roman building situated near the southern part of the wall in the eastern part of the lower city. It has been interpreted as an 'Emergency Hoard' with a Tpq of AD 249 (?) [RIC IV 107a]. Judging from the wear of the coins, it was desposited soon after the middle of the third century AD.

Mints: Rome (332); Nicomedia (11: Elagabalus); Antioch (6: 1 Caracalla and 5 Gordian III); 3 copies of Gordian III. Silver: 139, 213 coins; Silver w8: 462.0-912.5g The hoard was found during levelling works at a sawmill.

A farm laborer found a Roman coin hoard in a plot of a field in Lochhausen, 10 cm below the surface. The hoard contained approx. 1700 antonianini, of which 1675 specimens could be recorded. Part of the hoard was housed in the coin collection at Munich, but lost during the years of war. The list given in FMRD is based on the publication of hoard by M. Bernhardt in 1911. Unfortunately, this publication contains many mistakes and it is not any more possible to give an exact description of the con10t.
circa 1500 bronze coins of the Late Empire found in amphora. No further information

Around 20000 nummi? Doubtful. Confirmation required. “According to Bopearachchi the hoard consisted entirely of, “Roman third brass”. The fate of the coins is presented by Bopearachchi as follows: “We could only examine a few coins of this hoard; we learned later that the rest of the hoard was melted down”.
The hoard comprised 5 Tyrian and 2 shekels from the First Jewish Revolt.
A series of 20 Iron Age staters, found over a period of several years in a field. The last 3 staters found in 2012 are not listed in de Jersey.
A 'valuable find of gold and silver coins', of which 1 coin was a denarius of Antoninus Pius (broken and much defaced), found on Dewsbury Moor, near remains of 2 Roman querns.
Circa 50 argentei, +800 nummi: Diocletian - Constantius I (AD 305-306).

76 silver coins found in a building near the principia of the legionary fortress: 35 miliarenses, 41 siliquae: Constantine II, Constans, Constantius II, Vetranio, Constantius III Gallus, (AD 352-354); silver w8: 260.8-305.2g.
disposition: Museum Lauriacum - Museum der Stadt Enns, Austria

summary: 2 denarii found on a field by chance: Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius for Antoninus Pius (Divus).
Over 361 silver and bronze coins were found in 5 ceramic vessels. Only 191 coins were documented: 157 sestertii, 24 denarii were studied: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
669 denarii found with a ceramic vessel near a Carpic settlement: Republic – Marcus Aurelius (AD 166-167).
Initially 857 coins, only 168 silver coins are known, and jewelry found with a : Vespasian - Aurelian (Severina) (AD 270-275).
disposition: Museo Civico, Lodi, Italy (nowadays, 168 coins, 1 brooch and 1 silver ring); Biblioteca Laudense, Lodi, Italy

summary: Hoard of 450 denarii found with a ceramic vessel covered by another pot: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (Clodius Albinus Caesar) (AD 194-195). W8: 983 g. According to Kropotkin, the hoard ends with the coin of Clodius Albinus as all the coins of Septimius Severus are issues of AD 193-194.
disposition: Local History Museum, Uman, Ukraine (inv. nos. 1675/2760 et 2355/3440)

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 2507 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Aurelian (AD 270-275); w8: 6100 kg.
The hoard comprised 654 coins of which a total of 444 were recorded. These included 442 denarii from the Republic to Severus Alexander and 2 antoniniani of Caracalla and Elagabalus.
6 or 7? aurei found in grave no. 3: Gordian III 2, Philip I 3 (AD 244-249) and possibly Hostilian 1 with a drachm of Gotarzes II and 3 denarii of Augustus found during excavations.
3 coins: Marcus Aurelius: denarius, dupondius; Trajan Decius sestertius (AD 249-251).
Total amount of coins is unknown. The hoard contains 1 denarius and 236 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
The hoard comprised a considerable number of Continental Iron Age silver coins, which were quickly dispersed or melted down.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 31 radiates of the third century AD. Chardome examined 18 in the Musèe de Beaufort in August 1973. Collin and Provost provide a different catalogue of 7 Gallienus, 5 Claudius II, 3 Postumus, 4 Victorinus, 1 Tetricus I, I Tetricus II.
disposition: Musèe de Beaufort, France (18 coins studied)

summary: Hoard of 114 denarii: Republic - Nero (AD 64-68).
A clay pot containing 7 hundred Roman coins made of "silver and copper".

The hoard comprised 2 copper-alloy urns containing 515 Roman coins (denarii, antoniniani (radiates) and bronzes). The majority of the coins were well preserved. The division of the coins between the 2 urns was not recorded. The hoard was found while extracting limest1. Vespasian - Tacitus (AD 275-276).
2 denarii found on manor field: C. Porcius Cato, Hadrian (119-122).
disposition: Museum of Moravia, Brno, Czech Republic

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 15 pieces were recorded: Republic - Tiberius (AD 14-37).
The hoard comprised 29 silver and 8 bronze coins dated between 103-76 BC and AD 260-268.

The hoard comprised between 400 and 500 Roman coins and fragments of copper-alloy ornaments or instruments, all broken. 50 years after the discovery, Sayn (1925) suggested that the coins dated to the second century AD. The hoard was found by a young man in unknown circumstances.

A hoard of 582 late Roman coins, found in room D of house 113 during excavations of the University of Michigan Expedition at Kom Aushim-Karanis in 1925. The hoard comprised 2 barbarous imitation of radiates, 355 late Roman imperial coins, and 225 cast imitations.
76 coins: 51 antoniniani (radiates), 25 sestertii; silver w8: 16.5-147.8 g.
Hoard of 166 denarii (512.94 gr.) found stack together: Vespasian - Septimius Severus. It was found within the settlement of Chernyakov culture.
The hoard comprised a black ceramic vessel containing 270 antoniniani (radiates) from Gallienus to Aurelian. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of 73.9g and 336.5g
9 siliquae of Maximus of Barcelona found during the archaeological investigations at a domestic structure.
disposition: Museo del Corcho de Palafrugell, Girona, Spain

summary: A hoard of 4 siliquae of Theodosius, Marcian and Leo I (AD 457-474).

A hoard of denarii, found in an earthenware container, together with 3 silver bracelets, during the construction of the road from Kindelbrück to Weißensee, under an area of arable land. The con10t of the hoard was dispersed, but it could have amounted to more than 230 denarii.
The hoard comprised close to 20000 coins of which 490 were seen. These included issues of Saloninus, Gallienus and Postumus.

Coins at site of Nornour on Scilly Isles. The settlement was excav. in 1960s & early 1970s. Consisted of 11 circular st1 buildings, occupied & modified from MBA to end of Iron Age. During RB period most of settlement aband1d but a large collection of Roman artefacts dating from late 1st to 4th centuries AD found in the upper levels of buildings 1 and 2 (Butcher 1993). These comprised over 300 copper-alloy brooches, c. 25 finger rings, 10 bracelets, 83 Roman coins, glass beads, 13 pipe-clay figurines, miniature pots & other Roman artefacts (Butcher 2000-1). site initially interpreted as brooch-making workshop (Dudley 1968) but since reinterpreted as shrine (Butcher 1978; 1993; 2000-1). Penhallurick 2000-1. In S. Butcher. Roman Nornour, Isles of Scilly: a reconsideration. Cornish Archaeol. 39-40: 5-44.
39 Roman imperial denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
103 denari: Vitellius - Septimius Severus (AD 197-198); silver w8: 262.8-420.7 g.
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 12 (103 coins).

summary: 1 solidus of Valentinian II, 4 miliarenses and 61 siliquae, found over a period of several years, ranging from Constantius II to Arcadius, AD 395. Some of the siliquae were irregular 1s.
104 denarii: 71 Republic, 21 legionary series, 12 imperial: Republic - Augustus (2 BC - AD 4).
109 silver coins: 6 denarii, 103 antoniniani: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 247-248).
Hoard of nummi found within the ruins of a fortress. Only 3 coins are known: Maximian I, Maximinus II Daia, Licinius I as they entered the private collection A.N.Simonov.
8 Alexandrian bronzes: Claudius I 2, Vespasian 6. Probably part of the El-Hiba 43, found during excavations.
2 aurei of Vespasian and Trajan, probably, found in Braga.
16 Iron Age silver coins, found over a period of several years in a field.
A hoard of 50-1 cast bronze coins found in the gully of a roundhouse

Not far from Cunetium, at the top of the Salisbury Hill, a pot was found containing a considerable number of coins, almost all British, with 1 coin of Tiberius. The coins were dispersed, although some were later given to the British Museum. It was noted that they included some small silver coins of Epaticcus. With them were some uninscribed British coins (Remic type), of the type which originally had a coin of Philip of Macedon for its pattern. -- see hoard http://chre.ashmus.ox.ac.uk/hoard/2327 as well.
5000 antoniniani (radiates) found with more ceramic pots. Only 2249 were available for study: Valerian I and Gallienus - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 272).
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueologia, Lisboa; Museu Municipal do Bombarral; Museu Municipal Pedro Nunes, Alcácer do Sal, Portugal; private collection, Barcelona, Spain

summary: Originally 390, 371 preserved: Vitellius - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195); silver w8: 965.17 g.

5 Late Roman gold coins (Valentinian I - Anastasius, including 1 imitation), found during fieldwork ('Plaggenstechen') on the heather. A golden neckband was found nearby and it is to be assumed that the coins, all with loops, were pendants for this neckband. The find was made in the area of the 'Heidenstatt', today named "Heidenschanze", which is a large ring wall system (50 BC - end of 1st c. AD) close to Sievern.
45 nummi found hidden under an ashlar. The coins were issued for Theodosius I and Honorius, type GLORIA ROMANORVM (AD 393-395).
The hoard comprised 20 aurei of Augustus (27 BC - AD 14).
The hoard was concealed under 3 st1 slabs. There was no evidence of a container.

The hoard was found buried under a small heap of st1s and comprised 22 bronze coins. Of these coins, 11 were identified as dupondii or asses of particular emperors. The others were not identified with any certainty, but were 'more or less recognisable' as issues of Vespasian or Titus, Domitian, Trajan and Hadrian.
Unknown number of silver coins found in a ceramic vessel. 102 coins entered the museum collection in Kazanlak: 1 denarius, 101 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).

The Winchester hoard, a find of Iron Age / early Roman gold jewellery and 5 denari (now in the British Museum).BM collections online: "The Winchester hoard objects did not come from a grave, settlement or temple, but had been buried on their own on top of a small hill that might have been covered with trees. They may have been buried for safekeeping or as a religious offering.The hoard has 2 sets of gold jewellery, each comprising a necklace torc and 2 gold brooches held together by a chain. There are also 2 gold bracelets. A total of 1160 grams of very pure gold was used to make the objects. 1 of the torcs is bigger than the other, possibly because 1 was made for a man and the other for a woman".TAR 2000 pps. 16-18, no. 8; TAR 2001 91, p.181.
The hoard comprised '7 bronzes and 3 small bronzes' of Nîmes.' These should probably be interpreted as Augustan asses from Nîmes.

In January 2022, 2 detectorists each independently found a golden aureus on the same plot of land in the municipality of Sittard-Geleen. The coins were subsequently reported to PAN by both finders. Rumor has it that some additional gold coins may have been found at this site, but this is uncertain. In April 2022, 1 of the detectorists found another aureus. The 3 coins are: Vespasian, Titus and Trajan.
(c. 550) 165 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero - Commodus (AD 181-191).
The hoard comprised an unknown number of late antique gold coins, from Arcadius to Avitus. 96 coins were recorded for a global w8 of 427.2g.
6 sestertii: Marcus Aurelius, Severus Alexander 2, Julia Mammea, Maximinus I Thrax, Paulin (Diva) brought together with other Roman materials: glass urns, bricks.

During excavations on the site of the ancient town of Lyka, a hoard of 7 provincial coins of the Koinon of Macedonia (Hadrian - Faustina II) was found in trench II, in a very burnt layer, near a cencer and in the same depth with it and nearby silver votive plaques with relief representation. These have been interpreted as remnants of a ritual act, a "sealed group" of votive offerings in honour of a deity.
3561 coins of Lucius Verus.

A hoard of Iron Age staters found in Climping, at a rally in 2000 during which a Roman denarii hoard was found as well, and then in 2002. Estimates of the total con10ts are unreliable, but minimum figures of c. 50 Climping staters and c. 60 British Q - mostly Qb (ABC 488) - appear to be reasonable, while an upper total of c.135 coins has been suggested (de Jersey). A list of 65 coins is given in de Jersey, out of a possible total of ca. 110-135 coins.
12 silver coins: 4 denarii, 8 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver w8: 16-26.8 g.
(+38) 38 antoniniani (radiates): Aurelian - Probus (AD 276-282); silver w8: 7.9-46.6 g.

A hoard of possibly 35+ late Roman gold coins, including at least 5 medallions (Honorius, Galla Placidia), as well as solidi of 'Constantine', 'Valentinian', Valens, Gratian, Arcadius, Honorius, Johannes and 'other emperor and empresses at that time'. The medallions were encased in frames and attached to a gold necklace. Bracelets are also reported of.
disposition: Numismatic National Collection (2 coins); Cabinet des Médailles, Bibliothèque nationale de France, Paris (2 coins)

summary: A scatter of coins from the hoard were found by a farmer. A systematic investigation of the findspot by Mr. Pioger and Térouanne recoverd a further scatter of 800 coins as well as excavating 3 vessels containing 3600 coins (radiates and copies): Gordian III - Probus (AD 276-282). A catalogue of 1941 coins was prepared by R. Boissel. In addition, there were 2500 imitations and minimi. The coins were dispersed in June 1976, although some of the imitations were preserved in particular collections. A small portion of the hoard was found by a farmer. Following its discovery, there was a systematic investigation of the site. Silver: c.3600 (1941) coins; Silver w8: c.271.1-1874.1g

The hoard comprised more than 212 sestertii and antoniniani (radiates) from Hadrian to Postumus. All the coins with clear reverses of Postumus were from his 1st issue at Trier, suggesting a tpq of AD 260 to 261. However, 16 of the coins of Postumus were described as having 'diverse' reverses so we cannot be exactly certain of this date.
2 hoards not entirely recovered. 1 contained 7 coins: Salonina, Tacitus, Probus (5).
Unknown original number of coins. 19 antoniniani (radiates) were sold to a goldsmith. Probably the same hoard menti1d as found with an urn.

2 groups of coins, discovered in May 1989 while metal detecting on building ground at Elphinst1 Road, Hastings. The first group of coins (92 bronze coins, Nero - Hadrian) were found with the remains of a pot and the second group (52 denarii found 'in a lump', with 7 later addenda, Republic - Hadrian) was about 40 to 50 feet away from the first. This may suggest successive deposits but they were treated as 1 find at the time. They have been split here. This record is for the silver coins.
The hoard comprised between 500 and 600 Roman coins. The coins were bought by M. de Bois-Robert, a collector from Montreuil at the end of the 18th century or the beginning of the 19th.

539 nummi found with textile rests in a room destroyed by fire, located on the right side of the fort's prae10tura/principia? of the legionary fortress: Constantine I - Arcadius-Honorius (AD 402-408). Together with the coins were found: 1 melted silver item, 1 small ceramic pitcher, 1 lamp, 1 fragment from a cross-bow brooch, 2 knives, 1 iron key, 1 b1 hair comb.
disposition: Historische Museum der Stadt Wien, Austria

summary: 193 nummi found in an ox b1: Constans - Valentinian III (AD 425-455).
It comprises 15 Visigothic 'wreath' solidi of Valentinian III (AD 439-455) found in a lead roll.
3 coins: Hadrian dupondius, Septimius Severus denarius, Gordian III dupondius (AD 238-244).
Unknown initial number of coins. 40 silver coins: denarii, antoniniani: Caracalla - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver w8: 51.2-99.8 g.
disposition: Regional History Meseum, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1410-1414

summary: (+500) provincial bronze coins. 37 pieces entered the museum collection in Targovishte: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
56 denarii found in the Seaside baths complex. Only 31 have survived: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 202-205).

73 Icenian Iron Age coins and 14 Roman denarii found on a string of small sand islands surrounded by black peat, over a number of years. It is however difficult to give a precise breakdown of all the coins found at Joist Fen, or their relationship with each other.
4 denarii part of a hoard found on the same field like GANDARVE 1927, 1928, 1928-1931: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Diva Faustina I, Lucius Verus (AD 163-165).
34 nummi: Diocletian - Arcadius (297-402).
The hoard(?) comprised a "cluster" of 7 silver coins - 4 denarii, 1 plated denarius, 1 drachm - deposited during the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
Republican to AD 193-221 Silver: 527 coins; Silver w8: 966.2-1890.2g
A small hoard (or part of a larger 1?) of 4 denarii (Antoninus Pius - Julia Domna) found between the 2 southern walls of the horreum (grain warehouse) of the military fort of Mil10berg-Altstadt.

5 coins from the Trajan Decius reign were discovered by treasure hunters in 2011. The exact location and circumstances of the find are unknown. The coins have traces of fire, therefore, they may have been found in a burial (cremation).

The hoard comprised between 300 and 400 Roman coins, stuck together with corrosion products: Gallienus (sole) - Allectus (AD 286-293). Approximately 80 coins were destroyed during cleaning. Just over 220 coins were identified by A. Deville. In 1846, a further 4 or 5 argentei (?) and 40 antoniniani (radiates) said to be from the same hoard were noted by Joseph Curt. In 1862, Charles Roach Smith published an aureus from a Continental mint (RIC 621) from the Warne Collection which was reputed to be from the same hoard. The stated provenance for this coin should be treated with some caution. The nummus of Constantine I is also an intruder.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités, Rouen; Muncipal Library of Rouen; Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliothéque Natinoale, the Musée de Boulogne-sur-Mer, the British Museum (fewer than 10 coins), the Ashmolean Museum (fewer than 3 coins

summary: 109 antoniniani (radiates) found with ceramic vessel: Valerian I and Gallienus (Saloninus Caesar) - Diocletian/Maximian I (AD 284-293).
24 coins: 2 antoniniani (radiates), 1 denarius, 6 sestertii, 4 dupondii, 12 asses: Tiberius (Divus Augustus) – Florian (AD 276)
51 denarii found within Roman ruins: Republic - Augustus (20-19 BC).
Hoard of at least 167 silver coins found with ceramic vessel: 1 imitation of a Macedonia Prima tetradrachm, 1 drachm of Rhoemetalces I, 161 denarii: Republic - Augustus (11-10 BC).
disposition: City Museum of History, Nova Zagora, Bulgaria (161 coins); inv.nos . 2005 -2008)

summary: 100 provincial bronze coins found in a bronze vessel. 39 pieces entered the museum collection in Shumen: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 12089 (39 coins)

summary: Circa 700 nummi of Maxentius and other contemporary emperors.
A list of coins not securely belonging to the hoard. Nr. 3-4 are badly preserved, thus a clear determination is not possible.

3 4th C. coins (1 of House of Constantine I AD 335-47, 2 uncertain AE, found in single homogenous fill of 'working hollow', assoc. with poss. hearth/fire pit. Also late 4th C pottery. Poss. a small purse hoard, but not found in a tight group.

16 coins found with a ceramic vessel during archaeological excavations in a Carpic settlement. The coin of Antoninus Pius could be an intruder, otherwise 16 denarii: Mark Antony 8, Mark Antony 1 imitation, Augustus 1, Vespasian 5, 1 barbarous imitation.
15 coins: 3 denarii, 5 antoniniani. 7 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver w8: 10.9-17.1 g.
The hoard comprised 7 gold Celtic Iron Age staters.

Since at least 1969, an uncertain number of water-worn Iron Age staters have been recovered from the beach at Barton-on-Sea, mostly just to the west of the small stream which runs onto the beach at Beckton Bunny. They have presumably come from a hoard eroded out of the low cliff.
3 solidi of Valentinian II (2) and Arcadius (AD 383-388); gold w8: 13.35g.

The hoard comprised a ceramic urn containing an unknown number of third century Roman coins stuck together with corrosion products. They were found on the site of an Iron Age oppidum. 141 coins: Septimius Severus - Quintillus (AD 270)

The hoard comprised 2 aurei of Commodus, some silver denarii and an unknown number of bronze denominations. A further 3 solidi, including 1 of Constantine I and 1 of Constans, as well as a poorly described issue were also found although it is to be doubted whether they formed part of the hoard.

The collection of Mme Tourgouilhet du Martray contained 20 Roman coins found in or around Guérande including 1 aureus of Nero and 1 aureus of Vespasian. It is not clear whether the coins were site finds or part of a hoard.
disposition: The collection of Mme Tourgouilhet du Martray

summary: 99 denarii: Republican 46, imperial 53: Republic - Domitian (AD 81-96).
Hoard of 212 nummi: Constantine I - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
4 sestertii: 2 Marcus Aurelius, 2 Lucilla. Identification based on a picture. (Lang 2007, 257, fig. 153); w8, c. 80 g.

302 nummi and 1 gold finger ring discovered inside an earthenware container near a steam on Bodlywydd-uchaf farm. Most of the coins were observed to be of Constantine and his sons, including a number of GLORIA EXERCITVS and city commemorative types, but the majority of the hoard was dispersed by the finder soon after its discovery. In light of this, it cannot be known whether the opening and closing dates given for this hoard are correct. 2 further nummi were found in the same area by metal detectorists in 1987.
Hoard of mixed gold and silver coins and jewelry: denarii, solidi, half-siliqua. The latest coin, a miliarensis of Zeno (AD 474-491).
39 silver coins: 1 denarius, 38 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 260-269)
disposition: Musées royaux des Beaux-Arts de Belgique (39 coins)

summary: 7 sestertii: Antoninus Pius - Postumus (AD 260-269); together with 3 bronze rings.
5 asses of Augustus (15 BC).
Group of 22 coins: 21 antoniniani radiates of Claudius II (Divus) and 1 nummus of Valentinian II.
Unknown initial number of antoniniani. 8 pieces entered the museum collection in Sofia: Gordian III 1, Philip I 1, Otacilia Severa 1, Trajan Decius 5.
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 21422-21429 (8 coins)

summary: 2648 antoniniani (radiates) in a lump of over 5 kg: Trebonianus Gallus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
disposition: Landesmuseum, Klagenfurt; Münzkabinett, Kunsthistorischen Museum, Vienna, Austria (16 coins)

summary: 26 silver coins: 17 denarii, 9 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 251); silver w8: 35.5-53.2 g.

The 16 coins listed here (14 sestertii and 2 dupondii, ranging from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius) were found in the area of the Dampfziegelei in 1897 and 1898. All coins have the same patina and corrosion, so it could be a hoard. Further particulars about the circumstances of the find are undetermined.
Probably, 2 solidi of Valentinian III (AD 426-430) minted in Ravenna.
The hoard was found during the course of a rescue excavation and comprised 8 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Valerian and Gallienus.
596 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); Silver w8: 745.6-1548.5 g.
disposition: Museum of Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 9091-9632; 9469-9588 (557 coins)

summary: Hoard of at least 52 coins, part of a deposit of 61 coins recovered from the backfill of a well in Victoria Road, Winchester (F1093) during archaeological excavations in the 1970s. No evidence for a container was found.
1 silver stater and 13 bronze staters, reportedly found at Breakheart Bottom in 1991.

A total of 255 coins were found at Langwood Hill, Chatteris. Many of these were bronze coins ranging from the 1st to the 4th centuries AD. Of the remaining 1 gold and 30 silver coins, 23 were declared Treasure Trove and seem to represent 1 or more hoards, although their exact composition remains unclear. These 23 coins consists mainly in Icenian silver and Roman denarii (Republic to Tiberius).
A confused record of an undeclared hoard of 20 Gallo-Belgic E staters.
The hoard comprised approximately 50 silver Iron Age coins, 1 drachm of Marseille and 1 bronze of Ampurias. The hoard was found in a spring.
15 coins found in group in the remains of a Roman building, while excavating in the cellar of the Theological Seminar.
disposition: Rheinisches Landesmuseum, Bonn, Germany (inv. no. EV 1033)

summary: Hoard of 72 nummi, most of them belonged to Constantine I.

West Parade site Area III, Roman interval tower. In late Roman period, interval tower became derelict, & much of upper part prob. demolished/ robbed. Lower part of tower infilled with demolition debris, incl. ceramic tile frags. & mortar, animal b1 waste from food consumption, & bird & animal skeletons, incl. ravens & dogs, frogs & toads, & remains of owl pellets. 3 silver denarii in fine condition also found amongst demolition debris, of Trajan, Hadrian & Faustina, minted in early to mid 2nd C. before tower even built; & it is likely that they were hidden & subsequently lost, poss. as part of a larger hoard, whilst tower was still in use.Gilmour, B. 1999. Excavations. In C. Colyer, B.J.J. Gilmour & B. J1s The Defences of the Lower City. Excavations at The Park and West Parade 1970-2 and a Discussion of Other Sites Excavated up to 1994. The Archaeology of Lincoln VIII-2. CBA Res. Report 114, pp. 191.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 200 Iron Age coins in a good state of preservation. A second hoard of 110 (or 200?) coins, also in a ceramic vessel was found during the construction of the Maison de Gaburos. The hoard was found by a farmer, working in a field covered in brick and st1s. Probably, there is only 1 hoard.
The hoard comprised 755 prutot, deposited during the Jewish War (AD 66-72/3)

Over 700 late Roman coins recovered from ditch 535 during excavs in 1984-1985, & it was suggested that there are too many for casual loss. 500-520 coins at least make up hoard, dispersed either because original container broke or it was organic & subsequently decomposed. Further Roman features incl. field enclosures & burials.Davies, J.A. 1997. The Roman coins from Old Place, Sleaford. In S.M. Elsdon Old Sleaford Revealed. A Lincolnshire Settlement in Iron Age, Roman, Saxon & Medieval Times: Excavations 1882-1995. Oxbow, pp. 39, 176-180.
3 Iron Age coins (1 gold quarter stater of Cunobelin and 2 fragments of silver units of Amminus) and 6 Roman denarii (3 Republican, 2 Flavian and 1 unidentified fragment).
Hoard of 74 denarii found near a Dacian settlement: Republic – Augustus (2 BC – AD 4).
4th century.Small hoard of Roman coins found in 1978 in building beside Ermine Street in Area II of excavs of Roman settlement. Most coins in a heap with few scattered more widely.
Excavation of the Celtic Oppidum. In the layers dating from the time of Augustus, 4 Turonos Cantorix coins were found that could be a hoard, a purse or a deposition.
Hoard of 700 imperial bronze coins in the museum of Cagliari.
Unknown number of provincial bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel. 22 coins entered museum collection in Plovdiv: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2168

summary: 181 bronze coins: Greek - Valens: 1 Greek, 2 provincial, nummi.
Unpublished hoard of 3 denarii in BM file report. Declared Treasure Trove in 1980.
186 nummi from the time of Theodosius I (AD 379-395).
36 denari: 24 republican, 12 imperial: Republic - Titus (AD 80).
disposition: Muzeul Național de Istorie a României, Cabinetul Numismatic, Bucharest, Romania

summary: 343 bronze coins: 337 sestertii, 6 dupondii: Galba - Septimius Severus (AD 193-196). W8:8205.03 g.
disposition: Saint-Remi History Museum, Reims, France; inv. nos. B-C

summary: Mint distribution is menti1d so can probably be entered at level of coin. Silver: 107, 28 coins; silver w8: 20.3-132.8g.
disposition: Société de recherches de l'Atrèbatie septentrionale

summary: A hoard of ca. 246 Iron Age coins, dispersed through trade, of which different sets of photographs exist.
The hoard comprised a ceramic urn containing a single dupondius or as of Gordian III and 60 radiates from Carus to Maximian I.
hoard of 7 aurei and 196 denari found with a ceramic vessel: Republic - Titus (AD 79-81).

The hoard comprised a black ceramic vessel containing a hoard of coins and jewellery. The jewellery included a gold necklace, 3 gold intaglio finger rings, a gold and silver intaglio finger ring and an iron finger ring with silver decoration. The number of coins in the hoard is not known with any certainty. Pérot claims there were 100 sestertii and 150 denarii, whereas Clément catalogued 92 coins, including 67 bronzes (mostly sestertii) and 25 denarii (and radiates?). There were some identification errors with 1 sestertius and 2 denarii attributed to Antoninus Pius, when in fact they were issues of Caracalla.
A hoard of 1314 late Roman coins (1 aureus, 5 argentei and 1308 nummi ranging from Diocletian to Constantine I) that appear to have been buried in a wooden box.
An inhabitant of Lusignan found the hoard while digging.

The hoard comprises 561 bronze coins and several fragments (total w8 270 grams) dating between the second half of the 3rd century and the reign of Valentinian III (260-437 AD). A distinctive feature is the high amount of clipped coins and ancient imitations, some of them of local production. The imitative issues date the concealment to the third quarter of the 5th century AD.
disposition: Aquileia, Archaeological National Museum; University of Padua, department of Cultural Heritage

summary: 22 silver coins buried directly in the ground. 13 pieces were identified: Antoninus Pius - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).

A major late-Roman hoard of coins, gold jewellery and silver table u10sils was found in November 1992 at Hoxne, Suffolk. The Hoxne treasure was buried in a wooden box. Apart from the coins, the hoard comprised gold jewellery and small items of silver tableware. The find-spot is some 4 miles from the location where the Eye hoard of 650 gold coins of the same period was said to have been discovered in 1780. In total, 15210 coins were part of the hoard: 580 solidi (Valentinian I – Honorius); 60 miliarenses, 14137 siliquae, 5 half-siliquae and 428 irregular siliquae (Constantius II – Constantine III). Several addenda to the hoard were found after 1992.
126 bronze coins: 88 sestertii, 9 dupondii, 8 asses, 1 provincial coin; 20 bronze coins unknown denomination: Augustus - Antoninus Pius (AD 154-161).
disposition: Hungarian National Museum, Budapest, Hungary (1897); inventory list no. 460/1896

summary: 246 denarii found while ploughing: Hadrian - Septimius Severus (AD 202)
13482 nummi: Constantine I - Valentinian III (AD 425-435).
disposition: Cabinet des médailles de la Bibliothèque nationale de France Paris, France

summary: Hoatrd of 501 nummi re-discovered in the museum collections: Claudius Ii - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueologia, Lisboa, Portugal

summary: 20-25000 nummi found with a ceramic vessel. The latest coins belong to Honorius (AD 395-423).
disposition: Ca.mara Municipal de Paredes de Coura (5,000 coins)

summary: 83 eastern antoniniani (radiates) ranging in date from the joint reign of Valerian and Gallienus to Diocletian.
19 nummi ranging from Julian II to Jovian.
disposition: Museum at the Institute of Archaeology, Viminacium. Inv. 04_117/1-19.

summary: Unknown initial number of denarii; at least 10 were seen of which 1 of Vespasian.
disposition: D.I. Samokwesowa collection, Warszaw, Poland (1 denarius)

summary: 100 sestertii found together on an opus signinum floor: Hadrian - Trebonianus Gallus (Volusian Augustus) (AD 251-253).

The hoard comprised 2 or 3 ceramic urns filled with Roman coins, weighing approximately 5 kilos or perhaps 1200 coins. Although the containers were broken up and the hoard dispersed, 762 coins were recovered in the days following the hoard's discovery, including 10 from the presumed findspot. They were all radiates from Gordian III to Claudius II and Postumus.

111 coins confiscated in 1981. The find encompassed 69 provincial coins from Thessalonica (Commodus - Philip II), 14 from Pella (Caracalla - Otacilia Severa), 6 from Edessa (Caracalla - Gordian III), 3 from Dion (Elagabalus - Maximinus); 1 from Stobi (Septimius Severus), 9 from the Koinon of Macedonia, 5 uncertain 1s of 'Greek cities', 4 imperial coins (Vespasian - Maximinus).
The hoard comprised 348 coins: 1 antoninianus (radiate) and 347 nummi dated between AD 278-282 and AD 321-324 and 2 later coins dated between AD 351-361.
370 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Marius (AD 269); silver w8: 102.2-959.7 g.
800 silver coins: Nerva - Elagabalus (AD 218-222). No further Information.
40 denarii and 30 sestertii ranging from Domitian to Commodus (Crispina).
6 solidi found between 1788 and 1887 within the same village. Probably belonging to a larger hoard: Valentinian III 2, Theodosius II 2, Leo I 1, Libius Severus 1 (AD 461-465).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology and History in Elbląg (Elbing) (until 1944)

summary: 31 nummi, range: Constans/Constantius II - House of Theodosius (AD 379-423). Possible, part of the hoard Termini Imerse 1984 A.
disposition: Museo Civico "B. Romano" Comune di Termini Imerese

summary: 141 denarii. No further Information.
9 denarii: Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180)

The hoard comprised 50 Roman coins which were thought to be bronzes. There is no further information on denominational composition. It was found on communal heathland and pasture, at a very shallow depth. The majority of the coins were collected together by M. Auvray, mayor of Aclou.

The hoard comprised approximately 100 Roman silver coins in a ceramic vessel. The vessel was found inside an iron box. The coins were Roman in date. Lapierre purchased 4 of them. 3 depicted Roman emperors and the last a Roman empress.

The hoard comprised a large ceramic pot containing 15kg of 4th century nummi, approximately 5000 coins. The coins appeared to have been arranged in piles. The hoard was dispersed but Chaurand was able to study 1037 coins which had been kept by the finder's family. With the exception of 2 SOLI INVICTO COMITI issues struck in London and Arles in AD 315 to 316, the hoard comprised coins issued between AD 318 to 326. The hoard was found in a vineyard. Mints: 77 Londinium, 77 Lugdunum, 464 Treveri, 141 Arelate, 30 Roma, 90 Ticinum, 19 Aquileia, 46 Siscia, 2 Sirmium, 22 Thessalonica, 2 Nicomedia, 1 Cyzicus; uncertain 66.
636 nummi of the House of Constantine I and Licinius I (AD 328-329).
11 provincial bronze coins found in the barracks: Severus Alexander issued at the mints of Nicopolis ad Istrum and Marcianopolis (AD 222-235).
A scattered hoard with a complexe record, containing a minimum of perhaps 10 or 11 staters of Cunobelin, together with an aureus of Augustus.

The hoard comprised a total of either 5027 (according to Vlachogianni) or 5044 coins (previous reports). These include radiates from Caracalla to Gallienus and Salonina and 1 Roman Provincial bronze of Augustus from Sparta.
4 antoniniani (Gordian III - Trajan Decius) found during field work.

The hoard comprised a vessel containing 700 'large, medium and small bronzes' to which should probably be added a further 100 pieces which were scattered in the area surround the vessel. They included radiates and some GENIO POPVLI ROMANI nummi.
The hoard comprised a copper-alloy patera or pan containing 700 denarii from Augustus to Maximinus, a silver intaglio finger ring and an unspecified amount of gold jewellery.

Given the uncertainty about the origins of the hoard (found by a shepherd boy in a flint?), and in particular its possible confusion with Farley Heath, the reconstruction presented here must be treated with some caution (de Jersey). 18 coins, out of a possible total of 40 (?).
Unknown initial number of coins. Based on the diameter it is assumed they were sestertii. 51 coins were examined: Hadrian - Postumus (AD 260-268).
40 denarii and antoniniani.

Evans (1890, 485, repeated by Allen 1960a, 207) recorded several potins found at Bardwell, of his pl. H.8 type (cl. II). 3 coins can still be traced. As Haselgrove (1987, 283 no. 40) has pointed out, there is a Romano-British fort and settlement here and the coins could well be multiple site finds.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 300 sestertii from Hadrian to Septimius Severus.

2747 bronze coins, ranging from the 4th century BC (Neandria) to Basiliscus (AD 475-476), found in a small pot during the excavations lead by G. Brunton at Qaw el-Kebir, south of Asyut. Most of the coins were late Roman nummi, with some Ptolemaic and Alexandrian bronzes and coins from Aksum. 1264 coins were barbaric imitations or casts.
The hoard comprised 642 denarii and radiates from Septimius Severus to Postumus. Hobbes estimates a silver w8 of 157.1g.
Over 60 denarii found on a field during 19th-21st centuries: Vespasian - septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
disposition: National Museum of Archaeology, Warszaw, Poland (6 coins); Private collection (21 coins)

summary: 6 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Victorinus (AD 269-271).
Large hoard of silver coins. Only 5 pieces are known: Aurelian 2, Tacitus 1, Probus 2; silver w8: 1.0-1.4g.
12 antoniniani (radiates) found stuck together surrounded by some organic remaines froma leather bag: Gordian III - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-259).
135 sestertii found in a cooking pot covered by a plate: Domitian - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 236-238).
A siliqua of Honorius, from the mint of Trier, now in the BM, was found in the earth filling of a window-box of a flat in St. Pancras, together with 6 other siliquae of Valens, Maximus, and Arcadius.

This set of coins found in the Hispanic Roman city of Torrepared1s (Baena, Córdoba), which has been identified as Virtus Iulia ltuci, a city referred to by Pliny as a colonia immune of the Conventus Astigitanus. Though not quantitatively significant, the set is notable for its homogeneity and the rarity of its coins: it is composed of 6 dupondii and 1 as of the Nero period, which were all minted in Lugdunum in 66-67 AD. Its exceptional state of conservation and it is being discovered in the aerarium of the Curia, suggests that these coins were part of a consignment from the Imperial administration to the city of ltuci yet they were never circulated.
A hoard of a certain size was found in 1885 in Sandbruch. 29 coins (Magnentius - Constantius II) of this hoard are now in the Museum in Mainz.

“Possibly 200 (Roman bronze?) coins. Confirmation required. This information is only recorded by Weerakkody, based on personal information from Bopearachchi. The latter repeatedly mentions without detail, “several hundreds of unpublished Roman and Indo-Roman coins from Bentota, Kalutara and Negombo”.
±100 Republican and Imperial denarii ending with Augustus (27 BC - AD 14).
6 coins (Tetricus - Gratian) were found during the demolition of a building located next to the cemetery (under the foundations of the house or possibly, next to the chimney).

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 85 sestertii, the majority of which were rendered illegible by oxidation. However, those that could be identified range from issues of Hadrian to Commodus.
The hoard comprised at least 414 coins from the first part of the 5th century AD.
The hoard comprised 2 batches containing 24 bronzes from Trajan to Antoninus Pius for the first and 300 bronzes for the second.
Unknown number of bronze coins. 387 entered the museum collection in Sofia: Marcus Aurelius - Gallienus (AD 260-268). 13 coins are countermarked.
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 23101-23493

summary: Hoard of 18 solidi of Honorius, Theodosis II, Leo and Zeno (c.480) Gold: 18 coins; Gold w8: 80.1g;

The hoard comprised 97 nummi of a small module size (AE 3 and AE 4), ranging from Constans to the time of Theodosius I. Coins and 5 pieces of small sculpture in marble lay together within a small area in the fill of rubble construction in 1 of the buildings immediately east of the temple of Poseidon. The hoard has been interpreted as being deposited when Alaric invaded the Peloponnese in AD 396.
circa 150 denarii, 30 preserved. Nero-Seveus Alexander (AD 227). 1 nummus of Constantius II is an intruder.
27 Kentish potin and 1 Roman Republican denarius of C. Vibius Pansa (RRC 342). The Republican denarius is later in date than the potins.

This record has been created for the HER record of a hoard of 36 third century Roman coins found in the Waddon New Road, Croydon. The details of this find seem to differ from those associated with Robertson 2000, 235 no. 963: (apparently a 4th century hoard found in 1903) and the tetrarchic hoard of 34 coins found before 1914 associated with Robertson 2000, 251 no. 1047.Seaby's Coins and Medals Bulletin 1961, 234 reports 36 coins found in the Waddon New Road area during the excavation of a cutting between West Croydon and Pitlake in 1814 and in a private collection. Details are unfortunately vague: "All were Antoninianii and the range of dates encompassed only 30 years...Several rulers were represented and all coins with the exception of 1 originated from the same mint - Rome".
Hoard of circa 4000 coins. 400 coins entered the collection of Gh. Georgescu-Corabia, including issues of Pupienus, Gordian III and Philip I.
Hoard of denarii dispersed among locals. 88 denarii entered museums' collections. 6 denarii can be entered at coin level: Antoninus Pius 1, Lucius Verus 1, Faustina II 3, Commodus 1.
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Warsaw (8 coins), Lublin (60 coins), Poland; Local museum, Lutsk (20 coins), Ukraine.

summary: A hoard was found in Chassenon at some time in the 9teenth century AD and comprised 10 coins from Maximinus I Thrax to Aemilian. Some of the coins were kept by the family and can be identified by M. Dhénin. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of 12.6-22.9 g.
(?) 51 sestertii: Trajan - Severus Alexander (AD 228-231).
