The hoard comprised a greyware ceramic vessel containing 6000 coins from Valerian I to Probus. The last coin is of Probus, Lyon mint, AD 281 (Bastien type 347 or 348). Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of between 1161.2g and 6865.6g.
2830 silver coins: 2827 denarii, 1 plated denarius, 2 drachms: Augustus - Septimius Severus (AD 196-197); silver w8: before restoration: 9290g; after restoration: 9075.17g
disposition: History Museum ”Iulian Antonescu” Bacau, Bacau County, Romania

summary: A hoard of 2000+ silver coins (mainly Cappadocian didrachms, drachms and hemidrachms; 2 Lycian drachms; c.100 denarii) deposited c. 185 and found in 4 bronze pots in the village of Sor, near Kayseri. It was dispersed in several batches in the art trade. A large portion was published by W. Metcalf (932 coins) and another by W. Weiser (178 coins, the 'Münchner Fundkomplex'). In addition, 140 coins were recorded in Paris in 1980 (RPC III, p. 376). They consisted in 26 denarii (Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius), and 114 coins from Caesarea (Vespasian - Commodus)
15 coins: 3 heavily worn out denarii, 12 provincial bronze coins found in a sacred area (sanctuary) in a small dish: Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
200 Roman coins. No further information
The hoard comprised 10 Roman Imperial 'bronze' (i.e. antoniniani?) coins, found in a Roman bath house in the southern part of ancient Pella. The latest were of Aurelian, Florian and Probus.
Unknown number of solidi. 23 have been described: Valentinian I - Zeno (AD 474-476).
The hoard comprised 4 Republican denarii.

The hoard comprised 2 silver coins and 39 bronze coins. They were identified by Moreau de la Ronde who noted that they were all coins from the reign of Gallienus. The silver coins obviously date to before AD 260.

A group of 41 Roman gold and silver coins from the Republic to Claudius I, and a group of 5 staters of Cunobelin were found in 1981 at Manor Farm, Chippenham, Ely. It might be that these represent 2 separate deposits, as the finders stated that the material was concentrated in 2 areas in the field and they could not recall finding any of the Celtic coins alongside the Roman coins. The Roman coins clearly represent an early imperial hoard.
539 denarii and 538 antoniniani (radiates): Trajan - Postumus (AD 260-269).
10 Alexandria tetradrachms: Probus-Maximianus I (AD 284-285).
disposition: Museo Archeologico Regionale "P. Orsi", Siracusa: inv: 51795-51804

summary: 500 nummi found with a ceramic vessel: Tetrarchy - Honorius (AD 395-423). Only 54 could be identified.
disposition: Museo Archeologico Provinciale di Salerno, Italy (inv.nos. 17329-17382

summary: 1839 coins: 1834 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms, 5 Ptolemaic bronze coins: Ptolemaic dynasty - Aurelian (AD 270-275). "Acquired in Egypt by Dattari, who sold it to Milne and Currelly'.
disposition: Partly in Oxford, partly in Toronto. Detailed list in Oxford

summary: Hoard of denarii and antoniniani found in a ceramic vessel. 78 pieces entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: Severus Alexander - Probus (AD 276-282).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2072

summary: An imitation of Alexander III's stater and aureus of Augustus (27 BC - 14 AD).
disposition: private purchase by Ivan Stepapovich Ter-Asaturov

summary: 20 denarii: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 191).

Unknown originally number of coins. 119 silver coins: 89 antoniniani (radiates), 27 denarii and 3 uncertain silver denomination: Vespasian - Trajan Decius (AD 251). Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of 149.4-301.7 g.
A hoard of 84 "bronze coins dating to circa AD 350-360" found near the bath house of the Castle Hill villa complex during excavations in 1988-1989.See also IARCH-62F9DD

20323 bronze coins found under the pavement of a courtyard at the synagogue: Ptolemy IV - Zeno (AD 476-491). In Trench XII, after removing 3 large slabs and 8 medium sized 1s, 6000 coins were discovered. When the trench was enlarged 3 years later, another “19 kilograms” of coins were found. After cleaning, a total of 20323 coins were counted coming from Trench XII. In this trench, not 1, but 2 levels of mortar could be discerned, 1 on top of the other, and the coins were spread out between the upper layer and slabs of the floor, as well as between the first and second mortar level. After analyzing the layers, the excavators concluded that they were put in together to form the base for the courtyard and that the coins thus belong together.

Small hoard (?) of 18 coins retrieved in the museum collection coming from an old excavation. No further details on the conditions of discovery: Claudius II - Theodosius I/Arcadius/Honorius (AD 393-395).
Several hundred Roman silver coins (coins of Galba - Antoninus Pius / Marcus Aurelius are menti1d), found during building working in Minden, in or before 1844. The coins were lost.
30 bronze coins: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Found 800 m eastward from the hoard Koropie 2008 2
disposition: Laboratory of Archeology, Historical Sociology and Cultural Heritage, Faculty of Sociology, St. Petersburg State University, Russia

summary: 2 aureii of Vespasian from a lost hoard of 70-100 aureii, all of Vespasian
Large quantity of Roman provincial bronze coins. 50 coins were minted in Nicopolis ad Istrum, Marcianopolis, Hadrianopolis, Anchialus and Tomis.
Unknown initial number of coins. 1481 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. M I 453-1933

summary: 8 asses: Republic - Augustus (10-6 BC).
Hoard of 6 Roman coins, most likely denarii, including: Vespasian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

The hoard originally comprised ca. 1750 Greek/Roman republican/imperial/provincial silver and bronze coins ranging from 270 BC to the reign of Trajan (116 AD). 570 of them are know kept in the Shahat Archaeological Museum while further 84 specimens have been identified through photographic documentation.
2 denarii of Hadrian (AD 117-138).
The hoard comprised approximately 2000 coins ending with issues of Gordian III (AD 238-244).
50 bronze coins, probably, placed in a wooden box with b1 hinges: 49 sestertii, 1 as: Trajan - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
15 gold coins: 12 solidi, 3 tremisses: Leo I - Justin I (AD 518-524); gold w8: 57.9 g.
116 nummi: Constantine - Constantius II (AD 341-346).

3rd century. "6 coins, a small mid-3rd century AD hoard, found in soil (751A), 3 sealed by east wall (763) of Structure Y [a trapezoidal st1-walled enclosure appended to inner wall face of the round]. Another coin found in (728), the surface of Structure Y, & 2 more in overlying soil (785). These 3 coins of similar date & condition, & formed part of scattered hoard.

A hoard of 111 Roman imperial denarii was found by 5 treasure hunters in 2013 in Chernivtsi region. Information about the find and photos of some of the coins of the hoard were published by 1 of the finders on January 20, 2014 on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity. According to the finder, the hoard was found late at night, but there is no more detailed information about the further circumstances of the find. Judging by the information from the treasure hunter, the bulk of the coins in the hoard were denarii of Vespasian, Trajan and Hadrian, although there was also a coin of Galba, several denarii of Nerva, and 10-12 coins of Antoninus Pius and Faustina (I or II). In the photographs posted with the hoard information, there are images of 26 whole and 5 fragments of denarii (Vespasian, Terva, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius) – these were probably some of the coins that the informant found. The further fate of the coins in the hoard is unknown.
6 6 coins found near a tuff spring (votive offering?). 2 of the coins were halved: Augustus: 1 dupondius, 2 asses, 2 halved asses; Claudius I 1 As (AD 41-50).
68 denarii: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 150-151).

4600 coins dated between the end of the 3rd century and the 4th found during the excavations at the Roman villa. Most of the coins were nummi, some of them with the reverse REPARATIO REIPVB and GLORIA ROMANORVM. Fragments of linen were recovered from the coins, belonging to the bag with which the coins were kept.
disposition: Museu de Conimbriga/Câmara Municipal de Mêda, Portugal

summary: 16 sestertii: Trajan 13, Hadrian 3 (AD 121-122).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 13625-13640

summary: 3918 antoniniani of the second half of the 3rd century AD found on the territory of the village. No further information.

151 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms, 9 Greek bronzes, 1 provincial bronze and 1 ring: Ptolemaic dynasty - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 166-167). Reported to have been found in an alabaster container. Mixed up with another hoard of over 130 coins not identified.

A hoard of 653 denarii (Mark Antony – Geta) and 1 drachm of Caesarea in Cappadocia (Trajan), found in a garden at Muswell Hill in 1928, together with a silver spoon and a bronze ring, and pieces of the earthenware pot which had contained them.
35 solidi of Honorius and Arcadius (AD 394-395); gold w8: 155.75g.
A large hoard of Chute staters found by metal detectors over several visits, with a brief mention by Haselgrove (1978, 24).

The hoard comprised more than 30 'large bronze Roman coins. TAF speculates as to whether it is an entire hoard or part of a larger hoard. Found in a gravel quarry.32 coins were donated to the museum by M. Caille: Trajan - Postumus (AD 260-69).
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen, France. Inventory: III, 2, p. 78, no. 2005 (5.11.1908).

summary: 2611 coins, 2594 recovered: Vespasian - Valerian to Gallienus with some intruders (Divus Claudius II, Constantinopolis). Silver w8: 9270 kg.
IARCH record for a small Magnentian hoard of 16 nummi and a copper alloy bracelet. For full details and images see LANCUM-33EBC3. Unpublished catalogue by David Shotter and Stuart Noon.

A hoard of about 400 Roman silver coins, found at Torfoot, 7 miles south-west of Strathaven, in a glass bottle, while cleaning a drain. Coins of Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Faustina, wife of Antoninus, Crispina, wife of Commodus, and various other Emperors and Empresses, &c., all in good preservation, are menti1d. About 50 of the coins were so much verdigreated and adhering together, that they were broken with a hammer by a rude and unskillful hand, in order to separate them. J. Lindsay, View of the Coinage of Scotland (1845), 265, added Hadrian, Marcus, Caesar, Pompey and Crassus to the list of emperors etc. represented. The 3 last names may have been due to a misunderstanding of the legends on some coins. True Republican den. would be unusual in a hoard as late as the reign of Commodus.

Hoard of gold jewellrey and votive plates. From the 9 votive plates, 4 of them have stamped on the golden foil aurei of Diocletianus (2 plates) and Constantius I (1 plate) and 1 with an uncertain portrait, still 1 of the tetrarchs.
119 nummi of the period AD 306-318.
151 silver coins: 17 denarii, 134 antoniniani (radiates): Marcus Aurelius (Divus Antoninus Pius) - Trebonianus Gallus/Volusianus (AD 253).
disposition: The Iron Gates Region Museum Drobeta-Turnu Severin, Romania (1957)

summary: 204 nummi of the house of Constantine with a tpq of AD 340-341. No further information.
(1000-1200) 113 antoniniani: Gordian III - Tetrarchy (AD 293-294); silver w8: 217.1-1499.1 g.

In October 1987 members of the Andover Metal Detecting Club found 142 staters in 2 distinct clusters, approximately 55 m apart, 1 containing 58 coins and the other 84 (Haselgrove 1989, 13, 14). Each hoard - and it seems almost certain to be 2 separate deposits, rather than a scattered single hoard - contained a mixture of Gallo-Belgic E and British B (Chute) staters.
disposition: Museum of the Iron Age, Andover (part); Unknown (part)

summary: (896) 890 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (Ad 251-253).
The hoard comprised a ceramic urn filled with approximately 400 Roman sestertii 'dating to the era of the 12 Caesars.'
20 asses (imitations) of Tiberius for augustus (Divus) found during excavations at the Roman fort of Albaniana.

3 lots of coins bought from local people in Ihnasyah by Currelly, but considered to be 1 hoard given their similar patina. The find comprised 6476 nummi from the period AD 320-347/348. It might also have included 1 Alexandrian provincial bronze of Domitian, 1 Alexandrian tetradrachm of Philip I and Claudius II, as well as 1 mamluk dirham of Al-Nasir Nasir ad-Din Hassan (AD 1347-1351/1354-1361). These coins were not listed by Noeske in his catalogue.

A hoard of 1062 nummi, corroded together and found by farmers on the rubbish dump of an ancient settlement, east of Denchal. It consisted solely of coins of Constans and Constantius II with the legend FEL TEMP REPARATIO.

37 aurei were found in 1957, digging the trench for the foundations of a bungalow. There was no trace of a container. The coins were probably packed in rolls and wrapped in cloth which had perished. 34 were published in 1959, and a further 3 coins sent to the British Museum in 1965.
The hoard comprised 'a large number of bronze coins, apparently in gold or silver. 4teen were identified as issues of Aurelian.
Hoard 17 coins: 2 aurei, 15 denarii: Nero - Domitian (AD 88-89).
In 1867 west of Gräpel on the right bank of the Oste river coins were found 2 ft deep during the removal of sand from a ridge of hills. The find totals ca. 350+ denarii (Augustus? - Commodus).

A hoard of 1074 AE. The coins were found in a broken pot during excavations by the University of Michigan in the filling of Room D (House 137) at floor level. The hoard comprised 2 Greek coins, 2 Roman provincial coins, 777 late Roman imperial coins, 112 barbarous imitations, and 181 cast imitations. The hoard was published twice: by Milne in 1926 and by Haatvedt et al. in 1964. The list given here follows Noeske 2000, pp. 260-270 (after Milne 1926).
disposition: Kelsey Museum, Ann Arbor (937 coins); Egypt (11 coins); unknown (126 coins)

summary: 269 sestertii found with an urn: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 238-244).

A hoard of denarii was found approx. 0.7 km northwest of Ausleben, on the Ausleber Hoch (alt. 135 m) in a probable neolithic grave mound. 142 coins (Otho-Commodus) were described, but the total amount of coins is unknown.
18 bronze coins: Augustus - Marcus Aurelius
6 coins found as a roll were discovered in a pit within a Roman building: 1 antoninianus, 5 nummi: Aurelian - Valens (AD 364-378).
(c. 40) 27 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Trajan - Commodus (AD 190-191).
disposition: Muzeul Naţional de Etnografie şi Istorie Naturală; Inv. 18.494/AR 6.698-6.724, N 6.110; acquisition document 86/22.05.1986.

summary: 25 Roman nummi. These coins were transferred from Colombo to the Jaffna Museum for exhibition on 29th November 1945. No further information.
ca. 308 Iron Age potin coins, among which many fragments. No full report yet available.

The hoard comprised 28 nummi of the House of Constantine and was found in a Roman mausoleum in the cemetery of Cherchell (AD 333-335). Found togethare with an entirely preserved lamp and a fragment of a lamp.
The hoard had been discovered in İncilipınar vicinity of Göktepe village, Muğla, during a topsoil excavation in 1983. It contains 202 pieces of well preserved Roman folles (nummi).
8 bronze coins found in a grave, range: 3rd c. BC - early 4th c. AD.
Unknown number of bronze coins. 44 provincial coins have been noticed from mints of Lower Moesia and Thrace: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 193-2244).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. CLXXXII (7 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 117 bronze coins dated between Ptolemy I (323-283/2 BC) and Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).

The hoard was found during the excavation of 21 'puits funéraire' at Troussepoil and comprised 231 brass coins (sestertii?). Close to the hoard, 3 broken black ceramic jugs were excavated, 2 of which were filled with ashes and funeral pyre debris. Baudry thought that the coins had originally been placed in the jugs, but that hypothesis is not certain. The hoard was discovered during the excavation of 21 'puits funéraire' of Troussepoil.
5 denarii (Vespasian - Commodus Caesar), found together on the premises of the Pipinsburg (a megalithic hillfort of Viking times), close to Sievern.
14 coins: 11 Roman Republican denarii, 1 Republican bronze, 1 denarius of king Juba and 1 Augustan denarius. The particularity of this hoard are the graffiti on the coins.
2 silver units of ANTED corroded together. No further details known.

The hoard was found inside a vessel, apparently made of iron. The total number of coins found seems to be 90, although some reports detail at least 107. The coins were all bronze issues measuring between 25 and 35mm in diameter: Trajan - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Monedas conservadas en el Museo Arqueologico, Etnografico e Historico, Vasco, Spain (5 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised between 600 and 700 antoniniani (radiates) from Gallienus to Tetricus I. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of between 210.9g and 874.1g.
The hoard comprises 127 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Commodus to Trajan Decius with a top of AD 250-251.

15 AE nummi to AD375 (or possibly a Magnentian hoard with a stray nummus of Gratian), found with a (unrelated?) first century brooch and a sherd of greyware. The grey ware was not thought to form a container due to the small amount found. Addenda of 7 more coins and 5 more greyware sherds, which could perhaps suggest that this constituted a container.
10 antoniniani: Gordian III - Postumus (AD 2630-269); Silver w8: 3.7-11.5 g.

The hoard comprised a vessel containing 13kg of Roman coins (between 4500 and 4600 coins). Breuillac studied 2300 'small bronzes and billon coins' dating from Valerian to Aurelian, although Allard also notes a coin of Philip I. The hoard was found in a ditch close to the ruins of the Château de Curzay; silver w8: c. 1216.0-5624.1g.
5 solidi: Valentinian I - Valentinian II (AD 375-392).
42 nummi found in a cave: Constantine I (Divus) - Theodosius I/Honorius (AD 393-395).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Jerónimo Molina, Jumilla, Spain

summary: 4 coins (Syracuse, Augustus, Tiberius for Agrippa and Severus Alexander), allegedly found in the bed of the River Weser at low tide, at 'der Tiefer'. FMRD has listed this find under Bremen-Mahndorf, but doubts that it is genuine.

A hoard of at least 24 Roman imperial denarii: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192) and possibly a silver fibula were allegedly discovered by a treasure hunter in the late 2010s nearby village Semaki in Vinnytsia region. The coins were found in an area of 15x15 m. The silver brooch was found on the same area. Based on a photo of 5 coins, 3 of which were denarii from the time of Titus, Antoninus Pius and Commodus, 1 cast copy of a denarius with a portrait of Hadrian and an anonymous quadrans with a portrait of Mars on the obverse and cuirass on the reverse. While the denarii have general preservation and similar bronze oxides, the cast copy of the denarius and the anonymous quadrans are probably not part of the hoard. The further fate of the coins is unknown to me.
26 bronze coins of various denominations of both Roman and Byzantine denominations covering a 500 years: Augustus - Justinian I (AD 540-541).
1300 Provincial bronze coins of Alexandria: . 'Acquired in Egypt by Dattari, who sold it to Milne and Currelly.'
disposition: Partly in Oxford, partly in Toronto.

summary: Around 100 coins from Vitellius to Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
54 denarii: 51 republican, 3 imperials: Republic - Tiberius (AD 14-37).
disposition: County Museum Zalău, Romania; inv.no. CC 677/1997

summary: The hoard was found along with several inhumation burials and the foundations of buildings and comprised a mass of 80kg of Roman coins. The successive editions of the museum catalogue have varied catalogues for this hoard. For example, the catalogue of 1856 notes 35 coins for Otacilia Severa and Trajan Decius; the catalogue of 1903 mentions 3 sestertii of Trajan, Hadrian and Antoninus Pius (possibly site finds?) and 'small bronzes' of Philip and Maximian Herculeus. The mention of Maximian, 60 years after the discovery of the hoard is considered by TAF to be suspect. The hoard was found during dredging and ground levelling work, along with inhumation burials and building foundations. Silver: c.25000-30000 (39, 2) coins; Silver w8: -
The hoard was discovered in a burial and comprised 38 radiates from Gallienus to Tetricus II. An as of Augustus was also recovered which may be intrusive.
The hoard comprised 48 sestertii from Vespasian to Marcus Aurelius and was buried around AD 170.
The hoard comprised 48 coins from the Republic to Domitian (AD 90) as well as '2 rings.'

The hoard was discovered on 2 separate occasions and it is suggested that it is part of a much bigger deposit. A further 3 coins were found during the laying of a gas pipe for Gaz de France in the same field: Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver w8: 5.6-20.3g.
60 silver coins: 2 denarii, 58 antoniniani of the 3rd century AD. No further information.
6 coins found while extracting st1: Antoninus Pius 2, Faustina I 1, Commodus, 1 uncertain. No further information.

A hoard of at least 160 Roman imperial denarii was found by a treasure hunter in 2009 or 2010 near the village of Baikivka. According to his information, the hoard was partially ploughed, but the main part of it was at a depth of ca. 50 cm together with fragments of a vessel (pot?). The coins had traces of bronze oxides. Photographs of the deposit have not been preserved, but it is known that most of the coins date from the Nerva-Anto9 dynasty, including coins of Antoninus Pius and Commodus. The fate of the coins is unknown.

500-600 solidi (Valentinian I - Valens), found in the early 1980's in Karnak. 30 coins belonging to that hoard were seen by H.-Chr. Noeske in Luxor in Dec. 1986. All solidi were from the same reverse type (RESTITVTOR REI PVBLICAE).
Hoard of 100-200 of Republican denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Together was found some silver jewelrey.

20 6 coins (aurei and their imitations) were accessi1d from 11 persons under treasure trove legislation. They constituted a part of the hoard which contained also jewellery and was found in the land owned by private individuals. Some of the imitations are mould-linked.

The coins were found in a st1 sarcophagus along with some ashes. They comprised coins dating from the reign of Augustus (Altar of Lyon) to the reign of Maximinus (of Thrace?). The coins were found during the demolition of a tumulus.

Around 200 denarii. The person who ppresented 46 denarii menti1d that in total may have found around 200 pieces. Only 28 coins could be described. 1 denarius of Antoninus Pius was found in 2010: Vitellius - Clodius Albinus (AD 194-197).
18 coins : 13 denarii and 5 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus for Caracalla (Caesar) - Philip I (AD 244-247).

The hoard was found inside a coarse-ware vessel, of a blackish colour. The coins were within a compacted, ferruginous mass and comprised 47 antoniniani (radiates) from Elagabalus to Valerian I and Gallienus with a tpq of AD 259.
243 nummi of the time of Constantius II (4 coins of Constantius II were recorded in the Register of the Cyrene Museum, today, lost) (AD 348-361).
Around 1000 aurei from Augustus to -Domitian (AD 88-89) found in a ceramic vessel. 75 coins (types) are described by Riccio.

The denarii (Vespasian - Trajan) were found together with a bronze brooch in the main building of a villa rusticate, located between Altdorf and Jülich-Kirchberg, on the site of the Inden open pit mining site (Braunkohletagebau Inden).

1200-1300 bronze coins, found in a vessel south of the Roman fort, together with a silver ring. The coins were dispersed. 25 of them were described, and 11 further coins are still preserved in the museum Landshut (therefore, 36 are listed in FMRD, ranging from Vespasian to Severus Alexander).
Hoard of 180 denarii ending with issues of Tiberius, with a large majority of Augustus RIC 207 type (AD 2 BC - AD 4).
A small flint filled with 11 Iron Age coins.
23 nummi of the Constantine's I family found during archaeological excavations at the Roman villa. Uncertain, whether they were found together.
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Orense, Spain

summary: Hoard of 35 denarii found within the Dacian citadel during archaeological excavations. 34 are studied: Republic – Augustus (25-23 BC).
10 denarii: Trajan – Marcus Aurelius (AD 162).
disposition: NPÚ-ÚOP Pardubice, Náchod Castle collection, Czech Republic (inv.nos. 2.920, 3.016-3.023).

summary: Hoard of 21 coins - 6 denarii and 15 counterfeits. Pit also contained broken samian & coarseware pottery and an iron hook, possibly a mount for a purse. Pit found during southern vicus excavs. S of River Tees, to W of the N-S road (Holme House 71-2).

The hoard comprised a group of 270 large Roman bronzes (sestertii) weighing a little more than 5 kilos. When found, the coins were arranged in 5 or 6 horizontal rows. The hoard was quickly dispersed by the finder and only 28 coins were examined (24 by Rualt and 4 by Pellerin) A workman named David discovered the hoard while quarrying st1 at the foot of an old oak tree close to an ancient roadway.
A hoard of 5 bronze coins (Philippi, Koinon of Macedonia, Topirus), found in grave T2 in Lithochori.
Between 1500 and 3000 coins found in a ceramic vessel. 185 coins seen: Julia Domna to Tetricus II Silver: c.1500 coins; Silver w8: c.287.4-3897.6g.
35 denarii: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-162).
Hoard of 49 coins and jewelry was found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192). Jewelry: bronze loop, bronze buckle, silver buckle, 7 silver rings, 39 pearls of amber, coral, glass.
disposition: Local history museum Cherkasy, Ukraine (inv.no. 190092 - vanished in 1941-1945)

summary: An important site lying on high ground on the southern edge of the Downs, roughly in the centre-east of the Isle of Wight. The Iron Age coins were found over an area of at least 1 hectare, with "little clear evidence of clustering although the 2 quarter staters of Tincomaros [sic] were found no more than 3 metres apart"; other material (including almost 400 Roman coins, 8 finger rings, 6 pins and 33 copper alloy brooches) was found over a wider area of some 2.5 ha. This may be consis10t with a ritual site frequented over a longer period.
101 coins: 16 denarii, 85 antoniniani: Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver w8 122.1-240.8 g.
disposition: Regional Historical Museum, Vidin, Bulgaria; inv.no. 591

summary: 29 republican and imperial denarii: Republic - Tiberius (AD 14-37). PALERMO? 1893-b
disposition: Museo Nazionale di Palermo, Italy; inv. no. 1709 (in 1893)

summary: Roman coin hoard found in 1936. Discrepancy in location of findspot. HER reports that 18 coins, including an AE of Constantine the Great, were found in 1936 in Hadfield's Quarry in Pindale near a cottage called the Black Rabbit.
Sabina (wife of Hadrian) to Valens. 3 coins were pierced, 10 had suspension loops. Together were found fragments from a golden chain and small gold ingots
While digging for the foundations of a house a ceramic vessel with some 10s silver coins was found. 63 pieces were examined: 6 antoniniani, 57 denarii: Trajan - Gordian III (AD 238-244).

The hoard comprised more than 1000 (?) coins, which were either bronzes or radiates. 72 coins were preserved in Auzances. The bronzes were extremely worn and sometimes illegible. 62 were sestertii and 7 dupondii or asses, although TAF does not assign denomination by emperor.
28 solidi of Honorius and Arcadius (AD 402-408); gold w8: 124.6g.

A mixed hoard of 18 coins (Vitellius - Diva Faustina II) was unearthed in the southern area of the civilian town. The date of the latest coin is given as AD 145/161 in FMRD, but the reference of that coin (RIC 1383) is dated to AD 163-164.

The hoard was found in a cave shelter and comprised numerous ancient objects including pottery vessels, hipposandals and a sestertius of Hadrian, a dupondius of Antoninus Pius and a worn coin of another emperor, possibly Macrinus.
25 coins: 1 denarius, 12 antoniniani (radiates), 2 quadrantes, 10 unknown denomination: Claudius II - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

Over 3000 antoniniani (radiates) (8 kg) found with a amphora-like vessel. The largest number of coins belongs to Postumus. Other issuers: Valerian I, Gallienus, Salonina. An Alexander is menti1d among issuers, Severus Alexander (?).
The hoard comprised around 851 bronze coins of Alexander Jannaeus (103-76 BC)
1100 solidi, of which 840 recovered. 423 coins were studied: Theodosius I - Valentinian III (AD 425-455); gold w8: c. 4950g.
disposition: Museo Archeologico di Siracusa, Italyn (423 coins)

summary: 5 silver units of the Iceni found in March 2006 .
The coins (130 nummi from the time of Constantine I) were found in 1901 in Breisach, close to the Radbrunnen. The coins were described, but are now lost.
175 antoniniani entered museum collection in Kardzhali: Gordian III - Philip I (AD 244-249). No further information.
Grave find of 5 denarii (1 plated) Vespasian to Hadrian (AD 134-138)

Hoard of gold and silver coins of circa 6 kilos: 3.85 silver, 2.26 gold. The gold coins were wrapped in leather and together with most of the silver 1s they were distributed among the finders. 14 antoniniani (radiates) have been studied so far: Gordian III 8, and Philip I for Otacilia Severa 3, Gallienus 1, Claudius II 2.
A hoard of Iron Age silver units dispersed in a field and discovered over a period of years. The latest addenda are not listed in de Jersey, but included here.
313 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
10 antoniniani: Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).
884 denarii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).

The hoard comprised 7 iron or copper-alloy boxes filled with silver or small bronze coins of Gallienus, Claudius II, Tacitus, Probus, Diocletian and Maximian. Sirand acquired 6 antoniniani (radiates) from the hoard and noted that there were also silver vessels.
Circa 13000 antoniniani (radiates) found in 2 ceramic vessels. Among issuers: Gallienus, Postumus, Tetricus I; silver w8: c.3508.5-16237.8g.
Unknown original number of nummi. Only 19 coins are documented: Constantius II - Gratian (AD 378-383).

The hoard comprised more than 1000 antoniniani (radiates) of which 1038 were acquired by the Musée des Antiquités de Rouen' 'Une pelleteuse heurta' hit the vessel in which the hoard was buried: Trebonianus Gallus (Volusian Augustus) - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver w8: 281.2-1296.6g.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen, France

summary: 6 staters were found in September 1992. Sills suggests that 4 further coins of the same types, in much the same condition, which appeared in the trade in 1997, allegedly either from Wickham (Hants.) or Chichester (West Sussex), may also have been from this hoard. They are listed below following the 6 coins recorded by the BM.

The hoard comprised 31 Roman Provincial coins from Nicopolis from Caracalla to Trebonianus Gallus, found south of Nicopolis, at Agios Phaneromenes Vathi (Αγιας Φανερωμενης Βαθυ), where 1 of the 3 harbours of the city was located. The coins were found in 2 lots (of 5 and 26 coins), recovered at a few days interval, and both hidden under a tile.
7000 antoniniani up to AD 270. No further information.
1269 silver and bronze coins: 1251 denarii; 7 plated denarii; 9 antoniniani; 1 drachm; 1 bronze: Mark Antony - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235); Silver w8: 1777.1-4207.8g
disposition: National History Museum of Transylvania, Cluj-Napoca, Romania

summary: Ove 42 bronze coins. Only 6 coins were recovered and studied. tHey were all struck for Gaius with the same coin dies. All 6 pieces are imitations, possible from a local mint.
Uncertain total number of coins. 138 coins: 6 antoniniani, 7 silver coins, 3 sestertii, 122 provincial bronzes: Trajan - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-260); silver w8: 5.8-31.6 g.
6000 copper coins found in a ceramic vessel. Coins of Gordian III, Tetricus I and other issuers.
disposition: Mr. de la Fontaine (purchased for 40 Fr.)

summary: 4 denarii (Vespasian - Antoninus Pius), found at Aitnock fort (an Iron Age fort), situated on the summit of a cliff which rises about 60 feet perpendicularly from the waters of the Rye stream at the south-west angle of Hindog Glen near Dalry in Ayrshire. The coins had been wrapped in some material and were found in a layer of occupation.
A hoard of 25 aurei (Faustina I - Trajan Decius), 1 medallion of Gallienus and 16 articles of jewellery, found at Octavian Augustus Street in the ancient Jewish quarter in Alexandria.
331 coins : 322 sestertii, 1 dupondius and 8 uncertain sestertii: Galba - Severus Alexander (AD 232).
+2000 antoniniani (radiates) found in a bronze amphora: Gordian III - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
31 nummi: Constantine and his sons (AD 347-348).
The hoard comprised 4 aurei and 132 silver coins, as well as jewellery from the second century AD: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138). Associated with Bar Kochba revolt (AD 132-135).
Originally 5 denarii, 1 preserved: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 186). Found together with 1 gold finger ring, 3 silver finger rings.
513 denarii: Republic - Trajan (AD 101-102)
disposition: Museum of Art History, Vienna, Austria (1847)

summary: Hoard of 375 denarii. Only 7 coins were menti1d: Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Faustina II 3, Lucilla, Commode.

2 hoards (Kilkis A and B) were acquired by the museum of Thessaloniki in 1966 after having been found by some villagers in the areas of the Prefecture of Kilkis. Kilkis A comprised 27 coins, ranging from Diocletian to the Tetrarchy.
The hoard comprised 10 denarii from Hadrian to Otacilla Severa and 179 antoniniani (radiates) from Caracalla to Valerian I.
10 denarii: Republic - Augustus (2 BC - AD 4).
36 bronze coins ranging from Augustus to Vespasian found in a grave.
disposition: Museum of Croatian Archaeological Monuments in Split

summary: 10 coins found at Schrotzbug, which is a medieval castle on the Schienerberg: 1 dupondius, 2 aurei and 7 denarii, ranging from Titus Caesar to Severus Alexander.
The hoard comprised 24 bronze coins of the Bar Kokhba Revolt (AD 132-135/6).
IARCH record for 2 denarii found together with a metal detector. For images and further details see NMS-D4F0CA.
Around 300 silver coins of which 168 were documented: antoniniani, denarii: Septimius Severus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-259).
40 bronze coins were discovered with a ceramic vessel. Only 24 have provided some information: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
The hoard comprised approximately 1000 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Philip I.
Between 3000 and 6000 denarii were found with a wooden box in a peat bog. For 16 coins are known the issuers: Trajan - Septimius Severus.

In 1894 building remains were discovered during excavation works for a newly constructed building, which lay under a thick layer of fire and building debris. In the alcove of a room coins were found in a chest or in a locker next to many pots. 8-10 specimens belong to the finding, the latest from the period around 350.

The hoard comprised 111 nummi from Diocletian to Constantine I and Licinius I with a tpq of AD 309. All coins came from the mints of Trier or London but unfortunately, TAF does not elaborate on the mint distribution by emperor.

Within circular st1 Late Roman shrine in layer of brown sandy loam were 8 coins, 2 fibulae & a penannular brooch, though these were earlier in date. Curated? Immediately above the building in the topsoil, controlled metal detecting in 1982 recovered a further 9 coins, 7 iron spearheads & 3 iron sockets, & pottery. Some/all of these finds may be additional items from hoard in pit, dispersed slightly by medieval/early modern ploughing.
Denarius hoard consisting of 14 denarii found with metal detectoring. Galba to Antoninus Pius.
3 imperial AE (Tiberius) and 3 uncertain imperial As found in regio IX, insula 11, dolium of the counter of building 2 (thermopolium).
(+630: 30 aurei, +600 denarii and antoniniani) 557 coins: 18 aurei, 31 denarii, 508 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 15

find_spot_name: KÖLN - ST. MARIA IM KAPITOL VII
summary: In the inventory from 1899 5 coins are situated with the find location of Cologne, which based on their type might belong to the hoard.

A number of rare and unusual Iron Age coins, including a variety of continental types, have been recorded from 2 fields near Freshwater Bay. Possibly several distinct deposits, rather than a dispersed hoard?
A hoard of 3-400 aurei. 42 coins were recovered. They are all issues of Lucius Verus, 3 types (Coh. 157, 247, 248).
disposition: Royal Coin Room, Amsterdam, Netherlands (3 coins since 1894); 1 coin in Berlin

summary: A second small coin hoard (Hoard S) of 26 coins recovered from under cobbling at E end of Building 1, Site 1.
98 imitations of antoniniani of Tetricus I, found in a Roman villa (HA 56) where remains of a workshop producing imitation coins were also found.
The hoard comprised a grey-blue ceramic vessel containing 217 antoniniani (radiates) from Trebonianus Gallus to Victorinus. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of 66 g to 270.3g.
2 radiates (Gallienus and Victorinus) found along with a gold ring beneath a st1 in the valley side around Blaen-cwm-Pennant near Llangynog. No other information is available.
31 coins: 2 antoniniani (radiates), 29 nummi: Claudius II - Theodosius I (AD 381-383).
disposition: Casa-Museo Posada del Moro, Torrecampo, Spain

summary: 4370 coins found in a cooking pot with graffiti (ME X): 4 denarii, 4366 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Probus (AD 276-282)
disposition: Centre archéologique de la Mayenne, Jublains, France

summary: 28 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Valerian I (AD 258-259); silver w8: 35.0g.
240 silver coins: 228 denarii, 2 drahms found in a ceramic vessel: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 143-144).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 8

summary: A hoard of 72-82 coins of Verica and 4-5 of Epaticcus. It difficult to establish exactly how many coins it may have contained.
8 aurei: Nero - Antoninus Pius: M. Aurelius (Caesar) (AD 140-161)
During the drainage of a moor several small Roman coins were unearthed. The names of 6 emperors are menti1d. Some coins seem to be plated.
(c. 18 kg, 4062) 1590 silver coins denarii, antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver w8: 5078.8-10559.8 g.
The hoard comprised 19 bronze coins from the First Jewish Revolt (AD 67-68).
43 antoniniani: Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver w8: 12.6-52.8 g.

A hoard comprising 3 bronze coins of Augustus and Tiberius next to metal scraps (?) (Metalhortfund), found in the north wing of the Roman villa rustica at the location of Alt-Inden (act. Tagebau Inden).
26 sestertii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 195).
249 coins : 1 antoninianus (radiate), 248 nummi found in the Odeion's cavea: Quintillus/Aurelian (Divus Claudius II) - Theodosius II (AD 408 423). No traces of a container.
6 aurei: Hadrian - Valerian I (AD 255-256). The hoard comprises also gold and silver jewelry and tableware. Gold w8 aurei: 32.8-41.1 g; silver w8: 645.2 g
disposition: Museum of the Romano-Gallic civilisation, Lyon; Museé des Beaux-Arts, Lyon

summary: Hoard of 40 bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 24 coins were documented: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 140).
115 antoniniani: Caracalla to Trajan Decius. Found in 2 separate but homogeneous groups. Silver: 115 coins; Silver w8: 145.1-297.6g

The 3 coins (2 Alexandrian tetradrachms and 1 late Roman nummus) are thought to have been found in a jar/pot at the end of 1951 during excavations on the premises of a garden. The jar has not been preserved and it has been doubted that this is actually a hoard.
646 denarii, Republican to after 12 BC.
(Circa 20) 17 silver coins: Elagabalus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Okrazen Istoriceski Muzej, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1832 1-17

summary: 4 Roman AE coins and 1 Iron Age silver unit, found in a barrow, in which were found human b1s as well.
61 silver coins found in a Roman villa: 22 denarii, 39 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver w8: 100.8-168.5 g.
2115 nummi were discovered of which only 1671 survive: House of Theodosius - Anastasius (AD 491-518).
Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 9 pieces entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: Septimius Severus - Philip I
The hoard comprised 91 denarii and 416 sestertii from Nero to Gordian III (AD 241-244).
disposition: Musée archéologique départemental de Guiry-en-Vexin, France

summary: 55 antoniniani (radiates) : Gallienus - Diocletian (AD 284-293).
The hoard comprised 35 aurei (Nero-Lucius Verus) and 29 silver coins (Nero-Trajan).
A hoard of denarii, found in a field from 1962 until 2001. FMRD lists 67 coins (Trajan - Pertinax).

The hoard was discovered in 1933 by a farmer 100 m north of Rembrechts. 88 coins (mostly denarii, with some bronze coins, ranging from the Late Republic to Severus Alexander) were associated with jewellery. Most of the objects found with the coins were of silver.

The hoard comprised 4 bronze coins of Mattathias Antigonus (40-37 BC). 'This small hoard consists of 4 bronze coins found accreted together, due to the corrosion that covered them' (Farhi and Melamed 2014, 110)
Hallaton: 14 hoards were located in and around the entrance way. Hoard 08 comprises 6 Iron Age coins.
Originally circa 660 denarii, 290 coins were studied, 100 preserved: Titus - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver w8: 270.19 g. (100 coins).
22 nummi from the time of Constantine I and Constantius II found 1923 'Am Fort Josef', in front of the hospital.
+100 coins dating from Philip I to Valerian and Gallienus. No catalogue was made and no further information given about the composition of the hoard.
4 Iron Age East Anglian silver units (1 of which was a plated copy with a copper alloy core).
200 denarii found with a glass vessel. Some of them, issues of Augustus.
2669 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver w8: 721.6-3335.3 g.
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. CLVII

summary: Around 300 solidi. Only 12 coins are documented: Honorius - Valentinian III (AD 441-455).
The find comprises 2 "Gallo-Belgic" Aa class 4 gold staters, 1 of which is slightly bent to the edge. Addendum of 1 stater 2011 and of a quarter stater in 2012. (PAS).

A hoard of 6 nummi, comprising 4 FEL TEMP REPARATIO types of various sizes, 1 of Valens, and 1 possible Magnentian imitation, found in deposits overlying the natatio fountain house during consolidation works. The coins were fused together and could not be identified with any greater precision.
(1500) 1140 silver coins: 463 denarii, 677 antoniniani: Vespasian - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-268); silver w8: 1639.0-3601.0 g.
56 gold and silver coins., 15 coins were recovered: Augustus, Tiberius, Gaius and Claudius I (AD 44).
disposition: Kunsthistorisches Museum, Wien, Austria (14 coins, in 1845).

summary: A hoard 437 coins (?), composed of 1 denarius (Maximinus) and 436 antoniniani (325: Julia Domna - Gallienus; 111: Gallic empire) to AD 263, found in excavations conducted by the curé M. Duchâtel in Noyers. Note that the catalogue only lists 324 antonininiani for the period Julia Domna - Gallienus and 109 for the Gallic Empire (i.e. 434 coins in total, and not 437).

The hoard was found in a coarseware vessel which was broken. It comprised a block of Roman silver and bronze coins which had been stuck together with corrosion products. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of 249.6-505.0 g.
A hoard of approximate 835 gold coins with the latest issue being a coin of Leontius dating to AD 484 to 488. Hobbs estimates a precious metal w8 of approximately 3715.75g.

295 denarii and 2 sestertii (Mark Antony to Commodus) found on the latest floor level of Room 37. The coins were corroded together and no trace of a container was recovered. It is possible that 6 denarii presented to the British Museum in January 1930 by the Caerleon Excavation Committee may have come from this hoard (BM Register of Coin Accessions, Jan. 1930: Vespasian, 1; Hadrian, 3; Antoninus Pius, 1; Commodus, 1).
43 nummi; Licinius I - Constantine I (AD 318). Mints: 2 Londinium, 41 Arelate
The hoard comprised 93 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I and Gallienus to Probus with a tpq of AD 282.
Apparently a large hoard of Iron Age potin coins, of which only the 4 coins in the British Museum are preserved.

A hoard of 16 denarii (Vespasian - Caracalla), found in 1832, approx. 20 min from the so-called st1 bridge between Rhede and Borken, on a field in Vardingholt. The coins were sold in 1843 at auction in Münster.
Unknown number of silver and bronze coins. 2 dupondii of Domitian and 5 antoniniani of Gordian III are known.

In 1852, during the excavation of the Iron Age settlement of Worle Camp, a hoard of 3 antoniniani and 238 small bronze coins ranging up to Arcadius and Honorius, with a high percentage of barbarous radiates (77 coins) was found.
2 gold coins of Valentinian III: 1 solidus, 1 half solidus (semissis) (AD 435-445).
disposition: Frisian Museum, Leeuwarden (FML 349) in private collection

summary: (5000+) 14 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274)
104 denarii: 99 republican, 5 of Augustus (AD 19-18 BC).
6 silver coins: 3 denarii, 3 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-247) found during excavations
disposition: Muzeul Dunării de Jos, Călărași, Romania; inv.nos. 45361-45365, 52259

summary: Around 50 bronze coins were found in a m1y-box. Only 13 coins were recovered: 5 sestertii, 6 dupondii, 2 asses: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161) are kept in the National Museum in Ljubljana.
disposition: Narodni muzej, Numizmatični cabinet, Ljubljana, Slovenia (13 coins), inv.no.: 4584-4591; dispersed

summary: At Site 2, Pit 328, dug into top of Quarry 4 & poss. within Building VI, contained 76 coins from AD 260-8 to AD 351-60, incl. 21 radiates. Also pottery, cu alloy bracelet & sheet frag., but not clear what other objects were found

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing between 1500 and 2000 third century bronzes. 105 of these coins were identified. All were radiates, although it was noted that originally there were a 'certain number' of denarii of Postumus. 100 coins from the hoard were acquired by the Musée de Poitiers. Silver: c.1500-2000 (105) coins; Silver w8: 473.5-2186.5
disposition: Museum of Poitiers; private collections (2 coins); some coins lost

summary: 8 nummi found with a purse hanged on a belt in a grave: Constantine I - Constantius II (AD 355-361).
The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing 122 silver denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).

A hoard of 26 provincial bronze coins (Cnossos, Koinon of Crete) found in Agios Nikolaos, ranging from Claudius to Hadrian. The first report of the hoard menti1d approx. 30 coins of the Koinon of Crete struck under Trajan.
The hoard comprised 22 antoniniani (radiates) dated between the reigns of Valerian I and Gallienus and Claudius II (AD 268-270).

500-560 billon coins originally - mostly Marius, Postumus, and Victorinus, closing with 2 coins from 267. Also including coins of Claudius, Tetricus, Gordian III, Trebonianus Gallus; silver w8: c.136.0-624.0g.
Antoniniani (radiates) and nummi in uncertain proportions, from Gallienus to Tetrarchy; including 2 Carausius and 2 Allectus.
A find of 20 copper alloy coins (described as 'third brass') of Vespasian made in a garden.The Antiquary 46, 1910 p.162
It comprised 42 denarii from Antoninus Pius to Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).

There are conventionally thought to have been at least 3 separate finds of Iron Age coinage at South Ferriby, on the south bank of the Humber, in the first decade of the twentieth century. 2 of them are described in some detail by Roth, and the third is included by Allen in his Sylloge volume on the Coritani and in a short paper for Hull Museum. In total almost 170 coins can still be securely associated with this find (de Jersey, no. 172).
The hoard comprised c. 4000 antoniniani (radiates) and nummi (tpq Diocletian, AD 305?) found with 4 ceramic vessels.
185 silver coins (tetradrachms, denarius, shekels) found with a ceramic vessel next to another 1 (Qumran 1955 A) and not far from Qumran 1955 C.
5 solidi in hoard with spiral finger-ring, gold bracteate with Runic inscription, electron ingot.
7 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192) found in an Iron Age warrior grave.
980 antoniniani (radiates) found in 2 lots, in 1962, 1980, in a ceramic vessel: Septimius Severus (Geta Caesar/Augustus) - Tetricus I (AD 272).
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Bibliotheque Nationale de France, Paris

summary: 64 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Valerian I/Gallienus A (253-268); silver w8: 80.0 g.
A large hoard of 1500-2000 coins: 508 republican coins are identified; all the emperors up to Hadrian are represented except Augustus.

81 bronze coins (72 Dium, 3 Thessalonica, 1 koinon of Macedonia, 1 Philippi, 1 koinon of Thessaly, 3 Roman bronzes) ranging from Domitian to Antoninus Pius, found in the foundation level besides the east wall of the first (western) room excavated at the place of the former sanctuary of Zeus Olympios, next to 2 other hoards (Dion 1999 and Dion 2000). All 3 hoards were buried in clay vases. The exact function of the area where the hoards were found is unclear, but the hellenistic sanctuary of Zeus Olympios had been transformed in Roman times, the wall of the temenos built over, and a theatre established.
53 solidi found on the seabed: Valentinian I - Honorius (AD 395-423). Probably, it was kept in a wooden chest.
289 Icenian and Roman silver coins up to Nero were recovered from a building site at Scole House, Scole.
Circa 50 coins of silver and bronze. Only 36 were bought by the Museo Civico di Storia e Arte di Trieste: Vespasian - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
disposition: Museo Civico di Storia e Arte di Trieste, Italy. Mixed with the rest of the coins in the museum collection

summary: The hoard comprised numerous fragments of silvered copper-alloy tableware accompanied by 21 sestertii and antoniniani (radiates) from Trajan to Philip I (AD 244-249). TAF interprets it as a deposit of scrap metal in10ding for recycling.
103 denarii, among which 1 imitation: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 181).

A 4th century gold hoard which was sold on the art market in 1970. 390 solidi and a gold necklace of 5 pendants and 6 spacers (only 4 are known) and clasp; and a gold bracelet (559 g): Constantius II - Theodosius I (AD 388). These are assumed to have been found in Sidi Bu Saïd.
disposition: Cleveland Museum of Art, USA (octagonal pendant, 6 spacers); Dumbarton Oaks, Byzantine Collection, USA (1 hexangonal pendant, 1 circular pendant); The British Museum, London, UK (1 hexagonal pendant); Louvre Museum, Paris, France (1 circular pendant)

summary: Around 50 denarii of Galba, Vespasian and Nerva (AD 96-98).
disposition: Private collection Efisio Pischedda di Seneghe (in 1876).

summary: 2 solidi from hoard also containing ring gold and 3 gold bracteates. Both coins are imitiations.
24 large bronze cooins (sestertii and double sestertii?): Domitian - Postumus (AD 260-268).
Around 200 denarii. Recovered 135 denarii found with metal vessel: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 141-143).
disposition: National History Museum of Romania, Bucharest, Romania

summary: 113 coins: Claudius I - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251). No information on the denominations or other issuers.
The hoard was found between "le Champ de Navarre" and Jean-Ernest Darbot avenue. It comprised an uncertain number of aurei, maybe between 21 and 50. Only 12 are now recorded.
A hoard of 50 + large bronze coins of Ephesus, with some of Smyrna and 1 of Colophon dating to the 2nd century AD.

44 late Roman nummi (Constantius II to Theodosius I) and 1 local 3rd c. Palmyrene coin, found in the cella of the temple of Allat in a broken vessel that had been thrown on the floor with fragments of the cult statue found immediately above it. This hoard has been interpreted as an offering dating from the time preceding the destruction of the temple under Theodosius I.
4-500 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel. 29 coins were studied: Vespasian (Titus Caesar) – Philip I.
10 silver coins - 9 denarii, 1 siliqua - found by metal detecting on a ploughing field close to each other.
"Few hundreds", only 89 were seen: Balbinus - Maximian I (AD 294).
disposition: Collection P. du Chatellier; Musée de Bretagne, Rennes, France (inv.no. MAN 80313, 54 coins)

summary: 13 Roman silver coins, presented to the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland, in 1781, all dug up 'with a great many more' in the muir (= moorland) of Linlithgow. These probably came from a find of 300, found in the Burrowmuir, deposited in an earthen urn.
15 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 20

summary: HER record of a hoard of 102 coins found in the river at Thornborough. Appears to be a hoard dislodged from the river bank rather than an accumulation of finds deposited in the river. Latest coin Carausius or Diocletian.
The hoard comprised 60 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I and Tetricus II.

On December 1978, a hoard of 47 Roman silver siliquae was found on Gallows Hill, Thetford. The coins were found in a compact mass. Subsequently, 27 more siliquae were found (20 found in August 1981, and another group of 7 found in July 1982), bringing the total to 74, ranging from Constantius II to Magnus Maximus. About 450 m. from the findspot of the siliquae hoard, the Thetford treasure of gold and silver jewellery and silver spoons was found in 1979.

The hoard was found in 1989 in a field near Chalfont St Peter. The coins were contained in 4 pots, of which pots I, II and III were buried close together, and pot IV at a distance of 4 metres. The total number of coins in the hoard was 6682: 15 bronze coins, 45 denarii, 2511 antoniniani of the Central Empire, 3560 antoniniani of the Gallic Empire, 197 irregular coins, and 354 uncertain coins.
disposition: British Museum (part); Bucks. County Museum, Aylesbury (part)

summary: 141 denarii: Republic – Commodus (AD 180-192).
Unknown initial number of denarii. 6ty-3 coins were seen in the collection of the Friends of sciences Society Collection in Poznań: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Friends of sciences Society Collection, Poznań, Poland (63 coins)

summary: Circa 600 denarii, information provided on 540: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
disposition: Swedish History Museum, Stockholm (inv.no. 4521); Lunds Universitets Historiska Museum, Lund (inv.no. 27544 - 3 coins), Sweden

summary: A scattered hoard of 23 radiates (Salonina to Victorinus) found within the remains of an enclosed Romano-British farmstead.
Unknown number of silver coins. 3 of them are kept in the Museum of Cultural History Stralsund: Antoninus Pius denarius, Philip I antoniniani (radiates) (AD 248).
disposition: Museum of Cultural History Stralsund, Germany (3 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised an orange paste vessel containing 3 denarii and 214 antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Aurelian and Victorinus.
The hoard comprised 197 nummi dating to the 4th century AD.
Hoard of 282 coins: 252 denarii, 1 quinarius, 29 bronzes: Augustus - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
"A considerable large quantity" of coins of "middle bronzes", all of Postumus (AD 260-268). 4
(1006) 978 denarii: Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177).
2 Gallo-Belgic staters recorded in trade, reportedly found on the same site, in 1991 and 1992. Possibly a small hoard.
“some half a dozen Roman third brass coins”.
Originally, the hoard weighed 7 kg of nummi (”small bronze coins). 21 nummi entered the museum coin collection of sometime before 1907-1908: Constantine I - Constantius II (AD 355-361).
Hoard of few hundreds silver coins. Only 10 denarii recorded: Republic (32-31). Together was found a silver Celtiberian bracelet.
The coins were found on Weberbach street in the area of the tannery of Herr Varain from Trier

12000 nummi found with a big ceramic vessel on the area of the fort of the Ala Nova unit. Only 979 coins are known nowadays: Galeria Valeria, Maximinus II Daia, Licinius I, Licinius II, Constantine I and his family (AD 317).
disposition: Münzkabinett, Kunsthistorisches Museum, Wien (212 copies); Museum Carnuntinum, Bad-Deutsch Altenburg, Austrai (767 coins)

summary: In 1912 a find of 36 denarii in a pot was made by workers during excavations for the construction of a Tietz department store on Hohen street, between Schildergasse in the north and Cäcilienstraße in the south. It was acquired by J. Hagen from art-dealing for the museum of Bonn, from where it was delivered to the Roman-Germanic museum of Cologne in 1942. Found with a ceramic cooking pot.
200 denarii: Republic - Domitian (AD 86).
Originally, circa 1000 coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 37 are known: Constantine I - Valentinian II (AD 375-392).
disposition: Museo Provincial and Museo Diocesano de Lugo, Spain

summary: 21 silver coins: 8 republican denarii, 5 republican quinarii, 5 imperial denarii, 3 imperial quinarii: Republic - Tiberius (AD 14-37). Found together with 20 lead m1tary blank flans.
415 coins found in a ceramic vessel: 413 antoniniani (radiates), 1 possible bronze coin, 1 possible denarius: Trebonianus Gallus/Volusian - Diocletian/Maximian I (AD 284-293).
27 denarii found with a jug covered by a st1: 24 republican, 3 imperial of Augustus (25-23 BC). With 3 bracelets and 1 jewelry fragmented, also of silver.
disposition: Ashmolean Museum, Oxford (23 coins); the British Museum (4 coins)

summary: Ca. 100 antoniniani (Gallienus to Tetricus II) found in a pot behind the wall of a Roman house, close to the Schloßplatz. 65 have been described in FMRD, the others are lost.

77 Republican denarii, 12 uncertain Republican denarii, 1 Imperial aureus (Titus under Vespasian), 12 Imperial denarii (Augustus and Vespasian) and 7 Imperial AE (Galba and Vespasian) found with a skeleton in regio IX, insula 14, second atrium north of west wing of building 2.4 (house).

(100) 75 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel: 44 denarii, 29 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-247); silver w8: 101.7-155.2 g; together with irregular pieces of gold (13.5 g) found in a vessel
disposition: Museum of Roman and Dacian Civilisation Deva, Romania (73 coins, gold pieces, and the 3 sherds), Museum of Petroșani, Romania (2 coins)

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 52 denarii were found with a hand-made ceramic vessel: Mark Antony – Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
144 coins: 4 aurei, 140 antoniniani: Gordian III - Philip I; gold w8: 17.6 g; silver w8: 175.0 g. Together with a silver brooch.
Breakdown of mints is given suggesting that full breakdown is given in articles. Silver: 1406 coins; Silver w8: 40.1g
1640 coins found with a ceramic vessel: 3rd c. BC - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
(c. 260) 77 sestertii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 163-164)
17 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 21

summary: Originally a hoard of 68 coins but 1 went astray. From the 67 remaining coins (62 dupondii and 5 asses), 23 are completely illegible. The coins are heavily worn, suggested a much later burial than the latest coin.
96 denarii found with a ceramic pitcher: Republic – Septimius Severus (AD 201-210).
disposition: History Museum "lulian Antonescu", Bacău (91 coins); Cultural room, Ardeoani (4 coins); High-school ”Vasile Alecsandri”, Bacău (1 coin)

summary: A flint nodule containing 7 uniface (British Qb) staters was uncovered during landscaping work to create a golf course near Kingsclere. There appears to have been some pottery found nearby and possibly Roman roof tile and tesserae, although the accuracy of these observations is open to doubt.

In autumn 1985, treasure hunters found 2 ceramic vessels containing circa 670 denarii and antoniniani and around 130 provincial bronze coins (minted in Nicopolis ad Istrum, Marcianopolis, Tomis, Anchialus and Hadrianopolis). The last chronological coins are from the mid-3rd century.
A large hoard of republican and imperial denari. Only 20 pieces were seen. apparently, the latest coin belong to Tiberius (AD 14-37).

The hoard contains 37 silver coins (18 denarii and 19 antoniniani-radiates): Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 253-259). This hoard has been discovered along with some single coins from the Celts and Romans (sestertii from Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius and Commodus).

A hoard of at least 23 coins (denarii and aurei, ranging from the Republic to Vespasian), found during the construction of the city hospital in 1910, in cellar 12. 18 coins are now in the Mainz museum, at least 5 aurei of Nero were lost.

The hoard was found during the excavation of the courtyard of House L in Insula 27 at Colonia Ulpia Traiana. It comprised 5 denarii of Maximinus dating to AD 235-236. The excavation archives provide no further details about the circumstances of discovery.

The hoard comprised 72 'bronze denarii of the late Empire', possibly to be identified as either radiates or nummi. They were found in association with a bronze lamp and a large number of ceramic vessels.
The hoard comprised more than 120 nummi of Constantine I and Licinius I. Only 47 coins, probably representing a third of the hoard were not dispersed.

HER record for MOLAS excavations in 2002-3 at 21 Lime Street has the following: "A brickearth demolition layer at the top of the dumping sequence, which may have also served as a floor slab, produced a hoard of 10 silver denarii and some silver plated copies, including rare Republican forgeries, dated to AD 70 or later". No further details found.

Depression F3321 contained 7 re-deposited (curated?) Palaeo. handaxes in lowermost gravel fill, pottery & coins. Upper dark fills contained tile frags., mortar frags., a copper alloy brooch, finger rings, bracelet frags., tweezers, nail cleaner, pins and a key; a lead-filled bronze head, a bronze priest's head moulding, iron knife blades, an iron buckle, b1 pins & pieces of antler. Also 78 coins from F3321 - 17 of AD 270-284 & 10 of AD 293-296 in lower fills, 9 of AD 330-345 & 42 of AD 388-402 in upper fills.
5 denarii found on a field: Domitian - Severus Alexander (AD 231-235).
88 silver coins: 1 denarius, 87 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Quintillus (AD 270).
14 nummi the time of Constantine I (AD 333-335) found stuck to each other.
disposition: Institute of Archaeology, Coin Room, Bucharest, Romania

summary: IARCH record for a hoard of 30 denarii found between 1985 and 1992. The latest coins are 2 of Lucius Verus and Divus Antoninus both dated to AD 161 and an undated coin of Faustina II. This might suggest deposition in the earlier part of the reign of Marcus Aurelius. See WMID-1AC648 for full details and images. 1 of the coins of Trajan is a small fragment.
The hoard comprised 16 sestertii from Hadrian to Philip I and 25 denarii and radiates from Caracalla to Valerian I (AD 253-260).
A roll of 8 corroded and partly worn AE coins (Trajan to Lucius Verus), found within the group of furnaces north of the west gate (inside the Roman fort), in front of the furnace 5
Unknown number of coins found in a ceramic vessel. 103 coins entered museum collection in Stara Zagora: 5 denarii, 96 antoniniani, 2 provincial bronzes: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 247-249).
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Stara Zagora, Bulgaria; inv.no. 4318-4327

summary: Hoard of unknown number of denarii. Only 2 pieces are known: Trajan, Hadrian.

Group of 6 coins (silvered antonini) stuck together into 'a column', with a 7th found close by, found in topsoil just outside of apse of bath house in commander's praetorium/principia in Bowes Roman fort, excav. by Hartley & Frere in 1966-67. Latest coin an issue of Constantinus II of AD 332. Coins may have been originally wrapped in linen (in Shotter's coin report). Topsoil above a rubble layer containing pottery, wall plaster, iron nails & building st1, but no other topsoil finds menti1d.D. Shotter, The Roman coins. In Frere, S.S. and Fritts, R.L. 2009. Excavations at Bowes and Lease Rigg Roman Forts, pp.56 to 66. Yorkshire Archaeological Report No. 6, pp. 39.The radiate of Tetricus is given as RIC 100. The coin of Victorinus is listed as a copy. Shotter excludes the nummus from this group.
704 coins: 2 antoniniani (radiates), 683 sestertii, 9 dupondii, 10 asses: Claudius I - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 254).
107 denarii were found in a ceramic vessel together with 6 silver bracelets (3 pairs), a plated silver brooch and glass beads. No further informationn
More than 80 gold coins were discovered as surface finds between 1830 and 1958: Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-192). Only 7 of the coins were described sufficiently well to be accurately identified.
4 radiates & 9 nummi to AD 350. This small Fel Temp Hoard includes some earlier Constantinian pieces as well as debased radiates.
16 provincial bronze coins minted in Bizya: Geta 1, 15 Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria (11 coins)

summary: (7 kg) (1200+) 22 coins: 1 denarius, 20 antoniniani, 1 bronze: Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
The hoard comprised several vessels containing 1000s of Roman coins. Labourers working on an English army camp in 1939 or 1940 discovered this hoard.
495 silver coins: 1 denarius, 488 antoniniani (radiates): Augustus, Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver w8: 135.3-612.6 g.

A hoard of 60 late Roman coins (Constantin I - Constantius II) found during excavations made before the construction of a new Merkur store Am Spielhof. The coins had been burnt and are poorly preserved. Deposition possibly connected with the incursion of the Juthungen in AD 357.
53 coins (denarii, ranging from Nero to Macrinus) found in a bag, north of the Fort Stahlberg, within the perimeter of the city's hospital.

43 coins found between 2009 and 2018. They include 16 Roman Republican denarii, 17 Iron Age silver units and 9 Roman denarii up to Claudius, plus possibly 1 denarius of Trajan (but this coud be a stray find).
5 nummi Constantine I (AD 321) Mints: Londinium 1, Treveri 2, Ticinum 2.

14 coins (Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius, mostly bronzes) were found embedded in fire debris, on terrain M, Handwerkerbau (Fläche 60, Planum 0-1). N.B. Coin 1 (Vespasian) is wrongly described as a denarius in FMRD.
400 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Carus (AD 282-283).
disposition: Museo Civico di Legnago (16 coins); Museo Civico di Gallarate (239 coins)

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. Most likely there is just 1 hoard found here and 36 denarii are known: Vespasian – Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

4 gold coins found in a grave: Tiberius, Nero, Vitellius, Vespasian. Together were found 5 staters of Colchida, 3 denarii of Augustus; 51 Parthian drachms: Orode II 47, Artaban I 1, Sinatruces 1, Phraates III 1, Phraates IV 1 and a gold bracelet.

1590 bronze coins (1452 Dium, 47 koinon of Thessaly, 39 koinon of Macedonia, 13 Thessalonica, 7 Philippi, 2 Edessa, 2 Corinth, 1 Amphipolis, 1 Magydus, 1 Tralleis, 10 uncertain, and 15 Roman bronzes), ranging from Claudius to Antoninus Pius, found in the foundation level besides the west wall of the first (western) room excavated at the place of the former sanctuary of Zeus Olympios, next to 2 other hoards (Dion 1998 and Dion 2000). All 3 hoards were buried in clay vases. The exact function of the area where the hoards were found is unclear, but the hellenistic sanctuary of Zeus Olympios had been transformed in Roman times, the wall of the temenos built over, and a theatre established.
2 aurei: Augustus, Tiberius. No description. The coins are considered as single finds by Callu-Loriot. However, same year of finding same findspot close chronological range.
190 antoniniani, probably, part of Sushina 2: Gordian III - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
11 coins: 1 aureus, 9 denarii, 1 bronze: Marcus Aurelius - Elagabalus (AD 218-222); gold w8: 7.1-7.2 g; silver w8: 17.2-22.6 g.
The deposit was found during the demolition of Roman bridge piles and comprised approximately 4000 Roman Republican and Imperial coins, with the most recent being of Domitian.
Silver: (c.3500) 1100 silver coins: Augustus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver w8: c.4377.3-12562.7 g.
disposition: Musée Curtius, Liège, Belgium (3 coins); Collection L. Renard-Grenson, Liège, Belgium (147 coins)

summary: 19 AE sestertii and fractions to AD 242
3 Roman hoards found in St1a. This hoard comprises 22 denarii ranging up to Severus Alexander.
25 silver coins: 2 denarius, 23 antoniniani: Caracalla - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
90 sestertii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
Unknown initial number of coins. 145 denarii: Galba - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (AD 178-191).
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie Națională și Arheologie, Constanța, Romania; private colection V. Heisu from Parava (145 coins)

summary: 5 Iron Age gold coins, found between 2005 and 2016
21 antoniniani. T. Gerasimov saw 2 of Gordian III

c. 500-600 solidi and c. 3000 siliquae, found in 2 earthen pots by a labourer while digging in a quarry at Prior's Cleeve. Coins seem to range from Constantius II to Honorius. The list given here follows O'Neil's account, in NC 1936. Among them, some counterfeits were discovered, being copper plated with gold. The gold coins are in the most perfect state of preservation. The silver coins are worn and appear to have been in circulation.
28 antoniniani: Aurelian - Probus (AD 276-282).
3 solidi found at different times before 1857: Valentinian III, Julius Nepos, Anastasius (AD 491-518)
74 denarii: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192).

80 Roman coins were found in the soil of the basement of a house in Kronhofstraße during building works. Given the large chronological range of the coins (Republic to Late Empire!), this might be an assemblage of a modern collection rather than a hoard.
67 silver coins: 21 antoniniani (radiates), 46 denarii: Vespasian - Philip I (AD 247-249).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria

summary: 2 Western silver units.
53 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Caracalla (Julia Domna ) (AD 211-217).
Hoard of circa 150 solidi and Goths imitations of Asastasius I: Theodosius II to Anastasius I; gold w8: c. 667.5g.
disposition: Münzkabinett Berlin, Germany (10 coins). The rest were melted down.

summary: 79 bronze coins found in a cave: 1 antoninianus (radiate), 78 nummi: Probus - House of Theodosius I (AD 383-425).
disposition: Soprintendenza Archeologica del Friuli Venezia Giulia, Trieste, Italy

summary: 5 sestertii Augustus (15 BC) - imitations
disposition: Narodni muzej, Numizmatični cabinet, Ljubljana, Slovenia

summary: 89 antoniniani (radiates) ranging from Gordian III to Aemilian.

A. Marsden writes:Group of 14 copper alloy radiates of Carausius (7) and Allectus (7). Condition is generally poor (due to corrosion not wear) but the coins were retrieved from a small area and clearly form part of a dispersed hoardAs menti1d, most of the coins are corroded but it can be seen that their condition when they went into the ground was evidently very good. Given this lack of wear it is very tempting to connect the deposition of this coin hoard (assuming we are not dealing with an accidental purse loss) with the reconquest of Britain by Constantius Chlorus in 296. Certainly, given the dem1tisation of these radiates in 296, the hoard cannot date to very much later.
A hoard of 936 nummi (Tetrarchy), found 2 hours west of Oraio.
68-70 kg, 28-30000 antoniniani: Valerian I - Florian (AD 276); silver w8: 5221.1-36248.9 g (after Hobbs).
Around 100 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 87 provide information on the issuers: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
disposition: National museum Kielce, Poland (76 denarii); private collection (13 denarii)

summary: The hoard was found placed on a masonry slab and comprised a sestertius of Hadrian and 21 double sestertii of Postumus, including 4 imitations.
The hoard comprised 14 sestertii from Trajan to Commodus and was found placed next to 2 greyware ceramic vessels.

Over 40 Roman bronze coins, nummi of the Constantius II and the Houses of Valentinian I and of Theodosius I. Unearthed in 1888 by villagers digging a grave. No further details were reported. Bell, the then Archaeological Commissi1r, was able to secure 40 pieces. The coin types were: Constantius II: fel temp reparation (falling horseman). House of Valentinian I: concordia auggg (Roma or Constantinopolis). House of Theodosius: salus reipublicae (victory/captive); virtus exerciti (emperor/victory); gloria Romanorum (2 emperors).
28 sestertii: 15 Severus Alexander, 13 Gordian III found in the Dominican convent area.
Hoard of 230 coins of the Bosporan kings (AD 286-341).

697 bronze coins were found in 1927 during preparation for a road leading to a quarry in the Gemeindewald, at Leubrücke between Faha and Wei10. The coins were lost during the war, but their inventory was kept, so that 688 coins could be identified. They range from Galba to Septimius Severus (Julia Domna).

17 radiates found assoc. with remains of a ceramic container & human infant b1s in fill of a ditch. Poss. a foundation deposit under a timber building. 2 bronze scrap frags. & a bronze hook also menti1d, but not clear if assoc.

Over 500 coins were discovered on a parcel by a collector. G. Dembski have seen 68 denarii. Other scholars (Al. Ruske) expressed some doubts about these coins being part of a hoard: Hadrian - Severus alexander (AD 230).
A find of 4 Late Roman nummi (and 1 sestertius of Antoninus Pius), made in 1888 in Benstrup. Nothing further is known about the circumstances of this find.
A hoard of sestertii of which 4 pieces are known: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina II and Lucilla.
138 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Valerian (AD 253-260).
7 sestertii found together in a very good state of preservation inside an urban villa: Maximinus I Thrax - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).

27 coins found together in a roll (un petit rouleau de monnaies soudées ensemble par l'oxydation) next to the wall of the temple of Zeus, in Salamis. 26 silver issues of Cyprus (Vespasian to Titus) and 1 bronze coin (Berytus).
Unknown originally coin number. 5 antoniniani (radiates) and 87 denarii are known: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
8 bronze pieces: 6 sestertii, 2 medallions: Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) - Septimius Severus (AD 210).
11 denarii: Vespasian – Commodus (Divus Marcus Aurelius ) (AD 181).

During the excavation of the Anto9 Wall fort on the Bar Hill, a hoard of 13 denarii (Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius Caesar) was found at the bottom of a well. Most of them were imitations, 10 of them were cast of pure tin. Only 2 of the coins, of Mark Antony and of Vespasian, were genuine struck denarii of silver. 1 coin, of Hadrian, seemed to be of some alloy of copper, and the remaining 10 coins were cast, of almost pure tin, with no trace of alloy. Of these tin coins, 5, of Trajan, seemed to have come from the same moulds, and 3 others, also of Trajan, seemed to have come from the same moulds. It has been suggested that these were shams expressly manufactured for devotional purposes (throwing of m1y into wells from superstitious motives).
(c. 50) 25 bronze coins: 22 sestertii, 3 asses: House of Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169)
Urn found with circa circa 40 kilos of nummi of Maxentius. Only 247 have been studied (AD 309-312).
disposition: Civiche Raccolte Numismatiche di Milano, collection Brera (inv.nos. M.0.9.20603-20849).

summary: A hoard of 20+ Roman silver coins (i.e. certainly denarii), found while digging out peat on the Dörpstedter Moor.
(400) 359 silver coins: Commodus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver w8: 494.8-899.6 g.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Varna, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 3110-3468

summary: A hoard of 13 provincial coins, found in grave T207 of the Roman cemetery excavated at Strovolos. The coins are not described, but ill. fig. 23α and 23β. They comprised 6 pseudo-autonomous coins of Philippi (dated to the time of Claudius or Nero), 6 provincial coins of Amphipolis (Domitian) and 1 uncertain coin.
Hoard of 80 denarii. 19 coins were documented: Hadrian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).

15 coins, possibly nummi, found in a hard lump of earth in Wall-Lane tanyard, Nantwich, when the pits were being filled up, in or about the year 1849. All, or nearly all, are helmet headed, and are said to belong to various Roman emperors.
79 denarii found circa 25 m from the Jerzmanowice 2005 hoard and 1 more denarius found in 2009. Most likely 1 owner: Hadrian - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-196).
15 denarii: Vespasian/Titus - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
50 silver coins. 15 pieces were seen: 5 antoniniani, 10 denarii; silver w8: 65.2-131.5 g.
102 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms found during excavations in the foundation of a house: Claudius I (Messalina) - Antoninus Pius (AD 149-150).

Concreted group of about 15 small copper alloy coins or coin blanks, found by D'Arcy Hunt, identified by Moorhead (2000, 57 no. 79) as a hoard. Found among a group of detector finds from an unknown site in Lacock parish. The collection of D'Arcy Hunt is now in the Wiltshire Museum, Devizes.
The hoard comprised 14 silver Iron Age coins.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen; Inventory: III, 2, p. 48, no. 1871 (1893) and IV, no. 4554 (1931)

summary: 10 coins (denarii and bronze coins, ranging from Galba to Trajan) found by private persons in a burnt layer, inside the Steinkastell in Nida. It is still not unequivocal, whether the discovered coins form a hoard.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 1000 3rd century antoniniani (radiates), including an example of Gordian I or II.
8 provincial bronze coins: Caracalla - Gordian III (AD 238-244)
disposition: History Museum, Lovech, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1482 (8 coins)

summary: Record of 3 silver coins found in a garden (or possibly 1 (of Trajan) found in the garden and the others nearby). Referred to by Robertson 2000, 424 no. 1820 in record for another hoard, see IARCH-DFE96C.
The most plausible reconstruction suggests that there were 2 Iron Age hoards discovered at Mount Bat10, perhaps in 1830 and 1832, consisting of 4 gold and 9 silver coins.
The hoard comprised approximately 1400 radiates from Gallienus to Tacitus Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of between 337g and 1084g.
At least 29 denarii. 1 denarius of Domitian.
disposition: Sammlung der Gesellschaft für Pomrnersche Geschichte und Altertumskunde - Antiquarisches Museum, Town Museum Stettin, Poland.

summary: 125 nummi: Tetrarchy - Valens (AD 364-378).
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel holding approximately 300 'small bronzes' (radiates): Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 263).
11 denarii found with a cooking pot: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 134-135)
