The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing approximately 225 coins, apparently 209 denarii from Clodius Albinus to Gordian III and an as of Caracalla. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of between 305.5g and 698g.
23 nummi: Constans - Constantius II (AD 355-361). Uncertain whether they were found together, although the composition may suggest so.
disposition: Museo Civico "F. L. Belgiorno", Modica, Italy (inv.nos. 1475-1497)

summary: 523 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Gallienus - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
The hoard comprised over 300 bronze coins dated between the 4th and fifth centuries AD.

There is an account of Borlase receiving 4 radiates from the Rector of Lanreath that were found at the unidentified place of "Carlean" in 1785. The findspot was described as "near the northern extremity of [the earthwork known as] the Giant's-hedge, not far from Ethy", at Lerryn creek, on the Eastern banks of the River Fawy". Penhallurick suggests that Carlean is a misreading of Collon.
Hoard of circa 10 kilos, approx. 2000 coins. Only 23 pieces are documented: Gratian - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
1600 denarii found in a ceramic vessel - metal detecting - within an ancient settlement. The latest coins are from Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
1168 silver coins - antoniniani (radiates) and denarii found while metal detecting. Probably, ending with coins of Philip I (AD 244-249).
73 denarii: Republic - Augustus (AD 2 Bc - AD 4).
A rather confused record of finds relating to 28 Iron Age potin coins.
2 coins of Antoninus Pius, 1 Marcus Aurelius and 1 of Hadrian found in 1725, as part of a large 'parcel' of coins.
Unknown originally number of coins. 176 silver coins. Today lost.

The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 196 aurei, of which 61 were recorded in detail. Mints represented include: Rome (11), Pergamum (4), Colonia Patricia (4), Caesaraugusta (1), Spain (2 or 3), Nîmes (2 or 3), Lyon (10), uncertain (RIC I No. 539). The latest coin in the hoard is an issue from Lyon dating to 10 BC. A navvy found the hoard at the foot of a hill close to the forest on the 'Sentier des Moines' path. The hoard is dispersed. 21 aurei were acquired by the Cabinet des Médailles (Archives Register B, p. 130-1; purchased: 19.01.1835), 3 others by the Dupré Collection, then into the Wigan Collection (now in the British Museum). 1 coin was retained by the Countess de Songeons in the Château de l'Ermite in Ambenay.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bibliothèque Nationale, Paris

summary: (?) 3 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 174-175).
(+7000) 5688 denarii and antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Ruse, Bulgaria; in.nos. 4054-4238

summary: In 1885, 6 Roman gold coins and a golden clasp were dug up during digging works in the Main at Thüngersheim. In 1886 2 further gold coins were found at the same location. Coins range from Antoninus Pius to Gallienus.

A hoard consisting of 286 Roman imperial denarii was found in the late 2010s near the village of Matusiv in Cherkasy region. The deposit was allegedly found in 2 pots: 1 contained coins, the other a gold piece (bar) and a bead. The hoard was sold in pieces shortly after the find. 19 coins can be identified based on photos.
8 Iron Age silver units apparently declared Treasure and acquired by the British Museum.
At least 8 tremisses of Justinian and 3 Gallic imitations, raged up from the river bed.
79 denarii found en ruleau while digging a ditch: Vespasian - Severus Alexander (AD 223). Some coins may be intruders.
disposition: Collection of the public grammar school in Kalmar

summary: 1 denarius (Mark Antony), 9 gold staters of Cunobelin and 1 copper-alloy brooch.
(1567) 1559 antoniniani: Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver w8: 1960.1-4072.8 g.
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria

summary: A hoard of Roman denarii found with a ceramic vessel and spread in more lots. 121 coins are known: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
disposition: National Museum of History, Moscow, Russia (inv.no. 23357); Archaeological Museum, Warsaw, Poland (inv.no. 27); Gorodetsky Museum, Kyiv, Ukraine (until 1917)

summary: 10585 nummi: House of Constantine (AD 313-333)
19 silver coins: 18 denarii of Augustus, 1 republican quinarius (19-18 BC).
159 solidi ranging from Gratian to Honorius, AD 406.
11 nummi found under the burned floor of a building from the Late Roman fort: Constantius II - Valens (AD 364-378).

177 denarii with portraits of emperors from Vespasian to Trajan and 2 denarii of Mark Antony's 'legionary' series. The denarii were found with a ceramic vessel. The metal analyses, fresh minting loo-alike state of preservation for the large majority of the coins as well as the overw8 for most of the coins reveal a 'hoard' of ancient counterfeited coins. The dating of coin type is based on the genuine prototype, otherwise, it looks that they were all minted in/after AD 116.
disposition: Museum of National Union, alba Iulia, Romania

summary: The hoard comprised 'a block of between 200 and 400 radiates.': Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269.
122 antoniniani (radiates)found with a purse and in a wooden casket together with other objects: Caracalla - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
49 coins: 3 silver and 46 provincial bronze coins entered the museum collection in Shumen: Vespasian - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2100-2148 (49 coins)

summary: 7 contemporary aes copies of Claudius and Antonia Minor found during excavations of Usk Cattle Market.

160 staters were found within a "restricted area" of a single field, near a fording point across the River Brit (TAR 2003, 151 no. 352). The coins are nominally described as base silver, although some might more accurately be described as bronze.
2165 antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268); silver w8: 203.5-1011.5g.
disposition: Museo d'Antichità di Torino, Italy (1,355 coins); 810 coins were bought by a junk dealer.

summary: 1051 radiates of the later third century (Valerian to Tetricus I) found at a quarry. According to Lee (1862), the coins were in a "covered pot or pan of common black ware which was unfortunately broken."
Over 16000 denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Vespasian - Probus (AD 276-382). Found placed in 2 amphoras together with jewelry and silverware.
disposition: Musée de Bretagne, Rennes, France (4,159 coins)

summary: 315 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel: 297 denarii, 18 antoniniani (radiates): Marcus Aurelius - Gordian III (AD 243-244); silver w8: 439.5-814.6 g.
128 sestertii found with an Amphora: Claudius I 108, Drusus 13, 7 uncertain (AD 41-54).
Unknown number of provincial bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel. 25 pieces are known: Septimius Severus - Caracalla (AD 211-217).

Coins found close to the Roman fort at Old Carlisle while metal detecting. The find comprised 1 aureus of Titus (under Vespasian) and 17 denarii ranging from Mark Antony to the reign of Septimius Severus.
269 bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel during metal detecting: 252 sestertii, 4 dupondii, 13 asses: Domitian - Postumus (AD 260-261).
226 Celtic coins.
4-5000 imitations of antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I and II found in a ceramic vessel (AD 271-274).
Heap of sestertii, 6: Trajan 4, Commodus 1, uncertain 1 (AD 180-192).

The hoard comprised 15 denarii and radiates from Nerva to Valerian and Gallienus with a tpq of AD 257 to 258. The exact findspot of the hoard is not known, beyond the fact that it was found on the site of Colonia Ulpia Traiana. This ensemble could have been part of a larger hoard. The date of the find is described as several decades before 2010, when the hoard was published by Reuter.
20 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 188-189). Among them 2 imitations. Together it was found an iron axe typical for the Chernyakhov culture (4th-5th centuries AD).

The hoard comprises 16 Iron Age coins. It was characterised as being 1 of 16 individual votive deposits found at the site of an important Gallo-Roman sanctuary during excavations. Inventory No. 76-395 and 76.396
11 bronze coins: Domitian 1, Trajan 10 (AD 98-117).
The hoard comprised 91 nummi from the House of Constantine.
1937 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Probus (AD 276-282).
disposition: Musées Royaux d'Art et d'Histoire - Koninklijk Musea voor Kunst en Geschiedenis (Brussels)

summary: 134 silver coins. 28 entered the National Archaeological Institute with Museum in Sofia: Republic - Vespasian/Titus (AD 69-81).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 2806-2833

summary: 3089 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 257-258).
3 denarii found on a field: Trajan 1, Lucilla 1, Faustina II/Lucilla 1

20 siliqua found in an early medieval burial (Alemannic) and re-used as jewellery. All coins pierced close to the rim, attached as pairs by small metal rings to a belt, combined with other items (glass bead, amber bead, shell, 2 bronze rings).

209 coins: 1 antoninianus (radiate), 208 nummi: Carus - Valentinian III (AD 425-455) found in a cave. Mints: Antioch 3, Constantinopolis 2, Thessalonica 1, Aquileia 2, Rome 3, Siscia 1, Arelate 2, Lugdunum 2, Londinium 1.
8 nummi: Valentinian I - Theodosius (AD 388-393).

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 1200 Roman coins, which the finder distributed amongst his friends and acquaintances. Later investigation of the findspot recovered some pottery sherds and a certain number of coins that were identified by the Cabinet des Médailles, Paris by H. Huvelin.
3503 radiates to Probus, in a pot. Full identifications of all the coins of Probus is unavailable. Unpublished?
Around 50-60000 of silver and bronze coins (92 kilos) of the Late Empire found with an embossed copper cauldron. some issuers were identified as: Constantine I, Constantius II, Constants and Valens.
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Nacional de Madrid (4,000 coins); 2,000 divided between the museums of Rotterdam, Cluny, Marsella, Lugo, Oviedo and private collectors

summary: 61 denarii found with a ceramic vessel at the Dacian fortress: Republic – Augustus (13 BC).
disposition: National Székely Museum, Sf. Gheorghe, Romania (inv. nos. 15876–15936)

summary: 140 Roman silver coins (denarii and antoniniani ranging from Septimius Severus to Trajan Decius), were found in a pit filled with burnt destruction rubble in the vicus surrounding the Roman fort. The vast majority of the coins shows no signs of circulation.

A number (possibly 150) of Roman silver coins (possibly Nero - Antoninus Pius / Marcus Aurelius), found in the vicinity of the Herren-Holz, a quarter of an hour north of Spahn, lying on a mound of earth.

2 scattered groups of Durotrigan base silver staters found approximately 20 metres apart. It is unclear whether they should be considered as originating in 1 or 2 deposits. A single, widely-scattered hoard is perhaps more likely, and it now seems to be impossible to identify which coins were in which parcel.

The find comprised 37 coins including 3 radiates and 34 nummi. 25 coins are in the Stiftsbibliothek St. Gallen, with 12 additional donated to the Swiss National Museum in 1847 given a provenance of 'Näfels'. It is possible that this assemblage is not a hoard but a collection of single finds (see Bertolaccini/Zäch 2008).
disposition: Stifsbibliothek St. Gallen (25 coins); Swiss National Museum (12 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 65 bronze coins dated between 294-283 BC and AD 117-138.
Found in a cup (that was discarded), the hoard was recorded 10 years after being found. 8 coins to the coin level. 2 copies; 5 nummi Silver: 1, 2 coins; Silver w8: 2.95g

The hoard comprised a jug containing an agglomeration of 1454 Roman coins found with a small ceramic vessel. Gallia states that 1458 coins were found, but only 1454 were detailed. TAF suggests that a further 4 unidentified coins could be added: Gordian III - Probus (AD 276-282); silver w8: c.248.3-1144.0g.
The hoard comprised '40 Gallic gold coins in the form of buttons with representations of crescents and horses'. These appear to be staters of a uniface type attributed to Ambiens.
92 coins, only 14 have provided information on the issuers: Aurelian -Constantius II (AD 324-361).
7 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Diocletian (284-293).
14 coins: 2 antoniniani (radiates), 12 nummi: Gallienus (Salonina) – Valentinian I (AD 364-367).

5 gold coins of Valentinian I 'recently' found at Tewkesbury, according to a note published in 1846 (JBAA, I (1846), 157). These probably came from a hoard, but may only represent part of it. 3 further coins (Valentinian I, Valens and Gratian) were given to the Yorkshire museum in 1833.
Circa 2000 denarii but only 20 pieces indicate emperors from Antoninus Pius to Maximinus I Thrax.
Around 700 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. For only 2 coins are known the issuers: Domitian and Septimius Severus. The archives mention that the coins were minted between years 81 and 222.

Between 296 and 334 coins. The coins came out following the blasting activities on the Lueg Canal. G. Dembski considers as hoard these coins due to homogenous aspect of this numismatic evidence: Vesasian - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
77 nummi found grouped near a wall of the Roman villa: Constantine I - Theodosius I - Arcadius (AD 383-408).
disposition: Museo de la Ciudad de Alicante, Spain

summary: 700 coins found with a ceramic vessel near a wall: Probus - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
The hoard comprised a vessel containing between 1300 and 1500 copper-alloy coins from Antoninus Pius to Tetricus I.

The hoard comprised either a) a ceramic vessel containing several hundred sestertii of Nero to Marcus Aurelius. b) 2 ceramic vessels found on separate occasions containing 60 and 110 coins respectively.
48 antoniniani (radiates) from Elagabalus to Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).
6 nummi of the House of Valentinian (AD 367-378).
517 bronze and electrum Bosporan coins: Rhescuporis II - Ininthimeus (AD 238).
5 denarii (Vespasian - Antoninus Pius), found while digging for peat in the vicinity of the Buchow-Karpzow estate, probably only part of a larger find.
10 coins found compacted together during excavations in Tofts Field in 1974. Recovered from surface of first re-metalling of Dere Street, to the east of the later fort, in Tofts Field.
Unknown number of coins. 11 bronze coins have been noticed: Rhometalces I - Nero (AD 54-68).
Among the object found during the excavations at Haus Meer, were 9 nummi (AD 302-305) that probably belonged to a hoard.

The hoard comprised 109 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Postumus and was found in the corner of a Roman building uncovered during ploughing. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of between 30.4g and 135.3g.
2 silver units found near the parishes of Urchfont and Easterton in Wiltshire, but not from the same site as the other Urchfont hoards.

The hoard comprised 214 denarii and radiates from Commodus to Gordian III which are today lost. Also found in the excavations as isolated finds were a denarius of Septimius Severus, and 2 bronzes of Severus Alexander. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of 313.3-487.1g
Around 300 coins, of which 103 are preserved: House of Constantine I - Arcadius (AD 402-408).
disposition: Asociación de Amigos de la Historia de Calahorra, Spain

summary: On July 28, 1937, a hoard of 1478 silver and 2 copper coins was found in Rochester Road, St. Anne's, Bristol, in a pit that was being dug for a garage. No trace of any container could be found, though careful search was made. The silver coins were 1476 denarii (Mark Antony to Septimius Severus) and 2 drachms (Caesarea in Cappadocia and Lycia). Please note that Pearce and Mattingly's coin summary lists 128 denarii of Hadrian and 66 of Faustina I, but the catalogue includes 126 Hadrianic denarii, and 68 denarii of Faustina I.
disposition: British Museum (part); City of Bristol Museum and Art Gallery (part)

summary: 6-700 aurei. 12 pieces were presented in court at Volterra. Over 60 pieces sold to goldsmiths in Livorno are known to be all issued by Augustus, some for Caius and Lucius, the types with pontifical instruments (RIC, 206, Lugdunum, 2 BC - AD 4). 2 other types were identified: Augustus, bull IMP X (RIC, 168, Lugdunum, 15-13 BC); IMP XIIII: Augustus, togate, seated left on platform, receiving child from standing barbarian (RIC, 200, Lugdunum, 9 BC)

A number of coins were found during archaeological investigations in a karst st1 cave in 1977. Among these, a group of maiorinae of Magnentius could have been deposited together, but all other coins are single finds.
The hoard comprised 8 antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus' joint reign and Postumus with a tpq of AD 260 to 269. FMRL suggests that it was a small part of a much larger hoard.
214 radiates after AD 280. Found in a pit post-dating the rampart in a concreted mass. 1 official coin and 212 barbarous radiates of small module, 1 illegible coin.

157 coins of the first Tetrarchy (AD 294-305) found in a linen bag deposited on top of a wooden box with jewellery, in a pit in the Roman fort of Vemania. The hoard was buried in early AD 305, Garbsch / Kos, pp. 70-1.
At Camerton, 3 Roman villas were discovered in 1814 as well as 26 silver coins of Honorius, Arcadius, and the later Emperors, concealed between 2 Roman tiles.
The hoard comprised 254 denarii (10 serrati) from the Republic to Augustus (18 BC).
Hoard of circa 86-87 aurei found with a ceramic vessel with a graffiti "IRENE": Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

A great number of Roman coins, both gold and silver, found in an urn, close to Stratford. This includes a coin of Magnus Maximus. A gold coin of Valens, said to have been found at Stratford, may belong to this hoard.

10 bronze coins from cremation burial 317 in King Harry Lane late Iron Age cemetery (Stead and Rigby 1989, 354). The grave goods consisted of 3 pots and a brooch as well as the 10 coins, 3 of which were found on a platter. The bodies were identified as 1 adult and 1 immature. De Jersey (2015) notes the dating of Phase 1 burials from the site to AD 1-40.
The hoard comprised 119 nummi (AE 3) of Constantine I, Constantine II and Constantius II.

A hoard of nummi of unknown size, including a number of Constantinian GLORIA EXERCITVS types, discovered on a farm around 1850. There is no information on this hoard other than that provided by Boon (1967), quoting a letter dated 5th January 1855: "a few years ago on a farm called Tyddyn Isaf Penrhyndeudraeth opposite ford of Felenrhyd, in moving some st1s were found a great number (about 2 quarts my informant says) and of which I have 3 on the table before me of Roman coins of Constantinus with 2 warriors on the reverse." Boon surmises that the hoard must have been "1 of at least 5000 pieces", but the volume of coins given in the letter (2 imperial quarts; i.e., 2.2 litres) would not allow for such a number.

6 radiates and nummi found at various times at Breiddin hill fort. In 1875, 4 coins, thought to have been found near quarry workings on the western side of the hill fort about 10 years before, were donated to Powysland Museum. These were since lost among the museum's collections, but it is probable they included a radiate of Victorinus and 2 Constantinian nummi of GLORIA EXERCITVS (2 soldiers) and Constantinopolis types still in the museum's possession. These were followed in 1910 by around 12 more coins that were apparently found in the same area. Only 2 of these can now be identified among the museum's collections: 1 Constantinian nummus from Ticinum and 1 billon coin of Alexandria struck for Aurelian. The Alexandrian coin's association with the hoard is dubious, given the scarcity of such coins in British contexts.

A hoard found at Middle Farm, Cople, Bedfordshire in 2004 (2 solidi, 5 siliquae) and 2005 (10 siliquae). A solidus of Honorius, found before 1899 in a field, is presumably to be associated with this hoard. Coins range from Valens to Arcadius and Honorius, with the latest coins dating to AD 394-402.

A poor record of a small hoard of continental cast bronze, purportedly found near Penzance in the late 9teenth century. The coins entered the British Museum from 2 different sources and Allen (1960a, 280) notes that the 2 groups are not necessarily from the same hoard. In the absence of any further information the record cannot be regarded as particularly reliable
The hoard comprised 2800 nummi, mostly of Constantine I and Crispus.
Originally 66 denarii, 55 preserved: Titus - Commodus (AD 188-189); silver w8: 155.21 g.
Hoard of 181 coins, 32 denarii and 150 provincial bronze coins of Tyras: Mark Antony - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
286 denarii and 7 bits of gold found with a ceramic vessel using as lid another ceramic vessel: Republic - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235).
93 siliquae (1 imitation) of Constantius II (AD 351-355).
disposition: Odessa Archaeological Museum, Ukraine (93 coins inv.nos. 53879-53971)

summary: 750 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel. 726 pieces studied: 502 antoniniani, 224 denarii: Hadrian - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver w8: c. 940.4-2135.9 g. Found together with bronze statuettes of horses.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2525; History Museum, Kardzhali, Bulgaria;

summary: Hoard consisting of 17 solidi found during the excavation of Iron Age houses in 1949-50. Coins range from Theodosius II to Anastasius.
Trajan to Septimius Severus. The total number of coins is an estimate and there are thought to have been more than 1000. Found during ploughing
1094 antoniani: Valerian I - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 292). It was found during dredging works in the River Danube. Apparently, the hoard was originally packed as rolls of coins.
Unknown number of silver coins. 23 silver coins were seen: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver w8: 18.2-34.5 g.
disposition: Museum of History, Karnobat (12 coins); Regional History Museum, Burgas, Bulgaria (inv.no. XVI)

summary: Hoard of 187 coins, antoniniani and nummi: Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) - Theodosius I (AD 379-395).
A further gold solidus of Constantine III is attributed to the hoard by Gricourt (1959-1960). However, this is unlikely to be part of the hoard. Gold: 4, 2 coins; Gold w8: 20.8g;
4 coins found on a field. 3 of them on a radius of 1 m, the other 50 m away: denarius Hadrian, solidus Marcian, solidus Leo I, gold imitation Anastasius I (AD 493-526).

The hoard was found in the south-eastern corner of Ulpia Traiana, south of the city walls and close to the Roman port. It comprised 46 sestertii, denarii and radiates from Trajan to Postumus with a tpq of AD 260 to 268.

In 1864 reportedly more than 300 Roman coins were dug out at a field behind the Zorn'schen machine factory (on Landshuter street between Richard-Wagner street and Stobäusplatz). Descriptions of only 56 coins (1 denarius and 55 antoniniani, ranging from Julia Domna to Numerian) exist today. The coin of Numerian might not belong to this hoard.
Circa 150 denarii. 100 were studied: Hadrian - Pertinax (AD 193).
A hoard of an unknown number of denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Only 5 coins are documented: Domitian, Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Commodus, Philip I (AD ).
A scattered hoard of 39 Iron Age staters.
The hoard comprised a small black ceramic vessel closed with a stopper and containing 54 Republican and early Imperial denarii.
Pastscape / OS record of a tradition of a find of a "potful" of Roman coins in a field in which more recent finds have been made, including 2 coins of Claudius II.
4 coins found in Jülich, during the construction of the technology center.
Penhallurick (2009, 245 no. 251) records a metal detector find of 9 sestertii found in an area of about 50 square metres in the same field. Considered to be part of a scattered hoard.

47 denarii ranging from Nero to Hadrian (1 Nero, 3 Vespasian, 4 Titus, 6 Domitian, 3 Nerva, 20 Trajan, 10 Hadrian) were given to the Historisches Museum in Ol10 by the Schmid family in 1901/1902, next to 13 other Roman coins. Records say that all of these belonged to a find made in the vicinity of Matzendorf in 1841, but probably only the denarii are part of a hoard. No further details of the discovery are known.

The hoard was found during a rally of the Tamworth Metal Detecting Club and there were 18 finders in all. It included 2 aurei and 92 denarii, ranging from the Republican period to Domitian, a further denarii was found in 2004, bringing the total to 93 denarii. Note: this hoard was found within some 500 metres of 2 single aureus of Claudius I discovered in 1925 (Bland 522) and in 2007 (Bland 524).
The hoard comprised 1 dupondius and 5 asses terminating with issues of the period AD 178-183. The coins were found together, but without trace of a container.
30 coins found in a ceramic vessel: 1 antonianus (radiate), 29 nummi: Claudius II - Constantine I-Licinius I (AD 317).
(10.000+/-) 1112 antoniniani: Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver w8: c.1351.0-6249.0g
disposition: National Museum in Valjevo, Serbia (1112 coins) - 2001; dispersed

summary: Hoard (?) of 20 coins of the 4rd century AD foud during the building of a new street. Kropotkin places this hoard in the group of suspicious finds.
92 silver coins, 90 denarii, 2 drachms of Lycia: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 175); w8: 292.04 g.
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie și Arheologie, Piatra Neamț, Romania (inv.nos. 28530-

summary: 200 aurei, only 6 were available for study: Galba, Trajan, Hadrian, Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Lucius Verus.
“Large quantity” of Roman bronze coins. Of the 22 pieces secured by the Archaeological Commissi1r only 1 was identifiable: Arcadius, gloria Romanorum (3 emperors), Cyzicus, AD 406–408.
Hoard of 96 bronze staters of Rhescuporis V (AD242-267).
Sometime before 1869, somewhere in the vicinity of Nantes, a hoard comprising several hundreds antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I and Tetricus II was discovered.
134 sestertii: Nero - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
Unknown number of initial number of coins. 6427 coins: 19 antoniniani, 6408 nummi: Aurelian - Constantine I (AD 317).
18 antoniniani (raddiates) found in the dump of the ancient quarry: Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
It had been discovered in 2 earthen vessels. It comprised of 137 denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Only 97 are now recorded: Pertinax - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).

Coins run from Mark Antony to Trajan Decius, although it has been argued that the last coins could be intrusive. In that case, the hoard would end with issues of Gordian III. 81096 (and not 81044!) coins were published in 1934 by Mouchmov, after a further 20000+ coins had been dispersed. The total number of coins therefore exceeds 101096 specimens. The difference between our comput and the 81044 coins menti1d in the original publication resides in an error in counting the number of coins of Commodus (3146, whereas 3191 is correct) and reporting the correct number of coins of Caracalla in the table p. 6 of Mouchmov's publication. Note that further errors have occurred for Trajan (p. 21, last 3 entries, where numbers do not add up).
disposition: National Museum, Sofia (ca. 68,783 coins). Archaeology Museum, Varna, Bulgaria: inv.nos. 2807-2829, 4301-16363 (12,261 coins: Nero - Gordian III)

summary: 4 2nd c. AD coins were found during sharding in Flurdistrikt above the Geybach river.
5 solidi found with ceramic vessel sherds: Leo I - Basiliscus (AD 475-476); gold w8: 22.25g.
The hoard comprised 500 or 600 billon staters, which are attributed to the pre-Gallic Wars tribes of the Red1s and Veneti.
223 silver coins (tetradrachms, denarius, shekels) found with a ceramic vessel next to another 1 (Qumran 1953 B) and not far from Qumran 1953 C.
Circa 100 provincial bronze coins minted in Nicopolis ad Istrum, Marcianopolis, Odessus, Tomis, Dionysopolis: Elagabalus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
The hoard comprised 22 aurei (70 ca.-158-159 AD) found most likely between the West Bank, Upper Galilee and the Golan.
Originally, the hoard comprised 740 coins. Only 18 are studied at the moment: Tetricus I - Constantius II (AD 337-361).

A hoard of denarii, found while digging sand in a sand-pit, between the Lion Foundry, Kirkintilloch, and Barley Bank houses. 24 coins were first published in 1894, followed by a more complete list in 1911 (42 coins). 5 more coins were found since, giving a total of 47 denarii (Vespasian - Faustina II) that were published.
21 siliquae and 1 nummus, up to Honorius, AD 402.
101 coins found in a vineyard. 86 are documented by D. Chico. The structure of this discovery raises some suspicions: Gaius - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
The hoard was placed next to the skull of a skeleton in an inhumation grave and comprised 33 small bronzes antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
1312 antoniniani (radiates) ending with coins of Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver w8: 249.3g.
20 sestertii, found on a small plate with ashes: Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-187).
151 antoniniani: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 244-247).
disposition: Local museum Govora, Vâlcea County, Romania (1966); Muzeul de Istorie a Județului Vâlcea, Râmnicu Vâlcea, Romania (101 coins spread through the coin collection)

summary: Uknown number of silver Roman coins. 1 denarius of Severus Alexander and 2 coins of Gordian III are known.
230 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
Unknown originally number of coins. 86 bronze coins: Tiberius - Hadrian (AD 119-120).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Orense, Spain; private collections of M. Taborda and X. Taborda

summary: The hoard comprised 2 Roman Provincial coins (Thessalonica), found in grave Θ in Ierissos.

A scattered hoard of at least 409 coins (and up to 488) found in a layer of rubbly dark soil (context 4030) above in situ deposits of aisled Building 12 in the Dorset County Hospital / Hascombe Court excavations of 2001-2002.
600 denarii. 361 pieces were examined: Republic - Hadrian (AD 117-138); silver w8: 669.3-1389.9 g.
6 denarii, probably, part of a larger hoard: Antoninus Pius 3, Faustina I (Diva) 1, Antoninus Pius (Divus) 2
45 nummi found in a garden: Licinius I - House of Constantine (AD 340).
11 bronze coins: 5 sestertii, 4 dupondii, 2 asses: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-179)
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (11 coins), donations P. De Baeck.

summary: The hoard comprised 50 sestertii from Hadrian to Trajan Decius. It was found on the Arcellier property, but dispersed almost immediately.

1 denarius and 903 radiates (Maximinus I to Victorinus) found by a metal detectorist at Craig-y-Saeson Farm. Decayed fragments of a possible pewter container were found alongside the coins. No more precise depositional or contextual information is available. 8 coins are counterfeit. 7 are of Postumus, whose coinage in now recognised to have been promptly imitated. The other, of Philip I, is a compe10t creation of good w8, but stands out on account of its style
disposition: National Museum Cardiff (103); Newport Museum (40); private collections (761)

summary: 60 antoniniani (radiates) found with remains from a textile bag: Philip I - Claudius II (AD 268-270) in a doctor house.

The hoard comprised a ceramic pot containing 60 silver and billon coins. Joullietton noted the presence of coins of Otacilia Severa ('some'), Gallienus, Saloninus and Postumus ('a large number') of which many possessed the reverse type HERC DEVSONIENSI (E. 316) The hoard was found by a farmer cutting down a cherry tree in his garden.
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 17 nummi are documented: Constantine I - Magnentius (AD 350-353).
disposition: Senator Schwarz private collection, Burghowmuseum, Soest (in 1932)

summary: 5 Antoniniani found together on the 'Tokenberg', in Göstrup-Hüt10hau. These may be part of a larger find.
(700) 659 provincial bronze coins: Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: History Museum, Targovishte, Bulgaria; inv. no. 200

summary: Over 1000 denarii found in a forest. From only 5 of them are know the issuers: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211). Together with the hoard were found: 5 pearls, 1 amber piece, a silver plate and a spring from a crossbow brooch.
The hoard comprised 53 bronze coins dated between AD 69 and AD 247-249.

Found by chance by a herdsman, with no further indication provided. Ca. 30 Roman coins, Constantine (I) and Nero (sic!) are menti1d. No further notice is available in the Swiss National Museum (SLM). Probably not a hoard/purse, but rather an assemblage of single finds?
16 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 192).

The hoard was discovered in 1993 by Vasily Prigodich (excavator operator), during the digging in a chalk quarry (between the villages of Malyech and Kabaki). The coins were in a hand made pot. In total, the hoard contained 408 (or 409?) coins, but to study preserved only 383 denarii (Vespasian-Septimius Severus) and 4 barbarian imitations of denarii.
disposition: National Historical Museum of Republic of Belarus

summary: 22 billon tetradrachms of Aurelian (AD 274-275) found on the still of a niche in a wall of a room during excavations of a house.

A hoard of 4 denarii (2 Domitian and 2 Trajan) was found during field-walking in the South Annexe of the fort at Newstead. The coins were recovered in a little roll, with possible traces of a copper/bronze container.
39 nummi found in a small jug in the 'House of Hoard': Constantius II and Constans - Honorius (AD 408-423).
Hoard of 17 silver coins, comprising 7 denarii (Elagabal to Maximinus) and 10 radiates (Gordian III to Trebonianus Gallus)
ARCH record for 5 Iron Age gold staters.

A Whaddon Chase stater is "said to have been found, together with 4 other British coins, near Thetford". The coin is almost certainly BMC 310 (Chadburn 2006, hoard 8), which matches the w8 given by Evans. Haselgrove (1987, 328 no. 73) acknowledges that it could be a bona fide small hoard, but also suggests it could be a parcel from Whaddon Chase (CHRE 15390).
Unknown initial number of coins. 34 antoniniani: Gordian III -Valerian I (AD 259-260); silver w8: 42.5 g+
The coins were in the old collections of Leroy de la Brière and E. Lambert.

A gold coin of Theodosius I (AD 379-395) found c. 1800 in the foundations of the pele tower at Muncaster Castle. A coin today at the Carlisle museum is thought to come from the same location. The original find might well have consisted in more than just these 2 coins.
(3500-3600) 3106 antoniniani: Trebonianus Gallus - Tacitus (AD 276); silver w8: c.640.1-4436.6 g
disposition: Musée Chambéry, France, 1344 coins, Musée Château d'Annecy, France, Registre d'entrées, II, nos. 6480-6482, 9046 (137 coins and one vessel); Musée d'Art et d'Histoire de Genève, Switzerland

summary: The hoard was found mixed in with earth, without an obvious container. The excavators suggested an organic bag.
(c. 3000-3500) 474 denarii: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 168)
4 denarii (Vespasian - Trajan), allegedly found in 1845 in or around Minden. It is not impossible that these belonged to the Minden I find, made in 1844.
The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 122 denarii from Otho to Septimius Severus with a tpq of AD 193. There were also 'some illegible issues' and 3 silver spoons.
1100 or 1000 coins found with a bronze vessel. and gold coins from Antoninus Pius to Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
Circa 2000 coins, only 3 known: 2 of Severus Alexander, 1 of Philip I
The hoard comprised 132 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) of Marcus Aurelius to Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).
379 denarii from Republic to Augustus, including 4 coins of Juba I and 12 imitations.
The hoard comprised 12 coins of Gallienus and Tetricus I.
Unknown originally number of coins. 28 denarii are known: Antoninus Pius – Commodus (AD 190-191).
Hoard of around 50 denarii. 21 coins were brought for examination by the finder: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
(c. 230) 206 coins: 140 antoniniani and 66 nummi: Valerian I/Gallienus - Constantine I/Maxentius (AD 309-312)

The hoard comprised 2077 bronze coins along with bronze implements and scrap from a bronze foundry. Mostly quandrantes and semisses but also including Greek provincial, Greek, Republican up to 5th century AD
disposition: Heberden Coin Room, AShmolean Museum, Oxford, Great Britain

summary: Hughenden - Upon Piggott Common: 24 Roman coins (copper) discovered 1795 in throwing up a bankan earthen vessel about 18 inches below the surface.
It comprised 820 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
170 provincial coins: Nicopolis ad Istrum 77, Marcianopolis 69, Hadrianopolis 6, Odessos 4, Anchialus 9, Philippopolis 1, Pautalia 1: Caracalla - Gordian III (AD 238-244).

9234 denarii, 3 Lycian drachms and 1 drachm of Caesarea in Cappadocia ranging from the Republic to Severus Alexander, found in 1998 and 2000. The vast majority of the coins are from the mint of Rome, though 10% of the coins from the reign of Septimius Severus were from mints of the East of the Empire.
51 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-211).
The hoard comprised 43 tetradrachms and 95 radiates dating to the third century AD.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel filled with 10 sestertii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
101 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 175).
Circa 20000 antoniniani (radiates). Among the issuers were Trajan Decius and Tetricus I.
2 gold staters found about 2 hundred metres apart: 1 wild type of Cunobelin and 1 VEP CORF of the Corieltavi.
60 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211); silver w8: 110.9-175.9g

The hoard comprised bronze coins with the legend PIXTILOS, 100 bronze Carnutes eagle coins and a variety of eagle potins. The Cabinet des Médailles some bronze Carnutes coins (BN 6108-6180) which had been in the Saulcy and Luynes Collections.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Biblioteque Nationale, Paris

summary: In 1846 6 Roman gold coins (Tiberius - Nero) and a ring were found by a workman in 10sfelderau during the digging of a small earth mound, located on a paddock along the river 10sfelde Au.
7 bronze coins: 2 dupondii, 5 asses: Claudius I - Trajan (AD 101-102)
The hoard comprised approximately 10 tetradrachms and 35 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
1293 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms confiscated by the police from a gold and silversmith in the town. Together with 8 silver bracelets and 2 silver ingots
disposition: "the Alexandria Museum and partly to the Salle de Vente."

summary: A small scattered hoard which has generated considerable confusion in the literature. 7 Iron Age coins were acquired by the Hampshire County Museum Service, but the hoard might have contained more coins.
Uknown originally number of coins. 443 pieces were recovered: Claudius II - Honorius (AD 395-408).
Over 137 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel: 136 denarii, 1 drachm: Republic – Severus Alexander (AD 228-231).
disposition: History Museum, Târgu Neamț (24 coins); Local Museum, Târpești (44 coins)

summary: HER record of a group of 9 coins found in Bembridge in 2006:"3 Ases of Marcus Aurelius1 As of Vespasian1 As of Lucilla1 As of Lucilla or Faustina2 illegible ases1 nummus of either deified Constantius or Maximian[Object entry IOW.2006.63.1]"
(4872) 4040 coins: 1 denarius, 2 antoniniani, 4037 nummi: Severus Alexander - Valentinian II (AD 367-378).
disposition: Magyar Nemzeti Múzeum, Budapest , in 1933; some of coins dispersed

summary: The hoard comprised 586 bronze coins: Augustus-Philip I (AD 244-249).
11 silver coins: 1 denarius, 10 antoniniani: Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. no. 605 (11 coins)

summary: 1456 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Aurelian/Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver w8: 394.1-1819.1g.

3 denarii found a little distance away from 10 later denarii dating to around AD 198-201. The earliest coin is a Roman Republican denarius dating to 49 BC. Whilst these are commonly found in hoards dating up to the early second century, they would not be expected to be found in a hoard this late. It is therefore suggested that the 3 coins up to AD 69 should be considered as a separate deposit (hoard A).

103 denarii (Nero to Antoninus Pius) found near a large st1 building and a series of ditches identified by a geophysical survey in 1999 and described as a farmhouse. The site has turned up building debris, pottery, and a series of other metal finds, including at least 46 other denarii that might have come from the coin hoard (Treasure report SS 91 69).
Not a hoard but a collection of coins and artefacts found in a spring and stream bed. Not declared Treasure.
The hoard comprised 1 denarius of Elagabalus and 15 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Postumus. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of 7.3 to 19.6 g.
24 silver coins found in a st1 quarry: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251)
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 2424-2446 (24 coins)

summary: (c. 180) 31 antoniniani (radiates). Although are mention imperial portraits from Pupienus to Gallienus and Salonina the only more accurate Information on 31 coins is for issuers from Gordian III to Valerian I. The tpq hypothetically can be placed on AD 268; silver w8: 225.0 g.
disposition: Musée Château d'Annec, France (partially); Inv.no. 5352; registre d'entrées, I, p. 184, no. 5352

summary: Hoard of unknown number of Celtic gold and silver coins of type ABYDOS, Togirix of Caletes and Santons. Together were found republican denarii.
51 nummi of Constantius II (AD 337-361). No further details.
A hoard of 104 Roman coins (Philip I - Probus), found opposite the station of Mehrhoog, on a sand hill. The coins are lost.
18 coins, antoniniani (radiates) and nummi found lying together.
disposition: Rheinisches Landesmuseum, Bonn, Germany (inv. no. F 7953a)

summary: A hoard of 180 denarii, ranging from Nero to Commodus. 9 denarii (Otho-Commodus) were found in 1938, on Lord Clyde's estate of Briglands, Rumbling Bridge. Subsequent discoveries at the same place were made in 1948-57, 2-thirds of the way up the steep left (east) bank of the River Devon, after a coin was found at the opening of a rabbit hole. 1 further coin was reported in 1972.
Found during excavations in the pars urbana of the Roman villa rustica of Osterfingen, below an ash layer. 18 sestertii, Antoninus Pius, Faustina, Marcus Aurelius, Severus Alexander, Maximinus Thrax.

According to the catalogue prepared by P. Fustier, the hoard comprised 280 denarii and 847 antoniniani (radiates). However, this total must be considered as approximate as Fustier identified numerous coins as being radiates of Plautilla, a combination that does not exist. The hoard was found by a quarry worker called Rodriquez. It was almost completely dispersed although the Musée de Roanne did acquire 4 denarii of Septimius Severus, Julia Domna, Caracalla and Plautilla. Silver w8: 2064.9-4044.9g.

A small hoard consisting of approx. 30 Roman imperial denarii, a Constantius II solid with a loop and a gold pendant (or several pendants?), was discovered in the late 2010s near the village of Pohrebysche in the Vinnytsia region. Photos of the coins have not been preserved. The information is difficult to verify, so it is not quite clear whether we are talking about a hoard with accompanying items or about a hoard and items found separately at a neighboring settlement.

The hoard comprised 16 silver coins from the First Jewish Revolt (AD 66-72) and was found close to a ceramic oil lamp which may have acted as a marker for the hoard. The hoard contained 10 shekels of the First Jewish Revolt: 3 Year 1, 3 Year 2, 3 Year 3, and 1 Year 5; 1 half-shekel of Year 1, 3 half-shekels of Year 2; 1 Tyrian Shekel (AD 52/3); 1 Antiochene tetradrachm.

The hoard comprised a broken vessel containing more than 850 radiates (the total is estimated at approximately 1000 coins). The hoard was buried in a cemetery, not far from the village. The hoard was discovered by chance.
The hoard comprised 45 silver tetradrachms from Claudius I to Antoninus Pius. It is not clear whether the coins represent a complete hoard or part of a hoard.
'5 middle bronzes of Nero were discovered in a granite sarcophagus. Only 1 was quite well preserved. Its reverse depicts the temple of Janus.' (possibly an as RIC 190-191 or 198)
10 coins, a finger ring and a fibula in a wooden case with 3 hinges preserved
disposition: Musée communal des Beaux Arts et d'Archéologie de Nivelles

summary: The hoard comprised 9 figurines, 1 patera and 7 bronze coins from Vespasian to Commodus.

A hoard of Roman denarii and antoniniani from Caister (Norfolk), consisting of at least 846 coins Republic - Gallienus, with some coins of Postumus. Of these, 628 are known to have been discovered on 28 November 1946 during the excavation of a trench for water-mains on a new housing site at Belstead Avenue, East Caister (Caister-by-Yarmouth). Later, another finder produced 200 more coins from the same hoard and the authorities reported a further 19 coins as coming from the same find. Moreover Jenkins suspected that even more coins from the hoard remained in private hands. The hoard was published by Jenkins (NC 1947), with the following summary: 847 coins (664 denarii and 183 antoniniani). There are several inconsis10cies between Jenkins' catalogue and his summary. The first is that the total number of the coins in the catalogue is 846, not 847. The summary lists 3 denarii for Nerva, but catalogue records only 1. For Septimius Severus, the summary lists 290 coins, but the catalogue includes only 286. The summary lists 78 denarii for Caracalla, the catalogue only has 75. Finally the summary lists no antoniniani for Severus Alexander, but 1 is recorded in the appendix listing coins not examined by the BM. According to the catalogue, the hoard contained therefore 846 (653 denarii and 193 antoniniani). The list given in the catalogue has been followed here.
disposition: Norwich Castle Museum (part); British Museum (part, 34 specimens )

summary: 7 sestertii of Nero found during excavations at the Roman fort of Albaniana.

Details from Pastscape: "111 Roman coins were found at Witham Friary when draining a field belonging to Mr James Croom. They were well preserved, about the sizes of shillings and 6pences, and all but 1 were found in a round hole covered by a flat st1, about 12 inches below the surface. Some pieces of Roman ware were found at the same time....The collection was dispersed, but 6 siliquae, Julian II - Magnus Maximus (AD 360-388), were bought by J W Singer, the Frome brass founder, and are now in Somerset County Museum. Taunton Museum supposedly have no record of these coins, but the Ashmolean Museum have a bronze fibula with Roman coins of c. A.D. 390, at Witham, in 1867. A late 4th century hoard."

The hoard comprised 10 individual textile bags of coins, stored in a wooden box. Although only fragments of the textile bags survive, the way the coins have settled and corroded into 10 blocks makes it clear that they were originally stored in this way. The largest of the blocks of coins weighed 68 kilos before cleaning (and 55kg after cleaning) and the assemblage as a whole weighed 340kg after cleaning. It is estimated that the total number of coins in the hoard is 110000. Found during the construction of the new Hôtel de Ville, in the area where the flight of steps up to the building were being constructed. The hoard was deposited (in its entirety?) in the Musée d’Évreux. Several portions of the assemblage have now been lost, but the remainder of the assemblage has been cleaned and conserved, with the exception of a single block of coins which has been preserved in its original state. TAF states that the hoard has now been deposited in the Cabinet des Médailles and a new catalogue is being produced.

In 1911 a container with Roman coins was found by Italian workers during excavation works for the Welzheim railway station. The precise find location could not be determined. The hoard was dispersed, but 277 coins reached the Stuttgart Museum, and 379 coins in a private collection were also documented. In total, 670 coins are listed in FMRD. Coins range from the Late Republic to Severus Alexander. They are mostly denarii, with a few antoniniani and 4 aurei.
disposition: Local museum, Welzheim, Germany; private collection

summary: The hoard comprises 12 provincial bronzes of Augustus found stacked together.
1898 coins: 2 denarii, 1895 antoniniani (radiates), 1 nummus: Valerian I - Tetrarchy I (AD 296-297).
disposition: Musée d'Archéologie de Jura, Lons-le-Saunier, France

summary: 3 Late Roman coins (Constantine I - Constantius II), found in 1914 and now lost.
29 antoniniani (radiates) found buried under the floor and covered with a tegula: Gallienus (sole) - Divus Claudius II (AD 270).

A hoard of ca. 21 coins (15 provincial coins of Antioch, Nerva to Antoninus Pius; imitative SC coinage: 4 coins of Hatra, 2 of Assur?) found in a pot about 1915 at Assur. The exact number of coins was not recorded. Only the imitative SC coinages are described in detail.
disposition: Major Alfred Lühl, officer in the Turkish Army (1915)

summary: A hoard containing, thus far, 121 denarii. The first coins were found in the 1950's, and the rest through excavation and metal detectoring until 2017.
26 bronze coins. Among them, 1 billon coin of Alexandria for Diocletian.
The 22 late Roman and Byzantine gold coins were found in 1897 and 1898 in the field during quarrying, approx. 10 cm under the surface, between 2 flat st1s without trace of the container.
749 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Carinus (AD 284).
96 nummi found in a cave: Constantine I - Theodosius I/Arcadius (AD 388-402).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico, Etnográfico e Histórico Vasco, Bilbao, Spain

summary: The hoard comprised between 150 and 175 bronze coins 'mostly of the Early Empire'. 1 coin bears the effigy of Faustina II
Silver: 1000+ (83) antoniniani/radiates: Philip I - Claudius II (AD 268-270); silver w8: 271.0-1249.0 g.
disposition: Archaeological Museum Zagreb, Croatia (978 coins); dispersed

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 38 denarii were available for study: 2 republican and 36 imperial of Augustus (2 BC - AD 4).
disposition: Fondo Arqueológico Ricardo Marsal Monzón, Spain

summary: The coins were found inside a copper-alloy cauldron with a total w8 of 45kg. However, the hoard was rapidly dispersed, leaving a total of 2421 coins, corresponding to approximately 14% of the original find. This is estimated at 10000 coins.
A potful of Roman silver coins. Only 5 coins have been poorly documented: L. Scribonius Libo, Marcus Aurelius, Faustina I, Faustina II, Commodus.
465 coins: 15 antoniniani, 1 semis, 4 Greek provincial bronzes, 1 Byzantine bronze (intruder), 444 nummi: Marcus Aurelius - Gratian (AD 367-378); silver w8: 8.7-44.5g
30 bronze coins found during a digging near a modern house: Antoninus Pius - Costantius II (AD 355-361).
773 nummi found with a st1 box: Constans - House of Theodosius I (AD 393-395).
A possible scattered hoard of a Clacton type stater and quarter staters, found in the early 1980s. No further information available.

942 coins: 1 aureus (Caracalla) mounted in a necklace, 939 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani: Vespasian to Philip I, and 2 bronze coins (missing today). The hoard comprised gold (600 g) as well and silver jewellery (400 g), a shallow silver dish and a silver salt box.
The hoard comprised over 2 silver coins and an unknown quantity of bronze provincial Judaean coins.
287 nummi, 217 coins studied based on pictures: Gallienus - Theodosius (AD 393-395).
20 antoniniani. No further information .

53 antoniniani (radiates) were found on Hosenstraße 4-5. They were purchased in 1903. "The coin series is so unified that it seems reasonable to accept it as a small hoard; the state of preservation is especially uniform."
The hoard comprised 'half a dozen small bronzes of Diocletian, Maximian I and Constantine,' The hoard was found in a natural fissure in the rock while quarrying limest1 on the îlot de la Dive.
9 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
disposition: Private collection, loan Drents Museum Assen

summary: 50 denarii of the House of Vespasian (AD 69-96).

Unknown originally number of denarii. 5 coins are kept in the History Museum in Bacău: Trajan 1, Antoninus Pius (Faustina I/Diva Faustina I) 1, Marcus Aurelius 2, Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II/Diva Faustina II) 1.

2 radiate minimi (8 and 7 mm, 0.40 and 0.34 g., 1 with head to left, and 1 from dies too big for the flan), found with 'about 7 others' and a coin of Victorinus (Elmer 743, slightly worn) were discovered on the 13th tee of Pyle and Kenfig golf-course, before 1955. There were also some fragments of pottery.
disposition: National Museum of Wales (part); Grosvernor Museum (part)

summary: 1 denarius, 7 radiates, and 63 nummi (Commodus - Valentinian I), probably found in 1890 during construction work for the Busdorfschule. The coins were lost in 1945, but, except for 3, were found again in 1970.
A hoard of 428 denarii dating from Antoninus Pius to Maximinus Thrax (235/236) and 1 Caesarean drachm of Septimius Severus found at Sulakyurt.
disposition: Museum of Anatolian Civilisations, Ankara, Turkez

summary: The hoard comprised a flint nodule containing 10 silver coins attributed to the Eduens. Coutil suggests there was also a coin with the legend ATEVLA/VLATOS but this appears to be an error. The Musée des Antiquités de Rouen possesses at least 1 coin from the hoard (Scheers MGSM no. 168). Another is known from the Collection of A. Le Boucher.
A hoard of uncertain size, of which only 7 coins are known from Postumus (Elmer 131, 314, 335, 565, 566, 593) to Victorinus (Elmer 683).
8 kg of silver coins. 1406 were kept in the Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria, until 1971 when 662 coins were stolen: denarii and antoniniani: Vespasian - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. no. 933

summary: 2 lots of nummi (49, 35). No further information. Unpublished.
453 nummi of the Tetrarchy (AD 307). Part of the Seltz hoard.
disposition: Musée Préhistorique et Gallo-Romain de Strasbourg (453 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 41 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Aurelian and 16 barbarous copies; silver w8 of 12.1-50.3g.

In 1900 the Hanauer museum acquired 44 denarii from an antique dealer in Büdingen, which obviously belonged to a find. The coins were supposedly found in 1899 in Marköbel during the construction of a house. The coins are today no longer present in the Hanauer museum. Coins range from Nero to Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus).

74 coins: 68 denarii and 6 aurei (1 Tiberius (36-37 AD), 1 Nero (65-66 AD), 4 other) from Republican times (122 BC) until Vitellius (69 AD), possibly belonging to the same original hoard as VLOOTBEEK 1904

A hoard of 161 Roman Imperial denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211) was discovered by a treasure hunter in March 2020. Photos of the coins were published on the Violity treasure hunting forum on March 10, 2020. The conditions and circumstances of the find, as well as the fate of the hoard, are unknown.
Grave goods: aurei of Elagabalus, 2 denarii Augustus, 2 drachms Gotarzes.

Building D was a st1-walled rectangular structure with an aisled area & a series of separate rooms, & a bath-suite.Room 21 was in the NE corner, and originally 11 ft long and 14 ft wide, with heavily robbed wals & an op. sig. concrete floor, replaced twice by similar floors. In use with the second of these floors was a large pit 3 ft 16 in. wide, 9 ft long & 1 ft 9 in deep, with sharp sides & a cleanish filling. This may have held some form of tank or container. In final phase of room the pit was filled in & covered with concrete to bring it to level of surrounding floor, & in this concrete was found a small hoard of 5 coins (AD 330-341).Stead, I.M 1976. The Roman villa at Winterton. In I.M. Stead Excavations at Winterton Roman Villa and Other Roman Sites in North Lincolnshire 1958-1967. DoE Archaeol. Reports 9. London: HMSO, pp. 46.
The hoard comprised 1600 coins including an antoninianus (radiate) of Gallienus with a LAETITIA AVG reverse type.

In 1912, during the excavation of a Romano-British homestead at Hambledon Valley, a hoard was found, comprising 294 coins: 8 antoniniani and 287 AE (folles), ranging from Tetricus to Constantine II Caesar. Cathy King has assigned 1 ant. listed above under Tetricus II, to Tetricus I (b.?), and has identified 4 coins of Constantine I as fractions. The total no. of coins of Maximinus is given as 11, that of Constantine I as 207, that of Licinius I as 34, and that of Constantine II as 12.
A hoard of 11+ nummi from the tetrarchy (post-reform), found in a destruction layer of house B in Karanis. Only 11 coins could be identified.

Discovered during agricultural work near the village, on a field belonging to the peasant Grigory Radzevich. The hoard included 21 denarii (Trajan-Commodus) and silver items (ingot and 4 rings). The hoard was sent to the Imperial Archaeological Commission in St. Petersburg, where the coins were identified by J. Iversen; then transferred to the State Hermitage
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia

summary: 358 nummi (2.3 kg) found with a ceramic vessel. All belong to Maxentius (AD 306-312).
4 Roman bronze coins, excavated in shell sand north of the island Süderoog. The find depth was approximately 6 m.
19 nummi of the House of Constantine found in a grave

7 Claudian copper alloy coins said to have been found 'together' in mud from the river Colne at Colchester, possiby in the Sheepen area. No further details of the context are known. The hoard was seen at a coin fair and reported by Kenyon (Crummy 1987, 75).

The discovery of gold jewellery, objects and coinage in the Lava Gulf off the coast of Corsica is reputed to have begun in the 9teenth century after a chance find by a coral fisherman. 41 aurei or multiples of aurei first appeared on the antiquities market in 1956 (35 aurei and 6 multiples) followed by further discoveries in 1971 and in 1985. It is reputed to have included between 400 and 600 aurei and multiples of aurei of Gallienus, Claudius II, Quintillus and Aurelian, jewellery and gold finger rings which were melted down, a gold dish with a medallion of Gallienus at its centre, and possibly a gold statuette.
81 provincial bronze coins discovered in a ceramic vessel: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. 17 096-17 176

summary: A golden ring was found near Bedford by a metal-detector. 2 silver coins (denarii of Titus and Vespasian) may originally have formed part of a small hoard with the ring, though they were somewhat apart at the time of finding.
The hoard comprised 9 aurei found near the 'Caserne' of Autun. The aurei dated from Vespasian to Faustina I, and may be just a small part of a more important hoard.
11 antoniniani of Philip I found in a small ceramic vessel (AD 244-249)
The hoard comprised 20 silver coins from Julia Domna, Julia Mamaea, Gordian III, Philip I, Trajan Decius, Herennia Etruscilla, Volusian, Valerian, Gallienus and Salonina.
2 copper coins (Constantine I and Valentinian I), found in Kelston Manor House, now demolished, in 1676. Probably not a hoard.

The hoard comprised approximately 200 gold aurei dating to the Julio-Claudian period.They were found in association with sherds of pottery suggesting they were originally deposited in a ceramic container. It appears that they were not all catalogued although Ponton d'Amécourt examined a lot of 30 coins. M. Brun found the hoard in an area of hard and resistant ground, while working in his fields.
The hoard comprised approximately 100 shekels of the First Jewish Revolt (AD 66-73) with an engraved gem-seal.
disposition: 24 coins: T. Drake (England); 76 coins: M. Ganneau

summary: 4 staters of VEP CORF found by detectorists from the Shropshire Search Society .
32 silver and provincial bronze coins: 5 antoniniani, 12 denarii, 15 provincial bronzes: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver w8: 26.1-38 g.
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. CXXIX

summary: A hoard of 486 antoniniani, of which at least 467 are imitations of coins of Tetricus I or Tetricus II, Victorinus and Divus Claudius II Gothicus, probably buried AD 290. The hoard was found on a field between Welldorf and Jülich while metal detecting and the surrounding area was then excavated.
The find comprised numerous (1000-2000) copies of radiates of Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
10 bronze coins dating from the end of the 1st c. AD (Trajan?), found in a grave inside Tumulus 3D near Potamoi.
On the site of the Roman theatre, a hoard of 24 sestertii wrapped in cloth was found .
The hoard of 175 gold and silver Iron Age coins, and 23 Roman denarii, ranging from from c. 50 BC to the latter half of the second century AD, uncovered on a field at Waltham St. Lawrence.
Report ca. 20 of Iron Age silver coins found in the 1840's, at Tollard Royal. 1 of them is probably is probably SCBI 24, no. 909, in Salisbury Museum.

The hoard comprised 20 asses ending in issues of Claudius I and has been interpreted as he con10ts of a purse. Found during excavations, in a quarter to the north of the antique settlement. Found in tomb 1, a cremation burial. 20 asses, Tiberius to Claudius I; 13 coins corroded by fire.
disposition: Service des bâtiments, monuments et archéologie, Martigny/Sion

summary: A hoard containing nearly 100 silver denarii from the period of Trajan and Hadrian was unearthed between Trostadt and Siegritz.

A hoard of 'some 700 Roman copper coins' of the time of Constantine I, said to have been found in a box during building work, excavating the the site of a new hotel in Tavistock Square, Bloomsbury. 667 were listed by H. Mattingly, with rulers and mints. It is said that the hoard included also a base denarius of Lucius Verus, and a billon antoninus of Claudius II (JRS, XIV (1924), 229f.).
The hoard was found in a burial and comprised 8 coins of Balbinus and other contemporary emperors and a small gold chain with double pendant.
27 denarii: Vespasian for Titus (Caesar) - Septimius Severus (AD 205).
disposition: scattered in post pole - interpreted as save hoard, not ritual construction votive

summary: Hoard of 14 gold stateri of the Bosporan kings, Sauromates II (4) and Rhescuporis III (10) (AD 225).
380 nummi: Quintillus - Gratian (AD 367-383).
301 antoniniani (radiates): Postumus - Probus (AD 276-282).
4 denarii: Vitellius, Nerva, Trajan, Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) (AD 141-160).
15 sestertii found in a grave with ceramic objects: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
'The coins lay next to 1 another on the southern exterior of the perimeter under the wall terrace of the pillar temple. They apparently form a small hoard.'

Deposit of 3 clipped siliquae. An important number of clavi caligarii, i.e. iron hobnails, were also found in their immediate vicinity. This discovery is probably the first material evidence in a military context of the famous invasion of Hispania by the usurper ‘Constantinus III’.

1500 bronze coins (“oboli”) - nummi. “The Roman coins range from Diocletianus to Theodosius II, and there were also 18 Naimana imitations. This list is confused however by Codrington’s final sen10ce: “Some of these came from Mr. Trefusis’ fi nd on Shakerley estate”. Pearson, relying on the observation that the busts (in how many cases?) on the coins were facing the wrong direction (i. e. the left), declared all these coins to be imitations.”

It comprised 48 Kg of coins, in 3 earthen pots. The hoard was divided in several lots including 1 of 758 coins for P. Chenu. After some studies, this lot comprised 795 coins, from Valerian I to Diocletian (AD 284-305).
+3000 nummi: Tetrarchy - Constantine II (AD 337-340).
Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel (amphora?). 38 denarii were avalable for study: Antoninus Pius (Faustina I Diva) - Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
15 nummi: House of Constantine I (AD 306-361).
3 solidi recovered after a flood. 1 of Theodosius II minted in Constantinople (AD 430-440).
In a grave 8 nummi were found: Valentinian I 4, Valens 4 (AD 364-378)

The hoard comprised 19 amphorae filled with approximately 600 kg 53000 coins) of early 4th century nummi with the majority apparently coming from eastern mints. The coins were not worn and the amphorae appear to have been made specifically to accommodate the coins. At the moment, "The 5899 pieces that were analyzed were minted under the emperors Diocletian, Maximian, Constantius, Galerius, Constantine, Severus, Maximinus, Licinius and Maxentius. They came from the mints of Rome, Carthage, Aquileia, Treveri, Ticinum, Lugdunum, Londinium, Siscia and Ostia. A smaller number of coins came from Alexandria, Cyzicus, Thessaloniki, Heraklea, Nicomedia and Antiochi. The emperor whose name appears on the highest number of coins is Diocletian, and the mint, Carthage."
disposition: Provincial Archaeology Museum of Seville, Spain

summary: 31 coins: 1 antoninianus, 30 nummi: Gallienus - Valens (AD 367-378).
29 denarii: 28 republican, 1 imperial: Republic - Augustus (15-13 BC).
disposition: Collection unknown. About three quarters of the treasure was already melted down in 1870 by a goldsmith in Nordhorn.

summary: Hoard of 651 coins found in several ceramic vessels and a textile cloth. 570 coins were studied: 16 denarii, 96 antoniniani (radiates), 458 bronzes: Galba - Postumus (AD 263); silver w8: 134.0-1792.9g. 1 of the Postumus double sestertius is overstruck on a Marcus Aurelius sestertius of the type VICTORIAE AVG S C.

A hoard of 15 provincial (mainly Athens, period IVD, VB, VB/C, VC) and 42 sestertii (Trajan - Trajan Decius), with possibly 1 antoninianus of Gallienus (though this might be an intruder), found on the floor of the "Room of the 2 Marble Busts" in a large burnt house on the lower slopes of the Hill of the Nymphs. Since the coins lay within a small area directly on the floor it may be assumed that they fell from a purse or a m1y box dropped in the confusion that must have at10ded the burning of the house.
The hoard was found in a broken ceramic vessel and comprised at least 1183 radiates from Gordian III to Saloninus with a tpq. of AD 260.
Unknown initial number of coins. 91 denarii in the Regional History Museum in Pleven: Otho - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv.no. 975 1-70

summary: A hoard of 840 4th century coins down to c. 355, found while digging trenches for drains. All but 6 coins post-date the reform of AD 348.
56 denarii found on a field with shreds from the container ceramic vessel: Republic - Augustus (29-27 BC).

74 coins found with a Roman bronze jug: Vespasian - Valerian I (AD 256-257). Together were found: an Almgren 157 fibula, 5 bracelets, a pendant and 2 silver ingots on silver. The discovery has been interpreted as a silver craftsman hoard.
disposition: Muzeul Județean de Istorie și Arheologie Prahova, ploiești, Romania (inv.nos. 72696-72766)

summary: 2 solidi of Theodosius II (AD 430-440), 1 is pierced; gold w8: 8.9 g.
79 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 202-210). "Only 18 coins were found at first, the remainder being recovered when an excavation of the site was carried out the following month."
1310 silver coins: Antoninus Pius - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-259) coins; silver w8: 1496-3124.7 g.

2 wooden caskets (wooden has vanished) comprising coins and jewelry were found at 50 cm 1 from the other in a pithos pit in the citadel of Artezia. Inside the casket were 99 Bosporan bronze coins, which had most probably initially been placed in a small purse made of cloth or leather. The coins were thoroughly arranged in rouleaus. In the casket, there was also a large gold ring with which a small pile of 9 silver Roman denarii had fused. Under the ring in the cluster of coins, an iron knife had been found with a bronze ring, which had stuck to its blade when oxidization had taken place. Further finds had been 7 small trilobate iron-tanged arrowheads and 1 bronze bilobate socketed arrowhead dating from the Hellenistic period. Several bronze bracelets were found in the casket, made from thin wire which had collapsed in pieces; an elegant bronze ring; a spring-clasp earring made of poor-quality silver; 2 curved bronze strap buckles with a protruding tongue; a curved strap fas10er with 2 rivets on a rectangular plate, a small bronze ring, a silver buckle, bronze pincers, the fragmentary remains of a bow-shaped fibula with a broad back-plate and a fragment of a thin-walled convex plaque made of bronze. On the bottom of the casket between the coins and the jewelry items there lay on its side a figured 2-sided glass unguentarium. On top of the coins and jewelry there lay 2 large hollow silver anklets, and inside these, there was a necklace made of large eye-beads, an astragal, a large b1 pendant-cum-talisman triangular in shape, and also a small bronze amulet made of 2 pipes soldered together, which collapsed in part when it was being cleaned. On the casket, 2 small 1-handled jugs made from blue and white and greenish-yellow transparent glass had been standing in situ. While the hoard was being cleaned fragments of another glass vessel had also been found and 2 narrow-necked thin-walled unguentaria as well.

Around 100 gold coins of Constantine I/Constantius II and the House of Valentinian were found in the river Moselle. In the Moselle Towards the end of April 1958, having taken gravel from the bed of the Moselle between Ahn and Machtum, a dredger belonging to the company Hein de Machtum, brought in his load many currencies of Roman gold. They are pieces of: 321 1/2, 1 and 1/2 solidi, struck almost exclusively by the effigies of the emperors Valentinian I, Valens and Gratian, and preserved at the corner of the coin. The coins were discovered scattered in the gravel, especially on the site of the aforementi1d company located at the place called "Kommert" near Machtum and the depot of the Bridges and Chaussees located at a place called "Banzelt" near Roodt / Syr , where a truck had deposited 2 loads of this "enriched" gravel. Several pieces, especially the multiples, had more or less suffered from their passage through the crusher. No trace of a vessel was found, nor any piece of silver or bronze. It is impossible to estimate accurately the number of pieces found, but the information available to us suggests that it must have been more than a hundred. Coins entered private collections or were sold abroad. 2 pieces were acquired by the Cabinet of Medals of the Museum of History and Art, Luxbg. (Nos 24 and 29). The absence in this treasure of the coinage of Valentinian II, raised to the rank of Auguste on November 22, 375, and associated with his half-brother Gratien in the government of the western part of the empire, is explained by the fact by Pearce, that Valentinian II does not take part in the first emulation of the period 375-378, of which date the most recent pieces of the treasure. Among the solidi and multiples are several unpublished pieces and some minor variations. This treasure, flowing with a ship from Treves, represents, in our opinion, some of the donativa lavished by Gratien on the occasion of the sumptuous fetes celebrated during his decennalia (376/377).
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg; inv.no. 1993-200; private collection

summary: The hoard comprised 1 bronze vessel containing 7150 radiates from Tetricus I, Tetricus II, Valerian, Gallienus, Claudius Gothicus, Aurelianus and Probus. It must be linked to the treasure LA VINEUSE II
Group of 3 coins: Domitian denarius, Trajan denarius, Hadrian sestertius (AD 117-138).

Allegedly 70000 to 80000 Roman and Naimana bronze coins found in earthenware vessels. Doubtful. Confirmation required. An Indian Kunindas bronze coin (100 BC - AD 80) and a Victorian 1/4 Farthing (1868) may be regarded as intruders.
disposition: Archaeological Department in Colombo, Sri Lanka; private collections

summary: 7 denarii (Antoninus Pius to Septimius Severus) were unearthed in 1815 behind the Bergmühle. The coins are now lost.
15 kg of silver coins, 12 gold coins and 2 gold bracelets. No further information.
51 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I and II (AD 271-274).
Hoard of over 5000 antoniniani (radiates) and imitations: Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).

The hoard comprised a glass bottle containining more than 146 denarii from Nero to Elagabalus. The glass bottle, which acted as the container for the hoard, is preserved by the Musée de Mans (Inv. V. 62)
320 Roman coins. No further information.
9 denarii and 2 aes (Mark Antony to Antoninus Pius) found in Room 28.
25 provincial bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 244-249).
The hoard comprised 7 coins from the fifth century AD.
Unknown number of denarii and antoniniani. 11 pieces entered the museum collection in Shumen: Commodus 1, Severus Alexander 1, Gordian III 6, Philip I 2, Gallienus 1.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 13715-13725 (11 coins)

summary: 5 denarii found during survey in small area. Interpreted as small disturbed hoard.
The hoard comprised 57 dupondii and asses from Augustus to Antoninus Pius with a tpq of AD 150 to 151.
2 Dobunnic staters found early in 2006.
2 Iron Age coins found together.
Between 30 and 50000 nummi from Constantine I to Constantine II (AD 340). The dive teams identified 2 sets of coins in a large sandy area. They are in exceptional condition, only 4 are damaged.
disposition: Superintendency of Archaeology, Fine Arts & Landscape (SABAP), Sardinia’s Cultural Heritage Protection Unit

summary: c. 80 kg; 12000 nummi of the Tetrarchy. 5032 nummi are kept in the coin room of the National Museum of Slovenia in Ljubljana. 448 coins were presented in a catalogue by A. Jelocnik: Aurelian - Tetrarchy/Maxentius (AD 310).
disposition: Narodni muzej, Numizmatični cabinet, Ljubljana, Slovenia; 5,032 coins; the rest was sold in Trieste, Italy.

summary: Hoard of 300-400 denarii. Only 2 coins are documented: Trajan, Antoninus Pius.
A Regensburg employee submitted 8 sestertii (Antoninus Pius to Commodus) to the prehistorical state collection. The coins were derived from a find of unknown size in Regensburg.

Gold hoard of aurei, solidi and multiple of solidi: Tetrarchy - Constantius II-Magnentius (AD 353). The hoard, which according to some sources contained around 70-80 coins and a large amount of gold jewellery, was embezzled by the finders immediately after its discovery, divided and scattered in the trade.6 AV mults. assumed to be 2x; 32 AV sol. tpq c.353 Gold: 6, 32 coins; Gold w8: c.195.8g+;
13 denarii found in a mound next to ceramic vessels: Antoninus Pius - Commodus(AD 180).
disposition: Frisian Museum, Leeuwarden (FML A 1129-1141), 2 coins lost.

summary: The hoard comprised a small red ceramic vessel with a lid containing approximately 150 coins of the second and third century AD. It was probably a hoard of denarii and antoniniani (radiates).
2 Roman gold coins (Augustus) were found in the Venner Moor. A third specimen was found in the region of Venne and could well belong to the same find.
'The coins were dug up close to 1 another in 1936 during a follow-up investigation on the outer terrain h8 of the pillar temple. They appear to originally belong together.'

A hoard of 480 Icenian gold and silver coins and Roman denarii found near the middle of the Roman Field on the eastern outskirts of the 4th-century settlement in 1959. The pot is a butt beaker with a pedestal base, 8¼ in. high. Externally and internally the colour is a sandy brown with a dark fabric. Horizontal grooves frame faint vertical combings between these lines. This form is frequently found at Colchester and is regarded as pre-invasion in date.
344 Iron Age silver coins found in a ceramic vessel. The initial find was made in 1954.
Unknown initial number of coins. 815 silver coins found with a metal bucket: Julia Domna to Philip I; silver w8: 1019.3-2117.9g
disposition: National History of Antiquities Bucharest, Romania (815 coins) - 1886

summary: (3000) 2873 denarii and antoniniani: Nero - Philip I (AD 244-249)
disposition: Magyar Nemzeti Múzeum, Budapest, Hungary (6 coins), in 1865

summary: This find of 5 nummi may represent a dispersed hoard or possibly a purse drop. Found on the bed of the River Seine during dredging. All type of BEATA TRANQVILLITAS VOT XX. Mints of Londinium and Treveri.
Around 500 antoniniani (radiates). Only 96 coins were described: Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

The 1970 Sardes Hoard (420 coins) was found southeast of the entrance to the Synagogue in 1970. Most of these coins are dated to the 4th and fifth centuries AD. The coins had not been sealed by a container, so some of the coins listed here probably do not belong to the original hoard (see Buttrey et al., p. 123).
15 minima found in der Witz, close to the Promenadenweg.
100 silver coins were discovered. 24 have been seen: 9 antoniniani, 15 denarii: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 244-249).
368 aurei: Nero to Marcus Aurelius (AD 166).

Assemblage of 25 copper alloy coins from the Ancaster area donated to the British Museum by the finder in 2008. The group could be considered to be a hoard, containing Magnentian coins that have been cut to make smaller coins and contemporary copies of FEL TEMP fallen horseman type. However the group includes a cut Valentinianic coin and a possible Theodosian coin. Given the lack of contextual information available it is difficult to say which of these coins constitute a hoard.
9 solidi: Honorius - Valentinian III (AD 426-455); gold w8: 40.05g.

The hoard comprising a large earthenware vessel covered with a tile containing between 40 and 80kg of silver and billon coinage (denarii and radiates). A catalogue of 4084 coins was given to J. de Witte by the owner. A portion of the assemblage belonging to the finder was sold. ; Silver w8: 737.8-11636.9g.
The hoard comprised 31 sestertii, stacked 1 on top of the other, suggesting that they may have originally been packed in a tube or similar which has not survived: Nerva - Commodus (AD 189).
38 bronze coins: 1 sestertius, 37 nummi: Antoninus Pius - Magnus Maximus (AD 383-388).
disposition: ROB, Amersfoort > Historical and Archaeological Foundation (H.A.S.)ROB, Amersfoort

summary: The hoard comprised a black ceramic vessel with a lid containing between 1800 and 2000 radiates. No further information about the composition of the hoard was given.
Around 100 siliquae spread among locals. Only 1 coin of Constantius II minted in Constantinople (AD 351-355) was documented.
7 denarii found through several rounds of detecting.
The hoard comprised 35 aurei from Tiberius to Claudius, including commemorative issues for Drusus the Elder and Antonia.

In 1962 on Zehnthofstraße a pot with handles was found in a water conduit trench, whose con10ts consisted of approx. 700 solidi and siliqua coins, ranging from Julian I to Constantine III.
