The hoard comprised also 14 objects: a brooch, a ring, metal fittings and buckles of a sheath, and some hack-silver. The analysis of the small finds shows that their owner came from far in the east and might have been a Hun. Huns were recruited around 383, after the defeat of Eugenius the Usurper, and were stati1d on the Rhine
11 Republican denarii and 6 Imperial denarii (Augustus and Vespasian) found in regio VI, insula 2, building 4 (house).

Excavations in advance of A435 Norton Lenchwick bypass, now part of A46. In Area C3, rectangular st1 Building i was aligned E-W & 15 x 7m in size, with clay bonded walls with loosely dressed faces. Inside Building i there was a large deep cess pit 329, into which st1 slab floor partly subsided, but it was not clear if this was from an early phase of building, or a phase pre-dating it. There was a soil-filled hollow to E. To S was Building j, of aisled posthole construction & timber form, at least 16 x 6m in size, with a central drain gullly. These 2 structures may have been agric. buildings assoc. with a larger complex - Building j could have been a byre. During excav., however, controlled metal detecting & archaeol. recording around the 2 buildings plotted concs. of coins & brooches, with a particular focus on the NE corner of Building i, but also with groups to the N 7 SE; & to the E of Building j. The coins & brooches were sometimes individual but also in groups of c. 10-16 coins, which in several cases were spatially close to brooch finds. The coins & brooches were sometimes in soil layers, sometimes in very shallow 'scoops' in underlying natural subsoil. Some brooches were broken, others complete; & between Buildings i & j were 2 human skull frags.Mays, M. 2000. Roman coins. In S.C. Palmer Archaeological Excavations in the Arrow Valley, Warwickshire. Birmingham & Warwickshire Archaeol. Soc/ Highways Agency, pp. 84-87, 126-134.
25 silver coins, 5 recovered: Septimius Severus Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver w8: 7.1-9.3 g.
764 denarii: Republic - Trajan (AD 103-111). Together were found 4 silver earrings and 3 silver bracelets found in a ceramic vessel.
disposition: Regional History Museum Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos M II 3331-4094 (764 coins)

summary: 129 bronze coins (120 Dium, 4 koinon of Thessaly, 2 Thessalonica, 1 koinon of Macedonia, 1 Ilium and 1 uncertain), ranging from Claudius to Antoninus Pius, found in the foundation level besides the west wall of the first (western) room excavated at the place of the former sanctuary of Zeus Olympios, next to 2 other hoards (Dion 1998 and Dion 1999). All 3 hoards were buried in clay vases. The exact function of the area where the hoards were found is unclear, but the hellenistic sanctuary of Zeus Olympios had been transformed in Roman times, the wall of the temenos built over, and a theatre established.
The hoard was discovered near the village in 2011. Consisted of 13 denarii (Trajan-Pertinax). The circumstances of the find and the place of the coins storage are unknown.
12 denarii: Republic – Marcus Aurelius (Commodus Augustus) (AD 178). Some doubts have been expressed as the coins are now in a private collection.

A small hoard of 9 coins of Faustina II to Gallienus (sole reign), found at base of st1-lined pit at SE corner of ambulatory wall of later octagonal temple (building VI).5 of the coins could not be identified but were "not later than AD 270" (Wedlake 1982, 45). Denominations not given and the coins cannot be identified in the listing from the site. I have assumed them to be copper alloy. They are given as Faustina II (1), Gordian III (1), Gallienus (sole reign) (2) and unidentifed "up to AD 270" (5).
The deposit was found at the major Gallo-Roman spring sanctuary site at comprised 3 asses from Hadrian to Marcus Aurelius with a tpq of AD 164.
10 antoniniani (radiates) found during excavations at Arykanda on a floor from a house: Gordian - Trajan Decius (Herennius Etruscus Caesar). 'Possibly con10ts of a purse.'
A small hoard of 10 uninscribed south-western staters, found during a rally of the Vectis Searchers metal-detecting club.

In 1835, 3 vessels containing human b1 were found in a field. 1 of the vessels was broken. The 2 smaller vessels contained 18 coins of Tiberius and 1 of Claudius. The division of the coins between the 2 vessels is not clear.
17 denarii: Titus - Hadrian (AD 117).
1726 coins found in a bronze vessel: 3 denarii, 1723 antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Diocletian/Maximian I (AD 293-294); w8: 5650 kilos.
disposition: Musée d'Archéologie de Jura, Lons-le-Saunier, France

summary: A hoard of 23 copper coins, all of which appear to be Assur Class 3 (SC imitative coinage, blank obverse and inverted SC on reverse). Only 2 coins are preserved today, but the other were photographed. They were found on the floor of House Y (north of the palace) and could have constituted a purse at the moment of the Sasanian conquest.
14 nummi from the Tetrarchy (Diocletian to Constantius I), found in Mainz-Bretzenheim between 1910 and 1923.
(700-800) denarii and antoniniani. 251 coins are kept in the museum in Isperih: Galba - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-268).
4 aurei of Vespasian (AD 71-79). Found in the praetorium/principia of the auxiliary fort.
5 coins consisting in an imitation of Alexander's III, 3 denarii of Augustus, 1 drachm of 'Gotarzes II' found in a grave

A hoard of 94 denarii, ranging from Antoninus Pius to Severus Alexander, found at the Roman fort Vetoniana, inside the enclosure wall of the temple Jupiter Dolichenus. The hoard included objects as well.
1504 almost exclusively nummi. 1476 nummi, 4 Naimana imitations, 1 Sapur II, and 85 fragments: Constantine I - Marcian (AD 450-457).
disposition: Archaeological Department, Colombo, on 14th October 1975 (Inv: Arch. Dept. 75/12)

summary: The hoard was found in Grave 1720 in the south-western cemetery and comprised a single third century radiate and 190 nummi of the House of Constantine and House of Valentinian with a tpq of AD 367 to 378.
A hoard of 343 barbaric antoninianii (Gallienus - Carus, incl. Tetricus) and an unstruck flan were found in the substructure of a bathhouse of a villa rustica (HA 206).
253 bronze coins: 252 sestertii, 1 dupondius: Vespasian - Severus alexander (AD 222-235).

On Friday, August 3, some workmen digging in a chalk-pit, at Paulsgrove, on Portsdown Hill, found a skeleton in the chalk, in the left hand of which were 20-2 Roman third brass coins. Many of the coins were too corroded to be legible. They were all third brass, and some were of the reigns of Valens and Valentinianus. 1, very small, was of Theodosius.
HER record of 30 to 40 denarii from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius found in the mid 1970s following dredging of the Little Ouse and not apparently recorded elsewhere.

A Roman coin hoard was found in the field of a sexton containing more than 100 silver and copper coins, with most of the silver coins made of bad alloy. The sources mention coins of Severus Alexander, Gordian III, Gallienus, Salonina, Aurelian and Probus. 4 coins are listed in FMRD, of which a description exists. It can be assumed that the hoard comprised mostly antoniniani of the middle of the third century AD and was buried between 276 and 284 A.D.
ca. 80 sestertii and dupondii, but not all of them are identified: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 572 worn sestertii of the second century to Gordian III.
8 aurei, all found "within a few meters of each other, indicating a coin purse was likely dropped to the ground in the course of fighting, or in10tionally hidden."
2 (or more?) solidi (Constantius II, Magnetius), found on a potato field. The coins are lost.
Possibble hoard of unknown number of silver and bronze coins found within a cemetery. The only preserved coins are 2 denarii of Hadrian and Antoninus Pius.
disposition: Coin Room, National History Museum of Latvia, Riga (inv.nos. LNVM NUM - CVVM 120210: 1-2

summary: The hoard comprised 15 nummi dated between AD 355-360 and AD 450-550.
28 bronze coins: Severus Alexander - Valens found in a room. Uncertain whether all belong to a hoard or there are also single finds included.
disposition: Museo Arqueológico y de Historia de Elche, Portugal

summary: Hoard of 12-15 kilos of coins - 5500 pieces - found with a ceramic vessel. Only 270 were recovered: Trebonianus Gallus (Volusian Augustus) - Cludius II (AD 268-270).
A series of finds, probably representing 2 hoards predominantly of uninscribed East Anglian Iron Age gold coins. N.B. create 2 entries?
In 1854, 300 antoniniani (radiates) and nummi were discovered, probably within the bath-house at Divonne-les-Bains. TAF interprets the assemblage as a votive deposit.

105 antoniniani (radiates) were catalogued. The catalogue does not specify whether the radiates of Gallienus were of his sole or joint reign: Philip I for Otacilia Severa (Augusta) - Quintillus for Claudius II (Divus).
14 copper coins, reported as dated between possibly 69 and 117 AD, but inter alia Vespasian, Domitian, Hadrian, so 69-138 in any case.
Unknown original number of denarii, some information is known for 5 pieces: Antoninus Pius 3, Marcus Aurelius, Julia Domna (AD 193-211).
60 antoniniani of Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver w8: 75 g.
55 denarii found with a ceramic jar: Galba - Commodus (AD 189). Found 1 meter from STARYIE VALKY 2013 2, practically, 1 hoard.

Apparently, 17 solidi were found by chance together with other artefacts that may suggest a jewellery box a "small" necklace; a copper key; 3 gold bracelets, 7teen gold coins; a thin copper plate "with a name"; a gold ring. Only 3 coins minted in Ravenna were available for study at the time of discovery: Honorius 2, Valentinian III (AD 426-430).
Unknown initial number number of coins. T. Gerasimov mentions 12 silver coins: 3 denarii, 9 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251). Found in a ceramic vessel
The hoard comprised approximately 100 'small bronzes' - 'radiates' of Gallienus, Claudius II, Victorinus, Tetricus I and Tetricus II The hoard was found in the Reverchon quarry
7 nummi found in a wooden box in a cave with other artefacts: Constantius II (AD 337-361).
Circa 100 Roman coins, silver and bronze. Only, 2 denarii of Antoninus Pius and Faustina I and 5 bronze coins (Vespasian to Trajan) were known.

A group of 8 coins (Marcus Aurelius - Licinius I), found between Rummelsburg and Boxhagen, east of the Lich10berger Kietz, in a small 'urn'. The coins were lost and the list of coins looks suspicious.

The hoard comprised 67 Provincial coins mostly from local mints (Thessalonica, Macedonian Koinon) of the time of Gordian III, found in a Roman farmhouse located in a field southeast of the provincial road, west of Afytos.
63 coins: 9 denarii, 54 antoniniani: Marcus Aurelius - Trajan Decius (AD 251). Found in the baths.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Kyustendil, Bulgaria; inv. no. 743-782

summary: 21 coins coming from a donation: 20 antoniniani (radiates), 1 sestertius Gallienus (sole) - Diocletian. The sestertius of Antoninus Pius for Marcus Aurelius (Caesar), most likely, and intruder.
disposition: Museo Interdisciplinare Reg. di Messina: Fondo Naz. 866-887

summary: 14 denarii of Augustus minted in Lugdunum, all of type RIC 207 (2 BC - AD 4).
A hoard of 10 republican denarii. According to the finder, they all have the name PANSA inscribed.
72 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel: Augustus - Didius Julianus (AD 193).

25000 Roman coins. Doubtful. Confirmation required. This hoard is only known from personal information given by Bopearachchi to Weerakkody. No further mention of this find has been made since, not even in Bopearachchi’s publications during the 10 years up to 1996. In 1999, nothing was known about this hoard at the Archaeological Department, Colombo. In 1989, there had been some rumors that a pot full of coins had been found at Pidurangala about 10 years before, around 1979, but that nobody had ever seen these coins. It was argued that they had been dispersed immediately after discovery.
55 coins: 4 gold medallions, 5 aurei and 46 silver coins: Only 17 coins are studied: 4 medallions, 5 aurei, 8 argentei: Numerianus - Constantius I (AD 294).
disposition: National Hungarian Museum (Inv.no. 104.1885 - gold pieces only), Budapest, Hungary; private collections F. Trau (Vienna) and A. Bachofen von Echt (Nussdorf, Vienna)

summary: 153 nummi found in a fire layer: Constans - House of Theodosius I (AD 383-435).
disposition: Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Adria, Italy

summary: Amongst 76 coins found in the Musée d'Ernée with the label 'Jublain 1937', are 14 which appear to represent a hoard.

11 coins found over 3 private searches; 1 in 2009, 4 in 2011 and 6 in 2012 (described as "being stacked"). The 11 coins are dated from Nerva to Antoninus Pius. It is not certain that all 11 coins are part of a hoard, but it is likely as they have been found within a small geographical area.
A hoard of 2 solidi of the emperor Valens (364-378), found by a metal detectorist on agricultural land in the municipality of Buren (province of Gelderland).

find_spot_name: ROSE LANE SITE E XXI, A (1) HOARD 2
summary: Rose Lane Site E XXI, A (1) Hoard 2. 19 coins from Constantine II to House of Theodosius, also incl. 2 radiates. Deposit AD 388-420

The hoard comprised 1 denarius (Diva Faustina I) and 8-9 aes coins ranging fro Hadrian to Faustina II. They were recovered during the excavation of a inhumation burial (tomb 1/1965) in the necropolis and were interpreted as the con10ts of a purse. Only 5 coins are preserved today, but descriptions of the other 1s exist.
disposition: Ufficio dei beni culturali, Bellinzona (5 coins); lost (4-5 coins)

summary: IARCH record for scattered hoard of radiates (for full details see DOR-5D3543). Another hoard was previously found on the same field in 2013 (2013 T221 'Holt') with an addenda found in 2014 (2014 T962).
A hoard of 30 AE coins of Apamea, Cremna, Sagalassos, Aspendos, Perge and Galatia dating from the mid / late first century BC.

3432 late Roman bronze coins - nummi - ranging in date from Constantine I to Marcian. Of these only 342 were deemed in a suitable condition to be recorded in the museum inventory. The w8 of each coin in this sample varies between 1- 2.5g, with the majority being around 2g.
disposition: Museum of Anatolian Civilizations, Ankara, Turkey

summary: The hoard comprised 36 coins including 33 sestertii (1 subferratus) and 3 dupondii terminating with issues of AD 191-192. All coins are worn, so this is most probably a 3rd c. deposition.
11 antoniniani (Gallienus - Divus Claudius, AD 270) found on the southwestern slope of the Sommerberg directly above Furtwangen.
Hoard of circa 2000 nummi (5 kilos). Some of the coins are from the Time of Constantine I and his sons up to Valentinian I and Valens (AD 364-378).
112 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195).

A hoard of 197 denarii (Mark Antony to Trajan), found in a 'rude earthen vessel', while ploughing a field in 1874 near Lavenham Lodge. Of these, 184 were examined and 183 published, the others were dispersed.
31 billon tetradrachms of Alexandria: Valerian I and Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 272-273) found in a pottery jar during excavations beneath the floor in room of a house.
The hoard comprised approximately 200 silver coins, only for 97 of them were known the issuers: Antoninus Pius to Maximinus Thrax (AD 235-238).
17 denarii, 11 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 sestertius (separated): Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
81 nummi entered in the collection Traun without any certainty that they were found as a hoard: Constantius - Gratian (AD 367-378).

44 Antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Gallienus (sole) 2, Claudius II 44. Together with coin was found a male bronze statuette of 75 cm h8. Some doubts have been expressed about this discovery!
disposition: Coin Room, National History Museum of Latvia, Riga (inv.nos. LNVM NUM - CVVM 120193: 1-27; A 8173). 17 coins were lost during the period of the WWII

summary: Over 1054 coins were found, most of them oxidized together. Only 120 have been recorded to the level of the coin. Some 12 coins may have been lost (loose from the bulk of the hoard). Silver: 1054 (1, 127) coins; Silver w8: 285.7-2505.4g.
14 uncertain denominations: Republic - Philip I (AD 244-249).
The hoard comprised a large ceramic vessel containing 14 first and second century AD coins.
3 coins published in BNJ 57 (1987), pl. 1.16-18, presumably forming a small hoard.
Around 2000 denarii found on the surface after the river outflow. Only 8 denarii were known: Trajan 2, Hadrian 1, Faustina I 3, Commodus 2.
Hoard of 50 denarii. Only 8 pieces are documented: Antoninus Pius 3, Marcus Aurelius (Antoninus Pius Divus), Commodus 4.
disposition: National Museum of History, Moscow, Russia (inv.nos. 14863, 14865-14869)

summary: (+485) 472 silver coins: 106 denarii, 366 Septimius Severus - Gallienus with a tpq of AD 257/258. The coins were minted at Antioch (5 coins), Milan, Rome and Viminacium but data concerning the number of coins from each mint was not recorded. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of 598g to 1241.7g. The coins were accompanied by 8 pieces of jewellery: a tubulus, part of a chain; a conical tubulus, part of a chain; the fragment of a bracelet; a fragment of a bracelet; 3 parts of the coil of a bracelet; a piece of semi-circular sheet-metal, part of a chain.

A hoard of about 160 Roman imperial denarii was discovered by a treasure hunter in the late 2010s. The finder reported to me that the coins were found within a settlement of the Chernyakhiv culture. No other additional information about the circumstances of the find or the composition of the hoard.
Unknown number of coins. 63 antoniniani were seen: Aurelian - Probus (AD 276-282).

(1213) 1209 silver coins: 10 denarii, 1199 antoniniani: Caracalla - Gallienus (AD 259-268); silver w8: 1752.4-2218.6 g. The hoard was foun within the ruins of a Roman building placed in a bronze vessel
disposition: Muzeul Na'ional al Unirii Alba Iulia, Romania

summary: A small hoard (?) of 13 denarii flati (prototypes: denarii from Hadrian to Commodus) was discovered by a treasure hunter in February 2017, probably in Khmelnytskyi region. Information about the “purse of limes coins” and their common photo was published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity on February 17, 2017. The circumstances of the find are unknown. Perhaps, the author could interpret the remains of a denarii flati workshop as a “purse”. At the end of February 2017, the coins were sold at the auction Violity.
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 8 silver coins are known: 5 antoniniani (radiates), 3 denarii: Caracalla – Gallienus (sole).

A hoard of 292 siliquae of the second half of the 4th century AD was discovered in a field of Highfield Farm, Osbournby, Lincs, with the aid of a metal detector, on various occasions in 1979 and 1980. The hoard contained 33 clipped coins and 3 contemporary imitations. R. Bland, in CHRB VII, catalogued a further 20 coins (1 mil., 19 sil.) found in November 1983. To this, 1 needs to add a further addenda of 1 siliqua of Julian II (2009).

The finders show to Abbe Moreau c. 6700 antoniniani (radiates). The workers discovered the hoard in 3 vessels and shared the coins. V. Huguenot studied few coins of this hoard, from Antoninus Pius (probably Elagabalus) to Postumus (AD 260-269).
Hoard of 493 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel: 492 antoniniani (radiates), 1 denarius: Septimius Severus (Caracalla Augustus) - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver w8: 134.9-1281.3 g.
At least 3 gold coins were found, digging a ditch close to the shore at Heene.

Several Cheriton (British D) staters and a quarter stater type (BMC 568) were found by members of the Bedhampton Historical Research Group near Compton Down. They seem likely to have originated in a single deposit.

A hoard of 15 coins, found in a grave (grave 4) during the excavations at Pylos, in Volimidia, north of Chora. It has been described as 13 sestertii and 2 antoniniani, though Vlachogianni and Tourastoglou give a slightly different account of the emperors represented (see under References).
101 coins: 21 denarii, 74 antoniniani, 6 provincial bronzes: Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2780

summary: 355 nummi found with an amphora, during the archaeological excavations in sector 6D: Constantine I - Gratian (AD 367-375).
8 nummi: Theodosius I - Honorius (AD 383-423).

The hoard comprised 1 silver coin and 18 bronze coins dating from the 3rd c. AD, found close to Metsovo (BCH 1939). Touratsoglou mentions 18 sestertii (Maximinus Thrax - Gordian III), next to 1 denarius / antoninianus, with the find spot Anthochori. No further information available.

The hoard comprised 62 antoniniani (radiates) from Gallienus to the Tetrarchy with a tpq of AD 302 or 303. The mint distribution is given but not related to the individual issues. Hobbs estimates a silver w8 of between 12.5g and 42.4g
16 coins: 4 republican denarii, 12 asses: Republic - Augustus (15 BC).
The hoard comprised 28 nummi dated between AD 341 and AD 395.

A hoard of 25 solidi (Constantius II - Valens) from Ellerbek was discovered in 1933 by the landowner in a sand pit, on the north side of the river Hase. The finder uncovered a cylindrical bronze can with a hole 2mm in size. The find was purchased by the state museum of Hannover.

The hoard comprised 100 coins 'une centaine'. Gricourt only saw 3 coins from the find. They were antoniniani (radiates) of Gordian III, Philip and Herennia Etruscilla. A pharmacist from Somain discovered the hoard which was immediately dispersed.
27 bronze coins (Tiberius - Marcus Aurelius) found in an ash layer covered by a st1 and interpreted as a votive deposit.
43433 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 274-275); silver w8: 11726.9-54290.3 g

N 9159 "The only 'find' was a collection of 15 Roman coins of small value, all belonging to the reign of Constantine the Great. They were discovered about 8een inches below the surface of the ground, and immediately over the wide trench menti1d above. It is interesting to note that from the position in which they were discovered, it would seem that the trench had been filled up and the surface grass grown at the time when they were lost." J. Healy, in Journal of Royal Soc. Ant. of Ireland, XXX (1900), 176 "It has now transpired that the hoard was put there a day or 2 before for them [i.e. the excavators] to find." (J.D. Bateson, in PRIA, 73 (1973), C 2, 59f., no. 73, "Reign of Constantine I"). Uncertain location? Uncertain find?
228 denarii: Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (Crispina) (AD 177-191).
Unknown originally number of coins. 2 aurei, 8 denarii, and 3 natural formed mould are known. The identified 1 are all issues under Vespasian.
3 Gallo-Belgic staters reportedly found together early in 1992. Sills (2003, 364 no. 29) notes that they might conceivably be strays from the Harpsden Wood hoard (de Jersey 215).

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 5000 bronze coins. They were bought by M. Molchnet who stated that they included coins of Postumus, Victorinus, and a very large number of coins of Tetricus I. The hoard was found by a farmer, leveling of the ground surface in a barn.
17 denarii and 1 aureus: Gaius - Hadrian (AD 121-123).
32 bronze coins: 32 sestertii: Vespasian - Severus Alexander (AD 230)
The hoard was found during excavations and comprised 2 piles of 20 base silver coins (plated denarii?) from Augustus to Antoninus Pius or Marcus Aurelius.
Hoard of 11 denarii ending with Tiberius (AD 14-37).
The hoard comprised 7 silver coins of Year 3 of the First Jewish Revolt (AD 69).
750 nummi: Constantine I - Constantius II (AD 355-361).
disposition: Muzeul Național al Banatului, Coin Room, Timișoara, Romania; inv. no. 373

summary: The hoard comprised 97 nummi (19 identified) dated between AD 383-378 and AD 450-457.

The hoard comprised a large earthenware vessel containing 1100 bronze coins (for the most part sestertii) and 30 'small coins with surface silvering' (radiates). A summary catalogue of 200 of the best preserved examples was made by F. Homo. The hoard was found by workmen from the Letellier company during quarrying for st1. It was found at only a slight depth 'faible profondeur'.

The hoard comprised 'a bucketful of Roman coins, fused together with corrosion products. Cochet estimated that the total number of coins in the hoard was more than 300. The coins were antoniniani (radiates) of the third century depicting 10 emperors until Tacitus and Probus.
disposition: Musées d’Angers, France; Accession Register III, p. 37, no. 42 (3.11.1876)

summary: The hoard comprised 119 antoniniani (radiates). However, only 109 are preserved in the Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Tarragona as 10 were lost during successive renovations of the museum: Gallienus - Quintillus for Claudius II (Divus).
Unknown number of provincial bronze coins found in a small ceramic vessel. Y. Youroukova examined 9 pieces: Septimius Severus - Caracalla (AD 211-217).
10 coins: 2 silver, 8 bronze: Augustus - Titus (AD 79-81).
Unknown initial number of coins found in a copper alloy vessel: Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269-271).
Unknown number of imperial and provincial bronze coins. 36 pieces entered the museum collection in Shumen: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 13328/1-35 (35 coins)

summary: 3760 silver coins, only 10 are available for study: Vitellius - Commodus (AD 180)
disposition: National History Museum of Romania (10 coins in 1914); otherwise, dispersed.

summary: A hoard of 12 denarii documented based on the archives from the papers kept in the Real Academia de la Historia: Mark Antony - Tiberius (AD 15-16).
933 denarii and 2 antoniniani (radiates) spanning from Mark Antony to Maximinus I (AD 235-238).
Over 1001 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Marcus Aurelius - Diocletian (AD 288-289) found stored in a heap at the foot of a stairway leading to the second floor, during excavations of a house.
disposition: 995 coins in Ann Arbor, the rest in various Egyptian museums

summary: A group of coins, some of which were apparently found on the beach at Clacton in February 1905. 4 of them - a Gallo-Belgic A stater, 1 British La, 1 British Lb, and the Addedomaros stater - were in the Laver collection which was acquired by Colchester Museum in 1941, and seem to be reliably provenanced. To these may be added another British La stater, found in 1930, and possibly a second British Lb identified in the trade in 1992 (Sills 2003, 358). Allen (1960a, 202) also recorded a quarter stater found on the beach in 1924 which Haselgrove (1987, 272 no. 7) includes in his hoard figures; Sills (2003, 358) omits it. It is unclear whether these coins had any association with the Clacton 1898 hoard.
The hoard was found in Burial 21 of a Late Roman cemetery. It comprised a purse containing 15 4th century nummi ending with issues of Gratian.
A hoard of late Roman nummi, of which only 2 could be identified, found in the staircase of house C 56. At the time the hoard was hidden, this house was not in use any more.
Unknown number of solidi found on the same field, 2 coins of Theodosius II and 1 of Zeno are known; gold w8: 13.35 g.
Gold: 99 solidi: Gratian - Valentinian II (AD 388-392); Gold w8: 440.55g
The hoard of 63 aurei, found with an earthen vessel: Tiberius - Nerva (AD 96-98).
disposition: 28 coins from the hoard are in the Madras Museum.

summary: 40 imperial and provincial bronze coins in the museum collection in Shumen: Antoninus Pius - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 13629/1-22; 13634/1-18 (40 coins)

summary: A hoard of 170 Gallo-Belgic staters and 3 quarter-staters found between October 1990 and March 1991.
Unknown initial number of bronze coins. 24 pieces are kept in museum of Lovech: 1 sestertius, 23 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).

A hoard of Iron Age and Roman coins, found in an urn, ploughing in a field known as the 11 Acres. Sir John Evans succeeded in examining 249 of the coins: 10 gold coins of the Dobunni, 232 silver coins of the Dobunni, 3 Roman denarii, and 4 bronze coins.
2060 silver coins: 1849 denarii, 1 plated denarius, 209 antoniniani (radiates), 1 drachm: Vespasian - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-252).
disposition: History and Archaeology Museum Constanța, Romania

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 116 coins recovered from a private colector: Caracalla - Constantius II (AD 355-361)
disposition: Museum of the Highland Banat, Reșița, Romania

summary: (40) 20 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Postumus (AD 263); silver w8: c.14.6-84.0 g.
disposition: Collection Derjicke, Iddergem, Belgium (20 coins), in 1965

summary: 20 coins: 18 denarii, 2 bronze coins: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138).
2 aurei: Nero, Antoninus Pius .
22 coins were reported on, although it is likely that there were originally a few more (although not many more) in the hoard. Metcalfe suggests that there were originally 26 coins.
180 solidi (only 179 mention on Salama's list): Theodosius II - Anastasius (AD 495) and 1 gold ring. Found in the 'Bâtiment à auges' on the northern façade of the basilica.
disposition: Musée d'Alger (176 coins, Registre d'entrées, no 1222, March 1924); Musée de Djémila, Algeria (vanished between 1956-1962)

summary: 27 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver w8: 35.6-71.4 g.
14 denarii: Domitian 3; Nerva 3; Trajan 6; uncertain (Domitian or Trajan) 1; Hadrian 1 (AD 117-138).
Several Iron Age coins have been found in the vicinity of the Cornaway Bridge allotments, Portchester, which may have originated in a single deposit.

Hoard of 118 denarii: Hadrian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211). Together were found a pair of gold earrings, a silver belt buckle with a massive "proboscis" detached from the pin. Owing to the presence of this silver belt buckle the hoard is dated to the late 4th - early 5th century AD.
268 'copper coins' from the end of the 3rd century AD to the House of Valentinian. Most of the coins belong to the House of Constantine.
12 denari: Vespasian - Trajan (AD 114-117).
2 lots of nummi (99, 25). No further information. Unpublished.
2 solidi of Theodosius II minted in Constantinople (AD 441-450).
Hoard of unknown number of drachms. Only 9 coins of Peroz (AD 459-484) are known.
The hoard comprised 47 solidi: 2 of Theodosius I minted in Constantinople and 45 of Honorius minted in Ravenna with a tpq of AD 408-423.
2 solidi: Valens, Honorius for Arcadius (AD 395-402).

The hoard comprised numerous copper-alloy vessels, a mirror, a folding seat, Samian ware cups and plates and 6 glass bottles, 1 of which contained 40 very worn sestertii and dupondii of Nerva, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius and Faustina II.
214 AV and AR Republican and Imperial issues found in regio VI, insula 17, building 42 (house).
A substantial hoard of Durotrigan silver. Many of the coins were in good silver, weighing 5 g or more. The size of the hoard is unknown, but it almost certainly contained more than 500 coins.

During groundwork a coin hoard of 310 coins was unearthed near the Roman fort of Gunzenhausen. It comprised 308 denarii and 2 antoninianii, ranging from Commodus to Gordian III. Note that FMRD lists 310 coins, but in the summary only gives 309.

The hoard comprised an earthenware vessel containing between 1000 and 2000 Roman silver and billon coins, assumed to be radiates and nummi. 300 were examined by Pottier and 80 by Billiard. Found by a labourer in a quarry
The hoard comprised 12 bronze coins: 10 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 1 as: Commodus - Philip I (244-249 AD).
58 antoniniani, ranging from Caracalla to Volusian.
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 9 pieces were recorded: 7 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 1 as: Claudius I Commodus (AD 184).

The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 350 silver coins, 'nearly all debased coins.' The coins included issues of Antoninus Pius, Faustina, Marcus Aurelius, Commodus, Septimius Severus, Julia Domna, Caracalla, Geta, Plautilla, Macrinus, Diadumenian, Elagabalus, Julia Paula, Julia Maesa, Julia Soaemias, Severus Alexander, Maximinus, Maximus, Gordian III, Philip, Trajan Decius and Herennia Etruscilla. Piette mentions a coin of Diocletian but this is an error for Diadumenian.
Unknown originally number of coins. 53 denarii were recovered in 2 lots: Vespasian – Gordian III (AD 238-244).
600 antoniniani (radiates), of which 122 were recovered: Valerian I and Gallienus - Diocletian (AD 284-293); silver w8: 22.3-146.6 g.
310 denarii found with 2 leather bags placed in a ceramic vessel, 10 meters from BIRNIE 1996-2000 hoard: Nero - Pertinax (AD 193).

The hoard was found whilst dredging the marshland close to the railroad from Saint-Omer to Calais. Silver: 1636 (1450) antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269-271); silver w8: 442.7-2044.0 g.

A hoard of about 80 antoniniani was discovered by treasure hunters in the late 2010s between the villages of Stanislavchyk and Bud’ky in Vinnytsia region. It is known that the hoard contained coins of Gordian III.
Unknown originally number of coins. 94 denarii recovered: Republic – Augustus (16 BC).

3 aurei of Tiberius. They are considered imitations. Found within the archaeological site, at a shrine. "The coins were found inside a small pottery bowl in the building with another set of locally minted bronze coins and these could have been used for a religious offering."
31 coins: 29 antoniniani (radiates), 2 sestertii found together: Philip I - Claudius II (AD 268-270).

Nearly 300 Roman coins of the houses of Constantine I and Theodosius I (AD 408-423). The identifiable coin types (based on Still 1907): Crispus (Caesar); gloria exercitus (1 standard); vot xx mult xxx; vict aug; victoriae dd auggq nn (2 victories); vot xx mult xxx; Constantius II: fel temp reparatio (falling horseman); spes reipublice; House of Theodosius I: gloria Romanorum (emperor, captive); salus reipublicae (victory, captive); vot x mult xx; vot x mult xx; vot v; gloria Romanorum (emperor on horseback); virtus exerciti (emperor, victory); virtus exerciti (emperor, victory); concordia augg (Constantinopolis); urbs roma felix; gloria Romanorum (3 emperors); gloria Romanorum (2 emperors).
The hoard comprised a large number of Roman coins which were shared out between the finders. 4nier compiled a list, suggesting that 39 were of Nerva (and Trajan?) and 42 of Hadrian.

7 coins were reportedly found together in the Wet10berg community forest/Kreuzheck district in 1937 during retrieval of tree soil. They are Roman bronze coins, ranging from Nero to the late 4th c. AD.
The hoard comprised 514 imperial bronze coins: Nero-Septimius Severus (AD 193-196).
disposition: Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Altino, Italy; private collection; some lost

summary: Over 13 bronze coins. 15 probably antoniniani (radiates). According to Boersma 1967, no. 165 they are dated in the first half of the 1st century AD. No further information.
(over 100) 3 sestertii: Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius (Divus Lucius Verus) (AD 169).
The hoard comprised 49 sestertii from Trajan to Philip I and 2 Provincial bronzes from Patras (Caracalla).

6 coins were found during an excavation by the University of Leicester Archaeological Services (ULAS) on the 18th April 2012. All 6 coins are British Iron Age silver coins of the North Eastern regional series, which was produced in Lincolnshire and neighbouring counties from about 60/50 BC.
7 coins: 4 denarii, 2 asses, 1 quadrans: Mark Antony - Vespasian (AD 76).
A find of 32 Late Roman bronze coins (AD 330 - 402), which lay together close to the enclosing wall D. Interpreted as a 'hoard/votive deposit?' in FRMD.

The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing 33 aurei, 1 gold necklace, 2 bracelets and 1 gold ingot. The aurei range in date from Marcus Aurelius as Caesar to Diocletian. Hobbs estimates a gold w8 of c. 171.6-221.5g.
24 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel: Claudius I to Commodus (AD 180-183).
27 coins: 1 antoninianus, 26 nummi: Claudius II - Valens (AD 364-367).
The hoard comprised a burned pottery vessel containing 6 sestertii from Trajan to Commodus.
A hoard of 20 Corieltavian staters.

The hoard comprised 2 Iron Age coins. It was characterised as being 1 of 16 individual votive deposits found at the site of an important Gallo-Roman sanctuary during excavations. Inventory 76.395 and 76.396
1587 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Postumus (AD 260-269).

A group of copper alloy coins found in a garden, some of which were reported as having been in a leather wallet. Aspects of the find give cause to suspect that this may have been buried in modern times but it is included here as it has been published as a Roman hoard elsewhere.
110 silver Roman denarii recovered by excavation by the FLO and WYAS after initial detector find. For full details and images see SWYOR-810366. Unpublished catalogue by R. Abdy and V. Drost.
4500 antoniniani: Gordian III - Tacitus (AD 276).
disposition: Musée Chambéry, France, 1344 coins, Musée Château d'Annecy, France, Registre d'entrées, II, nos. 6480-6482, 9046 (137 coins and one vessel); Musée d'Art et d'Histoire de Genève, Switzerland

summary: Hoard of around 150 denarii: Vespasian - Severus Alexander (Julia Mamaea) (AD 222-235).
disposition: Statistical commission, Penza (in 1889); the high-school, Penza, Russia; old collection D. Ya. Samkvasov

summary: 25 silver coins found with ceramic vessel: 23 republican denarii, 1 denarius Augustus, 1 drachm Archaelaus IV of Cappadocia.
Unknown originally number of coins. 138 silver coins: 45 denarii, 93 antoniniani (radiates); silver w8: 181.2-323.9 g.; Septimius Severus -Philip I (AD 246-248).
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (file 1951) (130 coins)

summary: 17 antoniniani found in a ceramic vessel. Only 3 coins are known: Claudius II 1, Aurelian 2 (AD 270-275).
411 coins. 254 studied: 1 Greek bronze coin, 2 denarii, 9 antoniniani, 1 provincial bronze, 241 nummi: Greek - Theodosius II (AD 402-450).
disposition: National Museum of History, Belgrade, Serbia

summary: This hoard is incomplet. Only 12 (of 80) denarii of Augustus studied, although is has been assumed that the coins were all issues of Augustus in Lugdunum (2 BC - AD 4) of RIC 207.

In 1821 an urn with approx. 600 bronze coins (Licinius - Gratian) was found in Gu10brunnen. The coins were lost, but 305 coins that entered the museum of Speyer with find place 'Wörschweiler Klosterberg' certainly belonged to the same find. 291 of these could be found in the Speyer museum and are listed in FMRD.
236 aurei and denarii from the time of Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

A hoard of 427 silver coins (426 denarii and 1 Lycian drachm), of which the first lot was found in 1910 in a clay pot, while ploughing a field. It comprised 367 Roman denarii (Nero to Commodus), 1 Lycian drachm of Trajan and 1 contemporary cast forgery, also from Trajan. A further lot of 50 denarii (Mark Antony – Commodus) was found between April and December 1988 by members of the Chesterfield Metal Detector Club, in the vicinity of the first lot and can be regarded as a further portion of the same find. A further 8 denarii (Vitellius - Antoninus Pius) were found with the aid of metal detectors in November 2012.
disposition: Doncaster Museum (part); Newark Museum (part); British Museum (part)

summary: Hoard of circa 20 coins. Only 2 Republican denarii of C. Rennius were recovered.

A group of 19 Roman silver coins (of the Emperors Nero, Domitian, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Commodus, and the Empress Faustina), found while ploughing at Pitcullo in Fife, presented to the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland in 1781. The 19 coins have not been located in NMAS, Edinburgh

6 Roman coins (Valentinian I) were found on the h8 of the Schönebecker Sand, 1 km above Vegesack during excavation of the Weser in a depth of 8 meters. The historical museum and municipal museum preserved 3 of them. The latter were stolen in 1919.

The hoard consists of 73 coins found with a patera: 5 imperial denarii, 6 antoniniani (radiates), 62 Roman provincial bronzes: Trajan - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253). Most of the provincial coins presents early 3rd century AD countermarks.
The hoard comprised 54 silver shekels from Tyre and the First Jewish Revolt.
Hoard consisting of 9 solidi found in 1996. No other Iron Age finds from this site.
645 denarii, 1 gold necklace and other artefacts. 154 coins entered the museum collection in Sofia: 29 antoniniani, 125 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Valerian and Gallienus/Gallienus (AD 253-268).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.no. IX

summary: Hoard of unknown number of denarii. Some information on 4 of them: Vespasian 2, Faustina I/II, Julia Domna (AD 196-217).
A hoard comprising 25000 coins including coins dating from the reign of Gallienus through to Diocletian.
300 nummi of the House of Constantine I (AD 306-361) found during construction activities.
The hoard comprised 3 Roman Provincial coins: (Cassandrea, Philippi, Koinon of Macedonia), found in grave 589 in Ierissos.
45 coins found by the farmer Peder Madsen in 1850. The hoard was found collected without a preserved container. The coins were found bundled together beneath a big st1.
254 radiate imitations and a single radiate found as a dispersed hoard over 4x1.5m area, within depth of up to 0.20m of soil. No sign of a container. No further contextual details.
A hoard of 41 nummi (Constantine I - Arcadius, with some 5th century cross in wreath types), found in sector D (inv. 80D/89 and 80/D94) of Tell Atrib.
Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 36 pieces entered the museum collection in Shumen: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 12359/1-36 (36 coins)

summary: 26 gold solidi and 4 silver siliquae, ranging from Valens to Honorius, with an addenda of a further solidus of Arcadius (394-5), found in 2012, about 12 miles south–west of Norwich. The coins were found scattered over an area measuring about 30 m by 20 m. J A Davies, CHRB X, p. 468.
676 Roman imperial bronzes found in the ground: Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).

70+ AR and AE. The coins found in the period 1828-1833 are partly derived from the hoard and partly from discovered complexes. The coins from the complexes may not be included to the coin loss from Voorburg. A total of circa 200 pieces. Coins (81-269): Domitian, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Lucius Verus, Commodus, Septimius Severus, Julia Domna, Caracalla, Elagabalus, Severus Alexander, Julia Mamaea, Gallienus, Postumus.
disposition: Royal Museum of Antiquities, Leiden, Netherlands

summary: A certain amount of late Roman nummi was found in 1885 during work on the canalisation in Willigisstraße. Of these, 49 nummi (all from the tretrarchy) were described. These coins are now lost.
The hoard comprised 59 antoniniani (radiates) from Philip I to Aurelian or Tetricus I and was perhaps incomplete.
2 denarii to Augustus
242 antoniniani: Philip I - Postumus (AD 260-269).

The hoard comprised 113 Roman silver coins of different sizes, bearing the portraits of Gordian III, Philip I, Trajan Decius, Aemilian, Valerian I and Gallienus. Apparently, this list is not exhaustive. The hoard is probably 1 of antoniniani (radiates), although perhaps some denarii were present.
1 uncertain Imperial denarius, 1 uncertain denarius and 4 uncertain AE found with 6 skeletons and a gold bracelet on the via di Mercurio.

Record from Guildford Museum (noted on Pastscape) of a find of 9 nummi "of Diocletian, Maximian and Constatius I, dating overall AD 286-310" found as a group. A report on the coins is held by Guildford Museum (not consulted).

The hoard was found in 1973 during archaeological program. The archaeologists discovered 45 kg of sestertii, in 12 rolls in a wood box. It comprised c. 1980 sestertii from Philip I - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (Gallienus) (AD 253-268).
The hoard was found in 2 vessels by workers. For the city master, it comprised c. 8000 antoniniani (radiates). Among these coins, 796 from Valerian to Diocletian were identified.
The hoard comprised 34 denarii ending with Tiberius.
371 coins: Tetricus I - Valentinian III (AD 430-437) found in a room from a domestic building.
disposition: Museu Regional de Arqueologia D. Diogo de Sousa, Braga, Portugal

summary: 189 denarii: Nero – Marcus Aurelius (AD 176-177).
disposition: History Museum of Moldova, Iași (134 coins), History Museum "lulian Antonescu", Bacău (21 coins), History Museum, Onești (13 coins); Museum of History and Archaeology Piatra-Neamț (22 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised '93 or 99 Gaulish silver coins of 2 different dimensions, but of the same type.' It is likely that they were actually pale gold staters or quarter staters of type BN 6957-6961 and 6972-6979 attributed to Baiocasses. Found at the foot of a tree. 3 examples are accessi1d in the Musée de Rouen.
34 bronze coins: 20 sestertii, 14 asses: Severus Alexander - Valerian I and Gallienus (Gallienus) (AD 254-255).

The hoard comprised 33 Iron Age coins. It was characterised as being 1 of 16 individual votive deposits found at the site of an important Gallo-Roman sanctuary during excavations. Inventory No: 1970.1.33/1 to 33
Over 3500 silver coins. 322 coins studied: 2 denarii, 320 antoniniani (radiates): M. Aurelius (L. Verus) - Postumus (AD 260-269).
110 denarii. Only 79 were recovered: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193); silver w8: 202.4-323.4 g.

4 denarii, pressumably belonging to a hoard, found at the same place at different dates. ”The scientific literature has falsely perpetuated the locality of Mircești (situated 5 km to the west) as the place of origin for the coins.”
The hoard was found on the West of "Blanche-Fontaine" district. A worker discovered an amphora with 1000 aurei, only 164 are now recorded from Augustus to Hadrian.

4 uninscribed copper alloy Iron Age staters of the 'Hod Hill' type, found on the site of the Roman city Clausentum (Bitterne) near Southampton, together with bronze coins of the Roman Emperors Claudius I and Nero.
2 denarii: Elagabalus, Severus Alexander for Orbiana (Augusta).

A hoard of approximately 30000 'large and small bronzes', probably radiates and nummi. There were however, 2 large silver coins described as 'grand module' which have been interpreted as medallions: Valerian I - Constantine I.
HER record of a second scattered hoard of radiates of Tetricus I and II from within site LKH 003 found c. 1978. No further information, many thought to be unreported.
27 silver coins of unknown denomination and issuer. According to the NUMIS the tpq is around AD 250.

An unknown number of (exclusively Roman bronze?) coins. Codrington merely mentions, “(?) Constantius, Theodosius, Arcadius”. The corresponding coins of these 3 emperors were part of the Biddell collection. 3 coins, 1 of each emperor, were bought by Biddell on 13th January 1917.
HER record of an unrecorded late third-century hoard found by a metal-detectorist along with pottery sherds, a bracelet and a finger ring "with opposed dolphins".
12 nummi (Constans, Constantius II, and Magnentius), including a number of contemporary copies, found in a well in the area of the fort's eastern rampart.
Large hoard of mainly silver coins - denarii and antoniniani (radiates) - and some bronze coins. 242 coins are known: Titus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).
Unknown originally number of coins. There was an information on 5 gold coins, unknown issuers. Possible, that silver and bronze coins were part of the hoard.

A hoard of approximatively 400 silver coins discovered within a ceramic vessel, comprising a large majority of denarii (Trajan - Severus Alexander) and some Cappadocian drachms (up to Caracalla). The hoard was dispersed. Different accounts exist of its con10t, with Dundua 1979 publishing the 377 coins in the National Museum in Tbilisi (12 Cappadocian drachms and 365 denarii) and Zograf 1945 listing 417 coins (10 Cappadocian drachms and 407 denarii).
Unknown number of silver coins. 50 pieces entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2391, 50 coins

summary: 24 nummi found 10 m from CONIMBRIGA 1967-1968 hoard: Constantine I (Divus) - Theodosius I/Arcadius (AD 393-395).
The hoard consists between 60 and 70 silver drachms of Polemon II found in a ceramic jug.

A hoard of 138 Roman imperial denarii: Galba - Marcus Aurelius (AD 180-161) was discovered by a treasure hunter in 2017 in the Kyiv region. The first information about the hoard and photos of 60 coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity on January 6, 2017. Then the treasure hunter went to the hoard findspot 9 more times and found a different number of coins: 24 January (2 coins), 25 January (7 coins), 24 February (8 coins), 15 May (1 coin), 12 June (1 coin), 3 August (1 coin), 4 August (19 coins), 14 August (38 coins) and 20 August (1 coin). According to the finder, the deposit was found in the forest, under the trees. In the photograph on forum a small pit in the sandy soil (up to 50 cm deep) located on a slight slope can be seen. A few coins were closer to the surface, the main butch was deeper. The hoard was in a reddish-colored pottery vessel, of which several fragments have survived (according to the finder it was a “pot”, but judging by the photographs it was a pottery bowl). The coins are in very good condition (minimal wear). The coins were sold 1 by 1 at the Violity auction.

4th century. Coins 1-2, 4-7, 5?, 9 - find spot Tr 63, 2m NW of House 1. With exception of heavily corroded & illegible No. 5, all of similar AD 330-50 Constantinian date, & occur within area of 1.5m, despite being topsoil finds. Poss. a small disturbed hoard. Nowakowski J.A. & Quinnell, H. 2011. Trevelgue Head, Cornwall. The Importance of C.K. Croft Andrew's Excavations. Cornwall County Council.Coin report by Reece pp. 245-256, fig. 101.1.
7 sestertii found sealing a child burial in 1 of the house of C. Iulius Silvanus: Domnitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 151-152).

find_spot_name: KÖLN - ST. MARIA IM KAPITOL III
summary: 145 coins of the Constantinian period were inventoried in 1934; preservation, conditions, and patina indicate that they involve a cohesive find, most likely part the hoard.
Unknown initial number of coins. 11 silver coins in the Museum of Ruse: 1 denarius, 10 antoniniani: Caracalla - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver w8: 16.2 g.
disposition: History Museum, Ruse, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1495 (initially, 12 coins, after robbery only 8)

summary: The hoard comprised 214 Alexandrian tetradrachms from Claudius I to Hadrian. They were found under a floor surface during the excavation of a Late Roman house.
15 sestertii, dupondii, asses: Augustus-Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
Hoard of 1040 silver coins (?) found in a small ceramic vessel of which only 394 silver coins are known: Vespasian - Philip I (AD 247-249).
disposition: Museum, Panagyurishte; Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria

summary: A hoard of 300 Roman denarii ranging from Vespasian to Commodus (AD 74). Only 19 coins have been recorded. Based on the portrait style, the coins seem to be imitations of known genuine types.
disposition: Private collection A.A. Tarpi, Dushambe, Tajikistan

summary: 20 antoniniani of Aurelian part of a larger hoard.
The hoard comprised a large number of silver denarii of Clodius Albinus (approximately 15 pounds in w8 or 2000 pieces).

21 bronze coins,found with 2 pebbles and a bronze ring in the fill of the outer fort ditch. Found concreted together and later separated, probably a purse hoard although no traces of a container survived.

12 Iron Age coins were found on the Thames foreshore near Putney between October 2010 and December 2011. The location of the find suggests a link with the 'Putney Bridge Hoard' which appeared sporadically during the 1980s and 1990s. The coins are all so-called 'Flat Linear I potin'; a type of cast tin-bronze coin that appears to have been produced and used in northern Kent and close to the River Thames in Greater London during the late Iron Age. They can be dated to the late second century BC and early first century BC. (PAS).
A hoard of 10 antoniniani (Valerian I - Gallienus) found in a destruction deposit of a Roman villa 500 metres from Chaer1a.
15 gold coins and 2 pieces of jewelry found within a small area over a period of 150 years.
24 silver found in a ceramic vessel: 18 denarii, 6 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver w8: 34.1-63.8 g.
A hoard of 52 denarii (Vespasian - Antoninus Pius) and 1 drachm of Amisus, found during the breaking up of soil in Lausitz. The hoard might have been associated with a series of 7 cremation graves.

A hoard of 162 provincial coins of Athens (period V and VI), 1 sestertius (Trebonianus Gallus) and 34 antoniniani (Valerianus - Gallienus), found in a cave in the hills between Porto Rafti and Brauron.
99 nummi found in the old collection of the Archaeological Museum of Granada under the label "Tesoro Granada 1868": Maximinus II Daza - Licinius I (AD 316).
23 coins found in 3 piles found near a wall: 22 antoniniani (radiates).
Unknown number of antoniniani. 10 pieces were seen: Philip I, Otacilia, Trajan Decius.
2 solidi of Theodosius II (AD 408-450); gold w8: 8.9 g.
The hoard was found between "Place de la Crémaillère" and "Rue de la Charité", on the Est of "Hôpital de la Charité", in a bronze pitcher. It comprised c. 1300 coins.
16 nummi of the 4th century: Constantine I - Valens (AD 364-367).
disposition: Office of Underwater Archeology Eastern River Region (WOOR) WOOR

summary: Circa 500 coins, among which: 468 sestertii, 2 dupondii/asses: Titus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
Large number of silver coins. Only 14 pieces were identified: Vespasian - Philip I (AD 244-249).

A hoard of 1167 denarii and 2 antoniniani found in the south-wester of the Hungerbergacker property during spring 1937. FMRD associates the deposition of the hoard with the Alamannic invasions of Raetia in AD 233 and the assemblage is notable for the high proportion of eastern mints. Coins range from the late Republic to Severus Alexander.
disposition: Museum Straubing (ca. half of the coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 1 bronze coin struck under the reign of Ptolemy IX (115-104/1 BC) and further 259 Roman imperial bronze denominations ranging from Constantine the Great to that of Julian II (AD 335-363).
45 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 190-191); silver w8: 106.55 g. (41 coins)
disposition: Swedish History Museum, Stockholm (inv.no. 6293); Gotlands Fornsal, Visby, Finland A 1922 (inv.nos. A 2090, A 2091)

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. Only 3 antoniniani (radiates) are known: Gordian I, Philip I 2.
20 nummi of Constantine I for Constantine II (Caesra) minted in Londinium (AD 318).
Hoard of aurei and jewelry: 94 aurei: Nero - Aurelian (AD 270-275); gold w8: 648.8g.
54 from the 600 coins are known. All are antoniniani (radiates); silver w8: c.162g.

A pursefind (Börsenfund) consisting of 5 bronze coins of Vespasian, found in a post hole (Pos10bau IV) surrounding a Roman settlement or camp (HA 101) at Steinstraß, on the area of the open pit mine of Hambach (Braunkohletagebau Hambach), on the Roman road Cologne - Jülich.

A farmer from Buprich uncovered an earthenware container filled with many Roman coins in the vicinity of the village. The container appears to have contained more than 1000 antoniniani (Gallienus - Tetricus). 832 of them were described, but giving only the reverse legend, not the type. 727 are listed in FMRD.
Hoard of 200 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 2 denarii are documented: Faustina II, Commodus.
6 denarii: Republic - Tiberius (AD 14-37).
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (6 coins).

summary: 11 denarii found on the same field: Caesar – Vespasian (AD 69-79).

The hoard was found in a grave in the Gallo-Roman cemetery. A red ceramic urn was discovered, alongside a small bronze box containing a gold finger ring with glass setting and 3 aurei of Nero, Domitian and Antoninus Pius. It is not altogether clear whether the coins were found in the box or the urn.

A hoard of 14 coins, found in sector SO-XIII, in the area of the vicus surrounding the Roman fort of Apsaros. The coins were 8 silver coins of Caesarea in Cappadocia (Hadrian to Caracalla) and 6 bronzes from Trapezus (Marcus Aurelius to Alexander Severus). All coins were burnt.
IARCH record for a group of 4 silver radiates found fused together. For further details and images see NMS-865B3E. 2 of the coins could not be identified due to their condition.
6 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel together with a silver ring and a bracelet: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).

29 3rd-century coins of Gallienus, Victorinus, Tetricus I & II. Scattered along the bottom of an internal drain in building 2170. Dated by the excavators to AD 290, presumably on the basis of the barbarous radiate, though this could be earlier (listed as "reverse Pax" by Reece in Woodward et al. 116).Woodward et al. 1993. Excavations at Greyhound Yard, Dorchester 1981-4. DNHAS Mono. 12, pp. 62, 82, 116, figs 23, 30, plate 30. Building 2170

Among the 162 coins listed for Lehmbach in FMRD, 150 (Gallienus - Gratian) come from an excavation made in 1957 and look like a hoard, even if they were not reported as such at the time. They were found below a medieval layer. Lemberg was located on a Roman road.
2 burnt and fused silver denarii of Roman date. Both coins are distorted and have been rendered illegible. Diameter: 18.7mm; Thickness: 6.1mm; W8: 8.9g.

A hoard of ca. 639 Roman denarii, found in a 'crock' at Upwood Farm, near Handley, while digging up an allotment garden in 1877. A list of 571 coins (by emperor only, see NC 1950, pp. 311-312) was made by Dr. Blackmore who himself received 464 coins of the hoard. His list is as follows: Marcus Antonius 20, Nero 2, Galba 2, Otho 4, Vitellius 3, Vespasian 60, Titus 5, Domitian 31, Nerva 19, Trajan 55, Hadrian 78, Sabina 4, Aelius 4. Pius 79, Faustian I 44, Marcus Aurelius 63, Faustian II 23, Verus 14, Lucilla 13, Commodus 36, Crispina 5, Didius Iulianus 1, Severus 1, and Domna 1. What remains of these 464 coins is now preserved in the Dorchester Museum, but only 440 coins were catalogued by Roberston (NC 1950). These are all denarii (Mark Antony - Julia Domna), except for 1 Lycian drachm of Trajan.
A hoard of 15 Roman bronzer coins, allegedly found in the vicinity of Bad Pyrmont in 1935. FMRD considers that the list of coins ressembles more that of a private collection, than a hoard.
60 sestertii of Claudius I, all of the same type (RIC 96) found under a slab.
Gold coins of Gratian, Theodosius I, Arcadius, Honorius.
disposition: Museum of Shevchenko Scientific Society, Lvov, (between 1920-1939).

summary: The hoard comprised an unknown number of coins dating to the period AD 350 to 400. Hoard found during construction work; late Roman bronze coins in a small pot, 65 coins registered; no further indication.
The assemblage contained between 200 and 300 bronze coins. Blanchet interpreted this assemblage as a votive deposit.

On 18 March 2018, photos of 5 Roman provincial bronze coins Prusias ad Hypion: Macrinus - Gordian III (AD 238-244) with countermarks were published on the Ukrainian forum Violity. According to the finder, they were found at the same site on the territory of Khmelnytskyi region. Given the close chronology of the coins and the fact that they were issued by 1 mint, most likely it was a hoard. Coins: Macrinus (1), Maximunus Trax (2), Maximunus Trax (Maxim) (1), Gordian III (1).
The hoard comprised 13 silver coins including tetradrachms, drachms and denarii, dating between the reigns of Nero and Trajan.
A poorly-recorded hoard of early north-east coast staters.
The hoard comprised 'a lot of 62 double sestertii of Postumus (AD 260-268). They were sold to a dealer in Rouen who claimed they had been found in Eu.
2 aurei found in a lead sarcophagus: Trajan Decius, Tacitus (AD 275-276).
86 denarii found in a ceramic vessel: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
The hoard comprises of 67 silver coins, 34 denarii, 33 antoniniani (radiates), from Commodus to Trajan Decius with a tpq of AD 249-251.

“Several hoards” were found between 1987 and 1994. No details were reported. Weerakkody’s knowledge of these alleged hoards is solely based on personal information from Bopearachchi’s work. It is open to question whether the above-menti1d c. 800 imitations were also from these ‘several hoards’ or not.” Confirmation required.
A hoard of 23 late Roman coins (Constantius II to Gratian), found during the excavations of the Roman road fort (Straßenburgus).
4 coins (Claudius II - Tetricus), found in a garden in Gehrden.

Over 90 coins: antoniniani, provincial bronze medallions, provincial bronze coins: Caracalla - Gordian III (Ad 238-244). Provincial coins were minted in: Pautalia, Serdica, Philippopolis, Hadrianopolis, Deultum, Anchialus.
Unknown originally number of coins. 14 denarii are known: Republic – Augustus (20-16 BC).

168 bronze coins, range: (residual) Tetricius - Magnus Maximus. Findspot is a Greek sanctuary. Possible, multiple votive offerings as stated that other bronze artefacts were found together with these coins.
The hoard comprised a bronze vessel containing '300 billon coins (radiates) dating to the 3rd century AD.
1600 nummi: Carinus - Magnus Maximus (AD 383-388). Found in a ciste made of bricks and covered with a slab.
The hoard comprised 114 coins of the First Jewish Revolt from Year 4 (AD 69/70).
2 aurei depicting Lucius Verus (AD 161-169). No description. Callu-Loriot record these coins as single finds, however, same findspot, same coin issuer (quite rare).
11 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
43 silver and bronze coins, plated denarii: 41 denarii (19 plated), 1 sestertius, 1 as: Vespasian - Severus Alexander (AD 228-231). Found in the Principia building of the 5th Macedonica Legion fort.
Hallaton: 14 hoards were located in and around the entrance way. Hoard 06 comprises 208 Iron Age coins and 1 Roman denarius.
According to a note published in 1830, a young boy found 12 denarii "am Bühel". Only the names of the emperors are known. Coins range from Hadrian to Septimius Severus.

On 9 July 1962 a hoard of 4th century coins was found during excavations in a 4th century building site which ran along and to the South of Watling Street adjacent to Magiovinium. The coins were probably originally contained in a bag. There were approximately 251 loose coins and a conglomerate of perhaps 400 more. The general condition of the coins was very poor - many were totally illegible. It was suggested that the coins may have been originally fused together as a result of fire. This hoard is composed almost entirely of ancient copies to which a few of the very common coins of 330 to 348 were added. All the coins are of the lowest possible value. 306 AE coins were catalogued.
1867 coins: 1650 antoniniani (radiates), 215 imitation antoniniani (radiates), 1 sestertius, 1 bronze: Antoninus Pius (Faustina I), Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver w8: 504.5-2330.3 g.
162 silver coins: Republican denarii, imperial denarii; including 1 of Juba II, 1 Eastern Celts and 2 'animae': Republic - Augustus (2 BC - AD 4).
212 denarii found with a box: Nero - Septimius Severus (Cludius Albinus Caesar) (AD 194-195). Together were found 1 bronze box, 2 gold bracteates, 1 spiral rod and 1 gilt silver ring.
disposition: Swedish History Museum, Stockholm (inv.nos. 5204 coins; 4877 objects)

summary: The hoard comprised more than 4000 Roman coins. This hoard is frequently confused with ÉTAPLES 1842

7 denarii (Trajan - Antoninus Pius), set on a goblet ('Pokal') dating to around 1830, which were part of a hoard found in a pot at the beginning of the 19th c. on the grounds of the mansion of Welsede.
At the beginning of the 20th c., a hoard of 12 bronze coins and 3 denarii was found while extracting gravel. Probably 1st-2nd c. AD.
2826 bronze coins: 2 imperial, 2824 provincial bronze coins were found in a ceramic vessel: Hadrian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
3 solidi and 4 siliquae up to AD 402, found in 2011 and 2017.
